column2: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 -- The South Vietnamese Government appeared tonight to have solved the Constitutional stalemate that had blocked th filling of two Cabinet posts.

Bill McClellon, a De Witt Clinton junior, soared higher yesterday than any other schoolboy high jumper had before. The 17-year-old athlete leaped 6 feet 10 inches for a national record in the 61st annual Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships at Randalls Island.

MANCHESTER, England, June 4 (UPI) -- Margaret Smith of Australia and Maria Bueno of Brazil, who are expected to battle for the Wimbledon title later this month, today earned an opportunity to stage a preview of that showdown when they reached the final of the Northern lawn tennis championship.
CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies, behind Jim Bunning's tight pitching, timely extra-base hitting and costly Chicago errors, turned back the Cubs today, 6-0.

Exercises that the two American astronauts have been performing in their Gemini 4 spaceship are intended to help them overcome what scientists have feared to be a major hazard of prolonged space-flight.

BUCHAREST, June 4 -- Rumania's independence-minded Communist leadership has been quietly reducing the country's role as a member of the Soviet-led military bloc known as the Warsaw Pact, according to the highest authority.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- The Soviet leadership has decided to challenge Communist China's bid for primacy among the African and Asian nations at an international conference this month, diplomatic sources said today.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The United States reaffirmed today its willingness to attend a conference on Cambodia that would guarantee that country's territorial integrity, without linking this to the Vietnam problem.
The price of the British pound advanced yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here. It closed at $2.7942, up 7 points for the day.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A Young American Medal was designated today for a 7-year-old North Carolina girl who lost her life getting her young brother out of their burning house.

LIKE pitching two no-hitters on successive days, Jacques Tiffeau achieved the impossible in the fashion game. He followed his perfect performance with his Tiffeau Busch collection Wednesday with another Thursday for Monte-Sano Pruzan.
The revised New York State Penal Law, which passed the Assembly on Thursday with a minimum of controversy, ran into sharp criticism from widely disparate quarters yesterday.
A bill has been introduced in the State Senate that would automatically extend the terms of all Manhattan party district leaders for another year.
ST. LOUIS, June 4 (UPK) -- Joseph Cardinal Ritter asked other theologians tonight to join Roman Catholics in a "self-examination in the light of the Gospel."
Brokerage houses occasionally take polls to find out what their customers think about the stock market.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Justice Department filed suits today against two restaurants in Dublin, Go., and three in Camden, S.C., asserting that they had refused to serve Negroes and were violating the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President Johnson declared tonight that legal freedom and equality were "not enough" to guarantee Negroes their full share of American justice and American plenty.
LONDON, June 4 -- London Airport was thrown into chaos today, the first day of the long Whitsun weekend, by a wildcat strike of porters and baggage loaders of Brittsh European Airways.
Leading museum directors, art dealers and lawyers were urged yesterday to meet with State Legislators to try to prepare a bill to protect art purchasers against spurious paintings.

Salvatore Bonanno was freed from prison yesterday by Federal Judge Charles H. Tenney who ruled that the son of the missing Mafia boss, Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, had purged himself of civil contempt.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 4 -- Syria accused the United Arab Republic and other Arab states today of intending to leave Syria to face Israel alone in a possible showdown over the diversion of headwaters of the Jordan River.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices rose one-tenth of 1 per cent to 102.4 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended June 1, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The three national television networks, which provided nine and a half hours of continuous coverage to the launching and initial orbits of the Gemini 4 space flight on Thursday, will allot several more hours Monday to the recovery of the spacecraft.

Commissioner Armand D'Angelo of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity said yesterday that a ban on the use of 310 of the city's recirculating fountains would remain in effect because "of the gravity of the present water shortage."
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey says that air strikes alone will not do the job and that the war in Vietnam will have to be won on the ground by South Vietnamese forces.
The Chicago and North Western Railway, which reported a $706,000 profit on its commuter train operations last year, expects to clear $1 million this year, according to its chairman, Ben W. Heineman.
HERE are two engaging books for weekend pleasure. One is a spoof on international affairs by Marc Connelly. The other is William H. Schneider's cartoon voyage through the platitude latitudes.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 4 -- The deadlocked Dominican crisis came under fresh review today by an inter-American mediation committee seeking a political settlement.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews has arranged a dinner dance for June 17 at the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for its Brotherhood Scholarship Fund, Mrs. Ruth Axe is chairman of the evening.
W.R. Grace Co. is planning further expansion of its chemical operations through the proposed acquisition of Southbridge Plastic Products, Inc. The deal would involve almost $9 million.

After your praiseworthy series of editorials on the Vietnam situation it was disheartening to read The Times editorial of May 20 in which you imply acceptance of the idea that the United States, by calling off its bombing attacks on North Vietnam for one week, has done all it can to bring peace in Vietnam.
IN this new age of wigs and hairpieces, it hardly seems possible that anyone could come up with a new twist on the subject. But Michel Kazan, the hairdresser, has.
At 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning a new, chauffeur-driven black Mercury pulled up in front of the Board of Education building at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Administration's proposal to change the silver content of the dime, the quarter and the half dollar got an almost completely friendly reception today as hearings opened before the House Banking Committee.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 -- A senior American officer, reviewing setbacks suffered in the last week by South Vietnamese Government forces, predicted today that United States combat troops would enter the Vietnamese war this summer.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersy, declared today that foreign diplomats who violate speeding and other traffic laws in this country should be sent home.
GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 4 -- Using a favorite sand wedge with special skill, Julius Boros assumed the 36-hole lead in the $100,000 Buick open tournament today with a score of 139.
The Rev. Dr. W.A. Visser 't Hooft, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, urged Protestants yesterday to revise their image of the Roman Catholic Church in Latin America.
Copper, silver and soybeans held center stage yesterday in the commodities market.

" The Discovery of Scotland," by Maurice Lindsay, which Roy will issue on Monday, is an account of what that country was like in the 18th century and before. Mr. Lindsay, a Scottish poet and historian, has based his book on letters and journals of foreign visitors from the 13th century on.

Operations of Seeman Brothers, Inc., in the fiscal year ended Feb. 27 resulted in a net loss of $3,676,765, compared with a $974,998 loss the year before. Sales fell to $71,672,151 from the $125,645,250 volume of the preceding year.
HONOLULU -- Hawaii, geared to the American mainland until a few years ago, is rapidly gaining in its economic contacts with other countries.

MEXICO CITY, June 4 -- Negotiations are under way here to renew the United States-Mexico commercial air transportation agreement. United States airlines are pressing for increased fights into Mexico while companies here favor maintaining the status quo.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- To eliminate the hazards of the steering column, Matthew Vacante, an operator of a Long Island automobile body shop, has invented gear that includes two wheels but no post.
The haven for seamen from all over the world, the Seamen's Church Institute's building overlooking New York Harbor, is for sale for $2.5 million. In 1964, 236,000 sailors passed through its doors.
Representative John V. Lindsay invaded another solidly Democratic area of Brooklyn yesterday and received many promises of support.

To the youth of today it may be but a name of half-forgotten history, a far sound as of distant bells at night. But it will live forever; and to those who witnessed those days, that name still spurs the pulse and makes the spirit leap.

A 12-YEAR-OLD boy was dispatched to a West Side restaurant recently to pick up Chinese food for dinner. When he failed to return after three-quarters of an hour, his mother called the restaurant and was told the boy had picked up the order a good half hour earlier.
DEVON, Pa., June 4 -- The bubble finally burst on Kathy Kusner at the Devon horse show tonight and it took a cool 16-year-old to accomplish the feat.

I note with regret the approval [editorial May 25] of The New York Times of the proposal to make Fifth Avenue one way southbound and Madison Avenue one way northbound. This may indeed have beneficial effects in moving more traffic more swiftly.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee proposed today to turn over to the Organization of American States the Presidential...

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Fourteen Alabama state colleges that individually agreed to comply with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 are in danger of losing Federal funds. The danger arose because the State Board of Education, headed by Gov. George C. Wallace, has withheld a satisfactory compliance statement.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Pentagon issued a July draft call today for 17,100 men, the biggest since the 1961 Berlin crisis.

CLEVELAND, June 4 (UPI) -- The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company and the National Broadcasting Company disclosed today that the way had been cleared for an exchange of N.B.C.'s outlet in Philadelphia with Westinghouse's Cleveland station.

SOMEWHERE over the Sierras, rainbow trout swim. But, although the rainbow's natural habitat is in the swift-flowing streams that bubble westward from these mountains, it is now being successfully raised as far from the West Coast as Denmark and as close to it as Idaho.

NEW DELHI, June 4 (Reuters) -- India faced today its worst foreign exchange crisis since it became independent of Britain in 1947, with foreign reserves the lowest they have ever reached. Reserve-bank statistics showed that foreign assets declined last week to a record low of 773.4 million rupees (about $162 million).

Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Acting Superintendent of Schools, emphasized yesterday that a proposed redistribution of schools among 30 districts instead of the present 25 would have no effect on existing school zoning or feeder patterns.
The establishment of a headquarters in Washington to direct a nationwide campaign against consumer frauds was announced here yesterday by Paul Rand Dixon, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.
City College has announced plans to reorganize next fall its Institute of Film Techniques, established in 1941.

A $1.8 million damage suit against Arlene Francis ended early yesterday when a Queens jury found that the actress had not been negligent in connection with a 1963 automobile accident in which one woman was killed and four persons were injured.
BRONXVILLE, June 4 -- Mr. Shriver said here today that Senator Jacob K. Javits should consider his own "moonlighting" before accusing others of it.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 4 (UPI) -- Kathy Whitworth, the long hitter from Pecan Valley, Tex., shot a two-under-par 70 to take a one-stroke lead over Mickey Wright, another Texan, in the first round of the Bluegrass invitation golf tourney today at Hunting Creek Country Club.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, June 4 (UPI) -- The Sudanese police arrested today four former army officers believed to have been planning a coup d'etat.

No economic indicator means more in human terms than the unemployment rate, and none has lagged more stubbornly in the last four years of rising national prosperity. Accordingly, it is understandable that President Johnson takes pride in the fact that the jobless rate dropped last month to 4.6 per cent, the lowest level in seven and a half years.
An IND subway motorman was in critical condition last night at Kings County Hospital after having been trapped for more than eight hours in the crumpled cab of his wrecked train.

SAIGON, June 4 (UPI) -- Two United States marines were killed and 19 were wounded today in a battle that was believed to be the Marines heaviest fighting since their arrival in Vietnam. Five Marine companies and Marine jets were believed to have killed as many as 79 Communist guerrillas with the help of a Vietcong turncoat.
WARSAW, June 4 -- It was described as a most unusual cavalcade: "Mercedes, Peugeot, Volkswagen, Fiat. . . ."
ROME, June 4 -- Italy's uneasy alliance between Christian Democrats and Socialists was severely shaken today over the issue of indirect censorship of films on "ethical-social" grounds.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Post Office Department has invited members of Congress to submit names of candidates for summer jobs under President Johnson's youth employment campaign.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 4 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins combined Jimmie Hall's three hits and Gerry Fosnow's strong relief pitching tonight for a 9-5 victory over the Washington Senators.
IOWA CITY, June 4 (UPI) -- Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz made a plea today for increased emphasis on adult education.

The appointments of a master for a new trans-Atlantic luxury liner, a new steamship trade promotion specialist for American Steamship Lines and a new transportation director in Baltimore were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A Senate Banking subcommittee today approved a $7 billion, four-year housing bill including a new program of rent subsidies for low-income families.
Former members of the Peace Corps who would like to use their experience in the teaching profession were urged yesterday to investigate the possibilities through the City University of New York.
The 6 million share secondary offering of Ford Motor Company common stock by the Ford Foundation is expected to be made on June 21 or June 22.
Senator Robert Kennedy's name was mentioned yesterday in connection with a Philadelphia organization seeking a franchise in the American Football League.
HOUSTON, Saturday, June 5 -- Maj. James A. McDivitt sighted and photographed a satellite in space yesterday. Later he and Maj. Edward H. White 2d set a new American record for orbital flight.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- A spokesman for the National Council of Churches voiced support today for the Administration's proposal to repeal the clause of the Taft-Hartley Act that permits states to bar union shop contracts.
TRENTON, N.J., June 4 (AP) -- Blue Cross asked New Jersey today for permission to raise its rates an average of 23.5 per cent. If granted, it would be the second increase within a year.
GENEVA, June 4 -- Switzerland faced a major financial scandal today following the suspension from office of the chairman of the Federal Banking Commission.
NEWARK, June 4 -- The Republican party will open its first "community action" center in the nation here on Monday, in an effort to woo the Negro and the white voter sympathetic to his cause.

MONTREAL, June 4 (Canadian Press -- Movies on planes would have an adverse effect on fares, a spokesman for Air Canada said today, and the line is not considering movies for either domestic or international flights.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The appearance of several Soviet-built jet bombers in North Vietnam was viewed by Administration officials today as further evidence of a deepening Moscow commitment to the Vietnamese war.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase the amount that a person receiving Social Security retirement benefits can earn and still retain monthly payments.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's commencement address at Howard University in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

As a former rector of Saint Paul's Church Eastchester, Mount Vernon, I wish to correct and clarify certain statements made by Merrill Folsom in his May 15 news article regarding this shrine church soon to celebrate the 300th anniversary of its founding.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner for Germany and former president of the World Bank, gave qualified approval today to America's policies in South Vietnam and the Dominican Republic.

A negotiator for the shipping industry last night accused the president of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association of jumping up on the bargaining table during a heated debate and kicking him in the face.
LILLE, France, May 30 -- To the traveler, Lille, outwardly at least, seems un-French.

CINCINNATI, June 4 (AP) -- Johnny Edwards hit his third homer in four games, a three-run shot in the second inning that carried the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-2 victory tonight over the San Francisco Giants.
The city was ordered yesterday to pay an $11,250 painter's bill even though it said it wanted to wait until an investigation into alleged rigged bidding was completed.
United Air Lines, a carrier in search of a new image, announced yesterday the selection of the Leo Burnett Company as the agency to fashion that image.
BOGALUSA, La., June 4 -- A white man arrested in Mississippi in the murder of a Negro deputy sheriff in Louisiana waived extradition today and was returned to Louisiana to face trial.

Fortunately political barriers have no curbing effect on bird flights. Iron Curtains (or Bamboo ones) can't stop cranes and geese from winging their way across the Bering Sea for a visit to Canada, Alaska, California, or even as far south as New Mexico.
MOSCOW, June 4 -- A Communist youth newspaper called today for a campaign to preserve historic memorials of the Russian past.
The London stock market closed mixed yesterday, with Government bonds showing the biggest gains.

MIAMI, June 4 -- The Florida Legislature yesterday completed action on a bill that would permit the state's three largest thoroughbred tracks to hold summer, as well as winter, meetings, but certain provisions of the bill made it doubtful whether the tracks would take advantage of it.

As strategists for Representative John V. Lindsay envision it, his organization for the mayoral campaign will resemble a super-market chain, even to the opening of 76 store-front branches in the city's 76 Assembly Districts.
MIAMI BEACH, June 4 (UPI) -- Sue Ann Downey, a 20-year-old blonde from Columbus, Ohio, tonight was named Miss U.S.A. of 1965.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 4 -- Vincent Squillante, alias Jimmy Crosby, pleaded not guilty today to a Nassau County grand jury indictment charging him with attempting to extort $20,000 from a Roslyn Harbor music publisher.
E.J. Korvette, Inc., the country's largest discount chain, will take over the site of Saks-34th Street at Herald Square after the store is closed early next month.
The stock market limped into the weekend yesterday battered and bowed, but not broken.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4 -- Britain and Japan both ratified today amendments to the United Nations Charter.

As representative of one of the producer countries whose cause you so graciously pleaded in your May 29 editorial "Alarm Over Commodities" I wish to offer you thanks for helping to focus attention on one of the greatest handicaps suffered by underdeveloped economies.

STUTTGART, Germany, June 2 -- Apart from gala junketings tomorrow, the Stuttgart Ballet Festival came effectively to its end tonight with the guest appearance of the British Royal Ballet's Nadia Nerina in John Cranko's startling realization of "Swan Lake."
BIG SPRINGS, Neb., June 4 (AP) -- A tall, well-dressed man shot four country bank officials in the back today, then walked to a car, circled the block and drove away with $1,500 in loot.
ALBANY, June 4 -- Republican leaders are seriously considering blocking a political comeback by former State Senator MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan.
TEL AVIV, June 4 -- The Mapai party nominated Premier Levi Eshkol today as the party's candidate for Premier after next fall's parliamentary elections.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy's efforts to fill two long-standing vacancies on the Federal bench in New York City have floundered in a controversy over the age of one of his nominees.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 (AP) -- Next Wednesday will be quite a day for the Vogels, the Brushes and the Laughlins.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 4 (AP) -- A 52-year-old patient undergoing allergy tests at Strong Memorial Hospital died from what the hospital's medical director said was an accidental injection of a normal dose of penicillin.

A serious deadlock has developed between House and Senate conferees working on the constitutional amendment to provide for the disability of a President. We believe the merits of the argument are on the side of the House.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 4 -- The Chinese Nationalist Army has begun accelerated training of an army division for amphibious operations, an informed source said today.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 5 -- The Bergen County Republican policy committee announced today that it would not support Webster B. Todd for re-election as state chairman Tuesday in Trenton.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5 -- St. Peter's General Hospital will receive the proceeds of the New Brunswick Art Center's exhibition and the Middlesex County Horse Show and Country Fair, all to be held in Johnson Park for three days starting on June 25.
ROSE enthusiasts are invited to attend Dr. Cynthia Westcott's 25th annual Rose Days at the Springvale-on-the-Hudson apartments, Springvale, N.Y., Saturday and Sunday from 2 to 6 P.M.

Questions to followers of Maria Montessori as described in "Let the Child Teach Himself" (May 16) by Ronald and Beatrice Gross:

LOS ANGELES, June 5 (AP) -- Slippage and cracking of land on a bluff above a Pacific Coast highway here suddenly accelerated today, rending and shifting expensive houses and apartments and threatening a 36-unit motel below.
Two terrified women were swept into a police chase in upper Manhattan yesterday that culminated in the shooting of one holdup suspect and the capture of two others on a busy street.
NEWARK, June 5 -- The city and the fraternal Order of Police here are engaged in a protracted court battle over the question of overtime work.

HAARLEM, the Netherlands -- This ancient city is famous on two counts. It was the home of Frans Hals, the great genre painter, and is now the site of a splendid museum devoted mostly to his work. And it is the center of the great Dutch flower industry where, just last Friday, the annual 24-hour Flower Fair exploded in its customary frenzy of horn-tooting, all-night gaiety and floral displays.

TWENTY of the world's leading grand masters and international masters participated in the recent chess tournament at Zagreb, Yugoslavia. This event, staged to commemorate the liberation of the city from Nazi occupation 20 years ago, starred, among others, the world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union.

LATE Saturday night I finished Kathleen Winsor's new novel, "Wanderers Eastward, Wanderers West." It is a long book but I was entranced and interested all the way through. I, at least, found it hard to put down because I wanted to find out what was going to happen next.
WEST POTNT, N.Y., June 5 -- Commencement exercises will be held here Wednesday at 10 A.M. in Michie Stadium for the graduation of 596 members of the Corps of Cadets.

ONE of the nation's major travel organizations was an outgrowth of the solar eclipse that occurred in the Northeast in 1963. A Massachusetts couple, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Richter, decided to travel to Maine that summer to observe the phenomenon.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 5 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler will be the commencement speaker here next Wednesday when the United States Coast Guard Academy graduates 114 cadets who will be commissioned as ensigns in the Coast Guard.

" If that's a Goya, I'm a virgin," snapped Sir Gerald Kelly, former president of London's conservative Royal Academy of Art last week. He was referring to Britain's most publicized victim of artnapping -- a portrait of the Duke of Wellington stolen three and a half years ago from London's National Gallery and dramatically returned by the thief two weeks ago.

ALTHOUGH big league baseball players have won unenviable reputations as being the world's lousiest fist fighters, the exhibition of pacifism shown by Messrs. Clay and Liston not long ago has caused Alfonso Ramon Lopez, the blithe manager of the White Sox, to revise his opinions.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 5 -- Frank P. Beattie won the Grundoon Trophy today by sailing Galure to victory in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual Luders-16 Class long-distance race on Long Island Sound.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 -- Gone is the Mets' four-game winning streak, the longest they have compiled on the road in their history. It went up in the puff of a six-run first inning by the Pittsburgh Pirates and the smoke from Vernon Law's 2-hit shutout today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Four Government departments and four Federal agencies are the principal targets of the Seafarers International Union of America in a series of resolutions adopted this week at the union's 12th biennial convention.

NAPLES, Italy, June 5 -- Crown Prince Harald of Norway took the over-all lead in the world 5.5-meter yachting championships today, although he finished sixth behind the American yacht, Pride, in the fifth race of the series.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The French took another whack at upgrading Washington's social life last night. They permitted the Versailles that passes for their embassy to be the scene of the Opera Ball.

WISDOM, Mont. -- A southwestern corner of Montana known as the Big Hole is one of the last remnants of the Old West. Here, cattle graze on pastures of wild hay beneath the snow-capped skyline of the Great Divide.
HILO, Hawaii, May 28 -- Hawaii's volcanoes are becoming fickle and the scientists are puzzled.
HUTCHINSON, Kan., June 1 -- For years The Hutchinson News goaded the Kansas Legislature to heed the state Constitution and reapportion legislative districts.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 6 (AP) -- Crowds of Roman Catholics milled in the streets today and flew anti-Government banners in their sections of the South Vietnamese capital.

I HAVE recently visited London and Paris; and two questions continually discussed in those publishing centers, by writers, editors and reviewers are the same as two discussed in New York: "How long can the Spy Boom last?" and "What is the secret of James Bond's popularity?''

THE most talked-about men in America these days outside of James McDivitt, Edward White and Jersey Joe Walcott are the Yankees. It's not just that they're having monumental trouble defending their title after five straight pennants, but that they can't even draw close enough to the rest of the American League to make a real defense.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- What promotion work by one international restaurateur can do to aid the sales of California wines was detailed this week to a group of this state's leading vintners by Victor J.J. Bergeron.
MANILA, June 5 (AP) -- Flash Elorde of the Philippines retained his world junior lightweight title by knocking out Teruo Kosaka in the final minute of a brutal 15-round fight tonight.
The nation's airlines were having a baggage problem last week. The problem was not so much in handling it as in trying to come up with better rules for carrying it free.
COPIES of correspondence between the Eastman Kodak Company and a reader who questions whether the new Super 8 movies film size spells real progress have been received by this writer.
HERE comes the annual debut of a New York City Summer Festival Queen who, for the second successive year, is also the pretty drum-beater for the New York World's Fair.
Sales of department stores in the New York metropolitan area declined about 20 per cent last week from the level of the corresponding week in 1964, according to merchants' estimates.
Sunglasses are one of the strongest items of this or any other season, resident buying offices report. Frames are taking on larger and more decorative designs than ever before.

THE automobile race track at Langhorne, Pa., for 25 years one of the most exciting one-mile circuits in the nation, has changed its face and its shape and will present its new look to the public on Sunday, June 20.

PARIS -- General de Gaulle has recently emphasized in private the value he places on France's alliance with the United States despite awareness here that anti-French sentiments have mounted in America. De Gaulle regards his policy as "independence of action" but in no sense "anti-American."
RIO DE JANIERO, June 5 -- New successes in the Government's program to curb inflation were reported today as attention turned to unemployment problems.

The U.S. press has allowed to go unchallenged the unjustified attack by militant Senators on the Venezuelan Government for failing to show the alacrity of the Honduran and Brazilian Governments in cooperating in Operation Santo Domingo.

THE major musical event of the decade was Vladimir Horowitz's return to the concert stage May 9 after a 12-year intermission in his career. The major recording event will be the release this week of the live recording of that concert by Columbia Records. The two-disk set is not only of great historical importance, but is also the best album in the pianist's 40-odd-year career (M2L 328; stereo M2S 728).

The Federal Reserve Board is a unique institution in the Government. It is part of the Government, yet independent in the sense that legally it does not take orders from the President. And its job is of major importance: It controls monetary policy, meaning that it strongly influences the nation's money supply and the availability and cost of credit.
Several shipping lines have announced future cruise plans for their liners.
NATIONAL Education Television took a provocative tack last week in enlisting the services of the Consumers Union for a review of the safety factors in 1965 model automobiles.

Frank Gorman of Queens Village, the silver medalist in 1964 Olympic springboard diving, has just completed one Government job and is starting another.

KANSAS CITY, June 5 (AP) -- Dick Radatz hit his first major-league home run in the 11th inning and struck out eight in a scoreless three-inning relief stint in pacing the Boston Red Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.
A survey of the nation's military academies has concluded that while great strides have been made since World War II toward a liberal education, there are still many shortcomings.
HOUSTON, June 5 (AP) -- A water gun, a cap pistol and improvements to the propulsion gun carried by Maj. Edward H. White 2d on his space excursion are being developed.

MILWAUKEE, June 3 -- The National League of Cities this week set the stage for a close working relationship between city hall and the halls of learning.

It is unfortunate that Henry F. Graft overlooks the essential difference between the isolationist and neo-isolationist positions in "Isolationism Again -- With a Difference" (May 16). Whereas isolationists challenge the very principle of involvement, neo-isolationists question not the principle but its form, extent and attendant risks.

SOME innovations are in store for stamp collectors on the occasion of the 400th anniversary of the settlement of Florida next Aug. 28. This was the date when a Spanish expedition landed at the present St. Augustine, a spot destined to become the oldest permanent establishment of European colonists in what is now the continental United States.
NEWARK, June 5 -- If a special commission set up by Gov. Richard J. Hughes has its way, New Jersey women will play a bigger role in the state's legislative program.
Don't be alarmed if an odd-shaped balloon with a red parachute drops from the sky in the next three weeks. It won't be a visitor from outer space or a child's lost toy.
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Policy differences and charges of censorship are ruffling relations between the Voice of America and its parent agency, the United States Information Agency.

BOSTON -- On June 15, metropolitan Boston, an area already rich in historical museums, will welcome to its number the Capt. Robert Bennet Forbes House. This new museum is sure to attract wide interest because of its collection of chinoiserie and relevant memorabilia dating from the lucrative China trade of the 1830's.
NEW YORK STATE gives no special consideration to the fly fisherman's recreational desires as it does to other special interest groups such as skiers, bobsledders, hikers, boat users and campers.

FOR THIS WEEK: Cut roses in the morning and condition them before making arrangements. ... Daffodil foliage must ripen to form flowers for next year; do not mow grass where bulbs are nat uralized. ... Water young trees and shrubs. ... Pinch back snapdragons to encourage branching. ... Plant rooted cuttings of chrysanthemums in well-drained soil. ... Prune spirea, lilac and quince.

In Vietnam last week the tempo of the fighting picked up, with South Vietnamese forces taking several bad beatings. At the same time, the Communist governments were talking tougher and seemed to be moving farther away from negotiations.

A new theory of immunity has been proposed by a California medical researcher who says that if further experiments prove it correct, "tissue transplantation would become much more widely useful" than it is today.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 (AP) -- Claude Raymond, making his first major league start for the Houston Astros after 140 games as a reliever, pitched a 10-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.
PARIS, June 6 -- The French Socialist party agreed almost unanimously today to enter into a federation of non-Communist left and center political forces against the regime of President de Gaulle.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa., June 6 -- A 5-year-old German short-haired pointer, Ch. Gunhills Mesa Maverick, owned, bred and handled by P. Carl Tuttle of Bloomsbury, N.J., gained his first best-in-show title today at the 35th annual Delaware County Kennel Club fixture. There were 703 entries.

CHULAI, South Vietnam, June 3 -- A large United States Marine Corps air base has been put into operation under combat conditions in less than a month in this desolate coastal swatch of rolling sand dunes and scrub pine.
CAIRO, June 7 -- A general strike by telephone, wireless and postal workers continued today in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, severing communications for the third successive day.
A quiet man, Vincent L. Broderick, took command of the city's 27,000-member police force yesterday. He began the task, as he put it, of "enforcing the law in a time of great change."
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 7 -- The chief United Nations military observer in Kashmir chided both India and Pakistan today for their attitudes on the 18-year conflict here.
A bronze plaque honoring Adolph S. Ochs will be presented to The New York Times this morning, by Sigma Delta Chi, the professional journalistic society.

NEWARK, June 7 -- The importance of legislative reapportionment was pointed out today to more than 2,000 delegates to the fourth annual convention of the New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. The convention will end Wednesday.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 7 -- A 27-year-old New York woman died in Hartford Hospital this morning of injuries received Saturday night when she was struck by scattered debris after a teen-ager's car skidded into a heavy post.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city would sponsor a $1.38 million demonstration project for the treatment of drug addiction that would maintain heroin users on a nonaddictive drug while they underwent therapy and rehabilitation.
The United States Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers reached agreement yesterday on a new contract, ending a strike that began last Wednesday.
BUFFALO, June 7 -- Former Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney, Buffalo Republican, said today that he would not seek re-election to the Senate seat he lost in the 1964 Democratic landslide.

ABOARD U.S.S. WASP, off Bermuda, June 7 (UPI) -- Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d received a joyous greeting aboard the aircraft carrier Wasp today on their return from four days in orbit in the Gemini 4 spacecraft.
TAMPERE, Finland, June 7 (UPI) -- The last two Americans in the world Greco-Roman wrestling championships were eliminated tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies of Australia said today that his countrymen were "completely at one" with the United States on policy in Vietnam.
RABAT, Morocco, June 7 -- King Hassan II declared a state of emergency tonight and took over the Government in an effort to end a three-month political deadlock.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 7 (AP) -- School officials in Giles County, Va.; were found guilty of discrimination today for not hiring seven Negro teachers when the county desegregated its public school system last fall.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 7 (AP) -- Bill Campbell was eliminated from the British Amateur golf championship in the first round today and lost his chance for the biggest amateur golfing double in 30 years.

ADEN, June 6 -- "It was 7:10, the usual time," the wife of a British naval officer recalled. "For a while it used to be 8 o'clock but now they've gone back to 7:10. I was about to get in the shower but when we heard the noise, we all rushed to balcony to see what had happened."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 7 (AP) -- Leon Wagner and Rocky Colavito hit successive home runs in the fourth inning tonight as Luis Tiant baffled Minnesota with a brilliant two-hitter to give the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory over the Twins.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. WASP AT SEA, June 7 (UPI) -- Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d, who were repeatedly advised during their four days in space to drink more water, both chose that beverage over orange and grapefruit juice today when they reached the carrier Wasp after their orbital flight.
CAMPING can and should be a relaxing, enjoyable experience, but it takes time to learn the short cuts, tricks of the trade and what to avoid.

This year's graduates of Pace College were told last night that the "trend toward metropolitanism" had given them "a tremendous advantage," since they were educated at an urban school. The class numbered 402.

Ellis Rabb, artistic director of the Association of Producing Artists, the repertory company at the Phoenix Theater, is this year's winner of the Lola D'Annunzio Award for his "outstanding contribution to the Off Broadway theater."
BOGALUSA, La., June 7 -- Ernest Rayphael McElveen, a white man charged in the ambush murder of a Negro deputy sheriff near here last Wednesday night, asked for a preliminary hearing today.
BONN, June 7 -- With a vow "never to give up our ancestral homeland," the Association of Sudeten Germans ended its traditional Whitsuntide meeting in Stuttgart today.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc. and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net loss of $149,672 for the first quarter ended March 31. Total income for the period amounted to $377,550 which included $276,985 accrued interest on the amount awarded for properties condemned by the City of New York.
Four parcels of land left from property acquired by the city several years ago in the widening of Water Street in the financial district will be offered at auction Thursday.
BOSTON, June 7 (UPI) -- About 12,000 telephone company workers in five New England states, protesting the suspension of a union official, went on strike today.
The British pound advanced yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

Former Prime Minister Sir Alec Douglas-Home's new call for Britain to join the Common Market undoubtedly was sounded with an eye to the national election now looming -- and that is precisely its importance. His Conservative party, which sponsored Britain's unsuccessful application in 1961, termed the Common Market issue a "dead duck" in the campaign that preceded last October's election.
WARSAW, June 7 -- A woman wearing a handsome leather hat with a single feather pointed to the Volkswagen with pride and assured the man that she would never cheat him.

Following are excerpts from the conversation between the Gemini 4 and the Capsule Communications Center and Manned Space Flight Center in Houston on the last day of the four-day flight of Majs. James A. McDivitt and Edward H. White 2d:
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Yields on United States Treasury bills fell today to their lowest levels since last November.
THE Theater Company of Boston, which has been in business for a couple of years, has brought down a vivid production of John Arden's ribald, brawling, roaring "Live Like Pigs."
CONFUSION in the front office, delight in the counting house and consternation in the clubhouse mark the start of an eventful baseball week for New York today.
WHAT spectator sport did the Governor's lady and the musical comedy star indulge in yesterday afternoon?

DETROIT, June 7 (AP) -- United States auto makers expressed confidence today that they would reach their goal of an 897,000-car output this month. This would be the highest June total in automobile history.
SEABROOK, Tex., Jane 7 (UPI) -- Mrs. Patricia White said, "I always cry when I'm happy," and Mrs. Patricia McDivitt exclaimed, "It's all over."
Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced here yesterday that his department would concern itself with neighborhood parks as well as national parks.
CANTON, China -- China is governed today by a regime of oldsters, bound together by memories of shared danger, suffering and triumph.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 7 -- Gov. George C. Wallace's editors' tour of Alabama covered the route of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s civil rights march today in air-conditioned buses.
Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that the Atlantic alliance had deteriorated into "virtually a shambles" and needed an overhauling to bring about a joint approach.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 7 -- Uruguay is considering the possibility of returning to the presidential system of government.

Irving J. Bottner will be honored as Man of the Year at the 25th annual Man of the Year dinner dance of the 100 Greater New York auxiliary chapters of the City of Hope at the New York Hilton Sunday. Mr. Bottner, president of Esquire Shoe Care Products, will be cited for his contribution to the organization's medical center in Duarte, Calif.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- United States mayors were assured today of a stronger role in the anti-poverty drive.
MONTREAL, June 7 -- Jacques Plante, the National Hockey League's original masked goalie and one of its finest competitors, retired tonight.
Governor Rockefeller's proposal to beautify the banks of the Hudson River was criticized yesterday by the author of a rival Federal plan as "a blatant political move to head off Federal legislation."
THIS is a retrospective glance at some 1965 books. It is meant to be helpful in selecting your summer reading.

Full rental of the Pan American Building and increased earnings of Park Avenue and Grand Central Terminal-area hotels owned by the New York Central because of World's Fair business pushed revenues of the Grand Central Terminal to more than its expenses last year.

AS Mrs. Pupul Jayakar moved on sandaled feet though the white-walled interiors of Sona. The Golden One, she touched an ancient stone carving of Krishna, opened a brilliantly lacquered box, unfurled a bolt of gossamer-sheer silk and chatted constantly about India's 17 million craftsmen.

A panel of insurance-industry executives said yesterday it could not recommend "any specific program for flood insurance on dwelling buildings," but officials of state regulatory agencies continued to press for such a program.
Apparently word of President Johnson's concern for conserving the natural landscape has not reached the Atomic Energy Commission.

Taxpayers who have not received expected refunds will be happy to know that this is no sign the money is being held up pending an audit of their returns. The Federal Gov ernment and New York State are still processing checks.

ROME, June 7 -- A 12 per cent drop in the export prices of agricultural products and lagging production last year have been felt deeply by the developing countries largely dependent on commodity trade.
NAPLES, Italy, June 7 (AP) -- Grifone, sailed by Agostino Staulino and owned by the Italian Navy, won the world 5.5-meter yachting championship today with a victory in the seventh and final race.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A happy and proud President Johnson congratulated America's Gemini astronauts today and promptly invited them to his ranch for part of the weekend.

TOKYO, June 7 -- The Bank of Japan extended special loans and credit today totaling 4,500,000,000 yen ($12.0 million) through three commercial banks to help the Yamaichi Securities Company surmount its financial crisis.

Following are excerpts from the opinions in which the Supreme Court, by a 7-2 division, held unconstitutional yesterday the Connecticut law banning use and dissemination of birth control information and devices:

The nation's coastal and intercoastal fleets will not be affected by a strike that appears certain to bring a halt on June 15 to overseas operations of United States flag ships, management and union spokesmen agreed yesterday.

A bill to liberalize New York State's 1881 law against the dissemination of birth-control devices and information about them was reported out of the State Senate Rules Committee yesterday, with enhanced chances of passage.
PASADENA, Calif., June 7 (UPI) -- Timothy Nicholson, heir to a railroad fortune, was convicted today of manslaughter in the fatal shooting of his twin, Todd.

A $1.29 million judgment, the result of a stockholder's derivative suit, was entered against industrialist Edward Lamb and lone of his family-owned corporations in Federal District Court here yesterday.
BECKENHAM, England, June 7 (AP) -- A Russian and a South African played on the same tennis team today and the political truce promised by the Russians for Wimbledon had begun.

Howard D. Crosse is resigning as vice president in charge of bank supervision and bank relations of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York effective July 31 to set up a statewide holding company for the Franklin National Bank, Mineola, L.I.
LOS ANGELES, June 7 (UPI) -- Al Kaline's two-run homer in the eighth inning, his second homer of the game, gave the Detroit Tigers a 6-5 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.

Postmaster General John A. Gronouski declared yesterday that unless the public cooperated by zip-coding mail, the postal service would bog down in the next decade because of a continuing "mail explosion."

PARIS, June 7 -- There was a slight morning-after feeling in the French press and in political circles today after the euphoria of yesterday's victory for efforts to unite left and center political forces.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 7 (AP) -- An Army sergeant and a former Arlington, Va., real estate agent, charged with conspiring to deliver defense secrets to the Soviet Union, pleaded guilty today to lesser charges carrying possible penalties of up to 25 years in prison.
SOUTH CERNEY, England, June 7 (Reuters) -- Rolf Spanig, a 28-year-old West German student, won the 100-mile race today in the open class of the 1965 world gliding championships.
HARTFORD, June 7 -- Legislative leaders reached bipartisan agreement late today on Gov. John N. Dempsey's proposal for multimillion-dollar aid to the financially distressed New Haven Railroad.

" I don't know quite why, but women in the Tri-City area are buying a good deal more sportswear than they did last year," Kay Rabe, an attractive buyer from Denby's, Troy, N.Y., said yesterday, as she studied the tenant list in the lobby of 1407 Broadway.
BEHIND the facade of a one-family brownstone at 111 East 35th Street are enough decorating ideas to fill a score of efficiency apartments.

WHEN the British change over to the metric system, it will cause temporary chaos in many areas -- including cookbooks and recipes. But it is unlikely that it will alter the traditional roast beef and Yorkshire pudding of England or the Bannocks (oat cakes) of Scotland.
WHITE PLAINS, June 7 -- The new chairman of Westchester's Republican County organization served notice on party members tonight that he will be the boss.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara described the Administration's military pay-rise bill today as fair to both servicemen and taxpayers.

A large shipment of imported apparel, accessories and house-wares for the new Alexander's department store on East 59th Street cleared customs yesterday and will be held for the store's opening in August.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania June 7 -- The East African economic union and even the prospect of a political federation of Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania appeared today to be tottering under the weight of the visit of Communist China's Premier, Chou En-lai.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court struck down the Connecticut birth-control law today in a sweeping decision that established a new constitutional "right of privacy."
In his letter published May 20 A.M. Bentley, the Minister for Southern Rhodesia Affairs in Washington, creates a misunderstanding about his Government and its electorate.

There can be no argument with your concern [editorial June 2] over the unfinished business of the New York State Legislature. Many important bills demand immediate passage before the Legislature closes its doors for the rest of the year.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 7 -- The Dominican armed factions gave some signs today of greater readiness to negotiate a political settlement.
Criminal Court judges in Manhattan and Brooklyn who preside at trials resulting in convictions for serious misdemeanors will soon be relieved of the responsibility of sentencing the guilty.
HAVANA, June 7 -- Premier Fidel Castro triumphantly announced tonight that the sugar harvest had reached six million tons.
The Brown Williamson Tobacco Corporation and P. Lorillard Co. became yesterday the second and third of the four major cigarette makers to rescind a recent increase in filter cigarette prices.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a union forfeited its exemption from antitrust laws if it agreed with employers to impose wage scales on other employers.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 7 -- A small group of minority stockholders in the George A. Fuller Company, one of the nation's leading construction concerns, failed in their bid today to keep the company a public one.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- In June the air is full of advice. People are graduating and getting married and setting out on vacations, and it is the fate of these people to be battered with advice until they scream for mercy.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia, June 7 -- American and Yugoslav professors puzzled at a seminar here today over differing concepts of nationalism and of folklore, but their discussions were amicable and enlightening.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 7 -- Dr. Barnaby Conrad Keeney, president of Brown University since Aug. 16, 1955, announced today that he would resign June 30, 1966.

WHEN word reached the Yale campus yesterday that the Supreme Court had overturned Connecticut's birth-control law, one of Dr. C. Lee Buxton's friends sighed and said, "Now maybe he'll be able to go to a party without someone asking that tired joke about how he feels

HOUSTON, June 7 -- Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d landed safely in the Atlantic today after a four-day orbital flight. They had been aloft three times as long as the total logged by all previous American astronauts.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7 -- Ambassador Maxwell D. Taylor, who arrived in Washington today, is prepared to oppose any major change in the four-month-old policy of air strikes against North Vietnam.
ALBANY, June 7 -- A watered-down version of the strong code of legislative ethics that began its stormy journey through the Legislature five weeks ago won final passage tonight.
Trading was light yesterday on the Milan and Tokyo stock exchanges, which were among the few major overseas financial markets conducting business.
Frankie Narvaez, the 7-5 favorite of the oddsmakers and the sentimental choice of the fans, scored a majority decision over Johnny Bizzarro in the Madison Square Garden ring last night.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court held today that a 1961 decision based on the Fourth Amendment's prohibition against the admission of illegally obtained evidence in state trials will not be applied retroactively to void old convictions.
From an advertising standpoint, the four-day flight of Gemini 4 was a costly one for the three major television networks and a slightly embarrassing one for a major advertiser.
The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday five grants totaling almost $1 million.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- On this day when television provided the most magnificent example thus far of visual reporting of events while they are happening, the Supreme Court denied admission of the video camera's eye to criminal trials where its presence could have the effect of prejudicing the defendant's constitutional right to a fair trial.

The city's only oil refinery, one of the oldest in the world, will close after 111 years of continuous operation in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. the Socony Mobil Oil Company announced yesterday.
The month-old strike that curtailed the operation of Staten Island ferryboats ended last night, as 150 striking engineers voted unanimously to return to work at 9 o'clock this morning.
Steel production in the United States rose last week for the third consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The film of Maj. Edward H. White 2d making an excursion in space as Gemini 4 orbited the earth will be televised this morning -- possibly as early as 7 o'clock -- by all networks. It will be repeated several times throughout the day.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7 -- A widened role for the United Nations in restoring stability in the Dominican Republic was urged today by France, Uruguay and Jordan.
LITTLE FALLS, N.J., June 7 -- This Passaic County community has something new in traffic safety: a flagrant violation of state highway regulations.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 7 -- The fourth annual Debutante Ball of the Junior League of Bridgeport will be given June 18 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Belin du Pont 3d in Southport. The co-chairmen are Mrs. Cuyler H. Shaw and Mrs. Frederick S. Dellenbaugh 3d.

ISLAND PARK, L.I. June 7 -- An eight-month investigation by Nassau County authorities into fires that destroyed five nightclubs reportedly catering to sexual deviates resulted in the arrests early today of a reputed member of Cosa Nostra and two of his aides.

BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- Christian Scientists were urged today to find "areas of agreement" with other denominations. The board of directors told the annual meeting that individual members should not think of themselves "as entirely different or exclusive."
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Supreme Court threw out today the swindling conviction of Billie Sol Estes, Texas financier, because his trial in a Texas state court had been televised over his objection.

New products for the men who sell door-to-door went on display yesterday at the Trade Show Building on Eighth Avenue at 35th Street. Attendance by buyers was brisk at the start of the three-day event.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States today, the following proceedings were had:
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's opinions today on the use of television for coverage of the trial of Billie Sol Estes:
The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday the election of Albert P. Gagnebin and James C. Parlee, executive vice presidents, as members of its board.
National rivalries in Africa and some weekend floods in Kansas spurred price moves by two major commodities yesterday in a day that was otherwise marked by quiet futures trading.
Stockholders of Fotochrome, Inc., overwhelmingly approved yesterday the previously proposed acquisition of Williams Color Products, Inc., and the Eastern Camera and Photo Corporation, a retail chain.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 7 (UPI) -- A gas explosion ripped through a coal mine at Kakanj, near Sarajevo, today. At least 108 miners were reported to have been killed.
PORT HURON, Mich., June 7 (AP) -- Morris J. Rubin, a vice president and director of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company, was named president of Mueller Brass Company today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 7 (AP) -- The heads of two national news media groups criticized today the Supreme Court decision reversing the conviction of Billie Sol Estes because part of his trial was televised.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Hungarian Government suspended a Budapest radio broadcast today to help the American Gemini astronauts return safely to earth.

The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday the election of Dr. George H. Brown and Howard L. Letts as executive vice presidents. The posts are new. Dr. Brown and Mr. Letts, who were vice presidents, will also continue with their present responsibilities.

Eighteen golfers qualified yesterday at four sites -- Chicago, Cincinnati, Dallas and Portland Ore. -- for the 65th United States Open championship June 17 to 20 over the Bellerive course in St. Louis. An additional 101 will earn berths today at nine sites.

Creation of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority brings into being an agency urgently needed to cope with the mountainous problems of the New Haven and Long Island Rail Roads. Under the law just signed by Governor Rockefeller a five-member board will be given flexible powers to deal with all kinds of commuter services into New York City, by train, bus, plane or ferry.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A bill to curb tourist spending abroad was approved by the House today after being hastily diluted by the Ways and Means Committee.

MOSCOW, June 7 (Reuters) -- Communist union organizations today announced plans to organize strikes supporting Communist aims in Vietnam and a boycitt on United States troop and arms movements to South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Senate approved today President Johnson's request for $89 million of additional foreign aid economic funds for South Vietnam, Laos and Thailand. The vote was 42 to 26.
Publicly owned apparel companies apparently are learning how to do business more profitably.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange registered a broad decline yesterday in moderate trading.
NEW HAVEN, June 7 -- The value of rare coins stolen from Sterling Memorial Library at Yale University on May 29 was set today at $981,556.40.

Richard Lester, 33-year-old expatriate American who directed the Beatles's film "A Hard Day's Night," has been signed to direct the screen version of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," the Broadway musical.
Plans were announced yesterday for a secondary offering of 800,000 common shares of Revlon, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- The tendency of the modern American college student to be outspoken about his country's international problems was applauded today by Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the United States Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today to provide for 31 new United States District Court judges and seven additional appellate court judges in four circuits.
Mayor Wagner will propose reinstating proportional representation as the method of electing City Councilmen.
It was the first day of school yesterday for 700 jobless men.
PEKING, June 7 -- China, with massive purchases of trucks from France and the Soviet Union, is trying to wipe out the transport bottlenecks that hinder economic expansion.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Prof. Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. of Harvard University tonight criticized Lewis Mumford and Robert Lowell for their methods of protesting President Johnson's policies in Vietnam and the Dominican Republic.
Bargain hunters stepped into the picture yesterday afternoon and saved the stock market from another major setback.
ALBANY, June 7 -- The Assembly resoundingly defeated tonight a proposal to raise the state's minimum legal drinking age from 18 to 21 years.
HOUSTON, June 7 -- The dramatic successes of the Gemini 4 space flight, which ended today, have suddenly made the far more ambitious projects that are imminent seem probable and believable.

Representative John V. Lindsay, in shirtsleeves and on a walking tour in Harlem, said yesterday that if the nation had "the power, ingenuity and resources" to put two men into orbit, "surely we can improve conditons in the city."

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 7 -- Pat Cici, Pat Hannett, Moe Bass and Don Silverstein of Cedar Brook combined for a 28, 32 -- 60 today to win the Long Island Professional Golf Association's four-ball benefit tournament at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.
Ellis Island will be redesigned by Philip Johnson, New York architect, as a standard-setting project for the city's park program, Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced yesterday.

Mrs. Sugar Cane Redmond has been appointed assistant vice president of Pease Elliman, Inc. Mrs. Redmond, who joined the company about a year ago, specializes in the sale of town houses and cooperative apartments.

Some 25,000 varied lighting units from this country and Italy were on display for lighting-trade specialists yesterday at the formal opening of the fifth National Lighting Exposition and World Lighting Forum in the New York Coliseum.

THERE was both impertinence and impropriety in the hot-headed charge that Bobby Bragan leveled not long ago against Jocko Conlan. So unassailable is Jocko's integrity that no need exists for anyone to come to his defense. Yet the ugly connotations of brash Bobby's impetuous outburst cannot be ignored.

Harry C. Webb, president of the Pan American Sulphur Company, said yesterday in Houston that the concern had been officially notified by the Mexican Government that its exports of sulphur from Mexico cannot exceed 1.5 million metric tons a year in 1965 and 1966.
The coordinated bus-and-rail experimental transportation system from Rockland County to New York City will end June 25, the Tri-State Transportation Committee announced yesterday.

John Bartlow Martin, Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, 1962-64, and President Johnson's Special Envoy to the Dominican Republic during the present crisis, is currently at work on a book about his experiences on that island.

The $250 million of Chase Manhattan Bank capital notes to be sold this week have been priced to yield 4.60 per cent, but formal public offering of the securities has been scheduled for late Wednesday afternoon.

A superseding indictment accusing the chairman of the Harlem division of the Progressive Labor Movement, William Epton, of conspiracy to commit criminal anarchy and riot was returned yesterday by a New York County grand jury.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional today a provision of Federal law making it a crime for a Communist to serve as an official of a labor union.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today directed a Federal District court in Jackson, Miss., to decide whether to bar enforcement of the state's antipicketing statute.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 7 -- Fred Gronauer of Sleepy Hollow and Al Dreyfus of Harrison won the West chester County Golf Association pro-amateur tournament today with a 28, 34 -- 62 best ball score at Pelham Country Club.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 7 -- A two-and-a-half-mile extension of the eastern end of Northern State Parkway connecting with Veterans Memorial Highway will be opened here tomorrow.
BOSTON, June 7 -- Among the 1,847 degrees granted today by Boston College was a Bachelor of Science to Miss Luella Hennessey, a nurse to two generations of the Kennedy family.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers teed off on Lew Burdette and Ed Roebuck for seven runs in the fourth inning tonight and went on to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 14-3, as Sandy Koufax coasted to his eighth victory of the season.
CORDOBA, Argentina, June 7 (AP) -- The United States Consul here, Allison Temple Wanamaker of Seattle, was shot and seriously wounded from a passing car while driving his own car home tonight.

The 1965 Eastern Regional Championships ended, except for a handful of players, on Sunday night when the Mixed Team Championship was won by Michael Moss of Lynn, Mass., Evelyn Schwartz of Marblehead, Mass., and Ida Bennett and James Bennett Jr., both of New York.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 7 -- The eight clubs of the American Football League voted today to expand their organization by two teams in the 1966 season and tentatively committed themselves to add two more for the 1968 season.

IF yesterday's Supreme Court ruling throwing out the swindling conviction of Billie Sol Estes did not kill television coverage of criminal trials, it left it hanging by a thread. This was the initial reaction of legal observers to the 5-to-4 decision that produced six separate opinions, including a con currence by Justice John Marshall Harlan that served to keep alive a faint hope for the broadcasting media and those who favor its position.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 7 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, and other United Nations diplomats congratulated the Gemini astronaut team today.
Building permits issued in the 200 largest cities throughout the country increased 8.6 per cent in April to a 21-month high of $903.7 million, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings in its history for the fiscal year ended April 30.

THE stylishness of the Gemini 4 splashdown lent a touch of the anticlimactic to the live radio and television accounts of the return to the astronauts. The last leg of the four-day trip of Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d ran off so smoothly that TV anchor men were virtually reduntant.

JACKSON, Miss., June 7 -- A special session of the Mississippi Legislature was called today to "take reasonable steps" in rewriting state voter registration laws that conflict with the pending Federal voting rights bill and court rulings.
BOSTON, June 7 (UPI) -- Bill Skowron's two homers and John Buzhardt's pitching enabled the Chicago White Sox to end a three-game losing streak tonight with a 7-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
The 15th annual resupply mission of military installation in the Arctic got under way yesterday with the sailing of two Coast Guard icebreakers, the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service said.
Judy Holliday, whose portrayal of a junk dealer's doxy in "Born Yesterday" created a new kind of beautiful-but-dumb blonde, died of cancer yesterday. She was 42 years old.

A Pullman car with 12 passengers was derailed in Pennsylvania Station early yesterday. A few of the dozen passengers were thrown to the floor and the others were jostled, but no one needed medical treatment.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower broke ground for an expanded West Point today after turning his thoughts to the past for the reunion of the Class of '15.
The Army has joined the city's water conservation drive, and at least two rules will probably please enlisted men.
In the course of their historic voyage in Gemini 4, Majors McDivitt and White met brilliantly all the many tests the flight imposed upon their courage, their skill and their fortitude.

The Worthington Corporation said yesterday it would increase by 5 per cent the price of large centrifugal water chillers used in big industrial and commercial air-conditioning equipment. The increase was attributed to higher costs for materials.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (UPI) -- President Johnson today vetoed legislation to help repair flood damage in the Pacific Northwest.
The Chase Manhattan Bank's $250 million issue of capital notes was priced yesterday to yield 4.60 per cent, a price that appeared to cause a decline in the corporate bond market.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 7 -- Turkey officially denied today that she had asked Greece for the equivalent of a 386-square-mile zone in exchange for agreeing to the union of Cyprus with Greece.
James Cox Brady, the chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, warned yesterday that thoroughbred horse racing was in danger of being taxed to "a point of diminishing return."
JACKSON, Miss., June 7 (UPI) -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that this city's racial atmosphere had so improved it no longer needed a ban against civil rights demonstrations.

Vroom, put-put, vroom-vroom-VROOOOM -- and off she romps on her Harley-Davidson motorcycle for a steamy rendezvous with her middle-aged lover in West Germany. Young Rebecca had met him at a ski resort when her fiance wasn't looking; now, begoggled, done up in leather, she thinks of him as she careens along the autobahn.

The American Export Isbrandtsen Lines asked the Federal Government yesterday to declare that the bulk-commodity trade was essential to the promotion, expansion and maintenance of American foreign commerce.
Central Park, often cited as New York City's most valuable possession, was designated a National Historic Landmark yesterday.
The news item on page 37 in The Times of June 3 "Acousticians See a Pianissimo Era" brought to mind two extreme nuisances to which all subway riders in this city appear to be subjected of late.
The New York Giants announced yesterday the signing of Chuck Mercein, a 22-year-old, 230-pound fullback who was Yale's best player of the last few seasons.
KANSAS CITY, June 7 -- The New York Yankees went hitless tonight until the sixth inning, then rallied to defeat the Kansas City Athletics, 4-2, for their fourth straight victory.
MOSCOW, June 7 -- Citizens of the Georgian town of Gori are planning to reopen the municipal museum honoring their most illustrious native son, Stalin.

The Reading Company's incumbent management lost three of 11 board positions to a dissident stockholders' group at the annual meeting on May 25 in Philadelphia. The results of the election were made known yesterday when the meeting, which had been in recess, was reconvened.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 8 -- Dick Rendrickson of Giggsboro, N.J., led 18 qualifiers for the United States Open golf tournament from the Northeast area today when he posted a 69, 72 --141 over the 6,486-yard south and 7,063-yard north courses of Canoe Brook Country Club.
Steady selling all day yesterday pared paper values by about $5 billion in the stock market's most severe setback since President Kennedy was assassinated.

THERE is a maritime delicacy that Europeans have enjoyed for centuries, but that New Yorkers seem to have taken to with particular passion only within the last few years. Scarcely a decade ago mussels were a rarity in many fish markets about town, and today, with only slight exaggeration, it might be said that they are omnipresent.
On a wall in the office of Herman E. Krawitz hangs the 44th and final draft of the plans for the new Metropolitan Opera House.
Recent coverage of the Conservative party's opposition to the avowed "Republican-Fusion-Independent" candidacy of John V. Lindsay stressed the "Goldwater issue" as a prime factor.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A score of professional authors prmoting their books before the American Booksellers Association here paused in admiration today at the performance of a beginner, Helen Hayes.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Frank Howard continued his torrid hitting tonight, tripling home a run and scoring the other as the Washington Senators defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 2-0.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., June 8 -- The Soviet Union protested today that "inadmissible distortion" of the Soviet political position was creeping into United Nations records. The complaint was the second in recent months about translations of Soviet speeches and statements.
Booz, Allen Applied Research, Inc., scientific and technical services concern, announced yesterday the appointment of James N. Davis as vice president.

GENEVA, June 8 -- Hermann Hug, a Swiss banker who was arrested last week at the same time as Julio Munoz, a Spanish financier, in connection with a Swiss bank scandal, has been released from jail in Zurich.
KANSAS CITY, June 8 -- The New York Yankees went gunning for their fifth straight victory and seventh place in the American League tonight, but got neither.
Major expansion projects costing more than $90 million were dedicated or announced yesterday by leading manufacturers of the paper, chemical and steel industries.

TOKYO, June 8 -- The governing Liberal-Democratic party today squarely backed the United States position in Vietnam, opposed a "hasty" settlement between Japan and Communist China and endorsed the American nuclear deterrent as the principal support for world peace.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., June 8 (AP) -- Dr. Walt W. Rostow of the State Department said tonight that both the Vietnamese war and the conflict in the Dominican Republic in effect represented indirect aggression engineered by Communists.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- An antipoverty grant to a small Michigan community was described today as a "fraud and a disgrace" as House Republicans opened their own inquiry into the nation's "war on poverty.''
The United Artists Corporation reported a glowing profit picture for stockholders at the two-hour annual meeting here yesterday.
Several executive changes at the Horn Hardart Baking Company, Philadelphia, were announced yesterday.
HAVANA, June 8 -- Cubans were discussing today the prospect, held out by Premier Fidel Castro last night, of two or three more years of economic straits.
PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP) -- Bill Virdon scored the winning run on Hal Woodeshick's bases loaded balk with two out in the 11th inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Houston Astros 7-6.

There is no single explanation for the current shakeout in stock prices. Some analysts think investors were scared by William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who warned last week that the expansion might not last forever; others point to uncertainties abroad and a slowing of the expansion at home; technicians cite a host of signals they interpret bearishly, and customer's men report their clients are just not in a buying mood.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- Twelve elected poor persons sat down tonight with 18 appointed community leaders. The Philadelphia Antipoverty Action Committee, thus formed, is to set the course for an experiment in social and political democracy.
ABOARD THE U.S.S. WASP, At Sea, June 8 (AP) -- Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d roamed in the luxury of space aboard the Wasp today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 8 (AP) -- The United States Naval Academy retired football jersey No. 12 today in honor of Roger Staubach, a quiet unassuming quarterback who became the school's most celebrated athlete.

Amid the mounting controversy over events in the Dominican Republic and United States policies and actions there, we may be losing sight of some elementary facts underlying the situation in Latin America these days.
The Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court has directed all judges in the state to ignore a landmark ruling by the United States Court of Appeals on confessions.
Brandeis University celebrated the 70th birthday of one of its trustees and benefactors at a dinner last night and announced the receipt of $2,0772, 138 in new gifts.
HOLLYWOOD, June 8 (AP) -- A spokesman for Peter Lawford today quoted the actor as saying that he and his wife "categorically deny" a published report that they plan a legal separation.
SPRINAGAR, Kashmir June 8 -- Leaders of the Kashmir movement said today that India must eventually head their protest because it is based on the principles of Gandhi.
David Charnay, the former board chairman of Highway Trailer Industries Inc., and two other men connected with the company were found not guilty last night of stock market manipulation charges.

BRISTOL, England, June 8 (AP) -- Dennis Ralston, America's No. 1 player, had no trouble today in defeating Bristol's 16-year-old junior champion, John Stillman, 6-3, 6-0, in the first round of the rain-plagued West of England tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Treasury's need for new cash borrowings will be even smaller in the new fiscal year that begins July 1, than it was during last year. Undersecretary Frederick L. Deming said today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The man in charge of the Government's balance-of-payments statistics strongly opposed today a shift in those statistics as proposed recently by a high-level study group appointed by the Administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 -- The California Public Utilities Commission gave a qualified nod today in support of the application of the Gulf Pacific Pipeline Company in the hotly contested southern California pipeline case.
ST. LOUIS, June 8 (UPI) -- Deron Johnson, Leo Cardenas and a pitch-hitter, Art Shamsky, hit home runs off Bob Gibson tonight as the Cincinnati Reds scored a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP) -- Maury Wills drove in the winning run with a single with two out in the ninth inning tonight, giving the Los Angeles Dodgers a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phils.
New York University will award six honorary degrees and 6,735 undergraduate and graduate degrees and ceritificates a ceremonies this morning on its University Heights campus in the Bronx.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8 -- A program for producing more an cheaper home-printed books for the people of Asia, Africa and Lain-America was announced today by the United Nations Educational Scientific, and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Atomic Energy Commission's licensing board began study today of an application by a New York steamship line to operate the nuclear merchant ship Savannah in regular commercial service.
