The double bill of Samuel Beckett's "Krapp's Last Tape" and Edward Albee's "The Zoo Story" is being done again in Greenwich Village five years after it first played there: It opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theater, 33 Commerce Street, under the auspices of Theater 1965 (Richard Barr Clinton Wilder and Mr. Albee.

The City Council gave final approval last night to Mayor Wagner's record $3.875 billion budget after four and a half hours of hot debate, most of it about a provision to borrow $255 million to balance the budget.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, June 8 (Reuters) -- Communications with the Sudan were restored after a four-day break today.
TEL AVIV, June 8 -- A Hebrew adaption of the Broadway musical "Fiddler on the Roof" opened here last night in the Alhambra Theater.
Mims Thomason, president and general manager of United Press International, named Thomas R. Curran yesterday as assistant general manager of the press service.
NEWARK, June 8 -- The New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. disclosed today that it was studying a proposal to construct a two-year college.

BRUSSELS, June 8 -- The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community said today the six member nations had largely achieved their initial goals and should now "aim at more distant targets."

Ben Weber, the composer has been awarded the first Phebe Ketchum Thorne Fellowship of $300 a month for three years. The money which amounts to $10,800 tax free may be used in any way the recipient wishes.
The Sony Corporation of America took the lead yesterday in home video tape recording.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Johnson, who has talked about peace at nearly every opportunity in the last week, did so again today -- twice.

LONDON, June 8 (UPI) -- Soviet and other European Communists joined today in saluting Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d on their successful Gemini 4 space flight. But as usual, Communist China had nothing to say about the United States space achievements.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said tonight that major oil companies should not take advantage of their strength to reduce crude oil prices and injure small producers.

SCANDINAVIAN tablewares and furnishings have been accorded a royal fanfare in New York this spring. Yesterday afternoon Princess Christina Louise Helena, granddaughter of King Gustav VI Adolf of Sweden, appeared at Bonniers looking as glittering as the glasswares exhibition she had come to open.
MOSCOW, June 8 -- The Soviet Union launched another unmanned spacecraft toward the moon today in an apparent attempt to achieve a soft landing of an instrument package Friday evening.
The possibility of a lessee offering stock options to insure long-term leases at its discount stores was raised yesterday at the annual meeting of Vornado, Inc.

The pace of office leasing here increased in May, it was reported yesterday by Julien J. Studley, Inc. The real estate concern's monthly survey, called the Studley Report, said a total of 377,152 square feet of office space had been leased, compared 216,537 216,537 square feet in April and 278,436 square feet in March.
THERE is a school of thought that contends wildlife often exhibits human-like behavior. Others believe an animal is unreasoning and is incapable of such behavior.
The United States Weather Bureau here has moved, tentatively, to the sunny side of the street.
O. Pendleton Thomas, president of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, was elected yesterday to the board of the Bristol-Myers Company, a large producer of drugs and toiletries.
DETROIT, June 8 -- A Ford Motor Company official sought today to dispel any impression that there were signs of weakness in automobile demand.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 8 -- The leaders of Tanzania and Communist China joined today in denouncing United States involvement in Vietnam, the Dominican Republic and the Congo.

Fred W. Friendly, the president of the news division of the Columbia Broadcasting System, proposed yesterday that the three television networks work out a cooperative arrangement in coverage of manned space shots.
There will be no ticker-tape parade in New York for Maj. James A. McDivitt and his Gemini 4 co-pilot, Maj Edward H. White 2d.

HOUSTON, June 8 -- The biggest surprise so far to flight surgeons examing Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d is the lack of physical effect their four-day spaceflight seems to have had.
The American Stock Exchange had its second consecutive setback yesterday as the market dropped in quiet trading.
JACKSON, Miss., June 8 (UPI) -- Republicans were elected Mayors of two of Mississippi's larger cities tonight for the first time since Reconstruction.
GENEVA, June 8 -- Frank E. Figgures, Secretary General of the European Free Trade Association, was hospitalized after suffering what was described as a "slight" heart attack today.
The City of New York will soon ask Washington for $10,811,591 in antipoverty funds to finance what the city calls a "special summer crash program" against frustrations and tensions in the slums.

IN his many radio and television appearances, now numbering 20 a week on WOR and WOR-TV, Walter Kiernan has been set apart from his peers by his careful cultivation of a homespun quality to fit the urban market.

The settlement in Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.'s income tax case calls for him to pay $24,737.66 in additional taxes for the years 1949 through 1955 and $3,095.51 in penalties -- a total of $27,833.17.

ADEN, June 8 -- Reports from Yemen today indicated that royalist tribes in the north and east launched new attacks on Egyptian positions in that country in the last few days. An important battle was said to be under way at Haradh near the Saudi Arabian border.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- A Circuit Court judge granted an injunction today restraining the proposed citywide public school boycott planned for Thursday and Friday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 8 -- The belief is spreading in many quarters here, including the American Embassy, that Phan Huy Quat has been so weakened by Roman Catholic opposition that he cannot survive as Premier.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- It has always been a dubious practice for middle-aged or elderly gentlemen to make public pronouncements on sex, and the Supreme Court's latest adventure in this field only confirms the rule.

ANDERSON, Calif., June 8 -- Here in the forested vacationland of Northern California's Shasta County, spawning-bound salmon weighing up to 50 pounds disport themselves in the waters of the Sacramento River, 250 miles upstream from the Pacific.
The drama of Gemini 4 has pointed up one of the more unusual aspects of television coverage of major, fast-breaking news events. It might be called "instant sponsorship."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 8 (AP) -- People in Hanoi appear to be much less worried about being bombed by the United States Air Force than they were three months ago, travelers report.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House adopted today a last-minute compromise on the delicate issue of legislation affecting the Arab boycott of Israel.
A syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co. and associates submitted the winning bid yesterday for $25 million of the 29th series revenue term bonds of the Port of New York Authority.
GREAT NECK, L.I., June 8 -- Bob Kahn of New York gained the quarter-finals of the Long Island tennis championship today by upsetting John Mangan of Larchmont, N.Y., seeded third, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2.
RABAT, Morocco, June 8 -- King Hassan II took over the Government tonight after having proclaimed a state of emergency to take "resolute action" previously made impossible by party strife.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 8 (AP) -- Do Sparkle, racing in the colors of Mrs. Erma Sweeney, staged a closing rush to win the six furlong feature at Monmouth Park today, defeating the favored Silver Monarch in the last few strides.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Senate voted today to put $25 million in military aid for Latin America into an inter-American peace force controlled by the Organization of American States. The vote was 91 to 0.
New York City publicly notified striking ferryboat engineers and mates yesterday that they had forfeited their jobs and would have to reapply for positions as they become available.
BERLIN, June 8 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia received a roaring welcome to East Berlin today as he began his first visit to East Germany since his historic break with the Soviet bloc in 1948.
BOTH as a lawyer and a judge, New Jersey Supreme Court Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub has earned admiration from colleague and adversary alike for his command of the law and his quickness of mind.

HOUSTON, June 8 -- The first jet-propelled maneuvers of a human being afloat in space were shown today in the brilliant color films of Maj. Edward H. White 2d's excursion from his spacecraft last Thursday.
The National Association of (State) Insurance Commissioners is preparing to ask for Federal help in providing the pubic with flood insurance on dwellings.
The Early Bird satellite will televise an international classroom on Monday with Vice President Humphrey acting as visiting lecturer.
CAPETOWN, June 8 -- The South African Government's new round of harsh restrictions in cases of ordinary and political crime has encountered only minimal opposition so far.

Any hope that Mayor Wagner could be rescued from his own fiscal recklessness on the unbalanced $3.8 billion expense budget for 1965-66 vanished yesterday with Board of Estimate and City Council approval of the Mayor's borrow-now, pay-later plan to avoid instant taxation.

THE Reisinger Knockout Team Championship reached its semi-final last night, with all the favored teams eliminated. Charles Coon played Norman Neiger in one match, and Michael Moss played Arthur Miller in the other.

THE qualities that have made Alberto Giacometti an outstanding figure in modern art can be comprehensively appreciated in the major retrospective of his sculpture, paintings and drawings opening today at the Museum of Modern Art.
A group headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler submitted the winning bid yesterday for the $15 million of bonds of the Central Illinois Public Service Company.
BOSTON, June 8 (UPI) -- Joel Horlen drove in a run with one of his three singles tonight while pitching the Chicago White Sox to a 7-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
The British pound fell yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here. Forward sterling, however, continued to advance.

George Alan Smith, research and administrative associate of the special studies for the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, has been appointed executive administrator of the American National Theater and Academy.

The concept of the campus as a center for discussion of controversial issues and a forum for criticism of public policy "should be nurtured and nourished, and certainly should not be stifled or crushed," Dr. John R. Everett, president of the New School for Social Research, said last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 8 -- President-emeritus Dr. John A. Mackay told the graduates of Princeton Theological Seminary to avoid "the cult of the uncommitted" at the seminary's 153d annual commencement today.

PARIS -- While the French Government is admittedly disturbed by the degree of hostile feeling that has mounted in the United States, it remains convinced this is a transitory and nonessential factor to relationships between the two countries.
CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Joe Torre broke a 2-2 deadlock with a pinch homer in the 10th inning today and started the Milwaukee Braves on a surge that produced an 8-2 victory over the Cubs.
CANTON, China, -- Nothing seems to delight the Chinese quite so much as taking a foreign visitor on a tour of their young and bustling industry.

A 51-year-old Air Force Reserve colonel was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to 90 days in prison and fined $6,000 after being sharply criticized by the court for "plain, ordinary, cheap chiseling."
Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that he had reached a decision on whether to run for a fourth term. But he added that he was not yet ready to make it public.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 -- The names of 13 American newspapermen who 'will make up the 28th group of Nieman Fellows were announced today by Harvard University.
ALBANY, June 8 -- The members of the Legislature are apparently going to get a cost-of-legislating bonus.
An audience of nearly 17,000 cheered, whistled and applauded from 7 to 11:30 P.M. last night at a Madison Square Garden rally as one speaker after another assailed United States policy in Vietnam.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 8 -- An inter-American mediation commission today carried to the country's interior its search for a political settlement of the Dominican crisis.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 8 -- Harness racing fans, who on occasion have hooted trotters, pacers and drivers at Roosevelt Raceway, booed the tote board tonight. Many of the 18,394 punters found most disconcerting the failure of the $4 million computer mechanism to display accurate possible muteul payoffs on the third race.
Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., increased sales and earnings sharply in the three and nine month periods ended April 30, Samuel Bronfman, president, reported yesterday.

BALTIMORE, June 8 -- A philosophy professor at Johns Hopkins University criticized today America's preoccupation with science in the light of what he called its "appalling" ignorance of the humanities.
Baseball's first free-agent draft was conducted with unexpected efficiency at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, with all 20 major league clubs represented by top executives and busy staffs.

ORLANDO CEPEDA of the Giants has served his allotted 30-day term on the disabled list and should be ready to resume his role as one of the best and most consistent of Giant hitters. But the trick right knee is still giving the big fellow so much trouble -- it was operated on last December -- a report is in circulation that he may be through for the rest of the season.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee praised Sargent Shriver lavishly today and told him they could not care less if President Johnson insisted on his wearing two hats.
Prices turned up yesterday on the London Stock Exchange with Government bonds leading the advance on continued improvement of the pound on foreign-exchange markets.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 8 -- High expectations for the wine industry set the tone for the annual meeting here today of the Wine Institute of California.
BOSTON, June 8 (AP) -- The president of J.H. Goddard Co., a Boston securities concern, said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission was in error in the wording of a news release yesterday.

Premier Fidel Castro cast a shadow over the world sugar market yesterday when he announced that Cuba had already produced 6 million tons of sugar for the present crop year. This is the biggest crop since 1959 and a very large one compared with the 3.8 million tons estimated for last year.

A collection of essays by Robert Graves, called "Mammon and the Black Goddess," will be published June 18 by Doubleday. Among his essays are those based on his experiences as poet and in residence at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and as a lecturer at the London School of Economics.

Two films of Maj. Edward H. White 2d floating in space were televised repeatedly yesterday -- first in black and white and then in color -- by all three national networks. There will be repeats of the films today, with additional footage that is expected to be released by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
Corporate-bond prices rose in active trading yesterday, and this week's only utility bond issue was reported more than 75 per cent sold to investors.
Mohasco Industries, Inc., the largest carpeting producer in the United States, and the Balamundi Group of European companies, announced yesterday a joint venture to make tufted carpeting in Europe.

Ecumenism -- a word rarely heard beyond professional theological circles a few years ago -- has become so fashionable that it is rapidly losing its real meaning, the Rev. W.A. Visser 't Hooft, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House Banking Committee voted today to eliminate by 1970 silver from the half dollar as well as from the dime and the quarter.
ALBANY, June 8 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law today his own program to combat loan sharks.
Until last night the New York Mets had proved a pesky rival to the San Francisco Giants, winning four of the seven previous meetings.

ROME, June 8 -- An art forgery ring that has flooded the international market with hundreds, perhaps thousands of paintings falsely attributed to Giorgio de Chirico and other modern Italian masters has been discovered in Italy.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 8 -- The prosecution authorities of the South Korean Army indicted nine army officers today on charges of having plotted to overthrow President Chung Hee Park's government last month.

The Supreme Court's 7-to-2 decision invalidating Connecticut's birth-control law is a milestone in the judiciary's march toward enlarged guardianship of the nation's freedoms. It establishes a new "right of privacy."
Journalistic leaders paid tribute yesterday, with a plaque and speeches, to Adolph S. Ochs for having raised the standards of American journalism.

TORONTO, June 8 -- The Lamco Joint Venture, which is producing eight million tons of iron ore a year in Liberia, is planning a $51.5 million expansion program to increase production to 10 million tons a year, it was reported today.
BUENOS AIRES, June 8 -- The police threw a cordan around the city of Cordoba today in a search for gunmen who wounded the United States Consul last night.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The American Medical Association said today that it was placing an advertisement in 100 newspapers to make its position clear on its opposition to medicare. The advertisement calls medicare "the beginning of socialized medicine."
LONDON, June 8 -- Queen Elizabeth II solved a big problem for a select few today by announcing that new knights could be called "sir" as soon as the award of their title was announced.
The Board of Education was accused yesterday of threatening to use "kangaroo court methods" to remove Dr. Calvin E. Gross as Superintendent of Schools.

With a week left to avert an extensive tie-up of the nation's merchant fleet, the chief management negotiator told future mariners yesterday that labor-management differences "may yet spell the doom of an industry."

Prof. Lev Landau is one of the most eminent and respected scientists in the Soviet Union. We were amazed to see his name attached to a crudely propagandist letter (Times, June 2) denying the existence of official anti-Semitism in the U.S.S.R. and sternly forbidding Americans to take any interest in the condition of Jews under Soviet rule.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 8 -- Another battle of Atlanta began today as the two rival professional football leagues, American and National, fought for the right to place a team in the growing Southern city, which has a new $18 million stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Johnson, yielding part of the way to Congressional opposition, ordered the Veterans Administration today to proceed with the closing of six veterans hospitals out of the 11 originally recommended for closing last January.

ROME, June 8 -- Pope Paul VI has taken quiet administrative action to transfer rulings on some questions involving marriages between Roman Catholics and non-Roman Catholics from the hands of the ultraconservative Holy Office.
WASHINGTON. June 8 (UPI) -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today one of the key recommendations of the Warren Commission -- a bill making it a Federal crime to murder a President.

BOSTON, June 8 (UPI) -- A union spokesman announced today that 12,000 striking telephone company workers would return to their jobs at 7 A.M., Eastern daylight time, tomorrow even though the dispute that led to the two-day walkout remained unresolved.
The Meadow Brook National Bank, West Hempstead, L.I., announced yesterday that five officers and directors of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation had been added to the bank's board of directors.

PARIS, June 8 -- New York high school students preparing to take Regents examinations starting June 18 might like to know what 37,000 of their French contemporaries had to contend with today in the Paris region.
BALTIMORE, June 8 (AP) -- The earth has four vast bulges and four equally big depressions that affect the flight of satellites, scientists at Johns Hopkins University said yesterday.

Following are the organizations whose requests are included in the city's proposed $13,701,000 summer crash program against poverty. The figures following the names indicate the total value of the proposed project. In most cases, the Federal Government is being asked to allocate 10 per cent of the total, the city the remainder:
The Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that George Whitmore Jr. could be tried for attempted rape before facing prosecution on a murder indictment.
A number of Wall Street houses are estimating earnings for 1965 on the Dow-Jones industrial average at $52.50, and thereby hangs an interesting ratio.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- There was a mixed mood, with traces of bearish caution about the automobile industry and a general expectation of a slowdown next year, at an economic forecasting conference here today.
ALBANY, June 8 -- The Assembly, reversing its action of last week, voted overwhelmingly today to retain adultery as a crime on the state's lawbooks.
There was plenty of diverting entertainment at last night's "Tchaikovsky Promenade" at Philharmonic Hail.
The Port of New York handled a record amount of foreign cargo trade last year but was unable to halt the 12-year decline in its share of the nation's oceanborne foreign trade.

WHEN one competes in risk-taking, one is taking risks. If one takes risks, one may be unlucky and lose the gamble." Thus writes Herman Kahn, the best known of the dozen or so top civilian strategic theoreticians in America, in his new book on what might happen in a future war.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that in the face of a substantial increase in crime on buses, it planned to ask the city for $4.25 million to install two-way radios on its 4,100 buses.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The new president of George Washington University said today he would visit the campus soon to begin peace talks with faculty members in revolt against his appointment.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman initiated a program today to enlist the nation's young people in a campaign to beautify the countryside and the cities.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that in the face of a substantial increase in crime on buses, it planned to ask the city for $4.25 million to install two-way radios on its 4,100 buses.

The Ford Foundation' has made a grant of $2 million to the Manhattan School of Music. The money will go towards the school's $9.5 million expansion program in connection with its move into the building now occupied by the Juilliard School of Music. Juilliard is expected to move in 1967 to a new home in Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
WITH the horsy set, East has been East and West has been West, but now the twain have met. English-style riding has invaded the cowboy country.

HARTFORD, June 8 -- The General Assembly reached a compromise tonight on a highway construction budget that has kept the body deadlocked for days and prevented final action on most other major legislation.

Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, said at Long Island University's commencement ceremonies yesterday that New York City was doomed unless immediate steps were taken to create "a life-giving environment."
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 8 -- The United States was reported today to be using its good offices in an effort to reduce political strains between Brazil and Uruguay.
JONES BEACH, L.I., June 8 -- Under full and mostly useless canvas, La Belle Soeur, a $95,000 stage prop, sailed from Long Island City today to the Jones Beach Theater.

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 8 -- Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of the Creek Club scored 39, 39 -- 78 to take a two-stroke lead in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Sands Point Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman initiated a program today to enlist the nation's young people in a campaign to beautify the countryside and the cities.
ATHENS, June 8 -- The Government announced today that it would purge the army of all political influences.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Johnson has authorized his commanders in Vietnam to commit United States ground forces to combat if their assistance is requested by the South Vietnamese Army.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 8 -- Earnings of the United States Lines Company in the first half of this year were estimated at about $5.75 million, including a $3.86 million capital gain, John M. Franklin, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Johnson Administration urged Congress today to postpone for at least two years a decision on whether to repeal the 10 per cent Federal tax on sales of new passenger automobiles.
Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Affectionately may make racing history today. All the outstanding 5-year-old mare has to do is win the $25,000 added Liberty Belle Handicap at Aqueduct.

The defense in the Federal Court trial of three men accused of conspiring to blow up the Statue of Liberty rested its case before Judge William Herlands and a jury of 11 men and a woman yesterday after 15 days of testimony.

AN entry list exceeding 165 is reported for the national sports car races at the Vineland, N.J., course on Sunday. Among the driving stars are Bob Tullius of Alexandria, Va., in a Triumph; Don Yenko of Canonsburg, Pa., in a Corvette; Hal Keck of Hellertown, Pa., in a Cobra -Ford and Donna Mae Mims of Pittsburgh in a Sting Ray.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 8 -- The 48 newspapermen who are touring Alabama as guests of Gov. George C. Wallace ended another long day with small-town boosters and chambers of commerce today by watching a test firing of a Saturn 5 rocket engine at the Federal Space Research facility here.
Sam Snead qualified yesterday for his 25th consecutive United States Open championship -- the only major golf crown he has never won.
Actors Equity expressed concern yesterday over the 10 per cent ticket tax that will be lifted Jan. 1.
Manhattan College awarded degrees yesterday to 652 graduates at its 114th commencement. Cardinal Spellman presided at the outdoor ceremonies on the college quadrangle.

BABY girl, Arabian sheik or cosmopolitan-elegant -- these are three personalities the fashion-conscious woman may choose to adopt this fall. Each is propounded by a designer of influence as fall fashions continue to be unveiled on Seventh Avenue.
ALBANY, June 8 -- The Democrats produced today their long-delayed bill to repeal some of the harsher penalties of the Condon-Wadlin Act, which prohibits strikes by public employes.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 6 -- American businessmen and other foreign investors are turning to Taiwan in increasing numbers.

A huge structure that looks from the air like a stack of giant silver dollars and from the ground like a football stadium --circular except for a section sliced out to accommodate a woman and her dog -- is nearing completion on Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst.
Sam Snead qualified yesterday for his 25th consecutive United States Open championship -- the only major golf crown he has never won.
Actors Equity expressed concern yesterday over the 10 per cent ticket tax that will be lifted Jan. 1.
Manhattan College awarded degrees yesterday to 652 graduates at its 114th commencement. Cardinal Spellman presided at the outdoor ceremonies on the college quadrangle.

An indictment charging Philip B. Kohut, former Commissioner of Public Safety of Long Beach, L.I., with having taken bribes to promote the sate of 1,500 to 2,000 Duncan parking meters to Long Beach, was dismissed yesterday in Supreme Court by Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

Governor Rockefeller's June 5 message manifests a solitiousness about the Hudson River Valley that no one who has observed his performance in Albany would have anticipated. The state-born who approved the Sloan King project and who has stopped the Hudson River expressway bill now asks to be accepted as the defender of the valley against outside interests.
ANXIETY'S realm today is astonishingly adaptable. We listen with numb awe to doomsters prophesying annihilation for one and all -- and plan, simultaneously, vast renaissances in the arts.
Vice President Humphrey called on college graduates yesterday to join a "massive assault" on poverty throughout the world.
VARNADO, La., June 9 -- O'Neal Moore, a Negro deputy sheriff gunned down by night riders June 2, was buried here today by his church and family without fanfare.
MOSCOW, June 9 -- The Soviet rocket Luna 6 passed the halfway point today on its way to the moon. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said that all systems on the unmanned craft were functioning normally.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A servicemen who recently returned from France told today of buying a $2,650 automobile, having it repossessed after he had made $1,800 in payments, and still being held responsible for more than $1,300.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Federal Trade Commission ordered the Fruehauf Trailer Company today to divest itself of two truck trailer manufacturing companies that it acquired a decade ago.
Two persistent tormentors of the New York Mets, Willie Mays and Gaylord Perry of the San Francisco Giants, did them in again last night before a crowd of 37,660 at Shea Stadium. The score was 4-2.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 9 (AP) -- James A. Michener, the author, turned down an invitation to dine with President Johnson last night in order to pay tribute to a former teacher "who taught me how to write."

CAPETOWN, June 9 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd announced today that the South African Government was sending 100,000 sacks of grain to Basutoland, where it will be distributed by the political party most strongly in favor of close cooperation with South Africa.

A suit has been filed against David M. Milton, the chairman of the Equity Corporation, several associates and affiliated companies by a stockholder of Oceanic Trading Company, Inc., which at one time owned 1,773,665 shares of Equity.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 10 -- Fourteen United States servicemen were killed and 10 were wounded in desperate fighting early today when about 1,000 Vietcong overran a district capital and attacked a Special Forces camp 60 miles north of Saigon.
A State Supreme Court justice dismissed indictments yesterday against two Cubans and a Cuban-American accused of firing a bazooka at the United Nations.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, called yesterday for much larger expenditures for education. Present methods and sources of financing, he declared, will no longer suffice.

A decline of 1,625,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline supplies in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 210,879,000 barrels, compared with 212,504,000 in the preceding week and 206,002,000 a year earlier.

The Shell Funding Corporation, an American member of the Royal Dutch Shell Group petroleum companies, will issue today $120 million of 4 3/4 per cent collateral trust bonds, series B, that will mature June 1, 1985.

NORWALK, Conn., June 9 -- The Common Council has approved a capital improvements budget and by so doing has eliminated the need to provide funds for a new high school. The S4,500,000 budget includes $600,000 for renovation of the Norwalk High School on East Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The White House confirmed today that United States ground troops in South Vietnam had been authorized to enter into combat to support Vietnamese forces against Communist attacks.

Degrees and certificates were awarded last night to 188 graduates of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. The ceremonies were held in the Great Hall on Astor Place at Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- President Johnson s proposal to eliminate silver from future dimes and quarters won speedy approval today from the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

BRISTOL, England, June 9 (UPI) -- Dimitri Sturdza of Switzerland upset Gene Scott of St. James, L.I., 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, today in the second round of the Wst of England tennis tournament. The event is a tune-up for the Wimbledon, which starts June 21.

ALBANY, June 9 -- The Senate, reversing an action it took last week, narrowly passed a bill today that would freeze the waterfront work force in New York Harbor at its present level of about 24,000 longshoremen.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 9 -- Harold Gerber, vice president of Gertz, Long Island, had the best low net, a 72, and won the Rothschild Cup today at the 37th annual New York City Newspaper-Retail Dry Goods Association golf tournament at the Century Country Club.

Fierce competition in the retail gasoline market, long indigenous to this motoring-happy nation, has now cropped up in Britain -- but with the addition of a promotional gimmick that might make even American entrepreneurs sit up and take notice.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 9 -- More, not less, global trouble was predicted today by Gen. John Paul McConnell, Air Force Chief of Staff. In an address to 515 cadets in the Air Force Academy graduating class, he said:

HONGKONG, Thursday, June 10 -- The Vietcong has threatened call on volunteers from North Vietnam and other friendly countries in response to Washington's announcement that the United States forces in South Vietnam would fight if requested by the South Vietnamese forces.
Vice President Humphrey, in what was the next thing to a campaign speech for Mayor Wagner, predicted yesterday that the Mayor would run for a fourth term and be elected.

TOKYO, June 9 -- The chairman of the Tokyo Stock Exchange predicted today that a marked upturn in securities activity would hinge on a general recovery from Japan's economic recession. He said a recovery should come by the end of this year at the latest.
Men of wealth across the land who would dearly love to own a pro football team can now ponder this question -- is a franchise, any franchise, worth $7.5 million?

Trading in copper futures, which has been reacting recently to the heating and cooling in world political and economic events, showed a fairly strong upturn yesterday because of what one trader termed "the worsening situation in Vietnam."

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S "A Midsummer Night's Dream" was as lustrous and lavish as ever yesterday afternoon at the New York State Theater, where the New York City Ballet gave it for the first time this season.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that the national crime rate which hit a high last year, rose during the first three months of 1965.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 9 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Braves of the National League said today they had offered to pay $400,000 to Milwaukee County and $100,000 to Teams, Inc., a group of Milwaukee boosters, to be allowed to transfer from Milwaukee to Atlanta after the All-Star game on July 13.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 9 -- Only a few blocks from the prostitute-filled bars of Saigon's brassy Rue Tu Do, senior United States military officers are fighting a battle to distract off-duty American servicemen.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A Cuban exile leader convicted of counterfeiting produced evidence today to show that the Government had known of his plan to undermine Cuba's currency but had not disapproved.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company acquired yesterday the assets and business of Penick Ford, Ltd., Inc., for a cash consideration of $96,562,356. The purchase was made by Penick Ford, Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of Reynolds.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- A Chamber of Commerce spokesman said today that the Neighborhood Youth Corus was encouraging some youngsters to drop out of school and that the Job Corps was an expensive way to deal with the dropout problem.
Stock prices fell heavily in the final minutes of trading yesterday.
HOUSTON, June 9 -- Neither of the two satellites that Maj. James A. McDivitt reported seeing and photographing from the Gemini 4 spacecraft can be found on film, the space agency said today.

Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of Rockefeller Institute, conferred Doctor of Philosophy degrees yesterday on 11 young men and women who will become university professors in the sciences and humanities.
PARIS, June 9 -- The Festival du Marais opened tonight with a performance of Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet" given by the Zagreb Ballet in the courtyard of the Hotel de Rohan.

Charges of discrimination by construction trades against Negroes will be made a political issue in this year's mayoral campaign, according to Herbert Hill, labor secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
A $924,396 damage award to the widow and children of William Kapell, the pianist, was thrown out yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 9 (UPI) -- Honor Bright, a Keswick Stable 3-year-old filly, won the Miss Woodford Stakes today at Monmouth Park.
Stock markets abroad turned downward yesterday under the combined effects of the Wall Street trend and local conditions.

Substantial gains were made in sales and earnings of Russ Togs, Inc., in the 13 and weeks ended May 1, according to a report yesterday by Eli Rousso, president of the apparel and sportswear manufacturer.

Police Commissioner Vincent Broderick commanded a 30-man security force today at the funeral of an Army captain killed in Vietnam. The victim's family had been subjected to gloating anonymous calls and unsigned letters.

Actors Equity Association has called on the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service to impanel a group of experts in the performing arts to advise the service on the admission of alien actors to this country.
MOSCOW, June 9 -- The Soviet Union is expected to help North Vietnam rebuild the road network and bridges destroyed in four months of American aerial bombardment, diplomatic sources said today.

Gareth Martinis, 25-year-old son of Acting Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Martinis went on trial yesterday on five counts of vehicular homicide and one of assault. Three jurors were selected from the panel of 44.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 9 -- Rutgers University graduates were told tonight that they must think and act as individuals and not accept solutions of their problems in terms of mass housing, mass transportation, mass media and mass education.
ALBANY, June 9 -- A bill that would require public authorities in New York State to open their books and records to any person who wanted to inspect them was approved today by the Senate.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 9 -- Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told 596 graduates of the United States Military Academy today that they faced a messy world, but one in which the nation's position is far from hopeless.

The chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights paid a call yesterday on a graduate student from Ghana who has complained of racially motivated harassment at his apartment in Forest Hills, Queens.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Organization of American States officially summoned today an inter-American conference to meet in Rio de Janeiro, beginning Aug. 4.

Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China achieved a propaganda success but no real breakthrough on his visit to Tanzania. President Nyerere balanced a warm welcome and strong support of China's international policies with careful emphasis on his country's determination to guard its sovereignty and integrity.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 9 (AP) -- "Disquieting similarities" between the present real estate market and that of the 1920's have been noted by James C. Downs Jr., chairman of Real Estate Research Corporation of Chicago.
HONG KONG, June 9 -- The flow of refugees from Communist China has risen suddenly after a long period of quiet along the Chinese borders facing Hong Kong and Macao.
MOSCOW, June 9 -- The darling of Russia's musical world returned to Moscow's Conservatory last night.

PARIS, June 9 (UPI) -- The United States, Britain and France will compete among themselves for aircraft sales as well as try to outshine the Soviet Union in the 26th Le Bourget air show opening tomorrow.
HARTFORD, Conn., Thursday, June 10 -- Connecticut's General Assembly adjourned at 12:31 A.M. today after a day's weary progress through a morass of bills.
LONDON, June 9 -- Common sense tells one that Dame Margot Fonteyn, 46 years old, must have reached that point in her career when, to be blunt, she is getting worse and not better.
Two firemen who resigned after a scandal involving alleged visits by prostitutes to a Harlem firehouse asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to order their reinstatement.
Price reductions of 10 cents or more a pound on heavy-denier nylon industrial yarns were announced yesterday by the American Enka Corporation.
MOSCOW, June 9 -- A one-man show of the works of Martiros Sarian, one of the Soviet Union's most original painters, has opened in Moscow as part of the observance of his 85th birthday.
The city took initial and tentative steps yesterday toward re-employing some of the 130 ferryboat engineers and mates who ended their strike on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) -- Paul Jennings, new president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, ruled out any merger of his union with the United Electrical Workers today.

Varese of Italy, looked upon as the cinderella team of the International Soccer League in preseason estimates, made its American debut an impressive one last night by sweeping to a 2-to-0 triumph over Munchen 1860 of Munich, Germany.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Employes of the Chicago Traffic Court made about $1 million in the last year by fixing tickets, Sheriff Richard B. Ogilvie said today.
A group of major taxicab fleet owners will ask a Federal court today to halt a city-sponsored union-representation election among their workers.

The acquisition of land in noise-sensitive areas near airports and the displacement of residents were proposed today by Najeeb E. Halaby, Federal Aviation Administrator, as a possible solution to the aircraft noise problem.
LONDON, June 9 (UPI) -- One of Britain's larger building societies today increased the interest rate on mortgages fort home buyers to 7 per cent a year, effective July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to retain part of the 10 per cent Federal tax on passenger automobiles in the interest of highway safety and beauty.
ALBANY, June 9 -- A complete revision of the state's Penal Law, the first since 1881, won final legislative approval today by a vote of 45 to 10 in the Senate.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 9 -- The centerpiece of the Soviet Union's cultural program in Uruguay this season has been knocked off the stage for purely capitalistic reasons.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The American Booksellers Association ended its annual convention here tonight with general agreement that it had been the most successful in 65 years because the members had ordered more books from publishers and had got them to listen to more complaints.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 9 -- A contingent of 2,500 more American troops, including two battalions of Army combat engineers, began arriving today to build a major supply base at Camranh Bay.
CHICAGO, June 9 -- A Federal district judge refused today to dissolve a state court's injunction against a two-day school boycott scheduled to start tomorrow.

ALBANY, June 9 -- Assembly Majority Leader Moses M. Weinstein, who is the Democratic leader in Queens, said today that he was prepared to deny the party's redesignation to Senator Jack E. Bronston in the fall election.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Lawrence Young, a 56-year-old Negro cab driver, received today a $19,500 loan from the Small Business Administration to open a restaurant specializing in Southern fried chicken, thanks to President Johnson.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 9 -- International agencies today investigated reports of political assassinations of Dominican rebels. The reports said the rebels' opponents, the military-civilian junta, had directed its military forces or policemen to carry out the killings.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- In retrospect it would appear that when the President dispatched regular combat forces to Vietnam, their commitment to ground warfare would be generally foreseen as inevitable. To Prime Minister Menzies of Australia this foresight has always been "a simple matter," as he remarked today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today a 15-day suspension of Schweickart Co., a New York securities firm, for violation of margin regulations.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 9 -- People here are fond of saying that when the United States and Soviet Ambassadors meet, they invariably ask each other, "What's new?"

NOT since the days of William Tecumseh Sherman has there been such a wild scramble to get to Atlanta in a hurry. The Milwaukee Braves started it by agreeing to switch their baseball franchise to the spanking new stadium in the Georgia metropolis. In their greedy haste they bungled the operation and are stuck in Milwaukee as a lame duck team for this season.

New York has two critical administrative vacancies to fill -- one on the City Planning Commission and the other on the Housing and Redevelopment Board. Is the city looking for a planner and a housing expert to fill them? Certainly not. It is seeking a Brooklyn candidate, preferably Negro, for the former, and considering a Catholic, as such, for the latter.
THE answer to what is both becoming and proper on this summer's tennis courts may be found on the second floor of the Elizabeth Arden salon in a new section called the Tennis Boutique.

The Johnson Administration's decision authorizing a combat role for American troops in South Vietnam is only confirmed by yesterday's White House statement; yet the statement is carefully drafted to give the impression that the United States is not embarking on a radical new course.
CLEVELAND, June 9 -- Arnold Palmer, who is accustomed to battling par, found himself fighting a cold today. But he said he would be in tomorrow's field for the $125,000 Cleveland open.

LONDON, June 9 -- Official sources said today that no British-registered vessels traded regularly in North Vietnamese ports but that there were probably occasional visits by British-registered tramp ships.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 9 (AP) -- Gov. John A. Volpe praised today college students who take a stand on current issues.

President James M. Hester of New York University declared yesterday that the "new urban civilization" of today needs a new generation of city-oriented people capable of tackling the problems that seem insuperable to many members of the older generations.

Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said last night that the Justice Department was working with the American Bar Association and the American Law Institute in preparing legislation on criminal confessions.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- The New England Electric System said today it had made an offer to acquire Western Massachusetts Companies, which already is discussing affiliation with two Connecticut power concerns.
In the menus that follow, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- Lawyers defending four sponsors of Krebiozen turned back today a Government attempt to put into evidence records of 4,757 cancer patients who used the chemical.

OTTAWA, June 9 -- Heavy rains have ruined crops in the Lake St. Jean and Saguenay River regions, and French-Canadians there say rainmaking experiments are going on. Some point an accusing finger at New York, others at Ottawa.
NEWARK, June 9 -- The ouster of the chairman of the Bergen County Democratic Committee was the highlight today of party organization elections throughout the state.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 9 (AP) -- The Texas "Supreme Court refused today to consider an appeal by former employes seeking payment from a profit-sharing plan in a television station once owned by President Johnson's family.
The average person uses 60 gallons of water a day, a figure the State Health Commissioner says can be halved "with no danger to health and only minor alterations in living habits" during the drought.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- Dr. Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president and chief economist for Bankers Trust Company, projected today an increase to more than $90 billion in annual spending for goods and services by state and local governments in 1970 compared with outlays of $67 billion last year.

A thousand high school seniors will be guests of Lincoln Center at six performances by the New York Philharmonic, the New York City Ballet, the New York City Opera and the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center next season.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee will file two reports on its investigation of Robert G. Baker. One will be by the Democratic majority, the other by the Republican minority. The six Democrats agreed on the content of their report today.
Guitars and slide rules, surfboards and textbooks were among the gear hauled aboard the white-hulled Aurelia yesterday as 1,100 students set sail for study and play in Europe this summer.

Princess Christina Louise Helena of Sweden was guest of honor at a dinner dance in the St. Regis Roof last night. But there were some young Americans among the 275 predominantly Scandinavian guests who came away sure they had met that other 22-year-old Chris Bernadotte.

MOBILE, Ala., June 9 -- Gov. George C. Wallace's "anti-distortion tour" of Alabama for out-of-state newspaper editors ended here tonight with a boat ride and a beach party on the Gulf of Mexico, but without the Governor.
Prices of stocks on the American Stock Exchange continued to drift downward yesterday as trading accelerated.

An underwriting group headed by Glore, Forgan, William R Staats, Inc.; White Weld Co., Blyth Co., Drexel Co. and associates was awarded yesterday the $33,650,000 Dallas North Tollway revenue term bonds of the Texas Turnpike Authority.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Despite some semantic hedging at the White House today, private and public official comments here leave little room for doubt that American marines and soldiers are not yet actively supporting the South Vietnamese in battle but are likely to be soon.

PARIS, June 9 -- All week long, Frenchmen have been having dreams getting parking tickets and collecting the telephone numbers of beautiful girls. But now, as the weekend approaches, these events take on monumental significance: soon it will be time to pick le tierce.

KANSAS CITY, June 9 -- Mel Stottlemyre pitched a six-hitter against the Kansas City Athletics tonight and demonstrated for the seventh straight time that what's good for Mel Stottlemyre is good for the New York Yankees.
CANTON, China -- The other day a crowd gathered in Changsha, to the northeast of Canton, to watch children at play.

Columbia University unveiled yesterday 280 square feet of sculpture, a two-ton metal structure incorporating, among other things, cash-register keys and automobile parts. It is called "Business and Society."
The Chase Manhattan Bank's $250 million capital-note issue was offered to investors formally late yesterday afternoon priced to yield 4.60 per cent.

In a noisy, crowded room on the 27th floor of ITT Communications, Inc., yesterday, Clyde M. Widmann, the divisional sales manager of Gibson Greeting Cards, Inc., suffered stage fright as he waited for his call to speak to London via the Early Bird satellite.

A FEW days ago, Gov. John Noel Dempsey of Connecticut commented that a friend had told him he was moving from a small town in the southeastern corner of the state to Stamford to take a job as an assistant vice president at $41,000 a year.

Leo Cherne, the chairman of the International Rescue Committee, will leave for Saigon today to confer with American and South Vietnamese officials on the feasibility of re-establishing the committee's operations in South Vietnam.

LONDON, June 9 -- In the long tradition of nighttime roof-climbing at Cambridge University the soaring pinnacles of the King's College chapel are a challenge comparable, some say, to the north face of the Eiger in the Swiss Alps.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 9 -- Service areas on the New Jersey Turnpike will soon bear the names of famous people who were natives of New Jersey or who had strong ties with the Garden State.
I would like to point out some errors of fact in your May 26 editorial comment an the Belgian elections.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 9 (Reuters) -- President Chiang Kai-shek has pardoned Dr. Thomas W.I. Liao, American-trained engineer, for leading the so-called Formosan Independence Movement, it was reported today.

JACKSON, Miss., June 9 -- Mississippi Republicans, whose candidates were elected mayor in two cities and won other offices in five towns, looked today on their first major effort in municipal politics in 75 years as an exciting political breakthrough.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 9 -- Premier Forbes Burnham has told Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, leftist former Premier and leader of the opposition People's Progressive party, that the essential basis for the country's national unity must be for political leaders and political parties to exclude themselves from international Communism and colonialism in any form.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 9 -- The co-leaders of Bolivia's military junta have decided to go to Catavi, center of the country's richest tin-mining region, to appeal to the workers for support of their mine-reorganization program.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 9 -- More than 400 soldiers and secret servicemen cornered and killed the notorious bandit Efrain Gonzalez today in his fortified "town house" in the south side of Bogota.
Two of Europe's leading actors, Alec Guinness and Oskar Werner, will co-star in the first work written directly for the screen by Jean Anouilh, the French playwright.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- A House Labor subcommittee approved today the Administration's bill to repeal the section of the Taft-Hartley Law that permits states to ban union shop agreements.

THE Eastern trek is on. Store buyers who fear that they have exhausted the fashion markets of Europe are seeking new founts. Well-heeled tourists who have already "done" the Greek Islands and the London-Paris-Rome axis are flocking to the Orient and the Middle East. The women travelers, for many of whom shopping is most of the fun of leaving home, will be making their purchases largely in the form of clothing.
CLEVELAND, June 9 -- Friends in Ohio of the Republican National Chairman, Ray C. Bliss, put up a million dollars tonight to ease the party's financial distress.
THE Reisinger Knockout Championship was won last night by Michael Moss's team after a close and exciting final match. The result was six points in favor of the Moss team.
HOLLYWOOD, June 9 -- Electronovision Productions, Inc., today signed a new contract with the Screen Actors Guild, permitting the company to proceed with plans to produce additional motion pictures.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -- An extremely complex gas transmission case before the Federal Power Commission has been further complicated by the California Public Utility Commission's announcement of its position. Involved is the multibillion-dollar Gulf Pacific case.

The Columbia University School of Social Work will seek to answer a national problem that has puzzled welfare administrators: Why do three out of every five children in foster care turn out well and the other two badly?
RENNES, France, June 9 (AP) -- Michel Jazy of France bettered the world record for the mile run with a time of 3 minutes 53.6 seconds tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate refused today to disqualify for United States aid any nation more than a year behind in dues or assessments to the United Nations.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 9 -- President Sukarno, with the aid of the Communist party, is pursuing a campaign to neutralize the Indonesian Army as an anti-Communist force in this country.

A member of the Warren Commission has speculated that Mrs. Marina Oswald may have unwittingly goaded Lee Harvey Oswald to murder President Kennedy by refusing to live with him. The conjecture is in a book to be released June 14.

Contract negotiations between 12 ship lines and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association will resume today as a result of a request by Assistant Secretary of Labor James J. Reynolds. A strike is threatened for next Tuesday evening when current contracts expire.
MILWAUKEE, June 9 -- A Presbyterian minister and five other civil rights demonstrators were arrested at the 20th Street school today when they tried to stop a school bus.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 9 -- Premier Phan Huy Quat called on the country's ambitious young generals today to help preserve his Government.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Bringing the Ku Klux Klan under "effective control of the law," as President Johnson promised on March 26, is proving to be a problem for both the Administration and Congress.
The British pound dipped 5 points to 2.7932 yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here.

MOLLIE PARNIS, who knows how socialites like to dress. Christian Dior-New York, the local branch of the Paris couture house, and Donald Brooks, who divides his designing life between Seventh Avenue and the theater, all presented their fashion blueprints for the fall season yesterday.
Erwin Wasey, Inc., set out yesterday on what it hopes will be the "road back" in Chicago. And it has chosen a different vehicle in which to make the return trip.

Maxim Gorky is the subject of a biography and critical study that Appleton-Century will publish on Monday. It is called "Stormy Petrel: The Life and Work of Maxim Gorky." Dan Levin, the author, has spent five years in the research and writing of his book, both in America and Russia.
The time has come to move the erratic debate on American involvement in Vietnam into Congress, the committees of the Senate and House and to the floor of each chamber. [Editorial June 9.]

When Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Affectionately was a 2-year-old her trainer, Hirsch Jacobs, referred to the racer as the best filly he had ever trained. As the years went by and the daughter of Swaps and Searching compiled an impressive record, Jacobs had many opportunities to reiterate his earlier pronunciamento.
HOUSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Space officials released today a photographic first -- a picture of the Gemini 4 capsule taken by Maj. Edward H. White 2d during his maneuvering in space.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House approved today a $328 billion limit on the national debt for the fiscal year starting July 1. The figure is $4 billion above the present ceiling but $1 billion below the limit proposed by the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- An ambitious Federal program to help narcotics addicts was laid before Congress today by a bipartisan coalition of New York Senators and Representatives.

Roman Catholic residents of Greenpoint and Williamsburg said yesterday that they would appeal to the Pope and picket the Vatican Pavilion at the World's Fair on Sunday to protest plans for a $20 million hospital center to be built by the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn.
The Government and corporate-bond markets marked time yesterday as the $250 million Chase Manhattan Bank capital-notes offering took the spotlight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 -- Adlai E. Stevenson advised members of the Security Council today to encourage, not disparage, the Organization of American States' peace efforts in the Dominican Republic.

The bulk of this country's trans-oceanic shipping may be halted by a strike next Tuesday, despite the willingness of six maritime unions to extend their contracts for sixty days. Two other unions, representing deck and engine room officers, are holding to their "no-contract, no-work" rule, and their intransigence may nullify the majority's peace move.
ABOARD U.S.S. WASP, At Sea, June 9 (UPI) -- A little tired but in "great shape and wonderful spirits," Major Mc Divitt and Major White wound up exhausting medical tests today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- When, in early 1969, the time came to select the first astronaut to go to the moon, American space programers discovered that they had made a dreadful miscalculation.
The women's apparel industry appeared yesterday to be heading for one of its most successful fall seasons in recent years.
DEAL, N.J., June 9 -- Nancy Roth of Plant City, Fla., took a three-stroke lead today after the second round of the 59th annual Womens Eastern Golf Association championships.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House topped off one of the liveliest political skirmishes of the session today by voting to allow Americans to see a documentary film on the life and death of President Kennedy.
LONDON, June 9 -- A sheep dog trial is not the most exciting spectator sport in the world, but several thousand came to Hyde Park on the sunny Whit Monday holiday to watch, anyway.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 9 (UPI) -- Bill Hyndman, taking a tip from his 74-year-old caddy on the choice of club, shot an eagle on the 17th hole today to squeeze out a 1-up victory over Colin Strachan of Scotland and advance to the fourth round of the British Amateur golf championship.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 9 -- The Supreme Court decision that struck down the Connecticut birth control law is expected to affect the case of a 32-year-old former medical student who has been charged with giving out contraceptive information in violation of New York State law.
DEAL, N.J., June 9 -- Nancy Roth of Plant City, Fla., took a three-stroke lead today after the second round of the 59th annual Womens Eastern Golf Association championships.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House topped off one of the liveliest political skirmishes of the session today by voting to allow Americans to see a documentary film on the life and death of President Kennedy.
LONDON, June 9 -- A sheep dog trial is not the most exciting spectator sport in the world, but several thousand came to Hyde Park on the sunny Whit Monday holiday to watch, anyway.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 9 -- Dick Siderowf easily won the annual Hochster Memorial golf tournament today with a one under-par 139 for 36 holes at Quaker Ridge. The former Connecticut open and amateur champion took the amateur invitation competition by eight strokes over Bill Bogle of Dutchess.

The manifest and manifold benefits of expediting a state constitutional convention are so persuasive that no possible way of bringing it about should be ignored at Albany. An early convention is desirable to incorporate the fairer reapportionment of legislative seats that Federal and state courts insist upon. It is needed even more urgently for the general revision and simplification of the Constitution left unfinished by previous reform.

False rumors that President Johnson was ill swept through Wall Street yesterday, and before the White House squelched them, the stock market dropped sharply. Reports that Mr. Johnson had suffered either a heart attack or a stroke began to circulate soon after the opening of the New York Stock Exchange at 10 A.M. and reached a climax somewhere around 12:15 P.M.
The University of Iowa Ensemble for Contemporary Music offered a program of one and two-year-old works last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Heroism under fire, far beyond the normal duty of a diplomat, brought to John R. Clingerman today one of the United States Government's highest civilian awards.

Confidence in the retail business outlook has prompted the May Department Stores Company to project an expansion program that will increase the number of its stores in operation to 85 or 90 by 1970. Morton D. May, president, made the disclosure to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
AUGUST RANKIS of the Bronx, a former New York State champion, flashed his top form by winning the recent fifth North American-Latvian chess championship in Milwaukee.
50-year-old widow was raped in Queens early yesterday morning near her home in the fifth such crime in that borough within two weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Justice Department charged the nation's two largest distributors of magazines with coercing dealers to ensure preferential display of their publications on retail store racks.

KANSAS CITY, June 9 -- Three members of the New York Yankees were fined $250 apiece and several others were reprimanded by Manager Johnny Keane for "having one drink too many" in the Newark Airport terminal Sunday evening.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Paul H. Nitze, speaking to the class that he said would probably lead the Navy into the 21st century, warmed today that Communist China would be the big political problem for the next 40 years.

CINCINNATI, June 9 (UPI) -- Dr. Albert Sabin developer of the oral polio vaccine, said today that he learned from reliable health authorities on his just-completed European visit that Communist China had made great progress with a birth-control program and "surprising strides in health and education."

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The program of voluntary restraint on bank lending to foreign countries has converted an outflow of $2 billion last year and $400 million in the first two months of this year into an inflow of $140 million in April, it was disclosed today.

ALBANY, June 9 (AP) -- A bill that would permit harness racing to begin Jan. 5 and extend through Dec. 15 was approved by the State Senate today by a 52-3 vote. The season now runs from the third Thursday in February to the Saturday of the first full week in December.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Sargent Shriver got a friendly reception today as he defended in a Senate hearing the use of controversial psychological tests for Peace Corps volunteers.
ROME, June 9 -- Pope Paul VI will attend an ecumenical symphonic and choral concert Saturday. Works of composers of four religions will be played.
Representative John V. Lindsay took off his coat, rolled up his sleeves and campaigned busily yesterday in Sunnyside Queens, and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
" A car is like a woman," said a somewhat downtrodden husband recently. "The proper maintenance of either demands lots of time, attention and cash."
News officials of the three national television networks met yesterday to discuss ways for pooling technical facilities in covering manned space flights.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Johnson has opened a long-planned offensive against what he regards as unwarranted encroachment by Congress upon the prerogatives of the executive branch of the Government.

WEST POINT, June 9 -- Shortly before his graduation from the United States Military Academy today, Cadet John Alger of Aliquippa, Pa., sat erect in his Government-issue chair and gave his mind a freedom he wasn't yet allowing his carriage.
News officials of the three national television networks met yesterday to discuss ways for pooling technical facilities in covering manned space flights.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Johnson has opened a long-planned offensive against what he regards as unwarranted encroachment by Congress upon the prerogatives of the executive branch of the Government.

WEST POINT, June 9 -- Shortly before his graduation from the United States Military Academy today, Cadet John Alger of Aliquippa, Pa., sat erect in his Government-issue chair and gave his mind a freedom he wasn't yet allowing his carriage.
Ten former employes of the Internal Revenue Service and five accountants were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on bribery charges.
The current hearings on military pay before the House Armed Services Committee have already produced widely discrepant figures and discordant opinions.
Michael J. Quill urged yesterday that an armed policeman be placed on every city-owned bus to halt the recent increase in assaults on and robberies of drivers and passengers.

NOAH WEBSTER'S book, the dictionary, defines the word arrogate in this fashion: "To assume, or claim as one's own, unduly, proudly or presumptuously; to make undue claims to, from vanity or baseless pretensions to right or merit."
An Air Force missile expert said yesterday that radiation from an enemy nuclear attack posed a "potential threat" to the reliability of the nation's retaliatory missile system.
HOUSTON, June 10 -- The Gemini 4 astronauts came home today from a journey of almost two million miles.
Mayor Wagner's decision not to run for a fourth term has turned politics upside down in New York City, New York State and even, to a degree, in Washington.

New York State has the most illiberal and unrealistic divorce law in the nation, virtually unchanged since its enactment in 1787, with adultery the only allowable grounds. Repeatedly through the years the Legislature has refused to make even a study of the substance of this law.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, June 10 -- The monetary and banking system shared by Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania since all were British governed territories, is to be broken up, it was announced today.

Dr. Albert H. Bowker, Chancellor of the City University of New York, called yesterday for more Federal aid to technical education. He spoke at the commencement exercises of the New York City Community College at 300 Pearl Street, Brooklyn.

A closely contested soccer match is expected tonight when Milan of Italy and Santos of Brazil, two of the world's leading clubs, clash at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. The game will start at 8:30 o'clock.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, June 10 (Reuters) -- A coalition Government headed by former Foreign Minister Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub took office today after the new Constituent Assembly met for the first time. The Government replaces a temporary one headed by Sir-el-Khafun elKhalifa.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -Francis Keppel, Commissioner of Education, warned school officials today that discriminatory dismissal of Negro teachers would not be permitted under the desegregation guidelines issued by his office last April 29.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -Donald F. Turner, the nominee for head of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, underwent two hours of intensive questioning today before the Senate Antitrust subcommittee.
CANTON, China -- On a warm night not long ago I joined a couple of thousand other steaming fans at a performance of Communist China's latest hit, a tearjerker called "The Red Lantern."
PORTLAND, Ore., June 10 -- Governors crossed party lines today to report that majority sentiment in the Western states favored an Administration policy of "keeping the heat on" in Vietnam.

I read with great interest your June 5 editorial urging Governor Rockefeller to approve a referendum this November on the calling of a state constitutional convention. This bill is easily one of the most important passed by this session of the Legislature and your concern about the Governor's silence in this matter is timely.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 10 -- Mrs. Evans G. Morgan of Wee Burn and Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow were the respective winners today in the Catherine McLean Brook Memorial Medal tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association, played at Bonnie Briar C.C.
LISBON, June 10 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar presided today over a ceremony honoring 65 soldiers for distinguished service in the defense of Portugal's overseas possessions.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -The House Education and Labor Committee approved today an Administration-backed bill to appeal the section of the TaftHartley Act, 14(b), that permits states to outlaw the union shop.

Baseball boasts that its basic rules have remained unchanged for generations, but last night's 3-0 victory scored by the San Francisco Giants over the New York Mets before 34,358 at Shea Stadium suggested one timesaving reform.
EDDYSTONE, Pa., June 10 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation approved today a merger with Armour Co., the nation's second largest meat packer.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Retail sales rose 2 per cent in May to a record level, the Commerce Department reported today.
The United States Plywood Corporation, the world's largest plywood organization, had the highest sales and earnings in its 46-year history in the fourth quarter and the fiscal year ended April 30.

Justice Peter A. Quinn rejected yesterday in State Supreme Court an appeal by Walter C. Ivancevic for a temporary injunction to prevent the directors of the Equity Corporation, a closed-end, nondiversified investment concern, from removing him as its president.
TRENTON, June 10 -- New Jersey's Republican party convened here today with appeals for unity but without the big Bergen County delegation, which boycotted the meeting to snub the state chairman.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, challenged yesterday a Department of Defense claim that it had made "proper study" of the manning of 450 foreign-flag ships considered to be immediately available to the United States in an emergency.
ALBANY, June 10 -- After years of inaction, the Legislature has empowered a committee to recommend reform of the state's 178-year-old divorce laws.
Mayor Wagner, in an emotional 20-minute statement, announced at City Hall yesterday his "irrevocable" decision not to run for a fourth term.
Copper made news in futures trading again yesterday with another substantial rally.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- A Soviet philosopher who recently returned from a tour of the United States said today that he had found Americans increasingly curious about Marxism as a philosophy and less inclined to dismiss it as entirely hostile.
A world Jewish leader asserted yesterday that accusations against the Soviet Union over its treatment of Jews were "too often being distorted."
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Senators Joseph S. Clark and Robert F. Kennedy joined today in sponsoring a bill that would repeal the loyalty oath provisions of the National Defense Education Act.
Federal Judge Edmund L. PaLmieri refused yesterday to halt a city-sponsored election that will test the interest of full-time taxicab workers in joining a new union.
TRENTON, June 10 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he was preparing to take emergency action to conserve water in northern New Jersey, which, he said, faced a "disaster condition."

CHICAGO, June 10 (UPI) -Margie Masters of Australia took the first-round lead in the $9,000 Women's Western Open golf tournament today with a one-under-par 72 over the 6,399-yard Beverly Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Navy said today that the Curtiss-Wright Corporation could participate in future naval Weapons procurement, including the procurement of weapons system trainers.
GENEVA, June 10 -- Detailed bargaining on a projected pact to regulate world trade in grains was formally opened here today as part of the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting talks.
Promotion men are known to go to great lengths to promote something. Now, they're even going to great heights -- 41,000 feet to be exact.
The British pound inched ahead yesterday on foreign exchange markets here. It rose 2 points to $2.7934 in very light trading.
The city and county of Denver awarded six bond issues totaling $10,645,000 yesterday to a syndicate headed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

The Pacific Car and Foundry Company has announced the election of Robert D. O'Brien as chairman and chief executive officer. Charles M. Pigott, formerly executive vice president, succeeds Mr. O'Brien as president.

NINE times yesterday, when he was reading his 2,700-word decision not to seek re-election, Mayor Wagner mentioned his two sons. They are, he said, "the most personal and yet the highest of considerations."

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 10 -- A fireman made five trips up and down an extension ladder through heavy smoke last night to rescue a family of five trapped atop a burning building. The fire destroyed a three-story brick bathhouse and 11 boardwalk concessions, causing damage estimated at $700,000.

AREA A -- Some sea bass, plenty of blackfish and fluke are being taken off the jetties and piers. A few kingfish have been caught from the beaches off Sandy Hook to Manasquan, according to the report from Long Branch.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The future of the Brooklyn Navy Yard was left in doubt tonight as the House voted to place a tight Congressional curb on the closing of military installations.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 10 (AP) -- A settlement has been reached in the Chrysler Corporation's $30 million-libel suit against Sol A. Dann, Detroit lawyer and Chrysler stockholder, it was disclosed today.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 10 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedarbrook carded a 38, 39 -- 77 today for a 236 total to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole championship at the Creek Club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP) -- Ray Herbert's first National League shutout and consecutive sixth-inning homers by Rich Allen and Dick Stuart carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-0 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
HOLLYWOOD, June 10 -- Movie directing, traditionally a tough trade for an outsider to enter, seems to be opening its doors.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -Home runs by Hank Aaron and Rico Carty helped the Milwaukee Braves down the Chicago Cubs, 6-4, today after the visitors had spotted the Cubs a three-run lead. It was the Braves seventh victory in their last nine games.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A bill to cut excise taxes $4.7 billion was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee, 14 to 3.
Suddenly, in this impersonal and critical city, in this town where people rarely get sentimental about the Mayor, there was a strange new mood of melancholy yesterday.
DEAL, N.J., June 10 -- Nancy Roth of Plant City, Fla., won the 59th annual Women's Eastern Golf Association championship today over the Hollywood Golf Club course.

" Special Agent: A Quarter Century with the Treasury Department and the Secret Service" describes the work of Chief Frank J. Wilson during the years from 1936 to 1961. Written in collaboration with Beth Day, Mr. Wilson also discusses the psychology of the would-be assassin and offers several suggestions for decreasing the dangers of an attack on our head of state. From Holt, Rinehart Winston, July 5.

MCPHERSON, Kan., June 10 -- Duane Earl Pope, 22 years old, was a star defensive end on McPherson College's football team. One of his great pleasures was tinkering with auto engines. He didn't smoke or drink. If he had any peculiarity, it was simply that he was very quiet and reserved; even, some say, shy, particularly around girls.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Rain during May in the critically dry Great Plains areas raised this year's wheat-crop prospects to within 1 per cent of last year's above-average production.
The defense in the Statue of Liberty bomb-plot trial charged yesterday that the Police Department and the Government had entrapped three men who are defendants.
