When Henry Loomis stepped down in March as head of the Government's overseas broadcasting service, he declared in his farewell speech: "The Voice of America is not the voice of the Administration."

Oscar James Campbell, professor emeritus of English literature at Columbia University and adviser on the arts-center program there, paused the other day in his labors on two books to chide the editors of "Who's Who in America" for thinking he is inactive.
HONG KONG June 10 -- North Vietnam has begun a drive for army recruits in the face of American military actions in Vietnam.
CLEVELAND, June 10 -Tony Lema and Billy Casper, both concerned about their health, shared the first-round lead in the $125,000 Cleveland open tournament today with 67's.

LE BOURGET, France, June 10 -- United States, British and French Air Force men clambered all over the latest models of Soviet civil aircraft today, while Russian experts peered keenly at Western military planes and American space rockets.

PARIS -- Despite -- or perhaps because of -- the gravity of the international scene, a note of realism seems to be creeping into the world. This contradicts the worsening gloom in Vietnam, an insoluble Dominican mess and the efforts of China to beat emotional drums in Asia, Africa and Latin America.

The Democratic majority at Albany has finally worked out its tussle with organized labor over proposed revisions in the Condon-Wadlin Act prohibiting strikes by state or municipal employes. The compromise bill would provide a desirable strengthening of the machinery for peaceful settlement of disputes through collective bargaining. Where direct negotiations failed, advisory arbitration would avert any justification for recourse to economic strength by public workers.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 10 (AP) -- Bill Hyndman, a 49-year-old Philadelphia insurance broker, swept into the quarter-finals with a pair of impressive victories today and became the only remaining American in the British Amateur golf championship.
The nation's electric power production rose 5.9 per cent in the week ended June 5 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute.

Premier Castro's announcement that the Cuban sugar crop reached 6 million tons this year represents a remarkable accomplishment. There are doubts in Washington that the total really is as high as Mr. Castro says, but there is no question that the harvest is a large one and certainly far above that of the previous two years.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, speaking yesterday at the fourth annual commencement of Queensborough Community College of the City University, deplored the "blind nostalgia that refuses to look honestly at the present world."

The Columbia Broadcasting System has contributed another $100,000 to the educational television station WNDT (Channel 13). The announcement was made yesterday by the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, owner and operator of the station.

Threaded through the "farewell" address yesterday of the outgoing president of the National Association of (State) Insurance Commissioners was one thought: Fight Federal regulation of the insurance business.
The Diners' Club, Inc., has bought the music magazine Bravo for $130,000, and formed a subsidiary, the Bravo Corporation, to run it.
OTTAWA, June 10 -- The government of Quebec yielded today to the demands of angry citizens and called off all rain-making experiments for the rest of 1965.

SOCIALITES from Park Avenue to Southampton came to Seventh Avenue yesterday afternoon to witness the debut of one of their guests in drawing room and yacht. Oscar de la Renta, who has been a popular young man about town since he came to Elizabeth Arden a few years ago direct from Lanvin, the Paris couture house, presented his first collection for Jane Derby -- and it was a triumph.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 10 (AP) -- Sam McDowell continued his torrid strikeout pace tonight but needed Gary Bell's relief help in the ninth to preserve a 4-1 victory for the Cleveland Indians over the Minnesota Twins.
The corporate bond market moving up as the stock market declined, registered its second good-sized advance of the week yesterday.

Will there ever be another Saint-Exupery -- a man of action with a poet's "sense of life" and an eloquence that survives literary fashions? Not likely -- yet how the space age could use his like! The French aviator-philosopher (who vanished on a mission in World War II) was the last of the literary humanists, the last to extol without embarrassment man's "essence" and enduring glory.
CHICAGO, June 10 (UPI) -Sylvania Electric, Inc., has doubled its capacity to produce color-television sets, Robert J. Theis, president, told dealers at a showing of the 1966 Sylvania line.
Commentators abroad were divided yesterday on the significance of the United States decision to provide ground combat support for South Vietnamese forces when requested.

A bruising primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Mayor loomed last night after Mayor Wagner's withdrawal from the electoral race. At least three major forces seemed likely to contend for power, leading to three or more slates in the voting Sept. 14.

PARIS, June 10 -- Napoleon Bonaparte and Jean Cocteau, neither of whom were ever tested on cinder paths, posthumously joined in the national acclaim today for Michel Jazy, the new world record-holder in the mile run.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the Memorial Day week ended June 5 were considerably below the level of the corresponding week of 1964. The year-to-year decline resulted from the fact the holiday was not observed during the comparable week in 1964.
GRASSHOPPER, Ariz., June 10 (AP) -- Lynda Bird Johnson arrived in Arizona coach class on a commercial airliner today for nearly two weeks among the Apache Indians.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 10 -- Lights at the nearby Owego laboratories of the International Business Machines Corporation are burning all night while scientists and engineers cluster around a 59-pound computer that failed to function properly on the Space flight of Gemini 4.
Japan Air Lines will start an intensive three-week newspaper and magazine campaign this Sunday offering potential customers a guidebook to bargain-hunting in the Orient.
DETROIT June 10 (AP) -The nation's auto industry turned out 207.188 cars this week, setting a record high for six months production.
I wish to commend you on the June 6 news article by E.W. Kenworthy concerning Senate views on our Vietnam policy.
PISA, Italy, June 10 -- Pope Paul VI praised today the "great mind" and "immortal memory" of Galileo, the astronomer once condemned for heresy, in a speech in the scientist's home city.
Robert F. Wagner is paid $50,000 a year for running the world's second city, a momentous and infinitely detailed task that lately has been almost as full of crises as it usually is of routine.
PATERSON, N.J., June 10 -- A wooden barrier now separates part of Paterson from the adjacent borough of Totowa, and Totowa doesn't like it.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 10 -- Uruguay decided today to withdraw her representative from the United Nations Security Council as an expression of disapproval of his denunciation of United States policy in the Dominican Republic.
The Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York held its 107th commencement exercises last night in the Walt Whitman Auditorium of Brooklyn College.
The Pennsylvania Railroad may operate the Long Island Rail Road under the terms of the proposed $65 million sale of the Long Island to New York State.
A long-term leasehold on 12 six-story apartment buildings in the Bronx has been sold by the Boone Management Corporation to the Harsal Management Company.
The American National Theater and Academy will establish its first university-based regional office at the State University of New York at Albany in September.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Johnson asserted today there was "no reason for gloom or doom" concerning the country's economic outlook, adding that there were no conflicts of opinion within the Administration on this point.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 10 -- With the help of a $35,000 "talking typewriter," a four-month preschool program here has prepared 24 underprivileged 4-year-olds so well for kindergarten that the school system plans a $1.3 million expansion, officials announced today.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company's board of directors voted yesterday to split the common stock for the third time in six years. The authorized three-for-two split will be distributed about July 12 to holders of record June 21.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 10 -- The Organization of American States ordered today that a technical team of criminologists come "urgently" to the Dominican Republic to investigate evidence of political executions attributed to the military-backed junta regime.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -The House Foreign Affairs Committee refused today to limit Sargent Shriver to one Government position.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

In all the excitement about the sharp decline in the stock market, one important question is: Who's doing all the selling? During the last three days alone more than 19.2 million shares have changed hands on the Big Board.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- Wally Bunker, backed by three double plays from his Baltimore Oriole teammates, pitched his second complete game in five days tonight and gained a 5-1 victory over the Washington Senators.
HARTFORD, June 10 -- In the dying hours of the General Assembly session that ended at 12:31 A.M. today, Ellsworth L. Covell sat quietly and shook his head.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The chairman of a House subcommittee suggested today the Food and Drug Administration had relied on "junk mail" to warn physicians about two suspicious drugs.

Your June 2 advertising section quotes Walter S. Meyers, "an outdoor advertising executive," to the effect that the removal of billboards "would limit the freedom of the motorist to choose where he wanted to spend the night, where he wanted to eat and what kind of gasoline he wanted to buy."
Rubber companies, brokerage firms, shipping lines and distillers were among the first concerns to send on a test basis yesterday commercial - message transmissions via the Early Bird satellite.

A 10-minute standing ovation was given Mayor Wagner last night as he entered Manhattan Center, 34th Street and Eighth Avenue, to receive a scroll from the membership of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
The Oklahoma City Junior Symphony Orchestra, in town to play at the World's Fair this week, gave a concert in Town Hall last night under the direction of its conductor, T. Burns Westman.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- United States exports declined 14 per cent in April from the record reached in March following the dock strike, the Commerce Department said today. With the effects of the dock strike presumably now complete, it is clear that the nation's foreign trade surplus declined substantially in the first four months of the year.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

ALBANY, June 10 -- The Democratic legislative leaders confidently predicted today that Mayor Wagner's decision not to run for re-election would in no way deter passage next week of his revenue package for next year's New York City budget.
The elections of Harry W. Baechtold and William A. Gebhardt as vice presidents of the Marine Midland Trust Company were announced yesterday by George C. Textor, president.

An offering of 750,000 shares of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York's $100 par cumulative preferred stock was marketed yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Morgan Stanley Co. and the First Boston Corporation.
SAIGON, June 10 -- The Vietcong attack at Dongxoai began early today with a mortar barrage. Eighteen Americans are listed as dead or missing as a result of the frenzied fighting that followed.
ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -Leo Cardenas tripled with the bases loaded and Tommy Harper slammed four hits and scored the decisive run today as the Cincinati Reds defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-7.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Civil rights demonstrators, prevented by a court order from staging a boycott of the public schools, marched through the business district to City Hall and the Board of Education offices today, interrupting mid-day traffic for four hours.
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's announcement yesterday, declaring he will not run again, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the city Board of Education had the legal right to remove Dr. Calvin E. Gross as Superintendent of Schools "for cause."
Loans to business by the 14 weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York City declined $30 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
A top-level source familiar with hospital problems in the city said yesterday that two more hospitals would be shut down by the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn.
The London stock market showed a firming tone toward the close yesterday amid indications that the slump on Wall Street was being discounted.

TORONTO, June 10 (AP) -Bill Crothers upset Peter Snell of New Zealand, the world record-holder and a double Olympic champion, tonight in capturing the 880-yard run in the Toronto track and field meet. Crothers was clocked in the meet-record time of 1 minute 48.4 seconds.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 -- Nobody was more surprised at Mayor Wagner's withdrawal today than the man who predicted yesterday that he would run -- Hubert H. Humphrey, Vice President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- All the recent confusing statements about American policy in Vietnam agree on one thing at least -- the mission of the United States armed forces in that country is still limited.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 10 -- Speedy Scot, regarded by most fans, horsemen and experts as the world's top trotter, wound up dead last tonight in the $25,000 Rodney at Roosevelt Raceway. When that happens to a 2-to-5 favorite, it's shocking.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 11 -- United States helicopters flew more reinforcements into Dongxoai today. The Government forces began rapidly clearing the Vietcong from that district headquarters town 60 miles north of Saigon.

Mayor Wagner yesterday cited "free Shakespeare in the park and the preservation of Carnegie Hall . . . and . . . securing the Mets for our city" as two accomplishments here "in promoting and incouraging cultural facilities and diversification."
Mortimer M. Caplin. court-appointed trustee for Webb Knapp, Inc., is attempting to work out a settlement of the real estate company's disputed equity in the Paramount Building.
MAYOR WAGNER'S decision not to seek re-election will remove from the television scene a man who successfully defied all the presumed conditions for effective political performance on the home screen.
Governor Rockefeller praised Republican party workers yesterday and predicted that a Republican-controlled Legislature would be elected next November.
The wholesale commodity price index dropped to 104.6 on Wednesday from 104.8 on Tuesday.
LONDON, June 10 -- Queen Elizabeth II joined today in commemorating the fateful surrender of power by her ancestor, King John, at Runnymede 750 years ago.

LONDON, June 10 -- The three crewmen of British European Airways' midday jetliner flight from Paris sat back and folded their arms today while a computer took over for what officials called the first automatic landing of an airliner with passengers.
The American Stock Exchange turned in another bearish performance yesterday as the market dropped in active trading.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 10 -- Ambassador Velazquez declined comment tonight on the report that his Government was displeased with his action in the Security Council.
A Yale Express System, Inc., executive testified yesterday that the trucking company would not be able to continue operating without an infusion of additional working capital.
LAGOS, Nigeria, June 10 -- Foreign ministers of 35 African countries met in emergency session today to consider an accusation that Ghana is fostering subversion in many African states.
Mayor Wagner, who said yesterday that he had not thought of any job after he leaves City Hall on Dec. 31, will be eligible for a pension.
The resolution of a dozen major city issues became cloude yesterday with Mayor Wagner's announcement that he would not seek a fourth term.

BRISTOL, England, June 10 (AP) -- Top-seeded Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., won two matches today and led two other Americans into the semifinals of the West of England lawn tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Some of the more than 50,000 United States troops in South Vietnam are now poised for combat and the indications are that more combat units will soon join them. Yet Congress has at no time declared war on anyone in that area.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- President Johnson conferred today with Ambassador Maxwell D. Taylor about the new military and political crises Vietnam. Meanwhile, a new flurry of debate broke out in the Senate over the Administration's Vietnamese policy.
Representative John V. Lindsay praised Mayor Wagner yesterday as a great New Yorker, but insisted that the city needed a change from Democratic rule.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday the appointment of James R. Sullivan as vice president for marketing. He succeeds Arthur E. Baylis, who has been named vice president for staff.

As a plumber I should certainly welcome measures to save water as proposed by your paper, especially as the building trades are in a deep recession at present. A city law demanding the metering of all hot and cold water used would mean a tremendous boost for a number of trades, foremost among them plumbing.

Jack Schwadron, president of E.J. Korvette, Inc., is expected to resign today, and Eugene Ferkauf founder of Korvette, will take a more active role in the dramatically growing discount-store chain, according to Wall Street sources.
ALBANY, June 10 -- New York State's movie censorship procedure was declared unconstitutional today by the Court of Appeals.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -Half a dozen New York Yankees -- including Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris -tangled with their-toughest opponents of the season Sunday night at Newark Airport when they had "one too many" in front of Johnny Keane.
SANTO DOMINGO, June 8 -- The Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National City Bank, New York, are conducting their banking business out of the same room in the International Security Zone here.
On his 4,179th day as Mayor of New York, Robert Ferdinand Wagner spent only one hour and 31 minutes at City Hall yesterday.
BOSTON, June 10 (UPI) -Floyd Robinson's three-run triple off Dick Radatz gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

THOSE of us who live or work in New York know that almost anything can happen on Manhattan Island. You can meet the most marvelous girl in the world, or an insane murderer. You can find beauty, joy and love, or ugliness, misery and hate.
PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) -- Bob Veale ran his string of complete game victories to five tonight, by hurling the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-2 victory over the Houston Astros.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Uruguayan Ambassador here denied today the report that Dr. Velasquez's transfer was related to his speeches about the Dominican crisis.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 10 -- Former Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino said today that he would not seek re-election to the Legislature in November but expressed interest in running for Attorney General or Lieutenant Governor if offered the chance.
SRINAGAR, Kaskmir, June 9 -- At 5:30 o'clock this afternoon, the dusty circle they call Red Square was filled with Kashmiris.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 -- More than 800 women -and here and there a retired husband -- paid $6 apiece to peer at baronial splendor on a humid afternoon. The first relay of the house and garden tour to benefit the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford was held today in this suburb to which New York-based millionaire industrialists repair by air-conditioned limousine or railroad club car after their labors in the corporate jungles.

PARIS, June 10 (Reuters) -The French National Assembly today unanimously ratified amendments to the United Nations Charter that would increase the membership of the Security Council from 11 to 15 nations and of the Economic and Social Council from 19 to 27.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- To Washington has come the "Mother and Child" by Jacques Lipschitz, from Philadelphia, and Reuben Nakian's "The Emperor's Bedchamber," Oronzio Maldarelli's "Crouching Woman" and David Smith's "Lectern Sentinel" from New York.
WARSAW, June 10 (Reuters) -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, has protested to the Government that theological students drafted into the army are being mistreated.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Senate turned back two major attempts today to override Administration recommendations on the $3.44 billion foreign aid authorization bill. Leaders in both parties saw "an outside chance" of passing the measure tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee voted today to send the House a bill to make future coins of nickel-clad Copper.

ONE of the most exciting Reisinger Knockout finals for many years ended late Wednesday night in a victory for the team led by Michael Moss of Lynn, Mass. His teammates were James Bennett Jr. of Staten Island, Anthony Dionisi of New York, Harlow Lewis Of Philadelphia and Mark Blumenthal of Brookline, Mass.
NEW DELHI, June 10 (Reuters) -- India assumed powers under defense rules today to control all distribution of petroleum products.

A key maritime union offered a 30-day strike moratorium to a major segment of the United States merchant marine in exchange for a 26 per cent package increase in a four-year contract, shipping spokesmen said yesterday.
OTTAWA, June 10 -- Prime Minister Lal Bohadur Shastri of India arrived here today to discuss with Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson means of "maintaining the peace."
Chile and the Cerro Corporation are negotiating a contract to supply Japanese companies with 150,000 tons a year of copper concentrates, it was announced yesterday in Santiago, New York and Tokyo.
Price changes were announced yesterday for several industrial products.

Sidney Schwartz has been named controller and George Masefield director of management operations of the Franchard Corporation, realty investment concern. Mr. Schwartz, assistant controller for the last three years, succeeds Samuel S. Brown, who retired.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Stephen Ailes holds stock in a finance company that is under Congressional investigation for its loans to servicemen, but he has taken no part in operations of the company, an Army spokesman said today.
Nervous traders dominated the action on the stock market again yesterday, trimming almost $3 billion from paper values and running the week's losses to about $13 billion.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales in the week ended last Saturday declined 8 per cent to $5.2 billion, reflecting the short sales week in many lines of business because of Memorial Day.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- The Soviet Union announced today that its latest spacecraft Luna 6, intended to soft-land an instrument package on the moon, would miss the moon by 100,000 miles because of a failure in a midcourse maneuver.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk said this evening that the United States welcomes "peaceful revolution" in Latin America through the Alliance for Progress.
Stanley Robert Vinton, who was once known as the "teen-age Lawrence Welk," has grown up to become Bobby Vinton, the country's hottest male singer.
The First National City Bank's offering of $266,307,500 of convertible capital notes due in 1990 will carry a 4 per cent coupon, and will be convertible into common stock at $66.67 a share.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, is urging that the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions take more vigorous action to combat Communism and to help free trade unions in newly independent countries.
Edward Voss's Golpista demonstrated his liking for distance by winning the 2 1/2-mile Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
A short-cut method aimed at speedy settlement of disputes between local union workers and movie production companies will be established here.

Mayor Wagner has surprised practically everybody, and thrown the Democratic party into turmoil, by his announcement very late in the political season that after all he will not run for a fourth term. He has withdrawn in conclusive words. The scramble to succeed him, as nominee of the Democratic as well as the Liberal party, is on.
EAST VIEW, N.Y., June 11 -- Seventy-five of 80 hunger strikers continued their fast at the Westchester County Jail tonight, 24 hours after a non-violent protest against conditions there began.

THE annual invasion of the young British designers took place on schedule this week, but with a difference. Last year's comparatively quiet showings have given way to ear-shattering parties complete with Beatle-like combos and with models dancing rather than walking down runways.

BRUSSELS, June 11 -- The planned visit to Britain later this month of Dino Del Bo, the president of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, may, in time, prove to have been one of those figurative bridges across the English Channel that British Prime Minister Harold Wilson has been talking about.

The Government summed up yesterday its case against three men charged with conspiring to destroy the Statue of Liberty and asked the Federal Court jury of eleven men and one woman to find the defendants guilty of that charge and of conspiring to smuggle dynamite from Canada to implement the alleged plot.

Now that Mayor Wagner has retired from the race, the Liberal party is taking pains to emphasize that it is a free agent. Its often nearly automatic attachment to the Democratic cause is not to be taken for granted this year.
It was a trendless day for most commodity futures yesterday, as buyers and sellers apparently played a waiting game. Volume was light, and closing prices indecisive.

Mayor Wagner, a half-hour behind schedule and hurrying from one ceremonial function to another at City Hall, was asked yesterday if he intended to keep up the pace during his remaining days in office.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 11 (UPI) -- Harlis Miller of Norwalk, was sentenced today to life imprisonment for the second time for the slaying of Mrs. Isabel Sillan in 1962.

MOSCOW, June 11 (AP) -- Russian newspapers reported briefly today that Luna 6 would miss the moon. The announcement came at the end of a story that stressed that for almost two days everything on the unmanned flight worked normally.

On Sunday, June 6, our neighborhood -- 84th Street and Third Avenue and vicinity -- was host to the marchers assembling for the annual Puerto Rican Day parade. In preparation for the event the Police Department removed all parking on 84th and other nearby streets in the blocks between Third and Park Avenues.
Dino De Laurentiis, one of Italy's leading independent film producers, has contracted to make a series of features for exclusive worldwide release by Columbia Pictures.

A year-old monkey, apparently upset by the sight of a prospective purchaser he had recently bitten, broke out of his cage in a locked pet shop yesterday and went on a 90-minute rampage before the police and agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals broke in and subdued him.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 11 -- The Vesper Boat Club eight-oared crew of Philadelphia, winner of the Olympic gold medal at Tokyo, will undergo its first test of the 1965 season tomorrow in the American Henley regatta.

EDWARDS, Miss., June 11 -- The Northern volunteers for the Freedom Democratic Party's Summer Project, many of whom had not been in Mississippi until yesterday, are getting a quick course in the political life of the state.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee was asked today to continue for another five years a ship exchange program that enables freight lines to obtain vessels from the national defense reserve fleet.
The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a dentist was not obligated to submit proposed speeches and manuscripts about his profession for approval to a dental society of which he is a member.

In a three-day convention that ended yesterday, one of the nation's smallest unions was visited by the Vice President, the Secretary of Labor, the Mayor of New York, the president of the marged labor movement, the chairman of the "third force" in New York politics and the president of the central Labor Council of New York.

PATERSON, N.J., June 11 -- A Passaic County jury today acquitted John Kozma, 44 years old, of 80 Dick Street, Clifton of murdering his wife, Lorraine, 34, by reason of insanity. The jury ruled, however, that he had since returned to sanity.
The American Stock Exchange staged a mild rally yesterday in quiet trading.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, June 11 -- Minister of Justice Balthazar Vorster said today that the Government needed the power to arrest witnesses and to deny bail to the accused in criminal cases to protect itself from "professional saboteurs."
MOSCOW, June 11 -- The Soviet Union has asked the United States for the extradition of a man living in Mineola, L.I., as an alleged World War II war criminal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, has urged the Security Council to extend the life of the United Nations force in Cyprus for six months instead of three, as in the past.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Officials here voiced the hope today that the change in South Vietnam's four-month-old Government might have been more formal thou real.
The trading week on the London Stock Exchange closed yesterday with all sections subdued and price movements narrow.
It's not only red tape that slows the wheels of government. Sometimes it's white twine.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 9 -- The Australians are debating the high cost of Joan Sutherland, but they will probably pay the record admission prices being charged for the soprano's return to her native land after an absence of 14 years.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 -- A suit by Anheuser-Busch, Inc. to keep the Federal Trade Commission from holding hearings on possible antitrust violations in the brewery's yeast business was dismissed yesterday by United States District Judge James H. Meredith.

The New York Chamber of Commerce opposed yesterday the repeal of Section 14 (b) of the Taft-Hartley Act, which permits states to prohibit contracts requiring union membership as a condition of keeping a job.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, made a plea today for a national teacher corps to assist low income urban and rural areas.

TIME was when billing a summer concert as a Viennese program could mean only one thing: a series of waltzes, polkas and operetta excerpts by Johann Strauss. In the New York Philharmonic's "Viennese Promenade" at Philharmonic Hall last night, with the Austrian red-white-red flag on stage for emphasis, the spirit of the Waltz King was much in evidence, but not a note of his music was heard -- until encore time.

Milan of Italy and Santos of Sao Paulo, Brazil, two of the world's leading soccer teams, thrilled an overflow crowd of 23,000 last night as they fought to a 1-1 tie at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. The gathering was the largest in the history of the stadium.
The stock market regained its equilibrium yesterday to end a week of stunning losses on an encouraging note.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Dr. Edwin H. Land of Cambridge, Mass., will be honored at a Washington Conference next Thursday as a noted inventor, educator, scientist and business executive.
CHICAGO, June 11 -- At least 225 civil rights demonstrators were arrested today when they staged a sitdown during a march on City Hall.
DONGXOAI, South Vietnam, June 11 -- Nearly all the elements of the grim frontless war in South Vietnam were concentrated today in the area of this shattered little crossroads town.
In recent months you have published several editorials strongly attacking the Democrats controlling the Albany Legislature for their inept handling of state reapportionment.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Gordie Coleman's two-run homer in the ninth was the second hit of the day for the National League's top batter and lifted the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 11 -- Brandeis University opened weekend festivities marking its 14th commencement today by dedicating a $3.5 million theater arts center.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Representative Wright Patman of Texas does not want to hold Congressional hearings on the current state of the national economy, the stock market and other matters, but two leading Republicans have decided to press for a full public examination.

MILAN, Italy, June 11 -- Those interested in buying pieces of the "treasure of Fidel Castro" were warned today that "every possible legal action" would be taken to recover "from the buyers" these objects held to have been "illegally taken" from their legitimate owners.
Sir Robert Menzies, Australia's Prime Minister, said here yesterday that his country would be an active "junior partner" of the United States in Vietnam operations.
DENVER, June 11 (AP) -- The production of oil from shale in a test plant in western Colorado by a private concern may begin in July.

THE parent who panics at the thought of planning a child's birthday party night investigate the wealth of services in Manhattan and nearby areas. The list runs from an inexpensive boat trip to a new foreign restaurant that caters to children's parties to home entertainment by pixies or clowns.
Day-long negotiations aimed at averting a nationwide maritime strike next Tuesday ended late yesterday with both sides agreeing that no progress had been made.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The nation's money supply -- demand deposits and currency -- dropped by $1.2 billion in May and was about at the same level as it was at the end of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Eight young women broke a tradition of 140 years today by becoming the first of their sex to graduate from Jefferson Medical College.

Just about every politician who calls himself a Democrat spent long hours yesterday trying to decide who was the strongest candidate to oppose Republican Representative John V. Lindsay, now that Mayor Wagner has decided not to run for a fourth term.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 11 -- The field for next Thursday night's fourth edition of the Realization Trot at Roosevelt Raceway was reduced to five today with the withdrawal of Mrs. Lawrence B. Sheppard's Ayres.
Governor Rockefeller, pushing ahead with plans for a vast conservation program to beautify the Hudson River Valley, named 37 members yesterday to an advisory committee on the area.

The city effected curbs yesterday that will force the closing of a number of motel swimming pools as part of the continuing effort to conserve shrinking water supplies in metropolitan area reservoirs.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 11 -- Chile's recently announced plans to reach across seas to explore possible new markets for her copper -- even beyond the Iron Curtain -- is proving fruitful, it was indicated today.

STUTTGART, Germany, June 11 -- The attempted murder of a Yugoslav diplomat on Lake Censtance this week represented another encounter in a continuing blood feud between Croats and Serbs, police sources said today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate voted a $200 million reduction in the $3.44 billion foreign aid authorization bill today after having rejected several earlier attempts to make major cuts. The vote was 40 to 35.

PARIS, June 11 -- Four Republican Representatives arrived here today on a "fact-finding" mission sponsored by the House Republican Conference. The Congressmen are studying the issues that divide the United States and France in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley expressed concern today whether the nation was paying its military men enough.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission rejected today an atheist's demand for free broadcast time on 15 radio stations in Hawaii.
West Side civic groups lost their battle yesterday to save all of the High School of Commerce.

LAGOS, Nigeria, June 11 -- The Ministerial Council of the Organization of African Unity agreed today to set up a committee to reconcile differences between Ghana and the French-speaking African states that have threatened to boycott the organization's meeting in Accra.
The New York Philharmonic, Andre Kostelanetz conducting, with Laurel Hurley, soprano, and Carroll Glenn, violinist, will repeat last night's "Viennese Promenade" in Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30.

William Zeckendorf Jr. and Ronald A. Nicholson have resigned as president and executive vice president, respectively, of Webb Knapp, Inc. The company was thrown into a Chapter X bankruptcy reorganization last May 7.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 11 -- When Abram Leon Sachar raises money for Brandeis University, he tells prospects that he has an "edifice complex."

Further to our troubles in the Dominican Republic I think we should prepare ourselves for even more revolutions and bloodshed in Latin America and the possibility of seeing one or more of their countries go Communist.

Amid the concrete greenery, classroom windows and neighbor's kitchens and living rooms that surround a rectangular courtyard between West 11th and 12th Streets, the New School Summer Arts Festival '65 began last night.
LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- The Los Angeles Angels lost two arguments and one baseball game tonight and nearly lost their grip on sixth place to the New York Yankees.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 -- Eight American servicemen were killed today when their transport plane crashed in the mountains south of Pleiku.

The Hall of Presidents in the United States Pavilion at the World's Fair has evoked many comments from the hundreds of thousands of people who have seen the collection of Presidential memorabilia on display.
The first formal conversations ever undertaken by Roman Catholic and Lutheran theologians in this country will be held in Baltimore on July 6 and 7.
HAVANA, June 11 -- The share of Communist countries in Cuba's expanding foreign trade is shrinking, statistics made public by the Government showed today.

What's the future of Mayor Wagner's butler? And what will become of the Mayor's secretary, who once typed for Averell Harriman, and the Mayor's chauffeur, who used to lay asphalt, and the Mayor's barber, who got his political start by cutting Frank Hague's hair?

The ninth annual Wheelchair Games started yesterday at Bulova Park in Jackson Heights, Queens, with Steve Leatherman of the Pennsylvania D.Z.R. rolling a 360 for three games to win the stick bowling class.

John Gary, a slim, blond, boyishly handsome singer who describes himself as "a lyric baritone with a freakish range," has brought something to the Plaza Hotel's Persian Room that is not always found there.

The Fibreboard Paper Products Corporation in San Francisco, Calif., and the Yuba River Lumber Company, announced yesterday their purchase of the assets of the Pickering Lumber Corporation for more than $15 million cash.

PATERSON, N.J., June 11 -- Political and civic leaders here suggested today that there was a link between a Negro victory for control of the city's most powerful neighborhood Democratic organization and last July's racial demonstrations.
HOUSTON, June 11 -- President Johnson gave his heartiest congratulations to America's two Gemini 4 astronauts today, and recommended both for promotions.
The Foster Wheeler International Corporation, a subsidiary of the large producer of steam generating equipment, has announced the election of Charles E. McCulloch to the new post of president.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 -- A proposal that the Special Committee on Peace-keeping file a report with specific recommendations to the General Assembly by Tuesday was accepted today by Alex Quaison-Sackey of Ghana as chairman.

A $3 million issue of Budget Finance Plan 6 per cent subordinated capital income debentures due 2010 was offered to the public yesterday at 98 1/4, a price yielding 6.114 per cent, by underwriters led by Shearson, Hammill Co.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, refused to disqualify himself today from a steamship rate case now being reviewed by his regulatory agency.
CANTON, China -- After two months in Communist China, one finds his memory becoming a disjointed record of things seen and heard.
PARIS -- The United States has offered to cut its tariffs on chemicals as much as the law allows, according to responsible sources. But Europe is asking for more.

It was just 12 days ago -- although it must seem an eternity to many a stock-market follower -- that Federal Reserve Board Chairman William McChesney Martin Jr. noted "disquieting similarities" between the economic conditions of today and the nineteen-twenties.
The Waterfront Commission rushed a 13-page memorandum to members of the State Assembly last night urging them to reject a bill that would strip the agency of its policing powers over longshoremen.
More than 300 expectant mothers in the South Bronx paraded yesterday in front of St. Francis Hospital at 525 East 142d Street to protest its closing, announced for the end of this month.

If they carry out a threat, a group of Roman Catholics from the Greenpoint-Williamsburg district of Brooklyn will picket the Vatican Pavilion at the World's Fair tomorrow to protest against the decision of their Bishop to close St. Catherine's Hospital.

PARIS, June 11 -- American and other allied diplomats in Paris are looking to this weekend's meeting between President de Gaulle and Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany as a critical point for the future of the North Atlantic alliance.
CHICAGO, June 11 (UPI) -- Sue Maxwell scored the only sub-par round of the day, a one-under 72, today to take the 36-hole lead in the women's Western Open championship with a total of 145 strokes.
One of the world's top-ranking Eastern Orthodox theologians will mark the 25th anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood on Monday.
The Ampex Corporation achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fiscal year ended May 1.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 -- The Coast Guard's beautiful white square rigger, the Eagle, put to sea here today on her annual cadet cruise.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Republican National Finance Committee, which has been without a chairman since last November, is about to lose its top professional staff member.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, June 11 (UPI) -- Clive Clark, a 19-year-old architectural student, upset Bill Hyndman of Philadelphia in the quarter-finals of the British Amateur golf championship today and went on to gain a berth in tomorrow's all-English final against Mike Bonallack, a former titleholder.
BRUSSELS -- Confronted with a growing shortage of conventional sources of energy, the Common Market will place reliance on the atom in meeting increased power demands in the future.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Army Stephen Ailes has been summoned by Congressional investigators to testify about his stockholdings in a finance company criticized for its dealings with military personnel.

TOKYO, June 11 -- Tighter control over Japan's securities companies is to be exercised by the Finance Ministry under a system of licensing and registration established by recent revisions of the securities and exchange law.
DETROIT, June 11 (UPI) -- The auto industry will build 207,398 cars this week, compared with 168,203 last week and 179,821 in the same period a year ago, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 11 -- President Sukarno angrily denounced India today for her decision to work for the participation of Malaysia in the forthcoming African-Asian conference in Algiers.
Two Soviet officials ventured into a New York citadel of capitalism yesterday-and indicated that they would like an expanded interchange of technology with Western private enterprise.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The American Medical Association today charged the National Council of Senior Citizens with duplicity in pleading poverty to obtain free time on a national television network to answer a paid program by the A.M.A.
A jury with three alternates was completed yesterday for the trial of Gareth Martinis, 25-year-old son of Acting Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Martinis, yesterday.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 11 -- The United States is weighing the political effects on the Dominican cirisis of helping the junta regime meet the June payroll for the military, police and civil service.
The appointment of Jack R. Anderson as controller has been announced by the McCall Corporation.
CLEVELAND, June 11 -- Tommy Aaron, too ill to play golf last Tuesday, scored a 67 today and assumed the 36-hole lead in the $125,000 Cleveland open.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (UPI) -- Johnny Callison hit an inside the park home run with two out in the 10th inning tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-5 victory over the Houston Astros.
Representative John V. Lindsay suggested yesterday that leaders of minority groups be allowed to participate in the "decision-making process" at City Hall.

CAIRO, June 11 -- Informed sources said today that President Johnson was expected to sign in the next few days the authorization measure for the release of $37 million worth of long-delayed United States surplus food shipments to the United Arab Republic.
BRISTOL, England, June 11, (AP) -- Three Americans are among the four finalists who will play tomorrow for the men's and women's singles titles in the West of England tennis tournament.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Stockholders of Armour Co. approved today acquisition of the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation, a Philadelphia-based manufacturer of heavy equipment.
The unexpected happened yesterday at the annual meeting of the Blackstone Cigar Company. A top union official lauded the concern's sales efforts and the cooperation it receives from management.
American aid dollars are desperately needed in the underdeveloped world, but they are not rainmakers that will dissolve political barriers.
SURABAYA, Indonesia -- Somehow, in a nation of economic chaos and frenzied politics, Surabaya has managed to survive as a pleasant and slightly cosmopolitan city.

KANSAS CITY, June 11 (AP) -- Jim Landis hit his first homer of the season and Rollie Sheldon gained his first victory in a Kansas City uniform as the Athletics defeated the Cleveland Indians tonight, 5-2.
Haryou-Act got help yesterday from the voice and presence of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in announcing its $2,130,000 summer emergency program against poverty and delinquency in Harlem.
Eugene Ferkauf, who founded E.J. Korvette, Inc., with one small store in 1948 and saw it grow to a $725-million-a-year discount chain, assumed the company's presidency yesterday.

A book by Constance McLaughlin Green which Harper Row will issue next Wednesday, called "The Rise of Urban America," tells of the economic, political and social forces that influence urban expansion. Mhs. Green discusses the influence of city life on art and architecture and such present-day problems as race relations, population explosion and automation.
Recent events in the California Legislature underscore the need for prompt, imaginative action by the Federal Government toward establishing a worthy Redwood National Park.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) -- Don Buford hit a 10th-inning home run tonight to give the Chicago White Sox a 5-4 victory in the second game and a sweep of a double-header with the Washington Senators.
Following are excerpts from the news conference in Houston yesterday of Majs. James A. McDivitt and Edward H. White 2d, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 -- The Secretary General U Thant, cautioned today that enlargement of the United Nations role in the Dominican Republic would present some difficulties.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Johnson and the National Security Council heard a report today from Ambassador Maxwell D. Taylor about what he said would be "hard fighting" in South Vietnam in the months ahead.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 12 -- The generals of South Vietnam have once again taken power from the civilians by removing Premier Phan Huy Quat and Chief of State Phan Khac Suu.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The sponsors of last month's national teach-in on Vietnam said today that McGeorge Bundy had agreed to discuss the war with some of his academic critics over television this month.
BOSTON, June 11 (UPI) -- John Orsino's two-run homer in the fourth inning paced the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

PASADENA, Calif., June 11 -- Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, called today for a major overhaul of the nation's election procedures to bring them into step with a swift-moving, mobile society.
LONDON, June 11 -- The speaker, a stocky assistant professor of political science, gestured toward the audience of 1,000 students jammed into a cafeteria at University College, London.

A copy of an anthology of poetry and prose written by city junior high school pupils in memory of President John F. Kennedy was presented yesterday to a representative of the Kennedy family for the memorial library to be built at Harvard University.

NEW HAVEN, June 11 -- Three North Haven youths who assertedly molested a family because they believed the father was a Negro married to a white woman, were given suspended sentences and placed on probation today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 11 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana was accused in the Senate here today of causing division among the East African countries which widened yesterday with the disintegration of the East African Currency Board of Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania.
LONDON, June 11 -- Britain has informally suggested to the United States that it eliminate its levies on imported ears once the success of the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations is assured.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 11 -- A United States Attorney dismissed a bootlegging charge against a Providence woman today because he said her right to a fair trial had been prejudiced by a television broadcast of motion picture of her arrest.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 11 -- Duane Earl Pope, 22-year-old Kansas farm boy wanted in the killing of three bank officials during a holdup, was arrested today at the State Hotel in the downtown district.
LONDON, June 11 -- An overflow crowd packed Royal Albert Hall tonight for London's first "International Poetry Incarnation."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 -- A proposal for a world disarmament conference that would include Communist China was approved today by a vote of 89 to 0 in the 114-member Disarmament Commission.

NEWARK, June 11 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge set aside today a life imprisonment sentence imposed 45 years ago on ground that the defendant did not have proper legal counsel.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 11 -- Republican Governors expect to swing into action through a Washington office by midsummer in preparation for a campaign to elect more Republican Governors in 1966.
BONN, June 11 -- President de Gaulle and Chancellor Ludwig Erhard met privately for two hours today to discuss the issues dividing France and West Germany.

ORLANDO, Fla., June 11 (UPI) -- The leader of a militant anti-Castro organization and three other Cuban exiles were held by the Federal authorities today on charges of possessing 18 aerial bombs. Two Americans were also arrested.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- High Cuban Government officials are actively plotting to overthrow the regime of Premier Fidel Castro, his younger sister told a House subcommittee today.

TEN bushels of steamers, four bushels of littlenecks, 250 lobsters, 125 split broilers, 19 dozen ears of corn, one bushel of sweet potatoes, four dozen lemons and 25 pounds of butter headed Mark Donahue's marketing list recently.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Dr. Samuel A. Stratton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, told a commencement audience today that unbridled behavior in the name of individual liberty could lead only to an "ultimately chaotic and disorganized society."
BUDAPEST, June 11 (Reuters) -- Josef Cardinal Mindzenty, Primate of Hungary, saw Franz Cardinal Konig, Archbishop of Vienna, for 90 minutes in the United States Legation here today.

Stockholders of Gorton's of Gloucester, the nation's oldest seafood company, voted at the annual meeting in Gloucester, Mass., to change the name to the Gorton Corporation. E. Robert Kinney, president, said the new name would reflect more precisely the diversified activities of the company.
MEXICO CITY, June 11 (UPI) -- Mexico's National Foreign Trade Bank reported today that Cuba's foreign trade in the first nine months of 1964 was 39 per cent higher than the same period in 1963.

Baseball's largest crowd of 1965 -- 55,023 paid -- sat in on a stirring diamond drama last night at Shea Stadium. And whatever the loyalties of the onlookers, no one in the packed house with a jot of sentiment could have been happy deep down inside over the outcome.

MANNHEIM, Germany, June 11 (UPI) -- A West German physician who contracted smallpox in Ceylon was found guilty of negligent homicide today in the death of two persons in an outbreak of the disease after his return.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Virginia police have seized a cache of dynamite in woodlands 20 miles from Washington, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today it was at the site of a training camp run by the secret, armed organization called Minutemen.

Directors of the H.J. Heinz Company increased the quarterly dividend on common stock with a declaration of 30 cents a share. It is payable July 10 to holders of record June 21. In previous quarters shareholders had received 25 cents a share.

In Sligo the gull's cry is strident. The visitor is aware of it on waking and insistently through the day, as William Butler Yeats must have been, during his boyhood wanderings near the Sligo quays, along the Channel bogs to Rosses Point and the sea.
ALBANY, June 11 -- The State University has approved a 570-acre tract in Nassau County -- known as the Clark Estate -- as the site of a new four-year college of arts and sciences.

MANY of New York's older bridge players will remember the vigorous personality of George Beynon, who died in St. Petersburg, Fal., on Thursday at the age of 100. He was not only the oldest working bridge journalist in the United States, but perhaps also the oldest active newspaperman.

ALTHOUGH the art season continues diminuendo, a few late shows invite attention. Largest and most baffling of these is the private collection of Mrs. Frederick C. Havemeyer on view at Galerie Achard de Souza, 783 Madison Avenue at 66th Street.
The British pound moved ahead slightly in quiet trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
OTTAWA, June 11 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri of India and Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson of Canada held "friendly and frank" discussions today on Vietnam and other world problems.
Governor Rockefeller took steps yesterday to open the state civil service system to mentally retarded youths and adults.

I have become increasingly concerned about proposals by our State Department that the United States completely disarm and disband its military forces in favor of a United Nations military force. According to State Department Publication No. 7277 [Freedom From War: The United States Program for General and Complete Disarmament in a Peaceful World], the only military force we should retain would be a token force to maintain internal peace.
HOUSTON, June 11 -- The Gemini 4 astronauts made it clear today that man has solved the problem of mere survival in space and is now learning how to live and work there.

Films of Maj. Edward H. White 2d floating in space will be televised again tomorrow on two networks. The programs also will offer an evaluation of what the two-man Gemini 4 flight contributed toward the Apollo project to place a man on the moon.
SANDERSON, Tex., June 11 (UPI) -- A 15-foot wall of water struck this southwest Texas town without warning early today during a cloudburst, spreading death and destruction.
PARIS, June 11 -- For the second time in a year the French school system was thrown into turmoil today by revelations of leaks of questions for the vital baccalaureate examination.
Liberal party leaders began their search yesterday for a candidate for Mayor who could restore their party to its former balance-of-power role. That candidate could be John V. Lindsay.

With the strongest performances expected in the 880-yard run and the hammer throw, the 75th annual Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior outdoor track and field championships will be staged today at War Memorial Park in Yonkers.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Justice Department filed suit today against the Hat Corporation of America, the nation's largest manufacturer of men's hats, seeking to require it to divest itself of Style Park Hats, Inc., formerly the eighth largest.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced one-tenth of 1 per cent to 1025 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended June 8, Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., June 9 -- Southern Florida's six-month rainy season began with gushers this week and brought a joyful noise from conservationists in drought-parched Everglades National Park.
The bond market closed the week yesterday with a sprinkling of gains, but trading activity was especially light as both corporate and municipal bond traders took the day off for annual outings.
Two REA Express employes fired eight shots at bandits in two cars early yesterday after preventing a $45,000 holdup, the police reported.
A theory that optical illusions can be a deadly trap for pilots whose planes are heading toward each other at night will be studied in flight tests later this month by the Federal Aviation Agency.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 11 -- Three men were burned to death and 19 persons were injured early this morning when a fire quickly destroyed most of a sprawling frame hotel here.

BECKENHAM, England, June 11, (AP) -- Maria Bueno of Brazil, the No. 1 seeded player, easily defeated Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., 6-2, 6-0, today and reached the women's final of the Kent tennis championships.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (UPI) -- Felipe Alou's seventh-inning homer with two pinch-hitters, Mike de la Hoz and Ty Clinett on base, broke a 2-all tie tonight and powered the Milwaukee Braves to a 8-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 11 -- A luncheon for Vice President Humphrey was quickly shifted from a fashionable country club here to a private home after the Vice President learned the club was "restricted."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- White House officials and top Democratic party leaders ruled out today the possibility of any early intervention in the choice of the Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11 -- The 28th annual Off Soundings Club spring races started in two-day run today off NewI London Harbor as John H.! Boyd's Rhodes design fiber[ glass bounty, Southern Cross,, captured the 25.41-rniles Class! A-1 race.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 11 -- Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said tonight that the United States must be prepared to continue to resist a Communist take-over in Vietnam.
Bronx County Medical Society deplores the announced closing of St. Francis Hospital on the recommendation of the Hospital Review and Planning Council of Southern New York.
ALBANY, June 11 -- Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki said today that he would push for a statewide referendum next month so that there could be a constitutional convention next spring.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 (AP) -- Jim Pagliaroni hit a two-run homer and Frank Carpin turned in a two-hit relief performance for four innings tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-3, for their seventh straight victory and 19th in 21 games.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 11 (AP) -- The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill that would block the Justice Department from bringing an anti-trust suit against a bank merger long after it has been carried out. The measure now goes to the House.

DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- The American League-leading Minnesota Twins swept a double-header from Detroit in extra innings tonight, winning the opener, 5-4, in the 10th on Jimmie Hall's sacrifice fly and taking the second game by the same score on a triple by Hall that capped a three-run 12th.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Congressmen were urged today to support bills proposing the creation of a national memorial to former President Herbert Hoover at his birthplace in West Branch, Iowa.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Job Corps center at nearby Catoctin, Md., has lost more than 40 per cent of its enrollment.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 11 -- Leading international lending institutions have suspended consideration of further advances to Colombia pending some effort by the Government here to tackle its mounting fiscal woes.
The struggle for a socially responsible tax policy has scored an unexpected victory in the Senate Finance Committee.

Communist China's foreign moves naturally arouse more interest in the world than its domestic programs, which impinge on others less directly. The voyage of a single Peking official to Africa often can attract more attention than reforms that determine how 700 million Chinese live and think. Yet the requirements and thought-processes of China at home ultimately may affect the world far more profoundly than any current Peking probe abroad.
The biggest pop art painting in the world, James Rosenquist's 85-foot "F-111," is on display at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street.

LONDON, June 11 -- The Beatles have crossed the last social barrier. Queen Elizabeth included them tonight in her birthday honors list. The four young men with the odd haircuts were named members of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- A State Department diplomatic courier testified today that he had paid $760 for 16 ampules of Krebiozen for his father, who had cancer.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 12 -- Highfield's Tulip, the defending national champion, owned and ridden by Susan Blaisdell of Red Bank, N.J., won the large-pony title today after a hackoff in the Helping Hand horse show.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 12 (Reuters) -- Ethiopian and Somali troops clashed near the border last night, the Ethiopian Ministry of Information announced today.

AMARILLO, Tex. -- The yawning abyss of Palo Duro Canyon, in Palo Duro Canyon State Park southeast of here, will be lighted by a son-et-lumiere Old West production this summer. From Thursday through Sept. 6, "Thundering Sounds of the West" will be performed nightly, except Tuesdays, in the Canyon Pioneer Amphitheater.

SYDNEY, Australia -- Escorted tours of New Guinea are proving increasingly popular with both Australians and visitors from overseas. The 16-day trips are operated by Australia's two major airlines, Trans-Australia and Ansett-A.N.A.

MIAMI BEACH -- "See and take a plunge in the magnificent new $10,000 tile pool, equal to and unsurpassed by any swimming pool on the Atlantic Coast. Strictly sanitary." So read an advertisement in The Miami Herald on Sunday, June 13, 1915.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 12 -- Malcolm M. Kilduff, who made the first official announcement to the world that John F. Kennedy had been assassinated, resigned today as assistant White House press secretary.

In a few months, the Mondadori printing presses of Verona will begin turning out a series of paperbacks in seven languages, the final step in an unusual and interesting project on the part of an international group of publishers. The books will be the first five volumes of the World University Library, a series which will run to 100 volumes aimed at the freshman-sophomore college student the world over, as well as the general reader.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 12 -- A large-scale currency reform is expected here July 1. According to informed sources it will devalue the dinar from the present rate of 750 to the dollar down to 1,200 to the dollar.

LONDON, June 12 (UPI) -- Britons reacted today with laughter, astonishment and outright anger to the selection of the Beatles in Queen Elizabeth's honors list as Members of the Order of the British Empire.

The discovery of a "major new constituent of the universe" was reported yesterday by the Mount Wilson and Palomar Observatories in California. BIJOU, Calif. -- From high in the air, Lake Tahoe looks like a serene, azure jewel in a forest-green setting, the high reaches of the Sierra Nevada, rather than the subtle battlefield of a struggle with import for the entire nation.

Congress is moving toward debate and probable passage of Federal aid to higher education. Two identical bills (H.R. 3220 and S. 600 in House and Senate respectively) are currently going through the committee hearing process.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 12 -- Thirteen villages will hold elections in Nassau County on Tuesday, although there is a contest in only one, Atlantic Beach.
WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Don Lock blasted a grand-slam home run and Bennie Daniels pitched a five-hitter today in leading the Washington Senators to a 7-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- This state has 2,500 miles of coastline, hundreds of offshore islands, countless lakes, scores of rivers and streams, mountains, vast forests and even a desert -- small, but worthy of the name.
The stock and bond markets, after months of smooth sailing, hit an area of turbulence in early May and have found the going rough ever since.

What started three months ago as a grand jury inquiry into the alleged rigging of bids on painting contracts of the City Housing Authority has grown into a broad investigation involving seven public agencies.

PARIS, June 12 -- Having discovered virtue in the maxim that in union there is strength, a number of French political parties and groups on the left and center began negotiating this week to see how closely they could draw together against President de Gaulle.

BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK, Tex. -- Take a stretch of high desert the size of Rhode Island, add a cluster of mountains, sprinkle with wildlife, ghost towns, lost mines and artifacts of prehistoric, Indian, Spanish, Mexican and American settlers and invaders, border with a river that twists through cliffs a quarter of a mile high, and then top it all with endless sky.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will hold hearings to review United States actions in the Dominican Republic and possibly to suggest guidelines for action in any similar situations in the future.
CHICAGO, June 12 (UPI) -- Mrs. Marlene Hagge shot a one-under-par 72 today and took a two-stroke lead after 54 holes of the women's Western open golf tournament with a total of 219.

THE swarming New York art scene is a mixed boon to some dealers, who've been known to complain that the mobs who visit them don't do very much but rough up the parquet floors. Now Edith Halpert, director of the famed Downtown Gallery and long a Presence on the scene, has decided to remove herself to where the traffic isn't.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa. -- The Poconos, long a retreat for vacationists eager for a nice and easy pace, are about to welcome two attractions that will provide a much faster tempo. Scheduled to open this summer are two race tracks, both within convenient driving distance of resort centers such as Stroudsburg, Mount Pocono and Lake Harmony.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 12 -- The vast Congo territory, emerging from a year-long civil war, now faces at least three years of mopping up among roaming bands of outlaws.

IN his incisive critique of what he calls the "new radical" intelligentsia, Christopher Lasch argues that, before the turn of the century, intellectuals did not constitute a "subculture" or think of themselves as a "beleaguered minority." They formed, at least in their own eyes, a part of the middle class and were hardly conscious of being intellectuals at all.
Space research is continually refining man's knowledge of the shape of the earth and, in the process, is destroying the layman's concept of our planet as a uniformly round ball.
The Port of New York has registered increases during the first five months of this year in collections of duties on imports by sea and air and in travel, compared with 1964.

THE heroism of his fellow Leningraders in withstanding the terrific Nazi onslaught of 1941 is generally reckoned as the direct impetus for Shostakovich's creation of his Seventh Symphony, which is dedicated to his city and has come to be known as the "Leningrad" Symphony.

Two European orchestras and three conductors will make their New York debuts in Carnegie Hall's third annual International Festival of Visiting Orchestras next season. One of the orchestras is the Czech Philharmonic, which will bring with it two of the new conductors, Karel Ancerl and Vaclav Neumann.

Bellerive, the site of the 65th National Open golf championship this week, is a heavyweight course and it will take a heavyweight, such as Jack Nicklaus, to win the title, the man who fashioned the course has predicted.

" THINGS fall apart; the centre cannot hold," Yeats wrote in 1920; "Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world." Yet no poet of the 20th century worked more diligently to hold things together, struggled more resolutely against the growing anarchy of his times and ours.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 12 -- Navy's victory-starved crew outrowed Wisconsin in a mile and three-quarter duel off the banks of the Severn River today for their first victory of the season.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 12 -- Finance Minister James Gichuru has delivered a blistering attack in the Senate against Communist China for activities ranging from shipping arms under cover through Kenya to keeping a network of agents in the country on Chinese payroll.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 12 -- This suburban city of 20,000 will vote Tuesday on whether to join the growing number of communities switching to "middle schools."
Woman's voice at Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston: "Now have a drink of water."

ROLLENE SAAL asks, "Who reads Kahlil Gibran's "The Prophet' these days?" (May 16). When I was in Europe this winter I had a copy of "The Prophet" with me. In every city visited I was constantly approached by people who had read the book.

THE exploits of the Spanish conquistadors are not always considered proper fare for children's books: the truth about them is too harsh, too cruel, too immoral. Maia Wojciechowska, whose "Shadow of a Bull" won the 1964 John Newbery medal, faces the facts squarely in her brief, vigorous biography of the man who first explored much of the area that became the southern United States and who later served as Spanish Governor of Paraguay.

The advances in space exploration are breathtaking and exciting -- man has entered an entirely new era. This can be compared to evolution, when the fish first grew legs to leave his medium, the sea, and adapt himself to the terrestrial environment.

SPRINGFIELD, Vt. -- People like to talk about the Crown Point Road, for it combines a segment of authentic and colorful Colonial history with a sense of adventure. And there is just enough about it that is still unknown to make research into the road's history interesting to local residents, as well as visitors from far away.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- At times like this it may be helpful to cast a long look backward to see if the world has really gotten worse. Take it back twelve years to the time when this year's high school graduating class first toddled off to school holding mother's hand.
P O-Orient Lines, Britain's largest and oldest passenger steamship company, last week announced the establishment of its own sales organization in major North American cities.

HARTFORD, June 12 -- Voters will go to the polls in Connecticut on Tuesday to elect 84 delegates to a Constitutional Convention starting on July 1. It is the third such convention in the state's history.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- The Soviet Union asserted its claim today to form and lead an ad hoc front of Communists and nonaligned nations in opposition to United States policy in Vietnam and the Dominican Republic.

THE other day Lucie Bigelow Rosen was asked by a friend if she was planning to make a speech when the Caramoor Festival opened on Saturday night. The festival was 20 years old; a speech would be appropriate.

A Roman Catholic priest writing in the current issue of The National Catholic Reporter has urged Pope Paul VI and the Vatican Council "not to sweep the whole issue of clerical celibacy under the rug, but acknowledge the basic human right of the individual priest to marry."

THIRTY-FIVE New York area residents will be among the graduates of two-year courses at the New York Botanical Garden. Nine have completed courses in botany, 11 in landscape gardening and 15 in gardening.
South Africa and France gained places in the European Zone semi-finals of the Davis Cup competition yesterday.
The 11th annual session of the Frank C. Munson Memorial Institute of American Maritime History will begin on June 28 at Mystic Seaport in Mystic, Conn.

A British concern that has accounted for more than half of the world's marine radar sets afloat will attempt to extend its penetration of the American market tomorrow when it puts on display here 20 of its newly developed fully transistorized Transar sets.

MEXICO CITY -- The John F. Kennedy Project, which was opened here recently, is perhaps one of the most absorbing housing ventures in Latin America. Its 94 buildings, housing 3,104 apartments for graphic arts workers, have filled in another gap in this capital's skyline.

TOKYO, June 12 -- An oceanographic survey project, expected to be the largest ever undertaken, will start this month to resolve some of the mysteries about the flow of the kuroshio -- the black current, also called the Japan Current -- through the North Pacific.

An Atlanta restaurant, advertising to New Yorkers in big black letters "all the water you can drink without request," brings home to them that, thanks to the drought, they must order water even when they aren't drinking bourbon.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 12 -- A Norwegian bulk carrier and a Cuban freighter that collided last night at sea off the Pacific entrance to the Panama Canal were tied up at the Balboa piers today after being brought here by canal tugs.

Poetry is poetry regardless of the poet, whose sex should be of minor importance. Nevertheless, one might wish the fine poet Louis Simpson would not make absolute statements to the effect that "there have been no great modern women poets."
LOS ANGELES, June 12 (UPI) -- Homer Brennum of Dal-Dallas set a meet record in the national Amateur Athletic Union weight-lifting championships today by lifting 820 pounds in the 148-pound division.

Mason and Knights of Columbus will "meet and visit together in the spirit of friendship and mutual understanding" at the World's Fair on July 24. Spokesmen for both organizations, said such an event could not have happened five years ago.

THE problem that haunts contemporary culture is not, as is generally assumed, alienation. It is its parent: nihilism. This is nowhere more clearly seen than in the art that dominates the currently fashionable avant-garde scene. William Burroughs's splintered prose about a splintered humanity, Andy Warhol's bland, anti-judgmental representations, the aleatoric (chance) music of John Cage -- the aim hero is not to expand, extend or even transform: the aim is to destroy.

A GENTLE blind girl of 17 sits on a park bench with her first real friend, a night rewrite man on a newspaper. Her mother has just told her this man is a Negro. "I've been told about your kind," the girl says to the man. "
DURHAM, N.C., June 12--Duke University will begin a three-year campaign in September to raise $102.8 million, believed to be the largest monetary goal ever set by a Southern school.
LONDON -- Although none of Britain's basic economic problems have been solved by the eight-month-old Labor Government, the pound sterling will probably continue to be worth $2.80 for some time.
A 6-year-old girl was killed and her mother and three other children were seriously injured yesterday when they were struck by a car in a parking lot in Rockaway Beach, Queens.
BOSTON, June 12 -June weather that has gladdened the hearts of brides and college seniors presages a long, dry summer for suburbanites in the Northeast.
COLORADO SPRINGS -- A group of conservatives will gather at a woodsy Freedom School near here next month to frame what they believe will be a better Federal Constitution.

FOR THIS WEEK: Order fresh perennial seed for planting later this month. . . . Pinch back chrysanthemum plants to make them branch. . . . Examine edges of brown grass for chinch bug; if present, control with Sevin or diazinon. . . . Avoid excess cultivation which encourages evaporation of soil moisture; use. mulches.

The office of the Mayor of New York has been called the biggest elective job in the country after the Presidency. The Mayor is at once the chief executive, chief legislator, leading ceremonial figure and chief crisis-handler and man-to-blame of a polyglot city of 8 million bursting with social, economic and administrative problems.

Mr. Horwitz paid but scant attention to the problems of the aged in the upper-income brackets. Money helps, of course, but it isn't everything. The problems of old age beset both rich and poor alike. The ability to pay does not obviate the need for help.
MASSAPEQUA, L.I., June 12 -- This community's new $380,000 library building at Bar Harbour will be dedicated tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, B.W.I. -- There is a forbidding and barren, yet scenically stimulating, area in the northeastern part of this small island that the many tourists who vacation here seldom see. It is known as the Scotland District.

MILL RUN, Pa. -- In a bucolic Appalachian Mountain glen about five miles south of this tiny town stands a 27-year-old concrete house that is rapidly becoming one of the outstanding tourist attractions in Pennsylvania.
