AMHERST, Mass., June 12 -- The University of Massachusetts board of trustees, in a surprise move yesterday, selected Worcester as the site of the university medical school.

WATERLOO, Belgium -- On Friday, some 300,000 pilgrims, primarily British, are expected to overrun this battlefield near Brussels. Here, on June 18, 1815, the French Empire was dealt its final death blow, the future course of European history was set, Napoleon "met his Waterloo" and a colloquialism indicating total defeat entered the English language.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The vanguard of the summer vacationists has already arrived on Florida's west coast and, judging by its size, which is large, the summer season may turn out to be a record-breaking one.

HONG KONG, June 12 -- Thousands of persons, young and old, have been plunging into China's lakes and rivers in response to a Government campaign to promote swimming.

GREENFIELD PARK, N.Y. -- Members of the Greenfield Park Historical Association, anxious to preserve some of the old buildings that once played a prominent role in the everyday life of this vacation-oriented portion of Ulster County, plan to show the fruit of their labors on the afternoon of June 27.

JEAN LEE LATHAM makes Sam Houston a believable and very human hero. Tallest of the Texans, Old Sam remains Texas's most colorful figure. But his career had national significance, touching the fate of the Indians in the nation, the Mexican War that added our southwest quarter to the union, the Civil War and, of course, the evolution of Texas from Mexican province to independent republic to American statehood.

PRETTY, prickly-tempered Zeee, the tiny, bumblebee-sized fairy who dwells in Elizabeth Enright's tale, sparkles with personality. Zeee loathes people since they can't see her and inadvertently ruin her homes -- the pagoda tent of dock leaves, the summer beach cottage of a sand-pail, the silver pear of a deserted wasps' nest.

THE dignity and simplicity of some Missouri hillfolk are well portrayed in Mrs. Draper's story of a 12-year-old orphan boy setting out on the road to maturity. Young Punk Bunn feels sorry for himself because his sober, Bible-reading step-granny is (he thinks) too demanding and unloving.
GREENPORT, L.I., June 12 -- Light airs spoiled the final day of the annual Off Soundings Club two-day regatta today. Only three of the six cruising and racing classes finished.

BRIDGE tournaments continue to grow in size, and the Eastern Regional Championships, which ended a few days ago, were no exception. The total of 4,271 tables in play during 10 days set a record for any regional championship outside California.
PARIS, June 12 -- The boxing season is all but over in Paris, deferring for still another summer the answer to the French sports fans' most burning question: Is the kid as good as his father?

ROME, June 12 -- Italian political interest focused tonight on Sardinia, where weekend regional elections will give a measure of the popularity and staying power of the nation's ruling center-left coalition.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Charles H. Percy, faced with more than a normal share of political conundrums, has turned to social welfare work as a means of staying alive politically until he decides to run again.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 12 -- Florida has passed a law to restrain treasure hunters who seek gold and silver coins and priceless relics known to lie in the holds of sunken ships off the coasts.

STAMPS unusual in size, format and concept seem to be the order of the day. Such, for example, are two Israeli stamps to be issued on July 7. They herald the contribution that industries of the Dead Sea are making to the national economy, through the production of rock salt, sulphur and potash.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- The United States Olympic Committee approved today legislation bolstering the position of the Amateur Athletic Union in its dispute with the National Collegiate Athletic Association over control of national track teams.

KINGS PARK, L.I., June 12 -- The annual summer day fair of St. Johnland, a home for the aged, will be held there at Sunken Meadow Road on June 30. The home, founded in 1866, is the oldest of its kind on Long Island.

A DOUGHTY little Scottie handled by Johnny Murphy caused quite a stir at the Longshore-Southport dog show in 1962. A comparative unknown, she was named best of breed and then won the terrier group.

IN your issue of May 9 you published a review by William Kunstler of "A Man's Reach," an anthology of some of the writings of Judge Jerome Frank, edited by his daughter, Barbara Frank Kristine. The review quotes me, out of context, as authority for a criticism of Judge Frank which I neither share nor with which I agree.

Lloyd's Register of Shipping announced yesterday the appointment of William C.G. Knowles, vice chancellor of Hong Kong University, as executive director of the ship classification society. He will assume the post Jan. 1, 1966.

CAIRO, June 12 -- Prince Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of Malaysia, said at a news conference here today that he was ready to meet with President Sukarno of Indonesia "wherever he likes." He included the forthcoming African-Asian conference in Algiers among possible sites for talks aimed at a peaceful settlement of the Malaysian-Indonesian dispute.

READINGTON, N.J., June 12 -- Mrs. Michael Plumb, wife of the Olympic three-day rider, today won the open dressage championship at the Family Nursing Service horse show.

SUMMER is the time to root cuttings of choice shrubs. The new plants will be identical to the originals, except for sports which occur rarely. Shrub cuttings made at this season are known variously as semi-hardwood, half-hard, hardened greenwood and summerwood.

FERNANDINA BEACH, Fla. -- This northeast corner of Florida has great potential as a major tourist haven. Its assets include a long and interesting history and, perhaps more important, a superb natural setting.

SAN SALVADOR, June 7 -- The latest drive by Communist labor forces in El Salvador appears to have been dissipated before any of its basic objectives had been attained, but preoccupation with it lingers on.

ROME, June 12 -- Three greats of modern music -- Darius Milhaud, Francesco Malipiero and Igor Stravinsky -- shared a dais with Pope Paul VI today at a concert of their works on religious themes.

P. Morgan house, which would be demolished.

THIS Friday, in New Haven, Conn., several thousand adult males will forgather for an annual weekend of nostalgia. For some 300 or more of them, classmates of mine, with their wives and children, the occasion is expected to be particularly memorable -- our 25th reunion.

THE first day of summer is just a week away, and, happily, this means that three months of merrymaking and relaxation lie ahead for the vacationist. Nevertheless, the sobering old adage that says that summer will not last forever should be borne in mind; thus, no time should be wasted in planning holiday recreation and in making the most of this pleasant season.

Dore Schary, national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, charged yesterday that "guerrilla warfare" by the Ku Klux Klan had slowed compliance with desegregation laws in Southern rural areas.
Sargent Shriver, the director of the Peace Corps, proposed yesterday that an international education center be set up here to integrate foreign students into the American academic community.
A group of modern alchemists meet today through Thursday at the Statler Hilton Hotel at the International Powder Metallurgy Conference.

DURHAM, N.H., June 13 (UPI) -- Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, suggested today that any extension of the interest equalization tax be limited to one year, instead of two as proposed, beyond its scheduled expiration date of next Dec. 31.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company sent out last week its Relazioni e Bilancio to its Italian speaking stockholders and its Geschaftsbericht fur das Jahr to its German speaking stockholders.
Chief Justice Earl Warren has turned down a request by the Columbia Broadcasting System to televise proceedings before the United States Supreme Court.

The controversy is not over sending troops to protect and evacuate Americans, but over the role the United States played and is still playing in Dominican internal politics.

The largest crowd to watch the New York Mets at Shea Stadium, 58,220, turned into the noisiest when an umpire's decision went against the home team yesterday.

A bitter primary fight for the Manhattan Borough presidency seemed in prospect yesterday, as Harlem Democratic leaders met with the intention of designating someone other than Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, the incumbent.

The appointment of Hugo Weisgall as associate to the Lincoln Center Fund for Education and Creative Artistic Advancement was announced yesterday by Mark Schubart, vice president of Lincoln Center and executive director of the fund.

The passions and ardors of Revolutionary times, picturesquely phrased and faithfully collected, are reproduced in prolific amount in this vast book -- the first of a projected 15-to-20-volume shelf. Letters, broadsides, journals, dispatches, newspaper accounts and other documents reveal the physical and emotional crescendoes of a conflict that gave birth to a nation.

BRAMPTON, Ont., June 11 -- Earl K. Brownridge, president of American Motors (Canada), Ltd., raised the sights of Canadian automobile makers today with a forecast of a 4 per cent increase in 1965 industry sales to 630,000 cars.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 13 -- The absence of a Pulitzer Prize award in music for the last two years "has done harm to the cause of American music," according to William Schuman, president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts in New York.

LYNBROOK, L.I., June 13 -- The Rev. Christopher L. Webber, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, told worshipers here today that "winds of change" were moving in the Roman Catholic Church, but that "so far not much is blowing in that wind except some surface dust."

LAGOS, Nigeria, June 13 -- The Ministerial Council of the Organization of African Unity appealed today to its 36 members to do everything possible to insure the success of the heads-of-state meeting scheduled to take place at Accra in September.

LONDON, June 13 -- Igor Stravinsky contributed a new choral work and Henry Moore a huge sculpture. Andrei Vosnesensky recited in Russian, Peter O'Toole and Sir Laurence Olivier and Paul Scofield in English. Groucho Marx was himself.

AMHERST, Mass June 13 -- The 1,300 graduating students of the University of Massachusetts were urged today to invoke the strength of President Kennedy, to refuse to feel victimized or alienated, and never to join the bland who lead the bland.
BONN, June 13 -- France and West Germany are expected to show again in Brussels tomorrow that they remain at odds on how to advance the union of Europe.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 14 -- A battalion of United States paratroopers flew to an airstrip near Dongxoai yesterday and awaited orders that may send it into the biggest battle of the Vietnamese War.

The New York School of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, held its annual commencement exercises yesterday. Twelve members of the graduating class were ordained as rabbis and two graduates were invested as cantors.

Dr. Joachim Prinz, president of the American Jewish Congress, charged yesterday that the president of the German Restitution Court of Appeals in Bremen was a former Nazi.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Dr. Wernher von Braun, the German rocket scientist who is a leader in the United States effort to place a man on the moon, has quietly become one of the most outspoken spokesmen for racial moderation in the South.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has offered to acquire all of the assets of Hamilton Management Corporation through an exchange of stock, Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president of I.T., announced over the weekend.
HANOVER, N.H., June 13 -- Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall declared today that the United States led the world "in pollution and blight and despoilment."

Some 550 travel agents in six major metropolitan centers faced the loss of their accreditation to sell trans-Atlantic steamship passenger tickets next year.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The wholesale price index which began moving upward last fall after a long period of stability, continued to climb in May.

The regional shopping center came to Europe with a bang last year but the fireworks seem to be just beginning. Merchants in Europe and other parts of the world now realize, just as American retailers did a decade or so ago, the tremendous potential of the sales market outside the central cities.

Advertisers and their agencies have long bemoaned the harsh reality that 8 out of 10 new products fail. Even new products coming out of the top 50 companies, after test marketing, have a 60 per cent failure rate.

The Music Critics Circle of New York will not give its annual awards this year, Instead, a special citation has been voted to Charles Ives's Fourth Symphony "for its originality and genius." The Ives is ineligible for a regular award because it was written more than 25 years ago.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- Milt Pappas got credit for his first victory in almost a month with Stu Miller's ninth-inning relief help today as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Boston Red Sox. 1-0. A sacrifice fly in the fifth inning by John Orsino scored the run.
Ralph S. Arzoomanian of the State University of Iowa and Lillian Lipman of the University of Washington were named yesterday as the winners of the 13th annual National Collegiate Playwriting Contest.

WASHINGTON, June 14-The Treasury bill rate rose slightly at today's auction from last week's level, but remained sharply below the level that had prevailed earlier this year, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 14 -- Mike Krak of the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien, Conn., took some putting lessons from his colleague, Danny Galgano of Woodway C.C., also in Darien, over the weekend. As a result, Krak sank a 60-footer, a 40-footer and three-putted only one green in 36 holes to qualify today for the Professional Golfers' Association tournament during the metropolitan trials at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 14 (UPI) -- A scientist who shot a jet bomber carrying an atomic bomb because the plane disturbed his sleep was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $500 today by Federal Judge Cart Weinman.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A blue ribbon citizens committee has been organized to Work for the Administration's immigration reform bill.

The adjoining Victoria and Abbey Hotels on West 51st Street will be merged and operated as one by a group headed by George Geiger. The 600-room Victoria is on the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 51st Street, and the 450-room Abbey is just east, at 151 West 51st Street.
H.V. Kaltenborn, whose precise, clipped delivery of radio news was familiar to millions of Americans for 30 years, died here yesterday after a heart attack. He was 86 years old.

ALBANY, June 14 -- A bill that would all but repeal New York's 84-year-old law banning the sale or distribution of birth-control devices and information was approved overwhelmingly today by the Senate.
A program to help executives recognize and cope with their own and their employes' mental problems was announced here yesterday by the American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry.
BOSTON, June 14 (AP) -- A 34-year-old Boston woman whose blood has been pumped through the liver of a pig since Friday to keep her alive was described today as "unquestionably improved" by a doctor.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Air Force has embarked on a "golden rule" program aimed at improving the treatment of junior officers and enlisted men.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14 -- The United States is considering making a new disarmament overture to the Soviet Union. It would involve, on each side, the destruction of significant number of missile capable of delivering nuclear warheads.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- There is sufficient evidence of widespread apprehension in this country over recent military enforcements of United States foreign policy. Though neither public opinion polls nor the most advanced computers can determine the depth of this concern among the American people, the intensity with which it has been articulated in college circles suggests that there it runs deep.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 14 (AP) -- The Kansas City Star said yesterday a major troop movement from Fort Riley, Kan., appeared imminent.

Mrs. Beatrice M. Kaye, formerly with Charles H. Greenthal Co., real estate concern, has, been elected vice president of L.B. Kaye Associates, 667 Madison Avenue, brokers specializing in the sale of town houses.

The refusal by Commissioner of Marine and Aviation Leo Brown automatically to reinstate the 130 striking ferryboat engineers and mates to their posi tions was courageous and highly commendable. His decision to retain as regular employes the replacement engineers and mates is both honorable and within the letter and spirit of the law.

ROME. June 14 -- The newly elected Provost General of the Jesuits said today that it was necessary for the Roman Catholic Church to understand thoroughly the complexities of modern life in order to influence modern man.
A conspicuous but dingy building in Times Square will be remodeled to complement its sparkling neighbor, the 26-story white marble and glass Allied Chemical Tower.

ALBANY, June 14 -- The Senate voted today to authorize a state lottery similar to New Hampshire's, with the proceeds to be spent exclusively for education. The moral implications of the proposal were debated hotly for an hour and a half before it was approved by a vote of 35 to 18 and sent to an uncertain fate in the Assembly.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Rumors circulated in the Pentagon today that contingents of three Army divisions were being alerted for probable assignment to Vietnam. The divisions are the First Infantry, based at Fort Riley, Kan.; the 11th Airborne, at Fort Benning, Ga., and the 25th Infantry, at Schofield Barracks, Hawaii.
HAVANA, June 14 -- The Cuban Communist party set up its first full-fledged cell at Havana University in an apparent effort to tighten its control over students and teachers.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Carl T. Rowan, director of the United States Information Agency, testified today that its reporting of racial problems in the United States for overseas publication and broadcast tried to give a balanced picture.
The election of Dr. Thomas J. McLeer as vice president for research and development of the Vanadium Corporation of America was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Representative Ogden R. Reid, Republican of Westchester, proposed today a package of labor law revisions.
The Johnson, Administration soon will give active encouragement to private investment in developing nations, Assistant Secretary of Commerce Dr. Andrew F. Brimmer disclosed yesterday.
With television dramas now being filmed in Hollywood, Broadway actors are once again finding employment on radio, just as they did in the old days -- before television.
Yale Express System, Inc.'s senior creditors unanimously agreed yesterday that the beleagured trucking company's trustee should be permitted to sell $3 million in certificates of indebtedness.

The crisis in Colombia is deepening. Here in the United States little is seen or heard about Colombia's troubles. There is nothing sensational about the situation; there is no visible Communist threat; there is just a steady structural erosion that is bound to bring some form of collapse if it is not arrested fairly soon.

The skyrocketing cost of Blue Cross hospital insurance has been attributed by responsible officials largely to the uncontrolled increase in hospital costs. Until recently, anyone who could raise or borrow enough money was entitled to construct new hospital facilities without having to justify the public need for them. To correct and control this situation the Metcalf-McCloskey Act provided for review of proposed new hospital facilities by a state council and its affiliated regional agencies.

The Chicago North Western Railway, which for 106 years has been largely dependent on agricultural products and livestock traffic, has decided to supplement its carrier revenues by entering the chemical manufacturing field.
Botany Industries, Inc., a diversified operating and holding company, announced yesterday the appointment of Ralph D. Schneider as president of its retail division.
A go-between's version of how John P. Kennedy offered the Vice-Presidential nomination to Lyndon B. Johnson in 1960 and of Robert F. Kennedy's role in it was published by Life magazine yesterday.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation achieved the highest sales in its history in the fiscal year ended April 30. However, earnings dipped slightly, because of strikes and new mill opening costs, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Cheng Ting-chang used to sit up all night playing poker. This was before the Communist party showed him the folly of trying to draw to an inside straight. Now Cheng spends his spare time studying the works of Mao Tse-tung.
Eastern Air Lines, Inc., came under unusually heavy pressure yesterday, taking a 6 1/4-point loss on the New York Stock Exchange.

TORONTO, June 14 -- The Toronto Stock Exchange, under fire from two Government investigations, is instituting a major policy change. The exchange will downgrade the participation of brokers in administration and will strengthen the office of president.
MIAMI BEACH, June 14 -- Six Republican Ph.D's lectured a roomful of Young Republicans today on the danger of doctrinal orthodoxy to a political party's success.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 14 -- The young, left-wing radicals in the rebel camp mounted a rally today that outstripped in size and enthusiasm the anti-Communist demonstration in the opposing junta zone yesterday.

THE power push of the National Collegiate Athletic Association for control of amateur sports in this country was short-circuited with shocking abruptness over the weekend. A monkey wrench was tossed into Walter Byers's crunching steamroller by the neutral and knowledgeable United States Olympic Committee, forcing it to come to a grinding halt amid sparks of dismay and wails of despair.

Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots -- the union's largest local with a membership of 2,000 -- yesterday elected Joseph B. Gaier to serve as interim president until the end of the year.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 14 -- The state said today that inadequate relocation plans were delaying most urban-renewal projects in New York.
The blocks on 110th Street between Fifth and Eighth Avenues have been given a new name -- Central Park North.

Gimbels New York, which will acquire a rise in sales volume of 4 to 5 per cent when it takes over the three Saks-34th Street suburban stores, will also acquire an opportunity to evaluate new markets for stores.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14 -- Bill Bradley, Princeton's all-America basketball player and a Rhodes scholar received two awards and was named co-recipient with Cosmo Iacavazzi of a third today at the Senior Prize Exercises on Cannon Green.
VINCENT SHEEAN tells a fine, bloody, cautionary tale. The scene is Nero's Rome. It was not a place outstandingly given to underplaying gaudiness, decadence, and melodrama.

AMERICAN art is the theme of loan exhibitions opening today in two major New York museums. These are "Audubon Water-Colors and Drawings," at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, and "American Art From the Collection of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Goldstone," at the Brooklyn Museum.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, June 13 -- Swift, modern communications enable President Johnson to excercise precise "command and control" over the United States military effort in Vietnam, halfway around the World. Even the Syncom 2 satellite is used occasionally.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 -- McGeorge Bundy told a Harvard audience today that support of the Administration's foreign policy was far wider than many campus critics believed.
LONDON, June 14 (UPI) -- The Government refused today to restrict the appearances of American performers here in retaliation for United States refusal to grant permits to several British pop singers.
The Condon-Wadlin Act has long been a sore spot and area of controversy in the labor relations of public employes.
Paul R. Screvane, President of the City Council, announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday, the third Democrat to do so since Mayor Wagner's withdrawal last Thursday.

" It's dullsville," Walston Co.'s commodity department commented recently in a letter about wheat trading. Yesterday, that two-word sentence could have been applied to much of the trading in commodities.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (UPI) -- Booming kickoffs that soar beyond the end zone will be worthless in the new Continental Football League this year.
The Rev. Milton A. Galamison was ordered to serve 10 days in jail yerterday for abetting truancy last winters school boycotts.
Prices on the London stock exchange were narrowly mixed yesterday in light trading.

PASADENA, Calif., June 14 (AP) -- A radio signal that took 10 minutes to cross 107 million miles of space told engineers today that Mariner 4 had performed its final task before photographing Mars on July 14.
WINDSOR, England, June 14 -- "This lady's come all the way from Liverpool," said one of two smiling women to a policeman at Windsor Castle today.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 15 -- Antiaircraft installations capable of hitting planes at any altitude ring Hanoi, a North Vietnamese military commandant has told a visiting British Communist party delegation, according to today's London Daffy Worker.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 -- At a party in a Saigon orchid garden, a Vietnamese army officer chatted with an obviously charmed group of Government officials and diplomats clustered about. him.
Dr. Calvin E. Gross resigned last night as Superintendent of Schools effective Aug. 31.

For the first time in the history of North Atlantic air travel, alien passengers outnumbered American citizens flying last year between Scandinavian countries and the United States, Scandinavian Airlines System reported yesterday.
" EVERY woman with $600 to spend for an evening dress wants a Sarmi."

After allowing a decent period for mourning Mayor Wagner's withdrawal, City Council President Paul R. Screvane has announced his candidacy for Mayor. The list of those seeking the Democratic nomination lengthens daily; the roster of those apparently willing but undeclared is even longer.

The Police Department's Negro fraternal society has voted to seek formation of a civilian review board that would be independent of the department. It is moving to present its views to Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick.

ALBANY, June 14 -- The Senate came to grips with New York City's fiscal problems for the first time today, and the longest state legislative session in more than 50 years was promptly extended by another week.
PARIS, June 14 -- Prince Rainer III of Monaco issued an ultimatum today to the second-most powerful man in his Riviera realm, Aristotle S. Onassis.

Television networks in the United States and Europe suddenly refrained yesterday from using the Early Bird satellite for trans-Atlantic news programs. Although broadcasters on both sides of the Atlantic denied a boycott, it was obvious that their stand represented a silent protest against contemplated commercial rates for use of the satellite.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company announced today a $30 million expansion program for its glass and chemical products plants at Mount Clemens, Mich., Dearborn, Mich., and Nashville, Tenn.

MONTREAL, June 14 -- French Canada's sensitive feelings about British royalty came to the fore again today when a prominent Quebec Member of Parliament announnced he was returning his Order of the British Empire medal because the Queen had named the Beatles members of the Order of the British Empire.

CINCINNATI, June 14 -- Add another chapter to the implausible chronicle of the Amazin' Mets. Tonight, after being held hitless for 10 innings by Jim Maloney of Cincinnati, the New Yorkers snapped a 10-game losing streak by beating the third-place Reds, 1-0, on an 11th-inning homer by Johnny Lewis.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- Chicago civil rights leaders called off a march into the central business district today that had threatened to disrupt a celebration for the crew of Gemini 4.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 14 (UPI) -- A Kansas farm youth who ended a week-long nation-wide search by giving himself up got a court-appointed attorney today to help defend him against charges of staging a bank robbery and killing three persons.
After a minor recovery in the first hour of trading, stock prices resumed yesterday their month-long decline.

TOKYO, June 14 -- Japanese sponsors have canceled the scheduled postseason tour of the Pittsburgh Pirates this fall because of the fifth-place National League team's inferior drawing power here, an official of the Tokyo sponsoring organization said today.

Another warning that the West faces a possible collapse of its monetary system has been issued -- this time by the authoritative Bank for International Settlements. Its annual report calls for an international monetary truce; it insists that the major financial powers must agree on reforms of the international monetary system ff serious trouble is to be avoided.

On the 25th anniversary of the entry of Soviet forces into the Baltic states, exile leaders made public yesterday appeals to United Nations delegations to take up the issue of "Soviet colonialism." They also asked the delegations to support demands for a Soviet withdrawal and for Baltic self-determination.
The Alberto-Culver Company has withdrawn more than $20 million in billings from Compton Advertising Inc., in what it described as "the best interest of all concerned."

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee served notice today that the United States should consider pulling out of an international air agreement unless some form of mandatory insurance of passengers could be worked out.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Justice Department moved today for the first time to protect the rights of Negro teachers in Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Douglas Dillon, who recently resigned as Secretary of the Treasury, said today that early improvement in the global monetary system was "urgent" because deficits in the international payments of the United States "are now coming to an end."
A pair of Wall Street's favorite stocks sporting a link with the Government -- General Aniline and Comsat -- figuratively took it on the chin yesterday, along with the bulk of the market.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 -- Maj. Gen Nguyen Van Thieu, the new military ruler of South Vietnam, encountered difficulties tonight in the organization of a government.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations evidently has succeeded in eliminating from the Labor Department's budget an appropriation to finance a major study of job vacancies.
PARIS -- There is a new point of view in Europe's leading fashion magazines: Don't show any clothes.

THE resurgence of impassioned if imprecise activism on the college campus was studied last night in the "The Berkeley Rebels," a documentary prepared by the Columbia Broadcasting System News Division.
Bloodmobiles will call at five places in the metropolitan are today to receive donations of blood for the Red Cross.
Midnight tonight is a tax deadline for millions of Americans in the higher income brackets.
Production of steel in the United States declined 2 per cent last week to 2,692,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 14 (AP) -- Nearly 3,000 persons heard the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. tell the Oberlin College graduating class today that "our challenge is to remain awake during today's social revolution."

PHUOCVINH, South Vietnam, June 14 -- More than 1,000 South Vietnamese airborne troops were moved into an area north of Dongxoai today while United States paratroopers here waited for their first full-scale clash with the Vietcong.
DALLAS, June 24 (UPI) -- A Roman Catholic bishop, speaking at a Jewish convention, said today that Catholics and Jews are "like brothers" and need an understanding of each other's problems.

The failure of two successive odds-on choices, including the one in the feature race, seemed appropriate to the gray and uninspiring atmosphere at Aqueduct yesterday. The 26,802 fans took the setbacks calmly enough, however, as they wagered an impressive $2,801,787 on a nine-race card on which only two favorites won.
THE 65th Maryland trapshooting Championship, June 24 to 27, is shaping up as one of the East's top shooting attractions of the year.

The connection between birth control and wiretapping may not seem obvious to the naked eye. But there were legal experts yesterday who predicted that last week's ruling by the United States Supreme Court invalidating Connecticut's birth control statute would very likely mean the outlawing of wiretapping and other forms of electronic eavesdropping.
DETROIT, June 14 -- Carl Ogelsby, a 23-year-old graduate of the University of Michigan, was elected today president of Students for a Democratic Society.

At least 40 New York Stock Exchange member firms almost became unwitting accessories yesterday in what appears to have been a remote-control attempt to stage a multimillion-dollar manipulation in three Canadian stocks.
Cardinal Spellman was waiting yesterday for a buyer to purchase his valuable collection of rare coins.
The Univac division of Sperry Rand Corporation is quietly moving its operations to Philadelphia. Most of the Unwac operations are currently at 1290 Sixth Avenue.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for the easy-to-prepare main dish.

MIAMI BEACH, June 15 -- Jack Mills, the executive director of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, said tonight that Mr. Watson's victory was a "test operation" for new techniques that would be applied to other House contests around the country.
BONN, June 15 -- The East German police shot and killed a West Berlin man and critically wounded a woman companion today as they were pleasure-boating on a canal.

Pity the critically ill patient who is taken to a city hospital. Adequate nursing care cannot be had for love or money. During the recent desperate illness of a close relative, it was possible for me to obtain shared nursing care at the Coney Island Hospital, a modern municipal hospital in Brooklyn, for only one night.

A TOTAL of $15 million in Federal funds will be distributed among the 50 states on July 1 for fish and wildlife restoration projects. The money comes from excise taxes collected on the sale of hunting and fishing equipment.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association went on strike at midnight against 12 major ship companies.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 15 -- Miss Robin Biddle Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Martin Jr. of Brookville, who was presented Monday evening at the North Shore Junior League Debutante Cotillion, was honored last night at a dance given by her parents at the Piping Rock Club.

An all-day seminar on office buildings will be a feature of the international conference of the American Society of Appraisers at the Commodore Hotel on June 26. Four hundred appraisers from all fields are expected to attend the six-day annual meeting.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 15 -- Although all the available evidence indicates that Gov. William W Scranton is still genuinely undecided about his political future, Democrats here are attacking him as if he were already the Republican Presidential nominee in 1968.
More than 84,000 tons of airborne commercial foreign trade with a value of $1.5 billion moved through the Port of New York in 1964, the Port of New York Authority reported yesterday.

Erratic fluctuations in heavy trading marked stock market activity yesterday, but a recovery movement, which started late in the morning, developed into a full-scale rally and the market closed with gains for the day.

PARIS, June 15 -- Two Americans are visiting the Paris haunts of James Joyce before going to Dublin to celebrate the 61st anniversary tomorrow of Bloomsday, the day Joyce selected for the happenings in his "Ulysses."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 -- The Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution today approving the recommendation of U Thant, the Secretary General that the mandate of the United Nationc force in Cyprus be extended six months to Dec. 26, 1965.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 15 -- Eight of the nine qualifying races for nine championship berths in the 30th annual Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association regatta were held today on Manhasset Bay. Cheshire and Taft were first in their respective divisions.

The State Senate has rarely qualified as a deliberative body of distinction. Its members, over the years, have tended to vote arbitrarily along party lines; their perfunctory floor debate has, all too correctly, impressed most of them as a sham, a bore or both. Under these circumstances it is particularly discouraging to learn that Senator George R. Metcalf of Auburn plans to retire at the end of his present term.

Passengers on international airline flights involved in an accident have since 1934 been covered by the Warsaw Convention, which provides a unified liability code and uniform documentation on tickets and cargo for international air carriers. Under its antiquated provisions liability for loss of life or injury is limited to only $8,300, except where willful misconduct is proved.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 -- Jack Nicklaus resumed training today at the site of the United States Open golf championship, which begins Thursday. In a practice round over the Bellerive Country Club course, the 25-year-old Ohioan scored a 72.

ROME, June 15 (AP) -- Gian Carlo Menotti, the composer, announced today that his Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto would present a ballet with music by Ezra Pound. The American poet, now 79 years old, wrote the ballet, "Le Testament," in 1922.

PARIS -- The Soviet Union is "on the threshold of grandiose changes," on the verge of a "third revolution" which will ultimately lead in the direction of intellectual freedom and political democracy. This is the remarkable conclusion of Mihajlo Mihajlov, the young Yugoslav professor who was recently sentenced to nine months' imprisonment for slandering Russia in two articles for a Belgrade literary magazine.
New York Airways. Inc., which operates helicopter services in metropolitan New York, has received a new offer of financial assistance -- this one from Trans World Airlines.

The Financial Public Relations Association has overwhelmingly voted to close its doors to any new members from savings and loan associations. Present savings and loan members, however, will be permitted to stay.

ROME, June 15 -- Support for the parties of Italy's governing center left coalition held up generally well and recent Communist gains seemed checked in a patchwork of regional, provincial and local elections Sunday and yesterday.

Bishop Alvin A. Childs, Harlem's locality Mayor, charged yesterday that "the Wagner administration is in effect hampering the cause of peace" by refusing to allow "peace-in-Harlem" banners to be strung across eight streets.
MOSCOW, June 15 (AP) -- A woman historian, Evgenia I. Popova, has become the toast of Soviet academic circles by disputing some Soviet dogmas on life in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A relatively novel West German view of East Germany and of German unification problems is being presented to the Johnson Administration this week by Vice Chancellor Erich Mende.

LAST year when Sir Malcolm Sargent made his initial appearance as a conductor of the New York Philharmonic "Promenades," his programs were English and Shakespearean in source. Last night in Philharmonic Hall he offered a "Romantic Promenade."
Two youths were fatally injured this week in separate incidents of joy riding on the roof and undercarriage of elevator cars.

LONDON, June 15 -- On a three-week holiday from his brokerage business in Dallas, 31-year-old Ham Richardson hustled the sixth-seeded Wimbledon player, John Newcombe, right out of the Queens Club tennis tourney today and put himself into contention for the American Davis Cup team.

The Moiseyev Dance Company turned loose its dazzling tricks at Madison Square Garden last night before 8,200 onlookers to demonstrate what it had shown last month in the Metropolitan Opera House -- very skillful dancing that makes a marvelous show.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- Legislation to require warning labels on cigarette packages was cleared today by the House Rules Committee.

Negotiations among three New York newspapers -- The Herald Tribune, The World-Telegram and The Sun and The Journal-American -- about either a partial merger or some other joint cost-saving operation have been under way for several months.

WASHINGTON, June 15 Amid mutterings of discontent, the House obediently rewrote today a disaster relief bill that President Johnson vetoed last week as an unwarranted encroachment on the prerogatives of the Executive.
The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., in the fiscal year ended March 31 increased its sales and earnings each by 15 per cent over the previous year's levels, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
The $525 million of Federal National Mortgage Association participation certificates offered officially yesterday morning, were estimated more than 90 per cent sold by early afternoon.
The New York Yankees continued marching steadfastly to nowhere by losing to the Baltimore Orioles, 2-1, in 10 innings at Yankee Stadium last night.

The fashion world -- those retailers and producers who keep 35 million American women happy and buying -- took time out last night at the height of one of their busiest periods of the year to raise funds to try to convert man's inhumanity to man to a more fruitful and harmonious relationship.

LONDON, June 15 -- As a young woman Clementine Ogilvy Hozier, the beautiful brown-haired daughter of an army colonel and granddaughter of the ninth Earl of Airlie, never lacked suitors. But for six seasons after her coming-out dance, she coolly turned them down.
MOSCOW, June 15 -- The iconocclastic hero as a stock character on the current Moscow stage is stirring critical discussion among playwrights and theatrical writers.

Dr. Calvin E. Gross, who resigned Monday as Superintendent of Schools, will be offered a post as professor of educational administration at the University of Wisconsin, a university official said last night.
ALBANY, June 15 -- The Democratic majorities in the Assembly and the Senate passed today their bill to soften the penalties of the Condon-Wadlin Act, which makes strikes by public employes illegal.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 15 -- Former Representative Albert W. Watson, who defied Democratic punishment for having supported Barry Goldwater for President, won a resounding endorsement at the polls today.

MOSCOW, June 15 (UPI) -- A Russian flight engineer was shot dead by an airliner passenger who tried to hijack a plane in flight and flee the Soviet Union with a woman, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

The New York Shakespeare Festival, which does not perform on Monday nights, has decided to utilize those evenings for the presentation of a variety of cultural events, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Papp, founder and producer of the festival.

The air of mystery surrounding an attempt to manipulate three Canadian stocks through more than 40 New York Stock Exchange member firms deepened yesterday when a Toronto finance company defaulted on more than $5 million of notes.

ROCKLAND LAKE, N.Y., June 15 -- Governor Rockefeller officially opened Rockland Lake State Park here today, the first major recreation area to be built by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission outside Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park in more than 30 years.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- President Johnson told 14 graduates of the Capitol Page School today that their training equipped them to become "leaders in the cause of peace and freedom in the world."

The vehicular-homicide trial of Gareth Martinis, son of an acting Supreme Court justice, was slowed by constant sharp argument yesterday, as defense counsel sought to bar evidence given at Mr. Martinis's previous trial.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Armed Services Committee overwhelmingly approved today a $1 billion-a-year pay increase for the military, more than double the amount requested by the Johnson Administration.

TORONTO, June 15 -- Finance Minister Walter L. Gordon said last night he had warned James S. Rockefeller, chairman of the First National City Bank, New York, in July, 1963, against acquiring the Mercantile Bank of Canada because of possible restrictions.
BONN, June 15 -- President Tito's reconciliation trip to East Germany has plunged Yugoslavia's relations with West Germany to their lowest point.

Federal National Mortgage Association participation certificates valued at $525 million were formally offered to investors yesterday at prices to yield from 4.35 per cent in July, 1966, up to 4.50 per cent in 1971-80.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., June 15 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair took the lead in the 12th annual Elizabeth Goss Memorial round-robin golf tournament today with a total of 14 1/2 points at the end of two rounds in the 54-hole event.
A City Council committee postponed action yesterday on a resolution asking the State Legislature to pass a bill that calls for a referendum on proportional representation in City Council elections.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate passed a bill for $4.7 billion in excise tax reductions tonight. The vote was 84 to 3.
HAVANA, June 15 -- The opening of a big cotton mill has deepened the mystery of Maj. Ernesto Che Guevara, the maverick of the Cuban revolution.

VIENNA, June 15 -- George F. Kennan, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, suggested tonight the possibility of a United States of Europe with a place for Communist states.
PARIS, June 15 -- The French Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, expressed official opposition tonight to a "massive" increase in the price of gold and to a revival of the gold standard.
College students who have taken part in the civil rights movement were praised yesterday by Bernard Botein; Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department.
LONDON, June 15 -- The Government moved today to prevent segregation in British schools.

MANY hopeful parents picture their children voluntarily spending long summer hours devouring stacks of books. Other parents, with a determined glint in their eyes, have vowed this will be the summer to Do Something about Johnny's Reading.

TORONTO, June 15 -- Spokesmen for some Toronto Stock Exchange member firms that specialize in speculative mining stocks grumbled today that Howard D. Graham, president of the exchange, was assuming too much power at the expense of brokers.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Following is the text of an address on the Vietnam issue today by Senator J.W. Fulbright.
MOSCOW, June 15 -- The Soviet Union has resumed construction in Moscow of what is planned to be the world's highest reinforced-concrete television tower.
CHICAGO, June 15 -- Unusually cool weather thinned attendance tonight at the opening of the Ravinia Festival Association's 30th season of Chicago Symphony Orchestra concerts.

A cousin of General Imbert predicted in Puerto Rico Monday that United States forces would attack the rebel zone yesterday, Mr. Bosch said yesterday by telephone from San Juan, P.R., where he is in exile.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 (AP) -- The bell in the Memorial Church Tower in Harvard Yard tolled 87 times today for deceased members of the class of 1940.
LONDON, June 15 -- Leaders of the British bar, joined by representatives of the bars of the United States, Australia and New Zealand, paid homage today to Magna Carta.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 15 (UPI) -- Maj. James A. McDivitt and Maj. Edward H. White 2d returned in triumph today to the University of Michigan campus where they once toiled in relative obscurity as space researchers.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Negro and labor groups denounced tonight an attempt by Representative Adam Clayton Powell to tie the civil rights issue to repeal of Section 14 (b) of the Taft-Hartley Act.
SUFFERN, N.Y., June 15 -- Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller singled out the Geigy Chemical Corporation today as a successful example of the state's effort to attract foreign investment capital.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation announced yesterday it was doubling its capital spending for 1965 and also disclosed it was now conducting "preliminary negotiations with several companies" for possible acquisitions.
MIAMI BEACH, June 15 -- The civil rights issue moved to the fore at the convention of the Young Republican National Federation here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 -- A proposal for early resumption of intensive negotiations by the Geneva disarmament conference was approved today by 83 votes to 1, with 18 states abstaining. Members of the Soviet bloc and France were among the abstainers.
The British pound weakened considerably in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The decline was attributed to Britain's poor trade performance in May.
ALBANY, June 15 -- Governor Rockefeller signed a Democratic bill today to place before the voters next November the question of whether there should be a constitutional convention in 1967.
A strike by three unions has shut down 10 pulp and paper mills of the International Paper Company's Southern Kraft Division. About 13,000 employes are affected.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright proposed today that the United States conduct a "resolute but restrained" holding action in Vietnam until the Communists see the futility of trying to win a complete military victory and agree to negotiate.
BUFFALO, June 15 -- Mayor Chester C. Kowal and former Corporation Counsel Ralph Saft were indicted today by a grand jury investigating the closing of a municipal dump.

It is with deep concern that we view the introduction of the Dirksen proposal to set aside the Supreme Court reapportionment decisions. It is even more disturbing that some Senators who have been most vociferous in protecting Negro voting rights in the South seem disdainful of protecting these same rights in our urban and suburban areas.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy told 2,105 persons receiving degrees at Queens College yesterday that they must recognize the "magnitude and significance" of "a revolution for individual dignity" now going on all over the world.
DENVER, June 15 (AP) -- Winds, rain, hail and high water left scars over a wide section of Colorado today.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 15 (UPI) -- Maria Bueno of Brazil and Roy Emerson of Australia, the defending champions, were named today the top-seeded players for the Wimbledon lawn tennis championship, which begins next Monday.

One chocolate spoon, 102 animal headdresses, a set of handbells and children to play them, 112 costumes, a wind machine, a temple gong and several sand blocks are traveling from Manhattan to Westbury, L.I., this week.
ALBANY, June 15 -- Labor won a victory today when the Assembly voted overwhelmingly to dilute the authority of New York Harbor's Waterfront Commission and the current work force of longshoremen.

LONDON, June 15 -- A twice-torpedoed former sea captain and a coast guardsman who rescued nine sailors intend to join in a protest against the award to the Beatles of membership in the Order of the British Empire.

IT could have been 1935, with spotlights focusing on the starlets entering Grauman's Chinese Theater for the big premiere. Above their sequined gowns wrapped in white fox, their bright red lipstick glistens, their penciled brows are arched in perpetual astonishment and their chalk white faces are deftly rouged.
More than 75 per cent of the eligible taxi drivers and mechanics voted in a special 24-hour election to determine if they want to join a new union.
Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second District gave the commencement address yesterday at the Brooklyn Law School.

The earnings of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in the first fiscal quarter ended May 29 were about the same as in the period last year, "'give or take a couple of pennies per share." Byron Jay, president, made this report to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- It will take "a great deal of effort over a number of years" for the United States to achieve first place in space, the space agency's chief of manned flight said today.
JACKSON, Miss., June 15 -- Two hundred and three civil rights pickets and marchers were arrested near the Mississippi State Capitol today in the second day of racial demonstrations.

Arrangements have been made for a visit to the United Nations next autumn by Pope Paul VI, according to information made available to The New York Times. The visit would be the first to the United States by a pope.

A 4000-year-old Babylonian butcher's bill and a printed circuit for an electronic computer are among the "everyday things" assembled by Ernst Halberstadt, noted Boston artist, in a 40-foot mural in the Irving Trust Company's new branch at Third Avenue and 42d Street.
WALDEN, N.Y., June 15 -- To some, retirement means being turned out to pasture. This turned out to be especially true here today in the case of Turnout, a 19-year-old roan horse.

ASCOT, England ,June 15 (AP) -- Two American - owned horses won at the glamorous Royal Ascot race meeting today. One of them, Beddard, beat Queen Elizabeth's entry as the Queen and other members of Britain's royal family looked on.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange continued to lose ground yesterday although a late rally shaved most of the declines in active trading.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 15 -- The heaviest fighting in six weeks raged along the international security corridor today between rebel commandos on one side and United States and Brazilian troops on the other.

The Democratic majorities in the State Legislature, under intense union pressure, have whipped through a bill that makes a mockery of the ban on strikes by state and municipal employes. The proposed revisions in the Condon-Wadlin Act forbid strikes or slowdowns against the government, but make the penalties for violation so elastic that the chances they will ever be applied become almost zero.

HOLLYWOOD, June 15 -- Some performers have taken a long time to achieve stardom in the movie business but Ruth Gordon has set something of a record. The actress and playwright, who made her debut as a Broadway actress 50 years ago, has suddenly found herself in great demand in the movies and she is plainly delighted by it.
WASHINGTON, June45 -- An Administration bill to create a department of housing and urban development with cabinet rank is expected to win House approval tomorrow by a slim margin.

HARTFORD, June 15 -- Connecticut voters elected today the 84 delegates to a constitutional convention starting July 1. Their primary task will be to write a new constitutional framework for the General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A sharp domestic political issue is now developing over the nation's military strategy in Vietnam.

The price of First National City Bank stock slipped 3/4 point yesterday to 52 7/8 following the bank's disclosure that its second-quarter net operating earnings would be affected by a $4 million loss of "nonrecurring character."

The seven-week session of the 114-nation Disarmament Commission draws to a close on an unexpectedly positive note. Despite abstention by Moscow and the Communist bloc, the nonaligned nations obtained an 83-to-1 majority for early resumption of the seventeen-nation Geneva conference, where there could be serious work toward arms control and East-West detente.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- There is a growing belief among United States officials that any solution to the current stalemate in the Dominican Republic will have to bypass both the rebels and the junta.
Reform Democrats set up an 11-member committee yesterday to consider candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and to report back to a 161-member general committee next week.
HOUSTON, June 15 (AP) -- Bob Buhl and Ted Abernathy collaborated on a five-hitter as the Chicago Cubs blanked Houston tonight, 5-0, extending the Astros' losing streak to eight games.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- President Johnson unveiled today a model of a new Defense Department building and named the structure for the late James V. Forrestal, first Secretary of Defense.

The Delegate Assembly of the United Federation of Teachers yesterday authorized a strike against the city schools next fall unless the Board of Education came up with a more acceptable contract offer.
The board of the Lukens Steel Company proposed yesterday in Coatesville, Pa., a three-for-one split of the common stock.

James D. Landauer, president of the Grand Central Building Corporation, owner of the 59-story Pan Am Building at 200 Park Avenue, has announced the election of two officers who will be in charge of the skyscraper.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A group of college students who came here to lobby for the Mississippi Freedom Democratic party picketed the Justice Department today.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Four leading clergymen representing Mayor Richard J. Daley worked out a conditional moratorium late this afternoon on the civil rights demonstrations that have resulted in the arrest of at least 530 persons here since last Thursday.
The stock market, which has been in a month-long decline, staged a rally yesterday in its busiest session in 19 months.
Voters in Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island took part in annual elections yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A Jetstar aircraft similar to the plane used by President Johnson suffered potentially serious mechanical difficulties during a training flight over Pennsylvania.

The Quebec Hydro-Electric Commission, in its first competitive sale of debentures in the United States, sold a $50 million issue to an yesterday investment banking syndicate led by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 15 -- Princeton University conferred 1,224 academic degrees this morning in exercises held on the green in front of historic Nassau Hall.
MOSCOW, June 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Union says it will have its TU-144 supersonic air liner flying as soon as the British-French Concorde.

KEARNY, N.J., June 15 -- Don Rubell of New York, the top-seeded player, scored a third-round victory today in the New Jersey State tennis championship at the Arlington Players Club. He defeated Dick Appleby of Great Neck, L.I., 7-5, 6-4, and paced the field into the round of 16.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (AP) -- Rocky Colavito drove in three runs with his 13th homer of the season and Chuck Hinton also hit a homer as the Cleveland Indians scored an 8-3 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

Contracts totaling $10 million have been awarded to the P.J. Carlin Construction Company for the building expansion planned by Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. Four new floors and four horizontal wings will be added to the present five-story building, increasing its bed capacity from 268 to 450.

Suddenly it is hard to see the sun for the clouds. The drop in market prices, which demonstrated once again that stocks usually go down more quickly than they go up, has shaken confidence about the outlook for continued expansion. It will take more than a technical rally to restore flagging spirits.

City College will graduate the largest class in its history at its 119th commencement exercises tonight in Lewisohn Stadium, Convent Avenue and 138th Street. A total of 4,194 students will receive degrees.
State Supreme Court Justice J. Irwin Shapiro ordered the Queens County Medical Society yesterday to admit osteopaths to membership.

As the words "aggression," "self-determination" and "international morality" are debated with increasing intensity in the United States and elsewhere, a 25-year anniversary on June 15 to 17 requires the attention of all men concerned with peace, freedom and human rights.
A judge in Brooklyn set aside yesterday a jury's decision that a convicted murderer be electrocuted, and imposed instead, "in the interests of justice," a sentence of life imprisonment.
DETROIT, June 15 -- A two-way attack on pollution of Lake Erie, whose progressive clogging with man-made wastes has alarmed scientists, sanitarians and conservationists swung into motion today.

EBBETS FIELD, 'a temple to the bizarre, is only a glorious memory. So are the Brooklyn Dodgers, the high priests who not only performed their curious rites within its cloistered confines but also carried their peculiar brand of zaniness with them wherever they went. Accurate was the baseball truism: Everything happens in Brooklyn or to Brooklyn.

MARIO ANDRETTI, the 25-year-old Italian-born American who rocketed to fame with a third-place finish in this year's Indianapolis 500 race, stopped in New York yesterday on his way to Langhorne, Pa., to look over the newly paved one-mile D shaped track where a 100-mile championship event will be run Sunday.
DETROIT, June 15 -- One of the nation's leading criminologists called today for a revolution in law enforcement through the creation of metropolitan rather than municipal police forces.

A major painting by John Singleton Copley has returned home after a 194-year stay in England, and is now at the Brooklyn Museum. Dr. Axel von Saldern, curator of paintings and sculpture, called the acquisition the museum's most important purchase of an 18 century painting.

Wall Street finally got the rally it had been hoping for during all these many recent days of declines, both moderate and large. True, the gain in the key averages yesterday was not spectacular, but it was substantial and it occurred in heavy trading.

A former policewoman said yesterday that she had been advised by a Police Department surgeon to become pregnant in the hope of alleviating some injuries from a fall. She followed the advice and is now suing the city for $3,000 in pay forfeited when she was compelled to take a maternity leave.

AT current market prices, frying chickens and chicken parts are an economical meat buy, having the lowest cost per pound of any cooked edible meat. Among the parts, the chicken breast is the starting point for a multitude of delectable, quick, easy-to-fix dishes that are elegant enough for company fare.
SOONER or later an established Shakespeare festival should face up to the less popular plays in the canon. Not to do so is to indicate a lack of daring as well as a deficiency in responsibility.
Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican candidate for Mayor, asked the Liberal party yesterday for a meeting with a view to obtaining its endorsement of his candidacy.
LONDON, June 15 -- Britain's trading position worsened last month, with exports declining and imports rising to the highest level since records were kept, the Government reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 16 -- Vietcong terrorists exploded a plastic bomb this morning at Saigon's civilian airport, wounding at least 32 persons, including 20 United States servicemen.
Leonard Bernstein was pressed into service yesterday as an assistant director for an Off Broadway venture and enjoyed every minute of it.

CINCINNATI, June 15 -- Still aglow over their Monday night feat of transforming Jim Maloney's 10-inning no-hitter into an 11-inning victory, the New York Mets came out roaring against the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) -- The American Civil Liberties Union opposed today a suggestion in the Senate that television networks cooperate in offering prime-time children's programs of higher quality.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Senate ratified a protocol today providing for a one-year extension of the International Wheat Agreement -- from Aug. 1 to July 31, 1966.
The city moved yesterday to prevent owners of apartment houses with swimming pools from circumventing bans on the use of water by applying for licenses as commercial ventures.
Copper futures had a difficult day yesterday, closing lower because of a drop in copper futures prices on the London market, which opens and closes earlier than in New York.
Most foreign stock markets declined yesterday in reaction to the Wall-Street slide on Monday and unfavorable local conditions.

Because of the stock market slump, a pawnshop west of Fifth Avenue on 57th Street -- a rather exclusive shop that caters to the rich -- is placing an advertisement in The Wall Street Journal today inviting people who need money to pawn their diamonds and jewels.
Alsco, Inc., a leading fabricator of aluminum products said yesterday it would increase prices on most types of aluminum residential siding by $1 a hundred square feet.
The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company announced the elections yesterday of S. Bacon Fuller, Robert L. Taylor and Edgar M. Waller Jr. as directors.
Utah, which hasn't sold bonds in 45 years and hasn't had any bonds outstanding since 1955, returned to Wall Street yesterday to borrow $67 million.
LONDON, June15 -- Standing next to two of her late husband's wartime colleagues, Lady Spencer-Churchill of Chartwell in the County of Kent was introduced today to the House of Lords.
PARIS, June 15 -- France's far-fight-wing candidate for President, a sprightly Gallic version of Barry Goldwater, conceded today that he still "frightened" a good many Frenchmen.

PROPHECY is always a risky business, but the temptation to prophesy is sometimes irresistible. So I herewith predict that Lieut. Nicholas Ramage, commander of His Majesty's cutter Kathleen, will enjoy a highly successful career and survive some of the most perilous adventures experienced by any British naval officer in the entire history of the Napoleonic Wars.
Seventy-five tenants of a luxury East Side apartment house charged in court yesterday that instead of living in gracious splendor they inhabited a "house of horrors."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 15 -- The special committee of 33 appointed by the General Assembly to resolve a big-power controversy over peace-keeping operations adopted an interim report today that avoided specific recommendations.
Distribution of the 1965 edition of The New York Port Handbook will begin shortly, Paul G. Boise, chairman of the Port Resources Information Committee, Inc., announced yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ga., June 15 (AP) -- Eighteen soldiers were killed today when two Army assault helicopters collided and crashed during a training flight at nearby Fort Benning, the Army said.

MILWAUKEE, June 15 (AP) Felipe Alou drove in six runs and a single and Eddie Mathews slammed a homer for his 2,000th major league hit tonight as the Milwaukee Braves routed the Philadelphia Phillies, 12-7.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Further reassurances about the economy came today from President Johnson, the Democratic leaders of Congress and Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler.

The Columbia Broadcasting System news division said yesterday that commercial rates proposed for the Early Bird satellite might prevent routine use of it for television transmission. Unless the news is urgent, C.B.S. News said, it will continue to rely on air shipments of film and tape from Europe.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 15 -- New Jersey's new drug addiction treatment program for volunteers and those who elect to avoid jail sentences for narcotics use opened near here today.
LE BOURGET, France, June 15 -- The Soviet Union unveiled today the world's largest plane after it had made a surprise flight from Moscow to the International Air Show here.
ST. LOUIS, June 15 (AP) -- Donn Clendenon drove in four runs with two homers tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated St. Louis, 10-6, for their first victory in 18 games with the Cardinals.

LONDON, June 15 -- Prime Minister Wilson said today that his Government was "deeply disturbed about the present situation in Vietnam and the developments of the last two or three weeks." I. Jerome Riker, head of a real estate concern that managed high-priced East Side cooperatives, was indicted here yesterday on charges of stealing $524,584 from money he collected that was to have been used to pay for taxes, repairs, wages and maintenance.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 -- The militant Buddhist faction demanded today that civilian leaders be given key posts in the new military-dominated Government of South Vietnam.

The only sound statement in H. Thomas Osborne's letter, published June 5, complaining about professors trying to influence our foreign policy, is his guess that they voted for the President last November.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 15 -- Valiant Chief and Loredo Hanover finished the second race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight separated only by a nose.

City Council President Paul R. Screvane issued a plea yesterday to opponents in the Democratic scramble for the mayoral nomination not to engage in a "self-destructive intraparty struggle" that would serve Republican interests.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Administration recommended today major changes in Federal narcotics laws to shift the emphasis from harsh punishments to rehabilitation.

Despite a "slight lessening" of the trend toward increased retail sales in recent months, the Allied Stores Corporation looks to continued improvement of earnings for the balance of the year, Theodore Schlesinger, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting.
LONDON, June 15 -- The British Bridge League set up an inquiry today to examine the charges of cheating by two British players last month at the World Championships in Buenos Aires.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A few minutes before 11 last night Duke Ellington and his band were working up a head of steam in an excerpt from his "Black, Brown and Beige." The audience on the South Lawn of the White House, which included Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, artists, art patrons and critics, was relaxed after a 13-hour marathon of the arts, and some clapped hands to the beat of the band.

A WORLD record for a single bridge game in aid of chairty was set here on Monday night. About $17,000 was raised for the United Jewish Appeal in a tournament at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, a sharp gain over the record amount obtained last year in the same event.

DETROIT, June 15 (UPI) -- Denny McLain of Detroit tied an American League record for consecutive strike-outs with seven tonight and Willie Horton hit a three-run homer in the eighth as the Tigers scored a 6-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

The revised third edition of "The Game Is Up," which opened last night at the Downstairs at the Upstairs has new staging, new sketches and three new principals. The last version may have only been pleasant, but this one, with some cutting edges, has real kick.
The jumping fraternity bid adieu to Aqueduct yesterday until late August with six hurdlers taking part in the farewell number -- the seventh running of the $11,450 Annapolis Stakes.

The M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company was the broker in the sale of the leasehold on the Victoria Hotel on the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 51st Street to a hotel operating group headed by George Geiger.

The two insurance companies that underwrite most of the bail bonds in New York City announced yesterday new financial standards that could greatly increase the number of indigent defendants held in jail for trial or sentencing.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara announced today that six more combat battalions, plus supporting troops, were being sent to South Vietnam to offset the continuing build-up of Communist forces there.

The New York Yankees lost their third straight game last night -- and the Baltimore Orioles won their sixth straight -- when the Orioles overcame Al Downing, Pedro Ramos and a chilling wind to score a 5-1 victory.
The stock market made a half-hearted attempt yesterday to continue the recovery movement that developed on Tuesday afternoon, but still managed to advance moderately.

The Celanese Fibers Marketing Company, a division of Celanese Corporation of America, added 3 cents a pound on all sizes of rayon textile filament yarns. The change takes effect July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The Senate approved legislation today to raise the temporary national debt limit from $324 billion to $328 billion, a record.

VERSAILLES, France, June 18 -- President de Gaulle went to the country today with an earnest and insistent appeal to Frenchmen to fulfill their independent national destiny.

MOSCOW, June 16 -- A film glorifying the work of the Soviet secret police in uncovering economic crimes has been playing to full houses here.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The source of the timid mutiny against Representative Adam Clayton Powell by a subdivision of the committee he imperiously rules is only that the mutineers want to assure prompt House action on the President's proposal to repeal Sec. 14-B of the Taft-Hartley Act.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 16 -- Former Premier David Ben-Gurion called tonight for his political followers to break away from the Mapai party and form a party of "justice and comradeship."

Mayor Wagner's borrow now-tax later scheme is on its way through the Legislature in a triumph of political expediency over fiscal conscience. It represents a dangerous, unreal "balancing" of the city budget. It issues promissory notes for $256 million or more annually on the gamble that in November of next year the voters will step forward and volunteer to tax themselves more heavily and rescue the city from self-invited bankruptcy.
DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- Willie Horton drove in five runs tonight as the Detroit Tigers scored their fourth straight victory, a 9-4 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.

WEST PAWLET, Vt., June 16 -- Labrador retrievers belonging to James M. Mertz, who shuttles every week between his home in Rye, N.Y., and this village, may be the most widely known dogs anywhere in the roofing business.

A decline of 4,895,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the weekend were 205,984,000 barrels, compared with 210,879,000 a week earlier and 202,561,000 a year ago.
The British pound continued to weaken in fairly quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

OXFORD, England, June 16 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, former United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, and Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart encountered a hostile, heckling band of students today in a lively eight-hour teach-in on Vietnam at the Oxford Student Union.

HOLLYWOOD, June 16 -- Twentieth Century Fox disclosed today that it had signed Gene Kelly to produce and direct a musical romance about a World War I pilot.

ALBANY, June 16 -- A bill that would end the state's 84-year-old law against the dissemination of birth control devices and information won final passage today in the Legislature. Governor Rockefeller declined to say whether he would sign it.
