PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, warned today that racial discrimination would not be eliminated until the true meaning of human dignity was understood.

FAR HILLS, N.J., June 17 -- Miss Susan Mary Englehard was presented this evening at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Englehard Jr. Two green tents, one for dancing and one for dining, were erected on the grounds of Cragwood, the family estate.

HOUSTON, June 17 (UPI) -- Billy Williams singled with two out in the 11th inning tonight to drive in the winning run and give the Chicago Cubs a 6-5 triumph over the Houston Astros. The hit scored Doug Clemens who had opened the inning with a double.
Differences between Alan Jay Lerner, author, lyricist and co-sponsor of the incoming musical, "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever," and the Association of Theater Benefit Agents have been settled.

George D. Widener's Steeple Jill made the figures stand up in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Established the favorite in the 1 1/8-mile event for fillies and mares on the turf, Steeple Jill came through with a solid enough victory.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Not long after he arrived to take command of United States forces in Santo Domingo, Lieut. Gen Bruce Palmer Jr. sent the 82d Airborne Division's band marching down the International Security Corridor to play outside the United States Embassy.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- A Soviet civil servant criticized today the institution of the local village club, where farm folk are supposed to go for evening recreation and relaxation and where he found only boredom.
Lawrence Litchfield Jr. was elected yesterday to the board of the Joy Manufacturing Company, a large producer of mining machinery and construction.

THE audience at last night's "International Promenade" at Philadelphia Hall had a warm greeting for two old friends, Moura Lympany, the British pianist, and her solo vehicle, Grieg's Piano Concerto in A minor.

NEWARK, June 17 -- Patrolman Henry Martinez, 29 years old, was suspended by the Police Department today on order of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio. The patrolman, a member of the force for five years, last Saturday shot and killed a traffic violation suspect who allegedly slashed another policeman and fled.
The concept of turning out college graduates like widgets on an assembly line was attacked here last evening as discouraging initiative and creative activity.
The nuclear ship Savannah, the world's first atom-powered merchant vessel, has been cleared for commercial operation by a subsidiary of American Export Lines.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17 -- Britain is leading a campaign to raise more than $15 million from the advanced industrial countries to be applied against the United Nations deficit resulting from unpaid assessments for peacekeeping forces in the Congo and Middle East.
The city's property owners can expect to pay a record basic tax of $4.54 for each $100 of assessed valuation next year.
JACKSON, Miss., June 17 -- The Mississippi Senate passed a liberalized package of voting rights bills today as the capital city prepared for large racial demonstrations tomorrow.

RACIAL discrimination in Britain, a subject rather extensively covered by the networks, received further attention last night in a documentary produced by National Educational Television and the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Dr. Samuel B. Gould, president of the State University of New York, today urged increased communication within the arts, greater cooperation among art organizations and the establishment of community and national associations to speak for the arts.
The Electronic Assistance Corporation has named William H. Weise as controller, succeeding Harold S. Laver, who has resigned. Mr. Weise was formerly controller of the Lionel Toy Corporation.
" Cleopatra," once a threat to the financial security of 20th Century-Fox, now has a golden future.
ASCOT, England, June 17 -- Gypsies sold dried heather to the entering crowds, for luck. Religious zealots marched on the other side of the straightaway with signs warning that the end was near.
Perturbed by the drop of stock prices on Wall Street, the Johnson Administration has mustered all of its vocal chords in a chorus of optimism.

DETROIT, June 17 -- The city of Detroit, which dally pours 540 million gallons of partly treated sewage into Lake Erie's main tributary, expressed flat opposition today to a Federal proposal to institute "secondary" treatment of the sort employed by upward of 50 per cent of the nation's municipalities.
PAULINE TRIGERE turns out to be a swinger. The designer, known for the last couple of decades for her elegant clothes, proved yesterday in her fall collection that she can move to a modern beat.
The British pound was mostly steady in fairly active trading in foreign exchange markets here yesterday. At the close, sterling was quoted at $2.7912, down 1 point from the day before.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Representatives of four states argued before the Interstate Commerce Commission today against the proposed merger of five railroads in the Northwest.
SAIGON, Friday, June 18 -- United States Navy jet aircraft shot down two Communist MIG-17 jet fighters yesterday 40 miles from Hanoi.

Aloisio Mattar's three goals paced the Portuguesa eleven from Sao Paulo, Brazil, to a 6-3 victory last night over favored West Ham United of London in the first soccer game to be played at Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- A large number of Congressmen and their aides are spending the week in Paris attending the International Air Show as guests of the Air Force, Congressional sources said tonight.
Following are excerpts from a policy speech on law enforcement yesterday by Representative John V. Lindsay at a meeting of the Idlewild Lions Chub at John F. Kennedy International Airport:

PARIS, June 17 -- Soviet officials invited newsmen today inside the world's largest plane, the whale-shaped newly unveiled AN-22, for vodka and a sales pitch at the International Air Show at Le Bourget Airport here.

MIAMI BEACH, June 17 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper of Iowa, the ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today it was "high time" American bombers destroyed military and industrial targets on the periphery of Hanoi.
CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- Sonny Siebert pitched a three-hitter and struck out 15 tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Washington Senators, 5-0, for their fifth consecutive victory.
Andre Kostelanetz will conduct all five of the New York Philharmonic "promenade" concerts m Philharmonic Hall next week.

WHEN word came out of Grand Rapids recently that the usual June furniture market was being canceled and that all formal showings for buyers would probably be discontinued, it seemed to many a person -- especially to one over 30 -- that a particularly homey period in American life had come to an end.
MOSCOW, June 17 -- The Soviet Union withheld immediate comment tonight on the attempt of the British Commonwealth prime ministers to open a new avenue to Vietnam negotiations.
BRUSSELS, June 17 -- Walter Hallstein, President of the European Common Market Commission, obliquely reproved France today on two counts.

GALLANT rescuing operations are not as consistently applauded at the bridge table as they are in everyday life. If your partner is about to play a doubled contract at a low level, and perhaps suffer a heavy penalty, any well-meant intervention may make matters worse.

Trading in shares of the American Photocopy Equipment Company was halted yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as the street was flooded with rumors of a takeover by the International Business Machines Corporation.
New York City's first cultural information center will open on Monday in a former shoe store just east of Carnegie Hall. Mayor Wagner will preside at the formal inauguration ceremonies at 11:30 A.M.
Tiffany's will close its stores today in Manhattan, San Francisco, Beverly Hills and Houston to revise its price tags in anticipation of the imminent repeal of the Federal retail excise tax.

It was jazz in the Garden in the rain last night as the Museum of Modern Art opened its summer outdoor series. Sonny Rollins and his new group played, and very few people left during the moist hour in which the tenor saxophonist performed.
The city was eager to sell three valuable parcels of land yesterday and bidders were on the scene ready to buy, but neither side got a chance to make a deal.
Twelve judgeships, all now unfilled, constitute the greatest leverage still available to Mayor Wagner to help steer the nomination of a Democratic successor who meets his approval.
The Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee has authorized its leaders to call a strike to enforce its demands to be recognized as the bargaining agent for cabbies and mechanics.

PARIS -- There is a perceptible effort by our European allies to disengage from the United States military commitment in Vietnam either by active dissociation, as France, or by pressure against further U.S. escalation of the Southeast Asian war, as Britain.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Almost every day some official of the Government tries to quell the anxiety in the country about Vietnam -- yesterday it was Secretary McNamara, today it was President Johnson -- but the troublesome questions remain.
LONDON, June 17 -- The Times of London denied a report that Lord Thomson of Fleet was negotiating to acquire control of it. Lord Thomson also issued a denial.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17 -- The Special Committee on Apartheid called on the Security Council today to urge all members of the United Nations to sever economic and military relations with South Africa and curtail diplomatic representation there until she revises her racial policies.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 17 -- The defending champion, Jim De Piro of Branch Brook, and three other experienced golfers gained the semi-final round of the 64th annual New Jersey amateur championship today at the Plainfield Country Club.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Following are highlights of President Johnson's news conference today:

One corner of a city playground at 76th Street and Riverside Drive was transformed by a Western style of barn-raising party yesterday into a miniature frontier town, and the pint-sized inhabitants promptly moved in.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17 -- Several thousand Big Red alumni will be the nucleus of a Cornell-Pennsylvania rooting section tomorrow as the American collegians face a combined Oxford and Cambridge track and field team in their seventh meet.

THE Spanish style is still the top favorite in furnishings at Stern's. In the five model rooms opening today on the store's seventh floor Spanish chairs, tables, storage pieces and accessories are found in liberal numbers. Last season's Spanish designs, beside the elevators, carry this season's sale prices.

Representative John V. Lindsay proposed yesterday that the Police Department be "computerized" to increase its efficiency by as much as 20 per cent. "It is time we realized that the two-way radio is no longer the hottest innovation in law-enforcement circles," the Republican candidate for Mayor said.

WHITE PLAINS, June 17 -- Westchester Republican leaders picked candidates tonight for county offices and state legislative seats. The party abetted by a favorable interim legislative redistricting that it sponsored, hopes to regain in November the two Senate and two Assembly posts it lost last fall.

CAIRO, June 17 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has ordered Egyptian economists to operate on the assumption that United States aid will not be renewed and has allocated $46 million in hard currency to buy the wheat required by the United Arab Republic for the next three months.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 17 -- Commercial bankers here for the 69th annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association voiced generally strong optimism today about the economy of the state.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday for the second consecutive day in quiet trading.

AREA A -- Although heavy northeast winds from an ocean disturbance halted most fishing this week, it was expected that the storm would cause good conditions on the weekend. The expectation was that warm water would be blown inshore and the bottom would be churned up, increasing bait activity.

TORONTO, June 17 -- The Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., a finance company that defaulted Tuesday on its entire debt of about $105 million, was placed in receivership today. The Montreal Trust Company was named as receiver and manager.
DARIEN, Conn., June 17 -- Triplicate, a 4-year-old chestnut mare with virtually no experience, won two green jumper classes today at the opening session of the four-day Ox Ridge Horse Show.
Dr. John J. Meng, president of Hunter College, warned yesterday that extremism was growing on many college campuses and that any student or teacher guilty of it deserved "instant expulsion."
The Owens-Coming Fiberglas Corporation announced yesterday the election as a director of James M. Kemper Jr., chairman and president of the Kansas City Commerce Trust Company.
Most prices declined by the close of trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday after a half-hearted rally fizzled. Trading was dull and industrials led the decline.
Two men stood in front of teller Norma Melendez of the Freedom National Bank in Harlem yesterday. They had deposit slips in their hands.

Ten thousand commuters were delayed up to two hours last night on the Harlem Division of the New York Central Railroad. The delays were caused by a fire at the North White Plains station that destroyed a wooden platform, a canopy and a small frame waiting room.

LONDON, June 17 -- Dennis Ralston, top-ranking player in the United States, had a tremendous tussle with Tony Roche, the best of the rising young Australians, to reach the semi-finals of the London grass-court championship at the Queens Club today.
DETROIT, June 17 (AP)-Norm Cash's eighth - inning home run paced the Detroit Tigers to a 6-5 victory today and handed the Boston Red Sox their seventh straight setback.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, introduced a bill today to strengthen Federal antilottery laws.

The three men convicted last Monday in Federal Court of plotting to blow up the Statute of Liberty and other national shrines were sentenced yesterday to terms of 10 years each in Federal Prison by Judge William B. Herlands.

The New York Newspaper Guild asked The New York Herald Tribune yesterday for "six months' advance notice of any change in operations which might affect the security" of the editorial and commercial employes it represents.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Ralph R. Roberts, clerk of the House of Representatives, said today that he had no plans to question the payroll status of the wife of Representative Adam Clayton Powell in response to another Congressman's request.
The appointment of A.W. Clausen as senior vice president of the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, was announced yesterday by R.A. Peterson, president.
Four issues -- American Photocopy, Control Data, Sperry Rand and Korvette -- accounted for one-fifth of the day's 5.22-million share turnover on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Xerox Corporation said yesterday it had withdrawn a 90-minute documentary program, "The Making of the President 1964," from the Columbia Broadcasting System network, and would place the film on individual stations.

BONN, June 17 -- A team of West German analysts, having studied developments in East Germany since the Berlin wall was raised four years ago, have conceded that the division of Germany is deeper than ever.

More than 50 persons seeking to organize a New York City chapter of the Citizens' Councils of America found themselves out in the street last night after being denied the use of two meeting halls in Astoria, Queens.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 17 -- A peace plan calling for elections this year for a new government will be presented tomorrow to both Dominican factions by an inter-American mediation commission, an informed source said today.

SAIGON, Friday, June 18 (AP) -- After the B-52's swept over their target north of Saigon early today, a Squadron of Vietnam-based B-57 twin-jet fighter-bombers made runs over the target, pouring explosives and fire bombs, rockets and cannon shells into the dense foliage and along streams and clearings in the area.

A record weekly increase of $538 million in business loans by the 14 weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York City was reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday for the week ended Wednesday.
The State Supreme Court ordered the City Commissioner of Marine and Aviation yesterday to meet with the union that conducted the recent 36-day strike against the Staten Island ferry service.

As the stock market's recovery movement continues -- prices posted a gain yesterday for the third session in a row -- there are signs that the big institutional investors are moving back into the market.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The big back meadow of Sargent Shriver's country estate in Maryland looked like a drill field today as squads of children marched in ragged formation to shouted orders, performed situps, hopped in and out of auto tires ranged on the grass and somersaulted through hoops.
ST. LOUIS, June 17 -- Kel Nagle, a 44-year-old challenger from Sydney, Australia, set the pace with a 68 as surprises marked the first round of the United States Open golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The big back meadow of Sargent Shriver's country estate in Maryland looked like a drill field today as squads of children marched in ragged formation to shouted orders, performed situps, hopped in and out of auto tires ranged on the grass and somersaulted through hoops.
ST. LOUIS, June 17 -- Kel Nagle, a 44-year-old challenger from Sydney, Australia, set the pace with a 68 as surprises marked the first round of the United States Open golf championship today.
ROME June 17 -- Italy's joint stock companies are prepared to fight a left-leaning reform program aimed primarily at bringing them under direct state supervision.

LONDON, June 17 -- Leaders of the British Commonwealth decided today to take an initiative toward bringing the war in Vietnam to an end. Prime Minister Wilson of Britain and leaders of four other Commonwealth countries will visit the Governments principally concerned to try to lay the groundwork for a peace conference.

BUFFALO, June 17 -- Mayor Chester C. Kowal, who was found unconscious in his City Hall office early yesterday after his indictment in a grand jury investigation of the city's refuse disposal operation, was reported much improved today.
LONDON, June 17 (UPI) -- Jean Borotra, France's famous "Bounding Basque," today failed for the first time to clinch a place at Wimbledon for the lawn tennis championships starting Monday.

ST. LOUIS., June 17 -- The monster stretched out in the bright sunlight today, flexing its muscles and snorting defiance at the world's finest golfers. The monster is the Bellerive Country Club, a gargantuan chunk of real estate that represents the longest course on which the United States Open ever has been played.

CINCINNATI June 17 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis, an influential Reform Jewish group, called on its 875 members today to keep a close watch on the allocation of Federal education funds in their communities to prevent use of the funds for sectarian purposes.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to authorize the Federal Government to keep forever the rifle that killed President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Administration program of medical care for the aged was radically revamped by the Senate Finance Committee today to shift a greater share of the benefits to persons with low income.
Directors of the Southern California Edison Company announced yesterday that they authorized plans to sell $75 million of convertible debentures at competitive bidding.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

GREENWICH, Conn., June 17 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club, carding 42, 44-86, and Mrs. Hoyt P. Steele of Stanwich, with 43, 43-86, tied for low gross in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament at Innis Arden Golf Club today.

BIRMINGHAM, England, June 17 (UPI) -- Henry Cooper retained his British and Empire heavyweight boxing titles tonight when Johnny Prescott quit in his corner after absorbing a fearful beating in the 10th round of a scheduled 15-round bout.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 17 -- Money, which has a habit of going to money, did not change direction tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, where Dartmouth won the $100,195.75 Realization Trot and made a number of already-rich folks richer.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Congress approved today the final text of legislation for $4.6 billion in reductions on excise taxes on a wide variety of consumer goods.

A bill establishing 225 graduate fellowships in social science and public and international affiars at universities in the state was signed by Governor Rockefeller yesterday at his New York City office, 22 West 55th Street.
Two savings and loan associations in the New York area promoted their senior vice presidents to president yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Intercity truck loadings and carloadings of railroad freight in the week ended last Saturday both rose substantially from the levels of the week in 1964.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) -- Claude Osteen allowed one hit, a second-inning single by Jack Hiatt, and John Roseboro drove in two runs tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the San Francisco Giants, 3-0.

PEKING, June 17 -- With a sharp attack on India, Communist China is coming out in the open with its campaign to exclude the Soviet Union, Malaysia and South Vietnam from the second African-Asian conference in Algiers.

DENVER, June 17 (AP) -- Flooding caused by heavy rains left a trail of destruction along the South Platte River Valley and elsewhere in Colorado today. Two persons died in the waters that hurtled out of the mountains yesterday.

Your June 9 editorial referred to the action taken by the Board of Estimate and the City Council in voting to approve the Mayor's budget as indicating that any hope has vanished that the Mayor could be rescued from his own fiscal recklessness.
TRENTON, June 17 -- Thorn Lord, New Jersey Democratic chairman, committed suicide yesterday by strangling himself with an electric cord, officials disclosed today.

It was not the customary sound of banjos or ballads that opened the first New York Folk Festival last night at Carnegie Hall. Rather, keeping right in touch with the music that has much of the world's youth on the go, or go-go, the festival began with "big beat" music.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 (UPI) -- Vernon Law scattered seven hits for his sixth straight victory tonight in leading the Pittsburgh Pirates, to a 4-1 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Iron ore will take an increasingly larger share of international trade, while steel's share continues to decline. That is the prediction of Erland Waldenstrom, president of the Grangesberg Company, Sweden's largest iron and steel company, who was interviewed here yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 -- Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky asserted today that he would become Premier despite the opposition of United States officials and Vietnamese political factions.

A selective list of restaurants New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Four stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.

The New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles equaled the longest game of the season in the major leagues last night -- 16 innings -- with the Orioles winning, it, 2-1, and sending the Yankees to their fourth straight defeat.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Johnson announced today the appointment of two former Southern political figures to the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Johnson, who has been devoting much of his energy to the foreign involvements of the United States, took time today to expound on his relations with Congress and to express his satisfaction with them.
WASHINGTON. June 17 -- President Johnson said today that the Federal budget deficit for the year ending June 30 would be about $3.8 billion, or $2.5 billion less than his estimate of last January.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- A $45,188,244,000 appropriation to finance the armed forces in the coming fiscal year was approved today by the House Appropriations Committee.

Thurman Arnold has been associated with the law 45 years, either as an innovator or a dissenter. He has been Assistant United States Attorney General, Associate Judge of the United States Court of Appeals, Yale law professor and a founding partner of the Washington law firm, Arnold, Fortas Porter.
MILWAUKEE, June 17 (UPI) -- Joe Torre's single with the bases filled in the eighth inning tonight enabled the Milwaukee Braves to defeat Philadelphia, 4-2.

BACK from Radcliffe, where for a couple of days she was again Chris Bernadotte, a young girl among college chums, Princess Christina Louise Helena of Sweden ticked off yet one more royal duty yesterday. She attended a fashion show at the Swedish Consulate, 600 Park Avenue, that consisted of designs by her countrymen.

DENVER, June 17 -- The terms of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 require individual colleges to make certain that fraternities do not discriminate on racial grounds, Francis Keppel, Commissioner of Education, declared today.

TRENTON, June 18 -- The Democratic and Republican parties of New Jersey agreed in their platforms released today that the state was in urgent need of more money, but they evaded the question of how it is to be raised.

DETROIT, June 18 -- Michigan officials agreed today to implement a sweeping Federal program to reduce pollution of the Detroit River and the Michigan waters of Lake Erie, of which the river is the principal tributary.

LISBON, June 18 -- A Portuguese mining company has concluded financing arrangements with a Krupp consortium for the bulk of a $62.5 million investment in the development of iron ore mines in Portugal's West African province of Angola.

TORONTO, June 18 -- Prolonged labor negotiations with pulp and paper producers in eastern Canada have been marked this week by wildest walkouts at two mills in the St. Catharines, Ont., area, west of Niagara Falls.

Christ Episcopal Church, 5030 Riverdale Avenue, the Bronx, announced yesterday the election of the Rev. Robert R. Rodie Jr. as rector. He will succeed the Rev. Gerald V. Barry who is retiring this month.
THE Goldman Band was back in its shell on the Central Park Mall last night to open the 48th year of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, and it was business as usual.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 18 (AP) -- Premier Tage Erlander said today on returning from a 10-day official visit to the Soviet Union that the case of the missing Swedish diplomat, Raoul Wallenberg, must be closed.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service of the Department of Justice on May 27 made the decision to withdraw its efforts to deport the five South African entertainers, appearing as "Zulu Dancers" at the World's Fair.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- The free medical and hospital care that the Federal Government provides for American-flag seamen should be halted, a committee of the American Medical Association said today.
Although President Johnson is trying to persuade Americans to travel at home this year to "narrow our tourist dollar gap," a record number of Americans are going abroad.

LONDON, Saturday, June 19 -- The London Daily Worker reported today that United States planes bombed and strafed North Vietnam's Central Leprosy Institute last Sunday and Monday, killing 82 patients and wounding 30.

WATERLOO, Belgium, June 18 -- Roger Temmerman's cows usually graze in the pasture next to his two-story brick farmhouse. In the pasture stands a stone monument dedicated "to the French soldiers killed at Houguemont, 18 June 1815."

New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are all committed now to permanent legislative reapportionment, in conformity with the one-man, one-vote doctrine of the United States Supreme Court, through state constitutional conventions. This is a far better procedure than leaving it to a legislature whose members inevitably have a vested interest in protecting their own seats.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Luci Johnson, with a romantic upsweep hairdo and full-skirted gown of white organdy, led a dancing party at the White House tonight for sons and daughters of diplomats from 60 nations.
The Savoy Plaza, one of the city's most elegant hotels for several decades, will be closed permanently June 30, three months ahead of schedule, to allow wreckers to get an early start.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 18 -- The membership of the Syracuse chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality has voted unanimously to declare a six-month moratorium in its campaign against the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.
I would like to make three comments on your hard-hitting editorial of June 9 "Ground War in Asia":
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Strategic Air Command's debut in Vietnam was hailed here today by some officials as an important success but widely viewed by others as a humiliating failure.

DESPITE women's outcries against very short skirts, designers keep lifting hemlines. Short hems no longer mean last year's top-of-the-knee arrangements, but three, four and even five inches of bared thigh, particularly when the wearer sits down.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- "Experienced and disciplined members of the Communist movement" were "deep in the heart of" a group that guided peace-shattering demonstrations last fall and winter on the University of California's Berkeley campus, a State Senate subcommittee charged today.

BELGRADE, June 18 -- Tonight when asked for his reaction to the report of his possible nomination as a candidate for Mayor of New York, Mr. Moynihan paused for 10 seconds, caught his breath and asked: "What ?"

A ceremony at Liberty Island today will commemorate the 80th anniversary of the arrival here of the Statue of Liberty and begin a year-long celebration of the centennial of the idea for a gift from the people of France to the people of the United States.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., is offering rights to holders of its common stock to subscribe for $21,852,800 of 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures on the basis of $100 principal amount of debentures for each 20 shares held of record June 17.
The New York Board of Rabbis has called a special all-day conference for the 40 Jewish chaplains serving state and city prisons.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 18 -- One of Nassau County's most powerful Republicans, Palmer D. Farrington, Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, abruptly announced today that he would not seek re-election and that he planned to resign "at once."
The New York Times reported in its June 17 editions that 23 companies had been charged in a civil action in Federal Court with diverting grain shipments from Austria to Iron Curtain countries.

The National Maritime Union yesterday proposed a three-point program for long-range solutions to problems of the maritime industry. The union said its program should be adopted "instead of cheap and easy expedients."

The screen is about to have what is believed to be its first Negro detective hero. Sidney Poitier, who won an Academy award two years ago for "Lilies of the Field," will play the detective of John Ball's novel, "In the Heat of the Night."
In his first major appointment since assuming office, Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick yesterday named a Negro, Capt. Eldridge Waith, to command the 32d Precinct in Harlem.
The maritime strike situation deteriorated rapidly last night, and Federal officials in Washington discussed plans to move mediation efforts to the capital.
TOKYO, June 18 -- A new Government program designed to revive Japan's sagging business, announced today, sparked an immediate rally on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

NEWARK, June 18 -- Three hundred people, off-duty policemen and their wives and children, held a noisy demonstration in front of City Hall today to protest the suspension of a patrolman who fatally Shot a Negro prisoner last Friday.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency said today that a precautionary inspection of Lockheed Jetstar aircraft had not turned up any serious deficiency.
The 14 Brooklyn Democratic leaders opposed to Stanley Steingut vowed yesterday to continue their fight to depose him as their chief.

The Museum of Modern Art announced the election of its new president, Mrs. Bliss Parkinson, succeeding, William A.M. Burden, former Ambassador to Belgium, who served almost continuously as president or chairman of the board in the last 12 years.

The giant American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has more than 72 million telephones on its lines, is being challenged in court by Allied Telephone Company, which serves some 5,000 subscribers in Arkansas.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 18 -- "I feel as though Shakespeare should come strolling out of that front door!" a woman exclaimed today as she stood in front of a gothic revival mansion here.
A DOCUMENTARY on the narcotic appeal of gambling, whether the ponies in Britain or the wheels and cards in Las Vegas, was presented last night on the network of the American Broadcasting Company.

DARIEN, Conn., June 18 -- Anakonda, a 9-year-old gray mare who has spent five years on the United States equestrian team with no particular distinction, won two open jumper classes in the Ox Ridge horse show today to take the lead for the championship.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 18 -- Twenty-four years ago a North Carolina youth named Marion Lawton Hargrove Jr., received a letter of greeting from the President of the United States.
GLADEWATER, Tex., June 18 (AP) -- Seventeen persons were wounded tonight when a clown fired a supposedly unloaded shotgun into a rodeo crowd as part of the entertainment.

MOSCOW, June 18 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia was welcomed by the leaders of the Soviet Union today. It was their first meeting since the downfall of former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev eight months ago.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 18 -- It is the miles of white beaches backed by white sand dunes and tall eucalyptus trees on the north bank of the River Plate that have fashioned the pace of Montevideo's leisurely and relaxed life.

The Publishers Association of New York City avoided any involvement yesterday in a possible merger of The New York Herald Tribune, The New York World-Telegram and The Sun, and The New York Journal-American.
TOKYO, June 18 -- The Government was told today that it would have to raise its cost estimates by nearly 70 per cent if it wanted to get a nuclear-powered ship built here.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 18 -- Two families won an important round today in their legal battle to prove discrimination by the Packanack Lake Country Club and Community Association of which they are resident members.

A 15-year-old boy died and four other children between 11 and 15 were hospitalized here last week after sniffing Carbona, a cleaning fluid, Dr. John R. Philp, Deputy Commissioner of Health, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Johnson said today that a campaign to find summer work for teen-agers had produced pledges of more than 300,000 jobs.

When the showers descended at Aqueduct yesterday, the form players indulged in a rare bit of altruism. "It's good for the farmers, makes the tomatoes grow, and anyway, Songster likes the mud," was the general tone of the dedicated Hippophiles in the crowd of 26,749.
DENVER, June 18 -- No Negro will become a member of Sigma Chi, the fraternity's national president predicted today.
The first New York Folk Festival moved into its second day at Carnegie Hall yesterday, offering two major concerts and a seminar-workshop, "The Face of Poverty."
Two Brooklyn congressmen demanded an investigation yesterday into the Defense Department's announcement that the United States Navy was considering the purchase of noncombatant ships from Britain.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 18 -- The Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, fighting bitterly for control of college athletes, exchanged charges of intimidation and outright behind-the-back recruiting today.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- Gary Player of South Africa took a one-stroke lead today in the United States Open golf championship as a foreign golfer set the pace for the second consecutive day.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Daniel P. Moynihan, an Assistant Secretary of Labor in the Johnson Administration, is being discussed in high Democratic circles as a possible candidate for Mayor of New York.
The Scott Paper Company is making a bid for business outside its regular line of products.

The Administration's medicare bill has been turned into a monstrosity by the revisions written into it by the Senate Finance Committee. Under the guise of helping the poor, the new measure flouts every principle of social insurance, introduces a universal means test and raises the cost of health protection for every aged person with an income of more than $800 a year.

SEOUL, South Korea,, June 18 -- About 750 students of two Seoul universities demonstrated today against the expected signing of the South Korean-Japanese diplomatic normalization treaty and against United States support for it.

LONDON, June 18 -- In two days of talks with Chancellor of the Exchequer James Callaghan, French Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing has emphasized a new flexibility in the French approach toward reforming the international monetary structure.

As a member of the Science and Astronautics Committee in the House of Representative it is my duty to review our nation's space program. In the Committee's reports to Congress in 1963 and 1964 I joined in views criticizing the lack of an American program to secure "inner space" and control it militarily.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The first recorded case of cholera in the United States in more than 50 years occurred here early this month. The patient, now doing well, is a laboratory technician involved in cholera research.

SAIGON, Saturday, June 19 (AP) -- Marshal Ky, taking office today, is the youngest Premier in the history of the Vietnamese Republic. A flamboyant, mustached airman, he has personally led his planes on air strikes against North Vietnam.
The New York County Democratic organization designated Mrs. Constance Baker Motley yesterday as its candidate for a full four-year term as Manhattan Borough President.

THE goals and processes of American education have come under increasingly critical scrutiny in recent years. In this passionately eloquent, flawed, important book, Edgar Z. Friedenberg, professor of sociology at the University of California, conducts us on a harrowing tour of what it means to be an adolescent in America today and, more specifically, what it means to be a student in an American high school today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders called on the Johnson Administration today to indicate the limits of concessions that might be made to the Communists to end the Vietnam war.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved yesterday against what he charged was a bidders' ring of 20 plumbing contractors who conspired to prevent the state from letting all work on the University Teaching Hospital project in Brooklyn through one general contractor.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association said yesterday that it had filed with the city's Department of Marine and Aviation a request for hearings for reinstatements of personnel that had struck the Staten Island ferryboats for 36 days.

MIAMI BEACH, June 18 -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that Republicans should make sure their organization and candidates were adequately financed before they contributed to the Free Society Association or any other "splinter group."

A patrolman testified yesterday that Gareth Martinis smelled of alcohol, swayed when he walked, had bloodshot eyes and was "excited, antagonistic and talkative" when he was tested for sobriety after a fatal automobile accident in which he had been involved.

As the city's water supply continued to drop yesterday, swimming-pool owners and others affected by the strict regulations of the city sought other sources -- purchases from out of state or from private wells here.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz conferred for one hour yesterday with officials of the Treasurers and Ticket Sellers Union, Local 751, on the provisions of the new bill governing the distribution of tickets to Broadway shows.

BONN, June 18 -- The West German government, spurred by continued high demand for a new issue of "peoples shares," has decided to give up its majority interest in Veba, a large energy producer in the process of partial denationalization.
ALBANY, June 18 -- Cigarette sales in New York have continued to lag behind last year's levels, the Department of Taxation and Finance announced today.

CINCINNATI, June 18 -- Spiritual leaders of American Reform Judaism sharply assailed today the use of catering establishments, vacation resorts and public halls by "unsynagogue-minded" Jews for important religious events.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- When James Plemon Coleman arrived at the University of Mississippi in 1931 he carried a sack of sweet potatoes and a burning ambition to be Governor of his state.
PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) -- A crowd of several hundred white persons demonstrated last night outside a northeast Philadelphia home reportedly purchased by a Negro couple.
The stock market drifted downhill yesterday in the slowest trading in nearly a month.

WASHINGTON, Pa., June 18 -- Bret Hanover, the wonder horse of harness racing, paced to a course record tonight at Delvin Miller's dream-track-come-true, The Meadows. Handling a field of 10 other 3-year-olds as he had handled every other rival during an unblemished career, Richard Downing's undefeated colt achieved his 29th victory over a span of a little more than a season.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18 -- The United States Strategic Air Command failed to inflict significant casualties on Vietcong troops in its first bombing mission over South Vietnam, an official announcement on the raid indicated today.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week in a bearish manner yesterday as most stocks declined in very quiet trading.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Radio Corporation of America will receive a patent next week for memory cells that, according to the company, will enable a computer to operate more like the human brain.

Great things are expected from the decision to eliminate excise taxes on everything from lipstick to air conditioners. The Administration predicts that the loss of revenue will be offset by increased business activity; to support this hope it points to the improved economic results -- and the reduced budget deficit -- stemming from last year's $14-billion reduction in corporate and individual taxes.

MRS. JEAN WEILL of Strasbourg, France finds no difficulty in deciding on a first course for luncheon and dinner to serve her guests. As the young attractive wife of one of the leading packers of foie gras, distributed under the Louis Henry label, Mrs. Weill has devised a number of different but simple presentations of the delicacy.
How's the New York Stock Exchange's monthly investment plan doing? Very well indeed, the Big Board reported yesterday.

LE MANS, France, June 18 (UPI) -- Phil Hill of Santa Monica Calif., at the wheel of a 7-liter Ford prototype, shattered the lap record for the Le Mans track today when he toured the 13.461-kilometer (eight-mile) circuit in 3 minutes 33 seconds at an average speed of 227.509 kilometers (141.362 miles) per hour.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 18 -- Even if diplomats from Washington and London had been pulling the strings, today's international track meet between Cornell and Pennsylvania and a combined Oxford-Cambridge team couldn't have had a happier ending.
Earl Brown, Manhattan's deputy borough president, was sworn in yesterday as the first paid chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights.

The political implications of the detonation of the first successful atomic device at Alamogordo are discussed in "Atomic Diplomacy: Hiroshima and Potsdam" by Gar Alperovitz. The author is a fellow at King's College, Cambridge and was special consultant for the recent N.B.C. White Paper, "The Decision to Drop the Atomic Bomb."
A team of Philadelphia psychiatrists has moved the arena of battle against mental illness from the relatively peaceful office couch to the patient's own home.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 18 -- The New York State Banking Department is expected to begin soon a major study of laws applicable to state chartered commercial banks.
S. Hurok will leave New York today for a three-month safari that will take him to the talent preserves of Hollywood, London, Moscow, Copenhagen, Warsaw and perhaps Paris and Rome.

NEW DELHI, June 18 -- A Government spokesman said today that India would withdraw from two posts seized May 17 on the Pakistani side of the Kashmir cease-fire line as soon as the United Nations established an observer team there.

HARTFORD, June 18 -- Chief Judge Jay Rubinow of the Circuit Court said today that a system under which incarcerated persons held on felony charges are released without bail if they are unable to furnish a bond has been extended to cover the entire Circuit Court in the state.

Bronx detectives questioned more than 35 persons yesterday in the Thursday-night shooting of Arthur (Fat Sam) Repola, a convicted narcotics peddler who is reputed to have been close to the late Waxey Gordon, the racketeer.

NORWALK, Conn., June 18 -- Art explosion that damaged the interior of a Darien school administrator's unoccupied, automobile here early yesterday has led to the arrest of three teenagers on a charge of willful damage to personal property.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A major indicator of future business trends -- the volume of new orders received by manufacturers of durable goods -- declined substantially in May. The number of new houses on which construction was begun also dropped during the month.

Governor Rockefeller should veto the Mackell bill permitting New York City to construct a 330-car garage under Sara Delano Roosevelt Park, on the lower East Side. The only reason this strictly municipal matter came before the Legislature was to bypass Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris, who has stubbornly -- and rightly -- refused to consent to such misuse of a Public park.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 18 -- Gene Francis and Al Schrafel Jr. of the home club scored a seven-under-par 33, 32 -- 65, to win the Long Island Golf Association best-ball championship at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

Igor Kipnis's Bach-Handel recital at the New School last night, part of the school's Summer Arts Festival, was held in the indoor auditorium instead of the courtyard. Indoors or out, the harpsichordist more than sustained the real "festival" quality of the series, established with last Sunday's program by the Galliard Players.
LONDON, June 18 -- Obstacles arose today in the path of Britain's plan to dispatch a Commonwealth mission to seek an end of the war in Vietnam.

BAMBERG, Germany, June 18 (UPI) -- The Bamberg Council of Elders today ordered civilian vigilante patrols set up to help the police protect citizens and property against the threat of violence and arson by neo-Nazis.
AMERICAN, folk art is beginning to find its place in the cultural sun and two events in recent weeks should help to put it there: the opening of a major folk art gallery and a lively new museum show.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- The Association of American Physicians and Surgeons, Ind., has sent every doctor in the country an appeal to boycott the Administration's medicare program when it is passed by Congress, a spokesman for the association said here today.

BERLIN, June 18 (AP) -- An armed helicopter manned by East Germans flew over United States Army installations today, an Army spokesman said. He called the flight a dangerous challenge to the Western allies.

The Kremlin leadership has given Marshal Tito the warmest possible welcome to Moscow. Amid all the flowers, artillery salutes and streamers proclaiming friendship, nobody was untactful enough to mention the Soviet-Yugoslav coolness of only a half-year ago when Tito was publicly praising the deposed Nikita Khrushchev and Moscow sent only a low-level delegation to the Yugoslav party congress.
BUDAPEST, June 18 (AP) -- Premier Janos Kadar said in an interview today that the Vietnamese conflict was slowing down improvement in East-West relations.

A reserved young man in a neat gray suit walked into a meeting room at the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday, put down his slim attache case, and looked over a table covered with brochures describing job opportunities.

EVERY now and again New York's major art dealers allow us more than a glimpse of their holdings, making us realize how much of the iceberg lies beneath the surface of what normally glitters in their show windows.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The attractiveness of the Peace Corps appears to be leveling off.

FAR HILLS, N.J., June 18 -- The chosen 950 who never knew a raindrop fell last night over the hilltop estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Engelhard Jr., had hundreds of skilled artisans to thank for the luxurious diversions from the elements.

TRENTON, June 18 -- Isgilde, an aged hay mare from the Cismont Manor Stables of Keswick, Va., scored 21 points today and won the regular working hunter championship as the three-day Mercer Hospital horse show got under way.

HONG KONG, June 18 -- Peking strongly denounced the Soviet Union today for attempting to "gate crash" the conference of African and Asian nations in Algiers starting June 29 and declared that the Chinese opposed Soviet participation as "a question of principle."
The Transit Authority was accused yesterday of asking the State Legislature to "validate allegedly illegal actions" to force construction of a new Manhattan-Queens subway tunnel at 63d Street.
Oscar Mayer Co., in line with major meat packers, reported a decline in earnings in the 26 weeks ended May 1, despite increased sales, according to the semiannual report of the Chicago-based company.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Ray C. Bliss, the Republican National Chairman, said today that he was against political splinter groups in general and against Barry Goldwater's Free Society Association in particular.
BONN, June 18 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard today entered a diplomatic tug-of-war between West Germany and Israel that is delaying the opening of diplomatic relations between them.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party called on the Senate today to refuse to confirm the appointment of James P. Coleman to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for authority to provide financial assistance to New York Airways to help that company sustain its common carrier helicopter service here in the metropolitan area.
The New York Philharmonic, Sir Malcolm Sargent conducting, with Moura Lympany, pianist, will repeat Thursday night's "Promenade" concert in Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30.
Customers' net debit balances, which show the borrowings of individual investors on margin, rose $58 million during May to reach $5,154,000,000, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.
ALBANY, June 18 -- An Alcoholic could be committed to a state hospital for six months if Governor Rockefeller signs a bill passed by the Legislature this week.
DENVER, June 18 (AP) -- Floods set off by violent thunderstorms poured out of the mountains and eastward across the plains from Montana to New Mexico today.

An indictment accusing three Black Muslims of second degree assault as the result of a melee in Harlem last May 31 was handed up yesterday by a New York County grand jury. They and three other Black Muslims were also charged with unlawful assembly with an intent to breach the peace.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the short-interest position of common shares on the exchange in the last month fell by 468,407 shares to the lowest point since January.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- The slumpbound New York Mets continued tonight to find runs hard to come by. Held to four hits by Jack Sanford and Frank Linzy, they lost, 3-0, to the San Francisco Giants before 12,788 blanket-wrapped fans at Candlestick Park.

Francis M. Flynn, publisher of The Daily News, denied yesterday a published charge that The News had bought the equipment of the defunct New York Mirror and resold it to scattered purchasers to hamper possible competition.

PARIS, June 18 -- Carlos de Beistegui, an elderly Mexican millionaire who is famous in Europe for his parties and his palaces, told the Duchess of Windsor last night that he was really an early bird, but about 500 other guests under his roof kept him awake until 2:30 A.M.
JACKSON, Miss., June 18 -- A total of 103 civil rights workers and Mississippi Negroes were arrested this afternoon in sporadic demonstrations around the capital city.
Lowly athlete's foot, a common and irritating fungus infection, is not the sort of thing one ordinarily associates with "wonder drugs," the glamour products of the pharmaceutical industry.
The first live telecast here of a European sports event is scheduled for 10:30 A.M. today when the American Broadcasting Company presents the start of the 24-hour automobile race in Le Mans, France.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 18 -- The most powerful rocket ever known to have been launched roared from a manmade island of sand here today, carrying with it the Air Force's hopes for its own man-in-space program.

GENEVA, June 18 -- George L.P. Weaver, United States Assistant Secretary of Labor, suggested today that Soviet workers exert their influence to get Communist North Vietnam to "come to the conference table."
After delaying for more than a year in one case and two years in the other, Governor Rockefeller has ended the uncertainty about two holdover commissionerships in the State Liquor Authority.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- During a poll today of communities planning arts councils, a man brought down the house at the largest conference of the nation's arts leaders when he rose, smiled and said:
The Shakespeare-in-the-park production of "Coriolanus," which is scheduled to open July 7 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, is shaping up as a family affair.
PARIS, June 18 -- Vice President Humphrey came to Paris today amid signs that the French Government might be seeking to improve its relations with Washington.
DETROIT, June 18 (UPI) -- The Ford Motor Company announced today that effective next Tuesday prices for its passenger cars would be reduced to reflect the cut in Federal excise taxes.
BONN, June 18 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard said today that the West must brace itself for new trouble instigated by Communists in Berlin.

A poll of the 230-member investment banking syndicate offering the $250 million issue of Chase Manhattan Bank capital notes disclosed yesterday that slightly more than 60 per cent of the securities have been sold to investors.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 18 -- There were 94 yachts left from an entry of 101 today to make reasonably sure that the bienniel race from this distinguished seafaring base to the equally distinguished one at Newport, R.I., would set a new record for starters.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- The terror of Bellerive Country Club is still alive. The 195-yard par-3 water hole sixth continued to smash the hopes of many in the United States Open golf championship today.
WASHINGTON June 18 -- President Johnson announced today that excise tax cuts on a wide variety of consumer goods would go into effect Tuesday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 19 -- Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky formally assumed office today as Premier of South Vietnam and declared that he would...
BLUE POINT, L.I., June 18 -- The Suffolk County Republican Committee, meeting at the party's headquarters tonight, designated candidates for local and state offices.

The decline and fall of the Yankee empire was delayed at least 24 hours last night when the Yankees fell on the Minnesota Twins for six runs in the first inning and powered their way to a 10-2 victory.
Sales of the nation's leading chain stores and mail order houses rose moderately in May, to complete a fourth year of consecutive monthly gains.
The recent decline in the stock market has failed to bring about any burst in short selling by the general public, and Wall Street brokers generally view this as a healthy precaution.

PLANDOME, L.I., June 18 -- Gwen Pallante of Cedar Brook finished with a 40, 40 -- 80 for a three-day score of 239 to win the Women's Cross County Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship by one stroke at the Plandome Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices was unchanged at 102.6 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended June 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- The Catholic Interracial Council urged its members today to avoid breaking the law in school demonstrations. It made its appeal as about 50 civil rights demonstrators marched again around City Hall, as they have almost daily for nearly two weeks.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 18 -- In a move directed against the United States, Jordan and France attempted today to obtain a Security Council decision that neither side should cross the cease-fire line in the Dominican Republic.
The Midwest Stock Exchange announced yesterday the suspension of a member company for violation of the exchange's "rules for insolvency."

Four patrolmen who squeezed into the front compartment of a police van yesterday while their prisoners were riding in the back found themselves in an even tighter spot after two of the prisoners managed to remove a rear window and wriggle out.
A State Supreme Court Justice refused yesterday to sanction a rent strike being conducted by tenants of a luxury East Side apartment house to protest alleged lack of services.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 18 -- A recast Yale crew, accorded only the slightest chance for victory, takes on mighty Harvard tomorrow for approximately 20 minutes of rowing over four miles on the Thames River. This will be the 100th Yale-Harvard crew race, an event that is the oldest intercollegiate athletic contest in America.
The Parke-Bernet Galleries yesterday reported receipts of $13,471,835 from its recently ended season of auction sales, its first under the ownership of Sotheby Co. of London.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 18 -- Jim Torre, a 46-year-old Newark policeman, and Paul McGowan, a 34-year-old ex-marine, gained the final round today of the 64th annual New Jersey amateur golf championship at the Plainfield County Club.
PARIS, June 18 -- Pierre Emil George Salinger, former press secretary to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, wed a French writer today and declared "this country is already full of my French cousins."
Retailers across the country were preparing yesterday to put into effect the repeal of Federal excise taxes on a variety of consumer goods, something they have sought for almost 25 years.
PARIS, June 18 -- In just a few days in 1794, everything that was movable was moved from the Palace of Versailles and sold by public auction. It is proving a long and costly job to get it back again.

A NUMBER of bridge celebrities, including such international stars as Harry Fishbein, Lee Hazen, and Mrs. Dorothy Hayden, were the guests of the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., when it began its duplicate season on Thursday night under the direction of William Root.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 18 -- Charlie Greene of the University of Nebraska, who vowed a year ago to become the world's fastest sprinter, moved closer to his goal today by winning the National Collegiate title in the 100-yard dash.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -Correspondence about Krebiozen was admitted into evidence today over objections of lawyers defending four men on trial for their part in promoting the chemical compound Krebiozen, which is taken by some cancer patients.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Congressional investigators accepted assurances by Secretary of the Army Stephen Ailes today that there was nothing improper in his ownership of stock in a finance company that specializes in loans to servicemen.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 18 -- Tanzania blocked today a wide range of imports from Kenya and Uganda, her two partners in the East African Common Market. Some of the restrictions, especially in foods, will force Tanzanians to prod their lagging home industries into greater activity.

SYRACUSE, June 18 -- Washington and California of the Far West and Cornell and Navy of the East are expected to lead the processions on Onondaga Lake tomorrow in the 63d regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 18 -- As the Organization of American States mission renewed efforts today to end the hostilities that have made this city a bloody battleground, the talk was of peace but the atmosphere was of war.
The British pound gained slightly in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.7915, up 3 points from the level on Thursday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 18 -- A Centerport housewife, who pleaded guilty April 21 to an indictment charging she gave out poisonous and buttons in trick -or-treat packages to neighborhood children last Halloween, received a suspended sentence here in Suffolk County Court today.

Fifty young women walked through a floral arch and became debutantes at the New York Cotillion in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton last night. The event was one of five scheduled between Wednesday and Monday night in other cities by the National Scholarship Committee of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs to aid its scholarship program.
A compact that would allow states to help formulate national policies in education was proposed yesterday by Terry Sanford, former Governor of North Carolina.
Eight men who could swing the balance of power in the campaign for Mayor will meet this morning in a sixth-floor suite at the Astor Hotel.

" I've got my Irish up and I'm not going to resign," Paul Hardeman said yesterday when questioned about press reports that he would not be a management nominee for re-election as a director of the Franchard Corporation at this year's annual meeting.

Until very recently the Johnson Administration arguments for continued United States participation in the Vietnam war seemed to me roughly to balance the counterarguments. But the events of recent weeks -- major Vietcong successes, more active involvement by larger numbers of American soldiers, and renewed political turmoil in Saigon -- demand of that majority of us who have apathetically supported the official position that we reconsider the matter.
It was a good day for the grain markets yesterday. All the major grains showed gains except wheat, which closed 3/4 of a cent lower to 1/4 cent higher.

PARIS, June 17 -- The Republican Congressional fact-finding mission to Paris failed to live up to the scornful predictions of its detractors. The Congressmen did not spend their nights in the Lido, nor their afternoons in the Folies-Bergere, as had been expected.
Harold Koppersmith, a 41-year-old teacher dismissed on Tuesday because of repeated tardiness, was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court on a charge of disorderly conduct.

MIAMI BEACH, June 18 -- State Senator Tom R. Van Sickle of Fort Scott, Kan., a self-described conservative who ran with the financial backing of Barry Goldwater's campaign organization, was elected today as chairman of the Young Republican National Federation.
There are two factual fallacies in the reasoning of Leo Klaubor's June 7 letter in support of English literacy as a qualification for voting.
PARIS, June 18 -- An ambitious effort to unite the non-Communist left with the non-Gaullist center to end the seven-year reign of Gaullism collapsed early today.

If appearance were all, Sheila Jordan would have had a great success at Judson Hall last night. Miss Jordan is a Striking-looking woman whose brown hair, cut in a bushy sort of Dutch bob, frames a beautifully sculptured face and exciting eyes.
LONDON, June 18 -- It will be Dennis Ralston, the No. 1 player in the United States, against Roy Emerson, the world's top amateur, for the London grass-court championship tomorrow.
TOKYO -- Fresh octopus and ready-to-heat broiled eels from the deep freeze are among the newest examples of the industrial revolution now going on in Japanese kitchens.
Prices continued to drift downward yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -Robert C. Weaver, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, challenged the architectural profession today to channel "the pressure cooker forces of urbanization" into building a more beautiful America.

Or et Argent picked up a check for $38,675 for negotiable United States specie for his owner, Colin Campbell, at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old French-bred with the precious metals name won that amount by finishing first in the Bowling Green Handicap on the turf.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 -- Souther (Chick) Whittelsey sailed Interlude to the Luders-16 Class victory on Long Island Sound today during the season's eighth East-of-Rye Regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets of the Connecticut area.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The cheap way to restore a failing superiority complex is to stop at the drugstore and buy an armful of movie magazines. Talk about misery! Nobody knows what misery is until he has had three hours on the couch with the movie magazines.
Mr. Horwitz apparently was concerned chiefly with the Older Americans Act of 1965, but he ignored the important factor of inflation.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Gary Player's bid to take the United States Open golf title home to Johannesburg was closer to fulfillment today. The little South African was two strokes ahead at 211 after a third round of 71, achieved at the Bellerive Country Club course during 80-degree temperatures.
Tony Lema, who won the world series of golf last year, has a chance for another shot at the $50,000 top prize this year even if he fails to win one of the world's four major titles.
WAS the remarkable 13-hour manifestation at the White House last Monday its first and last Festival of the Arts there? Should there be another? Could it be duplicated or improved?

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 19 (UPI) -- Argentine-bred Tronado raced to a neck victory today in the $54,800 Inglewood Handicap at Hollywood Park, fighting off the challenge of Hill Rise in the final strides.
LOS ANGELES, June 19 (AP) -- Nick Willhite, with ninth-inning help, pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-0 victory over the Philadelpia Phillies today.
In the bouncy field of broadcasting, Station KWO-35 hardly qualifies as an example of what the industry sometimes refers to as "color radio."

SUMMER is the most severe season for northern lawns of cool-season grasses. The intense droughts of recent years have been especially damaging and many lawns are precariously close to serious trouble, but careful maintenance will greatly reduce the chances for serious summer injury.
Live picture coverage of the start of the Le Mans Grand Prix was wiped out yesterday by a technical failure at the ground station scheduled to feed the images to the Early Bird satellite.
Small as well as big companies are playing a part in efforts this year to cut the nation's multibillion-dollar foreign payments deficit.

Even as space explorers sterilize rockets slated to land on other celestial bodies so as not to contaminate them with traces of terrestrial life, the earth's newest "land mass" was recently declared a national preserve, off-limits to tourists and other casual visitors who might clutter it and distort the picture scientists are trying to get of how life becomes established on barren land.

FOUR gold medals were awarded to Americans at WIPA 1965, the Vienna International Philatelic Exhibition, which ended a week ago yesterday. Over-all, 53 medals were won by Americans, with several others receiving diplomas.

I HAVE a view on the handling accorded what Lester D. Johnson, Acting Commissioner of Customs, calls "ordinary citizens." It is rather at variance with his. I enclose a copy of the note I have sent to Mr. Johnson:
HOUSTON, June 19 (AP) -- Gene Freese's pinch-hit single and a double by Jose Pagan produced the tie-breaking run in the 11th inning as the Pittsburgh Pirate defeated Houston, 5-3, today.
ALGIERS, June 19 -- A bloodless coup d'etat by the army early today ousted President Ahmed Ben Bella, who was accused of being a "diabolical dictator" during his 33-month rule.
ALEXANDER H. COHEN, the Broadway producer, appearing last weekend on the "Monitor" radio program, offered a list of what he felt were the most influential factors in the sale of theater tickets.

LE MANS, France, June 19 -- The 24 hours of Le Mans, considered the world's sternest test of men, and race-cars, began its growling, howling run around to nowhere today under a remorseless sun that cooked the bear and baked the 51 snarling little automobiles that started the race.

A conductor's and a composer's dream of a better break for contemporary music has resulted, after two years of planning, organizing and hoping, in a grant of $265,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation to Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J.

MAY I assure Tom Jones that there is at least one teacher who does not hate musicals? On the contrary, I believe that several musicals of the last three decades are among the most important creative achievements of our theater.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 19 (UPI) -- Recent events have brought about a deterioration of relations between the major powers who "seem powerless to arrest it," Senator J.W. Fulbright said today.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Department of the Interior became today the first Federal agency to offer direct birth-control advice and services, including contraceptives.

LONDON, June 19 -- The celebration of the 750th anniversary of Magna Carta coincided this week with the beginning of what is described as the first major effort to rationalize all British law that has accumulated since the charter.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 -- In an early season full of pleasant surprises for the high-flying Los Angeles Dodgers, the development of bridge-playing Wes Parker into a top-drawer first-baseman is most significant.

THIS will be a strange summer for that venerable comedian and senior citizen of Beverly Hills, Jack Benny. For the first time in 33 years. Benny does not find himself in the midst of hectic preparations for a new season on radio or television.
Don Spero, Frank Sulger and Pete Virsis, the New York Athletic Club's champion scullers, will compete in the Royal British Henley championships June 28 to July 3 on the Thames River, Henley.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 19 -- Adios Ronnie led all the way to win the $12,500 feature mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. He upset the 17-to-20 favorite, Oreti, who finished third before a crowd of 37,382.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 19 -- The breeze died during the Beach Point Yacht Club Regatta today and none of the 106 boats that started was able to complete a race within the time limit.
Summer begins tomorrow and, in the light of the recent decline in the stock market, many puzzled investors are asking that seasonal question: "Will we see a summer rally?"

An article about the Tower of London in the Travel Section of June 6 noted that visitors could obtain permission to view the nightly locking of the main Tower gates, also called the Ceremony of the Keys, "by writing a letter, well in advance of the date desired, to the Resident Governor and Major of the Tower, Constable's Office, H.M. CINCINNATI, June 19 (AP) -- Jim Maloney, who pitched a 10-inning no-hitter his last time out, stopped Chicago on two hits for six innings today, but needed help from Joe Nuxhall before Cincinnati defeated the Cubs, 9-4.
Though Andrew Hacker's article "The College Grad Has Been Short-Changed" (June 6) displays his customary insight and breadth of knowledge, it seems to me needlessly gloomy in its conclusion.

PARIS, June 19 -- Paris sources suggested today that the bloodless coup d'etat by the Algerian Army had been set off by domestic events and would not lead to major changes in Algerian attitudes toward France and other Western powers.
The debate on international monetary reform is heating up.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 19 -- A 3-year-old bloodhound, Ch. St. Hubert Basilisk owned by Nancy F. Onthank of Greenwich, Conn., defeated 884 opponents today to win the best-in-show title at the 45th annual Bryn Mawr Kennel Club event.
The firemen's union and the nation's railroads are dueling with words and statistics over the effects of having taken the third man out of freight and yard locomotives.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 19 -- Jim Ryun of Wichita, Kan., set meet records of 4 minutes 4.3 seconds for the mile and 9:04 for the two-mile tonight in the sixth annual Golden West invitation track and field meet for high school seniors.

ROME, June 19 -- A projected visit by Pope Paul VI to the United Nations in New York raises many problems of policy, diplomacy and timing that must be resolved before any Vatican confirmation of plans for the trip can be made, according to church sources here.

WEIRS, N.H., June 19 -- A steel-helmeted police riot squad, backed up by National Guardsmen firing rock salt pellets and a fire truck dispersing tear gas, formed a battle line tonight to break up a riot by 10,000 young persons at Weirs Beach.

MONTREAL -- The difference between Expo '67, the Canadian world exhibition scheduled to be opened here on April 28, 1967, and any other world exposition or world's fair is that the Canadian event will become a tourist attraction two years before it greets its first paying customer.
EVERGLADES, Fla. -- This town on the lower Gulf Coast came close to passing into oblivion a few years ago. But it is now back on its feet again, and this time recovery seems to be permanent.
CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP) -- Fred Whitfield's bases-loaded single in the ninth inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 1-0 victory today over the Los Angeles Angels.

THERE are two witticisms which have survived the 1947 House Un-American Activities Committee's investigation of Hollywood. One of them is in this book. Ring Lardner Jr., asked by the committee if he was a member of the Communist party, replied, "I could answer it, but if I did, I would hate myself in the morning."

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 19 -- Don Rubell of Brooklyn opened play in the 29th annual Eastern clay-court tennis championships today with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Will Cammack of the Bronx. Rubell is seeded first in the tournament at the Oritani Field Club.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Republican leaders in Congress have begun to amalgamate into a party line their increasingly critical comments on President Johnson's conduct of the war in Vietnam. The movement has not yet developed into one of those definite inter-party cleavages on foreign policy that have been periodic in American history.

SYDNEY. "WE have no racial problems and we don't intend to create them," Australia's Minister for Immigration, Hubert Opperman, said recently in London. This year, Australia hopes to attract 145,000 new immigrants -- not one of them African or Asian. But while the country may be out of bounds to colored immigrants, inside white Australia's portals there is a growing nucleus of blacks, the Aborigines, who were there first.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 19 -- A strange and un-Latin paralysis has gripped this former model for the Alliance for Progress. FOR almost 25 years, Alfred Drake has been the ideal hero of the American musical theater. While the distaff side has had Merman, Martin and Channing, and more recently, Burnett and Streisand, there has been only one man -- Drake. He commanded two long-run hits, "Oklahoma!" and "Kiss Me Kate," and, beginning Tuesday, will star again in his biggest personal success, "Kismet," at the State Theater.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19 -- The Harvard varsity crew rowed the four long miles down the Thames River here this evening with the effortless ease reserved for a casual paddle on a pond. Far in the Crimson's wake came Yale as the Harvard eight gave its rival a fearful trouncing winning by lengths.

Patterson Jr. of the Public Events Department proclaimed Bartholdi Day in honor of the monument's French sculptor.
