PARIS, June 20 (UPI) -- Hundreds of screaming teenagers fought among themselves and against the police here tonight after a performance by the Beatles.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 20 -- Australia is wrestling with the effects of one of the worst droughts of the century.
HANS BERLINER of Washington, many times a contender in the United States open and invitational tournaments, won the recent District of Columbia chess championship.

PARIS, June 20 -- Hyeres III, a French mare, won the $64,000 Grand Steeplechase of Paris today for the second year in succession. The runner-up was Yasco, 1 1/2 lengths away, who also placed second last year.

Few of Bernard M. Baruch's associations with the world's great were as richly satisfactory as his friendship with Sir Winston Churchill. Brendan Bracken, long a Churchill aide, once wrote Mr. Baruch: "Nature has made you and Winston Churchill for each other and it does you great good to meet."
The Potomac Boat Club of Washington captured five events and scored 138 points to the 97th annual New capture York Athletic Club regatta yesterday on the Hunter's Island lagoon Olympic rowing course.

The establishment of an international mooring forum, with participation by some of the world's major oil companies, has been announced by M.J.H. Kirby, marine coordinator for the Shell group of companies.

A hotel convention center planned to be one of the largest in the country will be built as part of a multi-million dollar renovation program being undertaken by the new owners of the largest hotels in Charlotte, N.C., the Queen Charlotte and the Savoy-Barringer.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 19 -- A leading national banker forecast here that "unless the stock market is telling us we're in for a recession, I expect loan demand to continue strong."

In full view of baseball's largest crowd in four years, the New York Yankees fell farther out of contention in the American League race yesterday by losing a double-header to the Minnesota Twins, 6-4 and 7-4.
HARTFORD, June 20 -- Mark Twain's "celebrated jumping frog of Calaveras County" would have found the competition here yesterday just as unpredictable.
The Pilot, official newspaper of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, has editorially defended what it describes as "poor old pomp."
The Father Mendel Garden of Heredity, honoring the discoverer of the fundamental laws of genetics, was dedicated yesterday at the Vatican Pavilion in the World's Fair.
New York City policemen will start collecting signatures this week on petitions of their own to oppose a civilian review board for the Police Department.
ALBANY, June 20 -- Democratic legislative leaders were reported tonight to favor a major change in New York City's primary-election machinery.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 20 -- Jim McElreath of Arlington, Tex., driving John Zink's new rear-mounted Offenhauser, had the distinction of winning the first race on Langhorne's newly paved D-shaped mile track today.

GOLF: Gary Player, three holes away from his first United States Open championship, shot a double-bogey at the Bellerive Country Club in St. Louis yesterday and wound up in a tie with Kel Nagle of Australia. The pair will meet in an 18-hole playoff today. Player, from South Africa, held a three-stroke lead going into the 16th hole, a par three, where he faltered. Nagle, meanwhile, scored a birdie on the 606-yard 17th.

Priscilla Gordon, a Virginia-born soprano, and Alberto Figols, a tenor from Honduras, were presented in joint recital at Town Hall Saturday night by La Sociedad Honduras N.Y., Inc. Chances are that few New Yorkers have heard of the society, but it must be thanked for an unusually interesting evening.

LE MANS, France, June 20 -- Snarling along at 121 miles an hour, a blood-red Ferrari won the 24 Hours of Le Mans today, the sixth time in a row the Italian car has taken the annual French picnic with wheels.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 20. -- The Ford Motor Company of Australia has announced the first major issue of debentures to be made by an American company here since the United States tightened the flow of capital overseas early this year.

Yale Express System, Inc., said over the weekend that the operations of its two major divisions, the Yale Transport Corporation and the Republic Carloading and Distrib uting Company, Inc., would be separated.

ROME, June 20 -- Pope Paul VI completed today the second year of his reign, a year in which he marked out as his main temporal concerns the search for world peace and action to wipe out poverty and hunger.

The Metropolitan Opera will present its first concert of the season at Lewisohn Stadium at 8:30 tonight. Fausto Cleva will conduct, with Renata Tebaldi, soprano, Louis Sgarro, bass, and the Metropolitan Opera Chorus and Orchestra.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 -- The exact destination is unknown, but the United States Open Trophy is heading overseas for the first time since Ted Ray took it to Bonnie Britain in 1920. The direction may be vaguely described as southerly, but still in doubt is whether it will go to South Africa or Australia.
ROCKTON, Ill., June 20 (AP) -- Sandra Haynie won a sudden-death play-off from Kathy Whitworth and Mrs. Marlene Hagge today to take the $9,500 Cosmopolitan Women's open golf tournament.

Serious drama is a losing venture on Broadway, as shown by the record of the 1964-65 season. A dozen new dramas were produced. All failed. The only long-running drama, "The Subject Was Roses," opened at the end of the 1963-64 season.

They also know that human folly or human error won't influence the unpredictable date of the next eruption. That is up to God. But for 20 years we have all lived under the threat of nuclear warfare, knowing well that fallible mortals have the power to destroy much of mankind.

The Connecticut College School of Dance has been granted $10,200 by the Rockefeller Foundation to commission new works from Paul Draper, Lucas Hoving and Jose Limon. The works will be given their premieres in August in New London, during the college's 1965 American Dance Festival.

Poland has proposed that members of the Communist Bloc's international bank make their next capital contribution in the form of gold or freely convertible currencies. The proposal is aimed as a first step toward creating a transferable ruble fully convertible into gold or the major world trading currencies.

New musicals will be tried out Sunday nights, starting in the winter, for invited audiences at the 300-seat Forum Theater beneath the Vivian Beaumont Theater at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The program was announced yesterday by Richard Rodgers, president and producing director of Lincoln Center's Music Theater.

In the East River sits an island of 167 acres that was called Minnahanonck by the Indians, Varcken (Hog) Eylandt by the Dutch, Ferkens or Perkens by the English. Later it was called Manning's Island after its owner, Capt. John Manning, who in 1673 tamely surrendered New Netherlands to the Dutch when they briefly recaptured it and who was court-martialed and disgraced.

Today's college student who rejects conventional values and uses "phony" to describe much of what he sees had a counterpart in Koheleth, the author of the Old Testament's Book of Ecclesiastes, the executive minister of Riverside Church said yesterday.

Nearly 40 hours of performing time after it started Thursday night, the first New York Folk Festival closed last night. A 10-foot photograph of Carl Sandburg, the poet and pioneer folk-song popularizer, gazed down benignly from the stage of Carnegie Hall.

IN today's increasingly competitive, child-centered society, mothers and fathers never seem to run out of causes for anxiety. The current tension-producer for 4-to-6-year-old parents (as childhood experts are wont to call them) is the once pleasurable subject of reading.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- A panel of three Federal judges has taken under submission the trial evidence in the Government's attempt to break up the merger of two California banking giants. It will be months before the court decides whether there is ground for the step.

American medical scientists are collecting 50,000 human pituitary glands each year for a research program designed, among other things, to help dwarfed children grow to normal height.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 -- The defending champion, Roy Emerson -- the best amateur in the game -- is the favorite in the 79th All-England lawn tennis championships that open tomorrow in this historic oval a few miles from London.

In your June 11 editorial "A Divorce Law Study -- At Last" you pointed out that the Joint Legislative Committee authorized by the practically unanimous vote of both houses of the Legislature could do the necessary job of modernizing our ancient divorce law "if the chairman, to be drawn from the Senate, is a man capable of providing strong leadership."

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Federal Government has decided to help keep the New Haven Railroad's New York City commuter service running for as long as the next 18 months, according to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Johnson announced today that 54 countries would be represented at an international meeting in water desalting to be held in Washington Oct. 3 to 9.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP) -- Sam McDowell pitched a two-hitter and Lee Stange a five-hitter today as the Cleveland Indians swept a double-header from the Los Angeles Angels, 5-0 and 3-1, to extend their winning streak to nine games.
MOSCOW, June 20 -- The first contacts between the United States and Soviet footwear industries were established here last week by a leading American shoe manufacturer.

DARIEN, Conn., June 20 -- Anakonda won the open jumper championship at the Oxridge horse show today, but the 9-year-old gray mare was not on hand to receive the tricolor. Nor did she compete in the final class, the bonus point stake.

PARIS, June 20 -- The Tour de France, this country's most popular sports event, hits the road this week. Another Tour de France, even longer and only slightly less crowd-pleasing, crossed the finish line at the Elysee Palace today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 20 -- Amid a grave political and financial crisis, several influential political leaders are making a determined effort to preserve Uruguay as the oldest exponent in Latin America of the two-party system.

LACONIA, N.H., June 20 -- The motorcycles, their engines sounding insolently powerful, their helmeted riders still looking hip, roared out of here tonight, leaving this lake resort area in peace. TRW, Inc., has announced the appointment of Robert A. Burgin to the new post of vice president and assistant to the chairman. Mr. Burgin formerly served as a group vice president.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, June 21 -- Negotiations are being concluded for the sale of Huntington Hartford's multimillion dollar Paradise Island development off Nassau to the Mary Carter Paint Company of Tampa, Fla., the Lang Construction Company of London, and Jeffery Russell of London.

BONN, June 21 -- East Germany extended today a rapidly unfolding campaign to obtain from the Western world a higher measure of political recognition.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 21 (UPI) -- The Government has agreed to pay 5 million rupees or about $1l.5 million at official foreign exchange rates, as compensation to three oil companies, Esso, Caltex and Shell, whose properties were nationalized by the Government Petroleum Corporation two years ago during the regime of former Premier Mrs. Sirmiavo Bandaranaike.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 21 -- Thomas J. Harwood, Supervisor of Islip Township for eight and a half years, resigned today to take a newly created position as confidential secretary to Suffolk's Republican-dominated Board of Supervisors.
HONG KONG, June 21 -- Peking indicated tonight that the British Commonwealth peace mission on Vietnam would not be received in China.

After beating a field that included an odds-on favorite, Mrs. Charles Morgan's Chairman's Choice survived a foul claim and gained the victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Skeeter II was 3 1/2 lengths ahead of the Cain Hoy Stable's Pluck at the end of the one-mile purse.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 (AP) -- Kel Nagle's tee shot that struck a woman on the head today may have been the turning point in the playoff for the United States Open golf title.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -The Senate Armed Services Committee, responding to Administration wishes, rejected today a House-approved provision giving Congress a veto over the closing of military bases.
City Council President Paul R. Screvane announced yesterday the selection of three close associates of Mayor Wagner for his campaign staff.

WHITE PLAINS, June 21 -- A wild-goose chase on the lakes, rivers and reservoirs of Westchester County today resulted in the capture of 176 Canada geese, ganders and goslings for relocation in the hinterlands of Maine.
An immediate start in planning for a fourth jetport for the New York area was advocated yesterday by Harold E. Gray, president of Pan American World Airways.

Play Schools Association, a voluntary organization with which I have been associated for 48 years, and which I now am proud to serve as president, helps in making summer a happier and more constructive time for city-bound children and their parents.
The Interpublic group of Companies, Inc., that behemoth of advertising and many related services, has embraced yet another service -- that of international financial consultants.

BALDWIN, L.I., June 21 -- Ralph G. Caso of Merrick, a 47-year-old lawyer and Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, was designated tonight at the Republican candidate for Presiding Supervisor of Hempstead in the November elections by the Hempstead Town Committee.

A self-sustaining rapid transit commuter service between Westport, Conn., and Grand Central Terminal could be developed on New Haven Railroad tracks, according to a report made public yesterday by the New Haven Commuter Study Group, a private organization.
LONDON, June 21 -- Eight manufacturing companies were fined a total of $285,600 today for fixing prices in violation of a pledge under Britain's anti-trust laws.

The Latin American Times, an English-language newspaper covering news of the Americas, will begin five-day-a-week publication here on June 30, it was announced yesterday by Jorge Losada, the editor in chief.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 21 (AP) -- The color-conscious Government of South Africa is taking steps to settle the delicate case of the sun-tanned settler.

Alfred S. Wells, who began his career with the Corn Products Company 39 years ago as an office boy, has been elected to the newly created post of senior vice president for purchasing and distribution, the company announced over the weekend.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges has reported the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
MOSCOW, June 21 -- The Soviet Union made it clear today that it would not compromise on the basic beliefs of Communist ideology to heal the rift with Communist China.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 21 (UPI) -- Congolese rebels have killed all policemen in an attack on Nioki, a village 200 miles northeast of Leopoldville, a survivor reported today.
LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- A coroner has ruled that the deaths of two Queens teen-agers, whose bodies were found in a station wagon here, were a double suicide.
Dr. George James will retire as the Commissioner of Health on Oct. 31 to become vice president of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and dean of the new Mount Sinai School of Medicine.
The race to Atlanta between the two rival professional football leagues, the National and American, took another turn here yesterday and it was an obvious one by the 14 owners of the N.F.L.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 21 -- Britain, Canada and four Nordic countries pledged donations of $17,780,000 today to help extricate the United Nations from a financial crisis that had forced it to borrow to meet its payroll.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21 -- An athletic version of lend-lease will be on display tomorrow afternoon when a combined Yale-Harvard track team meets the Oxford-Cambridge squad of England at Harvard Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that the next 60 days would be the most critical for the American merchant marine since the passage of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.
While a large part of Wall Street's working population spent yesterday puzzling over the stock market decline, an attractive girl with hazel eyes and ash-blonde hair calmly was discussing automation.

The Ex-Cell-O Corporation. Detroit precision equipment and machine tool producer, has achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or six month period in its history, H.G. Bixby, president, reported yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 22 -- Tran Van Dong, a Vietcong terrorist who was accused of having attempted to blow up a United States officers' billet, was executed by a military firing squad at 5:55 A.M. today in the capital's central market place.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 -- In a green valley between two towering ridges, about 60 miles south of Hanoi, four lumbering United States Navy fighter planes desperately turned and banked to elude two pursuing Communist MIG jets.
The New York Giants announced yesterday that Joe Walton, the 29-year-old offensive end with eight seasons in the National Football League, had retired from active duty and would become a game scout.

How independent of the Democrats can the Liberal party be when a major public office is at stake? The question is now being tested as decision time approaches for the designation of a candidate for Mayor of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- With a lone voice raised in protest, the House voted today to make the assassination of a President or Vice President a Federal crime punishable by death.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21 -- The yachts that began the Annapolis-to-Newport race last Saturday were moving briskly toward the finish today on the wings of fresh winds from the south-southwest. It appeared likely that this would be one of the fastest passages of the biennial fixture.
Adios, widely acknowledged as the greatest standardbred procreator whose progency has earned nearly $15 million, is near death at the age of 25.

MOSCOW, June 21 (AP) -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, the Soviet Army commander in World War II, denounced today criticism voiced during the Khrushchev era that he had delayed the final strike against Berlin.

TORONTO, June 21 -- A Chrysler Corporation executive and a United States official, in addresses to the Air Pollution Control Association, differed today in their approach to controlling motor vehicle exhaust.

ALBANY, June 21 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed his secretary, Dr. William J. Ronan, to the $45,000-a-year chairmanship of the newly created Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority.

Officers of the Newspaper Guild of New York conferred yesterday with Joseph Kingsbury-Smith, publisher of The Journal-American, about reports that three of the city's newspapers were discussing joint, cost-saving operations.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission proposed today rules to limit television ownership to three stations in the 50 largest television market areas. No more than two could be very high frequency stations.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Cautiously and as unobstrusively as possible, the Administration is going ahead in helping underdeveloped nations curb their growing populations.
For most commodities futures, yesterday was a day of drift -- downwards. This fact inspired some discouraged and puzzled comments from commodity brokers and dealers.

" I TRY to love each course I play," Gary Jim Player once said. "I can't fight each course." His love affair with the links started spectacularly. The first time he ever played with his own clubs, he parred the first three holes.
SAIGON, June 21 (Reuters) -- More than 40 South Vietnamese Government troops were listed as dead or missing today following two Vietcong attacks and an ambush in the last 48 hours.

FRANKFURT, Germany -- Is the high-flying West German economy ready to come in for a landing? A few observers, with one eye on West Germany's recently weak ening international payments position, are starting to ask this question.
NHATRANG, South Vietnam June 20 -- An army field hospital is a place to learn about some aspects of war.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- Ed Bosse fired a second-round 66 and then defeated Claude Young of Winding Brook in a sudden-death playoff to gain a spot in the National Professional Golfer's Association tournament.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 21 -- The village of Walton (population 3.855) is going to try to stop the City of New York (population 7,781,984) from taking water from the Cannonsville Reservoir on the west branch of the Delaware River.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- "Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to another session of Third Degree, the prize-winning program that grills the nation's news makers until they beg for mercy. Today's news maker is Harold Pompey of Elk Track, N.Y.
The Studebaker Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had renegotiated $17 million of short-term debt into a long-term obligation at a more favorable rate of interest than it had been paying.
The seven singers who cluster around the piano on the tiny stage of the PLaza 9-introduce themselves three times each evening by proclaiming, "We're here because Julius Monk is not."
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the "rising tide of crime and fear on our subways has been reversed."
Ten resolutions calling for a doctors' boycott of medicare when the bill passes Congress were introduced yesterday in the House of Delegates of the American Medical...

LONDON -- It was Englishmen in their dark well-cut suits who once provided London with a somber sartorial glory. No one thinks much about them any more. All the attention goes to girls in short skirts with striking haircuts who are no less fierce about fashion than the long-haired young men who switch shirts twice a day.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a bill to designate the Indiana Dunes as a national lakeshore. The action was taken on a voice vote with no debate and no opposition.
Stocks sagged yesterday in the sleepiest session since last summer.
Councilman Joseph T. Sharkey, long a colorful figure in New York politics, said yesterday the time had come for him to end a 33-year career as a city legislator that had spanned five administrations.
ALBANY, June 21 -- Half of Governor Rockefeller's $400 million program to increase the state's outdoor recreation facilities cleared the Assembly today with hardly a dissent.
London stock exchange prices, reaching new lows for 1965, led a general downward price trend in foreign exchange markets yesterday. Prices in Zurich, however, were able to swim upstream.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 21 -- The call for a general strike by Dominican labor leaders was virtually ignored today.
Snow and ice and cold winter blasts, combined with Christmas carols and sleighs and presents -- that was the scene yesterday as the nation's stores went shopping here for their holiday displays.
All promotions to the rank of captain in the Police Department were frozen yesterday as the result of an eight-ear-old charge of unfair grading in a City Civil Service examination.

The College of Electors of the Hall of Fame at New York University is giving special study to five of the 225 nominees in the 1965 election. The five were recommended by the Committee of 21, a preliminary balloting group of the national shrine.
ENGLAND, June 21 -- It was a miserable day for tennis but a great one for the British as the All-England lawn tennis tournament opened under soggy skies this afternoon.

THAT time of year when almost any girl or woman with some office training can sail in and get a temporary job is rolling around again. The need for temporary office work ers is always most pronounced during the vacation months of July, August and September and the shortage is expected to be greater than ever this summer, according to the services (they do not want to be called agencies) that supply such help.

TOKYO, June 19 -- Japan is considering a series of loans totaling about $10 million to Nigeria, Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda to enable these African nations to improve their trade-balance position with this country, the Foreign Office said today.
CLEVELAND, June 21 (UPI) -- Jim Brown, the star fullback of the Cleveland Browns, was charged today with assault and battery by an 18-year-old girl.
HOLLYWOOD, June 21 -- The major motion-picture studios here are following the television networks in increasing their output designed specifically for teen-agers.

Carl Ullrich, the Columbia crew coach since 1961, resigned yesterday following a season in which the Lions failed to win a race and Ullrich dropped nine oarsmen for violations of training regulations.

Bernard Mannes Baruch was a speculator, as he described himself, and an immensely successful one. But he preferred to be known as an adviser to Presidents. He became a power and an authority, but he never quite attained all of the authority or the power that were within his grasp.
An unusual form of pneumonia, followed by complica- plications, is proving to be a common cause of the death of patients who have received kidney transplants, according to a report here yesterday.
Thirty-eight rare violins, making up one of the most notable private collections in the world, have been acquired by Rembert Wurlitzer, Inc., New York violin dealer.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- Gary Player of South Africa won the United States Open golf title today in a non-American playoff. With a 71, the sprightly, 29-year-old professional from Johannesburg defeated Kelvin Nagle of Sydney, Australia, by three strokes and then turned back the winner's check of $25,000.

A PLAYER who takes a save over an opposing game contract will usually know when the deal is over whether the save was a profitable one. But occasionally he will find that the opponent would have had some trouble.
Declines outnumbered gains by more than two to one on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as trading volume slumped to its lowest level t since Jan. 4.

IT was almost the same. Almost. Lewisohn Stadium was well filled last night for the start of the summer concerts there, and the physical characteristics of the plant were largely unchanged. There was a new orchestra shell, and there was a new amplifying system, neither of which looked very different unless one was looking for differences.
J. Stewart Baker Jr. resigned yesterday as a senior vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank to become president of the Alpha Portland Cement Company.

A better-than-expected increase in bank earnings so far this year is reported in the June, 1965, Bank Stock Quarterly, published by the M.A. Schapiro Co., Inc., underwriter, broker and dealer in bank securities.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- To be disregarded is the common fate of those who most clearly perceive the oncoming disasters of mankind and are the first to give warning. Although the career of Bernard M. Baruch was one of great and protean achievement, it was this lot of men of extraordinary prescience that denied him the most important contributions he could have made to the age in which he lived.

TORONTO, June 21 -- The Great Northern Capital Corporation said today it was discussing sale of its controlling interest in the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, the Toronto finance company that was put in receivership last week after defaulting on its $105 million debt.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- By a roll-call vote of 300 to 0, the House today passed a bill to make it easier for students to attend business, trade, technical and other vocational schools.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., June 21 -- Fifty Negroes and five whites marched 12 miles through Philadelphia and Neshoba County today to commemorate the first anniversary of the slaying of three civil rights workers. The march went without incident and the Congress of Racial Equality said it had signaled an "awakening" among the Negroes of Neshoba County.

Atheneum will publish on July 7 "The Making of a President 1964," by Theodore H. White. The author, a journalist and author since 1939, won a Pulitzer prize for "The Making of a President 1960." Mr. White has this to say about these two books: "I happen to think that American polities is one of the noblest arts of mankind; and I cannot do anything else but write about it."
TRENTON, June 21 (AP) -- Nonprofit private hospitals must bargain with their employes' unions, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

President Johnson and Robert F. Kennedy told different versions of how Mr. Johnson informed Mr. Kennedy in 1964 that he would not be the Democratic candidate for Vice President, according to a new book by Theodore H. White, which went on sale yesterday.
Steel production in the United States rose 1.8 per cent last week, to 2.74 million tons of ingot and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Johnson signed the bill to reduce excise taxes by $4.7 billion today and committed himself to future tax relief for the poor.
DALLAS, June 21 (AP) -- District Judge Joe B. Brown, who presided over Jack L. Ruby's murder trial, was removed at his own request today from further proceedings
The British pound edged ahead yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency served warning today it would crack down on pilots who buzzed crowded beach and resort areas.
HARTFORD, June 21 -Dr. Albert C. Jacobs, president of Trinity College here, announced today that the men's liberal arts school had received a challenge...

KATONAH, N.Y., June 20 -- The 20th annual Caramoor festival got under way last night and, despite the sudden downpour and chilly temperature, the concert was a real pleasure. The music was good and the Walter and Lucie Rosen estate near Katonah, the site of the festival, was as beautiful as ever.
WHITE PLAINS, June 21 -- Westchester Republicans, in a convention unmarred by floor fights, designated tonight a full slate of candidates for the November elections.
LONDON, June 21 -- The Commonwealth peace mission on Vietnam pressed on with its plans today despite the unpromising first response from Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China.

When the Kansas City Athletics begin a four-game series at Yankee Stadium tonight with a double-header starting at 5 P.M., they will perform the same function for the New York Yankees that a small mirror does when placed near the lips of a dying man: they will reveal whether there is any visible sign of life.

Water Commissioner Armand D'Angelo urged Mayor Wagner yesterday to look into the feasibility of tapping the Hudson River. This was one of three plans offered as a means of augmenting the city's dwindling water supply.
BROOKS Robinson leaned on his 33-ounce bat and his .318 batting average the other day and fielded a question, which is a pretty good trick, even for the most valuable player in the American League.
PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP) -- Gov. John Connally of Texas said today current oil and gas explorations were not sufficient to maintain a healthy domestic industry.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- McGeorge Bundy, in a debate with his academic critics tonight, defended the Administration's policy on Vietnam as necessary to keep a commitment to South Vietnam, to strengthen world order and confidence in the support of the United States, and to prevent Communist aggression against other nations.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Anthony J. Celebrezze, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today approval of grants and loans totaling $63.7 million to 130 colleges and universities to help finance construction of new facilities.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Johnson announced today he would appoint LeRoy Collins to succeed Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as Under Secretary of Commerce.

CAIRO, June 21 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser's top aide returned today from an urgent mission to Algeria described by informed sources here as an effort to save the life of former President Ben Bella.
Government-bond prices continued to inch upward yesterday, and trading activity increased.
Representative John V. Lindsay took his campaign for Mayor to the sweltering sidewalks of the Lower East Side and the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn yesterday.

ROME, June 21 (Comtelburo) -- The simultaneous issue of a bond loan by the National Electricity Board (E.N.EL.) in Italy and in European Economic Community countries "in the next few weeks" was jointly announced tonight by E.N.EL. and by Mediobanca of Milan.
THE Ute Indian tribe at the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation, Fort Duchesne, Utah, once again will offer their Nu Tuveep hunting expeditions to visiting sportsmen.
PARIS, June 21 -- To foreigners who watched him when he was the power behind the Ben Bella regime, Colonel Boumedienne always seemed withdrawn elusive and mysterious.

LONDON, June 21 -- Thirteen African and Asian nations of the British Commonwealth called on the new Algerian Government today to postpone the conference of 50 African and Asian countries scheduled to begin in Algiers June 29.

Plans were filed yesterday with the Department of Buildings for a 45-story office building that will be built on a superblock -- four blocks made into one -- bounded by South, Whitehall, Water and Broad Streets, near the Battery. Costs are estimated at $26,750,000.
The extension of the durable-press concept to all-cotton garments has received a big push with the announcement of a new mechanical process that stretches cotton fibers.
Mayor Wagner formally opened New York City's first cultural Information Center yesterday. It is at 148 West 57th Street.

Senator Russell Long's successful disintegration of the medicare bill will prove a disservice, not only to the people who will suffer from it, but also to the reputations of lawmakers who permit their legislative activities to take on a life of their own without realizing that laws are means to ends, and not ends in themselves.
Skulduggery in mail-order laboratories could provide the plot for a medical serial, but tonight it will be investigated on Walter Cronkite's evening news.

After 63 years of operation, Saks-34th Street, at Herald Square, began a "going out of business" sale yesterday. The first-day's results indicate that the promotion may be the most successful the store has ever held.

CRANSTON, R.I., June 21 -- The Narragansett Brewing Company announced today an agreement of sale to the Falstaff Brewing Corporation of St. Louis for $17.5 million in cash and $2 million in Falstaff common stock.

Barbara Cavanagh stood among 150 guests at a Gracie Mansion lawn party early last evening wearing dark glasses, a triple strand of pearls, and a blue linen dress trimmed in green. Her ring finger was covered with a white glove wrapped so conspicuously around her knuckles that dozens of people soon began sneaking peaks at it, and photographers soon began taking pictures of it.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 -- A four-year agreement, providing for a total increase of 3.2 per cent each year in wages and fringe benefits, has been reached by West Coast shipowners and deck officers.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 21 -- Fourteen Cambodian soldiers and a Thai police officer were killed yesterday in clashes near the Thai-Cambodian frontier, 255 miles southeast of Bangkok in Trat Province.

DETROIT, June 21 -- The 2.7 million member Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod, one of the most theologically conservative of this country's major Protestant denominations, is making historic advances in the area of ecumenical, or cooperative, Christianity.

PARIS, June 21 (Reuters) -- Riot policemen and troops occupied the center of Algiers tonight after an afternoon of demonstrations supporting former President Ben Bella, according to reports reaching here.
James Farmer, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality said at a news conference yesterday that the organization planned to step up its political activities in Newark and elsewhere.

BUENOS AIRES, June 22 -- Foreign Minister Miguel Angel Zavala Ortiz charged last night that a profusion of mediators in the Dominican crisis had hindered rather than helped the Organization of American States in its quest for a settlement.

ALBANY, June 22 -- The sponsor of a quarter-horse racing bill brought a stunned hush to the Assembly chamber today when he disclosed that he and his family had been threatened by anonymous telephone calls and that the last call had been traced to the Assembly switchboard.
ALBANY, Wednesday, June 23 -- One of the longest, most disorganized, most controversial yet most productive sessions of the Legislature crept toward adjournment this morning.

It was a meat-and-potatoes day on the commodities exchanges yesterday as pork bellies, from which bacon is sliced, and potatoes proved to be the significant upward movers in an otherwise quiet trading day.

The Clerk of the House of Representatives has stated that he has no intention of looking into the eligibility of Mrs. Adam Clayton Powell for the annual salary of $18,907 she draws as a staff member of the House Education and Welfare Committee, of which her husband is chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- George W. Mitchell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, called today for more sophisticated measures of the degree of concentration in banking for use in weighing merger proposals.
BONN, June 22 -- Most young American executives probably would give up their eye-teeth and their noontime martinis for a foreign assignment.
The Bank of America announced yesterday the appointment of C.J. Medberry and J.F. Herwood as senior vice presidents. They formerly were vice presidents.
The annul four-day Newport Jazz Festival will open this year on July 1 at a new locale and with a broadened spectrum.
The New York Yankees broke a three-game losing streak, but still slipped a notch nearer limbo last night when they split a double-header with the last-place Kansas City Athletics.
HOLLYWOOD, June 22 -- David O. Selznick, one of the leading producers in the motion picture industry, died of a coronary occlusion this afternoon at Mount Sinai Hospital.
The Ford Foundation's secondary offering of six million shares of Ford Motor Company common stock was quickly sold out yesterday morning after being offered to the public at $52.25 a share.

ATLANTA, June 22 (UPI) -- Delta Air Lines, Inc., announced today it had joined the free-for-all race for a franchise to operate the third route service between New York and Boston and Florida now served by Northeast Airlines.
CAMRANH BAY, South Vietnam, June 21 -- "Have you got any problems?" the American general asked the junior South Vietnamese naval officer.
Duke Ellington's "Golden Broom and the Green Apple" and Leonard Bernstein's "Chichester Psalms" will be given world premieres at the New York Philharmonic's French-American festival in July.
CLEVELAND, June 22 (UPI) -- The Lake Carriers Association said today shipments of iron ore, coal and grain over the Great Lakes in May increased over the like month of last year.

BALTIMORE, June 22 (UPI) -- Earl Wilson pitched a four-hitter tonight as the Boston Red Sox handed Robin Roberts his seventh straight defeat, 4-2. The victory gave the Red Sox a split in a double-header with Baltimore after the Orioles took the opener, 4-1.

Queens Borough President Mario J. Cariello said yesterday that he would ask the City Council to amend the City Charter to give broader voting powers to the five Borough Presidents who sit on the Site Selection Board.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Sales of new homes in the first four months of the year trailed sales in the similar period of 1964 by 6,000 homes, the Census Bureau said today.
The British pound fell in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
The stock market put in another lazy day yesterday as traders assessed the Ford Foundation's secondary offering of six million Ford shares.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Johnson has decided that it is in the national interest to send the United Arab Republic the $37 million in surplus farm products still undelivered under a three-year contract that expires June 30.

O. Roy Chalk, the multimillionaire businessman, has sent letters to every member of the House in an effort to get approval of four amendments to a bill authorizing the construction of a subway system in Washington.

Now that the $3 million Federal grant essential to maintaining the New Haven Railroad's commuter service into New York for the next eighteen months seems assured, some of the longer-range problems require urgent attention. The engineering study just released by the New Haven Commuter Study Group, Inc., indicates that some drastic cuts will be required to keep it going without continuing subsidy.
HOLLYWOOD, June 22 (AP) -- Chester Conklin, the walrus-mustached Keystone Kop of the silent screen, has eloped at the age of 79.
LONDON, June 22 -- A Soviet diplomat here has indicated that his Government will let the Commonwealth peace mission on Vietnam visit Moscow.
TRENTON, June 22 (AP) -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today he would appoint a panel to investigate Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
Consumers responded sluggishly on the first day of Federal excise tax reductions yesterday, but indications were strong that their interest would soon quicken.

Algeria's new leader, Col. Houari Boumedienne, is a tough but shy revolutionary. The austere colonel is no orator, no crowd pleaser, and he knows it. He is more doer than talker, more Arab than French and much more Islamic than Marxist.

Worldwide distribution rights, excluding six countries, to Dino DeLaurentiis's Italian-made production of "The Bible," have been acquired by 20th Century-Fox. The announcement of the deal was made yesterday by Darryl F. Zanuck, president of Fox.
The refusal of filing clerks to make Criminal Court records available for public inspection was, in effect, overruled yesterday in a unanimous decision of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

The appointment of Fred P. Schmitt as general manager for the United States Lines on the Pacific Coast with headquarters in San Francisco was announced yesterday by William B. Rand, president of the company.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 22 -- The first major benefit of the summer season here, the annual Rose Show, was held Saturday at the Parrish Museum on Jobs Lane. Some 400 persons attended the seventh annual event, sponsored by the Southampton Garden Club for the benefit of its civic projects.

PARIS -- Nothing of a specific nature was accomplished by Sunday's de Gaulle-Humphrey colloquy. Nevertheless, it helped emphasize a suddenly friendlier mood in Franco-American relationships. These had seemed to be deteriorating to a degree that disturbed not only the United States Government but important French officials and a considerable body of this country's public opinion.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, June 23 -- Seoul was a tense city filled with helmeted policemen and troop convoys moving through the streets in a show of force yesterday as the hour for the treaty-signing in Tokyo drew near.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Seven civil rights demonstrators who staged a sit-in inside the White House on March 11 were sentenced today to serve 180 days each in jail. Their attorney said he would appeal.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 22 -- A three-and-a-half-year-old oil dispute ended today with the signing of an agreement giving three oil companies -- units of British Shell and of Esso and Caltex of the United States -- about $11 million in compensation for property seized by the Ceylonese Government in 1961.
PASADENA, Calif., June 22 -- "If I was an octopus, I'd have all eight fingers crossed."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22 -- A combined Harvard-Yale track squad, heavily fortified with Crimson athletes, staged a surprising uprising early tonight to defeat an Oxford-Cambridge team, 11-5, in the biennial meet.

Shareholders of the Ethyl Corporation, at a special meeting held yesterday in Richmond, Va., approved the reclassification of the class A and B common stock into one class of common stock with general voting rights.

GRIFFIN, Ga., June 22 (AP) -- City officials closed public swimming pools and youth centers today rather than integrate them and the Justice Department began an investigation under the Civil Rights Act.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 (AP) -- The performing arts have undergone tremendous expansion in the last 20 years but almost all of it has been in the amateur field, the president of Actors Equity Association said today.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The University of Mississippi Law School said today that it would seek out Negro students from low-income families under a new Ford Foundation scholarship program.

Walter Scott Co. has assembled the east blockfront of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) between 36th and 37th Streets and plans to erect a 32-story office tower with ground floor showrooms on the site.

Just where is the economy headed? The answer, according to the Johnson Administration, is onward and upward. Its spokesmen scoff at the threat, seen by Federal Reserve Chairman William McChesney Martin Jr., of an unstable boom followed by a bust.
Paperboard production rose to 396,400 tons in the week ended June 19, from 387,932 tons in the corresponding 1964 week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

Varese of Italy must win its match tonight with West Ham United of London at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, to remain in the fight for the first section title in the International Soccer League tournament.
On every square mile of this city an average of 60 tons of heavy dust falls each month.
MILWAUKEE, June 22 (UPI) -- Doug Clemens's three-run homer in the third inning tonight touched off a 12-hit Chicago Cubs attack that included six doubles and trounced the Milwaukee Braves, 6-1.

HOUSTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Randy Matson, the world shot-put record holder, said today a knee injury would keep him out of the Amateur Athletic Union meet this weekend, but he hopes to get on the United States team for a Russian meet just the same.

The Cities Service Company went outside the oil industry to select its new chairman and chief executive officer in designating John L. Burns yesterday to the top posts effective Jan. 1. The new president, effective on the same date, will be Charles S. Mitchell, who has spent his entire business career with the petroleum company.

ALGIERS, June 22 -- Amid conflicting reports on the prospects for convening the Asian-African leaders' conference here next Tuesday, Col. Houari Boumedienne's four-day-old regime sought today to show continuity at home and to gain recognition abroad.

A RACE with a $1,000 purse has been added to the program for the United States road racing championship meeting at Watkins Glen, N.Y., this weekend. A 46-mile consolation event has been authorized by the Sports Car Club of America for those cars and drivers who fail to qualify for the main event.
CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) -- Chuck Hinton led off the 10th inning with a home run, giving the Cleveland Indians a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight for their 10th straight triumph.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 -- Dennis Ralston beat Ham Richardson, 15-13, 9-7, 6-2, before an enthralled crowd at the Wimbledon tennis tournament today.

The New York Post suspended publication "temporarily" late yesterday afternoon following an appeal from its publisher that the newspaper be allowed to introduce a new method of setting type. When the members of New York Typographical Union No. 6 rejected the personal request of Dorothy Schiff, the publisher, the management told the entire staff that there was "no work to be performed."
WASHINGTON, Pa., June 22 (UPI) -- Adios, the sire of many harness racing champions, died today.

THREE museum exhibitions opening today insure visitors and New Yorkers alike that throughout the summer they will have something to look at in the field of contemporary art. These are "Young America 1965" at the Whitney Museum of American Art; "Works of Art in Editions" at the Museum of Modern Art, and a big print show at the Brooklyn Museum.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick yesterday named John F. Shanley chief inspector, the highest rank in the department.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe for an easy-to-prepare main dish is given.

DETROIT, June 22 -- The theologically conservative Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod began debate here today on a proposal to join three other church bodies in a new cooperative agency that will unite most of the nation's 8,600,000 Lutherans in a joint program of theological study and service activities.
CONCORD, Calif., June 22 -- A luxury-type rapid transit car with carpeted floor, large tinted windows and wide, upholstered seats for 72 passengers was unveiled here today.
General Mills, Inc., the nation's largest flour miller, attained record earnings in the fiscal year ended on May 30.

WHERE the kitchen is concerned, there is probably no group in the nation today more deserving of panegyrics than the paper products people. Working in the vicinity of sink and stove without wax paper, paper towels and related materials is well-nigh unthinkable.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced in Cincinnati yesterday the appointment of Murray Sawits as a vice president.

Standing stiffly at attention under a sweltering sun that beat down on City Hall Plaza 56 new Housing Authority patrolmen were sworn in yesterday as members of a force dedicated to protecting the 535,000 residents of the authority's 136 developments.
Indian Head Mills, Inc., a producer of cotton products, hosiery and metal parts, announced yesterday the election of Royall Victor Jr. as a director.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22 -- A remarkable feat in distance yacht racing developed tonight when the 57-foot aluminum yawl named Dyna, owned and sailed adroitly by Clayton Ewing of Easton, Md., not only triumphed again in the fastest Annapolis-to-Newport event, but remained unbeaten in her division for the third time in a row.
Representative John V. Lindsay called last night for a "drastic overhaul" of the city's Civil Service, in which, he asserted, "efficiency is merely tolerated and incompetence often rewarded."

TOKYO, June 22 -- Japan and South Korea today signed a treaty and 20 related documents restoring full diplomatic relations after a lapse of 55 years. The action was a result of 14 years of intermittent negotiations.
DETROIT, June 22 (AP) -- George Brunet held Detroit hitless for six innings tonight and wound up with a 3-hitter as the Los Angeles Angels beat the Tigers, 3-0.
New issues of utility and commercial bank bonds, capital notes and debentures were sold to investors in impressively heavy volume yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, June 22 -- The reported extortion of $350 from a white youth at New Rochelle High School by a Negro classmate who promised "protection" from other Negro students was investigated today by the Westchester District Attorney's office.

PARIS, June, 22 -- What is called the largest exhibition of American sculpture ever to have been shown in Europe was of-officially inaugurated at the Musee Rodin today. It has been organized by the International Council of New York's Museum of Modern Art, shipped across the Atlantic by the United States Lines and installed with the help of the Rodin's staff.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 22 -- The resignation of Finance Minister Hernando Duran Dussan late yesterday sent shock waves through the business community here. The first impact today was to tumble the peso by 50 points to a record low of 19.70 to the dollar.

The Saigon Government, totally dependent on American support, stated that terrorists, corrupt officials, speculators and black marketeers will be shot without trial but with maximum publicity (New York Times, June 17).

WHO was the greatest of all heavyweight champions, Jack Dempsey or Joe Louis? This was the one question that was constantly and unfailingly asked at every stop made by the U.S.O. troupe of Fred Corcoran, Jack Sharkey and Lefty Gomez during their overseas trips to entertain servicemen during World War II. Corcoran, the master of ceremonies, adroitly handed that teaser to Sharkey, the only man ever to fight them both.

FRANKFORT, Ky., June 22 -- An angry delegation of Eastern Kentucky mountaineers, staged a 175-mile motorcade the Capitol here today to protest the Spread of strip coal mining on their impoverished land.

The letter of Prof. Herman Finer published June 13 misses its mark widely in supporting Secretary of State Rusk and chiding Prof. Vera Micheles Dean for taking issue with the Secretary's pronouncement on those who are bewildered by our foreign policy and actions.

WHITE PLAINS, June 22 -- Westchester Democrats unveiled tonight a slate of candidates they hope will end in November the Republicans' 57 years of "one-party rule" in this county and increase the 1964 Democratic gains in Westchester's legislative representation at Albany.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Justice Department has offered to set aside requests for records from six New York daily newspapers issued last week as part of an antitrust investigation.

A special committee of the City Council that has been studying air pollution since early this year reported yesterday that New York's foul air was a contributing factor in an increasing death rate from respiratory diseases and lung cancer.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22 -- More than 20 generals have been knocked out of military life in the political struggle in South Vietnam.
The City Council voted 29-4 yesterday to set a record basic real estate tax rate of $4.56 for each $100 of assessed valuation.
An Illinois woman who gave up her plane seat to a man was sent a thank you note yesterday by a top executive of American Airlines. Last Sunday, she was wined and dined for her gesture.
The battle for Atlanta among the rival pro football leagues, is all but over, with the latecomer, the National Football League, the winner over the American League.

No one knows the real scope of the problem posed by dependence on stimulant and sedative drugs, speakers told the American Medical Association yesterday, but they agreed the problem is a matter of concern.
Frank D. O'Connor, who has been Queens District Attorney since 1956, plans to announce today that he is officially joining the battle for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

NASHVILLE, June 22 -- Southern School News, a monthly publication that has documented school desegregation in Southern and border states since the Supreme Court desegregation decision of 1954, appeared for the last time today.
About $45 million of State and municipal bonds were sold yesterday to underwriters who faced a market that at best could be called moderately active.

NEW DELHI, June 22 -- Followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi invited President Sukarno of Indonesia today to come here and study the principles of nonviolence taught by the late leader of India's independence movement.

SAIGON, Wednesday, June 23 (AP) -- South Vietnamese forces killed 54 Vietcong and captured 15 in an operation north of Danang, a United States Army spokesman said today. He said the government forces had suffered 3 dead and 12 wounded in the operation, which has been going on since Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate Banking Committee rejected today by an 8-6 vote a mandatory ban against American companies' supplying information to Arab countries in furtherance of the Arab economic boycott of Israel.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 (UPI) -- Vernon Law hit a three-run homer in the second inning tonight, then set down San Francisco on four hits as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored a 6-0 victory over the Giants.

HOUSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Richie Allen's two-run single and Tony Gonzalez' inside-the-park two-run homer marked a Philadelphia five-run seventh inning tonight as the Phillies defeated the Houston Astro's 7 -- 2.
NEW JERSEY youths expecting to hunt this fall are reminded by the state's Fish and Game Division that they must meet qualifications for a hunting license.

The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in total operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended May 31. Operating revenues rose to $351,723,315 from $327,220,308 in the 1964 period.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Following is the text of a letter on population explosion from former President Dwight E. Eisenhower to Senator Ernest Gruening, Democrat of Alaska, who is chairman of the Senate Government Operations subcommittee on foreign aid expenditures:

PITTSBURGH, June 22 (AP) -- The Governors of Texas, Louisiana and Kansas expressed serious concern today over the level of oil imports and steadily increasing petroleum production from Federal leases off the Louisiana coast.

JOHN UPDIKE, 33 years old, author of two volumes of poetry, two of short stories and three novels, recipient of the 1964 National Book Award for Fiction and an elected member of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, occupies a most curious position among American writers. Every so often, when it comes to mind, he is hailed as one of our most talented writers -- perhaps the most talented -- certainly promising.

TORONTO, June 22 -- A research team has found that from Jan. 29 to Feb. 12, 1963 heavy air pollution was a major factor, along with an epidemic of Asian influenza and extreme cold, in causing 617 more deaths than normal in New York City.

A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted two former American Stock Exchange specialists, Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re and his son, Gerard R. Re, for conspiracy and evasion of $964,241.61 in Federal income taxes during 1958 and 1959.

APPARENTLY one of the facts of life that the Music Theater of Lincoln Center must face when it chooses a musical for the New York State Theater is that it must select something that will fill the stage, something that can be caparisoned to magnetize the eye and make the play a conversation piece.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey said today that President de Gaulle "would like to see" President Johnson.

Alger Lee Christian, a member of the American freighter Almeria Lykes, was reported to be in satisfactory condition in the sick bay of the West German liner Bremen after undergoing a four-hour emergency operation early yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- President Johnson today nominated two astronauts, Comdr. Waiter M. Schirra and Lieut. Comdr. John W. Young, for Navy promotions.
New York City's Council Against Poverty laid down ground rules rules yesterday for determing the membership committees to administer the antipoverty program in poor neighborhoods.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 -- The Mets jumped to a two-run lead on the Los Angeles Dodgers in the second inning tonight, but couldn't make it stand up and had to settle for an even break in their exciting, low-scoring four-game series with the National League leaders.

COLOGNE, Germany, June 22 -- A group of 160 grown men wearing short pants, colored shirts and funny little hats, pedaled their bicycles slowly out of Cologne's Fair Grounds and into European sports history today.
A 45-year-old certified public accountant was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison for giving $1,000 in bribes and tips to Internal Revenue Service auditors.

LONDON, June 22 -- Queen Elizabeth II led a brief but moving ceremony at Westminster Hall today to mark the 700th anniversary of the summoning of the first Parliament.

The Rev. Merle S. Irwin was elected moderator of the United Presbyterian Synod of New York last night as delegates from presbyteries in New York and Puerto Rico began a three-day meeting at Keuka College in Keuka Park, N.Y.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22 -- Mrs. Irving Kaufman of Century and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, the co-medalists, led the way today into the second round of the 62d annual women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.
A second edition of "A Teacher's Guide to Lincoln Center" has been published by Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A new era of good feeling has enveloped the once fractious relations of the building trades and industrial unions of the building trades and industrial American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
BUFFALO, June 22 (AP) -- Mayor Chester C. Kowal, who was indicted for conspiracy this month by an Erie County grand jury, said tonight he would not run for re-election this year.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Delta Air lines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today for authority to operate between Boston and New York and the Florida cities now served under extended temporary authority by Northeast Airlines.

" You mean you never heard that before?" asked Garland Lamb, a Negro who manages the Park Hotel on 110th and Park Avenue, where rooms with double beds and a bath rent for $5.50 a day. "Why that's an old saying in this part of Park Avenue."
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- President Johnson is going to San Francisco this weekend to do some repair work on U.S. relations with the United Nations. It will not be an easy journey.

Leo Cherne, chairman of the International Rescue Committee, announced yesterday a program to aid war orphans in South Vietnam. It is to be administered in Saigon by a former Premier, Dr. Phan Huy Quat, and a former Minister of Health, Dr. Nguyen Tang Nguyen.
ROME, June 22 -- Vatican sources ridiculed today reports that the proposed Ecumenical Council declaration absolving Jews collectively of guilt in the crucifixion of Jesus had been shelved.
Stock prices showed a improved tone in London yesterday in contrast to the general downward trend of recent trading sessions.
Plans for a one-day schoolboy relay carnival to be held here the weekend of the Penn Relays were disclosed yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22 -- United States Air Force jets flew north of Hanoi today to bomb a North Vietnamese ammunition dump and a barracks area, the latter 80 miles from the Chinese Communist border.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 22 -- Rebel leaders were reported today to be in favor of accepting some of the major points in the peace proposals advanced last week by the three-man committee of the Organization of American States.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs discounted today fears that an end of the deficit in the international payments of the United States would quickly bring economic difficulties to Europe.
GENEVA, June 22 -- The European Free Trade Association voiced concern today over the increasing diversion of trade as a result of Western Europe's cleavage into two rival economic blocs.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Mayor James H.J. Tate moved reluctantly today against striking truck drivers.
TRENTON, June 22 -- A national civil rights group invoked Federal antitrust laws here today in its fight against housing discrimination.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- An additional $4.3 million for New York's antipoverty campaign was approved today by Sargent Shriver, Director of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

Directors of the Norfolk Western Railway approved yesterday a plan for replacing the company's 615,440 shares of noncallable 4 per cent adjustment preferred stock and 458,380 shares of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

TRENTON, June 22 -- A self-styled "Marxist and Socialist" professor at Rutgers, who recently denounced United States policy in Vietnam and praised the Vietcong, has found a protector in Gov. Richard J. Hughes.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House passed legislation today to require that cigarette packages carry a warning that smoking may be hazardous to health.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 22 -- Seven bodies that bore signs of violent treatment were found today by an inter-American team of criminologists.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered a 10-day suspension today of trading in securities of the Belock Instrument Corporation, of Long Island, N.Y.

The British-Canadian-Nordic donations of almost $18 million to the United Nations seek to liquidate not only the U.N.'s deficit but the whole controversy over past assessments for peacekeeping operations. The paralysis of the General Assembly during the last year has demonstrated that the United Nations can be destroyed, but certainly cannot be strengthened by the effort to force a major power to pay for peacekeeping activities of which it has disapproved.

EXPERTS are sharply divided on whether opening bids in a four-card major-suit are acceptable. This is a matter of bidding style that can be argued ad infinitum, but there is a related fallacy that needs to be pointed out.
The plight of the strike-plagued merchant marine widened yesterday, and a leading shipping executive called for intervention by top Federal officials in Washington.
ALBANY, June 22 -- The creation of "super school districts" to provide vocational education was approved by both houses of the Legislature as it pushed toward adjournment today.
HAMBURG, Germany, June 22 (UPI) -- Six East German vacationers escaped to West Germany last night by diving off a cruise ship in the Baltic Sea. They were picked up by West German patrol boats.
New York City told Westchester County yesterday that it must curtail its use of the city's water supply.
The results of a five-month investigation to test the reliability of mail-order medical laboratories were disclosed last night by a fact-finding unit of the Columbia Broadcasting System.
First reports of new-car sales in mid-June show for the most part strong sales.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange were mixed yesterday in what turned out to be the slowest trading of the year.

A five-length victory by Red Gar of the Hobeau Farm proved gratifying to the favorite players among the 26,195 customers at Aqueduct yesterday. Red Gar's success occurred in the six-furlong race that featured the program, and the victory was worth $4.30 for $2 to those who backed him.
Mary Harrison Lindsay made her debut as a speaker to a political club yesterday and demonstrated political astuteness on behalf of her husband John V. Lindsay.
NEWARK, June 22 -- Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio ended a dispute with his police force today by lifting the suspension of a patrolman who fatally shot a Negro on June 12.
MOSCOW, June 22 -- A picture of alert Soviet provincial youth with broad interests but no place to go emerges from a survey published by the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda.
The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company sold $40 million of debentures at competitive bidding yesterday.

WESTBURY. L.I., June 23 -- Hans B., a German-bred, British-owned trotter who has been beating pacers, as well as standardbreds of his gait, arrived in the country today, following a 12-hour 40-minute flight from London.
Leading American Negro artists, writers, performers and educators will participate in the first World Festival of Negro Arts to be held next year from April 1 to 24 in Dakar, Senegal.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The two-room cottage in West Branch, Iowa, where former President Herbert C. Hoover was born was designated a national historic landmark tonight.
The appointment of Louis F. Kacel as production vice president of Joseph E. Seagram and Sons, Inc., was announced yesterday by Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the large distiller.

CAIRO, June 22 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China, seconded by President Gamal Abdel Nasser, stepped up a campaign tonight for opening the conference of African and Asian nations in Algeria next Tuesday as scheduled.
The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell a controlling interest in its three Mexican subsidiaries to a group of Mexican industrialists.

THE hottest influence in furniture at the 97-acre Merchandise Mart in Chicago this week seems to be the nineteen-thirties look, while the biggest seller may be the Mediterranean look with the Spanish phase way out in front.
The centerpiece of last night's "Tchaikovsky Promenade" with the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall was a performance of three scenes from his opera, "The Queen of Spades."

ALBANY, June 22 -- Governor Rockefeller quoted Franklin D. Roosevelt today and then vetoed a Democratic measurer that would have softened restrictions against strikes by public employes.

THE HAGUE, June 22 -- Premier Joseph M.L.T. WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Federal judicial hierarchy is pushing a campaign to make its trial judges abandon their traditional role as passive umpires between opposing lawyers land to become more masterful in controlling trials.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- United States companies repatriated $77 million in short-term funds held in Canadian banks between the announcement of the voluntary balance- of-payments program Feb. 10 and the end of March, it was disclosed today.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., June 22 -- Charles T. Matthews, 39-year-old Republican assistant district attorney in Suffolk County, bolted his party tonight to accept the Democratic designation for county prosecutor.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate voted today to aid children of the unemployed in the District of Columbia as part of a one-year antipoverty program.

License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo said yesterday that he was moving to halt "illegal distribution of bulk tickets" from Broadway hits "to illicit out-of-state brokers, who have been scalping them." Successful shows and "certain local brokers" will be checked, he said.

The New York Stock Exchange has started an investigation into the false rumor of President Johnson's illness that generated heavy selling waves on June 9.

A broad realignment of top management was announced yesterday by the American Cyanamid Company, a Wayne, N.J., producer of chemicals and drugs.

CINCINNATI, June 22 (AP) -- Tommy Harper hit a homer in the third inning, then doubled home the tie-breaking run in the fifth as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 4-2, and completed a sweep of a doubleheader.

TOKYO, June 20 -- A New York theater group headed by Harold Clurman, here to participate in a new kind of international collaboration in the performing arts, has left in triumph after giving an informal and unplanned presentation of Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night" for selected audiences.

Stock prices advanced for the most part in London yesterday, with the major indexes continuing to show the firmer tones established Tuesday after earlier declines.
