SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 (AP) -- Tony Gonzalez's sixth-inning single propelled the Philadelphia Phillies to a 3-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants today and spoiled Juan Marichal's bid to become the first 12-game winner in the majors this season.
Allocations of ship construction subsidies will be guided by a new approach, the Maritime Administration announced yesterday.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 24 (UPI) -- A Federal District Court approved a divestiture plan today stripping the El Paso Natural Gas Company of the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation and appointing officers and directors of a new company.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 -- Uncle Max, owned and ridden by 19-year-old Neal Shapiro of Glen Head, L.I., lost to two other horses, but still took the lead for the open jumper championship today in the Fairfield Hunt Club horse show.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 23 -- The forthcoming Yugoslav economic reform, whose outlines are only dimly drawn today, appears to have important implications not only for this Communist country, but for others as well.

The General Tire and Rubber Company registered new records in earnings for the three and six months ended May 31, despite a decline in sales, the report of T.F. O'Neil, chairman, and M.G. O'Neil, president, disclosed yesterday.

The national economic loss caused by dirty air was estimated yesterday at $11 billion or more each year, with $520 million damage in New York City. Both estimates were exclusive of the costs of sickness and death attributable to poisons and irritants in the air.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 24 (UPI) -- About 120 members of a union local changed a protest over wages into a wildcat strike today and shut down much of the construction under way at the space center here.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach urged the legal profession today to meet the needs of the poor by relaxing its rules against lawyers' soliciting clients and non-lawyers' giving legal advice.
Federal mediation officials increased pressure on striking maritime unions and the shipping industry yesterday to end the dispute and get United States flag vessels moving again.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 24 (AP) -- Lionel Hebert and Dick Mayer posted seven-under-par 64's today to tie for the first-round lead in the $100,000 St. Paul open over the Keller course.

CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) -- Max Alvis hit his 13th homer and drove in another run with a single to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 3-1 victory over Minnesota tonight. The victory moved the Indians to within one-half game of the league-leading Twins.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday a series of changes in top executive positions to become effective July 1. The changes were announced following a meeting of the corporation's executive committee.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Vice President Humphrey today called a meeting next week of the nation's top space advisory body that is expected to result in the first military man-in-space program.

Roland Sheldon, who used to pitch for the New York Yankees, pitched against them yesterday for the Kansas City Athletics and must have wondered what all the fuss had been about in the old Yankee days.

BECAUSE of Courreges, who has brought a racy new spirit to clothes, it is becoming increasingly difficult to tell the difference between undergarments and fashions meant to be seen. Lingerie, the last repository of feminine frippery, has gone space-age.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A four-man commission set in motion today plans for rebuilding the west front of the Capitol, which engineers say is in danger of collapsing.

ALDEBURGH, England, June 24 -- This year's Aldeburgh Festival offers no fewer than three new works by Benjamin Britten. Last week, a couple of versatile Hungarian schoolboys played his "Gemini" Variations on an Epigram of Kodaly for flute, violin and piano duet, and Sunday Mstislav Rostropovich will give the first performance of the Suite for Cello Solo.

LONDON, June 24 -- President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana, an influential member of the Commonwealth peace mission on Vietnam, said today that the mission's task would be eased if the United States stopped its "provocative air raids in North Vietnam."
On two social welfare issues the Senate has had second thoughts that were better than the first.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- Mayor Orville L. Hubbard of suburban Dearborn and his two top police aides were acquitted by a United States District Court jury today of all counts in a civil rights indictment. Deliberation by the jury of eight women and four men totaled slightly more than eight hours.

Mayor Wagner hailed the 1965 Legislature for "most fruitful" accomplishment, "courage and responsibility" in disclosing yesterday that more than 75 per cent of the city's legislative program had been approved.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Representative William M. McCulloch of Ohio told the House Rules Committee today that unless the Administration's voting rights bill was amended, unqualified voters might decide close elections for local, state and possibly national office.
DARIEN, Conn., June 24 -- Residents defended this community today in the wake of a new police case involving teen-age drinking at adult-sponsored debutante parties.

MODESTY hardly has been one of the outstanding virtues of Ken Harrelson, the relatively new first baseman of the Kansas City Athletics. But on him it looks good. The 23-year-old Georgian is a blithe spirit with so much charm, personality and color that he is a welcome addition to the lodge even if he is not quite as extraordinary a performer as he thinks he is. Or is he?
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The next Gemini mission will last eight days instead of the seven originally planned, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.
Prospects for further price increases for aluminum mill products strengthened yesterday.

Nineteen years ago, John H. McCoy was 24, and had $1,000 and an idea. Today Mr. McCoy is president of the National Rolling Mills Company -- a result of his idea -- which has sales of some $10 million a year and competes with the giants of the steel industry.

SOME people remind you of other people, but only vaguely so that for an hour or two you keep wondering of whom. Muhlbach is one of these. A widower with two children and a good job as an insurance expert, Muhlbach is intelligent and cultivated, but lonely, ineffectual and emotionally distraut. A comic figure, a pathetic one and probably a symbolical one, he haunts the mind with his remote resemblance to somebody else.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Conferees of the House and the Senate have composed their differences over a constitutional amendment providing for Presidential disability and the filling of a Vice-Presidential vacancy.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 24 -- The American general fingered his text, then stared intently across the table at his Communist counterpart.
ALBANY, June 24 -- Governor Rockefeller vetoed two education bills tonight on the ground that they violated the constitutional principle of separation of church and state.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate minority leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, raised the possibility today that the United States would soon double its forces in South Vietnam -- to presumably at least 120,000 men -- and begin ground artillery fire across the border into North Vietnam.
The city's Labor Department was temporarily enjoined yesterday from counting and making public the results of a union representation election it conducted among 12,326 taxi cab drivers.
EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., June 24 (AP) -- Two Air Force planes training for warfare in Vietnam collided in flight today over remote woodlands of the Florida Panhandle, killing four men.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a liberalized version of the Administration bill to provide medical insurance for the aged and to increase Social Security cash benefits. The vote was 12 to 5.
ALGIERS, June 24 -- Plans to begin the conference of African and Asian chiefs of state and government on schedule next Tuesday appeared on the verge of collapse tonight.
MOSCOW, June 24 -- The rejuvenated Operetta Theater here forsook its usual Viennese waltzes tonight for the nervous rhythms and taut dancing of the American musical "West Side Story."
John B. King, the highest-ranking Negro in the city school system, was nominated yesterday for the position of executive deputy superintendent of schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 24 -- Enlargement of the Security Council from 11 to 15 members, and of the Economic and Social Council from 18 to 27 has been assured through the ratification of two amendments to the United Nations Charter.
The constitutionality of the city's proposed water fluoridation program was affirmed yesterday by the Appellate Division.
LONDON, Friday, June 25 -- The Hanoi radio reported today that Sgt. Harold George Bennett of the United States had been executed in Vietnam, local radio monitors reported.

A businessman who survived a three-car accident in which five persons were killed testified yesterday at the trial of the only other survivor, Gareth Martinis, 25-year-old son of an acting Supreme Court Justice. The defendant is charged with vehicular homicide and assault.
LONDON, June 24 -- The great Indian dancer Balasaraswati returned to London tonight to start a series of concerts at the Commonwealth Institute.
LONDON, June 24 -- Peter O'Toole has returned to the stage here in David Mercer's "Ride a Cock Horse," which opened tonight at the Piccadilly Theater.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- In his first major speech in the Senate, Robert Kennedy rebuked the Administration for not going faster in its efforts to control the spread of nuclear weapons.
Thirteen state-supported colleges in Virginia sold $33.85 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds yesterday.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 24 -- A 27-year-old Army lieutenant's reluctance to accept United States foreign policy in Vietnam led to his general court-martial here today on charges that include alleged "wilful disobedience to expose himself to hostile elements and hazardous conditions."
A new statewide program designed to encourage instructional performances in dance, theater and music has been established by the New York State Council on the Arts.
If the stock market continues to decline, Wall Street may be talking more this summer about the Dow theory.

William F. Buckley Jr., leading apostle of Goldwaterism on the Eastern Seaboard, has offered himself as the Conservative party candidate for Mayor. He regards New York as a city to be saved from crisis and, with his usual diffidence, himself as the man to do it. Whether New York is also ready for Mr. Buckley is another matter. Popular demand that he become a candidate has been thunderously absent.
ALBANY, June 24 -- Following are the major actions taken by the Legislature during the regular 1965 session that ended yesterday:

Mrs. Richard C. Marcus won an uncontested separation yesterday after testifying thtat her husband, whose father is president of the Neiman-Marcus department store, had broken her jaw in Dallas and had slapped her in New York.
Mrs. Pat Edrich and Mimi Kanarek, both of New York, reached the final of the Rose Taubele Memorial tennis tournament yesterday at the New York Tennis Club in the Bronx.
BONN, June 24 -- Soviet and East German troops, possibly engaged in a war on Western nerves, appeared today on highways linking. Berlin with West Germany.
BOSTON, June 24 (UPI) -- The world champion Boston Celtics have been sold to the Ruppert-Knickerbocker Brewery for $3 million, it was announced tonight.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 24 -- A time bomb planted by terrorists earlier today exploded about 5 P.M. on the ground floor of the three-story United States Consulate in the center of the city.
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson was accused here yesterday of negotiating Liberal party endorsements for Republican candidates in return for state jobs paying up to $18,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, D.C., June 24 -- A State Department official said today that no report of a request for aid had been received from the United States Embassy in Algiers. He did not discount the possibility that informal conversations about aid might have taken place.
LONDON, June 24 -- A joint committee of lawyers and journalists recommended today that the British law of libel and contempt be eased to permit greater freedom of publication.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Following is the text of a constitutional amendment on Presidential disability and Vice-Presidential vacancies agreed on today by a SenateHouse conference committee:
A form of corn has been discovered whose protein content is close enough to that of animal products so that it may help solve some of the world's most acute nutrition problems.

WHITE PLAINS, JUNE 24 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair and Mrs. Murray Gordon of Elmwood will meet in the 36-hole final of the 62d annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's championship tomorrow.

The Harvard University Press has chosen a name for its chatty, informative newsletter -- "The Browser." Three persons suggested the name in a contest run by the press among its readers in the book trade, and many other names that appealed to the press managers were submitted.
BOSTON, June 24 -- The Government began today an investigation of racial discrimination charges brought against Boston's public schools under the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
The Board of Health adopted new laws yesterday regulating the transportation and sale of water brought into the city.
The Bangor Punta Alegre Sugar Corporation, a holding company, is planning to add knitting manufacturing to its long list of diversified activities.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the latest week ended June 19 were both ahead of the corresponding week of 1964. This has been consistent with the 1965 trend of improving year-to-year conditions.

Two Broadway ticket brokers were found guilty of scalping yesterday at a hearing at the Department of Licenses. License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo suspended their licenses for six and three months, respectively.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Administration's long stalled higher education bill was approved late today by the House Education and Labor Committee after prodding by the White House.

NYACK, N.Y., June 24 -- Jack Benny returned tonight from television's millions of viewers to an audience of 792 living, smartly dressed and visibly appreciative persons in the green and gold charm of the Tappan Zee Playhouse here. It was a sentimental reunion.

A FLUFFY-COIFED blonde stormed Third Avenue antiques and furnishings shops in a two-day siege in early May. She was Joanna Barnes, an actress who is both decorating a set and creating a role for a new television series, "The Trials of O'Brien."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 24 -- Charles T. Matthews, an assistant district attorney who bolted the Republican party Tuesday night to run for county prosecutor on the Democratic ticket, declared today that he had made no charge that anybody committed a crime.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, June 23 -- For three weeks, paratroops of the United States' 173d Airborne Brigade, whose headquarters are here, have not heard a shot fired in anger. Military men wonder whether they have arrived at a formula that may finally defeat the Vietcong.
The Board of Estimate turned down yesterday a proposal to merge the Transit Authority police with the city police.
It is not difficult to put a person into a hypnotic trance lover television, a psychiatrist said at a medical meeting here yesterday.
GOLDSBORO, N.C., June 24 (AP) -- The County Welfare Board in this eastern North Carolina community rescinded today its order that welfare recipients could not own television sets or telephones.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 24 -- The eighth edition of Gian Carlo Menotti's Festival of Two Worlds opened tonight with a fast-paced performance of Giuseppe Verdi's "Otello," directed by Thomas Schippers, the young American conductor, who has made a specialty at Spoleto of turning old operatic warhorses into exciting spectacles.

For several years metropolitan New York has been witness to the gradual outstripping of its water supply owing to population growth and increased industrial use. Last year more energy was devoted to projects to add toxic substances to the water than to the task of resolving the shortage.
ALGIERS, June 24 -- Col. Houari Boumedienne's five-day- old Revolutionary Council has quietly sought assurances of new aid for Algeria's depressed economy from both France and the United States.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 -- The heads of two major Jewish rights agencies sharply differed today on the strength of the radical-right movement.
LEE, Mass., June 24 -- The Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival opened its 33d season tonight m this quiet village in the Berkshire hills.

As the United Nations celebrates at San Francisco the twentieth anniversary of its Charter, one's mind goes back to those tumultuous days of 1945 when the document was being drawn up, wrangled over and signed
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday that "the essential factor in police work is the human factor, not the computer."

AREA A -- Despite an early-afternoon rainfall, sea-bass, fluke and porgies were being taken off Brielle, N.J. The bluefish were reported picking up 14 to 17 miles east of Manasquan Inlet by trolling from small boats and chumming from the party vessels.
P. Ballantine Sons apparently hopes to move in on the "Pepsi Generation."
The leaders of the American Medical Association offered yesterday to discuss medicare with President Johnson.
Liberal party leaders were reported yesterday to be swinging toward the endorsement of Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican candidate for Mayor.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 (UPI) -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, United Nations Under Secretary for Special Political Affairs, said today it was a "fatal gap" for 700 million mainland Chinese to be unrepresented in the United Nations.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 24 -- There is no end to "King Lear." Ask Morris Carnovsky; he knows.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Alan Fox of Los Angeles celebrated his 26th birthday a day before time by knocking out the No 3 seeded player, Jan-Erik Lundquist of Sweden, 7-9, 7-5, 6-2, 7-5, today at wet, windy Wimbledon. It was the surprise of the tournament.
James Reston asks what the President could do in Vietnam. Here are two suggestions:
From the chief inspector to the newest rookie, members of the Police Department have been put through a course in how to deal with Molotov cocktails.

DETROIT, June 24 -- The Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod, one of the most theologically conservative of the larger Protestant denominations in this country, has taken two important strides toward better understanding among Christians.

Thirty-seven American college students whose passports had been stolen left Kennedy Airport for an around-the-world trip last night after the Portuguese Ambassador to the United States induced the State Department to let them go without the passports.
YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, June 24 -- Canada's vast Northwest Territories moved a step closer to self-government today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- An insistent question has arisen again: if the stock market goes down, doesn't that mean trouble ahead for the economy as a whole? The an swer to the question, as worded, is no. Stock price trends are not a certain sign.
Governor Rockefeller threw New York City's antipoverty program into jeopardy yesterday when he threatened to the heart of the operation.

Burley Parke, who trains for Louis E. Wolfson's Harbor View Farm, was an extremely pleased horseman yesterday following the victory of Sammyren, one of his 3-year-old pupils, in the featured 1 1-16-mile, $10,000 Art Market at Aqueduct.

William F. Buckley Jr. announced his candidacy for Mayor on the Conservative party line yesterday. He said he would introduce "the other candidates to the New York that seethes with frustration while the politicians conduct their quadrennial charade."

BALTIMORE, June 24 (AP) -- Milt Pappas, given home run support by Brooks Robinson and Luis Aparicio, stopped the Boston Red Sox, 4-1, on seven hits tonight and pitched the surging Baltimore Orioles to their 12th victory in 14 starts.

TONIGHT'S television feature is Jack Paar without tears. The humorist is closing out an eight-year run on the home screen and picking up his option on a sabbatical. It is an ingratiating withdrawal, warm and winning in its tidy mellowness, but it is also something more, the completion of a chapter of individualism that has not been unimportant to TV.

The class of '65, the first in a pioneer gardening trainee project developed by the city's cooperative education program with the New York Botanical Garden, graduated last night at ceremonies in the auditorium of the garden's administration building.

An official of Montreal's 1967 World's Fair said yesterday that the New York fair had left a sour taste with many industrial exhibitors, making the recruitment of industrial participants for the Canadian exposition more difficult.
MONTREAL, June 24 -- French Canada combined patriotism, religion and merrymaking today in celebrating the festival of its patron saint, Jean Baptiste.

The new Whitney Museum of American Art, going up on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and 75th Street, looked to some observers yesterday more like a piece of junk sculpture than the "dramatic work of art" envisioned by its sponsors when construction plans were announced in 1963.
Both shadow and substance cast a spell on some major commodity markets yesterday.
MOSCOW, June 24 -- The Soviet Union announced today that plans for a power project on the Lower Volga River had been shelved after protests by conservation groups.
A surprise wave of selling battered the stock market yesterday, carrying away $6 billion in paper values and rolling back leading averages to levels below those at the beginning of the year.

In Waiter Sullivan's excellent news article (June 13) on "Finding of Blue Galaxies Backs 'Big Bang' Theory" the following statement appears: "It was Dr. Einstein who first proposed that gravity would bend light and his prediction was demonstrated in the eclipse of 1919, when the light from a star could be observed as it skirted the sun."
Nearly all of the active issues traded on the American Stock Exchange yesterday closed off, as declines outnumbered advances by more than seven to one.

The crisp, urgent trumpet of Max Kaminsky, punching away over Bud Freeman's looping lines on tenor saxophone -- a combination that had set the pace for the eight-piece Summa Cum Laude Orchestra 25 years ago -- floated nostalgically through the soft night air in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art last night.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Republican leaders in Congress assailed the Johnson Administration today for what they called a backdown in the fight to force the Soviet Union to pay United Nations peacekeeping assessments.
MOST things can be done more quickly today than they could 20 years ago, from running 100 yards to traveling around the world, and becoming a bridge expert is no exception to the rule.

PARIS -- The Vietnam war has managed to disrupt alliances on both sides of the fence. For months the escalating conflict has show SEATO to be meaningless. Only today Saigon, a SEATO protectorate, broke relations with SEATO member France. But the Communist alliance is, if anything, in worse condition.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- William Cody Kelly, who was dismissed from his post at the Republican National Committee yesterday for breaking into a colleague's desk, said today that the party's national chairman, Ray C. Bliss, was advised of the incident the next day and "professed satisfaction with my work."
In the fickle world of television, there is no magic formula for transfixing an audience and holding its allegiance, but one technique in the endurance contest might be called freshening the format.
TOKYO, June 24 -- The Bank of Japan will cut the official discount rate by 0.365 of 1 per cent tomorrow, Government and financial sources reported today.

SPOKANE, Wash., June 24 (AP) -- Gerry Lindgren of Washington State University, one of the country's leading distance runners, said today he probably would not run in the Amateur Athletic Union's track and field championships which start Saturday because of a bad ankle.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Senate Banking Committee approved by 10 to 4 today a $7.3 billion, four-year housing program after revising a controversial plan for rent subsidies to low-income families.

The Parker-Hannifin Corporation announced yesterday a refinancing of its long-term and short-term bank loans through a direct placement of $16 million of 4 7/8 per cent notes with institutional investors.
CINCINNATI, June 24 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals routed the Cincinnati Reds, 11-4, tonight while pounding out 12 hits.

Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., operator of the harness-racing track in Westbury, L.I., has filed a $3 million antitrust suit in United States District Court in Brooklyn, charging Universal Controls, Inc., with conducting a monopoly.
The election of Edmund H. Fallon as a director of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation was announced yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 24 -- South Korean students staged demonstrations and hunger strikes again today in protest against the treaty re-establishing relations with Japan. A fasting Opposition leader, Mrs. Pak Soon Chun, fainted and was sent to a hospital.
LOS ANGELES, June 24 -- A lawyer here has become a potential millionaire -- because a jury found that the telephone company had given him bad service.

The Consumers Power Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended May 31. The big Michigan utility also announced the election of John F. Gordon as a director.
Jack Dempsey became 70 years old yesterday and a lot of people felt a little older -- but not Dempsey.
HOUSTON, June 24 -- The Mets, who didn't do well here outdoors, either, still are looking for their first victory in the all-enclosed Astrodome.

NEWARK, June 24 -- The Girl Scout Council of Greater Essex County today became the first voluntary, nonprofit organization in the nation to take an active role in President Johnson's antipoverty campaign.

General Acceptance Corporation, Allentown, Pa., a leading consumer-finance company, announced late yesterday that it was looking into the possibility of acquiring the assets and liabilities of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Toronto.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The majority of Alabama's 118 school boards have revolted against Gov. George C. Wallace's plan for resisting enforcement of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 (AP) -- Willie Stargell hammered three home runs and a double, driving in six runs and leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 13-3 victory over the National League-leading Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
TRENTON, June 24 -- The Republican state convention today condemned "the doctrine of 'extremism,'" whether to the right or to the left.
ROME, June 24 -- Pope Paul VI said today that he hoped soon to be able to make a statement redefining the Roman Catholic teaching on birth control.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A State Department spokesman denied today a report that a plan to set up what would amount to a form of temporary trusteeship government in the Dominican Republic had been drawn up by the Organization of American States committee in Santo Domingo.

In his speech on the proliferation of nuclear weapons, Senator Robert F. Kennedy addressed himself to the most important issue confronting not only the Government of the United States but all of mankind. Unless the spread of nuclear weapons is halted, there will be no security for any power, great or small.
" Those golden age clubs -- I've tried them all -- they're all pretty tarnished. But this one and you can thank that lady there, really makes you shine."

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional approval today of an Administration request to keep the ailing Area Redevelopment Administration alive while Congress considers legislation to transform and expand it.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate approved by an overwhelming margin today the Administration's bill to give the nation a new coinage, with no silver in dimes and quarters.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- There is an atmosphere of festivity along with frantic preparations here today on the eve of the two-day meeting commemorating the signing of the United Nations Charter.
GENEVA, June 24 -- Switzerland received confirmation today of the effectiveness of her campaign to reduce her foreign population.

RAMESES II would be spellbound. You too, might be interested in all exhibition opening tomorrow at the Time-Life Exhibition Center, Time and Life Building, Sixth Avenue, Rockefeller Center, showing what is being done to save Rameses' temples at Abu Simbel, 1,000 miles up the Nile from Alexandria.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 24 (UPI) -- The Chamber of Deputies passed the Government's copper bill today authorizing the formation of mixed companies, with the participation of the state and the American producers here.

The assignment of Col. Victor Ralph Bisceglia of the Inspector General's Office in the Washington headquarters of the Marine Corps to be director of the First Marine Corps District in Garden City, L.I., was announced yesterday. The transfer is effective July 6.
I read your June 9 editorial on the Mayor's Budget, and the letter [June 18] from Bronx Borough President Periconi (for whom I have a high regard) defending his vote in favor of it.
ALBANY, June 24 (AP) -- New York will switch its license-plate color scheme to blue and golden yellow next year, when it converts to so-called permanent plates.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Food shortages and layoffs mounted here today on the fourth day of a wildcat strike by the 12,000 members of Teamsters Local 107.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 24 -- A change in equipment tonight worked wonders for Oreti, the New Zealand pacing gelding who raced one mile in 1:59 3/5 and gained a neck decision over Cold Front in the $25,000 Duane Hanover Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

Government securities held in Federal Reserve custody for official foreign accounts fell $282 million, to $7,286,000,000, in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

DR. CHARLES LOWELL HUDSON, 61 years old, the new president-elect of the American Medical Association, is an unruffled ex-combat doctor with a fondness for showy, expensive cars. These two qualities -- calmness and sedate showmanship -- have propelled Dr. Hudson to to the top of the nation's medical hierarchy, and will be crucially important during the one-year term he will begin next June.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday vetoed the controversial Mackell bill, which would have stripped the Waterfront Commission of its major weapons in policing the piers on both sides of the Hudson River in the Port of New York.

The Hughes Tool Company (Toolco) asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for authorization to retain the voting rights to 1,363,636 additional shares of Trans World Airlines stock that it received last March 31.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned downward yesterday in listless trading. Although brokers said there was "only a trickle of selling," one key market index eased to a 1965 low.

DUBLIN, June 24 -- Penelope Donovan left for Granny's house tonight. Not to hide, mind you, but just to get away from the telephone for a bit. Penelope Donovan is one of five Dubliners with a live ticket on Saturday's Irish Sweeps Derby.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The recent uptrend in prices of Treasury bills, and the concurrent decline in yields, was reflected in today's monthly sale of one-year bills.
Plans for a $20 million shopping and office center on 5.5-acre plot adjacent to the City Hall in White Plains has been approved by the White Plains Planning Commission and the Common Council.
JACKSON, Miss., June 24 -- James Forman and 73 other civil rights demonstrators were arrested today, after assembling in a private parking lot to voice charges of police brutality.

BONN, June 25 -- The East German Government stepped up its pressure against West Berlin and the West German Government tonight by announcing stringent new restrictions on barge traffic to the metropolis isolated within East Germany 110 miles behind the Iron Curtain.
HOUSTON, June 25 -- The malign spell that Houston's Astros cast over the New York Mets, inside or outside the Astrodome, continued in effect tonight.

The execution of Sgt. Harold G. Bennett by the Vietcong stands out as a special horror among all the horrors of the war in Vietnam. Sergeant Bennett had been captured in uniform during military operations; he had been held as a prisoner of war for almost a half-year before his murder. All the sanctions established by international law for the protection of war prisoners were brazenly ignored when he was killed.
Educational station WNDT (Channel 13) will name six new members to its board of trustees at a meeting here on Tuesday.

WITH weather as near perfect as one could hope for and better than average cooperation from passing aircraft, the musical fare at Lewisohn Stadium last night was received with unmistakable enthusiasm by 11,000 or 12,000 persons predisposed to enjoyment.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 25 Neal Shapiro, who piloted Jacks or Better to the national open jumper high-point championship last year, suffered a fractured left ankle in a spill with the aged brown gelding today at the Fairfield Hunt Club horse show.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized Pan American Airways and Trans World Airlines today to subsidize New York Airways' helicopter service temporarily.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Joe Horlen scattered eight hits and, aided by four double plays, pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 6-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 24 -- Bill Steinkraus, captain of the United States Equestrian Team, made his first start of the season today and won two jumper classes in the Mercer County Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The United States has decided against putting any new restrictions on imports of livestock from Canada. The step is being taken despite Canada's decision to allow imports of animals from Western Europe, where the foot-and-mouth disease exists.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 25 -- A 27-year-old Army lieutenant, Richard R. Steinke of Milwaukee, was convicted by a court-martial today of refusing to obey orders and to expose himself to "hazardous conditions and hostile elements."
MILWAUKEE, June 25 (UPI) -- Don Pavletich's two-run homer in the 11th inning tonight gave the second-place Cincinnati Reds a 3-1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

ALGIERS, June 25 -- About 500 shirt-sleeved youths, led by left-wing students, paraded noisily again tonight through downtown Algiers, shouting slogans against Col. Houari Boumedienne's new Revolutionary Council.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- James B. Carey strongly objected today to a vote of censure against him by the executive board of the International Union of Electrical Workers.

Twayne Publishers has added a Hebrew section to its world literature project, which encompasses critical studies of the leading writers of a dozen national literatures. The publishers now have contracts covering 1,200 books for the project, and have printed 85 in their series of United States authors.
WARSAW, June 25 -- An avant-garde Polish movie shorn of politics and ideology has received an unusually good reception in this city.
NICKERSON, Kan., June 25 (UPI) -- The Arkansas River rolled across farmland near here today but the knockout punch was gone from the worst flood in western Kansas history.

The strike of licensed officers of the merchant marine in a contract dispute immobilized the industry's biggest ship -- the superliner United States -- yesterday and 1,500 passengers were forced to land through picket lines.
A man was stabbed in the Grand Central subway station at 7:40 P.M. yesterday when he came to the aid of a husband fighting three young men who had insulted his wife, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Government is planning a drive to prevent taxpayers from taking excessive tax deductions for spending on charity balls and other functions, Internal Revenue spokesmen said yesterday.

A TWO-PART study of life in South Africa, contrasting the affluence of the white minority colony and regimentation of the Negro majority, has opened on Channel 13. The first installment, titled "The Fruit of Fear," was seen Thursday and the second will be presented Monday evening.

The Metropolitan Opera will present a Rodgers and Hammerstein program, with Richard Rodgers and Franz Allers conducting; Laurel Hurley soprano; Marcia Baldwin, mezzo soprano; Nicholas Di Virgilio, tenor, and William Walker, baritone, at Lewisohn Stadium tonight at 8:30.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., June 25 -- Jim Hall and Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., who are here for Sunday's 200-mile United States Road racing championship contest, happened to pass through Indianapolis earlier in the week.

EDWARDS, Miss., June 25 (UPI) -- A white man drove into a center of the National Council of Churches today and opened fire on the headquarters of training programs for pre-school children in 75 Mississippi communities. No one was hurt.

While Lewis and Clark were following the Missouri to its source one hundred and sixty years ago this June, two obscure New Englanders were surveying the valley of the Pemigwasset River in New Hampshire.

BUENOS AIRES, June 25 -- Argentina formally concluded a round of complicated and drawn-out negotiations today to refinance her short-term debts with 11 West European nations, Japan and the United States.
TOKYO, June 25 -- Simultaneously with its reduction of the official discount rate by 0.365 per cent, to 5.475 per cent, the Bank of Japan today discontinued its control of commercial bank lending.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The nation's money supply rebounded sharply in the first half of June from the decline in May, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. said today it was "a tragedy" that the Legislature had amended a major educational bill in a manner that led Governor Rockefeller to veto it on a church-state issue.
Trading in commodity futures dawdled yesterday as traders turned their attention toward the weekend.
Wan C. Karp, one of the busiest purveyors of art in a gallery that is a giant in the world of op, pop and other vogues, has taken time out from selling to write a novel.
Sticking close to the week-long pattern, the American Stock Exchange ended the week yesterday in a bearish mood. Declines outnumbered advances by more than 3 to 1.

NAKURU, Kenya, June 25 -- John Okello, the self-styled field marshal of the revolution in Zanzibar a year ago last January, stood in the prisoners dock in court today and said his days as a revolutionary were over.

Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, has called upon school superintendents in the state to hire qualified Negro teachers who lose their jobs in the South because of "integration procedures."
Long-term Government bond prices continued to rise yesterday and closed out a second consecutive week of small gains, making the most substantial advance since late January.
THE HAGUE, June 25 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Symphony ended tonight its three-month European tour with a performance in Kurahaus Hall at the seaside resort of Scheveningen near here.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 25 (UPI) -- About half of a 5,700-man construction force observed wildcat picket lines for the second day today at the nation's space center, slowing work on major facilities.
ATHENS, June 25 -- The Greek parliament gave the Government of Premier George Papandreou a 163-to-21 vote of confidence tonight. Parliament afterward recessed for the summer.

The New York Court of Claims ruled yesterday that a child born as a result of the rape of a patient in a state mental institution might recover damages from the state for having been brought into life.
MONTREAL, June 25 -- Actors Equity and Union des Artistes signed an agreement today, resolving their long-standing jurisdictional dispute over the Place des Arts concert hall here.

Construction companies are paying more these days for three of the four "M's" required to run a business: machines, manpower and money. However, prices of the fourth one, materials, apparently are being held in line.
William H. McKeon said last night that he had been giving "some consideration" to resigning from his post as state chairman of the Democratic party.

The rivalry between District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor and City Council President Paul R. Screvane for the Democratic nomination for Mayor has badly split the party organization in Queens, their home county.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution said today that President Johnson's bill to abolish the national origins quota system of immigration would destroy "a first-line of defense in perpetuating our institutions of freedom and the American way of life."

ALGIERS, Saturday, Jan. 26 -- A mysterious explosion last night shook the conference hall where Asian and African foreign ministers are to meet later today to decide whether to hold a summit conference on schedule today.
WHARTON, N.J., June 25 -- Police Chief Abe Hocking has been suspended from his post, and the residents of this Morris County borough are angry and shocked.
A white teacher accused of punishing a Negro pupil by dabbing yellow water-color paint on the child's face was assigned yesterday to another school for the remaining three days of the school term.
CINCINNATI, June 25 -- Francis L. Dale, a corporation attorney who is active in civic affairs, will become the president and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer Sept. 30.

Manager Bill Rigney of the Los Angeles Angels took one of those strategic gambles last night that make baseball such a fascinating matter for second-guessers. It didn't pan out and it led to a 5-1 defeat that enabled the New York Yankees to climb as high as sixth place for the first time in nearly two months.
Federal authorities are searching for two narcotics defendants who disappeared Thursday while a jury was deliberating their case.
BUFFALO, June 25 -- Quarterback, the most glamorous position in football, will be especially well-staffed at the All-America football game to be played tomorrow night in War Memorial Stadium.

The appointment of Russell J. Roberts as executive vice president of the American Dock Company, Inc., was announced yesterday by C. Leslie Rice, president.
PARIS, June 25 (AP) -- The French 6,000-meter-relay team with Michel Jazy running the third leg, bettered the world record tonight with a time of 14 minutes 49 seconds.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- George F. Kennan, the former United States Ambassador whom Stalin denounced and barred from the Soviet Union 13 years ago, was back in Moscow today for the first time since his departure.

PARIS, June 25 -- Gaston Defferre, the Socialist Mayor of Marseilles, announced today the withdrawal of his candidacy for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The State Department expressed grave concern today about the Vietcong's execution of an Army sergeant, Harold G. Bennett, in reprisal for the shooting of a rebel terrorist by South Vietnamese authorities.

President Johnson's speech to the United Nations in San Francisco must disappoint all who had hoped he would capture the world's imagination by specific proposals for attaining the objectives that brought the U.N. into being. Instead, the great bulk of the President's speech consisted of noble but trite sentiments whose mere repetition makes no contribution to their realization.
The stock market registered three losses for every gain yesterday as paper values were stripped by an additional $3 billion in a day of active -- and disappointing -- trading.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25 (UPI) -- Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky, South Vietnam's new Premier, relented today on his decision to close all of 36 of Saigon's Vietnamese-language newspapers. He said only 16 would be closed.
Prices on the London stock exchange fell yesterday to a new 1965 low for the second successive day.
A meeting at midnight tomorrow of the city's taxi drivers was called yesterday to consider a course of action in a labor situation described by one union official as "at the breaking point."

The department will take over on July 1 sole responsibility for code enforcement activities, now split among five city agencies.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 25 -- After a four-year growth spree, the South African economy is starting to slow down.

A laboratory where boys and girls between the ages of 8 and 16 can conduct their own research and experiments was formally opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

A formal accounting of Marilyn Monroe's estate, which is not expected to provide the million dollars in bequests the late actress hoped for, will be filed in Surrogate Court here in three months.

The Liberal party announced yesterday that it was holding to its plans to select a candidate for Mayor at a two-day conference starting Monday despite intense pressure to delay the meeting.

An advertising agency that was convicted of the fraudulent promotion of Regimen Tablets, a worthless reducing pill, was fined $50,000 yesterday in United States District Court, Brooklyn. The agency is Kastor, Hilton, Chesley, Clifford Atherton.

The United States Treasury is playing coy on the issue of international monetary reform. Frederick L. Deming, its Under Secretary for Monetary Affairs, is getting ready to discuss reform with other financial powers but he does not hold much hope of a quick consensus. He prefers to wait until the present surplus of dollars abroad gives way to scarcity before coming to an agreement on improving the international payments mechanism.

WASHINGTON June 25 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent to 102.8 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended June 22, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Cole, its author, and to the Office of the Chief of Military History. It dissects with scrupulous care and painstaking detail the largest battle in which United States troops have ever fought.

DETROIT, June 25 -- The 2,700,000-member Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod ended its general convention here today with a ringing reaffirmation of the strict inerrancy of the Scriptures.

BOSTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Boston's biggest inning of the season, a seven-run fifth, carried the Red Sox to an 8-6 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- For every $100 of stock sold on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during the three months this year, $4.10 worth was sold off the floor in what is called the "third market."

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., June 25 -- President Johnson arrived here tonight for a weekend rest at his ranch after a busy 24 hours in which he made three speeches, ate breakfast with a former President, met with the Secretary General of the United Nations, did some old-style political handshaking and startled some early risers in Kansas City, Mo., by taking a walk around their downtown.
GLENDALE, Calif., June 25 -- A memorial service for David O. Selznick was held today at Forest Lawn Cemetery with the type of all-star cast befitting a movie titan.

PARIS, June 25 -- Gaston Defferre, who withdrew today as a candidate for the French Presidency, has been known as one of the few political adversaries who could command the respect of President de Gaulle.
CHICAGO, June 25 (UPI) -- More than 600 men, women and children made a two-mile march to Chicago's City Hall today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- A political poker game has been in progress this week in Sacramento. The result is a special session of the California Legislature, which opened yesterday scarcely a week after the legislators had ended their regular 120-day session with an unbalanced budget.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 26 -- Ambassador Taylor said today that the bombing of a riverboat restaurant here last night was "a deed bearing the unmistakable label of the Vietcong terrorism." In a prepared statement he said:
Some Wall Street brokers, searching busily for indicators of market trends, decided last week they may have found one clue to the future within the New York Stock Exchange itself.
Two hundred persons watched from the street yesterday as the police tried to coax a young woman from a parapet atop the 21-story Drake Hotel at Park Avenue and 56th Street.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service expressed satisfaction last week with both the "quantity and quality" of responses received from private American ship operators to its request for bids for the private construction of a roll-on, roll-off vessel for charter to the Navy.

Mrs. Rosemary Gunning, an opponent of changes in the neighborhood-school system, was described yesterday as "the leading candidate at this point" for a place on the Conservative party ticket headed by William F. Buckley Jr.

COME July 15, 9,000 teen-age girls will pitch 6,000 tents in the rugged hills of Farragut, Idaho, for Roundup, a kind of summit conference of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. In preparation for this get-together, most of the girls filled out a comprehensive questionnaire studded with searching queries about their lives and thoughts.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 26 -- For the first time after 25 years of silence, the question of whether a monarchy is a good thing is again being discussed publicly in the Netherlands. The discussions have been sparked by the decision of the 27-year-old crown-princess, Beatrix, to marry a German who was a member of the Hitler youth organization and served with the German army in Italy.
JERSEY CITY, June 26 -- Mail service ends at midnight today the Central Railroad of New Jersey and passenger service is also being cut as a result.

DETROIT, June 26 -- Most businessmen appear to be heeding President Johnson's request that they pass along the benefits of this week's excise tax cut to consumers. But a substantial number seem to be increasing their profits with the money.

LONDON, June 26 -- Prime Minister Wilson and his Government have passed the point of immediate political danger and can now look forward to governing in relative serenity for months. Mr. Wilson underlined the situation today by announcing that he had no intention of calling an election this year.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- If the Federal Government has anything to say about it, business will be about as good in the second half of this year as it was in the booming first half.

Philadelphia Inquirer: The United Nations, which has been in a sadly sagging state lately, received a revivifying boost from President Johnson. . . . The President did not just say, "Many happy returns," and let it go at that. He gave the United Nations the best birthday gift it could receive: a sense of mission and dedication in a world that badly needs its offices.

Federal District Judge Inzer B. Wyatt has upheld his order suppressing most of the evidence in the stock-fraud and income-tax evasion cases against financier Lowell M. Birrell.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 26 -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd has complained bitterly about racially mixed receptions held by United States diplomats in South Africa.
KUCHING, Malaysia, June 26 -- An Indonesian raid this week typified a new pattern that the war against Malaysia has assumed.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- New York State troopers are spending part of their summer here diving for evidence of a British pre-Revolutionary military disaster of 207 years ago.

Stores have begun to place orders for early fall sportswear, resident buying offices report. Activity in the fall coat and suit market began several weeks ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 26 -- Family planning will be among the items to be discussed at a world population conference to be held Aug. 30 to Sept. 10 in Belgrade. Some 700 demographic experts, nominated by their governments, will participate.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- All commercial banks in Colombia will be closed tomorrow for the usual three-day midyear audit. When they reopen Thursday the nation's bankers will know just how much damage was caused by the last six months of economic deterioration.

New York taxi drivers went on strike early today against the owners of almost 7,000 metered fleet taxicabs in the city.

Leo Brown, Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation, has announced the withdrawal of a proposed schedule of higher wharfage rates charged for tying up vessels and barges at municipal docks.

Governor Rockefeller seems to have confused everybody, including his own aides, by his notice to Washington that he found it "impossible to endorse" a projected $5.6 million grant to this city for six Community Progress Centers in poor neighborhoods. It now develops that the Governor was not issuing a veto ultimatum under the Economic Opportunity Act but was merely in search of "administrative clarification."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 28 (UPI) -- A wildcat strike -- the seventh major labor tie-up at this space center in 17 months -- slowed work today on more than $178 million of construction for the third consecutive work day.

THE Metropolitan Opera made its first venture into jazz last night at Lewisohn Stadium and chose its program shrewdly. For a milieu accustomed to the lighter aspects of "serious" music, there was the Dave Brubeck Quartet.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Administration won a crucial first round today when the House voted 230 to 115 to begin debate on the controversial housing bill.
GENEVA June 28 -- The Swiss Government dismissed today the chairman of the Federal Banking Commission and replaced him with a former Finance Minister in an effort to clear up a major bank scandal.
Steel production fell 2 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 28 -- A seven-foot-high cross was burned on the front lawn of an interracially married couple last night in this all-white neighborhood.

Like Solomon, though without his magic ring, Lorenz can "talk" with the animals; what's more, he can make this talk comprehensible and utterly fascinating to the rest of us.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -High government officials are troubles of the pound sterling are over and that Britain's balance of payments is turning the corner, but they are still far from certain that this is the case.

LONDON, June 28 (UPI) -Britain moved back into the black in its payments account in the first quarter of this year. It was the first time this account has shown a surplus in the balance of payments since the April-June quarter of 1963, the Treasury reported today.

European export prices for iron and steel products rose substantially more last year than corresponding prices in the United States but were still below levels in this country.

The British pound edged ahead yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

New York Airways began helicopter service yesterday between Manhattan and the Trans World Airlines terminals at Kennedy and LaGuardia Airports. Formerly, the helicopters had used the American Airlines terminals at the two airports.
