In refuting William McChesney Martin's warning of certain disquieting similarities between present conditions and those of the late twenties that preceded the great depression, Gardner Ackley, Economic Adviser to the President, said in effect that at the moment the danger of inflation "appears remote."

" A little touch of Harry in the night" came last evening to Harlem's Mount Morris Park, transformed for the occasion into the royal courts and rival camps of 15th-century England and France as they converged on the bloody field at Agincourt.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- About 80 persons were arrested here today when they staged a street sitdown minutes after Mayor Richard J. Daley met civil rights leaders in his office in an effort to settle a racial dispute.

Prices tumbled yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Of the 861 issues traded, 627 declined, 176 were unchanged and only 58 advanced. Volume increased to 1,943,500 shares from 1,522,825 on Friday.
The city's Project Head Start enrolled 10,139 in its first week of registration, the chairman of the New York City Council Against Poverty announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- Gen. William F. McKee assured the Senate Commerce Committee today that he would continue present patent policies of the Federal Aviation Agency if the Senate confirmed him as F.A.A. administrator.

LONDON, June 28 -- After months of strenuous preparation, Covent Garden tonight brought off one its greatest achievements since the war: The first production in a non-German speaking opera house of Schoenberg's prodigiously complex masterpiece, "Moses and Aaron."
Lester Lum (Tex) Colbert who resigned as chairman and president of the Chrysler Corporation in July, 1961, will retire as chairman of the Chrysler Corporation of Canada tomorrow.
The president of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theaters, Inc. called yesterday for a cut in proposed rates for international satellite television programing.
BOSTON, June 28 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians vaulted into a first-place tie for the American League lead by overcoming the Boston Red Sox tonight, 9-2.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- Robin Hood Dell opened the second week of its 36th season tonight with an overflow crowd of 28,000 on hand for a program headed by two Philadelphians -- Marian Anderson as soloist and her 28-year-old nephew, James De Priest, as conductor.

The Senate and the House are at odds over what to do about the duty-free ceiling of $100 allowed American tourists. The House Ways and Means Committee rejected the Administration's proposal to lower the ceiling to $50, but the Senate Finance Committee -- after first agreeing that a reduction would do little, if anything, to reduce the deficit in the balance of payments -- has gone along with the White House.

" Too many stores and too many discounters -- and too much under withholding of Federal income taxes which had to be made good. That's why lots of furniture dealers in the Northeast section are having a lot rougher time than last year," Samuel Goldberg, partner, Northeast Home Furnishers, Philadelphia, asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- The Administration gained an eleventh-hour victory today in its efforts to limit tourists to $50 worth of duty-free goods when they return from abroad.

A TOWERING superlative, like a little knowledge, is a dangerous thing. But the present temptation is to state without equivocation that Henri Soule's recently reopened La Cote Basque at 5 East 55th Street is the handsomest restaurant in Manhattan.
Princess Beatrix, the slightly plump, apple-cheeked heiress to the Dutch throne, is considered a Princess of the people. She has had an informal style of living.

PARIS, June 28 -- The New York City Ballet opened an 11-week tour, which will take them to 10 cities, with a performance tonight at the Paris Opera. Their reception, from a standing-room-only audience, was cool.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- Space agency officials promised today that Mariner 4's pictures of Mars would not be arbitrarily withheld from the public just to give scientists the first look at them.
Three painting contractors were indicated here yesterday on charges of perjuring themselves when they swore in bids on New York City Housing Authority jobs that the bids were not collusive.

Demonstrations for and against new procedures to review charges of police brutality threaten to fill City Hall Park today. Peaceful participation in such demonstrations is an undoubted right of all citizens interested in making known their views on municipal legislation. But the plan of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to mass 10,000 off-duty policemen against any change in the existing departmental machinery is an ill-advised exercise of that right.
Don Rubell, the top favorite, withdrew yesterday from the New York State clay-court championship because of pulled leg tendons.
Most owner-drivers took their cabs out yesterday. But not Joe, a cabby from Brooklyn who owns his own hack. He refused to cruise because of his sympathy for fleet drivers.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas -- over the protests of both Democratic and Republican members of the House Banking Committee -- publicly accused James J. Saxon today of having acted illegally in 29 separate instances during his tenure as Controller of the Currency.
" You diggin' for gold?" the small boy asked, peering over the stone rim of a dry well at the two men inside.
MIAMI BEACH, June 29 -Dr. William R. Tolbert Jr., vice president of Liberia, was elected president of the Baptist World Alliance by acclamation here today.

HENLEY, England, June 29 (AP) -- America's Olympic gold medal rowing eight -- a crew in a leaky boat -- tried to regain its form today as 208 entries, a record, completed final tune-ups for the Henley Royal Regatta.

Two more prosecution witnesses testified yesterday that Gareth Martinis, 25-year-old son of an acting Supreme Court Justice, was speeding prior to an accident in which five people were killed, and appeared intoxicated afterward.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 29 -- Urban renewal and community development without subsidy or other help from goverrnent were strongly advocated today by the sponsors of some of the most ambitious projects in the United States.
TRENTON, June 29 -- A strong, central state authority to carry out the "orderly development'' of New Jersey's meadowlands was recommended this morning in an official report to Gov. Richard J. Hughes.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -Scores of civil rights leaders, ministers and at least one Congressman converged on a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today to condemn the appointment of former Gov. J.P. Coleman of Mississippi to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- Business output in the United States will show a "good sized rise" in the April-May-June quarter, the Commerce Department said today.
TEL AVIV, June 29 -- David Ben-Gurion, the former Premier, tonight broke away from the dominant Mapai party, which he founded 35 years ago.
The British pound eased yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The State Department today described the joint United States and South Vietnamese military operation as a "search-and-destroy mission" consistent with policies set out by the White House this month.
Members of the United Federation of Teachers, by a margin of more than 14 to 1, have voted to go on strike next fall in the city unless the Board of Education improves its contract offer before then.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Antonina Bubnova of the Soviet Union streaked to two firsts today as the Russians took four gold medals in the 10th International Games for the Deaf.
DUBLIN, June 29 (AP) -United States Ambassador Raymond R. Guest declared today that Ireland was losing American tourist trade because only her national air line, Aer Lingus, can land at Dublin.
NEW DELHI, June 29 -- India and Pakistan agreed today on a cease-fire in the disputed Rann of Cutch.

The American Stock Exchange ran like a rollercoaster yesterday. Up until noon, advances and declines were about even. Then, trading roared downhill, only to go into a sharp upward climb in the final hour and a half of the session.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 29 -John F. English, Democratic chairman of Nassau County, and Ralph G. Caso, a Republican and Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, were subpoenaed today to appear before a grand jury investigating charges of payoffs and influence peddling in the county's acquisition of public lands.
That old bit of philosophy that maintains that things have to get better because they can't get any worse would have found a firm believer in Louis Olah at Aqueduct yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -Ray C. Bliss, the Republican National Chairman, won the first tentative victory today in his effort to centralize party fund-raising activities. The Republican Congressional Campaign Committee agreed to let its top money-raiser take on the additional duties of acting director of the Republican National Finance Committee.
BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) -- Curt Blefary's two-run single in the eighth inning lifted the Baltimore Orioles to a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

SAN-FRANCISCO, June 29 (AP) -- John Roseboro and Jim Gilliam drove in a total of eight runs and Sandy Koufax became the major league's first 13-game winner as the Los Angeles Dodgers whipped the San Francisco Giants, 9-3, today.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 29 (AP) -- Printing and reproduction workers voted tonight to end a six-day-old strike and submit the dispute to the President's Missile Sites Labor Commission.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 29 -- The political future of former President Joaquin Balaguer, who returned from exile yesterday, dominated the news in the Dominican Republic today.

SALONIKA, Greece, June 29 (AP) -- Five monks were arrested today on charges of smuggling and trading in Byzantine art treasures taken from a Russian Orthodox monastery on Mount Athos, the police announced.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 29 (AP) -- A special legislative committee charged today that agree civil rights organizations were Communist-inspired and that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was "actively engaged in promoting the Communist line."
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued their slow downdrift yesterday to set new 1965 lows for the fourth successive day.

GRAND slams are rarely bid in rubber bridge. The tendency is to wait for a virtual certainty, partly because it takes a practiced partnership to judge that the odds are sufficiently favorable, and partly because of human cupidity.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The nation lost $117 million of gold in May, the smallest loss for the year to date, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The New York Times Index for 1964, almost 1,200 pages of concise abstracts of virtually all the news contained in The Times throughout the year, was published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Dr. John Rock of Brookline, Mass., testified today that "present population growth rates on this planet present an obviously lethal threat to all that civilization has achieved."
Prices of copper futures rose substantially yesterday in fairly active trading.

MONTREAL, June 29 -- Czechoslovakia surmounted political opposition from anti-Communist nations today and was elected to the 27-member Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization, a specialized United Nations agency with 109 members.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 29 -- The Alabama legislative committee is made up of three House members and two Senators, including a Senator who once sought to have the state library director removed because of her selection of books on racial matters.

For the last five weeks, Warren Spahn has been waging a personal duel with a man who pitched his last major league game in 1906. The old-timer, Kid Nichols, held his own again last night as Spahn and the New York Mets suffered an 8-6 defeat at the hands of the Milwaukee Braves at Shea Stadium.
LONDON, June 29 (AP) -- Robert Herrick's "Poetical Commonplace Book" was bought at auction today by a New York dealer for 34,000 ($95,200).

Stockholders of Diners' Club, Inc., were told at their annual meeting yesterday that the company's charge volume had been increasing sharply since it expanded its coverage to include passage on major domestic and international airlines.
" It's been my whole life -- I shall miss it terribly!"

WHEN Dr. Timothy William Thomas Costello takes out his 20-cent package of tobacco and stuffs a pinch into the tar-stained bowl of his corncob pipe, his role as a university professor begins to take on verisimilitude that few casting directors would find elusive.
LONDON, June 29 -- The town was buzzing today over the Royal Opera Company's monumental production of Arnold Schoenberg's "Moses and Aaron," complete with realistic orgy.
BONN, June 29 -- A West German court ruled today that a bad mark in Latin was an extenuating circumstance in the murder of a high school teacher by a former student.
The city and a group of unions representing laborers in different departments completed yesterday a series of negotiations to raise all their pay scales.
ALBANY, June 29 -- Governor Rockefeller signed today a bill requiring a health warning on every package of cigarettes sold in New York state after June 1, 1966.

HUNTINGTON VALLEY, Pa., June 29 -- Mary Jo Ahlander of Boston, Beth Reese of Philadelphia and Pamela Singleton of New York won the best-ball tournament in the junior interclub team matches here today.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) -Mothers brandishing baseball bats have brought at least a temporary end to rowdy behavior and vandalism in Franz Park.

Criminal Court Judge Maurice Wahl yesterday dismissed charges against two Columbia University students who had been accused of violating Park Department regulations by visiting the Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Riverside Park after midnight.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Alabama's Department of Education has agreed to comply with provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the United States Office of Education said today.
A Capitol Airways spokesman informed several hundred teachers at a meeting last night that four charter flights to Europe for which they had paid were not likely to take off.
Dr. Eugene G. Fubini, who resigned Monday as Assistant Secretary of Defense, was elected yesterday as a vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation.
" The Journal of the History of Ideas" is observing its 25th anniversary, deep in thought and reasonably far in the black.
About $71 million of new municipal bonds were put on the market yesterday and received what could at best be called a fair reception.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 29 -- President Joseph Kasavubu asserted his authority over Premier Moise Tshombe today in a message broadcast to the nation on the eve of the anniversary of the Congo's independence.

WITH 173D AIRBORNE BRIGADE, in Zone D, South Vietnam, June 29 -- Zone D is a flat, eerie jungle, thick with scrub trees and tall grass, hot and wet in intermittent rain and strong tropical sun, the air filled with dragonflies and Vietcong sniper bullets.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A break appeared imminent today in the long stalemated effort to rewrite key portions of the nation's immigration law.

DESPITE his aristocratic background, Jimmy Van Alen of Newport, R.I., is an admitted revolutionary. For many years he has been trying to light a few bombs under tennis authorities in order to jolt them out of their archaic, standpat ways by the introduction of a radically new method of scoring, one designed to make the sport more popular with the masses.

SAIGON, June 29 (AP) -- Communist mortars pounded United States and Australian artillery positions in Zone D tonight after the Vietcong ended a day-long jungle drive. One American was killed in the attack and other casualties were reported.

Michael Dunn, whose performance as Cousin Lyman, the dwarf in Edward Albee's "The Ballad of the Sad Cafe" gained him the accolade of "best supporting actor" in Variety's poll of critics a year ago, has now turned his talents to a nightclub presentation at the Upstairs at the Duplex, 55 Grove Street, in Greenwich Village.
The stock market surprised both Wall Street and Main Street yesterday with some of its most erratic movements in memory. Trading was the heaviest in more than three years.

The Bauer Dredging and Construction Company of Port Laveca, Tex., has signed a contract with Local 25, Maline Division, International Union of Operating Engineers, Stephen J. Leslie, president of the union reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -The Government's use of a rock 'n' roll show to appeal to school dropouts was sharply attacked today by Republican Senators.

" A Salute to Britain" concert will be given by the Metropolitan Opera at Lewisohn Stadium tonight at 8:30. Ignace Strasfogel will conduct, Martyn Green, will sing Gilbert and Sullivan excerpts and Gracie Fields will give music hall sketches.

" F. Scott Fitzgerald: A Critical Portrait," by Henry Dan Piper, will be published by Holt, Rinehart and Winston on July 26. Dr. Piper, whose scholarly career has taken him from Princeton to the University of Pennsylvania, Columbia, California Institute of Technology and now to Southern Illinois University, has set out to write an authoritative, comprehensive and critical biography of Fitzgerald.

The chief labor negotiator for the city's major newspapers asserted yesterday that unions often opposed the interest of both individual employes and managements when confronting the problems of automation.
MOLEPOLOLE, Bechuanaland, June 28 -- A threat of famine is hanging over this vast, barren British protectorate.

In New York State alone it is estimated that there are currently 700,000 alcoholics. If Governor Rockefeller signs the Metcalf-Mondello bill now before him, the state will take its most important step toward prevention and control of alcoholism since 1952, when it formally adopted the principle that alcoholism is a disease and not a crime.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), June 29 -- Thousands of wildly enthusiastic ultra-Orthodox Jews poured through the streets here today to greet their leader, Rabbi Joel Teitelbaum of Brooklyn.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 29 -- When "Henry IV, Part I" was last presented at the Festival Theater some years ago, the Falstaff was burly, trumpet-voiced Douglas Campbell. In this year's revival Mr. Campbell is thundering tempestuously as Hot-spur, and Tony van Bridge's Falstaff seems comparatively restrained.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -Plans for the development of Independence Center, a $50 million office building complex with related facilities on Independence Mall, were announced today.

Seven Arts Productions, Ltd., has reported that Louis A. Chesler, Morris Mac Schwebel and 15 other individuals may have sold more than 125,000 shares of the company's stock "in violation of the registration requirements of the Securities Act of 1933."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 -- In the finest tennis of this fortnight, Billie Jean Moffitt bustled Lesley Turner of Australia right out of Wimbledon to gain the semi-finals and a crack at the reigning champion, Maria Bueno of Brazil.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- British Chancellor of the Exchequer James Callaghan began two days of brief talks today with a number of top United States and international officials.

Our city fathers, having apparently received the nod of the State Assembly, have hit their yearly target again: another substantial increase in the real estate tax. Perhaps they will use some of this money for the pious objective of fighting poverty.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm-product prices increased by 2 per cent during the month ended June 15.

MONTAUK, L.I., June 29. -- The big swordfish lazed on the surface, his large, hook-like dorsal fin sticking up. Six or eight feet behind, the great sickle of his tail, seemingly too thin to push such a heavy body through the water, protruded.
JACKSON, Miss., June 29 (AP) -- The police arrested 75 civil rights demonstrators, including six white ministers, in breaking up a protest march on the capitol today.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 29 -- A bill to place strict control on lobbyists was killed by the Illinois Senate today.
The Appellate Division castigated State Supreme Court Justice John L. Flynn yesterday for his "constant interference" in the presentation of a negligence case.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -The crew members of a Pan American World Airways jetliner that lost an engine and part of a wing will receive medals for their "masterful feat of airmanship" in saving 143 passengers, the Federal Aviation Agency said today.

Although few New Yorkers are aware of it, a spirited political contest is now going on in this city and it is not to determine who will be the next Mayor of New York. It is the election to decide who will be the president of the 940,000-member National Education Association for 1966-67.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 28 -- The Venezuelan Congress passed a bill tonight requiring that all foreign insurance concerns operating here to become local corporations with 51 per cent in Venezuelan capital.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -Nicholas Guy Roosevelt, retired Philadelphia investment banker, died yesterday at his home in nearby Ambler. He was 81 years old.
Among the benefits to be realized from getting people into better housing by helping them with rent subsidies is one which has been getting too little attention [Editorial June 29].

BOSTON, June 29 -- Another challenge was hurled here today during the Advertising Federation of America's convention -one of somewhat less moment than yesterday's, but one, nonetheless, made just as seriously.
Mayor Wagner yesterday appointed the 11 members of the new Landmarks Preservation Commission.

The trend toward incorporation by the big old-line Wall Street brokerage houses in accelerating. Harris, Upham Co., one of the oldest and best-known brokerage firms, announced yesterday that it would change from a partnership to a corporation Sept. 1.

HOUSTON, June 29 (UPI) -The space agency formally signed up its first six astroscientists today. It said it would have them trained for space-flight in three years, possibly in time for one to get aboard the first manned trip to the moon.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP) -- Home runs by Tony Gonzalez, Johnny Callison and Dick Stuart, and Bo Belinsky's six-hit pitching, gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 7-1 victory tonight over the St. Louis Cards.

The efforts of Commissioner D'Angelo are commendable but inadequate, as evidenced by his suggestion to use chlorinated Hudson River water in New York City. There is a suggestion that would probably conserve more water than all the measures so far combined, but it would probably have the Real Estate Board and its lobby up in arms.
The flow of net new orders for machine tools, which turned sharply downward in April, declined again in May, according to the National Tool Builders Association.
The New York Orchestral Society gave its first concert of the summer at the Central Park Mall last night. The airplane count was low, the mosquito count nil and the music count way up.

The Liberal party has cast its lot with John V. Lindsay for Mayor of New York. This is a political event of momentous importance, validating Mr. Lindsay's insistence on true fusion in pursuit of good government. The endorsement was a logical step for the Liberal party; Mr. Lindsay is wholly compatible with Liberal ideology. No Democratic candidate is more so.
New York City and much of the Northeast are suffering from the most protracted drought on record. It has lasted four years and the city may soon be forced to take drastic water conservation measures.
PARIS, June 29 -- France and Algeria appeared today to be moving toward closer cooperation than they have had during the three years since Algeria won independence.
The Budd Company, which has pioneered several important railroad developments, said yesterday it could build a train that could go 160 miles an hour.

The execution of Sgt. Harold G. Bennett was a major tragedy of the Vietnamese war [Editorial June 26]. However, responsibility for this tragedy must be placed not only on the Vietcong, but also on the policies of our own State Department.

PARIS -- Franco-American relationships and the entire question of France's attitude toward the North Atlantic alliance may be joggled this week when the report of a Republican fact-finding mission is published in Washington.

LUXEMBOURG, June 29 -- Britain suggested today closer ties between the Common Market and the seven-nation European Free Trade Association, (EFTA). The proposal was first made at an EFTA meeting in May in Vienna.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Following is the 61-31 roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected today the Administration request to limit duty-free imports of returning overseas visitors to $50 as recommended by the Senate Finance Committee:

The Metropolitan Opera Association has added a new member to its board and two new members to the association itself. Kenneth A. Ives, a real estate broker, has been elected to the board. James F. Jaffray and Mrs. Polk Guest have been elected to membership.

LONDON, June 29 -- A proposal to make room for more administrators at Oxford University at the expense of academics was narrowly carried today after one of the biggest controversies at the university in years.

THE carterer's assistants were whipping up what Mrs. Robert Love called French Provincial hors d'oeuvre and American Tom Collinses yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of her apartment at 1120 Park Avenue.
Henry Cowell, the composer, retired yesterday from the faculty of Columbia University. Mr. Cowell, who is 68 years old, will devote his full time to composing. He is now working on his 20th Symphony.

Was it a pop art wake or a revival meeting? No one at the party staged by Basic Books last evening at Andy Warhol's studio seemed quite sure. But the gathering, held to celebrate the publication of "Pop Art," a new book by John Rublowsky and Ken Heyman, was by no means lacking in pop ingredients.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson honored Dr. Mary I. Bunting, the first woman member of the Atomic Energy Commission, in a farewell luncheon at the White House today.
James B. Donovan, who will retire tomorrow as president of the Board of Education, was treated yesterday by the Borough of Brooklyn like a 40-year teacher on the eve of his last day in the classroom.
CLEVELAND, June 29 (UPI) -- White Consolidated Industries announced today it had filed suit against the Singer Company, seeking $13,068,000 in treble damages under the Federal antitrust laws.
An underwriting group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Inc., offered yesterday 460,000 shares of Polaroid Corporation common stock at $55.50 a share -- a $25,530,000 block.

Plans for developing high-speed rail transportation in the Northeast Corridor between Boston and Washington are advancing in the capital. The Administration has asked Congress for $90 million to finance a three-year research program. Included would be a 150-mile-an-hour electrically propelled train; twenty miles of reinforced track on the main line of the Pennsylvania, south of Trenton, where it could be tested, and self-propelled gas turbine cars on the New Haven between Boston and Providence.
SAN DIEGO, June 29 -- Peter Snell is en route to Europe for his last fling. He wants badly to regain the world mile record, and then he wants badly, to enjoy a retirement devoted to golf and tennis.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Agency for International Development said tonight it was investigating applications for two $10,000 insurance policies on the life of an aid official submitted after he had been kidnapped by the Vietcong last February.
" OFFENBACH PROMENADE" at Philharmonic Hall. Under a blue banner that read, "Paris, France," four short white stools topped with pink cushions. Franz Allers trips to podium, raises baton.
LONDON, June 29 -- An initial victory went to the Government today in its fight to control prices and kages by persuasion.

MOSCOW, June 29 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin warned today against attempts to interfere in the internal affairs of emerging nations. He denounced the United States by name. The Soviet leader did not mention China but rebutted specific points of Peking's appeals to African and Asian countries.

At 3:03 P.M., yesterday, the New York Stock Exchange tape clacked out a simple message -- "FIVE HOUR VOLUME 9.2 MILLION SHARES" -- but it was enough to gladden the hearts of brokers during a rising stock market.

OTTAWA, June 29 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson tonight announced to a tense House of Commons the resignation of Justice Minister Guy Favreau following criticism of the minister's handling of a bribery case.

The Emmys Awards demonstrated a continuing interest in culture yesterday by making themselves available to TV shows involving the Louvre, Leonardo da Vinci and James Baldwin. Nominees for the 1964-65 season were announced by the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A group of universities has formed a new corporation that will offer to manage a proposed $280 million atom-smasher machine should Congress approve construction.

The office of State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has obtained an injunction to prevent Thomas D. Voiss from soliciting funds for his musical "Brave New World" until it is registered as required by the State Theatrical Financing Act.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) Pete Rose drove in three runs in leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-5 second-game victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates that gave the Reds a split in a double-header tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee approved by a divided vote today the nomination of a retired Air Force general, William F. McKee, to head the Federal Aviation Agency.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 29 -- Units of Kenya's paramilitary police rolled northward into the parched areas of Nanyuki and Laikipia tonight to meet the fiercest attacks by nomadic Somali raiders, known as Shifta, that Kenya has known in her year and a half of independence.

The Johnson Administration and the stock market are both behaving in roller coaster fashion. The trouble is that neither is contributing much light to the controversy over where the economy is headed.
District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens proposed yesterday that the five Democratic county committees take a secret ballot to narrow the growing field of party candidates for Mayor.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 29 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan said tonight that more than 30 highly trained Indian and Pakistani divisions were facing each other along their countries' frontiers.
Saks-34th Street, the 63-year-old specialty store at Herald Square, has taken another, very short, lease on life.

BALTIMORE, June 29 -- Dr. Melvin J. Humphrey resigned today as executive director of the city's antipoverty program in a reported rift with Morton Yacht, chairman of the commission that oversees the program.

Since the opening of the World's Fair in 1964 all kinds of things have been pilfered -pewter, candlesticks from the Spanish Pavilion, transistor radios from the Japanese Pavilion, red tail-lights from the Ford Rotunda.
The Bankers Trust Company painted a generally optimistic picture of the economy yesterday for the rest of this year, "if not through the early part of 1966 as well."

JIM HALL and Hap Sharp of Midland, Tex., who ran away with the first two places in the United States road racing championship event at Watkins Glen, N.Y., last Sunday, have sent their Chevrolet-Chaparrals up to the St. Jovite-Mt. Tremblant course in Quebec for next Sunday's Labatt Trophy race.

Mrs. Leo Simon, New York patron of the arts and philanthropist, has given a $125,000 organ to Carnegie Hall. The installation of the instrument will necessitate major alterations to the stage of the hall.

Few political movements have been so bizarre, so world-shaking, so fully documented or so elusive of rational comprehension as German National Socialism. Considering all the books, brilliant and sleazy, that have been written, the subject might seem exhausted. But these three studies, all of the better category and all by professional historians, testify that there are still important aspects of the Nazi phenomenon to be explored and understood.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 29 -- A couple of maidens, which around a racetrack is an endearing term for horses that never have won, captured the first two events at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The result was an "Uncle Sam" daily double of $884.20, which means the names of the winners must be reported to the Internal Revenue Service for income-tax purposes.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -The Federal Government gave approval today for construction of the $97.3 million Bellevue South urban renewal project on the East Side of Manhattan in New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -The Senate, in a sharp defeat for the Administration, refused today to limit to $50 the amount of duty-free goods that returning travelers may bring into the country. The vote was 61 to 31.
FOR the second time in 22 years, the Coty American Fashion Critics' Award failed to single out a Seventh Avenue designer to receive the Winnie, the bronze trophy signifying the group's top accolade.

DENVER, June 29 -- Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of the City College of New York, told the annual N.A.A.C.P. convention tonight that the time had come to make an important choice of tactics, one that would affect the future moral climate of American society.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Guitars and new player-pianos attracted major interest today at the annual music show displaying what was billed as the world's largest exhibit of musical merchandise and home entertainment products under one roof.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- "The American Bell," a $250,000 sound-and-light dramatization of events leading to the Declaration of Independence, will not be shown this summer at Independence Hall. It had been presented each summer since its premiere, July 2, 1962.
The 14-day-old maritime strike moved into a crisis atmosphere yesterday as a Federal official in Washington warned that the strikers were demanding too much.

A three-man delegation from the Banco de la Republica, Uruguay's central bank, arrived here yesterday from Montevideo to renegotiate some overdue loans with a number of commercial banks and possibly to open some new lines of credit.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts went nearly $1 million over its goal of $15.5 million in public contributions today with the presentation of Italy's gift, $1,168,000 worth of marble for the structure.

A letter to The Times [June 18] argued that "involvement of church-related institutions in Project Headstart and other antipoverty programs constitutes a major step backward" in that "those who enter a church building to avail themselves of the benefits of the project will again experience the degrading feeling of being a recipient of charity."
The National Labor Relations Board yesterday ordered individual union representation elections held in 38 fleet taxi garages here.

Your editorial of June 22 "Tension in Kashmir" does manifest your concern for the continuity of peace on the Indian subcontinent. But like a Sunday preacher who mechanically uses words like God, Almighty and the like you prate terms such as plebiscite and self-determination in advancing a solution for the Kashmir dispute.

C.F. Childs Co., a financial concern that has described itself as "the oldest house in America specializing in Government securities," is withdrawing from trading and underwriting Treasury, municipal and corporate securities, effective today.

Percy C. Magnus, the 72-year-old former president of the New York Board of Trade, was convicted in Federal Court yesterday of willful failure to pay income taxes for the years 1955 to 1957, amounting to about $85,000.

Bob Barker of Port Washington, L.I., the top favorite in the New York State claycourt championship, defeated Herb Charlop of New York, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday in the third round at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

SAIGON, June 29 (AP) -- Three square miles of Zone D, scene of the new anti-Vietcong offensive, were subjected to saturation bombing on June 18 by 27 of the Strategic Air Command's B-52 Jets and dozens of smaller planes.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Agency for International Development announced today that 19 volunteer graduate students had been sent to Vietnam to assist in health, educational and similar work in rural areas this summer.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department said today smokers in the United States are using more cigarettes now than they did before the smoking and health report of Jan. 11, 1964.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 -- It began as something less than a real Wimbledon day, when the sun glints off the ivy, and the red, pink, green, blue and yellow of the ladies' straw hats clash with the grammar school beanies and the flowers outside the walls of the center court.
Twelve union officials called to testify before a Senate subcommittee yesterday invoked the Fifth Amendment and refused to discuss their members' welfare funds.
The temperature reached 95 degrees at 4:35 P.M. yesterday. It was a record for the year and a harbinger of the long, hot months ahead.

BOSTON, June 29 (AP) -- Max Alvis rapped three hits, including a two-run homer, as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8-5, tonight, and took sole possession of first place in the American League.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -Racial and ethnic groups of poor persons protested today that entrenched power was shutting them out of the planning to combat poverty in some areas.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 29 -- Adlai E. Stevenson has been urged by a group of prominent artists, writers and scientists to resign as chief United States delegate to the United Nations as a protest against the Administration's foreign policy -- particularly in Vietnam.
The Douglas Aircraft Company lifted its sales and earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended May 31, and also reported yesterday a strong backlog dominated by commercial business.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 -- United States bomber pilots, participating in the American offensive against the Vietcong in Zone D, are feeling the frustrations of trying to hit an enemy burrowed deep among tall trees.

ALGIERS, June 29 -- Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika was reliably reported today to have summoned Soviet and other diplomats to warn them against "any interference in Algeria's internal affairs."

INWOOD, L.I., June 29 -Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedarbrook and Mrs. Gino Scalamandre of Sands Point, scored 42, 39 -- 81 today to repeat as winners in the 27th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association John B. Mackie Memorial Scotch foursome tournament at the Inwood Country Club.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick came out strongly yesterday against controversial proposals for an independent civilian board to review complaints of police brutality.
The National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing said yesterday that the nation's real estate interests were involved in a "concerted effort to nullify fair housing legislation."

A sweater manufacturer in Queens and a coffee company in Brooklyn have received long-term, low-interest second mortgage loans from the city to help expand their plants. The loans have been made by the city's Industrial Development Corporation, established in 1964 to retain and expand industries here and bring new ones to the city.
AS the White Queen told Alice, it only takes practice to be able to believe impossible things: "Why sometimes," she said, "I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast."

The McMillan Corporations, a new subsidiary of Lundy Electronics and Systems, Inc., has named David H. Robinson to the post of general manager. He was marketing manager for the aerospace systems division of the Radio Corporation of America.
LOS ANGELES, June 29 -William M. Keck Sr., the oil magnate, died owing $36.4 million to three banks in New York and Texas, but his estate is still expected to be worth upward of $160 million.
WHO cuts the hair of the men who cut the hair of the world's best-coifed women?

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Prof. Richard E. Neustadt suggested today that the nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization forget the divisive problem of reorganizing the alliance and concentrate on more "concrete ventures of common interest."

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Al Downing pitched a no-hitter for 6-2/3 innings tonight, then lost both the no-hitter and the ball game when the Washington Senators nipped the New York Yankees in the stretch, 2-1.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn. June 29 (AP) -- Zoilo Versalles' sacrifice fly with one out in the ninth inning scored Dave Boswell, a pinch runner, with the run that gave the Minnesota Twins a 7-6 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 29 -- Kelso's return to the races today at Monmouth Park was a training success, but a financial failure for those who bet on the 8-year-old gelding to win. The greatest money winner in the annals of the American turf finished third in a $5,000 allowance race that was intended to be a mere exercise for him.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Freedom from Hunger Foundaal two weeks ago, Massachusetts and Nevada were expected to knock out their own restriction said today the world faced a "global food catastrophe."

ALGIERS, June 29 -- The Algerian coup d'etat and the testy frictions of its first 10 days have left the Arab world, already torn by dissension over Palestine policy, in greater disarray than at any other time since Syria seceded from the United Arab Republic in September, 1961.
ELGIN, Ill., June 29 (AP) -- Six of nine men nominated by the management of the Elgin National Watch Company were elected directors today.
The quarterback took the center snap, pranced rapidly backward 10 paces, cocked his right arm and threw a forward pass. The football spiraled at high velocity 20 yards into the receiver's hands.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 29 (AP) -- Derek Graham of Britain captured the 5,000-meter run in the Zurich international meet today, defeating Gerry Lindgren of the United States and Gaston Roelants of Belgium.

WHITE PLAINS, June 29 -- The Westchester District Attorney's office began an investigation today to determine whether negligence at the county's Grasslands Hospital at Eastview, had contributed to the death there Saturday night of John S. Colton, 56 years old, of 176 Beach Street, Rockaway Beach.
MOSCOW, June 29 -- The Soviet Union is beginning to face up to an unaccustomed problem in its economy: how to insure full employment for its citizens.
CHICAGO, June 29 -- Civil rights leaders met with members of the School Board here today but failed to resolve any differences.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Johnson Administration was reported unmoved today by suggestions that it indicate a willingness to negotiate directly with the Vietcong. Officials maintain that in any case there is no one in Vietnam to talk to at this point and little to talk about.
The Amphenol Corporation, a widely diversified maker of electronic components, timing devices and deep-pile fabrics, plans to add illuminated electric signs and signal devices to its product lines.
Is margin playing a key role in the market's sharp decline of the last six weeks?

Dr. Timothy W. Costello, a 49-year-old psychology professor, was chosen yesterday as a running mate by Representative John V. Lindsay, the Republican who won the possibly decisive Liberal party endorsement for Mayor on Monday.
The Pellon Corporation, a producer of non-woven fabrics, has developed a spun-web textile that can combine two other textile surfaces.

AMERICAN writers who live in Europe for any considerable length of time are likely to write novels about Americans living in Europe. The change of air and the exchange of familiar backgrounds for unfamiliar ones seem inspirational in a literary sense. From Hawthorne and James through Hemingway, Lewis, Wolfe and Fitzgerald and scores of lesser lights, American novelists have written about their fellow countrymen behaving in Europe differently than at home.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -The Republican National Committee voted today to try to moderate the confusion of its national conventions.

The briefest rejoinder to William F. Larsen's comment of June 23 on my letter of June 13, in which I supported Secretary Rusk's charge that some in the academic community are "gullible" and "disregard plain facts":

Vice President Humphrey, in a recent address to the National War College, spoke of "a bold new form of aggression which could rank in military importance with the discovery of gunpowder. I refer to the 'war of national liberation.' . . . This new, sophisticated form of warfare is becoming the major challenge to our security." President Johnson, Secretary Rusk, Ambassador Stevenson and many other American leaders could be quoted in a similar vein.
Trading in the stock market yesterday was the heaviest in more than three years.
The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it had successfully completed its offering to shareholders of $266,307,500 of 4 per cent convertible capital notes.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 29 (AP) -- The National Sheriffs Association witnessed a demonstration today of what was described as "the ultimate weapon in using minimum force to disperse a mob" -- a bubbleblowing machine.
A group composed largely of American clergymen left Kennedy International Airport last night for Paris en route to South Vietnam, where they seek to begin a goodwill mission.
The American Stock Exchange reflected yesterday the strength shown on the New York Stock Exchange, although volume lagged somewhat. Trading fell to 1.75 million shares from 2.72 million Tuesday.
A New Jersey contractor and a New York land development concern have joined forces to develop an industrial park on 200 acres of former grazing land in Orangetown, Rockland County.

SOME of the most interesting bridge hands occur when the declarer is faced by a terrible break in the trump suit. If he keeps his head, as declarer did in the deal shown, he can sometimes maneuver an endplay situation to his advantage.
WARSAW, June 30 -- Poland's elite security troops were taken from the Ministry of Interior today and put under the control of the Ministry of Defense.

CAIRO, June 30 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China flew home today after a brief official visit that turned into a 12-day Egyptian "holiday," with cruises in the Nile and nightly movies at a palace of the late King Farouk.

ALBANY, June 30 -- By next Jan. 1, virtually all owners of apartment buildings in New York City will have to install a peephole in the entrance door of every apartment so that the tenant can see and identify any person standing outside.
The stock market boomed again yesterday as prices registered their biggest one-day gains in more than a year and half.
A New Rochelle travel agent was charged with grand larceny yesterday in the alleged charter flight swindle of several hundred schoolteachers.

DENVER, June 30 -- A curtain was briefly raised today on the growing animosity of the underprivileged Negroes against those who have advanced to the middle grid professional classes. Animosity was also revealed against the Negro Baptist clergy, the domininat Protestant group among America's 20 million Negroes.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 30 -- Call it the "perfecta," as it is listed here, or the "exacta," as it is labeled at some other gambling palaces, this form of exotic wagering, introduced to this state at Monticello Raceway tonight, is a "betting gimmick" designed to stimulate business.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 30 -- Governor Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon told the American Works Association today that the nation should look at its water problems from a continental approach.
JACKSON, Miss., June 30 -- A three-judge panel in New Orleans temporarily enjoined this city today from arresting more civil rights demonstrators under its parade and handbill ordinances.

BALTIMORE, June 30 -- Handwriting an art, or an Art? Is such a thing possible in this day and age, that of the printing press, the typewriter, the telephone, the dictaphone and the inflexible ball-point pen?
The nation's electric power production rose 3.4 per cent in the week ended June 26, from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) -- Fred Newman pitched a two-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Angels snapped a five-game losing streak by beating the Minnesota Twins, 5-0.
A two-day extension of the week-long trial of a typesetting computer at The New York Post was announced yesterday in an agreement between the newspaper and New York Typographical Union No. 6.
The election of Claude S. Ramsey Jr. to the new post of executive vice president was announced yesterday by the American Enka Corporation, a producer of chemical fiber.

A cache of arms that included three mortars, 30 machine guns and 2,000 rounds of ammunition was uncovered in Brooklyn last night hours before it was to be turned over to anti-Castro Cubans, the police reported.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 -- The Soviet Union and the Ukraine have paid $5,508,000 toward the United Nations regular budget for 1965, but have not altered their refusal to pay for Congo peace-keeping costs.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would take no reprisals against the Liberal party for backing Republican Representative John V. Lindsay for Mayor.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Secretary of the Treasury urged today a revision of tax laws covering foreigners who invest in the United States.
John A. McCone, former director of the Central Intelligence Agency and chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, was elected yesterday to the board of the Standard Oil Company of California.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia and the leaders of the Soviet Union signed a joint statement today in the Kremlin. Reliable sources said that it expressed greater harmony between the two countries on international issues than at any time since Yugoslavia's expulsion from the Communist movement by Stalin in 1948.

HOUSTON, June 30 (AP) -- Jim Wynn drove in one run with a triple in the eighth inning tonight and then stole home as the Houston Astros scored a 6 -- 4 triumph over the San Francisco Giants. Three runs by the Giants had tied the game in the top of the inning.

Every man has the right to ask a rhetorical question, but so, one supposes, does every man at whose expense they are asked have the right to make the effort to undeceive those who are led astray by them. To judge from your editorial "What Makes Buckley Run?"
PARIS, June 30 -- President de Gaulle won Parliamentary approval last night for a central point of his vision of the new French society: Cooperation between labor and management.

Directors of the Storer Broadcasting Company met here yesterday afternoon, but up to late last night there was no word what action the board decided to take with respect to an option the company has to acquire working control of Northeast Airlines.
CHICAGO, June 30 -- Accusations of Communist agitation and witch-hunting were exchanged today as Chicago's civil rights demonstrations were resumed by 90 activists marching on City Hall.
The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company will begin an advertising campaign for its new Masterpiece filter cigarette next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- President Johnson presented Young American Medals for bravery and service today to four youths -- one posthumously. He said they symbolized an American younger generation equal to any demands "that destiny might make of them."
The 25-acre site of Steeplechase Park, the first of the great Coney Island amusement parks, is expected to be used for a major housing development, it was disclosed last night.

VANCOUVER, B.C., June 30 -- The use of a single fuel, natural gas, to supply the complete energy requirements of a skyscraper, a shopping center or a group of apartment buildings was advocated today as a means of reducing construction and operating costs.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today by voice vote President Johnson's controversial nomination of a retired Air Force general, William F. McKee, to head the Federal Aviation Agency.
The American League chose to sacrifice speed and defense for power in its selection of a starting line-up for the All-Star game against the National League at Minnesota July 13.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- It will be Roy Emerson against Fred Stolle in the old familiar script.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 29 -- At a training center near here Battery 161 of New Zealand's small military forces is packing its gear. The battery's 120 men and four 105 field guns will be flown to Saigon in three Hercules transports that the New Zealand Air Force recently acquired from the United States.

New York has such a profusion of candidates for Mayor this year, with such diversity of viewpoints, that it might have been assumed that Vito P. Battista would feel he was not needed on the hustings. But the Brooklyn architect, city planner and omnipresent gadfly of the Board of Estimate at budget-making time, has heard the call again and will run against John V. Lindsay for the Republican nomination.

David G. Baird, a man who for decades has flitted anonymously between his world of high finance and the world of the poor, came out into the open yesterday to be honored by Mayor Wagner and about 350 leaders of the city's health and welfare agencies.

The City Housing Authority is paying more under new contracts for painting than it would have paid for the same work under contracts it canceled or refused to award as a result of a grand jury investigation into bid rigging.
STRATFORD, Ont., June 30 -- "Henry IV, Part II" travels here under the name of "Falstaff," probably to minimize confusion, since both Part I and Part II are being performed at this year's festival.
A majority of the Democratic district leaders in Queens voted last night to endorse City Council President Paul R. Screvane for the party's mayoral nomination.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 30 -- David Ben-Gurion, former Israeli Premier, was said today to be popular enough to gain 10 of Parliament's 120 seats in the forthcoming election.

The World's Fair is studying the possibility of extending an invitation to Pope Paul VI to visit the fair if he should come to the United States for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly on Oct. 23.
NEWARK, June 30 (AP) -- Five new antipoverty programs totaling $1.5 million were proposed for Newark today by Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio.

An immediate investigation of alleged "racism" in the Police Department was demanded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor, a former member of the Board of Education and pastor of Brooklyn's largest Protestant Church, the Concord Baptist Church of Christ.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler repeated today his view that, as far as "the eye of economic foresight can see ahead," there was no indication of economic difficulty for the country.
BRUSSELS, Thursday, July 1 -- The Common Market was plunged into a crisis early today.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 30 (UPI) -- The University of California will put sweeping new rules into effect tomorrow that give the chancellors of the nine campuses more independence and the 65,000 students more freedom.

The Beneficial Finance Company, a large consumer finance agency, announced yesterday the election of Edgar T. Higgins as a director. Mr. Higgins is vice president, counsel and a member of the executive committee of the Beneficial Management Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 30 -- "You should hear what's going on," Charles Rapp said today. "Right now I'm getting ready to collapse." With the July 4 weekend approaching, Mr. Rapp, a bald, energetic, 56-year-old man who is the leading booking agent in the Catskill Mountains, is lining up comedians, sopranos, tenors, baritones, blues singers, folk singers, harmonica players, accordion players, jugglers, magicians, ballroom dancers and tap dancers for hundreds of hotels.
Herbert Johannes Steel, former political commentator and an unsuccessful candidate for Congress here, was convicted on 14 counts of stock fraud last night.

The $5 million bonds of the Fort Worth, Tex., independent school district were awarded yesterday to a group headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank. The group's bid set an annual net interest cost of 3.2338 per cent.

BALTIMORE, June 30 -- The New York Yankees brought up reinforcements from the International League again tonight, but as the reinforcements arrived the tattered old regulars were knocking off the Baltimore Orioles, 5-4.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Secretary of the Treasury and the British Chancellor of the Exchequer agreed today to press forward toward an improved international monetary system, but they made clear they did not count on any quick results.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Four House Republicans recommended today that President Johnson make a trip to Europe "for the single purpose of visiting President de Gaulle of France."
HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa., June 30 -- A strong Philadelphia girls junior golf team defeated Boston and New York today in intercity team matches for the Mrs. Frank Enos Trophy.
JOHN SANDER, who lives on East 58th Street, decided that his next dog would be a dachshund, but then he saw a Jack Russell terrier and wanted one.
The month of June was more chaotic and hectic than merry on the stock market. But it was certainly historic as measured by volume of trading and wide stock price swings.
TORONTO, June 30 -- Pulp and paper producers in eastern Canada, who supply at least 60 per cent of the United States newsprint requirements, are facing an uncertain period of labor negotiations.
PHOENIX, Ariz., June 30 (UPI) -- The Phoenix Evening American, an afternoon offset newspaper, suspended daily operation effective today.

SEGU BUNUK, Sarawak, June 27 -- Shreds of smoke from breakfast fires lingered over Segu Bunuk this morning and shouting children made the split bamboo planks of the long veranda crackle as they played hide and seek among the doors of the longhouse.

THIS will have to be personal. There's no other way I can write it. When Jack Mara, president of the New York Football Giants, died on Tuesday, the sports world lost one of its best-liked and most admirable executives. He was my closest friend -- a friend for more than 30 years.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 -- A spokesman for Secretary General Thant said today that he was gratified at the cease-fire in the Rann of Cutch and would be ready to offer his assistance if needed.
The rain that has been falling mainly in the southwestern Plain States did it again yesterday and helped push up prices of wheat futures.

HENLEY, England, June 30 -- The Royal Henley Regatta, four days of caste reunions, cheap carnival and classic crew racing, began today on the placid River Thames with a record-breaking performance in the single sculls by Don Spero of the New York Athletic Club.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 1 -- A Government infantry battalion fought its way out of a Vietcong trap late yesterday in Phubon Province in the Central Highlands.

The Great Western Financial Corporation of Los Angeles moved a step closer yesterday otward complete centralization of its operations by announcing plans for a merger of two of its southern California associations.

ROME, June 30 -- Delegates from 30 countries to the 85th anniversary congress of the Organization for Rehabilitation and Training, ending here today, approved a five-year program for expansion and intensification of vocational and technical training.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- President Johnson signed tonight a bill providing a four-year extension of export controls.
