PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP) -- Tony Taylor's seventh-inning single that drove in Bobby Wine gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 3-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of I per cent to a record in May and is expected to go up again in June despite the excise tax cuts, the Government reported today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 301t -- President Humberto Castello! Braneo received President Freil with military honors at the! Galeao Air Force Base today, i The two Presidents talked for l 40 minutes at the base corn-I mander's residence. No com-i muniqu was issued. [ After an hour and 30 minutes] on the ground, Mr. Frei and his l party continued the trip toI Europe in an Alitalia jet flight.

The effectiveness of the city's "More Effective Schools" was questioned yesterday by a member of the Board of Education yesterday about an hour after he and his colleagues voted to spend $3 million to establish 10 more such schools next fall.
BONN, June 30 -- Gunmen critically wounded three Yugoslav exiles living in West Germany when they fired a volley of shots into a Croatian welfare agency in Dusseldorf today.
MANVILLE, N.J., June 30 (AP) -- Nine truckloads of dirt were dumped on Brooks Boulevard yesterday by a man who owns the land on which a section of the roadway was built.
Mediators kept bargaining teams in session last night in the 16-day maritime strike that kept more than 3,000 passengers awaiting a verdict on their travel plans.
" I think the stock market is going to be good," Max Rubin declared yesterday. "I'm a trader and an investor -- a little of each -- but I haven't bought or sold any stocks in three weeks."

FRED SNITZER, a Brooklyn expert, went gunning for big game recently when he faced Grand Master Bobby Fischer, the United States champion, in Fischer's simultaneous exhibition at the Church Center of the United Nations.
BUENOS AIRES, June 30 -- The Presidents of Chile and Argentina today discussed the Dominican crisis and its implication for the future of the Organization of American States.
LONDON, June 30 -- The North Vietnamese Government has indicated that it may receive the Commonwealth peace mission if the mission's approaches reflect a formal recognition of it as a government.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Del Le John, a 31-year-old rookie third baseman, made two key hits today in his first two major league times at bat and scored the fourth run for the Los Angeles Dodgers as they downed the Chicago Cubs, 4-3, for a split of their double-header.
A court order yesterday cleared the way for the closing today of St. Catherine's Hospital in Brooklyn over strong protests by residents in the Greenpoint-Williamsburg area.

Atlanta yesterday became a National Football League city. Pete Rozelle, the league commissioner who was in Atlanta, accepted -- on behalf of the league -- the application of Rankin M. Smith, an insurance executive, as the owner of the new franchise.

One hundred and fifty-six glass panels ranging in size up to 18 feet wide and 14 feet high are being installed this week in the new Metropolitan Opera House being built at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Three witnesses testified in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday that Gareth Martinis was belligerent and intoxicated at the 50th Precinct station house to which he was taken following an accident on May 19, 1963, that killed five persons.
EDWARDS, Miss., June 30 (UPI) -- A white lawyer was convicted today of firing shots into an Project Headstart office on the grounds of a civil rights headquarters here last Friday.

Robert L. Bendick, the producer of a children's series that will appear in the fall over the National Broadcasting Company network, said yesterday that the programs would employ song, dance and the Socratic method of inquiry to stimulate children's interest in the world they live in.
FRENCH decorators have been establishing beachheads in New York for decades. Now Valerian S. Rybar, Yugoslav-born American designer, intends to conduct his overseas operations from Paris.

KANSAS CITY, June 30 (AP) -- Johnny Buzhardt hit Bert Campaneris with a pitch with the bases loaded in the ninth inning, forcing in Ed Charles with the run that gave Kansas City a 4-3 victory over Chicago and a sweep of their doubleheader tonight.

The director of the urban redevelopment division of the Action Council for Better Cities, Stephen D. Moses, has been named vice president and secretary of the recently organized City Reconstruction Corporation.

THE corner boutique is replacing the vanishing dressmaker in the modern woman's life. It provides clothes that are individual-looking and few-of-a-kind. The proprietor can usually be coaxed into making small variations in design and fabric. And there is often an adjacent workroom that can effect major construction changes such as equipping a size 10 bodice with a size 12 skirt.
The National Labor Relations Board yesterday set July 21 as the date for garage-by-garage elections for union representation among many of the city's striking taxi drivers.

Although expenditures for education are at a record high, there are still 10 million pupils in deteriorated buildings, according to a report made public yesterday. Seven million of these children occupy schools that are fire hazards, the report declared.

Bobby Ussery was Mr. Outside and Mr. Inside in two winning endeavors at Aqueduct yesterday. In his latter role, he won the feature event on the card, a 1 1/8-mile turf race, aboard the Meadowhill's Tarpon.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Ray C. Bliss, the Chairman of the Republican National Committee, has good reason for concern whenever a new splinter group appears within the party. Each cuts down the flow of money into the central treasury, and money is the sap political organizations require to grow on -- sometimes, as in the case of the Republican party, merely to survive the next general election.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Labor Department advised Congress today that a national law was needed to deal with the growing problem of denial of employment to older persons even though they are still able to work with full productivity.
GENEVA, June 30 -- The United States concluded an $800,000 real estate deal today that gave it title to almost six acres of choice Geneva land.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Congress met President Johnson halfway today in efforts to stem the flow of dollars overseas by approving a compromise bill aimed at discouraging spending abroad by American tourists.
PARIS, June 30 -- France has decided to withdraw her representative on the United Nations command in Korea effective tomorrow, authorized sources said today.
Governor Rockefeller's recent action to make jobs available to the mentally retarded in the State Civil Service is a commendable one and worthy of enthusiastic public support.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A top-secret report to President Johnson is understood to have recommended that a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons be given priority over the establishment of an Atlantic nuclear force.
Mayor Wagner laid down a hard-and-fast city policy yesterday of building municipal parking plazas and garages to stop the use of public streets as parking lots.
DANANG, South Vietnam Thursday, July 1 -- Communist guerrillas made a surprise penetration attack on the Danang Air Base in the pre-dawn darkness today.

LONDON, June 30 -- The House of Commons was besieged today by a leftist-inspired group of about 4,000 persons petitioning the British Government to dissociate itself from United States policy in Vietnam.
School is out! At noon yesterday, 1,044,621 pupils were released from classroom routines in the city's 850 public schools. But they were greeted at the exits by a gray drizzle.
Directors of the Asgrow Seed Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one stock split and company officers said they would recommend the adoption of a 10-cent quarterly dividend on the new stock.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Washington Senators scored on a double-play grounder in the first inning and on Ken Hamlin's sacrifice fly in the second tonight, then went on to beat the Cleveland Indians, 2-1.
Governor Rockefeller vetoed last night the bill that would have put the city's revised antipoverty structure into effect.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. -- When Costatino Nivola, the sculptor, cooks in the back lawn of his East Hampton home, it is usually with the bold and inventive touch characteristic of the work that has brought him fame.

BAMRERG, Germany, June 30 (AP) -- Vandals smeared Nazi slogans on a gymnasts' statue near Bamberg's Sports Stadium last night. The smears included the statement, "to the gallows with the Jew accomplice Erhard."
MILFORD, Conn., June 30 -- A one-boy crusade against the sale of "sexy books to teen-agers" has been undertaken by William Crowshaw Bevan, a high school junior who was 16 years old yesterday.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 30 -- Peace negotiations have made the committee of the Organization of American States increasingly popular with the rebel forces here, but increasingly unpopular with the military-civilian junta.

A squadron of four destroyers from four North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations -- the first to operate as an integral multinational force -- is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow morning for a four-day visit.

A broadly representative group of Jewish organizations submitted a set of guidelines yesterday to United States Education Commissioner Francis Keppel in connection with the recently enacted law on Federal aid to education.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored two runs in the fifth inning and five in the ninth tonight as they defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-1, snapping Vern Law's winning streak at eight games.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House passed the housing bill tonight after narrowly defeating efforts to kill the Administration's rent subsidy plan.

WROXTON, England, June 30 -- A stately Oxfordshire home on 56 rolling acres of lawns, lakes and woodlands was dedicated today as Wroxton College, the first educational institution on English soil to be owned by an American university.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate Rules Committee passed today another milestone, and possibly its last one, in its long investigation of the business affairs of Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate's Democratic majority.
The striped bass is one of the important game fish for multitudes of fishermen along the Atlantic coast. Two important spawning areas of the bass are the Delaware and the Hudson Rivers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The General Services Administration -- the Government's official shopper -- disclosed today the final list of 17 safety features it would demand in all new cars it bought, beginning with the 1967 models.

HENLEY, June 30 (AP) -- Francis Sulger of the New York Athletic Club won his first heat of the Diamond Sculls today at the Royal Henley Regatta. The New Yorker defeated J.S. Pilgrim-Morris of the British Royal Air Force by half a length in 8:06.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- This is graduation day at the Agency for International Development.
The stockholders of the American Tobacco Company voted yesterday at a special meeting in Newark to retire the preferred stock.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Md., June 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Union took a commanding lead today in the race for gold medals at the International Games for the Deaf, while the United States came up with its first double winner and also gained its first gold medal in swimming.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A proposed constitutional amendment to deal with the long-vexing problem of Presidential disability encountered new difficulties in the Senate today. Final Congressional action was postponed until next week.

Better times appear in prospect for the Long Island Rail Road and its 260,000 daily riders. The chairman of the new Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority, Dr. William J. Ronan, holds out the promise of a $200 million modernization program without a fare increase. That would seem too good to be true to commuters who have known six fare increases in the past ten years.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Plans for a $71 million combined church center and middle-income housing project Were made known today by the board of directors of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist.
Convertible bonds, securely linked to changes in stock prices, advanced sharply yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- Pravda explained patiently today why the Moskva Restaurant, one of the largest in the Soviet capital, should be allowed to buy more than 5 rubles ($5.55) worth of soup greens a day.

Chile's proposed program to double copper production over the next five years will not adversely affect prices for the metal, Radomiro Tomic, Chilean Ambassador to the United States declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Treasury Secretary Henry H. Fowler disclosed today another in a series of reductions in the estimated budget deficit for the fiscal year that ended today.

E. J. Korvette, Inc., the nation's leading discount chain, will set up a new wholly-owned subsidiary, Korvette Home Furnishings Centers, Inc., combining both its previously leased furniture and carpet operations.
The Ralston Purina Company announced yesterday it was moving about $4.3 million in billings from Guild, Bascom Bonfigli, Inc., to a larger agency.
A boatload of 800 politicians and their wives spent a day at the races yesterday, doping the longshots in both bangtails and politics.

TORONTO, June 30 -- A major controlling interest has been acquired in the Bulkley Valley Pulp and Timber, Ltd., of Houston, B.C., by Bathurst Paper, Ltd., of Montreal, and the Bowaters Canadian Corporation, part of the London-based Bowater Paper Corporation, it was announced today.
GROTON, Conn., Thursday, July 1 (AP) -- Production workers went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today against the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation.

Prof. Everett W. Bovard's June 25 letter recommending prohibition of our use of napalm and the South Vietnamese use of torture of prisoners has answered well James Reston's question about what the President could do in Vietnam.

ALGIERS, June 30 -- In his first speech since the ouster of President Ahmed Ben Bella June 19, Col. Houari Boumedienne declared today that Algeria had "no need of advice from abroad on how to build socialism."
DECORATING buffs who are willing to run the gantlet of exposed cement pillars in the skeletal lobby of a new luxury apartment house may pick up some design ideas this summer.

Frank Sinatra, making his first public appearance in New York in eight years, will open the sixth season of the Forest Hills Music Festival at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium on Thursday, July 8. He will also appear on July 9 and July 10.
HAZARD, Ky., June 30 (UPI) -- Gov. Edward T. Breathitt announced today steps he would take to combat the damage done by strip and auger mining.
Governor Rockefeller is too young to have participated as I did in the early epic battles for the principle of the variant of the direct primary which now awaits his signature.
THE word from Ducks Unlimited, the conservation organization that maintains large areas of waterfowl production grounds, bogs and waters in Canada, is that things are going swimmingly, so to speak.

Wars of "national liberation," which American leaders now rate as the major threat in the struggle of the Communist world against the non-Communist, know no rules and offer no tangible targets. This is what makes them so difficult to combat.

The 30-story Savoy Plaza, which officially closed yesterday, will be home for the next two weeks to seven guests, who will reside in splendid isolation in suites scattered throughout the hotel's upper 18 floors.
SASSAFRAS, Ky. -- Coal is touching off another angry uprising here in eastern Kentucky, where it is virtually the only industry in the most chronically depressed section of Appalachia.

BONN, June 30 -- A few months before his death in 1955, Albert Einstein wrote a friend that if he could start his life all over again he would not choose a profession "that has to do with the search for knowledge."
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, delivered a stinging reply today to the mounting Republican campaign for more aggressive military and political actions in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to provide 34 new United States District Court judges and 10 new Appellate Court judges in five circuits.

WASHINGTON June 30 (UPI) -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today he had strongly recommended President Johnson's nomination of former Gov. J. P. Coleman of Mississippi to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

The Federal Aviation Agency was criticized yesterday for its method of selecting small airports to receive Federally-financed all-weather landing aids, such as the electronic Instrument Landing System.
Constance Baker Motley, Borough President of Manhattan, yesterday urged revisions in the City Charter to allow for more active citizen participation in government.
The departure of Kenneth E. BeLieu from Government service today is a loss to the Administration, and -- more specifically -- to the Navy.
Donald C. Cook, a close friend and adviser to President Johnson, believes strongly that the outlook for the second half is for "continued over-all strength and growth in the economy."

A June 22 news article indicated that the late Marilyn Monroe's million-dollar estate will be "completely consumed by Federal income, state and estate taxes." As a result, a $100,000 trust fund which was supposed to provide $5,000 annually for the support of Miss Monroe's mother, a patient in a California sanitarium, will be reduced to nonexistence.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 30 -- A little bit of Irish tuck on grass made greener by an afternoon rainfall provided a fitting backdrop for a head victory by the Irish-bred Carry Forward II over the Briardale Farms' Convex at Monmouth Park today.

The stock market surged ahead yesterday for the second session in a row. Optimism spread on Wall Street as the Dow-Jones average of 30 blue-chip stocks jumped 16.63 points to close at 868.03. It was the biggest gain for the average since Nov. 26, 1963, when a recovery of 32.03 points was registered in the first day of trading following the assassination of President Kennedy.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
" Hurricanes? They're certainly no concern of mine" said an otherwise cautious family man in Westchester County the other day.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 30 -- The United States' program of economic aid to Nationalist China ended today.
The Old West converged on Long Capitol Plenery last month for the presentation of United Artists' live, "The Hallelujah Trail."
Prices on the London Stock Exchange failed to hold earlier gains yesterday, and closed at 1965 lows for the fifth successive day.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 30 -- Pakistan and India agreed today to order their troops to withdraw from the entire delineated border between them and end the confrontation of their armed forces.
Gary Kroll's second spotless Job of long relief pitching in three days brought the New York Mets a 6-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium last night before a crowd of 20,946.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 30 -- Riot policemen were called to the offices of the mine workers union today to control a group of "rebel" miners protesting the upgrading of black workers.
The British pound moved up slightly yesterday in moderately active dealings on foreign exchange markets here.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today that 800 Minutemen I intercontinental ballistic missiles were now in firing position, completing on schedule a two-and-a-half-year program.

Gracie Fields, Commander of the Order of the British Empire and queen of the English minstrel halls, took the Metropolitan Opera's "Salute to Britain" last night in Lewisohn Stadium. No other monarch could have done it more stylishly.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 30 -- A group highly critical of the Supreme Court in recent years -- the National Association of Attorneys General -- ended its convention here today with indications of a friendlier view toward the Court.
Tony Vincent of New York, seeded third, defeated Peter Jurow of Laurelton, Queens, 6-2, 6-0, in the fourth round of the New York State clay-court championship yesterday.
The Beatrice Foods Company registered record results for the quarter ended May 31 with increases of 9 per cent in volume and 23 per cent in profits, William G. Karnes, president, reported yesterday.

" The Flight From Woman," by Karl Stern, which Farrar, Straus Giroux will publish on July 12, suggests that modern society is being defeminized and therefore dehumanized -- moving from momism to nonism. The author is professor of psychiatry at the University of Ottawa and an author.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson hailed Project Headstart today as a lifeline to rescue those of the next generation who are "lost in a sea of too little of everything."

Theodore W. Kheel and a Swiss bank are among the major motivators of the Republic National Bank, which is expected to begin "general commercial banking" operations about Oct. 1. The bank will be situated on the corner of Fifth Avenue and 40th Street.
The Continental Oil Company assigned yesterday a corporate vice president and the head of a Canadian affiliate as coordinators of exploration and marketing activities.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 -- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has suspended all Vietnamese-language daily newspapers despite earlier assurances to the publishes that he was rescinding the suspension order.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Navy and the Weather Bureau hope to set off self-destructive forces in a hurricane this year by subjecting its central energy cell to an eight-hour bombardment with silver iodide crystals.

The talks between Chancellor of the Exchequer James Callaghan and Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler indicate that progress on the monetary front is being made. The two fiscal managers reaffirmed the close links that exist between the pound and the dollar, agreeing that the two key currencies which form the twin pillars of the present international monetary system will continue to play their essential role.
Homeowners in New York and New Jersey are learning that the prolonged drought and the resulting water conservation regulations will mean financial as well as esthetic damage.
Any hope that the steel, cement and other domestic industries may have had of combating imports through antidumping legislation are dead, at least temporarily.

WHITE PLAINS, June 30 -- Harold E. Schmit, a marketing executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, died in White Plains hospital last night of a fractured skull after a street scuffle with a man who thought his wife had been insulted.

The Chicago North Western Railway, which arranged on June 14 to buy the Velsicol Chemical Corporation of Chicago for $90 million, effective today, announced plans yesterday to acquire a better than 80 per cent interest with Velsicol in the Michigan Chemical Corporation.

BOSTON, July 1 (UPI) -- The Storer Broadcasting Company and Louis J. Hector, trustee for the Hughes Tool Company's controlling interest in Northeast Airlines, Inc., announced today an agreement to extend the option on Northeast stock.
For those thinking about renting a car in the New York area for the Fourth of July weekend, the word yesterday was: Forget it.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 1 (AP) -- Gamble Benedict, whose runaway marriage to a one-time chauffeur caused a stir on two continents, was married today to Thomas F. Gallagher Jr., an $11,500-a-year state police investigator.

Ambassador George C. McGhee's recent warning that it is time to stop Judging Germany on the basis of its Nazi past was generally a well-reasoned and cogent statement. It is clearly unwarranted to view Germany today as though a return to Nazism were a serious possibility.

Three men were arraigned yesterday on charges of having amassed an illegal arms cache in Brooklyn for shipment to anti-Castro forces in Cuba. Included were mortars, machine guns, revolvers and pistols.
BRUNEI, June 29 -- A word heard frequently today in Brunei is "Sabar," which in Malay means "Be patient."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The flood of teen-agers into the labor force in June was absorbed in about the normal degree and unemployment in the month was virtually unchanged, the Labor Department reported today.
MANVILLE, N.J., July 1 (AP) -- Joseph Utasi removed 45 tons of dirt today that he had dumped on Brooks Boulevard Tuesday.
The combination of perfect weather and Earl Fatha Hines on piano drew a capacity crowd to the Museum of Modern Art last night for the third concert of the museum's Jazz in the Garden series.
BRUSSELS, July 1 -- The Common Market Commission struck a conciliatory attitude today in an attempt to rescue the European Economic Community from a crisis that developed early this morning.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., July 1 -- Dave Kelley, a professional from Ridgefield, Conn., today won four blue ribbons at the opening session of the Great Barrington horse show.
With Manul Ycaza forcing him to the front at the start and keeping him there all the way, Valiant Bull registered a convincing victory in the main event at Aqueduct yesterday.
The engagement of "Golden Boy," starring Sammy Davis, at the Majestic Theater has been suspended until Monday night because of injuries suffered by Mr. Davis Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A Republican fund-raising committee that wants to dramatize some of Barry Goldwater's campaign themes for television has run into a problem familiar to many other TV producers: sponsor trouble.

The Franco Western Oil Company, a division of the Franco Wyoming Oil Company, of Paris, has sold its producing and royalty interests in about 60,000 acres of the McElroy Ranch in western Texas to Warren Co., an affiliate of the Warren American Oil Company, of Tulsa, Okla. W.K. Warren Jr., president of Warren American Oil, said the price was "in excess of $35 million."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, said today that President Johnson "must not yield" to those Democrats in Congress who "would abandon the free people of South Vietnam."
Thousands of New Yorkers will abandon the city today for their favorite mountains or beaches as the long Fourth of July weekend begins.

Under a battered black top-hat -- a hat that has been rained on, snowed on, stepped on by horses, scratched by tree limbs, scorched by the sun, blown away but always returned -- is the smiling face of Sam Arthurs, a 73-year-old coachman who suddenly has become one of the living landmarks that the city wishes to preserve.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Treasury's stock of silver fell below one billion ounces today for the first time in 30 years.

Senator Jacob K. Javits sharply criticized the Johnson Administration last night for its decision to resume the shipment of wheat to the United Arab Republic. He said that such aid helped President Gamal Abdel Nasser build up his army for an eventual attack against Israel.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The White House announced today the resignation of Thomas K. Finletter as United States Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ALTHOUGH thousands of books about World War II are stacked several layers deep in every major library, many more are still to come. The war correspondents and novelists, the generals and statesmen, have all tried to report, explain, justify and dramatize. And the first wave of histories has already hit the literary beaches.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 1 -The Illinois General Assembly adjourned today without having reapportioned Congressional districts or the districts for the Legislature's two Houses.
The Treasury's gold stock fell $359 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

SAIGON, Friday, July 2 (UPI) -- Communist guerrillas attacked the United States airfield at Soctrang in the Mekong delta with mortar fire last night, forcing a temporary evacuation or American helicopters, an American military spokesman said today.
The art world is experiencing a bonanza in Western Americana these days.
KINGS POINT, L.I., July 1 -The age of sails, almost forgotten in the nation's race to train mariner cadets in the operation of push-button, nuclear-powered ships, came back in billowing glory today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- The Department of Justice filed a civil suit today against the voting registrars of Marengo County, Ala., charging discrimination against Negroes and seeking the immediate suspension of a special new voting test.
GASTONIA, N.C., July 1 (UPI) -- Representative T. Ashton Thompson of Louisiana was struck and killed by a truck today on a busy highway after a state patrolman had stopped him for speeding.
LONDON, July 1 -- The scornful rejection by North Vietnam appears to end all immediate prospects for the Commonwealth peace mission.

The directors of several major employment agencies and advertising agencies that place newspaper ads reported yesterday that they knew Title VII of the Civil Rights Act was going into effect today -- but that was all they knew.
Gareth Martinis heard his own words read into the record by the prosecution yesterday at his trial in Bronx Supreme Court on charges of vehicular homicide.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union called today for the enlargement of the United Nations Security Council to include more seats for new African and Asian nations.

Plans for a 31-story apartment building that will occupy the west blockfront of Third Avenue, between 64th and 65th Street, have been filed with the City Department of Buildings by David Frankel and Lawrence J. Goldrich, real estate investors.

A majority of the nine savings and loan associations in the New York-New Jersey area paying higher interest rates than those prevailing on deposits in this district have elected to continue doing so this quarter despite the prospect of Federal Home Loan Bank restrictions on their lending activities.
The British pound scored a gain yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Oh, those mighty New York Mets!

The information in the following article was assembled by Joseph A. Loftus of The New York Times Washington Bureau, Sydney H. Schanberg of the Albany Bureau and Paul L. Montgomery of the New York staff.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Joseph Campbell, Controller General of the United States since 1954, has told President Johnson that he wishes to retire, effective July 31. Mr. Campbell has been in ill health. At present he is undergoing tests in Georgetown Hospital.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 1 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today he had warned Britain that if she tried to call a conference on the Rhodesian Constitution "we would regard this as interference in our internal affairs."

AREA A -- Ideal weather yesterday helped keep bottom fishing excellent on the wrecks off Barnegat Light. Anglers were taking porgies and sea bass with clams. The first tuna of the season -- six -- ranging from 15 to 25 pounds were boated with trolled feather and cedar plugs.

CAIRO, July 1 -- The Soviet Union, already a supplier of the United Arab Republic's arms and co-sponsor of the Aswan High Dam, has scored a new propaganda coup over the United States by stepping in with emergency shipments of wheat.
RIO DE JANIERO, July 1 -Brazil's irate coffee planters received a curt rejection from the Government today on their demands for increased support prices for the new crop.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 1 -- The police raided the newsroom of the Rand Daily Mail today and seized the notes and drafts for a series of articles on conditions in South African prisons.
The Board of Estimate held its first meeting of the new fiscal year yesterday, a session that was described by Controller Abraham D. Beame as "meaningless, useless and time consuming."

The smell of soap and good stew filled the spotless, polished hallways of two buildings on West ll7th Street yesterday as Mrs. Garland Lamb, a determined woman in her 40's, talked with pride about a community she calls Morningside Village.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- The automobile industry reported today record production for the first six months of this year and for June.
Colt Industries, Inc., formerly the Penn-Texas Corporation, filed yesterday an involuntary bankruptcy petition against Jacques Sarlie in United States District Court here.

PARIS -- Helene Rochas, the head of Rochas Perfumes, which had a $6 million turnover last year, giggles like a little girl when you call her the No. One locomotive in town. She admits, with a twinkle, that she is.

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 1 -- A plea for more equal tax treatment of commercial and residential properties was made today as the National Association of Building Owners and Managers ended its 58th annual convention here.

A New Rochelle travel agent who has been charged with defrauding several hundred teachers in a charter flight scheme was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of illegally raising a certified check.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- A new communications system linking virtually every non-Communist airline in the world went into operation today.
TRENTON, July 1 -- The Delaware River Basin Commission and New York City could reach no agreement today over how to combat the water shortage in the four-state commission area.
The stock market passed a critical test yesterday with flying colors, rallying toward the close of the session to chalk up a comfortable gain after showing some signs of weakness earlier in the day.

THE HAGUE, July 1 -- The second Holland Festival program offered by the Netherlands Dance Theater was presented here tonight. Its major novelty was the world premiere of "The Game of Noah" by the American choreographer Glen Tetley.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, discussed today with Msgr. Alberto Giovannetti, observer for the Holy See, the outlook for a visit to the United Nations by Pope Paul VI. The Pontiff is considering such a visit. Neither Mr. Thant nor Msgr. Giovannetti was prepared to say that a final decision had been made.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 1 -- The nation's water shortage problem came under increased scrutiny here today as the American Water Works Association neared the end of its 85th annual convention.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 1 -Commercial ships that averaged a 7 per cent increase in size, paid 7.4 per cent more in tolls and hauled 8.4 per cent more in cargoes passed through the Panama Canal during the fiscal year 1965, which ended yesterday.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, July 1 -- A preliminary review of the United States' first sizable combat foray into Vietcong territory, the two-and-ahalf-day action in a jungle area known as Zone D, suggests that American troops can live and fight in the jungle if necessary.
JACKSON, Miss., July 1 (AP) -- Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr.'s program to liberalize state voting requirements cleared the Mississippi Legislature today and was signed into law.
It has been said before but it merits special attention when it is said by one of the nation's biggest banks:
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -Glenn Beckert's second and third homers of the season produced four runs today and led the Chicago Cubs to a 6-3 victory over the National League leading Los Angeles Dodgers.

DENVER, July 1 (UPI) -The N.A.A.C.P. was asked today to call on South American, Asian and African nations to bar missionaries of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints because of an alleged "doctrine of non-white inferiority."
PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, Friday, July 2 (Reuters) -The bodies of two missionary priests, an American and a German, were found today in the wreckage of their light plane on a New Guinea mountainside.
Controller Abraham D. Beame, one of five Democratic candidates for Mayor, asked the Liberal party yesterday for permission to enter its mayoral primary against Representative John V. Lindsay.

Attempts by extremist groups to take over control of education through, school boards and parent-teacher organizations were more prevalent in the last year than ever before, according to reports made to the National Education Association.
The Conservative party named Mrs. Rosemary R. Gunning and Hugh Markey yesterday to complete its citywide ticket headed by William F. Buckley Jr.
I read with interest your editorial of June 23 "Home Rule Triumphant" concerning the passage of the bids in Albany that interfered with the financial problems of New York City.
New York City's $16 million antipoverty drive was saved yesterday by an 11th hour Federal-city agreement on a new agency to run the campaign here.
A new advertising agency officially came into being yesterday -- Mogul Baker Byrne Weiss, Inc.
Three dapper gunmen handcuffed two Manhattan jewelers together yesterday, rifled their stock, and vanished into Madison Avenue with a quartermillion dollars in carefully selected gems.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A man who has never held a pilot's license took over one of the most important jobs in aviation today. He is William Fulton McKee, a short, solidly built man with the stern look of a general, which he used to be.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 1 -- In a program note for the Stratford Festival's revival of "Julius Caesar," Douglas Campbell, the director, has jotted down some thoughts about the play. His main point is the drama's special timeliness.
The International Longshoremen's Association has joined the ranks of major maritime unions that publish their own official organs with the publication of the first issue of The Longshore News.
!IOBLESVlLLE Ind., July 1 (AP) -- William Dudley Pelley, founder of the Fascist organization known as the Silver Shirts, died yesterday at his home here. He was 75 years old.

ALTHOUGH slams win world championships and dominate the bridge columns, it is part scores that win pair tournaments. Part scores, as a rule, offer more scope for skillful play than a slam: the lead changes hands more often and far more variations are possible.

In coping with the "wars of national liberation," which are now the basic strategy of the Communist nations in their campaign for world conquest, the first thing to keep in mind is that unless the threatened country wants to save itself no one else can save it. The idea that the United States can do it all alone is a dangerous misconception.

A 48-year-old employe of The World-Telegram and The Sun is believed to have jumped more than 200 feet to his death from near the mid-point of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge into the Narrows early yesterday. A police launch was dragging for the body.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -United States officials had expected the Common Market nations to reach an interim agreement on agricultural financing without reaching another crisis in which France threatened the entire organization.

SPOLETO, Italy, July 1 -- Ezra Pound, the 80-year-old American poet, was the star here today at Gian Carlo Menotti's Festival of Two Worlds. The events is in its second week in this town in the Umbrian hills in Central Italy.

The report of the Senate Rules Committee's Democratic majority on the affairs of Robert G. Baker is as unsatisfactory as the investigation that preceded it. It does suggest that there may be grounds for indicting Mr. Baker and it does present a series of proposals for supervising and restricting the activities of Senate employes; but it conspicuously refrains from demanding that Senators themselves observe higher ethical standard.

The General Electric Company announced here yesterday that it had successfully converted a space-age component to a device for home use at low cost. The component is a silicon-controlled rectifier, known as SCR, that is best described as a cousin to the transister.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 1 -Senator Edward J. Speno, chairman of Nassau County's Republican party said here tonight that he had given the information about a "Republican official" that started a grand jury investigation into possible influence peddling and payoffs in the acquisition of county land.
A four-man ring that allegedly stole more than $32,000 in passages from a dozen airlines by using stolen and forged credit cards was reported broken yesterday by district Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

Alan Fineberg has been appointed vice president in charge of real estate of the Supermarkets Operating Company of Union, N.J., operator of the Shop-Rite chain of supermarkets. He had been the company's real estate manager since 1962.
BOSTON, July 1, (UPI) -The Detroit Tigers rallied for a run on two hits and a fielder's choice in the ninth inning today for a 2-1 victory over Earl Wilson and the Boston Red Sox.
The Navy has awarded a $5,864,500 contract to the Harris-Intertype Corporation for development of a computerized system for automatic check-out of naval aircraft electronics.

BALTIMORE, July 1 -- Steve Barber, Curt Blefary, Brooks Robinson and "Astrodome vision" ganged up on Whitey Ford tonight, ending his winning streak at six games and giving the Baltimore Orioles a 4-3 victory over the New York Yankees.

BONN, July 1 -- Volkswagenwerk, A.G., has no immediate plans to increase the price of its automobiles, Heinz Nordhoff, general director of the West German car company, said at the annual meeting today.
DENVER, July 1 -- In the view of civil rights leaders meeting here, a landmark will be established tomorrow when Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 goes into effect.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 1 -- A Beverly Hills type development is planned on Grand Bahama Island under a project of Albert C. Gannaway Jr. of Gannaway Productions, Ltd.
PARIS, July 1 -- The French Government today put the future of the Common Market in doubt and threatened in effect to block all future steps toward the integration of Europe.

TOKYO, July 1 -- Favorable business conditions abroad, if they last, are expected to enhance Japan's position as one of the world's leading exporting nations this year. The drive to sell Japanese products in other countries has been intensified as a result of stagnant markets at home.
The weather, the water shortage and withholding and excise taxes all conspired in June to hold department store sales in the New York area slightly below 1964 levels.
Abe Fortas, Washington lawyer and confidant of President Johnson, was elected a vice president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., yesterday.

New York's Democratic party is clearly in trouble because of its profusion of candidates for Mayor. The probable heir of the Wagner mantle, Paul R. Screvane, won endorsement from the party organization in Queens, his home county, but by so small a margin over District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor that his victory there can hardly be regarded as a substantial one.
DURHAM, N.C., July 1 -A Negro delegate burst into the Congress of Racial Equality's convention headquarters today, grinning in amazement.
HOLLYWOOD, July 1 -- For a man with a lot on his mind, Mike Nichols cuts a cool and jaunty figure around town these days.

Seven youths confronted Representative John V. Lindsay yesterday with "Buckley for Mayor" signs and "we want Buckley" shouts. Mr. Lindsay was opening a Lindsay-for-Mayor headquarters at 120-19 Liberty Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens.
The Varian house, a Bronx landmark dating from 1770, was moved to a new site yesterday.

LISBON, July 1 -- Portuguese Catholics opposed to the authoritarian regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar have formed an underground organization called the Christian Movement for Democratic action.

JACKSON, Miss., July 1 (UPI) -- Civil rights demonstrators, taking quick advantage of a Federal Court order, staged a two-hour march today around the state Capitol Building, past the Governor's mansion and through downtown Jackson.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Leon Wagner's two-run homer, three singles by Max Alvis and a pair of doubles by Chuck Hinton led the Cleveland Indians to a 7-2 victory over Washington tonight. The triumph increased Cleveland's American League lead to one game.
LONDON, July 1 -- The famous Elgin marbles are to remain in Britain.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler is deeply concerned by what he believes is premature optimism about the success achieved so far in eliminating the payments deficit.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -Senate and House conferees agreed today that all cigarette packages must carry a warning that smoking may be dangerous to health.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -Early activation of a committee to oversee senatorial ethics, authorized almost a year ago, was promised today by the Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The fate of more than one million persons whose homes or businesses will be razed during the next seven years for urban renewal and municipal highway construction came under cautious scrutiny today before a one-man Senate subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -The first national law prohibiting discrimination against minority groups in private employment goes into effect tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- A bomb threat against Mayor Richard J. Daley today heightened a clash between him and civil rights leaders over the Mayor's charge that Communists participated in demonstrations that have been going on here for three weeks.
The five civil fights leaders who urged [Times, June 5] the naming of a civilian review board and the creation of 17,000 jobs to avert another hot summer appear to be quite presumptuous.
The City Planning Commission said yesterday that "New York City's top priority highway project" should be a Cross Brooklyn Expressway along the route of the Long Island Rail Road's Bay Ridge line.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 1 (UPI) -- Russ Hodge of the Santa Clara Valley Youth Village won two of the first five events to take the lead over favored Bill Toomey of the Los Angeles Striders in the national Amateur Athletic Union championship decathlon last night.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 -- More than 400 marines from the United States Seventh Fleet were rushed today into Quinhon, 100 miles south of the Danang Air Base, where Communist forces scored a psychological victory over American marines earlier in the day.
PITTSBURGH, July 1 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals rallied to score seven runs in the last two innings tonight and defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-6.
Despite the Wall Street rally, which tended to stimulate most foreign stock markets, prices on the London Stock Exchange slipped yesterday to new 1965 lows for the sixth consecutive day.
There were signs of strength on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, although volume was lacking with only 1.09 million shares traded. There were 1.75 million shares in Wednesday's market.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -President Johnson said today that there had never been a "period of more harmonious relations" between the "classes and groups" in American society than there is now.
The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced yesterday it had arranged for the sale of $75 million of first mortgage sinking fund 4.60 per cent bonds due July 1, 1995.
BONN, July 1 -- East Germany contended today that the West had knuckled under to its demands to be treated like a sovereign state. Western Allied sources said, "Nonsense."
Officials of the city's three major botanical gardens declared yesterday they would be in "real trouble" and suffer irreparable damage if the drought continued for another month.
LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- The British Government today announced recognition of the revolutionary regime of Col. Houari Boumedienne as the legal Government of Algeria.

In a marked departure from tradition, two of America's most conservative publishing houses have contracted to publish autobiographical musings by two leading movie queens, both in their early 30's: Elizabeth Taylor and Shirley MacLaine.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- Ray Culp hurled a threehitter and scored the winning run tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 2-1, for their fifth straight victory.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The publisher of a book by former Postmaster General J. Edward Day has ordered the apparently illegal dust jackets of the book destroyed.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 1 -Rumors and cryptic newspaper headlines strengthened the value of the Colombian peso to 17 to the United States dollar here today.
WASHINGTON, July 1--Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. announced today that he would not compete in the Democratic primary for Mayor of New York.

CAIRO, July 1 -- Premier Ahmed Mohammed Noman, who headed Yemen's first independent-minded Government since the imamate was overthrown in 1962, has resigned, throwing the republican regime into political turmoil.
Government bond prices declined slightly yesterday for the third consecutive day this week.
With the three television networks scheduling more and more feature films, concern has grown about the continuing availability of movies.
Traders in commodity futures remained mostly on the sidelines yesterday, a bit wary about taking a plunge.

NEW DELHI, July 1 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri said tonight that Pakistan's "aggression" in the Rann of Cutch would be "clearly and fully vacated" under the ceasefire agreement signed yesterday.
SAIGON, July 1 (AP) -United States Air Force and Navy planes struck at North Vietnam today without letup.
KUTZTOWN, Pa. -- The Mennonite woman, her dark hair pulled back under a stiff net cap, sat in a corner of the storefront office, shyness shining in her face.

Net operating income of the Bank of America declined in the first half of 1965 from the period a year ago. Its president, Rudolph A. Peterson, in issuing the report yesterday, attributed the reduction to increased interest rates paid on savings deposits.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 1 -Not one of the four horsemen in attendance at an Alibi Breakfast in the John Peel pub of the Island Inn today was bold enough to predict an upset in tomorrow night's $50,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- They could have used last year's program. The reigning champion, Maria Bueno, will meet Margaret Smith on Saturday in a replay of the wonderful 1964 final and Roy Emerson will defend against Fred Stolle tomorrow for the title he won against Fred here a year ago.
LOS ANGELES -- Richard Ney, an actor turned investment counselor, recently has been appearing in guest spots on local television in an unusual and rather isolated role.
The departures of three major passenger liners tomorrow for European or Southern ports were canceled yesterday as mediation efforts collapsed in the 16th day of a three-union walkout.
The city of Redondo Beach, Calif., has defaulted on a $252,400 semi-annual interest payment on a $9 million issue of small boat harbor revenue bonds sold in 1959.

PARIS -- At the heart of Franco-American differences is a French feeling that our policy unfairly penalizes an ally and seeks to heighten U.S. technological advantages. Until consequent resentment is allayed, relations cannot substantially improve.
Ernest E. Weil has been named executive vice president of the glove division of the Kayser-Roth Corporation. He had been vice president of the unit.
After the buffeting taken by stock prices last month, individual investors may find some consolation in the knowledge that they are suffering not alone -- but in large numbers.

The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund has set up a project to press for enforcement of the fair employment section of the Civil Rights Act through local committees. The section becomes effective today.

HENLEY, England, July 1 -Vesper, the Olympic champion, defeated Harvard's eight-oared crew by two-thirds of a length today with a lusty disrespect for a Soviet record, an American instant legend and British amenities.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 1 (AP) -- The secret is out. Prince Charles flunked math and science at Gordonstoun School in Scotland.
An additional force of 1,400 policemen and 150 patrol cars was assigned last night to deal with violence and vandalism resulting from the city's taxicab strike, now in its fifth day.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The nation's capital joined 116 other areas of the country today in adopting the Federal Government's food stamp plan for raising dietary standards of low-income residents.
HENLEY, England, July 1 (UPI) -- It was a big day at the Henley Royal Regatta for American oarsmen today as most of them swept to victories in trial heats.
ALBANY, July 1 -- The state's Family Court judges were given a new legal tool today for solving cases where fathers refuse to support their families.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 1 -- Brig. Gen. Antonio Imbert Barreras said tonight that once he was certain the threat of Communism or despotism of any kind no longer existed he would step down as leader of the Dominican junta and return to private life.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Rail carloadings and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended June 26 were both considerably above the volume in the corresponding week of 1964. This is consistent with the year to year increases which have been reported during the current year.

HARTFORD, July 1 -- The third constitutional convention in Connecticut's history convened today in the historic old State House in downtown Hartford to revise the Constitution drafted in the same building by a constitutional convention in 1818.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Retail sales across the nation declined 1 per cent to $5.47 billion in the week ended June 26 but were 9 per cent above those of the corresponding 1964 week, the Commerce Department said today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 1 (UPI) -- The St. Petersburg City Council joined with other groups today in opposing the Women's Job Corps Center here and asked that it be moved as soon as possible.
Buildings Commissioner Harold Birns was appointed as a judge of the Civil Court yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The Mayor named Deputy Buildings Commissioner Judah Gribetz to succeed Mr. Birns.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 1 -Playing her best golf in 10 years of championship competition, Mrs. Kathy Cornelius score a 71 today to lead the first round of the Women's United States Open.
Robert Barker was hard pressed to defeat Wilbert Davis of New York yesterday in the New York State clay-court championship at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

Growing violence marred the continuation of the taxicab strike yesterday despite the National Labor Relations Board order for elections July 21 in 38 of the city's 83-fleet taxicab garages to determine the question of union representation for the drivers. With characteristic disregard for the riding public, Harry Van Arsdale Jr., leader of the campaign to unionize the drivers, says the strike will continue just as if there had been no ruling by the N.L.R.B.
TRENTON, July 1 -- Commuters who travel between North Jersey and New York City face the pleasant prospect of improved rail connections under a Federal grant of $8.7 million.
The National Labor Relations Board has ordered a swimsuit manufacturer in Florida to bargain with the union it left behind in Queens.
Steeplechase Park, a Coney Island landmark since 1897, was sold yesterday for more than $2.5 million to Fred C. Trump, a real estate developer.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 1 (AP) -- The Newport Jazz Festival opened its 12th season tonight in a new, 12,000-seat arena before an audience of about 3,500.

A new stamp collector's rarity is the original cover on "My Appointed Round: 929 Days as Postmaster General," by J. Edward Day, which Holt, Rinehart and Winston will publish on next Thursday. The jacket showed a batch of canceled stamps beside the title.

The world's largest corporate enterprise, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, achieved in the 12 months ended May 31 the highest earnings ever reported for any 12-month period by any company.
Bobbie Brooks, Inc., registered record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended April 30, Maurice Saltzman, president of the Cleveland apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Congress is approaching the Fourth of July in the usual midsummer mood, and that spells trouble for any President. In the case of President Johnson, it spells a good deal less trouble than it has for others and there now is an undercurrent of confidence at the White House that there will be no major setbacks at this session.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that commission profits of member firms on securities transactions remained "disappointingly low" in 1964, and he hinted broadly that Wall Street needed higher fees.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The United Church of Christ, meeting here in biennial convention, elected today its first Negro Moderator, the highest honorary office in the two-million member Protestant denomination.
CHICAGO, July 1 (UPI) -Rex Baxter used a new putter today to cure a 14-month putting slump for a five-under-par 66 and the first-round lead in the $70,000 Western Open.

Ten singers new to the Metropolitan Opera will join the company during the 1965-66 season. Of the four women and six men, five are Americans, two of them native New Yorkers. Three are Spanish, one is a Czechoslovak and one is from Italy.
HOUSTON, July 1 (UPI) -Two 37-year-old astronauts, Maj. Frank Borman and Lieut. Comdr. James A. Lovell, will fly a Gemini capsule into orbit for as long as two weeks early next year.
A 5 cent stamp commemorating the 100th year of the Salvation Army will be released here today in a special ceremony at the New York Hilton.

Lloyd K. Garrison, acting president of the Board of Education, has told other board members that if he should be named full-time president, his health and law practice would limit the time he could spend on board duties.

A VICTORY dinner to celebrate the forthcoming dredging of silt and sand from Little Neck Bay in Queens will be held on July 27 at the Bayside Yacht Club. Attending will be members of the organizing committee from the communities of Saddle Rock, Harbor Hills, Great Neck Estates, Douglaston and Bayside that pushed for the necessary state and Federal ap propriations.
KANSAS CITY, July 1 (AP) -- A one-coach passenger train, which the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad hopes was its last, pulled into Kansas City today 2 hours 40 minutes late.
GROTON, Conn, July 1 -Twelve thousand production workers at the Electric Boat Submarine Construction Yard here went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today when their contract expired.
WHITE PLAINS, July 1 -Membership in the John Birch Society has doubled in New York City's suburbs in the last four months, national leaders of the society said here today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 -- United States Navy pilots bombed a large oil storage area 40 miles southeast of Hanoi today. It was the closest strike to the North Vietnamese capital yet made.
Plans for another season of free chamber music in Washington Square Park have been canceled for this year.
AT a pretheater dinner party one of the guests, a slight woman with silvery blond hair and the sky-blue eyes of a Siamese cat, walked into the room and immediately drew all eyes.

The 50th anniversary of Kiwanis International, a community service organization for business and professional men, will be celebrated for five days beginning tomorrow at its annual convention at Madison Square Garden.
MOSCOW, July 2 -- The Soviet Union has announced that it will test the profit-motivated economic reform program in yet another area, the food-processing industry.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- The first public exhibition of Presidential memorabilia opened in the White House today for Fourth of July weekend visitors.

Mr. Shalett, a native of Stamford, Conn., became a reporter for The Chattanooga Times in 1930 and seven years later joined the staff of The New York Times. In 1939-40 he covered the New York World's Fair and the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia and the Democratic Convention in Chicago.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 -- Brazil's National Security Council approved today private investments, both national and foreign, in petrochemical industries.

The top burden of 120 pounds was hardly a deterrent to the Templeton Stable's Ballet Rose in the six-furlong main race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4year-old daughter of Native Dancer carried the package with ease and grace as she moved to a four-length triumph in 1:09 3-5.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2 -- The United States Government has received a $2,500,000 check, thanks largely to Soviet and Ukrainian payments last Tuesday for the United Nations 1965 budget.

CARBONDALE, Ill., July 2 (UPI) -- The athletic director of Southern Illinois University protested today to President Johnson the ineligibity of the college's defending champion of women's gymnastics team at the National Amateur Athletic Union meet.
JUNEAU, Alaska, July 1 -- A run of red salmon that is expected to be the heaviest since Alaska was voted into statehood seven years ago has provided the 49th state with a controversial topic.

Before the final cheers fade away for the accomplishments of the 1965 New York Legislature, a particularly dismal failure should be recorded. That was the demise, once more, of the legislation to repeal the state's archaic full-crew laws that require over-manning of the railroads. The Democrats, in command of the Legislature for the first time in thirty years, did not even permit the repealer to reach a floor vote.
ALBANY, July 2 -- The Wagner administration's plan to build a garage beneath Sara Delano Roosevelt Park, on the Lower East Side, was rejected today by Governor Rockefeller.
LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP) -- Joe Adcock singled home a tie-breaking run in the seventh inning tonight as the Los Angeles Angels defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5-4.
LOS ANGELES, July 2 -- Law enforcement officials of California are planning to use emergency tactics this weekend to keep watch on scheduled outings of motorcycle clubs.
ALGIERS, July 2 -- Defense Minister Houari Boumedienne was reliably reported tonight to be resisting demands that he formally assume the title of President.
The Navy has awarded a $10.6 million contract to the Thiokol Chemical Corporation for continued production of packaged liquid engines for Bullpup missiles.
CHICAGO, July 2 -- Illinois Communist spokesmen conceded today that Mayor Richard J. Daley had been correct in his charge that many Communists are engaged in civil rights demonstrations in Chicago.

When the signing the Declaration of Independence was first celebrated 189 years ago, no common flag flew over the thirteen colonies. It was not until the following year that the Stars and Stripes was first displayed, and not until 1818 that Congress acted to make the Fourth of July the proper and official date for adding new stars to the flag to symbolize the admission of new states to the union.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 2 -The long and tempestuous courtship between the Pure Oil Company and the Union Oil Company of California entered its final scenes today when Pure stockholders voted overwhelmingly at a special meeting to say yes to Union's terms of marriage.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- One of the restless, energetic young men who serve as aides to William D. Rogers, the outgoing United States Deputy Coordinator of the Alliance for Progress, remarked the other day:
BRUNEI, June 30 -- Brunei is suffering from one of the world's rarest governmental diseases: She makes more money than she can spend.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 2 -- The new president of the American Waterworks Association asserted today that there is really no water shortage in the nation, but a shortage of facilities to provide water where it is needed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 -- A Canadian-owned utility supplying power to the Rio de Janeiro-Saa Paulo area announced today it would invest $225 million in an expansion plan to benefit industrial and domestic consumers.

The only one of the five announced candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination who had a chance to meet President Johnson yesterday missed out because he was caught in a traffic jam.
A cautious holiday spirit led to a low volume of trading in commodities markets yesterday, setting a lower trend for many futures prices.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board issued for comment today a proposed rule reducing the maximum loan that an insured savings and loan association could make to a single borrower.
Acting Mayor Paul R. Screvane summoned representatives of fleet taxicab owners and the striking Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee to City Hall today in an effort to end the taxi strike.

RICHMOND, July 2 -- Gov. Albertis S. Harrison Jr. has approved a controversial $90,000 Federal antipoverty project that will provide intensive "catch-up" reading instruction for Negro children in Virginia's Prince Edward County.
The elderly, infirm and friendless are among those who have suffered the greatest hardships as a result of the five-day-old taxi strike.
BRUSSELS, July 2 -- Anxiety about the future of the European Economic Community abated somewhat today as France participated in two committee meetings.
As recent tangled events in the city's antipoverty effort began to clear yesterday, it appeared that the $9,183,616 community action program was at last ready to get under way.
The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway announced yesterday its purchase of 1,500 covered hopper-cars from the Pullman-Standard division of Pullman, Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 (UPI) -- A powerful earthquake in Alaska's Aleutian Islands triggered brief tidal wave alerts today along the West Coast and in Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -Under the heading "Can be found" in the 1965 Yearbook of Washington's National Cathedral School for Girls, the entry for Luci Baines Johnson reads "talking philosophy.'' Under "Inspired by," is "Thomas Aquinas."

The Military Sea Transportation Service has been forced to hire three foreign-flag ships to carry military cargoes to South Vietnam and Turkey as a result of the strike by marine engineers against American-flag vessels.

One important factor in the stock market's new-found strength is apparently the reentry of mutual funds into the buyer's column after months during which they either sold on balance or quietly retired to the sidelines.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -Luci Baines Johnson, younger daughter of the President, became a Roman Catholic today, on her 18th birthday. She was baptized at St. Matthew's Cathedral, seven blocks from the White House.
Following is the text of speech delivered yesterday by Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick during a promotion ceremony for 47 members of the department at Police Headquarters:

Full support of the 940,000-member National Education Association was pledged yesterday to the Oklahoma Teachers Association in its fight against "steadily deteriorating school conditions".
MELBOURNE, Fla., July 2 (AP) -- The discovery of a Spanish galleon that is expected to yield great sunken treasures was announced today by the Real 8 Corporation.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 2 -- Mayor Wagner of New York arrived here today with his two sons Robert F. Jr., 21 years old, and Duncan, 18.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 2 -- "Benny Goodman Presents" is the over-all title for the little festival of jazz and chamber music now in its third summer here, where Mr. Goodman, a local resident, produces the concerts for the benefit of the Stamford Museum.

Following is a transcript of President Johnson's speech before the National Education Association at Madison Square Garden yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:
JACKSON, Miss., July 2 -More than 200 civil rights demonstrators marched to the Mississippi State Capitol today under the protection of a Federal court order.

DENVER, July 2 -- The board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People came out today against confirmation of former Gov. James P. Coleman of Mississippi as a Federal judge.

FAR and away the most provocative entry in the catalogue of "The Dark Mirror," the exhibition at the American Federation of Arts, 41 East 65th Street, is the announcement that Hilario Munoz's "Head" has been withdrawn from the exhibition.
The Chelsea section of Manhattan was inundated with entertainment last night, and from all indications the audiences showed no signs of ennui.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 2 (UPI) -- Bili Toomey and Russ Hedge, who won eight events between them in the national Amateur Athletic Union decathlon championship, were the newest members of the United States track and field team today.
Within minutes after President Johnson's plane landed here yesterday, the police issued an alarm for a man who had previously threatened the President's life. It was rescinded 10 minutes later.

Three Jewish religious leaders, representing branches of Judaism, last night voiced criticism of Orthodox hegemony in Israel that ranged from mild reproach to a demand for the "complete separation of church and state" in that country.

DANANG, South Vietnam, July 2 (UPI) -- The Vietcong guerrillas who staged a surprise attack on the United States air base here killed three civilians who tried to sound the alarm, it was disclosed today.
Canadian Breweries, Inc., reported yesterday a decline in earnings for the three and six months ended April 30.
In several parts of California meetings of the clubs have been raided by the police.

In what City Hall erroneously described as a "statement calling for a balanced system of transportation in the city," Mayor Wagner is attempting to revive a long-defunct $100-million parking garage construction program. Released with some fanfare as a major declaration of policy, this statement adds nothing new to the "balanced transportation" picture.
President Johnson announced yesterday that he would soon propose a National Teachers Corps to help teachers in city slums and poor rural areas.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 2 -- Peace, which has been a painful illusion in the Dominican Republic for more than two months, seemed today to be within two weeks of reality.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Treasury bill rate rose sharply today from the level of Monday's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
ALBANY, July 2 -- If a teen-ager's father found out that his son had been convicted of speeding and disciplined him for it, would it make the son a better driver?
" Several weeks ago it started with one," said Walter of the Roosevelt Hotel's Men's Bar, holding up a stubby index finger. "Then came two or three. Now it's motorcycle row."

LOS ANGELES, July 2 -- One of the biggest mergers in the history of the oil industry was ratified in a laconic 15-minute proceeding today when the stockholders of the Union Oil of California voted overwhelmingly to acquire the Midwestern-based Pure Oil Company for upward of $600 million.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- A two-run homer in the eighth inning by Dick Stuart carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4 -- 3 victory over Cincinnati tonight and extended their winning streak to six games.
Travel agents on the nation's domestic airlines reiterated their opposition yesterday to a move to cut their commissions.

BOSTON, July 2 -- The New York Yankees, a team that historians used to call the Bombers, suddenly produced their heaviest bombardment in several years tonight in a saturation raid on Fenway Park that ended in a 16-2 rout of the Boston Red Sox.

A $41 million lawsuit was filed in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday accusing a bank, an accounting firm and a former executive with conspiring to loot the Continental Vending Machine Corporation of Westbury, L.I., before it was declared bankrupt.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Consumer credit resumed a more normal pace of increase in May, following the record growth in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 2 -- President Julius K. Nyerere predicted today that a railway line would be built between Tanzania and her copper-producing neighbor. Zambia, whether his country got the money from the East or West.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A Republican Congressman accused "left-wing extremists" today of carrying on a telephone campaign of abuse and intimidation against wives, mothers and even widows of American servicemen, who are in Vietnam.

New York City's antipoverty program has surmounted two major crises in 24 hours arising out of sharp conflicts of opinion between Governor Rockefeller and officials of the Wagner administration. After bitter recriminations by both sides the program has been cleared to go ahead without essential change.

The St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Heights has been sold to a group of Chinese investors in Hong Kong for about $3.85 million. The seller was Vantar Properties, Inc., which bought the hotel at auction in January, 1964, for $2.5 million.
Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick declared yesterday that any police officer who could not respect the rights of Negro and Puerto Rican citizens should quit the force.
The Hackensack Trust Company has announced the election of Joseph Kozlik as president and chief executive officer. Mr. Kozlik, who continues as chairman, succeeds Anthony Pepe, who has retired.

The Hamilton Management Corporation announced yesterday that directors have approved the offer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to acquire the remaining stock of Hamilton for about $13.5 million of I.T. T. stock.

Arlen Properties Inc., a building company wllich has constructed several of the retail properties recently added by E.J. Korvette, Inc., completed this week the balance of its deposit payment for the purchase of the Saks-34th Street building at Herald Square.

The hope that visits by a British Commonwealth delegation to the capitals most concerned with the Vietnam conflict might contribute to ending that war has been dealt heavy blows by the negative attitudes of the Communists, expressed most recently by North Vietnam and the Vietcong. Nevertheless the British Government's thinking may yet play a useful role.

CHICAGO, July 2 (UPI) -- Young Rex Baxter defied the wind today to card a four-under-par 67 and hold his lead midway through the $70,000 Western open golf tourney. He had a two-stroke margin with a 36-hole total of 133, nine under par.
STOCKHOLM, July 2 (Comtelburo) -- The Under Secretary of the Treasury of the United States said today that he did not believe the British pound would be devalued.
It was just too much to expect that the New York Mets could continue their winning habits.

LENOX, Mass., July 2 -- The 28th Berkshire Festival was opened tonight by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood, and everything functioned in smooth, well-oiled fashion as befits the ranking summer music series in this country.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, June 26 -- The Mackenzie North district, with its bloc of 1,200 Dogrib Indians, is represented in the Northwest Territories Council this year by a native of Lebanon who calls himself "the Canadian Arab of the North."

There were no fireworks in yesterday's trading on the American Stock Exchange, but it was still a healthy market with gains outnumbering declines by a 2-to-1 margin as volume reached 1,093,000 shares.
Treasury bills eased early yesterday and then registered a partial recovery in the afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The United States today won the basketball gold medal in the 10th International Games for the Deaf by smashing Finland, 84-44.

A wind-blown fire, thought by officials to have been started by children, destroyed a Brooklyn lumberyard and threatened to sweep over a large section of the marshy Canarsie waterfront yesterday. It was finally extinguished by 200 firemen after three hours.

The Saranac Handicap, the mare attraction on today's card, has attracted a field of seven, making for a gross value of $56,400. The winner of this onemile event for 3-year-olds will earn $36,660. It will be the richest of the 58 runnings of the stakes, which was first held at Saratoga in 1901.
BONN, July 2 -- The Bundestag, the lower house of the Parliament, approved a Government bill today for the sale of further shares in the Veba company.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 2 -Only one horse, Speedy Scot, will represent the United States in the forthcoming $100,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on the night of July 10. LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- Marie Collier, an Australian-born soprano, won an ovation at Covent Garden tonight when she substituted for the ailing Maria Callas in the title role of "Tosca."

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- Roy Emerson has won Wimbledon again. The dark, fighting-fit 28-year-old from the Australian bush crushed his teammate, Fred Stolle, today by 6-2, 6-4, 6-4 in 67 minutes of slashing serve and volley that was almost mechanical in its perfection.
The British pound closed at $2.7909 in foreign-exchange trading here yesterday, compared with a closing price Thursday of $2.7927.

NOROTON, Conn., July 2 -Craig Van Collie of the Norwalk Shore and Country Club today won a five-race junior regatta that was held at the conclusion of the Finn training symposium at Noroton Yacht Club.
LONDON, July 2 -- The Duke of Edinburgh said today that he favored postponing a solution of the problem of Rhodesia rather than "risk a blood bath" by forcing the issue.
About 250 Harlem youths, most of them high school drop outs, were graduated yesterday from the Associated Community Teams pre-employment training program.

BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP) -- Rocky Colavito drove in five runs with his 19th homer, a double and single tonight, and Lee Stange pitched a four-hitter as the American League-leading Cleveland Indians routed Baltimore, 8-0.

ANCHORAGE, July 2 -- Alaska's coastal areas appeared to state disaster officials late today to have escape damage from the heavy earthquake at Umnak Island, far out in the Aleutians.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 2 -- Harold Strachan, the author of a series of critical articles on prison conditions in South Africa, was served with a banning order under the Suppression of Communism Act today, just as the final installment of the series reached the newsstands.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The United States will lend Turkey $40 million to help her meet the foreign exchange costs of the vast Keban Dam project at the headwaters of the Euphrates River.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A State Department spokesman said today there has been a 20 per cent decline in the number of ships from non-Communist countries arriving at North Vietnamese ports in the first four month of this year compared to the same period last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 2 -- As the tempo increased in the women's United States Open golf championship today, Mrs. Kathy Cornelius retained the lead with a 36-hole total of 146. The 1956 champion played the Atlantic City Country Club course in three hours and scored a 75 to take a two-stroke advantage.
