DURHAM, N.C., July 2 -- The Congress of Racial Equality called anew for broad changes in the new Federal law against discrimination by private employers as the law went into effect today.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 21 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said tonight the United States must negotiate a settlement in Vietnam and announced he was considering joining in "peace rallies" and teach-ins.

KANSAS CITY, July 2 (AP) -- Jim Grant pitched a five-hitter tonight and Tony Oliva drove in two runs as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 3-1, and remained one game behind the American League-leading Cleveland Indians.

Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, was ordered yesterday to explain in court Friday why an election by secret ballot could not be held for officers of the Inland Terminal Workers Union, I.L.A. Local 1730.

THE specialty of La Fontanella, a new catering service at 1304 Second Ave. (between 68th and 69th Streets), is a selection of pastry, turnovers with savory fillings dubbed empanellas. "It rhymes with fontanella," explained Mrs. Nellie Oppes, the hazel-eyed, blonde Argentine woman who is part-owner and head chef of the new establishment. "We made up the name to separate our turnovers from the many poor-quality empanadas offered in this city."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 102.7 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended June 29, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices moved lower in each of the major commodity groupings -- farm products, processed foods and industrial commodities.

HONG KONG, July 3 -- Leaving behind the shambles of the aborted Algiers Conference of African and Asian leaders, Premier Chou En-lai, the Chinese Communist Premier and number one diplomatic salesman, returned to Peking this week with unhappy tales to relate.

DENVER, July 3 -- The 56th annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People ended today with the organization ready to cooperate with the Administration in the implementation of the Civil Rights Act and other social legislation of the last two Congresses.

FATHER: One of the taboos imposed on the British royal family is that its members should not speak out on controversial public issues. Prince Philip, a strong-minded and independent man, often chafed at that taboo and last week he shattered it altogether.

" What sort of book, when, and under what conditions do you read for pure enjoyment?" The Editor of the Book Review put that question recently to a widely assorted group of persons -- from the First Lady to the manager of the Yankees. Some of the replies are printed below.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 (AP) -- Marcellino Lopez and Bob Lee combined to pitch a five-hitter and lead the Los Angeles Angels to a 5-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox. It was Chicago's fifth straight defeat.

THE picture of Africa accepted over most of the outside world is that, until the coming of the white man, the continent lay under a cloud of darkness and superstition, torn by endless tribal wars in which the main interest of either side lay, not so much in victory, as in putting opponents to death afterward with ingenious ferocity.

As one who has passed through United States Customs many times during the past 19 years, I must object to the selfpitying "badgered feeling" attitudes of the many complaints about Customs officials.

MEXICO CITY, July 3 (UPI) -- Former President Janio Quadros of Brazil said at an impromptu news conference today he would "like to know who gave the United States its authority as a super policeman of the world."

In Vietnam last Monday, American troops, along with Smith Vietnamese and Australians, took off on their most ambitious offensive so far -- a sweep into Zone D. a jungle fastness northwest of Saigon. Their mission was to "search and destroy" -- hit hard into what for 20 years had been a sanctuary for Communist guerrillas.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (AP) -- The Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California tonight termed Miss Johnson's baptism by a Catholic priest "a direct slap at our church."

ATLANTIC CITY, July 3 -Carol Mann, who decided in high school to use her 6-foot-3-inch height for golf instead of basketball, took the 54-hole lead today in the women's United States Open with an aggregate of 218.

A prominent Jewish educator last night deplored what he termed the domination of Jewish organizational life by "only a few" and that American Jews have little direct voice in its varied activities.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Denny McLain allowed only one hit -- Don Lock's single in the third -- as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Washington Senators, 1-0, today in a game called after five innings because of rain.

MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) -- Igor Ter-Ovanesyan of the Soviet Union won the broad jump with an effort of 25 feet 5 inches and Enrique Figuerola of Cuba took the 100-meter dash in 10.2 seconds at the annual Brothers Zhamensky track and field meet in Minsk today.

IT is quite possible that anyone who entered the nineteen-twenties as a twelve-year-old man and departed them as a twenty-two-year-old adolescent (it was an extremely confusing decade for everybody) is unqualified to review "The Twenties Revisited," an exhibition that opened last week at the Gallery of Modern Art on Columbus Circle.
BONN, July 3 -- West Germany's test of strength with East Germany over the use of waterways to Berlin continued today with the stopping of three more East German barges at a Western checkpoint.

The Western Pennsylvania National Bank has started guaranteeing checks cashed at Pittsburgh retail establishments during non-banking hours. The system is believed to be the first such arrangement in the banking industry.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Some 18.4 million fish died in 1964 from water pollution, the United States Public Health Service said today.

THE United States Equestrian Team has high hopes for Trick Track, a 5-year-old chestnut gelding who is so new he doesn't even know his way around the Gladstone, N.J., training center yet.
FOR THIS WEEK: Everyone deserves a respite from chores during the three-day week-end. . . . Relax in a cool shady nook of the garden with the latest best seller.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Home runs by Billy Williams and Ed Bailey backed Larry Jackson's five-hit pitching as the Chicago Cubs defeated the San Francisco Giants. 4-1, today.

HOUSTON, July 3 -- With surprising but decisive intervention from Republican State Chairman Peter O'Donnell and Senator John G. Tower, the extreme right wing of the Texas Republican party was defeated this week in a major test of intraparty power.

Construction of the world's largest movable radio telescope has begun in California. The California Institute of Technology will install it on rails in a mountain-walled valley 250 miles north of Pasadena. It plans to add seven more antennas to the array.
GOLDEN GATE PARK'S newest garden was dedicated last month to a new proposition -- that public gardens are not only for looking, but for smelling, for touching and even for tasting.
The dean of public watchdogs at Albany, Dr. George H. Hallett Jr., has called the recently ended 188th session of the Legislature "the most productive in over 30 years."

CAMOGLI, Italy -- I stopped in this small town to have a cup of espresso. Instead of staying 15 minutes, I remained a week.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Soviet Union has begun a massive effort to penetrate the world's commercial aircraft market.
KUCHING, Malaysia, June 29 -- Another search for traces of men who lived in Borneo more than 40,000 years ago is scheduled to begin in the Great Cave of Niah in August.
The duties of the city's two Deputy Mayors were fully defined for the first time last week in an executive order issued by Mayor Wagner to the heads of city departments and agencies.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 4 -- Carol Mann, a tall golfer with a fine short game, won the women's United States Open championship today and when she posted her concluding 72 at the Atlantic City Country Club, she gave way to tears.

The problem of air pollution in New York is again receiving the attention of the press and officials. That polluted air is now costing us heavily in health and money is well recognized. Unfortunately, the plans for improving our life's breath are tentative and long range.

MUNICH, Germany, July 4 -- The fourth West German Parliament will adjourn this week, having in its four-year existence neither marred nor greatly enhanced the Bonn republic's tentative standing as a parliamentary democracy.

FORMBY, England, July 4 (AP) -- Sam Snead retained the world senior golf championship today when he defeated Charlie Ward of Britain, 1 up, in 37 holes over the 6,862-yard par-73 Formby course. But it took a bit of luck for the 6-foot Snead to beat the 5-foot-4-inch Ward.

WHEN Charles Durbin's superior historical novel about war, politics and treachery in Renaissance Italy, "The Mercenary," was published a year and a half ago it failed to receive the critical attention it deserved. The European Economic Community is once again in the throes of crisis. The immediate cause is a disagreement between the French and the other members of the Common Market over agricultural policy, but the fight is really over who should control the power and the pace of economic integration.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 4 -- Deep concern was expressed today by high-level United States military and diplomatic officials that extremists in the rebel forces were smuggling guns into the interior of the country for terrorist actions after peace was restored.

ADAPTATIONS of Tiffany-style lamps are beginning to take all sorts of unpredictable turns. The most recent departure is a garden table umbrella printed to look like colored leaded glass. Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican-Liberal designate for Mayor, got the kind of exposure yesterday that every candidate enjoys as he carried his campaign to the voters at crowded Rockaway beaches.

The Rev. Robert J. McCracken said yesterday that the false assumption that man's problems are fundamentally technological and economic had led to widespread misgivings about the Great Society.
HONOLULU, July 4 (AP) -- A serf-described expert rifleman was held today as the sniper who killed a Honolulu policeman and wounded five other persons last night .

The United States Realty and Investing Company of Newark, participating in an urban renewal development of the area, is preparing to start construction in the fall on a five-story office building at 909-11 Broad Street in Newark, several hundred feet north of the intersection of Broad and Hill Streets.

Lisa Howard, the former television reporter, died in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday. The East Hampton Village police said that the 35-year-old Miss Howard had apparently committed suicide by taking an overdose of sleeping tablets.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Administration has been urged to make explicit its policy of pressing for the opening of channels of communication and information exchanges with Communist China.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Billy Casper, who cut his weight from 220 pounds to 180 since August, won the Western open today with a closing 64 for a 72-hole total of 14-under-par 270.

LIMA, Peru, July 4 (UPI) -- The Peruvian Government tonight suspended civil liberties throughout the country for 30 days to combat Communist guerrilla activity in the interior.

DETROIT, July 4 -- The United States needs fewer and better librarians, according to Lawrence Clark Powell, dean of the Library Service School of the University of California. He delivered the keynote address here today to the annual conference of the American Library Association.

Steno, Italy's 5-year-old trotting champion, arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night en route to quarantine at Clifton, N.J., and then the International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway next Saturday.
MOSCOW, July 4 -- Attempts to increase the efficiency of the Moscow subway system have led to the introduction of automatic equipment to replace one of the two engineers now on each train.
Rowdy, beer-drinking youths went on a holiday rampage this weekend at resorts in New York, Ohio, Missouri and Iowa, causing considerable property damage and leaving at least 93 persons injured.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 4 (AP) -- Four turbaned students from India being given an official tour of the State Capitol were attacked by a crowd at a segregationist rally today, and two of them were beaten.
PURCHASE N.Y., July 4 -- Greenwich defeated New Haven, 9-7, in the final of the Eastern Polo League round-robin tournament today and won the United States Lines Trophy at Blind Brook Polo Club.
The Maritime Administration has permitted approximately $1 million in "unwarranted cost" to creep into its program of subsidizing the construction of merchant ships, Congress has been advised.

Bonwit Teller, New York-based specialty chain of fashion stores in major Eastern cities, will spend approximately $2 million within the next two years in a capital improvement program that may involve all 12 stores, Miss Mildred Custin, president revealed in an interview.

The erosion of New York continues, and there are subtler and more dangerous methods of destruction than the bulldozer. One of the most insidious is the zoning change. Right now requests for revision of zoning are threatening two of the city's most attractive and historic neighborhoods -- Gramercy Park and Murray Hill.
LONDON, July 4 -- Four directors of the biggest printing combine in Britain are seeking to oust its chairman because he is claiming a 1964 salary of $756,000, or about $2,700 dollars a day.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 -- With the split-second timing and security precautions that have come to be associated with Presidential visits, Frank Sinatra came to Newport this evening.

OTTAWA, July 4 -- The Canadian economy, which in 1929 was geared to a toppling stock market, is based today upon high employment, high consumer demand and the need to maintain the technical efficiency required by competition, economic specialists have told the Government.

While Wall Street and Seventh Avenue took the day off yesterday, gem fanciers -- lapidaries, gemologists, would-be diamond-finders and others just interested in semiprecious stones -- did a big volume of business at the New York Trade Show Building.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 4 (UPI) -- Louis Armstrong was entertained today by hundreds of teen-agers at his 65th birthday party here.
CHICAGO, July 4 -- A staid, old Protestant church on Chicago's blighted Near West Side became an interracial "Metropolitan Cathedral of Secular Issues" today.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 4 -- Thunderbird, a fiber-glass sloop of the California 40 breed of stock racing yachts, required 14 1/2 hours to sail 45 miles in a painfully slow overnight race conducted by the Riverside Yacht Club, but when all the returns were in today she was the main winner.

TORONTO, July 4 -- Thirteen thousand people began leaving Toronto for their homes in 92 countries tonight at the end of a three-day convention of Alcoholics Anonymous, at which familiar ideas about the disease and its treatment were challenged.

MOSCOW, July 4 -- A new Soviet version of "War and Peace," reputed to be one of the most expensive and ambitious movies ever made, is a leading contender for the highest prize at the Moscow Film Festival starting tomorrow.

MOSCOW, July 4 (AP) -- Janus Lusis of the Soviet Union won the javelin event today with a throw of 280 feet 11 inches in the Znamensky Brothers Memorial track and field meet at Minsk. Tass, the official Soviet press agency, called this the world's best javelin performance of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Negro revolution, which has been concerned primarily with attacking racial discrimination, is showing signs as well of becoming a vehicle for opposition to the United States' military posture abroad.
BONN, July 4 -- East Germany grudgingly recognized today the continued validity of permits issued by the occupying powers for barge traffic crossing into West Germany.
WELCH, W. Va., July 4 -- Here in the heart of Appalachia, antipoverty officials nodded knowingly when New York City underwent a crisis last week.
Standing desolate and mute, Steeplechase Park resembled an eerie setting for a poignant drama yesterday afternoon.
Mention of the variable annuity raises quizzical eyebrows, but the relatively new weapon against inflationary erosion of retirement income is gaining favor, though it is still not widely available.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- Rico Carty slammed a two-run homer and Frank Bolling drove in two more runs with a single today as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5 -- 2, and ended a four-game losing streak.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., July 3 -Long after most other countries in the world, New Zealand will move this year fully into the jet age.

In deciding to join with Britain to seek an international consensus to reform the present monetary system, the United States must do some fresh thinking. Both countries are against a change in the price of gold or a diminution in the role of either the dollar or the International Monetary Fund, but they have not yet settled on what they are for.

Tourists arriving in Yugoslavia find that dollars can be officially exchanged for 1,000 dinars each rather than 750, the rate obtaining a few days ago. If Belgrade observers are correct, this latest partial devaluation -- the new rate does not apply to commercial transactions -- is the first of a series of major reforms that are expected to have major impact on the Yugoslav economy.
Stan Freberg, who added a new beat to radio last year with his religious jingles, said yesterday that he was prepared to create similar commercials for television.
COVENTRY, England, July 4 -- For want of two automobile door frames, Britain has lost more than $3 million in urgently needed exports over the last month.

Negotiations between the International Union of Masters, Mates and Pilots and the Tanker Service Committee will be resumed today at 10:30 A.M. at the Belmont Plaza Hotel. The negotiations are to end a three-week strike that has tied up 62 United States flag tankers of 14 companies.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- A tall, genial, slightly graying educator has become the first Negro Moderator, or spiritual leader, of the United Church of Christ. He is Dr. Hollis Freeman Price, president of LeMoyne College in Memphis since 1943.

The city transit system's fiscal year 1965-66 has begun with a gloomy outlook that requires hard, unpleasant policy decisions. After all conceivable bookkeeping sleight-of-hand, a net operating deficit of $39 million is foreseen, and this does not take into account the cost of a year-end wage settlement with Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 5 -- Once-beaten Bonjour Hanover, a full-sister to the undefeated Bret Hanover, captured the $14,800.50 Debutante Stake No. 19 as the 127th year of harness racing at Historic Track began today.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) -- Despite a sharp decline in the Soviet economy during the last five years, there has been a "conspicuous rise in defense expenditures," a Congressional study warns.

A New Jersey State Assembly committee investigating the remarks of a Rutgers University teacher at a campus Vietnam teach-in has urged the state university to re-evaluate its policies on academic freedom.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 5 -- The Charlottesville school board has scrapped its "freedom-of-choice" policy in favor of a school district attendance plan that will substantially broaden integration of both pupils and teachers throughout the city.

TAEJON, South Korea, July 5 -- Farmers in the drought-stricken area around this provincial capital, heartened by several inches of rain over the weekend and helped by thousands of volunteers, are working feverishly to complete their severely delayed rice transplanting.

Despite President Johnson's adjurations to visit the U.S.A. first, virtually everyone in the fashion business has just been to, has just left for or is shortly leaving for Europe. Everyone except Larry Aldrich, that is.
GENEVA, July 5 -- A new move toward Christian unity was made today with the announcement that the Roman Catholic Church and the Lutheran World Federation would establish a joint working group.

As the House of Representatives begins debate on the voting rights bill today, its overriding objective should be to make this measure airtight and dependable. Congress is sure to pass a bill; the test is whether it passes one that will do the job and not need amendments and revisions in a year or two.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 5 (AP) -- The Garden State Parkway has joined the New Jersey Turnpike in its battle against speeding diplomats.

LONDON, July 5 -- In a sense Martha Graham's final conquest of the British ballet world should perhaps be dated from tonight. And it was a conquest in which Miss Graham, the Boadicea of the night, was regrettably absent.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 6 -- Leftists gained nine seats in the election to the upper house of the Diet (Parliament), Sunday, but Premier Eisaku Sato's ruling Liberal-Democratic party retained its majority.

Dorothy Schiff, publisher of The New York Post, postponed an immediate showdown last night with the printers' union over regular use of the laborsaving computer whose initial use led to a one-day suspension of the paper on June 23.

Two mighty home runs by Ron Swoboda and sparkling pitching by Larry Bearnarth and Tommy Parsons kept the Monday magic of the New York Mets marching magnificently onward at Shea Stadium yesterday by providing a double-header victory over the Chicago Cubs, 3-2 and 3-0.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 5 -- United States officials have decided that no useful purpose would be served in pressing for the establishment of a permanent inter-American peace force at the hemisphere conference opening Aug. 4 in Rio de Janeiro.

The Richmond County Republican organization served notice yesterday on Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican-Liberal designee for Mayor, that Republican candidates for local office there would take the Conservative party nomination if offered.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- The nation's third largest city is watching New York's travail in drought with both implicit sympathy and something of the surprise of the tortoise who outraced the hare.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- When hard bargaining begins in a few months on improving the International Monetary System, the United States will discover strong support among many of the leading financial nations for a new device called the "cru."

WESTBURY, L.I, July 5 -- Three of the seven pacers who started the featured one-mile invitation tonight at Roosevelt Raceway had not won a race this season. The trio, Top Dollar (0 for 9), Mr. Childs (0 for 14) and Delightful Time (0 for 6) finished one, two, three.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- There are more reasons than the personal goodwill Senator Dirksen enjoys in the political community and throughout the nation for hoping he will soon recover from the nagging stomach ailment which has again sent him to the hospital.
PARIS, July 5 -- Porfirio Rubirosa, former Dominican diplomat, international sportsman and playboy, died in an automobile accident here today.

TOKYO, July 5 -- Japanese officials have expressed "extreme interest" in President Johnson's proposals for cooperative development projects in Southeast Asia, Eugene R. Black said today.
LACAVE, France, July 5 (Reuters) -- Seven French girls retrained to normal life today after spending 15 days in a cave 350 feet below the surface.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July, 5 -- Harborvale Stables' Summer Scandal faced nine rival fillies today that had much more experience and much larger bankrolls than she, but proved she had the most speed by sweeping to an unexpected victory in the rich Monmouth Oaks.

The cogent arguments of your June 19 editorial "Parks Not for Parking" are abundantly confirmed by sad experience in San Francisco, a city which Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes mistakenly described as "progressive" in its garage-building policies.

The death of a Dalmatian dog last Friday at the animal research laboratory of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx has set off a demand by a New York Congressman for legislation to curtail the theft of pet dogs for medical research.

The death of a Dalmatian dog last Friday at the animal research laboratory of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx has set off a demand by a New York Congressman for legislation to curtail the theft of pet dogs for medical research.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) -- The Government extended today its antipoverty program to hard-pressed small-businessmen.
GREAT GULL ISLAND, L.I., July 5 -- Two women ornithologists went back to the city today after completing a week of isolation on this bleak and deserted island off the northeast tip of Long Island.

Despite overcast skies and plenty of rain, students of form came by boat, rail and interstate bus. The race trains brought 2,303, buses from New York carried 500 and 710 made the voyage from Jersey City, the Battery and Bay Ridge aboard the Keansburg Line's steamer.

DETROIT, July 5 -- The New York Yankees ended their holiday weekend by the rockets' red glare today, surviving a barrage of firecrackers and catcalls as they split a rowdy double-header with the Detroit Tigers before 40,153 persons.

BONN, July 5 -- West Germany's giant Friedrich Krupp company is considering divesting itself of part of its vast coal and steel holdings through the sale of stock to the public, according to reports circulating in financial circles here.
THE South is changing. So are its novelists. We see life and literature in joint transition as we read Jesse Hill Ford's upheaval in novel form, "The Liberation of Lord Byron Jones."
DUBLIN, July 5 -- It was the grandest and certainly the giddiest ball the Irish have given in years, and one reason was the guest of honor, a good-looking girl whose maiden name is Kelly.
Sammy Davis is expected to sign a contract today guaranteeing him nearly $1 million in salary over a three-year period.

BERLIN, July 5 -- Otto Winzer, the East German Foreign Minister, warned today that Communist military aircraft might resume flights over West Berlin if the "aggressive and provocative policy" of the West German Government continued.

FLIN FLON, Man., July 5 -- Dr. Alex Fedoric, a biologist and supervisor of the sport fishing section of the Manitoba Department of Mines and Natural Resources, hasn't come right out and said that he would like to psychoanalyze a trout, but he would.

The Stauffer Chemical Company, which ranks tenth largest in the chemical industry, had its best quarter on record in the three months ended June 30, with profits rising more than 40 per cent above those in the second quarter a year ago, Hans Stauffer, president, said in an interview over the weekend.
UTICA, N.Y., July 5 (AP) -- A storm smashed into the Utica area today, bringing six inches of rain in four hours. Cellars in hundreds of homes were flooded and several highways were damaged.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 5 -- This city went through a nervous half hour today when it seemed that fighting might break out and end the tense cease-fire just when negotiations were under way to establish peace.
LEADVILLE, Colo., July 5 -- The United States Army mountain training center at Camp Hale was silenced this summer for the first time since World War II.

AZUSA, Calif., July 5 (AP) -- Striking machinists at Aerojet-General Corporation facilities in Southern California approved by a 6-to-1 margin today an agreement reached with management, a union official said.
Dr. Timothy J. Costello, professorial, pipe-smoking candidate for President of the City Council, got in some face-to-face politicking yesterday in his effort to make himself known to New York voters.

ROME, July 6 -- Teen-age marriages in the United States, contracted under the romantic-erotic stimuli of movies, television and advertising, are foundering in increasing numbers on dirty dishes in the sink and end-of-the-month bills. This was the report made today by Clark W. Blackburn, director general of the Family Service Association of America, of New York, to the International Union of Family Organizations, meeting here.
City Councilman Edward J. Sadowsky of Queens, announcing that he would seek re-election, said yesterday he had been denied redesignation by the Democrats "in a naked act of nepotism."
MOSCOW, July 6 (Reuters) -- An audience of about 5,000 gave a polite but unenthusiastic welcome today to the Greek and Austrian entries in the fourth Moscow Film Festival, which opened yesterday.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 6 (AP) -- Jimmie Hall twice hit two-run homers tonight and Jim Grant checked the Boston Red Sox on eight hits as the Minnesota Twins scored a 9-0 victory. It was the sixth straight triumph for the league-leading Twins.
ALBANY, July 6 (AP) -- Justice Russell G. Hunt granted a preliminary injunction today staying preparation for the election of legislators under a Republican reapportionment plan.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 6 -- A former North American champion, Mrs. Timothea Schneider Larr of Seawanhaka-Corinthian, and Sue Kron of Port Washington finished in a tie for first place today in the regional qualifying races and took the two area places for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

OAKDALE, L.I., July 6 -- Dave Van Nostrand skippered the Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club crew to victory today in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's area eliminations for the junior championship.

BONN, July 6 -- The West German Government is moving to organize resistance to what it regards as a characteristic move by President De Gaulle aimed at bending France's Common Market partners to his will.
Three members of the New York City Police Department, including one of the most decorated detectives on the force, have been transferred as a result of a departmental investigation.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 6 -- The New York Yacht Club's junior regatta, which often has encountered cantakerous wind or protracted calm, had ample breeze for the 20th staging of the event today, and all but a handful of 179 starting boats completed their races on Long Island Sound.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 6 (UPI) -- The Rhodesian Stock Exchange closed today without a single transaction being consummated. It was believed to be the first time under normal market conditions that absolutely no business was transacted.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it expected to remove by Aug. 1 a huge construction tower that has obscured the corner of 13th Street and the Avenue of the Americas for almost four years.

The universal metering of water as a conservation measure has been under debate in New York for more than a hundred years. We would have thought that, in view of previous expert engineering studies, no more studies were necessary.

ROME, July 6 (UPI) -- A Rome court trying Sophia Loren and Carlo Ponti on bigamy charges today received a series of anonymous accusations, including a complaint that Miss Loren is not a great actress.

CHICHESTER, England, July 6 -- The fourth annual Chichester Festival Theater opened tonight in this small Sussex city with a handsomely mounted drama about Scottish border trouble in the early 16th century.
For the sixth consecutive trading session, pork belly futures set new life-of-contract highs yesterday.

" Chinese Journal," by Gun and Jan Myrdal, will be published by Pantheon in October. The book extends the account of life in China that Jan Myrdal wrote in "Report From a Chinese Village," which appeared early this year.

The body of a 13-year-old boy who had been missing from his Queens home since June 27 was found early yesterday in the bedroom of a West Side hotel. The police chaged a 34-year-old unemployed dress salesman with the boy's murder.
PARIS -- In a noisy working-class district of Paris, behind a high stone wall, hides a tranquil village.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Three former heavyweight boxing champions told a Congressional committee today that the sport was getting worse and that a Federal commission should be created to control it.

The fourth annual Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition will be held next Jan. 3 to 19 at Carnegie Hall. As in the past two years, it will be for conductors. There will be fewer first prize winners, but the cash awards will be higher.
Controller Abraham D. Beame challenged Representative John V. Lindsay yesterday to a lunch-hour debate in the garment center Friday on "Who is the real liberal?"
A modest late rally in industrial issues helped to steady prices on the London Stock Exchange yesterday but the 30-stock average slipped to another new 1965 low.
DETROIT, July 6 -- The American Library Association voted today in favor of barring from membership any institution that dicriminates against library users.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 -- Harsh and brutal measures have increased on both sides as the intensity of the war in South Vietnam has risen.

HIGH-LEVEL executives of the Columbia Broadcasting System, which now owns the New York Yankees, can learn an important lesson about the baseball business by contemplating a few unexpected batting statistics.
LONDON, July 6 -- The quest for the great British male classical dancer has developed into a serial story, rather like the quest for the British world heavyweight boxing champion or the Davis Cup.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today he would "cooperate to the fullest extent" with Attorney General Richmond Flowers of Alabama in his investigation of the Alabama Ku Klux Klan.
A bright experimental scroen for displaying stock prices made its debut yesterday on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 6 -- Although a theater remains to be built and a fund of $3.5 million remains to be raised, Ithacans are confident that they will begin their first festival on June 30, 1967, probably with a production of Sophocles's "Oedipus."
Shipping leaders involved in the current strike of sea-going personnel believe that a single all-powerful czar may be the ultimate answer to labor troubles that constantly plague the industry.

I wish to thank The New York Times for the editorial "The Perennial Battista" of July 1. Although the article was written in a facetious manner, and was meant to degrade and demean me, I still thank you, because any knock from The New York Times can be counted as a boost.

LONDON, July 6 -- The two senior members of Prime Minister Wilson's Cabinet were forced today to explain strong words they had used about the Opposition. Their public embarrassment struck a blow at the prestige of the Labor Government.
Some of the nation's top nutrition experts are concerned at the new popularity of the low-carbohydrate reducing diet, which one of them calls "nonsense" and another compares to "mass murder."

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 -- A Federal investigatory commission was named today to investigate charges of financial irregularities in the Brazilian affiliate of Mannesmann Steel of Duesseldorf, West Germany.

The once-familiar Western Union messenger boy moved closer to oblivion yesterday. There was no role for him in a new service announced by the company as it continued its march into the future world of communications.

Speedy Scot, the defending champion, was made the 1-5 favorite to win Saturday's $100,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway after getting the No. 4 starting position yesterday. The draw was held at the Forum of the Twelve Caesars.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The Senate by voice vote gave its final approval today to a bill requiring a health warning on all cigarette packages.

The 58th Street branch of the Public Library will be put on the auction block next month in an unusual offer in which the city hopes to promote a tax-producing office tower on the site and still retain the library there.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 (AP) -- Argentina announced today plans for massive importation of crude oil. This will counteract a shortage developing as a result of canceled contracts with petroleum companies.

ISOM, Ky., July 6 -- The first mountain dirt was turned today starting construction on the 2,350 miles of "development highways" designed to let some of the nation's affluence into the impoverished and remote Appalachian hills.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he had not predicted that a recession or depression was around the corner and did not know if one could come.
BRIDGEPORT Conn. -- Patients and physicians at Bridgeport Hospital are finding life a little easier these days thanks to a group of youthful volunteers from Fairfield University.

PARIS, July 6 -- A 5-year-old named Elma, who drinks the water wherever she goes, has been trotting through Europe this year trying to convince the Europeans that all American girls are just like her. The French, however, seem to prefer their own.

The New York Post, the city's first newspaper to set part of its type by computer, was back printing solely by conventional means. Yesterday Negotiations over further use of the computer were in indefinite suspension.

NEW YORK is a summer music festival. Last night another outdoor concert series got under way, this time on the Lower East Side, as the Lower Eastside Neighborhood Association began its 10th year of Evenings by the River.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 6 -- Six Colonial homes and a contemporary one are on the itinerary of the 17th Open House Day Tour, to be held on Saturday.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 6 -- The stage is set here for a political battle to reunify Katanga Province as the first step in a plan for a Congo confederation.
Strategists for Representative John V. Lindsay said yesterday that they were increasingly worried about the lack of a vital ingredient in his campaign for Mayor -- money.
The Government is planning to erect a $37.9 million Federal office building in Foley Square to house the United States Court of Appeals and about a dozen Federal agencies.
Columbia and New York Universities are among 50 schools sharing almost $39 million in Federal grants announced yesterday in Washington.

" My Childhood," a documentary about the early lives of Vice President Humphrey and James Baldwin, the author, received an Emmy nomination last week. Yesterday, the producer learned that there had been a mistake.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation battled today attempts by seven companies to reduce its authority.

THE work of the Job Corps Center at Camp Kilmer, N.J., and the Neighborhood Youth Corps in Newark received a sympathetic examination last night from station WNBC-TV in a program produced, directed and written by John G. Fuller.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 -- United States, South Vietnamese and Australian troops set out today on another attempt to find the Vietcong in their Zone D jungle stronghold.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) -- Don Cardwell pitched a six-hitter for his seventh straight victory and drove in two runs with a single tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Philadelphia Phils, 8-4.

The commander and officers of the French destroyer Bouvet will be guests of honor at the 6th Bastille Day Ball, to be held at the Astor on Saturday. Proceeds will go to the relief funds administered by the Committee of French Speaking Societies and the Federation of French War Veterans.

Cincinnati and Suburban Bell Telephone Company announced yesterday plans for a two-for-one split, an increase in the dividend and a rights offering. The company, owned 28.4 per cent by American Telephone and Telegraph Company, called a Special meeting of stockholders for Nov. 15 to vote on the proposed stock spat.
SWANLEY, England, Wednesday, July 7 (Reuters) -- International telephone links were thrown into confusion yesterday when a workman dug a hole outside Bert's Cafe here.

A medicare bill which will result in profound changes in the practice of medicine in the United States will soon be passed by the Congress. Surely, the evidence clearly indicates the need for medicare legislation, but the present bill has major defects which have not been emphasized because intransigence on both sides has precluded a constructive dialogue between the Congress and the medical profession.

BERLIN, July 6 -- France's New Wave film directors emerged as the over-all victors at Berlin's 15th annual film festival tonight with Jean Luc Godard's "Alphaville" taking the "Golden Bear" first prize and Agnes Var's "Le Bonheur" winning a special "Silver Bear" award.
The three-day Fourth of July weekend apparently was not long enough for the bond market. Trading yesterday was described as extremely quiet as prices declined slightly.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Senate gave final approval today to a proposed constitutional amendment on Presidential disability and succession, sending it to the states for ratification.
TRENTON, July 6 (AP) -- New Jersey is taking a new look at New Hampshire's venture into the lottery business.

Macy's New York has taken an option on a large site near Fishkill, N.Y., for a shopping center that would include a new Macy branch, David L. Yunich, president, dis closed yesterday. Fishkill is in Dutchess County, about 70 miles north of New York.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 6 -- Despite losing more than an hour yesterday afternoon in transferring an injured crewman, the ocean racing schooner Nina took the lead in the 63-boat race from Marblehead to Halifax, N.S., before sunset today.
The ubiquitous newsletter, which in the past has propelled such figures as Austin Kiplinger and Bernard Gallagher to a form of fame, has gained another adherent in the public relations field.

THE competition for the driver's championship in the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing is as tight as ever after last Sunday's Firecracker 400 at Daytona Beach, Fla. Dick Hutcherson is still the leader and Ned Jarrett is still second, with Marvin Panch and Junior Johnson a bit more secure in the first 10.

PARIS, July 6 -- France withdrew her permanent representative from the European Economic Community today. The action was interpreted here as the beginning of a French power play intended to force the five other member countries to accept the terms they rejected at a foreign ministers' conference in Brussels last Thursday.

Gareth Martinis began his defense yesterday, with testimony by a police sergeant who said that Mr. Martinis did not appear to him to be under the influence of alcohol following an automobile accident in which five persons were killed.
TRENTON, July 6 -- The State Supreme Court ordered new trials today for two convicted first-degree murderers.
SOUTHPORT, England, July 16 -- The way they are talking, the trip hardly seems worthwhile.

CAIRO, July 6 -- President Abdullah al-Salal was reported tonight to have formed a new republican Cabinet in Yemen dominated by military officers, dashing hopes for a peaceful settlement of Yemen's prolonged civil war.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- A move by a civil rights group to have Federal funds withheld from the Chicago School system on the ground that it is deliberately racially segregated aroused angry reaction among members of the Chicago Board of Education.

MARIANNE MOORE, the poet whose tricorn inspired a group of Adolfo's new hats, couldn't make it to his showing yesterday at the Sheryy-Netherland. But for a moment it looked as if Elizabeth Barrett Browning had.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- Luci Baines Johnson said today that her baptism into the Roman Catholic Church was a "personal matter" and that she had gone about it "in a personal way."

The projected World Trade Center on the Lower West Side got its biggest tenant last night with the announcement in Washington that the Bureau of Customs would take 763,500 square feet of floor space in the 16-acre complex.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States announced today that it recognizes the new Algerian Government led by Col. Houari Boumedienne.
A new Italian-language weekly newspaper, Corriere di New York, went on sale last night for the first time at newsstands in the metropolitan area.
Former Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri will hang out a new shingle today as he attempts to remove some of the bitterness generated by last week's taxi-cab strike.
The appointment of Richard A. Harper as administrative vice president of Seven Arts Productions, Ltd., was announced yesterday by Eliot Hyman, president of the motion-picture distributor.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Johnson's latest step toward an American supersonic airliner has created disappointment in almost every quarter.
LONDON, July 6 -- The house where Sir Winston Churchill lived for many years and where he died last January 28, Hyde Park Gardens, is to be sold at auction in mid-October.

CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- Lou Johnson rapped three hits, driving in two runs, and Dick Tracewski knocked in two runs on two hits as the Los Angeles Dodgers outslugged the Cincinnati Reds, 11-7, tonight and climbed back into first place.

BLANTYRE, Malawi, July 6 (AP) -- Prime Minister H. Kamuzu Banda said today that Communist China was spending millions of dollars to corrupt African leaders and the money could be better spent feeding the Chinese.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Senator John Sherman Cooper, Republican of Kentucky, introduced a measure today to prohibit any officer or employe of the Senate from soliciting, accepting or distributing any political campaign funds.

PARIS -- Talk of a de Gaulle-Johnson meeting has recently revived in the United States. There were erroneous reports this had been discussed when the General received Vice President Humphrey. A Republican fact-finding mission urged Washington to take the initiative in seeking a tete-a-tete.
NEW BRUSWICK, N.J., July 6 -- The birthplace of Joyce Kilmer, the soldier-poet, may be demolished unless American Legionnaires who own the two-story frame dwelling can raise about $15,000.

A five-story office building at 135 Cedar Street, between Washington and Greenwich Streets, has been bought by Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., the public relations concern. The new building, with about 10,800 square feet of space, is adjacent to the company's main building at 131 Cedar Street.

Several thousand monogrammed items, ranging from antique brass doorknobs to silver ash trays, were bought yesterday by New York residents with the initials SH or SP at a special sale at the Savoy Plaza Hotel.
BALTIMORE, July 6 (AP) -- Lutheran and Roman Catholic clergymen and laymen sat down together today to discuss basic beliefs of the two churches.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 6 -- Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N.J. who heads the draw, led the way into the quarterfinal round of the New York State girls' tennis championship today on the opening day of the tournament at the Round Hill Club.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July 6 -- All ethnic Chinese living in an area 15 miles southeast of Kuching, the capital of Sarawak, were ordered today to move into resettlement areas.
BLED, Yugoslavia, July 6 (AP) -- The case of a young Russian poet sentenced to five years at hard labor for "parasitism" last year is under review by the Soviet Supreme Court, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Johnson entertained Sir Robert Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, at a small dinner at the White House tonight.
LONDON, July 6 -- A second big Wall Street brokerage house with a London branch office has decided to advertise for British business.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Representative John F. Lindsay said today he would "not be embarrassed in the slightest" if Senator Jacob K. Javits supported a constitutional amendment permitting one house of a state legislature to be apportioned on factors other that population.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations committee approved today more free trips home and bigger telephone and air mail-special delivery postage allowances for Senators.

OTTAWA, July 6 -- Guy Rouleau, former Parliamentary Secretary to Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson, gave up his seat in the House of Commons today. He acted at the request of the Prime Minister, who is trying to dissociate the Government from alleged misdoings involving a bribery and coercion conspiracy.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Monsanto Company of St. Louis received 10 patents today for what it regards as a highly important intermediate process in the production of nylon.
New York City returned yesterday to a 1954 source of water -- wells in Nassau County -- to supplement its dwindling daily supply.
The British pound inched ahead yesterday in quiet dealings on foreign exchange markets here.
Project Head Start, a $5,642,357, eight-week program for the preschool children of the poor, got under way yesterday at 276 centers in the city.

The emphasis was on youth at Aqueduct yesterday as six 2-year-old fillies, five of them eligible for next Wednesday's 59th running of the $25,000 added Astoria, went through their paces in the featured $10,000 My Dear Girl.
SELMA, Ala., July 6 -- A prominent integration leader was indicted today on charges of embezzling thousands of dollars donated to the civil rights movement here.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Last year showed a continuation of the downward trend in births in the United States and a new low for infant mortality, the Public Health Service reported today.
Traffic deaths during the Fourth of July weekend throughout the country rose to a record 552 for a three-day holiday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A more formal and extensive mechanism for coordinating policies among the Government agencies that regulate banks and savings and loan associations was announced today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler.
Public holdings of Series E and H United States Savings Bonds showed a net gain during June, including accrued interest, of $61 million, the Treasury Department reported yesterday.

Four major New York City banks disclosed yesterday that unseasonally heavy demand for business loans helped them achieve sharp increases and, in some cases, set records in earnings for the first half of 1965.
The Senate's overwhelming approval of the constitutional amendment on Presidential disability and succession moves this vital reform one step further toward ratification.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (UPI) -- Dean Chance scored his fifth victory of the season tonight after failing on five previous attempts, but he lasted only five innings as the Los Angeles Angels scored a 6-2 victory over the Washington Senators.

A Denver Chicago Trucking Company spokesman said yesterday the concern hoped to make at least a "small" profit on the management contract it expects to sign with the financially troubled Yale Express System, Inc.

DETROIT, July 6 -- An uneasy lull developed in the "brush-back war" between the New York Yankees and Detroit Tigers tonight. But the Tigers still stalked Yankee pitchers with bats and pounded out an 8-0 victory while Denny McLain won his sixth straight game.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 6 (UPI) -- Rockburn Stable's Carnival Queen had too much speed for eight other fillies in the $5,000 Evening Out Purse at Monmouth Park today, pulling away to a six-length lead at the start of the stretch and then coasting to a 2 1/2-length victory.
Your excellent June 29 editorial "Supporting Rent Subsidies" omitted several additional important pluses for New York City.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 6 -- An $18,600 stakes race may not be quite the occasion for experimenting, but Billy Haughton did that today at Historic Track and did not regret it.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The State Department disclosed today that two Soviet antiaircraft missile sites in North Vietnam were virtually ready to receive weapons and that two others were nearing completion.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- In the next few days, the secretary of the Senate will deliver an enrolled, or official copy of S.J. Res. 1, printed on fancy, thick parchment, to the administrator of the General Services Administration, Lawson Knott.
The stock market was quiet yesterday, with most prices showing changes of only fractions on the downward side. Volume slipped to 3.4 million shares.
TRENTON, July 6 -- New Jersey got a stern new law today to combat drunken driving by youths.
Market analysts listened to optimistic predictions from officials of the National Can Corportation yesterday.
" Tin cans, like matches, are usually taken for granted,'' according to Hamilton H. Howry Jr.

ONE technical term that bridge has borrowed from chess is the coup en passant. The meaning changes somewhat, because the bridge player slips one past the opponent while the chess player frustrates his opponent's attempt to slip one past.

OTTAWA (Canadian Press) July 7 -- Canada's official holdings of gold and United States dollars eased downwards $18.6 million during June to end the month at $2,480,100,000, the lowest figure in more than a year.

The New York State Penal Code has no specific statutes making it a crime to induceI minors to drink alcoholic beverages or to use narcotics. Such actions, however, are subject to prosecution under the children and sales sections of the Code.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 6 -- The former Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead said today that he knew when he resigned three weeks ago that a grand jury would be "associating my name" in an investigation into possible influence peddling and pay-offs in the acquisition of county lands.

BONN, July 6 -- The West German and French teams will train together for the next Olympic Games in Grenoble, France, and Mexico City, Maurice Herzog, the French High Commissioner for Youth and Sports, said today.
In the wake of Colonel Boumedienne's speech at the celebration of the third anniversary of Algerian independence, the political shape of Algeria after Ben Bella is emerging with increasing clarity.

THE world of sports has been in a straitjacket for so long that it comes as a surprise to find almost every sphere of athletic activity on the expansion bandwagon. Pro football has spread out and will spread further. Basketball is committed to the two-way stretch in another year and hockey has hit on an unusual way of doubling its size.
Three small, pajama-clad children were found dead in bed with plastic bags over their heads yesterday in the second floor apartment of their two-family home at 37-32 64th Street, Woodside, Queens.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- The Kremlin skyline of fanciful 17th-century spires and domes is interrupted these days by the straight lines of television antennas linked to the official apartments below.
The H American Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif., which operates a community antenna television system announced the election yesterday of Harold R. Sugerman as executive vice president.
When I read the letter by Prof. Jerome B. King in your June 24 issue, I could not help thinking that he had a distorted concept of war and its objectives.
TOKYO, July 6 (UPI) -- The Japanese Government has warned Pan American World Airways against landing any more cargo planes at Haneda International Airport without official approval.

Secretary of the Interior Stewart Udall has followed the advice of his Advisory Committee on Wildlife Management by giving the Division of Predator and Rodent Control a new name. It is now the Division of Wildlife Services. But the new name will not make it smell sweeter unless there is also a marked change from the old policy of "control for control's sake," which the committee denounced.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- The Soviet Union has made it a crime to entice minors under 18 years of age into drunkenness and the use of narcotics.

A substantial expansion of trade between major ports in northwestern Europe and ports in northern Iran, via the year-old Volga-Baltic Canal, has been reported by Dmitri Zotov, Soviet deputy minister of merchant marine.
A big old-fashioned outing was held yesterday on Flushing Meadow, the day for members of Kiwanis holding an international convention in New York to see the World's Fair.
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, showed a 1.6 per cent increase in sales in its first fiscal quarter ended May 29 above the period a year ago.
The Metropolitan Opera joined hands with the Newport Folk Festival last night to present an evening of folk songs at Lewisohn Stadium.
Disagreement over fees to be paid to the Port of New York Authority for the use of its terminals is delaying the start of a new airport bus service around the city.
TEL AVIV, July 6 -- A United States civil rights worker became the focus of a debate tonight when he was charged with putting the plight of the Negro above that of his fellow Jews.

THE first thing to be said is that Theodore H. White's book about the Presidential campaign of 1964 is just as compellingly interesting as its distinguished predecessor about the 1960 campaign. What is the secret of Mr. White's extraordinary ability to rehash material already worn threadbare in newspapers and magazines and produce books of fresh excitement and illuminating insight?

A new doctoral program in the Portuguese language and literature will be offered this September at Queens College, Dr. Albert H. Bowker, Chancellor of the City University of New York, announced yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 6 -- Ranking American military men here believe the intensified Vietnam war has heightened rather than diminished the importance of maintaining a strong military guard against possible Communist aggression in Korea.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 6 -- With lobster catches getting scarcer, the price is getting higher and lobstermen of Long Island and in Maine are worried.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- A Defense Department spokesman said today that it was essential for the Government to have a special exemption from patent laws.
The Army has awarded a $44,977,568 contract to the General Dynamics Corporation for production of digital subscriber terminal equipment.
ALGIERS, July 7 -- Colonel Boumedienne, who became president of Algeria's Revolutionary Council yesterday donned a dark gray suit and received the diplomatic corps like a chief of state today.

A persistent defect of this country's commercial radio and television system is that, lacking anything resembling the "Third Program" of the B.B.C., there no regular provision for meeting the needs of certain small specialized audiences.

LONDON, July 6 -- Arrogant, humble, bombastic, insecure, frenzied, loyal, unpredictable, brilliant, bumbling, irrepressible -- these are some of the adjectives used to describe George Alfred Brown, the Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, who ranks second only to Prime Minister Wilson in Britain's Labor Government.

KANSAS CITY, July 6 (AP) -- Steve Barber drove in two runs with a homer and a sacrifice fly and gave only three hits to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-1 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.

TORONTO, July 6 (Canadian Press) -- The General Acceptance Corporation of Allentown, Pa., held informal talks today with tale Montreal Trust Company on the possibility of taking over the sales and finance end of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 6 (Reuters) -- Mayor Wagner said here tonight that New York was not likely to have any racial riots this year like the ones that took place last summer.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- House Democratic leaders were confident today that they could get the votes to defeat a Republican substitute for the Administration-backed voting rights bill.

A specialist on foreign taxes and investments asserted here yesterday that the "backlash" created by President Johnson's payments program was largely responsible for an estimated 4 per cent drop in United States commercial exports during the first half of 1965.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 7 -- B-52 jet bombers carried out another "spoiling mission" raid today on a jungle area 35 miles northeast of Saigon, United States military officials announced.
HOLLYWOOD, July 6 -- The television networks' decision to devote vastly more prime time to the showing of motion pictures next season is bringing a sharp response from Hollywood.
BRUSSELS, July 6 -- The European Common Market consciously underplayed its crisis today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Anthony J. Celebrezze announced plans today to retain and modernize the Public Health Service hospitals in Boston, Norfolk, Va., and Galveston, Tex.
LONDON, July 6 -- Britain has received no official protests from British Commonweatlh governments about Prince Philip's observations on Rhodesia.

ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP) -- Lou Brock made three hits, drove in one run and scored the other two as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the San Francisco Giants, 3-2, tonight for their seventh straight triumph.
DUESSELDORF, West Germany, July 6 (Reuters) -- The Gillette Company won a legal battle today giving it the exclusive right to produce its long-life stainless steel razor blades in West Germany.
PITTSBURGH, July 6, (UPI) -- The police shot and killed today a gunman who killed a police lieutenant in a pre-dawn reign of terror.

Margaret Webster will direct two of the three revivals to be put on this season by the National Repertory Theater on tour and in New York. One of her assignments will be "The Madwoman of Chaillot," the Jean Giraudoux-Maurice Valency comedy.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board held out the prospect today of improved airline service for intermediate-size cities as smaller jet planes come into use.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that 31 per cent of the 4.5 million workers the Administration seeks to bring under the minimum wage law now made less than $1.25 an hour.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 -- A violent political attack by Gov. Carlos Lacerda of Guanabara State against President Humberto Castelo Branco boomeranged today against the Governor's presidential candidacy.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Lyndon Johnson now is beginning to feel the inevitable heat of the burning scrutiny that Americans eagerly give to every act, word, folly and foible of their Presidents. In Mr. Johnson's case the heat is beginning to scorch a little later and a little more intensely than usual.

Investors and brokers must have extended the Fourth of July holiday by another day as volume all but disappeared on the American Stock Exchange. The 860,000 shares that were traded represented the year's lowest volume and compared with 1,093,000 shares last Friday.
BOSTON, July 6 (UPI) -- Manager Al Lopez named nine more players to the American League All-Star team today, but Washington, Kansas City and Los Angeles still were not represented.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Despite last year's big tax cut, the Treasury's total cash receipts in the fiscal year ended last Wednesday rose by nearly $4 billion from the year before.
LONDON, Wednesday, July 7 -- The Labor Government was defeated on an important clause in the finance bill in the House of Commons early today. It also lost two other votes.

THE annual report of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare on fish killed because of pollution puts the 1964 mortality at 18.4 million. This may seem a horrendous number, but specialists in the field say that for every dead fish seen, there are as least 10 not seen, not reported.
ALBANY, July 6 -- Governor Rockefeller signed today a bill permitting harness racing tracks to stay open nearly the entire year.

SANTO DOMINGON, Dominican Republic, July 6 (UPI) -- A spokesman for the junta government today warned the Organization of American States against any attempt to "impose" a provisional regime on the Dominican Republic.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Senate opened debate on the Administration's medicare bill today with passage by a one-sided vote apparently assured.
United States steel production set a record in the first six months of this year.

Second-quarter earnings of the Bristol-Myers Company are expected to increase to about 58 cents a share, Gavin K. MacBain, president of the big pharmaceutical, cosmetics and toiletries producer, reported to shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del.

TORONTO (Canadian Press) July 6 -- The proposed sale of an additional 600 billion cubic feet of natural gas for $250 million in the next 20 years was announced yesterday by Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Johnson Administration is watching President de Gaulle's latest assault upon European union and allied integration with fascination, sorrow and disciplined silence.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 -- The Justice Department filed suit today to block the merger of the Mercantile Trust Company and the Security Trust Company, the largest and the fifth-largest banks, respectively, in St. Louis.
PARIS, July 7 -- The French Government turned its attention today to the internal political and economic consequences of its break with the majority of its partners in the Common Market.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 7 -- Until today, speculation among horsemen had given Stanley Dancer-trained trotters a solid chance to finish one, two, three in the Hambletonian at Du Quoin, Ill., on Sept. 1.
California sold two bond issues totaling $120 million yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company, the First Nation Bank of Chicago and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara is preparing to suggest changes in the officer promotion system by rewarding military talent over seniority.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- LeRoy Collins, director of the Community Relations Service for the last year, was sworn in today as Under Secretary of Commerce.

MOSCOW, July 7 -- The Soviet Union urged the United States today to reconsider a North Vietnamese formula to end the war in Vietnam, a formula American officials consider nothing short of capitulation.

Representative John V. Lindsay has eight names on his list of Democrats being considered for the post of City Controller on his multiparty or fusion ticket, reliable informants said yesterday. Among the leading possibilities who have been asked in recent days whether they would be interested in running with the Republican-Liberal designee are:

Two Democrats in the race for Mayor called for more information yesterday about a published report that Governor Rockefeller had pledged $500,000 toward the campaign expenses of Representative John V. Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Luci Baines Johnson took part today in a half-hour demonstration of techniques for identifying certain eye defects in children as part of her father's antipoverty program.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 (AP) -- Howie Koplitz and Ron Kline pitched 8 2/3 innings of shutout ball in relief of injured Frank Kreutzer as the Washington Senators defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 3-1, tonight.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP) -Tom Haller's two-run homer with two out in the 13th inning tonight gave the San Francisco Giants a 4-2 victory and ended the St. Louis Cardinals' winning streak at seven games.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -Gene Mauch, the National League All-Star manager, departed from custom today and passed over three "second choices" as he picked nine players for the 1965 team.
Lethargy again marked trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume moved ahead slightly, reaching 890,000 shares against 875,000 the day before.

Two defense witnesses testified yesterday at the trial of Gareth Martinis that he did not appear intoxicated following an accident in 1963 in which five persons were killed. Mr. Martinis, 25-year-old son of an acting Supreme Court justice, is on trial in Supreme Court in the Bronx on a charge of vehicular homicide.

LEE, Mass., July 7 -- A felicitous combination of something old and something new has produced an especially gratifying program for the third week of the 1965 Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, which began last night in the Ted Shawn Theater.

CAIRO, July 7 -- The military rulers of Yemen, headed by President Abdullah al-Salal, have arrested 40 or 50 followers of the former civilian Premier, Ahmed Noman, in a continuing power struggle, well-placed sources said today.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 7 -- Ellsworth Bunker of the United States, the leading inter-American mediator here, asserted today that last night's outbreak of fighting would not affect the complex Dominican peace negotiations.

LEONIA, N.J., July 7 -- Arnold Weisselberg, founder and chairman of the Wyssmont Company, Inc., a chemicals processing concern in Fort Lee, died yesterday in his home at 20 Paulin Boulevard here. He was 65 years old.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -Singles by Rocky Colavito and Fred Whitfield were the key hits in a three-run 11th inning tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Chicago White Sox, 4-2, for a sweep of a double-header.
Car owners will pay from $1 to $35 more a year for liability insurance under a sweeping overhaul of rates approved yesterday by the State Insurance Department.

WENTZLE RUML Jr. of East Orange, N.J., offered ideas for improving dog show procedures recently and one was a widening of the allowed distance between all-breed events held on the same day. Rural is the American Kennel Club delegate for the Dayton Kennel Club, the secretary of the Dog Writers Association of America and the new chairman of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- Chris Short's three-hit pitching and an eighth-inning homer by Clay Dalrymple lifted the Philadelphia Phillies to a 1-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
THE HOT and weary patrons of the Ronda Snack Bar got more than they paid for Tuesday afternoon with their gazpasho and their sangria.

BOGALUSA, La., July 7 -- Bogalusa Negroes took to the streets today for their first civil rights march in more than two months. Unlike previous marches, this one encountered nothing more severe than a summer rain.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A compromise has been reached on disputed printing of more than 600 depositions submitted by the Mississippi Freedom Democratic party in its effort to unseat the five Representatives from that state.

The general manager of Barney's, the bargain clothing store, at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street, promised "irrevocably" in Criminal Court yesterday to obey the Sabbath law and not do business on Sundays.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., July 7 -- About two weeks ago Mrs. J. Leonard Reinsch of Atlanta underwent heart surgery at Auckland's Green Lane Hospital.

Even though he spotted his opposition more than a little ground when he got away slowly, Ogden Phipps's Buckpasser registered his fourth straight triumph yesterday by taking the $34,375 Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct.

The three defeats the Labor Government has just suffered in the House of Commons do not prove that Britain faces an immediate political crisis. The setbacks resulted from a parliamentary trick played by the Conservatives. They caught the Government napping. The issues on which the votes were taken were not of major importance.
The Police Department postponed yesterday the filing of departmental charges against three policemen who were transfered out of a Harlem precinct.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Carl R. Schedler, former associate director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, died today at George Washington University Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 69 years old.

A proposal to use up to 1 per cent of the total construction cost of all new city buildings to make them beautiful was disclosed yesterday by the recently formed Committee to Beautify the City of New York.
BONN, July 7 -- West Germany and Israel, each striving to impose a particular stamp on their relations, are accepting a draw in a diplomatic wrestling match.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 -Sea water could be transformed into fresh water with atomic power at about one-fifth of current costs, according to the latest Federally sponsored engineering study.

CHICAGO July 7 -- The Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., announced today that Chicago had been selected as the site of the first full-scale civil rights program to be undertaken by his Southern Christian Leadership Conference in a major Northern city.
Two major steel installations began operations yesterday.
WHEN he went out West in the 19th century, an indomitable old pioneer once proudly said, "I was worth nothing -- and now I owe $2 million."
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 7 -- Gov. William A. Egan may face bitter opposition within his party if he seeks a third term next year.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., July 7 (AP) -- The Nassau police arrested five white teen-agers tonight in the burning of a six-foot cross and the smashing of windows at the home of an interracial couple.
A "chew-it-yourself" bubble gum art exhibition and a "happening" will be held on July 20 at the Sheraton-East to benefit the Police Athletic League.

Television producing, anyone? The rat race is on. By Aug. 1 the three national TV networks will have made most of their decisions on the fate of about 200 ideas for new programs in the season of 1966-67. They will rule on which ventures will be dropped by the wayside and which will be made into pilot films.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- President Johnson was serenaded by 40 Texas youngsters at the White House today.
HALIFAX N.S., July 7 (AP) -- The 47-foot schooner Carillon appeared tonight to have won the 360-mile yacht race from Marblehead, Mass., to Halifax on the basis of corrected time.
Drastic rules to end fleecing of motorists by parking garages and lots were announced yesterday by City License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo.
FEW thing tear the heart as much as the sight of a sick child. For those who must be hospitalized for weeks, months and even years, any respite from pain and monotony is welcome.

DANANG, South Vietnam, July 7 -- Communist reinforcements for the war in South Vietnam are infiltrating in increasing numbers directly across part of the demilitarized zone on the border at the 17th Parallel, according to recent evidence.
PITTSBURGH, July 7 (UPI) -- The police said today that a gunman who touched off a shooting spree yesterday that left three persons dead had killed himself and was not shot by the police.

ALBANY, July 7 -- The state's rigid laws on criminal insanity have been liberalized under a bill signed by Governor Rockefeller. The Governor's office here said that Mr. Rockefeller, who is on a brief vacation in Venezuela, signed the measure last week.
Members of the Park Association of New York City finished their program yesterday to add a little touch of beauty to the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

Thomas S. Lamont filed a complete denial yesterday of Securities and Exchange Commission charges that he had advised Morgan Guaranty Trust Company to buy Texas Gulf sulphur Company stock on the basis of inside information that the mining concern had made a rich mineral strike in Ontario.
Kenneth Mygatt, an executive of New York travel agencies for nearly 40 years, died Saturday while on a visit to Sheridan, Wyo. He was 86 years old and lived at 7 Kimberly Place, New Canaan, Conn.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 7 -- Wesley Cotterell, chairman of Cotterell, Mitchell Fifer, a general insurance firm at 151 William Street, New York, died today at the age of 68. He lived at 123 Chester Avenue, Garden City, L.I.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- From the standpoint of average life expectancy, the best part of the country to be born in is the West-North Central states for white persons and the Pacific States for non-whites.
Parked cars or not, the show must go on. This could have served last night as a motto for the Mobilization for Youth Summer Theater Project's opening performance.

The sudden indisposition of Fausto Cleva after conducting the first three numbers of last night's Metropolitan Opera program in Lewisohn Stadium caused only one minor alteration -- the omission of Chabrier's "Espana."
HARTFORD, July 7 -- A bill prohibiting professional boxing in Connecticut until the sport comes under Federal regulations was signed today by Gov. John N. Dempsey.

The last-place finish of the New York Giants in the National Football League last fall failed to dampen the public's fervor for tickets to the team's home games this season at Yankee Stadium. Tickets this fall will be more difficult to come by than ever before because none will be put on general sale.

DETROIT, July 7 -- The Yankees shook up their pitching staff today. They put Bill Stafford, a right-hander, on the disabled list because of a sore right shoulder, sold Bob Tiefenauer, the 35-year-old knuckle-ball expert, to their Toledo club of the International League, and called up two right-handers, Pete Mikkelsen and Jim Brenneman, from Toledo.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- A four-state water emergency was declared tonight for the Delaware River basin. New York City was directed to reduce immediately its consumption of Delaware water by 75 million gallons a day.
PARIS, July 7 -- A refrigerator that originally cost its owner $2,400, and has since involved him in six years of litigation, was in the news again today.

Kilmarnock, the Scottish League champion, posted its first victory in the Second Section of the International Soccer League tournament last night by turning back West Bromwich Albion of England, 2-0, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 7 -- In view of the great popularity of the Bertolt Brech-Kurt Weill "Die Dreigroschenoper," better known in the United States as "The Three-penny Opera," it is surprising that "Mahagonny" by the same collaborators is all but unknown here.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Exports declined 4 per cent in May from April, but remained well above the level of May a year ago, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Paramount Building, the 38-year-old landmark on Times Square, will soon be on the market again.
A 21-year-old Brooklyn man released from jail two days ago was charged yesterday with having beaten an elderly invalid woman. He was captured at rifle-point in a fight with a truck driver.
ATLANTA, July 7 -- The Rev. Ralph D. Abernathy termed the arrest of Mr. Reese a segregationist attempt to "divide and conquer."
LONDON, July 7 -- Prime Minister Wilson and his advisers decided today to brush off their three embarrassing defeats in the House of Commons early today.

THE greatest veteran on the international bridge scene is undoubtedly Maurice Harrison Gray of Great Britain, who played as well as ever, and that is very well indeed, in the recent world championships in Buenos Aires.
" Sane Toys for Healthy Kids" is the theme for the 1965 advertising campaign of the Lionel Toy Corporation.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 7 (UPI) -- A Navy helicopter plunged into the St. Johns River here today, killing three men, one a midshipman at the Naval Academy.
KANSAS CITY, July 7 (UPI) -- Johnny Miller, with late-inning relief help from Stu Miller, gained a 1-0 victory for the Baltimore Orioles over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 8 -- Communist troops have overrun another district capital in Kontum Province and ambushed South Vietnamese troops sent as reinforcements.
Conservationists, local officials and eight young members of the Junior Audubon Society opened the city's newest park yesterday -- 70 acres of hilly oak and hickory woodland.
