NEW JERSEY has settled on its 1965 hunting schedule with little change from last year's rules and laws.

Controller Abraham D. Beame and Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor, announced candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination, have been consulting on forming a slate on which both would be represented.
The British pound advanced yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

BALTIMORE, July 7 -- Spiritual descendants of Martin Luther and Jesuit sons of Ignatius Loyola, the Protestant and Roman Catholic giants of the Reformation, completed two days of rigorous theological discussions here today. They will meet again next February.

An effort spearheaded by Paul R. Screvane, President of the City Council, will be made at a World's Fair executive committee meeting today to cut the admission price to the fair during the evening hours.

Along the river where the big ships come and go it was a day that depicted the sad plight of the American merchant marine. The ships were moving yesterday all right, but they were mostly foreign. The France and the Statendam came in, along with the Castel Felice.
ALBANY, July 7 -- The State Public Works Department released today its proposal for the route of a nine-mile stretch of the new Lower Hudson Expressway.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 7 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins scored their seventh straight victory tonight, beating the Boston Red Sox 5-2, behind Johnny Klippstein's relief pitching and Bernie Allen's hitting that accounted for three runs batted in.

Litton Industries, Inc., a producer of office equipment and defense products, announced yesterday a series of personnel changes involving its Amecom, McKiernan-Terry Marine and Kimball Systems divisions.

Tickets for the Array-Notre Dame football game at Shea Stadium on Saturday night, Oct. 9, wil[ be avaiIable to persons who buy season tickets for the cadets' five home games in Michie Stadium at West Point thi's fall.
Organized labor in New York agreed yesterday to give more money and manpower to the campaign to organize taxicab workers into a new union.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara administered the oath of office today to Stanley R. Resor as Secretary of tile Army.
The Interestate Commerce Commission said yesterday it would analyze various types of New Haven railroad passenger service to obtain a cost breakdown on commuter and through service.
DETROIT, July 7 -- The New York Yankees got out from behind that eight ball long enough tonight to snap a two-game losing streak by defeating the Detroit Tigers, 4-3.

The increasing numbers of corporation executives who relocate in New York City for long training peroods or for permanent reassignment has led Pease Elliman to set up a special department to help personnel directors find apartments for their companies' employes.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 7 -- Nassau County was urged by its Charter Revision Commission today to increase the membership of the Board of Supervisors and to substitute a one-man, one-vote system for the weighted voting used now.
Soybeans and pork bellies were the centers of attention in commodity markets yesterday, when they showed some interesting price rises.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The submission by Congress to the states of the constitutional amendment to assure continuity in the capable exercise of the "powers and duties" of the Presidency was final recognition of a peril which has existed for 176 years.
DETROIT, July 7 -- General Motors announced today that six safety items would be standard equipment on all its 1966 model passenger cars.

Beckman Instruments, Inc., is planning to acquire Industrial Instruments, Inc., of Cedar Grove, N.J., a manufacturer of precision measuring and control instrumentation, for stock valued at $5.7 million.

SELMA, Ala., July 7 (UPI) -- The Rev. F.D. Reese of the Ebeneezer Baptist Church, an integration leader charged with embezzling civil rights funds, was released from jail today to the shouts and cheers of a group of his followers.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that its first-half operations set a record for net operating earnings and as of June 30 it had established new highs in assets, deposits and loans.

The United States Treasury's report at the end of the 1965 fiscal year indicates that despite the income-tax cuts last year, total Treasury cash receipts actually increased by $4 billion over fiscal 1964. Moreover, the difference between Government cash payments and receipts declined to under a billion dollars during the period July 1, 1964-June 30, 1965, in contrast to the $2.4 billion deficit of the previous year.

Edward C. Keefe, executive vice president of the Oklahoma Independent College Foundation in Oklahoma City, was elected president of Kiwanis International at yesterday's session of the organization's 50th anniversary convention in Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, July 7 (AP) -- Fourteen nations have agreed to try to curb the Slaughter of whales, the International Whaling Commission said today.
BUENOS AIRES, July 7 -- The United States Embassy in Santiago has assured the Government of Chile that a study into the "potential for internal war" in Latin-American countries will be called off.
The appointment of Alexander E. Fox as deputy superintendent of the New York State Insurance Department was announced yesterday by Henry Root Stern Jr., State Superintendent.
I read with interest your July 2 editorial "City Democrats in Trouble."
The Amerace Corporation lifted sales and earnings in the 24 weeks ended June 20 to new records, John T. Whitely, president, reported yesterday.
The Reform Democratic movement voted early today to endorse Representative William F. Ryan for Mayor.
Montgomery Ward Co.'s registration yesterday of $150 million of debentures depressed prices of many recently offered corporate bonds 1/8-point.
Project Head Start, a $5,642,357 program for the preschool children of the poor, was having trouble yesterday enrolling its quota of 26,000 children.

Purchase of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, long billed as "the greatest show on earth," is being considered by American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and the Madison Square Garden Corporation.
National Airlines announced yesterday that it had obtained several favorable revisions to a $70 million bank loan agreement. So far the airline has borrowed $53 million.

COLONEL FAIRFAX, that condemned sorcerer with a power over women, gained his freedom again from the Tower of London, in scarlet doublet and good tenor voice, as the American Savoyards last night prolonged their summer run by adding "The Yeomen of the Guard" to their repertory at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street.

DR. BRUNO SCHMIDT of Homer, N.Y., who once almost forfeited a tournament game because he had to leave to attend to a birth, found the time last month to clinch the New York State amateur championship.
Pueblo Supermarkets, Inc., which operates 12 food stores in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, may soon acquire H.C. Bohack Co., which has 194 supermarkets.
Industrial film-making techniques are, in many instances, as advanced as those of such renowned feature film directors as Fellini, Resnais and Antonioni.

Earle W. Webb, former president and chairman of the Ethyl Corporation, died yesterday in Baden-Baden, Germany, while on a vacation. He was 82 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn. and Palm Beach, Fla.

CINCINNATI, July 7 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Reds regained first place in the National League tonight by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-6, on Leo Cardenas's two-out home run off Bob Miller in the ninth inning.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes took the side of the City Planning Commission yesterday in urging the construction of a Cross-Brooklyn Expressway instead of the Bushwick Expressway proposed by Robert Moses.

SPRINGFIELD, Ore., July 7 (UPI) -- A housewife and her 12-year-old son were feared today to have been abducted by two ex-convicts, suspected of robbing a bank and killing a deputy sheriff several hours before.

Former Senator Kenneth B. Keating, trustee in reorganization for the Yale Express System, Inc., named Kenneth T. Sheehy as general manager and chief executive officer of the company. Mr. Sheehy, a vice president and director of the Denver Chicago Trucking Company, will be directly responsible to Mr. Keating.

The Appellate Division rejected yesterday an effort by Representative Adam Clayton Powell to prevent an examination of his Congressional account to see if there were any grounds for criminal prosecution.

Larry Jackson need only show up as the starting pitcher against the Mets and it seems the result is a foregone conclusion. He did as expected yesterday, pitching most of the way as the Cubs gained an 8-3 victory over the Mets before 33,594 persons (17,916 paid) at Shea Stadium.
The Kings County Trust Company and the Lafayette National Bank, both of Brooklyn, plan to merge.

The concept of Gwen Verdon's next musical, "Sweet Charity," has been altered. It will be drawn entirely from the Federico Fellini film, "Nights of Cabiria," with the locale switched from Rome to Broadway.
" THIS isn't a business with me," said Col. Geoffrey Alexander Baron Langford. "It's a hobby, and I aim to keep it as such."
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 7 -- Attorney General Charles Njonjo today described an attempt to take over the headquarters of the Kenya African National Union yesterday as "abortive coup d'etat."

As a registered New York City Democrat who has voted for Democratic party candidates about 80 per cent of the time, I read William Buckley's letter of July 1 to you with great interest. I also had read your very poor editorial [June 25] to which Mr. Buckley referred.

MOSCOW, July 7 (AP) -- Pravda, the Communist party organ, took a rare step in this country today and published the photographs of three wanted men. It appealed to the Soviet public to help track them down.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday that children in public schools could not recite nursery prayers during school time.
Representative John V. Lindsay, the Republican Liberal candidate for Mayor, is finding New York to be a pocket of poverty -- for campaign funds.

It's great when the boss provides -- or contributes to -- a pension plan, whether he be inspired by social conscience, the persuasive powers of labor leaders or the need to offer employment incentives.
" The handbag industry has been protesting the excise tax for years and now that it has been lifted, the industry owes it to itself and its customers to raise its sights."

SOUTHPORT, England, July 7 -- It seemed like old times With the magic of his putter, Tony Lema, the defending champion, scored a 68 today to lead a field of 130 in the 94th British Open at Royal Birkdale.

TOKYO, July 7 -- The Bank of Japan announced today that it had granted a special loan of 1 billion yen ($2,777,800) to the Oi Securities Company of Osaka, Japan's fifth largest in the field. The loan is being made through commercial banks.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Government now has enough preliminary figures to convince officials that there was a surplus in the balance of international payments in the second quarter of this year -- the first in nearly eight years.

PEKING, July 7 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communists at-two counts today, poking fun at the defeat of pro-Soviet Communists in the Japanese elections and criticizing Moscow's welcome to President Tito of Yugoslavia on his recent visit.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 7 -- The school board of Berkeley, site of the University of California, voted 3 to 1 last night to revive old-fashioned spanking in the grammar schools.

The Algerian analogy to the Vietnam dilemma which Dr. John Frenster so admirably presented in his letter published June 20 concludes with these words: ". . . de Gaulle . . . has found that a national consensus can only be secured by a willingness to spend an initial popularity for what all humanity knows to be needed."

The Allegheny Power System has outlined a construction program that calls for the outlay of $224 million over the next four years, ending in 1968, J. Lee Rice Jr., president, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
MILWAUKEE, July 7 (UPI) -- Rico Carty hammered out three hits, including a scoring single and a home run, to lead the Milwaukee Braves to a 5-2 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

The defense of the America's Cup against Australia's challenge in 1967 gained impetus yesterday with the information that a three-man New York Yacht Club syndicate had been formed to finance the design and building of a new 12-Meter yacht.

Air Canada, an airline owned by the Canadian Government, has ordered two DC-8 jetliners from the Douglas Aircraft Company. The planes, which cost $8 million each and seat 139 passengers, are to be delivered in the spring of 1966.
BUENOS AIRES, July 7 (AP) -- Juan Carlos Pugliese, the Economy Minister, predicted today that out-of-court settlements with foreign oil companies would be completed this month.

SAIGON, Thursday, July 8 (AP) -- One United States Air Force F-105 jet fighter-bomber was downed over North Vietnam yesterday, and the pilot was apparently captured after bailing out, a United States spokesman reported today.

The annual Emmy controversy is on again. The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences was told yesterday by Metromedia, Inc., that an apparent nominating error had been what Metromedia considered "disgraceful."

FRANKFURT, Germany, July 7 -- The hot contest for the German natural gas market, which erupted a year ago and contributed to the ill feeling between the West German oil industry and the international oil companies, appears to have been amicably settled.

Prices were mixed at the close after trending higher during most of the trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Profittaking reduced earlier advances before the day ended but the list as a whole still showed more gains than declines.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor ruled today that the States Steamship Company could increase from 13 to 26 a year the number of calls its vessels could make at Hawaii in connection with its California-Far East cargo service.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -Prudential Lines, Inc., disclosed plans today for the construction of 16 ships that would carry fully loaded lighters to cargo unloading areas.

The Rockefeller veto of legislation which would have curtailed the powers of the Waterfront Commission, as well as the failure of the New Jersey Legislature to act favorably upon the same proposal, indicates a perpetuation of the myth that the waterfront is a jungle inhabited by criminals of all sorts and that nothing has been accomplished by the Commission since 1953.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Leo D. Welch, chairman and chief executive officer of the Communications Satellite Corporation, announced today he wants to retire from active direction of the company.
Thirty-five young Puerto Ricans left New York by chartered plane yesterday for a musical goodwill tour.
SINCE being named on Sunday as the temporary czar of the city's taxicab industry, Vincent Richard Impellitteri, who does not own a car, has, as usual, made several trips here and there by cab.
MADRID, July 7 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco shuffled his Cabinet today in an effort to help the Spanish economy.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz urged Congress today to strike down the barriers that excluded migrant farm workers from the economic protection and the social benefits that workers in other fields have long enjoyed.
LONDON, Thursday, July 8 -- Prime Minister Wilson has sent a junior minister on a secret mission to make personal contact with the Government of North Vietnam, two British newspapers reported today.

ATLANTA, July 7 -- Austin T. Walden, who had led Negroes in legal battles for equality in the Deep South for half a century, was buried today in ceremonies attended by a large part of Atlanta's white and Negro leadership.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The recent Improvement in United States payments should not lead to any letup in the efforts to wipe out the deficit, Federal Reserve Chairman William McChesney Martin Jr. told a House committee today.

The Senate passed a so-called water pollution control bill on Jan. 28; the House passed a weaker version on April 28. Months have now passed, and both bills still lie in legislative limbo. No conferees have been appointed and no formal action taken to reconcile the differences.
BALTIMORE July 7 -- The Gemini 5 astronauts will chase "the world's ugliest satellite" around the earth for six hours next month to practice rendezvous in space.
BRUSSELS, July 7 -- The six-member Common Market sought today to function as best it could on five cylinders.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The sign on the bus rolling through Washington today said "sight-seeing," but nobody looked out the windows. The faces were turned toward the driver in rapt attention as he described the statues and monuments and vistas of the capital.
What will American Telephone and Telegraph earn in calendar 1965?

WASHINGTON July 7 (UPI) -- Southern opponents of voting rights legislation disclosed today their strategy for attempting to defeat President Johnson's plan for extending the franchise to more Negroes.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Gerald R. Ford, House Republican leader, urged President Johnson today to order "effective air action" against antiaircraft missile sites in North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Pressure was building today for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to move against racial imbalance in the public schools of the North and West.

BONN, July 7 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard and President Giuseppe Saragat of Italy agreed today to back an attempt of the Common Market's Executive Commission to end the dispute that threatens the existence of the European Economic Community.

The High Voltage Engineer-i ing Corporation of Burlington, Mass., announced yesterday that it had been awarded "a far-reaching patent covering a nexv method of generating high voltage direct current electric 'power."
Congressional hearings on the future of the Hudson River have been postponed for two weeks. They were to have been held in Westchester and Putnam Countis tomorrow and Saturday.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- It is a mark of distinction with some conscientious cooks to keep a ledger of meals served in the home. It is a worthwhile diary, a potential source of amusement, reckoning and nostalgia for the years that follow.
OTTAWA, July 7 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson made seven changes in his Liberal Cabinet today following the resignation of Guy Favreau, his controversial Justice Minister.
The stock market continued to drift downward yesterday, as volume dwindled to its lowest level in almost two years.

Project Head Start was an invitation to all the elements in the communities of the nation, under Government leadership with Government assistance, to lend a hand in the war against poverty where it will help the most -- on behalf of the individual child.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Defense Department is undertaking a top-level review of Project Camelot, a controversial multimillion-dollar study of the possibilities for armed revolution in Latin America and other developing areas.

When an independent Israel was only a beckoning vision, Moshe Sharett was its firm, persuasive, resourceful advocate before audiences large and small, official and unofficial. He spent fifteen years as head of the political department of the Zionist Executive, "nursing the unconquerable hope, . . . clutching the inviolable shade." When his vision was realized in 1948 he naturally became his country's first Foreign Minister and later its Premier.
OTTAWA, July 7 -- The Royal Canadian Air Force has adopted the twin-jet Northrop F-5 as its new tactical fighter.

C. Michael Paul, an oilman who used to play the violin, is donating $1 million for a recital hall at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts where young talent will be able to gain the public ear more easily than he could in his youth.

The Weather Bureau disclosed yesterday that some of New York City's polluted air could come from the sea as well as from neighboring communities. But the source of this contamination from the sea has not been determined.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 (UPI) -- An Army veteran of the fighting in Vietnam whose mother said he was refused psychiatric help at a veterans' hospital apparently went berserk tonight and began shooting at passing cars, sheriff's deputies reported.
LONDON, July 7 -- In the decorous precincts of Sotheby Co., the auctioneers, a letter from George Bernard Shaw of the subject of forming a trade union for prostitutes was sold today for $108.
WELCH, W. Va., July 7 -- He lived at the head of the hollow, poor but full of dreams.
James E. Kraus, founder and senior partner of Kraus, Ostreicher Co., certified public accountants, died yesterday morning of a heart attack in Liberty, N.Y., where he was vacationing.

LIMA, Peru, July 7 -- United States aid for economic and social development in Peru is in "no way" affected by the Communist guerrilla activities in the Andean Highlands, Jack Hood Vaughn, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate voted today to provide limited cash Social Security benefits for retired workers at the age of 60 years.

Frank Nadaline Jr., chairman of Fotochrome, Inc., has sold 51,737 shares of the company's common stock in recent months, the American Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday in its latest report on changes in shareholdings of corporate insiders.

In an editorial on June 29 The New York Times deplored mass demonstrations by members of the police force engaged "in a show of strength outside a building where legislation unwelcome to it is under consideration." At the same time you were careful to point out that participation in such a demonstration is an undoubted right."
With this year's auction season behind him, Louis J. Marion, president of Parke-Bernet Galleries, has resigned to form his own appraisal firm.

Mitsui Co., Ltd., one of the world's largest trading companies, announced through its New York office yesterday that it was pooling the resources of 12 companies in the Mitsui group to form Japan's first general consulting and civil engineering concern for construction projects.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee recommended today that the Public Health Service be required to provide adequate hospital services for seamen without regard to budgetary limitations.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 8 Although he was more than a mile away nibbling hay in his stall, Speedy Scot was foremost in the minds of representatives of Britain, Sweden, Italy, France and New Zealand, who met over breakfast this morning to discuss a horse race.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission told broadcasters and advertisers today how to avoid distortion, tampering and deception in the use of audience surveys.
Following the sketches of the incoming and outgoing United States Ambassadors to South Vietnam:

KANSAS CITY, July 8 (UPI) -- Baltimore completed a sweep of a four-game series with Kansas City today, with Wally Bunker pitching the Orioles to a 10-6 victory. The loss was the seventh in succession for the Athletics.

GENERALLY speaking, the announcement did not get the headlines throughout the country that once it would have commanded. If it had happened five years earlier, it would have been sensational news. Yet there still is considerable fascination in the fact that Joe Bellino, one of the superstars of Naval Academy football history, has signed to play pro ball with the Boston Patriots this season.
TOKYO, July 8 (AP) -- Pan American World Airways announced the temporary suspension of its new round-the-world air-cargo service today because of Japan's denial of landing rights.

A Cuban physician is being sought as a witness in a two-state investigation of narcotics and abortion activities. Authorities are trying to learn whether police protection or hoodlum extortion might have been involved.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has elected Robert H. Craft to its Rockefeller Center Advisory Board. Mr. Craft is chairman of the finance committee of the Missouri-Pacific Railroad Corporation.
Under the guidance of the seasoned Johnny Rotz, George D. Widener's Mount Regina scored a 2 1/2-length victory over Jerry Basta's Kisco Gal in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 8 (AP) -- A Canadian Pacific Airlines DC6-B carrying 52 people crashed this afternoon in the rugged Cariboo country about 170 miles northeast of here. Rescue officials at the scene said there were no survivors.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Senate and House conferees on the $3.36 billion foreign aid authorization, still in disagreement, have set a record for time spent in trying to compose differences between the two houses' versions of the bill. Most House negotiators blame the Administration for the prolonged impasse.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Four stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.
The State Supreme Court yesterday rejected a poet's bid to read his works in Washington Square Park without prior approval by the Parks Department.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 8 (UPI) -- Three members will be installed in the National Museum of Racing Hall of Fame on Aug. 9.
Mayor Wagner has given orders to tap the Hudson River to supplement the city's dwindling water supply.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Sometime in 1967, a Gemini astronaut may clip an aluminum coupon from an orbiting Pegasus micrometeoroid satellite and return it to earth.
LONDON, July 9 -- Sir Laurence Olivier announced today that he would resign as director of the Chichester Festival Theater, effective next Christmas.
TRENTON, July 8 (AP) -- State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, accused the Hughes administration today of setting the Round Valley Reservoir project back three years.

Otis Chandler, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, has been named to the advisory board of the American Press Institute of Columbia University. Dr. Grayson Kirk, president' of the university announced yesterday that .Mr. Chandler would fill the. remaining two years in the terra of Nick ,B. Williams; editor of The Los Angeles Times, who has resigned from the advisory board.
BOGALUSA, La., July 8 -- A Negro shot and seriously wounded a white man who attacked him today during a civil rights march on a downtown street.
The British pound fell yesterday in light trading on foreign exchange markets here.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 8 (Comtelburo) -- The Colombian Government has imposed strict controls to prevent the outflow of money.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 8 -- Forbidden by his bishop to speak, write or wear his cassock in public, the Rev. Martin Amaya Martinez led a large protest demonstration in Tunja, 80 miles northeast of Bogota, last night.

Two men who beat a painting executive with tire irons will be brought here from Sing Sing Prison next week for questioning before the grand jury that is investigating the city's paint contracts scandal.
The use of multiple corporations by taxicab companies to cut their liability in accident lawsuits was condemned yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate six new ambassadors in Africa and the Middle East. The list includes two New Yorkers, one of them a Negro.
A three-year program to provide opportunities for Southern journalists to undertake advanced study will be financed by a grant of, $700,000 announced here yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 8 (UPI) -- Six "rich kids," including the son a former president of the Oklahoma Bar Association, were charged today with grabbing a 15-year-old girl off the street, driving to a farm field and raping her.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department estimated today that 14,205,000 acres were planted in cotton this year. This was 4 per cent less than last year.

ROME, July 8 (AP) -- Reports from Hungary of severe prison terms given seven Hungarian Roman Catholic priests on charges of activities against the Budapest Communist regime have caused "great surprise and grief" here, Vatican sources said today.
The daily net free reserve position of New York City banks fell to its lowest level in more than five years in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
MIAMI, July 8 -- A dispute over the construction of a school suburban Negro community here threatened today to erupt into a racial demonstration.
ALBANY, July 8 -- Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill that would have extended the $1.25 an hour minimum wage to the 126,00 domestic workers in the state.
Prices were mixed in quiet trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Insurance shares and gold mining issues were the chief gainers.

Loud commercials that jolt the television viewer out of his electronic euphoria will be officially frowned upon by the Federal Communications Commission in a statement of policy to be issued either today or next week.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 8 (UPI) -- Dominican rebel leaders met privately today for more than five hours in what appeared to be a significant step toward a solution of the 11-week-old political crisis.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 8 -- Morton H. Engel's 41-foot yawl, Huntress was declared winner of the Marblehead-Halifax race today.
The Board of Education, which has been without a president for more than a week, announced yesterday the election of Lloyd K. Garrison to fill the post.
Copper futures presented a paradox yesterday for their followers to interpret. The London market showed some declines; the market here moved upward. Often the two moved in the same direction.

It is my firm belief that The New York Times, because of its failure to take into consideration its unique place in the newspaper world, frequently takes a position which is against the national interest.
A new rule aimed at preventing jetliners from skidding off the ends of rain-soaked runways will be placed in effect Jan. 15 by the Federal Aviation Agency.

The First National City Bank, the largest bank in the city, reported yesterday that it had achieved record first-half earnings of $1.70 a share. This compared with earnings of $1.57 a share for the period last year.

A WOMAN toured the new art gallery in Sloane's furniture store recently and then inquired plaintively of the gallery's director, an informed and discerning man in his field, "Don't you have any nice bedroom pictures?" He had just been asked by another customer, "Don't you have any basic things! You know, little nothings in art?"
Henry T. Kramer has been appointed president of L'Aiglon Apparel, Inc., the company announced yesterday, following a board meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended July 3 was considerably ahead of the corresponding week of 1964. The increase was attributed mainly to the fact that the Independence Day holiday fell on a Saturday in 1964.

The new building code proposed for the city would bring the architecture of the 20th century to New York. It could be the source of vastly improved architectural standards, or a new round of abuses by speculative builders.

MILWAUKEE, July 8 (UPI) -- Frank Bolling singled home Mike de la Hoz with the winning run in the 12th inning today to offset a 6-for-6 performance by Joe Morgan and give the Milwaukee Braves a 9-8 victory over the Houston Astros.
The nation's electric power production rose 9.3 per cent in the week ended July 3 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

President Johnson has made a surprising but logical move in sending Henry Cabot Lodge back to Saigon as Ambassador. While Mr. Lodge is doing his best, as he obviously will, to carry out the Johnson policies in Vietnam, some of his fellow-Republicans in Congress have made it clear that they will be doing their best to embarrass and harass the President in his efforts to prevent the war from escalating too dangerously.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- An outfield collision on a routine lily ball with two out in the fifth today led to three Chicago runs and a 3-2 White Sox triumph over the Cleveland Indians.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler had his first meeting today with the new Treasury Consultative Committee of the Business Council.

PARIS -- When General de Gaulle talks of "Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals," he seems to mean what this implies politically as well as geographically. Geographers conventionally fix the frontier between Europe and Asia along the Ural range, but for de Gaulle this border also apparently has another significance.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- The concept of "righteous civil disobedience" to achieve civil rights or other goals is "incompatible with the American legal system and society," an American Bar Association official contends.
ALBANY, July 8 -- Frank C. Moore has resigned as chairman of the State University's board of trustees after 11 years in the post, several of them marked by controversy.
John H. Breck Jr., whose father founded the world's largest manufacturer of shampoos, John H. Breck, Inc., became one of the 1,366 members of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
Roberto Victor Duke had his first helicopter ride yesterday -- 21 hours after he was born aboard the cruise liner Victoria 240 miles off Cape Hatteras.
PARIS, June 8 -- The Rothschilds won a part victory today in their judicial action against a new book about the Jews of France.
A Manhattan grand jury indicted three alleged numbers bankers yesterday for conspiracy to bribe policemen.
A small-time club fighter, 26-year-old Lenny Mangiapane, knifed a man and was shot by his victim in a climax to a family feud, the police in Queens reported early yesterday.
Following in the shadow of the Big Board, trading on the American Stock Exchange moved at a brisker pace yesterday. Gains easily outnumbered losses.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 9 -- United States paratroop forces reported yesterday that they had inflicted more than 100 casualties on Vietcong soldiers during the first three days of an allied offensive in Zone D.

Indicated net income of the Puritan Fashions Corporation rose to $603,385, equal to 51 cents a share, in the second fiscal quarter from $365,185, or 31 cents a share, in the corresponding 1964 quarter, it was reported yesterday. Sales in the period ended May 29 increased to $20,741,807 from $11,376,812 a year earlier.
PITTSBURGH, July 8 (AP) -- Two-run doubles by Ron Fairly and Jim Lefebvre keyed a five-run sixth-inning outburst that carried the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 9-4 victory over Pittsburgh tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Johnson has been getting a bad press lately. George Reedy is leaving his job as White House press secretary. Not many reporters in Washing-ington thought Mr. Reedy was effective in that job.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 8 -- Jim Rogers and Dan Hogan, two Yale Blues, carried off top honors today in the Anderson Memorial golf tourney, which is following a new format.

A three-man delegation from the Banco dela Republica, Uruguay's central bank, has held what one source called "a preliminary discussion" with commercial banks here on the subject of negotiating some overdue loans, and further discussions have been scheduled for next week.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 8 -- President Raul Leoni signed today the controversial Insurance Bill that requires foreign insurers to become local corporations with 51 per cent Venezuelan capital. The bill was passed in both Houses of Congress last week and now becomes law.

David F. Dixon, the president of a phantom team called the New Orleans Football Club, Inc., confirmed a report yesterday that he intended to pursue a National Football League franchise that might cost as much as $9 million.
A THREE - OVER - THREE response, say three spades when partner has opened with three diamonds, may be made for three different reasons.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Crude oil runs to stills averaged 9,115,000 barrels daily during the week ended Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported today. This compared with 9,097,000 barrels daily in the previous week and 8,959,000 barrels daily a year before.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Johnson warned a group of lawmakers today that he might hold Congress in session until November to pass his entire legislative program for the session.
Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., and the Eastman Kodak Company unveiled jointly yesterday a new concept in flash photography.
JERICHO, L.I., July 8 -- The second midsummer dinner dance for the benefit of the Mental Health Association of Nassau County will be held at the Meaddowbrook Club on July 17.

A public offering of $50 million of Burlington Industries, Inc., debentures priced to yield 4.80 per cent was placed on the market yesterday, and was estimated to be 95 per cent sold by late afternoon.
The average American driver, whom a nationally televised test proved to be only a fair performer behind the wheel of the family car, will get another chance to improve his rating on Monday, Aug. 30.
PARIS, July 8 -- U Thant declared here today that he had "precise ideas" on what should be done by the interested powers to end the war in Vietnam.

LONDON, July 8 -- The orchestra, splendid in scarlet coats, softly played "Dancing in the Dark." Queen Elizabeth II laid a sword lightly across the shoulders of a kneeling man in a morning coat and striped trousers, and he arose a 'knight.

NEWPORT, R.L, July 8 -- Rodney Laver of Australia lost to Luis Ayala of Chile today in a stunning reversal on the opening day of the first professional round-robin tournament to be held on the turf of the Newport , Casino, the home of the national Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame.
Municipal bond underwriters, encouraged by the acceptance of the $120 million California issue that sold Wednesday, appeared a little more aggressive in bidding yesterday.

DETROIT, July 8 -- Pete Mikkelsen, who had pitched in 69 games for the New York Yankees without starting one, started one tonight. But he lost it when Mickey Lolich of the Detroit Tigers overpowered the Yankees, 6-1, on just two days of rest.

The Mets traded Frank Lary to a contending team for the second time in less than a year, sending the right-handed pitcher yesterday to the Chicago White Sox for a player to be named later. To fill the vacancy, the Mets recalled Gordon Richardson, a left-handed pitcher, from Buffalo.

SYDNEY, Australia -- On July 12, stock brokers in Australia will apply a new flat rate of charges that will decrease commissions for certain kinds of stock transactions and increase them somewhat for others.
Robert Moses defeated a determined final effort yesterday to cut the admission price to the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Defense Department canceled today its controversial Camelot project, a $4 million program to study the possibility of insurgency in Latin-American countries and other developing nations.

OAKDALE, L.I., July 8 -- Chris Andon and his Westhampton Yacht Squadron crew today led the Eastern area qualifiers into the finals of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior championship.
A television camera and a computer will be used, in a new system of automatic license-plate identification, to catch car thieves or criminals fleeing from the scene of a crime.
BONN, July 8 -- The West German Government has asked its Western Allies to surrender their veto power over the application of West German treaties to West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, July g (UPI) -- The Defense Department announced today that 90 nuclear Mace-A missiles would be pulled out of West Germany by the end of June, 1966. Their Iron Curtain targets will be assigned to other weapons, including Pershing ballistic missiles.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company denied yesterday that it had attempted to conceal a major Canadian ore find so that 13 officers, directors and other insiders could capitalize on the discovery in the stock market.

SANTEE, Calif., July 8 -- A line of happy, clamoring children at the gate of a public swimming pool here symbolizes what experts regard as a breakthrough in the nation's battle against its increasingly over-taxed water supplies.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 8 -- A Darien couple were fined $100 each today for having served liquor to minors at a 1964 debutante party after which a 19-year-old college student was killed in a car accident.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Major amendments to the Administration's Social Security-medicare bill were rejected today as the Senate moved at a slackened pace toward passage of the measure.
New York City has announced plans to borrow $175.05 million on July 20 through a competitive sale of two bond issues.
Operations of the Stanley Warner Corporation for the quarter and the nine months ended May 29 resulted in record profits, S.H. Fabian, president of the diversified company, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 8 (UPI) -- More civil rights demonstrators sprawled in the street today to protest the policies of Chicago's School Superintendent, Benjamin C. Willis.

BALTIMORE, July 8 -- The launching of the largest cargo barge ever built in this country -- a 420-foot, 19,000-ton craft -- took place here today at the Sparrows Point shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- After a news conference last year, President Johnson was chatting in his office with some lingering reporters. In his best story-telling style, the President was recalling a tour he once made with Jack Dempsey to sell Government bonds in World War II.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 8 -- In a season that has produced more top-flight 2-year-old pacers than have been seen in recent years, Mrs. Helen R. Buck's Overcall, a half-brother to the great Overtrick, today stamped himself as the best of the juvenile lot.

A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner has asserted that New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 "engaged in unfair labor practice" in a long-pending dispute over a work assignment at The New York Times.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 (AP) -- The trustees of the Ohio State University refused today to abandon the school's rule limiting appearances by controversial speakers.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- Retail sales rose to about $5.8 billion last week, up about 5 per cent from the preceding week's $5.5 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

SAIGON, July 8 (AP) -- In a section of the Mekong delta 70 miles southwest of Saigon, Vietnamese Government troops have killed 78 Vietcong guerrillas and captured seven in four days, a United States spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Representative John V. Lindsay's campaign for Mayor of New York was reported today to have been bolstered by fund-raising pledges totaling $1,250,000.

Two men were arrested yesterday on charges of selling 6,000 one-ounce bottles of erstaz Chanel No. 5, each containing 11 cents worth of domestic perfume, for $15 apiece. The genuine article costs $25.

Dr. Glueck when he was director of the American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem, turned up traces of the Nabateans, a people with great skill in water storage who inhabited desert lands in what is now Jordan 15 centuries ago.

Eleven American debutantes will be presented at the second American-Madrid Debutante Ball at the Palace of Bavaria and Georgia in Madrid next Thursday. The event will be the highlight of a month's tour of Europe led by Mary-Stuart Montague Price, Washington social consultant.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Archbishop Patrick A. O'Boyle said today that one of his priests who had baptized Luci Johnson as a Roman Catholic had not implied that her earlier baptism in the Episcopal church was invalid.

Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday its best second quarter and first half in history. An R.C.A. report showed new highs in virtually every phase of operations, including new sales records for a single month, quarter and half-year. The record for one month was established in June.
Representative John V. Lindsay's list of prospective Democratic running mates for Controller was narrowed slightly last night when Arthur Levitt Jr. announced that he would not be a candidate.

SOUTHPORT, England, July 8 -- The defending champion, Tony Lema, and the Australian beanpole, Bruce Devlin, today shared the lead with 140's halfway through the British Open over the sand dunes at Royal Birkdale. Fifty golfers survived the cut at 149 and will play the final two rounds tomorrow.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 8 -- California's top appointive official, his wife and their baby daughter vanished early today. Gov. Edmund G. Brown said he believed they were kidnapped by two armed Oregon ex-convicts fleeing from murder, bank robbery and kidnapping charges.
PARIS, July 8 (AP) -- Zoltan Nemere of Hungary won the men's individual epee title in the world fencing championships tonight.

The Louisville Title Insurance Company of New York has opened offices at 350 Old Country Road in Mineola, L.I. The new company was licensed by the New York State Department of Insurance on June 17. It will specialize in title insurance services for the banking, building and real estate fields.
Fairchild Hiller Corporation has proposed the acquisition of Republic Aviation Corporation's operating assets, according to a joint announcement Yesterday by the two companies.
LONDON, July 8 -- member of the gang that staged Britain's 'great train robbery nearly two years ago escaped from prison 'today.
MOSCOW, July 8 -- The Soviet Government has worked out a plan for loosening the centralized planning controls over the machine-building industry, one of the key sectors of the economy.
Stock prices rallied in late trading yesterday, and sharp gains were registered by many issues on rising volume.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 8 (UPI) -- Three thousand residents fled their home early today when fire threatened to touch off more than a ton of explosives at a rocket fuel plant.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- House Republican leaders fought doggedly in the cloakroom today to hold together the Republican-Southern Democratic coalition they need to pass their substitute for the Administration's voting rights bill.

Robert M. Fuoss, 52 years old is resigning as a senior editor of Reader's Digest and returning to Federated Department Stores, Inc., where he has been elected to the newly established post of executive vice president.
The Basic Products Corporation announced yesterday in Milwaukee the appointment of Frank H. Roby as chief executive officer.
Frank Sinatra and Count Basic opened the sixth Forest Hills Music Festival in Queens last night, and it was a gasser.

Every weekday at 10:30 A.M. 20 or more men, some in suitcoats, some in shirtsleeves, amble through swinging doors of the New York Mercantile Exchange ate 6 Harrison Street to the corner reserved for trading in spot eggs, or eggs for immediate delivery.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 8 -- An international convention completed and opened for signature here today establishes as a new principle of international law the right of landlocked countries to have access to the sea.
DANANG, South Vietnam, July 8 -- In a new kind of war, the powerful United State Marine forces that like to think of themselves as a rushing torrent are instead an "inkstain."
A man accused of shooting a woman bookkeeper and robbing a Westchester restaurant was captured yesterday after a struggle near Times Square.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -- Richie Allen hit the first grand-slam homer of his major league career tonight as he led the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-2 victory over San Francisco and a split of their double-header.

FORT SMITH, Northwest Territories, June 29 -- A new federal commission visited here a few days ago in search of fresh answers to an old question: What should Canada do about her Northwest Territories?
