Gareth Martinis denied denied in supreme Court yesterday that he was intoxicated when he became involved in a three-car collision in which five persons were killed and a sixth critically injured.
The Palace Theater, once a leading vaudeville house, now showing films, has been sold and will be converted into a legitimate theater.
A man accused of shooting a woman bookkeeper and robbing a Westchester restaurant was captured yesterday after a struggle near Times Square.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -- Richie Allen hit the first grand-slam homer of his major league career tonight as he led the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-2 victory over San Francisco and a split of their double-header.
BRUSSELS, July 8 -- A French official attended a meeting here today of a low-level committee of the Common Market. This suggested that France's boycott was not total.
PARIS, July 8 -- High-ranking French officials appeared hopeful today that a substantial easing of the Common Market crisis might be brought about next week, much sooner than previously expected.

CENTERVILLE, Mass., July 8 -- Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean emeritus of Barnard College, the women's branch of Columbia University, died last night at the age of 87. She had been in a nursing home here for the last year.
LIMA, Peru, July 8 -- Subversion by Communist guerrillas is posing a political problem for President Fernando Belaunde Terry's progressive, social minded administration.
Following are highlights of the proposed City Building Code and some of the changes in construction methods and materials that would result:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Paul Mantz, a 61-year-old aviation pioneer and legendary movie stunt pilot, was killed in an airplane crash this morning in Yuma, Ariz. As three motion picture cameras ground away, he met his death when the plane he was flying hit a small sand dune, overturned and disintegrated.

KIAMESHA LAKE, New York, July 8 -- Jimmy Demaret, the host professional, teamed with Sonny Abrams and Bernie Libby of Washington and Joe Grubbs of nearby Monticello to capture top honors in the net best-ball of foursome competition today as the first Concord invitation golf tournament started.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Congress sent to the White House today a bill designed to curtail illicit traffic in goof balls and pep pills.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Johnson nominated Henry Cabot Lodge today to resume the position of Ambassador to South Vietnam, in place of Maxwell D. Taylor.

MILFORD, Pa., July 8 -- Just before noon the deputy Delaware river master, Robert E. Fish, picked up the telephone in his office on Broad Street and gave the order that New York City must start releasing 200 million gallons of water a day from its Pepacton and Neversink Reservoirs.

The Chromalloy Corporation, whose principal business is metal processing and fabricating, is further diversifying its activities through the acquisition of Color-Craft Products, Inc., Richard P. Seelig, president of Chromalloy, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- George E. Reedy, President Johnson's press secretary, began an indefinite leave of absence today for treatment of a painful foot ailment.

LONDON, July 8 -- London has "Swan Lake" somewhat as it has Big Ben; it is always there. The latest production, new, lavish and rather terrible was presented tonight by the Festival Ballet at the New Victoria Theater.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 8 -- President Joseph Kasavubu and Premier Moise Tshome of the Congo met for half an hour today in an attempt to break a deadlock following a decision by Mr. Kasavubu that Minister of the Interior Godefroid Munongo must resign.

The bulk of Bernard M. Baruch's multimillion-dollar estate will be given in grants and loans to students attending City College's Baruch School of Business and Public Administration, it was disclosed yesterday.

The third housing project for the elderly to be built by the Yonkers Housing Authority will be started soon on two sites. One sits is on Central Park Avenue south of Tuckaheo Road and the other on Seymour Street at Ashburton Avenue.

NAHA, Okinawa, July 8 -- A 33-year-old Army doctor from Plainfield, N.J., pleaded not guilty at a general court-martial today to charges including the feigning of mental illness while serving in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the rates shown:

District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor pulled out of the five-way battle for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday. He will seek the Democratic nomination for City Council President and support Controller Abraham D. Beame's race for the mayoral nomination.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Sargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, announced today that he had appointed Robert T. Freeman, a 47-year old Negro, to one of the five top positions in the corps.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation today announced the selection of a 310-acre site near Brewster, Wash., for construction of a station.
Federal mediation will resume today in the 23-day-old maritime strike, bringing disputing engineers and employers together for the first time in more than a week.
PARIS, July 8 -- A high United States official painted today a generally pessimistic picture of the outlook for easing the deficit in the United States' international payments.

Frank Wille, State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that he had formed a 12-man committee to conduct "a comprehensive and basic reappraisal" of the law, regulations and supervisory concepts that govern the operations of state-chartered commercial banks.
Prices improved on the London Stock Exchange yesterday with early gains in most sections extended in late trading.

SALISBURY, Conn., July 9 -- Leslie Woods of Pebble Beach, Calif., piloted Thoughtful to the junior working hunter championship in the Lakeville horse show tonight. It was the first time Miss Woods had ridden the mount in competition.
MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP) -- Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., defeated Tom Edlefson in the quarter-final round of the Western open tennis tournament today, 6-2,9-7.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- An official of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation confirmed today that the agency was considering a proposal to revive the San Francisco National Bank.

The Regional Plan Association, spurred by a victory of a civic group in Philadelphia, has renewed its pleas that a thorough study be made of the feasibility of building the Lower Manhattan Expressway below street level.

Literary critics today are tough-minded for fear of being mistaken for mere appreciators. J.B. Broadbent, author of an influential work on Milton's "Paradise Lost," is representative in his no-nonsense study of attitudes toward love as reflected and shaped by poets from 12th-century Provence to Yeats.

A one-eyed cat named Joey, the pet in Jilly's saloon at 256 West 52d Street, usually relaxes quietly at the bar, rarely drinks anything stronger than Dubonnet and does not often run into other cats -- except when Frank Sinatra is in town.
The police were searching yesterday as far south as Florida for an unlicensed Cuban physician who is wanted for questioning in New York and New Jersey about an alleged abortion ring.

GENEVA, July 9 -- Raul Prebisch, Secretary General of the new United Nations Trade and Development Conference, said today it was the responsibility of the governments to avoid duplication of effort by the conference and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
ALBANY, July 9 -- New York State's highest court divided 4 to 3 today in ordering the cancellation of a special legislative election for November that had been ordered by a Federal court.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A pharmaceutical house received five patents this week for its Robot Chemist, a machine that is expected to take over routine clinical testing in hospitals. The automatic device is about the size of three portable phonographs.
ATHENS, Saturday, July 10 (Reuters) -- Eighteen-year-old Queen Anne-Marie of Greece gave birth to a girl at the royal castle of Mon Repos, on the Ionian island of Corfu, early today.

TORONTO, July 9 -- Shares of the British Mortgage and Trust Company, an 88-year-old concern suffered today their sharpest drop of a four-week decline, despite an announcement last night that one of Canada's biggest uranium mining concerns was negotiating to take control.
SAIGON, South Vietnam July 9 -- At least five American servicemen were killed and 11 United States marines were wounded today when Vietcong guerrillas attacked a Government navy base at Chulai.

Four men were arrested yesterday and Thursday by agents from the Internal Revenue Service and Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick's confidential squad on charges of violating the Federal gambling tax law.

A major stalemate has arisen between Senate and House conferees on this year's $3.36 billion foreign-aid authorization bill. Nine meetings in seven days have proved inadequate to iron out differences between the two versions.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., July 9 (UPI) -- A small college here has been accused by state education officials of selling diplomas.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 (UPI) -- Bob Veale, a Pittsburgh Pirate left-hander who was named to the National League All-Star pitching staff yesterday, celebrated tonight with a five-hit, 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Control of a leading space-age manufacturing and research company should be decided this morning at the annual meeting of the Atlantic Research Corporation of Alexandria, Va.
ALBANY, July 9 -- New York State's 84-year-old ban on the dissemination of birth control devices and information has been removed from the statute books.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Plans for launching rockets from Northern Canada to an altitude of 100 miles, to trap some of the dust particles drifting in space, were announced jointly by the Air Force and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today.
The Mets can't even handle the Houston Astros outdoors.
PARIS, July 9 -- France has informed the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that she is not interested in entering a NATO nuclear committee proposed by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 9 -- A decision in the case of Pvt. David Ovall, who has been on a hunger strike here since late last month, is expected "very shortly," an Army spokesman said today.
WOMEN may hays waistlines in their future, according to a shy and slender designer from London.

The United States Weather Bureau, at 11 P.M. yesterday, provided the following as the boating outlook for Long Island Sound, Montauk Point to Block Island, the lower Hudson River, New York Harbor and nearby offshore waters:
NEW DELHI, July 9 -- Burmah Shell, which operates the largest oil refinery in India, has decided to reduce prices of crude oil imported from the Persian Gulf.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., July 9 (UPI) -- The 83-foot schooner Serena took a slim lead today in the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific yacht race from Los Angeles harbor to Honolulu.

Arrangements are being made for the Theater Guild, Gerard Oestreicher and Theodore Mann to present Peter Shaffer's London success, "The Royal Hunt of the Sun" here in November. The plot deals with Pizarro's conquest of Peru.

LONDON, July 9 -- The High Court of Britain has been asked to decide whether a night-club waitress can dress like a bunny and be called a bunny if she is not employed by Playboy Clubs, the "inventor" of the bunny.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 9 -- Former Presiding Supervisor Palmer D. Farrington of the Town of Hempstead said today that he would not appear before a Nassau County grand jury investigating influence peddling and payoffs unless he was granted immunity.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Johnson said today that he expected that the situation in Vietnam would get worse and that the number of United States troops there would have to exceed the announced goal of 75,000.
The short-term money market continued tight yesterday and Federal funds traded at 4 1/4 per cent, a quarter of a point above the Federal Reserve's rate.

LISBON, July 9 -- The Portuguese political police have conditionally freed Dr. Julieta Gandara, the woman named "prisoner of the year" last September by Amnesty International, it was officially confirmed today.

Distinguished artists, writers, editors, painters, in a public protest (Times, June 27), demand an end to that "dirty war" in Vietnam. They call upon all citizens to "end our silence,'' "our country's shame" and condemn our immoral, inhuman foreign policy.
Potato futures prices marched ahead yesterday in lackadaisical trading.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The drought in the Northeastern states is spreading.
TOKYO, July 9 -- A misunderstanding between Leopold Stokowski and two local orchestras has resulted, after intervention by United States Embassy officials, in his agreement to lead both ensembles.
" . . . This hexagonal oddity . . . the much-talked-about rotating apartments that will require three hours to make a 360 turn. . . . Tenants will never be aware of their building's . . . movement."

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Total business inventories rose by $400 million, seasonally adjusted, in May, only about half as much as the monthly average in the first four months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 9 -- Robert Bolivar de Pugh, national coordinator of the rightwing Minutemen organization, turned himself in late today to face kidnapping charges.
" What's Jerry Tsai doing in the market?"
The Teleprompter Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of three New York City master-television-antenna companies $2 million for stock and cash.
A self-help project by Negroes involving the reclamation of slum tenements was announced yesterday by Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, executive director of the Interfaith Health Association.

The International Finance Corporation once was faced with the problem of deciding whether to invest in a jute mill in West Pakistan when the source of raw material was in East Pakistan, 1,000 miles away and separated by India.
The County Trust Company of White Plains, the largest commercial bank in Westchester County, reported yesterday first-half net operating income of $1.47 a share, up from $1.39 for the 1964 period.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 9 -- To clarify the action taken yesterday by the conference on transit trade of land-flocked countries, the executive secretary of the conference stated today that the convention as adopted did not affirm the right of access to the sea as a principle of international law.
Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan has set Aug. 30 for a hearing on the fairness and adequacy of the proposed settlement of stockholder suit against the Futterman Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- Jim Bunning of Philadelphia pitched 6 1/3 innings of no-hit ball and wound up with a five-hitter, while Johnny Callison drove in four runs tonight in the Phillies' 10-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, July 8 -- The crime of supporting African nationalist causes is being relentlessly prosecuted and severely punished in a seemingly endless series of trials here in the eastern part of the Cape Province.
On July 9, 1776, George Washington had the Declaration of Independence read for the first time to the troops of the Continental Army arrayed on the Commons, an area that is now City Hall Park.

A patrolman was charged yesterday with extorting $75 from a 37-year-old prostitute, stealing $20 from her and threatening, in a corridor of the Criminal Courts building, to accuse her of a crime unless she gave him $600.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -- Pressed by a widening lag in oil production, Argentine officials are hinting that the Government may ease certain nationalistic attitudes in or der to break the stalemate in negotiations with private petroleum companies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 -- Although Henry Cabot Lodge left Vietnam a year ago as a popular figure among the Vietnamese, his return as Ambassador, announced yesterday. is causing more concern and doubt than celebration.
Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson said yesterday that he planned to resign his $25,000-a-year post soon to enter the academic field.

COTTON VELOUR -- a lustrous, supple, velvety fabric used in apparel for men, women and children -- is shaping up as one of the most talked about materials in the ready-to-wear market. Although only a small part of the total textile picture, knit cotton velours are causing market excitement far out of proportion to their sales. Fabric producers, garment manufacturers and retailers are anticipating a big fall season for these velours.

LONDON, July 9 -- A few hundred yards from Piccadilly Circus, 150 guests of Trans World Airlines mingled tonight, making small talk about London's cold July and sipping California wines. The wine stewards were solicitous. "Something white and not too sweet, sir?" one asked. "Try the Emerald dry." "Delightful," said a man munching Wisconsin sliced cheddar cheese.
Council President Paul R. Screvane called on Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia yesterday to begin an investigation into the recent increase in automobile insurance rates.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 9 -- Optimism for a negotiated peace within at few days was on the rise again today -- just as it was this time last week. There is reason for the hope, but the men closest to the truth know that anything can change here overnight.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The House of Representatives passed the Administration voting rights bill tonight, 333 to 85.
BALTIMORE, July 9 (UPI) -- Milt Pappas registered his ninth victory of the year tonight with a four-hitter as he pitched the Baltimore Orioles to a 1-0 triumph over the Chicago White Sox.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The nation's money supply rose by $1.2 billion between the second half of May and the second half of June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the largest increase for any monthly period this year.

GENEVA, July 9 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the United States delegate to the United Nations, called today for a search for a pattern of urban development that "will avoid the blight and misery so visible in many cities throughout the world."

ROME, July 9 (UPI) -- The Jesuits announced today the adjournment of their 38th general congregation until next year after the session was unable in two months of discussions to agree on plans to streamline the order.

A series of remarkable medical experiments has opened new hope for many victims of liver disease. At the University of Kentucky, at Harvard and elsewhere, patients near death because of liver ailments have had their lives prolonged for varying periods by operations that have, in effect, substituted livers taken from animals for the defective human organs.

Democratic candidates who have been battling among themselves for party nominations turned their attack yesterday on the campaign finances of Representative John V. Lindsay, their Republican-Liberal rival for Mayor.

Little, Brown will publish next spring a biography of Joseph Clark Grew, career diplomat for 40 years and United States Ambassador to Japan from 1931 to the time of the Pearl Harbor attack in 1941. Dr. Waldo Heinrichs of the Johns Hopkins University is author of the book.

A seriously injured crew member of the disabled 110-foot fishing vessel Dodo was removed from the ship by Coast Guard helicopter yesterday afternoon at a point 17 miles east of Manasquan, N.J., and flown to Point Pleasant, N.J., for hospitalization.
" THE great secret . . .," Henry Higgins told Eliza Doolittle, "is not having bad manners or good manners or any other particular sort of manners but having the same manner for all human souls. . ."

Calls for police review boards have stemmed largely from what appear to be the unnecessary killings of persons resisting arrest or attacking policemen with a knife. Although capital punishment, even for deliberate murder, has been abolished, the summary execution of any one who attacks a policeman seems to be tolerated.
NEWARK, July 9 (AP) -- Five men were convicted tonight in Federal court of taking part in a conspiracy involving more than $2 million in counterfeit bonds. A sixth man was found not guilty.

SAIGON, July 9 (AP) -- The United States marines who rushed to the rescue of a Vietnamese naval headquarters overrun by the Vietcong crushed the assault force in bloody fighting, a United States spokesman said today.

It was disturbing to read about some aspects of the picketing by police in front of the New York City Hall. [Times, June 30.] They have a right to picket, but the following description by your reporter was most disturbing: "On the other side of City Hall police pickets in sports shirts and slacks, service revolvers bulging in their hip pockets, cheered Commissioner Vincent Broderick when he drove through their lines."
Reaction to the State Court of Appeals ruling yesterday barring a special legislative election this fall ranged from delight to distress.

The American Maritime Association, a management group comprising about 40 per cent of the nation's ocean-going merchant fleet, has issued a report titled "Growth of the U.S.S.R. Foreign Trade Fleet," which traces the expansion of the Soviet merchant fleet from 354 ships in 1939 to 1,746 today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -The Senate took a memorable step today to establish a fulltime watchdog committee over the ethics of its members, officers and employes. It is the first time that an internal disciplinary body of either house of Congress has been set up on a continuing basis.
BERLIN, July 9 -- The Supreme Administrative Court of West Germany ruled here today that a German is a Jew if born of a Jewish mother.
A tour of six houses and their gardens is being planned by the Garden Club of East Hampton, L.I., for Wednesday from 2 to 5 P.M.

The passage in the House of the voting rights bill is a triumph for the cause of democratic government. It could mean the end in the near future for reactionary, self-serving, racist rule in many parts of the rural South. It hands to the Southern Negro the most important weapon he can use in his struggle for justice -- the vote.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 9 -- The Colombian business community expressed confusion today ever the Government's latest moves to restrict the outflow of capital.
The General Electric Company reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings for the first half and second quarter.
RICHMOND, July 9 (UPI) -- The island of Tangier, a romote fishing community in lower Chesapeake Bay, found a doctor today after an eight-month worldwide search.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 9 -- The New York Yankees, who escaped a flood the last time they were in Minnesota, moved into the path of a deluge tonight as they opened a four-game series with the first-place Twins.
HONG KONG, July 9 -- Overseas Chinese are being prodded by Peking into taking a more active part in the Communist struggle for Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Johnson indicated today that another income tax cut next year would depend on continued progress in making savings in Government spending, particularly defense spending.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9 -- Despite the prospect of a runaway -- or trotaway -- victory by Speedy Scot, the lone American horse in the 1 1/4-mile test, the $100,000 Roosevelt International Trot is expected to attract 40,000 harness racing devotees to Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.
Ship activity in the Port of New York was off last month, compared with the volume of arrivals and departures in May, 1965, and in June, 1964.
ALBANY, July 9 -- The Court of Appeals extended today the United States Supreme Court's one-man, one-vote precept to governing bodies on a local level.
100 MILE HOUSE, B.C., July 9 (Canadian Press) -- Investigators were working today on a bomb theory in the crash of a Canadian Pacific Airlines plane yesterday that killed all 52 persons on board.

A CONTRACT is said to be played "upside-down" if dummy has trump length and declarer has fewer than four trumps. Sometimes this happens by design, as when transfer bids are used to make the strong hand the declarer.

Net income of the Standard Fruit and Steamship Company of New Orleans declined to $2,065,000 in the 24 weeks ended June 19 from $3.12 million earned in the corresponding period a year before, the report disclosed yesterday.

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., July 9 -- Herbert Weiss, the 38-year-old building contractor who was brutally beaten on the head with a baseball bat by an intruder in his home early this morning, was reported to be in critical condition late today at Huntington Hospital.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9 -- Mrs. Donna Floyd Fales of New York, seeded No. 1, and Nancy Reed of Washington, No. 2 in the draw, gained the final of the women's Eastern clay-court tennis championship today.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 9 -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales narrowly won his first singles match in the Newport round-robin professional tennis tournament for the Cartier Cup today at the Casino.

ALBANY, July 9 -- Following are the texts of the decision written by Chief Judge Charles S. Desmond, a concurring opinion by Judge Adrian P. Burke, a dissenting memorandum by Judges Stanley H. Fuld, John Van Voorhis and Francis Bergan, and a separate dissent by Judge Bergan in the Court of Appeals ruling today in the state reapportionment case:

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 102.5 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended July 6, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods decreased in price while industrial commodities rose.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- On his first full day as White House press secretary, Bill D. Moyers held a full-scale press briefing and then produced the President for a news conference.

Trading on the American Stock Exchange finally picked up a bit in the final session of the week, as volume managed to cross the one million level for the first time. Trading totaled 1.19 million shares against 988,000 shares on Thursday.
E.J. Korvette, Inc., is planning to integrate its carpet and furniture operations, using the same personnel, warehousing and trucking facilities, the store made known yesterday.
Roman Catholics and Protestants will soon be reading officially approved English translations of the Bible that are identical -- almost.
FORT LEE, N.J., July 9 -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a theft suspect wounded each other in a pistol battle near the Fort Lee Shopping Center today.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (UPI) -- Jim Maloney scored his 10th victory of the season and Vada Pinson drove in three runs tonight as the Cincinnati Reds belted the Milwaukee Braves, 6-2, and regained first place in the National League.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 9 (UPI) -- Curtis P. Harris, Oklahoma County Attorney, said today that the father of one of seven teen-age boys accused of raping a 15-year old girl had tried to persuade the girl's family not to prosecute.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 9 -- A California state official, his wife and their baby daughter were released today at the Nevada border by two murder suspects who meekly surrendered to the police. Hale Champion, the 41-year-old State Finance Director, was slightly wounded.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Following is the White House transcript of President Johnson's news conference in his office today:

LOS ANGELES, July 9 (UPI) -- Vic Power singled with the bases loaded in the ninth inning tonight to score Joe Adcock and give the Los Angeles Angels a 4-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the first game of a doubleheader.
MOSCOW July 9 -- American officials are hoping once again to discover Soviet intentions in Vietnam when President Johnson's Ambassador at Large, W. Averell Harriman, visits here next week.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- An old Congressional feud boiled over on the floor of the House of Representatives today as the two top men on the Judiciary Committee had at one another with hot words and scornful disdain.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 9 -- Frank Wharton, a fledgling as a touring professional, created a considerable stir with a four-under par 68 today in the first round of the $5,000 Concord invitation 36-hole golf tournament.
NO one has more cause to rejoice at the fashionable woman's current penchant for one naked shoulder and for floating around after sunset in gauzy dance dresses than George Stavropoulos.
J.P. Stevens and Company has announced the appointment of Donald C. Johnston as a vice president. He has served since 1960 as assistant executive officer of the woolen and worsted division.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- Dartmouth equaled the wordl's record of 2:00 1-5 for the mile for trotting stallions on a half-mile track in winning the $12,700 Titan Cup at Historic Track today. Dartmouth scored in straight heats in the feature event of the closing day session of the Grand Circuit meeting.
The city's desperate quest for new sources of water was threatened yesterday by other thirsty communities.

The Court of Appeals, New York State's highest judicial tribunal, ruled yesterday that the special legislative election scheduled in November could not be held because it violated the State Constitution in at least two respects. By so doing it placed itself in direct opposition to the United States District Court's order that the election must be held under Republican Plan A.
Referring to your lead editorial "German Example on India'' of June 24, I feel obliged to draw to your attention the following facts:
PRAGUE, July 9 (AP) -- Peter Snell of New Zealand lost his ninth straight race today and two Polish girls broke the women's world record for 100 meters in the Resicky Memorial track and field meet.
LONDON, July 9 -- U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, conferred today with British officials about the Vietnam situation. He called the discussions "very useful."
A Wisonsin Governor 57 years old and a 16-ton Mexican stone head 2,500 years, arrived at Gate No. 2 at the World's Fair about the same time yesterday morning.

HOLLYWOOD, July 9 -- Producers here are encountering the most severe squeeze on studio facilities in many years as a result of stepped-up movie production, peak output of television shows and an unexpected decline in so-called runaway productions.
A movement is under way among influential Republicans to convince Governor Rockefeller that he should not run for re-election next year, or if that fails, to force him out in a convention fight.
Four persons were charged with attempted ticket scalping last night for the sold-out Frank Sinatra concert at Forest Hills Stadium in Queens.
Rain water could be stored on roofs for 24 hours under a provision of the proposed new Building Code that will be considered by the City Council in the fall.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- The pace of racial protest in Chicago quickened today as aides of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, made preparations for his House Education Committee investigation here.

Regina Resnik has sung Carmen just about everywhere in the world and has been doing so for the last 20 years. Finally, last night, she got to singing it with the Metropolitan Opera Company when the Bizet opera was given a concert performance at Lewisohn Stadium.

INUVIK, Northwest Territories, June 28 -- Passengers in the twin-engine aircraft flying over the intersection of the Arctic Circle and the Mackenzie River surveyed an expanse so watery that Noah's flood seemed to be just ebbing.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Prospects of a record or near-record production of crops appeared possible today on the basis of a Department of Agriculture report that farmers have planted more land this year and are producing more corn and wheat.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 9 -- Ecuadorian troops dispersed more than 21,000 political demonstrators today, with tear-gas bombs and shots in the air.
Steps are being taken to improve the standards of the Equity Theater, the 22-year-old nonprofit venture that serves as a showcase for performers and theater technicians.
THE day is never long enough for Ingeborg Markus. The Berlin-born designer often goes without sleep for three or four days "just to keep up with things."
DETROIT, July 9 -- The American Motors Corporation announced today that it would augment the standard safety features on all its 1966 models.

Revco D.S., Inc., has acquired control of the Gallaher Drug Company. It has bought a 75 per cent interest in Gallaher, a chain of 52 retail units in Ohio and Kentucky. Bernard Shulman, president of Revco, said yesterday the transaction involved in excess of $2 million.

Standing on a milk crate on top of a station wagon in the garment district, Controller Abraham D. Beame appealed to Liberal party members yesterday to let him enter their primary against representative John V. Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Nothing so well illustrates the continuing disability of the Republican party as the plight in which the House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, finds himself today.
The British pound eased in quiet trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

Approval by the Senate of the medicare bill brings this historic measure close to final enactment. Nothing now remains except for the House and Senate to reconcile their comparatively minor differences and send the bill to the President for signature.

MELBOURNE, July 9 -- General Motors-Holden's Proprietary, Ltd., maker of the all -Australian Holden car, announced today it had made a profit of 18,756,824 (Australian), equivalent to $41,265,002, in 1964.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate passed the Administration's Social Security-medicare bill tonight.
Hiroshima, 20 years after the bomb, will be the focus of an hour-long documentary on WNDT (Channel 13) at 9 P.M. on Aug. 4.

Running briskly up front while the stronger horses -- or rather their riders -- seemed to be watching one another, Jacques Wimpfheimer's Petite Rouge scored an impressive victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.
Nine property owners on the East Side opened a legal attack in State Supreme Court yesterday against the Transit Authority's projected Manhattan-Queens subway tunnel at 63d Street.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 9 -- The new chapter of the segregationist Citizens Councils of Alabama here has decided to hold no more meetings that are advertised as open to the public.
MOSCOW, July 9 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, called today for broader rights of workers in the management of their factories.

The All-Star Game managers selected their eight-man pitching staffs yesterday and the National League mound crew is composed mainly of superstars, while relative newcomers make up most of the American League's corps.
The jury that will decide whether Gareth Martinis is guilty of vehicular homicide may also be asked to decide whether his trial placed him in double jeopardy.
Mayor Wagner and Barbara Joan Cavanagh, sister of Deputy Mayor Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., will be married July 26.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Earl Wilson and a first-day rookie, Jim Gosger, hit home runs tonight to get Boston rolling to a 10-1 second-game victory over the Washington Senators and give the Red Sox an even break in the doubleheader.

OCEAN BEACH, L.I. -- Bikini-clad sun worshipers who have long considered Fire Island their private domain are sharing it this season with Park Service rangers as the National Seashore project gets under way.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Traces of the pesticide DDT have been found in seals, penguins and fish in Anarctica, a continent where there is no record of use of the pesticide, the National Science Foundation said today.
AIX-LES-BAINS, France, July 9 -- A caravan of more than 300 cars and trucks drove into this resort town at the foot of the Savoy Alps in midafternoon. It was followed by 100 men on bicycles.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, called yesterday for the appointment of a Presidential commission to cope with the effects of the drought in the Northeast.

This latest darling of the New Breed is a Met with a future. It should be quite a future, too, because the muscular Swoboda -- his teammates call him L'il Abner -- is only 20 years old.

As a 360-degree examination of "the situation" in the South of the 1960's, however, it has a stunning sociological relevance. I know of no recent novel in any genre that has made the same exploration with so much knowledge, sympathy -- and ultimate implacability.

THE season of festivals has returned, and the voice of Shakespeare again is heard on stages across the continent. Whenever there is a spate of Shakespearean productions, there is the recurrent question: How far are producers, directors, designers and performers entitled to go in taking liberties with their playwright?

NAHA, Okinawa, July 10 -- One of the charges against Capt. Sanford Wolfson, an Army doctor on trial here for allegedly having feigned mental illness to avoid service in Vietnam, was changed yesterday.

BROADWAY is looming large for David Rayfiel, the television and film writer. It will come into full view for the author when his latest play, "Nathan Weinstein's Daughter," is produced next winter by Philip Rose, the sponsor of "The Owl and the Pussycat" and the nurturer of such items as "A Raisin in the Sun," "Purlie Victorious" and "Nobody Loves an Albatross."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (Reuters) -- Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky, the Premier, charged today that war profiteers were undermining his Government, the ninth since the overthrow of President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963.

HOUSTON, July 10 (AP) -- Randy Matson, the world shot-put king, put together one of his best series of throws tonight and was added to the United States team that will compete against the Soviet Union in Moscow July 30 and 31.
A fire broke out in an empty building on East 120th Street last week, leaped to the adjacent tenement and within a short time destroyed the living quarters of 10 families.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 10 (UPI) -- The National League, with what appears to be a decided edge in power, speed and pitching, was made a 7-to-5 favorite over the American League today for the 36th All-Star Game on Tuesday.
BAY SHORE, L.I., July 10 -- Peter Zendt's Hasty Hare led the Cottontails home today in the first race of the weekend invitation regatta sponsored by the Bayberry Yacht Club.

LONDON, July 10 -- In a corner of London where there is lawn enough and time, Dudley J.V. Hamilton-Miller relit his pipe, hefted the mallet he has used since 1926 and slowly, coolly stalked onto the playing field. He ignored the sudden rain: A croquet match is suspended only when the court is under water.

NEWARK, July 10 -- The Senate Special Committee on Aging was deluged at a hearing today with appeals for help to make it possible for the elderly poor to enrich their lives, rather than merely to survive.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 10 -- John Gans of Staten Island today won the 52d annual Block Island predicted-log contest. His 53-foot Huckins, Miaha, flying the burgee of the New York Athletic Yacht Club, the host club, covered the 103-mile course from Pelham to Block Island at 15 1/2 knots with a total error of 363 seconds or 1.1971 per cent error.

The set presents the Hungarian composer as pianist -- and a formidable one -- in a recital with the violinist Joseph Szigeti which was recorded live at the Library of Congress in Washington on April 13, 1940.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 10 -- This is a city near the eastern shoreline of the Great Plains -- those endless rolling plains of the American interior that Josiah Gregg called the "grand prairie ocean." Along this shoreline the westward migration, stunned by the immensity and loneliness and aridity of the land-sea ahead, halted for nearly a half-century.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- One of the least-known, most pleasant and inexpensive sightseeing trips offered in Puerto Rico is the cruise around San Juan Bay. Kennedy (5 feet 10 inches, 163 pounds, and 4 months short of 40) remains a keen hiker, yachtsman, horse rider and player of touch football. The Air Reduction Company, Inc., achieved the highest sales and earnings in its 50-year history in the second-quarter and half-year periods ended June 30, according to Geroge S. Dillon, president of the industrial concern.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 11 (UPI) -- Roy Emerson of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, suffered a surprising defeat today at the hands of the No. 1 player in Europe, Manuel Santana of Spain, in the singles final of the Swedish international clay court tennis championships.
CINCINNATI, July 11 (AP) -- Hank Aaron's, two-run homer in the seventh inning today gave Ken Johnson of the Milwaukee Braves a 2-1 victory over Sammy Ellis of the Cincinnati Reds in a pitching duel.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 11 (AP) -- Kathy Whitworth scored a closing-round two-under-par 70 to win the $10,000 Ladies Professional Golfers' Association Midwest open golf tournament today with a 219.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 11 -- President Johnson announced today his selection of two Negroes, one as a Federal judge and the other as a personal military aide.
Seven men arrested in Brooklyn were charged yesterday with criminally receiving raincoats stolen in a $180,000 burglary at the Botany GMR Corporation of Hauppauge, L.I.

CAIRO, July 11 -- A new crisis broke out today in the Yemeni republican Government with reports that President Abdullah al-Salal had revoked an order naming himself premier and setting up a new Cabinet dominated by military officers.

STRASBOURG, France, July 11 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, sternly warned the Jews of the United States tonight against groups that fail to participate in joint action with other Jewish communities.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 11 -- There were moments at Roosevelt Raceway last night when Speedy Scot, 3-10 in the wagering in the $100,000 International Trot, was almost out of sight. At no time, however, was the favorite out of minds of most of the 45,203 harness-racing ehthusiasts.
The political ferment in Ecuador may come as a surprise to American newspaper readers, but it has been building up for a long time.

ALBANY, July 11 -- Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill that would have given Building Department inspectors in New York City and Buffalo the power to enter and inspect a multiple dwelling at any time without warrants.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 11 -- Bob Broege of the Shark River, N.J., Yacht Club won the Red Grant Memorial Trophy, the top prize in the 19th Red Grant Regatta that concluded today on Raritan Bay.
Thin crowds at the World's Fair this season have forced the largest restaurant at the fair, to stop serving luncheons.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- No one knows whether Chicago is destined to become the delayed focus of this year's summer of Negro discontent in the North. as civil rights leaders predict it surely will. But forces are gathering here for a major political-racial collision, and the testing time is not far off.

The concept of combining under a single governmental administration all forms of passenger travel in New York City, or almost all, has been increasingly talked about for several years. Now John J. Gilhooley, member of the New York City Transit Authority, has enlarged his previous views along this line, and presented them to the state-city committee that is beginning its study of the economics of the transit system.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 -- The United States is viewed here as definitely on the road to taking over the main burden of combat in the war against the Communist guerrillas.
There will be no rest for the weary this week as investment bankers face another slate of municipal and corporate offerings.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 (AP) -- Dean Chance broke a scoreless tie with a fifth-inning bunt single today and pitched his first complete game in two months as the Los Angeles Angels beat the Cleveland Indians, 2-0, for their third straight shut-out.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Orville L. Freeman, has accused the First National City Bank of New York of "sheer economic nonsense" and of "playing politics" in its attack on the Administration's farm program.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 (UPI) -- The Ticonderoga, a 72-foot ketch, continued to make its bid today to sweep the honors in the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific yacht race.
PITTSBURGH, July 11 -- Supply and demand still seem evenly balanced in the steel market.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 11 -- Opposition leaders who organized demonstrations Friday for a return to civilian rule will be deported, Ecuador's military junta announced today.
With the flight of Mariner 4 past Mars only two days off, directors of the project are anxiously eyeing two errant moons lest they steal the eye of the vehicle's camera system.
WALDEN, N.Y., July 11 -- Topping the 816-dog field at today's Walkill Kennel Club Show was P. Carl Tuttle's German shorthaired pointer, Ch. Gunhill's Mesa Maverick of Bloomsbury, N.J.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11 -- A panel of 12 experts convened by the International Labor Organization has recommended that the maximum permissible load carried by an adult male worker should be 40 kilograms (88 pounds).

Two musicals with Italian themes, "It's About Time" and "Little World, Hello!", are in preparation for Broadway. The first to be done is "It's About Time," which will have its pre-Broadway tryout in London early next year.

The thesis that religious metaphors have become harmful to the Christian church is not considered revolutionary in English theological circles, according to Dr. Roy Lee, Chaplain of St. Catherine's and Nuffield Colleges at Oxford, England.
New York Stereotypers Union No. 1 yesterday rescinded the contract agreement it had reached with the publishers of the city's major newspapers.
MOSCOW, July 11 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin insisted today that the Soviet Union would "keep firmly to the chosen course" in Vietnam, despite pressure from both Washington and Peking.

Controller Abraham D. Beame warned yesterday that "the grave financial risk" he said the city was running in borrowing to balance its budget had been heightened by the Court of Appeals decision barring the election of a new Legislature this fall.

RYE, N.Y., July 11 -- William L. Butler of Apawamis and Jack Holmes, unattached, defeated George Chittendon of Apawamis and Austin Carey of the Hartford Golf Club, 1 up, today to win the first flight of the annual Apawamis Country Club member-guest golf tournament.

JUST off the coastal road in Libya, not very far from Tripoli, the British Army Field Detention Prison squatted in patch of blazing desert. The white buildings were scattered about on white sand and surrounded by a white wall. Inside the compound rose an artificial hill constructed of rocks and sand.
SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., July 11 -- James G. (Tony) Dill of the Old Cove Yacht Club successfully defended his Greater Long Island District Lightning Class championship on Gardiners Bay today.
The J. Walter Thompson Company, the world's largest advertising agency, announced over the weekend the election of three vice presidents.

Transit Commissioner John Gilhooley proposed yesterday a comprehensive new New York City Transportation Authority to take over subways, buses, Triborough Bridge and Tunnel facilities, Traffic Department operations and ferries.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 11 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew of the Minnesota Twins was named today to start at first base for the American League in the All-Star Game tomorrow when Bill Skowron of the Chicago White Sox was forced off the team with an injured side.
An off-duty patrolman, saddened and angered by the knife slaying of an old neighborhood friend, played a key role yesterday in the capture of an 18-year-old suspect in the slaying.

John French's June 25 letter attacking Representative John Lindsay surprised me so by its inaccuracy and partisan content (Mr. French campaigned full time for Mr. Lindsay's opponent in last year's Congressional election) that I am constrained to write in order to set the record straight.
Foreign diplomats tend to ignore New York's parking regulations because they see the natives doing the same, according to a legal adviser to the United States Mission to the United Nations.
Old age has set in on the main streets of small upstate New York cities, causing a boom in urban renewal, and concern among politicians, merchants and residents.

Norbert Sanders of the Gaelic-American Athletic Club captured the seventh annual 5,000-meter race sponsored by the Road Runners Club yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. His time was 15 minutes 38.5 seconds.
KANSAS CITY, July 11 (AP) -- Home runs by Norm Cash, Gates Brown and Dick McAuliffe gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics today.
A relatively obscure Democratic State Senator and mild-mannered law professor have forced the showdown scheduled for tomorrow in Federal District Court here on New York's re-apportionment plans.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Three-run homers by Chris Krug and Ernie Banks backed the shutout pitching of Larry Jackson and Cat Koonce today as the Chicago Cubs swept a pair of 6-0 games from the St. Louis Cardinals.

" I've been a critical observer of the American way of life for many years and I've been curious about the whole question of how $1 bills can be sold for 79 cents," declared Walter Henry Nelson, author of "The Great Discount Delusion," over the weekend.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 11 -- Bern Gaiser piloted Too Tell to the limit jumper championship in the Melody Farms junior horse show today despite the fact that he didn't win a class and had to survive a four-horse jumpoff.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 11 -- This city has been thrown into a quandary by the Court of Appeals ruling that its plan for a City Council election this fall is unconstitutional.

The Metropolitan Opera added a star Saturday night: Ella Fitzgerald made her debut with the Met orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium. She didn't sing "Aida," but there were plenty of triumphal choruses of tunes from America's Golden Age of Jazz.

Norbert Sanders of the Gaelic-American Athletic Club captured the seventh annual 5,000-meter race sponsored by the Road Runners Club yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. His time was 15 minutes 38.5 seconds.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday his recollection was that he had not even answered the May 14 letter from State Senator John H. Hughes urging the Republicans to replace Governor Rockefeller as their Gubernatorial candidate next year.
The path was cleared yesterday for two abstract sculptures to be exhibited at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
Three top-level executive changes were announced yesterday by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 12 -- So impressively did Steno of Italy rally following his early break in Saturday night's $100,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway, two $100,000 bids have been made for him.
ALBANY, July 12 -- Mexican divorces were ruled valid today by New York's highest court.
The nation's 505 mutual savings banks registered a record increase in deposits for the month of June, but the industry experts are at a loss to explain why.
The disclosure last month by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., of a pucker-free manufacturing technique for shirt and blouse seams brought great joy to the heart of a New Yorker named George Weiss.

Businessmen were urged yesterday to "assume the responsibility for training the unemployed" and to establish a nationwide network of "learning pools" to augment the programs being undertaken under the poverty program by the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector) July 12 -- He sits in a shaded study surrounded by books, a diminutive figure behind a large desk. He is writing Israel's history in longhand, filling small sheets with Hebrew script.
MOSCOW, July 12 -- Soviet authorities are counting on a system of incentive payments to reap a good harvest this year despite the handicap of a late spring.

PARIS, July 12 -- Official sources in France expressed cautious satisfaction today over the United States' call for a world conference aimed at "substantial improvements" in the 20-year-old international monetary system.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 12 -- Rod Laver won the first Newport professional medal-play tennis tournament tonight before a gallery of 2,000 at the Casino.
ALBANY, July 12 -- Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill that would have provided $1 million in state aid this year to New York City for prekindergarten schooling for the children of the poor.

IN its first season at Lewisohn Stadium, the Metropolitan Opera has naturally been stressing singers as soloists, but it took an instrumentalist to outdraw any of the vocal artists. PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Mayor James H.J. Tate announced today the withdrawal of Philadelphia's objections to the proposed merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads.
PARIS, July 12 -- A libel suit was filed here today against Giorgio de Chirico, the Italian painter, and La Table Ronde, the French publisher of his autobiography.
BOGALUSA, La., July 12 -- Gov. John J. McKeithen asked the Negro demonstrators of Bogalusa today for a 30-day cooling-off period.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Did John F. Kennedy really want Lyndon B. Johnson as a candidate for Vice President in 1960, or did Mr. Kennedy make him a politically motivated offer that he expected and wanted Mr. Johnson to reject?
With earth's messenger, Mariner 4, nearing Mars, the flying saucer enthusiasts are having a field day with a rash of reports on strange visitations to the earth.
The Coast Guard's Automated Merchant Vessel Reporting system, a voluntary program for reporting the position of ships at sea, has been extended to the Pacific Ocean.
Both sides summed up yesterday in the vehicular homicide trial of Gareth Martinis.
The port's longshore accident frequency rate last year was substantially the same as in 1963 the Safety Bureau of the New York Shipping Association reported yesterday.

The recent publicity given to the pollution of the atmosphere in New York City strikingly demonstrates the vital role of the public health profession in safeguarding the health and lives of our citizens.
Ten trailers equipped to register voters and conduct literacy tests will cruise the city's streets starting Monday as part of a six-week summer registration drive.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Treasury bill rate rose substantially at today's auction for the second week in succession, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
LONDON, July12 (AP) -- Extra guards were rushed to Manchester's Strangeways Prison to prevent the escape of another train robber, a Home Office spokesman disclosed today.

The voting rights bill, now approved by both houses of Congress, goes to conference for resolution of the differences between the versions adopted by the Senate and the House. On every major point at issue the House bill is superior. If the final measure follows it in most respects, it will be a triumph for democracy and a major weapon against racial discrimination.
BONN, July 12 -- The Bonn Government said today that West Germany would renounce the right to acquire its own nuclear arsenal only if Germany's security and eventual reunification were guaranteed.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made loans totaling more than $1 billion for the first time in its fiscal year ended June 30.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, is confident he now has the votes to report from committee his constitutional amendment on apportionment of state legislatures.

ALBANY, July 12 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that Roy M. Cohn, the lawyer, must pay two brothers in the parachute manufacturing business $522,200 as a result of a complex stock transfer deal made when he headed the Lionel Corporation.
The Spanish Pavilion, described by critics a "the jewel" of the World's Fair, will remain only as a memory at the close of the season.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 (UPI) -- Vice President Humphrey, confronted by black-bordered picket signs protesting the United States stand in Vietnam, made a strong defense today of Administration policy in which he warned critics not to mistake appeasement for peace.
Women comedians like women shot-putters come to their profession with a certain handicap. Traditionally, women are supposed to be beautiful, seductive, gentle and fair -- not funny or muscular.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Television and radio broadcasters must take steps to avoid objectionably loud commercials, or risk losing their licenses, the Federal Communications Commission announced today.

TOKYO (Reuters) -- Japanese girls trying to emulate Western charms are paying for wider eyes and bigger bosoms. The answer is plastic surgery -- for about 20,000 yen ($56) a time. Enlargement of the eyes to Western proportions is eagerly sought by office girls, bar hostesses, princesses and the wives of cabinet ministers. So are operations to enlarge flat noses and meager busts.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 12 (UPI) -- Ships of two nations searched the North Atlantic today after 16 crewmen were reported dead or missing in the crash of an Air Force radar plane with 19 aboard. Only three men survived.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, asked President Johnson yesterday to call for the resignation of Nicholas Johnson from his $20,000-a-year post as Maritime Administrator.
Steel production in the United States declined last week for the third consecutive week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

A summary judgment of $148,500 has been awarded to the Theater Guild in an action against insurance companies to recover losses sustained when the guild was forced to close "Dear Me, the Sky Is Falling" in 1963 because of the illness of its star, Gertrude Berg.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP) -- United Nations Under Secretary Ralph J. Bunche said today the world organization was working toward a solution in seating Communist China and this could not be more than two years off.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 12 -- The start of the closed-course part of the Storm Trysail Club's new competitive venture, Block Island Race Week, provided light exercises in unsteady breezes for 153 cruising yachts today.
TRENTON, July 12 (AP) -- New Jersey's milk price control system was upheld today by the State Supreme Court.
The stock market sat on the fence yesterday, immobilized by the uncertainty of international developments on one side and by conflicting predictions about the domestic economy on the other.
GENEVA, July 12 (AP) -- Israel accused the Soviet Union today of cultural discrimination against its Jewish community and asked that it be ended.
Representative William F. Ryan said yesterday that under no circumstances would he withdraw from the Democratic primary for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The principal spokesmen for the House Republicans on equal rights legislation, Representatives Ford of Michigan and McCulloch of Ohio, were justified in the resentment they expressed today of President Johnson's adverse comment on their substitute voting-protection bill.
Bruno Sammartino earned a split decision in his foul-filled match with Dr. Bill Miller before 17,134 wrestling fans at Madison Square Garden last night.
Price changes in futures of commodities were mixed yesterday on the nation's major exchanges.

MOSCOW, July 12 -- Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman arrived in Moscow today hoping for an opportunity to meet the top Soviet leaders and survey with them the prospects for a settlement of the war in Vietnam.
Mayor Wagner will endorse Paul R. Screvane as his successor but will leave the timing for his announcement to the City Council President, according to sources close to the two men.
The Democratic leadership in the State Legislature made an 11th-hour attempt yesterday to scuttle a Republican move in Federal Court here today to force a special legislative election in November.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Republican national chairman Ray C. Bliss was urged today by Representative Melvin R. Laird, Republican of Wisconsin, to use the prestige of his office to discourage all splinter organizations.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 12 -- A terrorist bomb destroyed the jeep of the commander of an Ecuadorian marine battalion here today amid a new outburst of protest against the country's military rulers.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System took a careful and conservative count of the pulse of the television world last night. It did a documentary on ratings, the figures that purportedly give a clue to the relative populartiy of shows on the air.

Three city policemen were charged last night with conspiring to conceal an illegal abortion and attempting to extort $50,000 from an unlicensed Cuban physician wanted for questioning about the abortion.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- Two policemen and three pickets of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were injured today when violence erupted outside a building where a hearing on the Girard College racial controversy was being held.
TWENTY minutes before her fashion show was due to go on in the Crystal Pavillion of the Sherry-Netherland yesterday, Emme wanted to die.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, in an unusual action, publicly defended today President Johnson's appointment of former Mississippi Gov. James P. Coleman to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

The paper industry has hardly ranked as the most dynamic performer of the domestic economy in the last decade. Earnings of the leading paper companies, in fact, failed to show any net progress between 1956 and 1963, before moving to a new high lat year.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12 -- President Abdel Salam Arif reshuffled his Cabinet last night, reinforcing the belief among observers that he may be changing his policy toward the Arab world.

NEWARK, July 12 (UPI) -- A Federal judge awarded the Internal Revenue Service more than $2.4 million today that had been amassed by Joseph Moriarty, one-time numbers racket leader. The money was discovered in a Jersey City garage three years ago.
NEW DELHI, July 12 -- India opened a campaign today to provide plastic contraceptive loops for a million women within the next year.

Burlington Industries, Inc., held a reception here yesterday for the nation's fashion press to show off its fabrics for fall. But it turned out that the nation's largest textile company also had something else up its promotional sleeve.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 12 (AP) -- Mrs. George S. Tyluki's Doc Tones, trained by her husband and ridden by an apprentice, Barry Pearl, triumphed in a three-horse photo finish in the feature at Monmouth Park today.

LAE, New Guinea, July 12 -- Pacific island representatives launched a strong move here today to gain a major voice in deciding programs for the cooperative social and economic development of island territories stretching 7,000 miles across the Central and South Pacific.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The United States and Japan began a three-day meeting today to discuss the trading frictions that have arisen between the two nations, both of them aggressive exporters and voracious importers of each other's products.
A few hundred polite, sunburned boys swinging mean racquets invaded the West Side Tennis Club yesterday for the annual Eastern junior championships.

FRANKFURT, July 12, (Comtelburo) -- The West German slice of the first European parallel loan bond issue, floated today by E.N.E.L., the Italian national electricity board, was selling more slowly than its counterparts in Luxembourg, Belgium and The Netherlands.

PARIS, July 12 -- Undersecretary of State George W. Ball conveyed to France and other European Governments today the Administration's determination to press its military effort in Vietnam and to increase the number of American troops there.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A huge new national recreation area designed to serve 30 million residents on the Eastern Seaboard was approved today by the House of Representatives.

OTTAWA, July 12 -- The report stressing the need for close consultation and more "quiet diplomacy" between the United States and Canada was described in Ottawa today as a "friendly, useful" document containing much needed to be said.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The possibility that frozen oceans beneath the surface of Mars may support life "cannot be ignored," a leading Air Force scientist said today.
Birds, beasts and fishes as seen by artists through the centuries are in "Natural History Illustrated," a show opening today at the American Museum of Natural History.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 12 -- The anniversary of the departure of the occupying United States Marines in 1924 was observed with a huge demonstration in the rebel zone this morning.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 12 -- The concentration of power in the National League line-up for tomorrow's All-Star game is awesome enough to scare little children and big pitchers. There probably hasn't been anything to match it in the history of this midsummer dream game since 1934 when the American League sent to the plate in succession Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Jimmy Foxx, Al Simmons and Joe Cronin.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Fresh explosions shook Chicago's downtown and near West Side areas last night and early today as authorities were seeking persons responsible for two earlier bombings.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 12 (AP) -- The establishment of civiilan police review boards, which have been urged by civil rights groups in many areas, was opposed today by delegates to a police officers' convention.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 12 -- Indonesia has suspended the program of sending scholars and medical personnel to the United States for postgraduate training, the Education Ministry said today. The program was one of the last remaining American aid projects here.
You can get from Forest Hills to Brooklyn by way of 59th Street in Manhattan, but in this case it was a funny way to run the railroad.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP) -- A Pittsburgh high school student and an Iowa college boy shot 71's today to lead a field of 150 in the first of two 18-hole qualifying rounds for the United States Public Links golf championship.
Three security analysts who play key roles in forming investment policy for the Lehman Corporation were promoted yesterday to the new post of investment vice president.

TORONTO, July 12 -- A strike by more than 650 printers against Toronto's three daily newspapers has entered its second year. For Local 91 of the International Typographical Union which walked out July 9, 1964, in a disagreement about automation, the situation looks unpromising.

The crudely scrawled letters on the mail box and the small cardboard sign in the window are the only indications that the floor above the Spanish-American grocery at 203 East 115th Street in East Harlem is the home of the Block Development Project.

The Senate Public Works Committee gave its approval yesterday for construction of the third Federal building in the Foley Square government complex, of which an $80 million, 41-story office tower and 8-story courthouse are being built now.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Legislation to provide high-speed rail transportation between New York and Washington won its first Congressional test today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were slightly higher yesterday after a day of fairly quiet trading.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it had set aside $10 million to help community-supported educational television during the next four years.
NEW CITY, N.Y., July 12 -- An action was started in the State Supreme Court here today to force inmmediate reapportionment for the Rockland County Board of Supervisors.

Sammyren of Harbor View Farm turned in a third-straight winning performance on the turf at Aqueduct yesterday, registering by two lengths over Roy Kidder's Flag in the feature.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The deadlock in the House Immigration subcommittee that has held up the Administration's bill to reform the nation's basic immigration law appeared to have been broken over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Washington policemen will get National Guard assistance tomorrow in an effort to control a parade of Shriners that will begin during peak morning traffic.
Eli Lilly Co., the first major pharmaceutical company to issue semiannual financial reports, realized a 58.8 per cent gain in earnings in the first half of this year on a sales gain of 26.3 per cent.

The American Stock Exchange showed a little more vitality yesterday than during the final sessions of last week. Volume rose to 1.22 million shares, from 1.19 million in last Friday's trading, but in the final analysis, the market was a stand-off.
ALBANY, July 12 -- The validity of a 1964 law designed to reduce the price of liquor in New York State was upheld today by the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals.

CAIRO, July 12 -- Two high officials of the civilian Government that recently collapsed in Yemen said today they had been barred from leaving the United Arab Republic.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- The summertime living is easy in the dune-bordered communities of eastern Long Island, but the colonists take their leisure in different ways. Southampton's life purrs as quietly as a Rolls-Royce among the middle-aged and older generations, but roars like a Jaguar at night when the young get away from their parents and gyrate at a night spot called Mitty's General Store.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 12 -- The White House made public today a report recommending close, continuous and candid consultation between the United States and Canada as the cornerstone of improved relations between the two nations.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 12 -- More than 350 college professors had joined a growing campaign to block the ratification of the treaty for normal diplomatic relations with Japan as the National Assembly opened a special session today to consider ratification.

Leaders of the campaign for changes in New York State's divorce law said yesterday that they were happy to see some legal fog dispelled.
TURKS started fortifying the upper Bosporus in 1452. At the other end -- Constantinople -- Byzantines reacted as we did in 1962 when the Soviets lavished missile parks on Cuba.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 12 -- The World Peace Congress was marked more by conflict than by concord today, with Communist China attacking the Soviet Union and the Russians walking out on an Albanian speaker.

The International Resistance Company, television and electronic components producer, cleared $1,675,316, or $1.12 a share, on sales of $18,464,021 in the 25 weeks to June 27. This compares with $896,028; or 60 cents a share, on sales of $14,321,496 in the 1964 period, according to the announcement yesterday.

The commanding officer of a soldier who has been on a hunger strike recommended last night that the 23-year-old conscientious objector be released from service as unsuitable because of a "defective attitude."

Unhappiness with Nelson A. Rockefeller, which seems to be endemic to Syracuse, has prompted that city's State Senator John H. Hughes to write a letter appealing to Senator Jacob K. Javits to help save the Republican party from defeat in the election next year. Mr. Hughes says that Governor Rockefeller cannot possibly win a third term, and the implication is that the man who could save the party is Mr. Javits.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Bargains resulting from the excise tax cut are certain to produce more retail sales, Stanley M. Ford said today as the National Housewares Manufacturers Association, of which he is president, opened its week-long exhibit.

WASHINGTON July 12 -- A friend who knew Dr. Robert Mayer White, the nation's top weatherman, as boy in Boston said his most vivid memory is of someone "energetically striding up the street," Dr. White has not slowed down since, even when he wrote a thesis for his doctorate of science at Massachusetts Institute of Technology entitled "Global Energy Balance."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 12 -- A par 4 on the final hole helped Mark Hirsch of Pine Hollow to tie Steve Feldman of Seawane at 72 for medal honors today in the Long Island Golf Association junior championship at the Garden City Country Club.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 12 -- President Johnson today named Dr. Robert M. White to head a new Government agency that will pull together scattered efforts to study and safeguard against the weather and related natural phenomena.

Your article on July 2 with respect to the loss of plants in New York's Botanical Gardens serves to illustrate the rashness with which a good deal of the city's water-conservation program is being carried out.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Republican Governors' Association and the Ripon Society jointly announced their support today for the "Heller Plan" of sharing part of the Federal income tax with the states on a no-strings basis.
RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 12 (AP) -- Two major upsets were scored as the national clay-court tennis championships opened today.
The British pound advanced slightly yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- Factory jobs went over the 18 million mark in June and almost bettered the record achieved during the boom days of World War II, the Labor Department reported today.

STRASBOURG, France, July 12 -- An American Jewish leader called at an important international Jewish assembly today for the establishment of a single organization to speak for the six million Jews in the United States.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12 -- A tour of five estates here has been announced by the Southampton Garden Club's president, Mrs. H. Allan Sillcox. The tour, on Thursday, July 22, will raise funds for the club to plant a small garden at the recently restored Pelletreau 17th-century silver shop museum on Main Street.

Panofsky, whose letter was published on July 5 relating to the Atomic Energy Commission's power line which is planned to bring power to the Stanford Linear Accelerator, a research project in high energy physics headed by Dr. Panofsky, obviously believes that all human values must be disregarded unless they contribute to the search for the ultimate physical particle.
DETROIT, July 12 (AP) -- Some United States automobile plants have completed 1965 model production, while others will not finish their 1965 runs until mid-August.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 -- American marines have driven about 200 Vietcong from a heavily fortified base two miles southwest of the Danang air base.
PARIS, July 12, (AP) -- The Soviet Union defeated Italy, 9-7, tonight in the team saber finals of the world fencing championships and took its fourth title as the competition ended.

" Day of Trinity," by Lansing Lamont, a book about the first atom bomb in New Mexico, which Atheneum will publish on Friday, contains an account of the official explanation to newspapers which said that an ammunition depot had exploded.
The proposal to combine an "intermediate" school with two tall middle-income apartment houses on the site now occupied by the Squadron A Armory is clearly an attempt to do too much with too little.
BOSTON, July 12 -- A Federal court held today, in effect, that racial imbalance resulting from impartial application of a neighborhood school plan is not equivalent to segregation.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The United States proposal over the weekend for a world conference to seek improvements in the international monetary system fell like a bombshell among foreign and international financial officials.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- House republican leaders, in an angry rebuttal to President Johnson's criticism of their stand on the voting rights bill, declared today that the President was a "Lyndon-come-lately" to the cause of civil rights.

HONOLULU, July 12 (UPI) -- The 72-foot ketch, Ticonderoga, and the 73-foot South African ketch, Stormvogel, were headed toward a record elapsed-time finish in the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific yacht race today.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Eight university presidents are scheduled to meet tomorrow to help select a school Superintendent to succeed Dr. Benjamin C. Willis, the $48,500-a-year official who has been the target of protracted civil rights attacks.
MOSCOW, July 12 (AP) -- A Soviet audience warmly applauded the film "My Fair Lady" tonight with the "Rain in Spain" number receiving the biggest hand.
BERLIN, July 12 -- East Germany has quiety begun the production and sale of contraceptive pills in an apparent attempt to halt a growing tide of illegal abortions.

The Glen Alden Corporation announced yesterday that it has offered to purchase a million common shares of McKesson Robbins, Inc., at $49 a share, net to the seller. This amounts to nearly 25 per cent of the 4,254,154 McKesson Robbins shares outstanding.
Opponents of plans for a hydroelectric project in the Hudson Highlands have taken their battle into the Federal courts.

William Zeckendorf has resigned as chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., and said yesterday he planned to act "in concert with and as a consultant to" a real estate company recently formed by his son and son-in-law.
ZERMATT, Switzerland, July 13 (AP) -- Viewers in Europe, the United States and Canada will climb the Matterhorn by television tomorrow if the good weather holds out.

Unfortunately, The Times news article of July 1 on strip mining leaves the reader with the erroneous impression that T.V.A. condones the destructive effects of this type of mining.

Following is the text of the order issued yesterday by a special three-judge Federal Court setting a legislative election in New York State for Nov. 2, 1965, and excerpts from the court arguments preceding it:
A three-judge Federal court met a challenge to its power yesterday by reaffirming an order for a special legislative election on Nov. 2 that New York State's highest court had canceled.
Fragmentary reports indicated yesterday that the new-car sales boom rolled into the second half of the year in high gear.

The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company's $60 million of debentures, to be offered formally today at a yield of 4.58 per cent, are estimated 50 per cent spoken for.

Federal District Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon, granted the Justice Department an extension until Aug. 16 to file a proposed "plan of relief" in the antitrust suit against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

LONG BEACH, Calif., July 13 -- Nine prominent sculptors from Italy, France and Japan among other nations started work this week on a bold project that will transform a college campus here into a showcase of sculpture.
