STRATFORD, Conn., July 13 Sikorsky Aircraft said today that one of its 17,000-pound helicopters had achieved a speed of 242 miles an hour in level flight with the aid of two turbo jet engines. The mark is believed to be the highest speed ever reached by a helicopter without fixed wings.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 13 -- The winner of the Newport round-robin medal-play tournament yesterday, Rod Laver of Australia, will defend his title in the United States professional grass-court tennis championship starting tomorrow at the Longwood Cricket Club.

The fireboat Senator Robert F. Wagner left its pier at 90th Street in the East River at 1 P.M., yesterday on a humdrum dock inspection tour of Welfare Island. But it was summoned hastily home when its own land-based firehouse caught fire.

The One Hundred Men, an organization of leading Negroes from throughout the city, announced yesterday that it was inviting all the mayoral candidates to a meeting July 27 to question them on problems of minority groups.
Paris is drawing fewer American air travelers, the Port of New York Authority reported yesterday in a 200-page study on "New York's Air Passenger Market."

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reversed yesterday in a 4-to-1 decision the conviction of Adrian F. Mason, former Suffolk County Democratic leader, who was accused of having demanded a $2,500 kickback from a paving contractor.

PARIS, July 13 -- An enlisted man aboard the United States carrier Shangri-La pressed the wrong button. Soon, a mile or so away, several thousand vacationers basking on the famed beaches of Cannes found themselves facing a spreading slick of thick black fuel oil instead of the azure Mediterranean.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- The United States District Court today abruptly ended the 10-week-old grand jury investigation of alleged fraud in the reporting of election returns here in the bitterly contested battle for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in April, 1964.
Handbag prices may rise an average of 5 per cent by the time American women begin their Christmas shopping.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 13 -- The American League contrived to launch a rally that saved it from the utter humiliation of an abject rout in Minnesota's glorious sunshine today. But it still added up to a 6-5 defeat. This salves pride ever so slightly, although it still cannot alter the fact that the National League has finally taken the lead for the first time in the All-Star midsummer festival.
STRASBOURG, France, July 13 -- The Chief Rabbi of Rumania has appealed to world Jewish leaders to send teachers and rabbis to serve in his country.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday the election of Vaughn Crawford as curator of ancient Near Eastern art and Thomas P.F. Hoving as curator of medieval art and the Cloisters.

PARIS, July 13 -- The man who runs Yves Saint Laurent, the shy and temperamental young designer, resisted the notion today that his small couture house would change because of its acquisition by a giant cosmetics empire. Mack Robinson, the American businessman and financier from Atlanta, Ga., who had previously backed Saint Laurent.
Representative John V. Lindsay made a bid for the support of organized labor yesterday by unequivocally backing the drive to unionize the city's taxicab drivers.

As a result of the Federal district court's reaffirmation yesterday of its order of May 24, it is virtually certain that New York State will elect a new Legislature Nov. 2 under the terms of Republican Plan A.

They are digging up the grass at Jacob Riis Houses, planted carefully 18 years ago to bring a bit of country to the city in New York's public housing. WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Judge Thurgood Marshall, former chief legal officer for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was named by President Johnson today to be United States Solicitor General.

Worldwide operations of the International Business Machines Corporation led to record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first six months of 1965, the semiannual report disclosed yesterday.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 13 -- Ecuador's military junta conferred in an atmosphere of political crisis today with former President Galo Plaza Lasso as disturbances continued in Guayaquil, the country's main port city.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., July 13 -- Terry Wilcox posted four birdies during a five-hole stretch on his way to a 3-under-par 69 this morning and then scored 74 in the afternoon to win the Westchester County open golf tournament for the second straight year.

PASADENA, Calif., July 13 -- Following is a timetable for the attempt by the spacecraft Mariner 4 to photograph Mars tomorrow. All times are Eastern daylight time. Travel time for all signals is 12 minutes one way. Time until receipt of verification from space craft is 24 minutes.
HONG KONG, July 13 -- Peking threatened the United States with "due punishment" today in a bitter press attack arising out of an alleged intrusion by American jets into Yunnan Province Sunday.

PASADENA, Calif., July 13 -- A fingertip of mankind reaches out tomorrow across 134 million miles of space to Mars, almost touching the only other body of the solar system widely suspected of harboring life.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 13 -- Negotiations toward a provisional government slowed today. One of the three members of the Organization of American States, mediation committee has departed for Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- In its 12-year history the United States Information Agency has been headed by a professional diplomat, a political philosopher, a successful journalist and a famous broadcaster.
LONDON, Wednesday, July 14 -- The bill to abolish the death penalty for murder was passed early today by the House of Commons.

State Senator Jerome L. Wilson, an active proponent of divorce-law reform in New York State, will be named chairman of a joint legislative committee to recommend changes, authoritative sources in the Legislature disclosed yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 13 -- A sharp disagreement between the governing and opposition parties caused an initial deadlock today in proposed parliamentary action on the treaty normalizing diplomatic relations between South Korea and Japan.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 13 (AP) --Wisconsin beat out Nebraska by just four minutes today to become the first state to ratify the proposed 25th Amendment, specifying procedures for coping with Presidential disability and Vice-Presidential vacancies.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Nine thousand Government workers went home last night as employes of the Weather Bureau and the Coast and Geodetic Survey. Today they came to work as employes of the Environmental Science Services Administration.

LONDON, July 13 -- Britain's trade figures for June showed a recovery, but there was little change in the long-term excess of imports over exports.
A State Supreme Court judge yesterday stripped "This Is Burlesque" of its name.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today he thought the press, Congress and the public -- with minor exceptions -- had given him "strong support and excellent cooperation."
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk today cautioned Japan against providing soft credits that could be regarded as aid to Communist countries rather than trade.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 13 -- Kerosene lamps, tandem bicycles, shirtwaists, straw hats and steamer trunks will provide the setting for the Ladies Village Improvement Society's 70th anniversary fair, to be held July 30, on the grounds of the 17th-century Mulford Farm.

LONDON, July 13 (Reuters) -- Britain disclosed a new initiative on Southeast Asia today as one of the Government's junior ministers left Hanoi for London after an apparent rebuff from North Vietnamese leaders.

LAE, New Guinea, July 13 -- Population pressures and overcrowded cities have become problems of major concern at a conference here of representatives of 17 Pacific territories.

TORONTO, July 13 -- On the eve of the Canadian open, foreign and United States players agreed that American golfing prestige remained high despite victories by non-Americans in both the United States and British Opens this year.
Canadian Pacific Airlines, which is operated by the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, has announced the election of J.C. Gilmer as president.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved today the appointment of former Gov. James P. Coleman of Mississippi to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

The Falstaff Brewing Corporation reported second-quarter profits of $1,886,787, or 42 cents a share, up from $1,880,485, or 42 cents a share, in the corresponding 1964 quarter. Sales increased to $37,397,947 from $36,863,704 a year earlier.
PARIS, July 13 (AP) -- Ramon Sota of Spain fired an 11-under-par 62 today, with the aid of a double eagle 2, to take the lead at the halfway mark of the French open golf tournament.

ONE of the most painful experiences at the bridge table is to be squeezed by one's partner. It becomes worse when the partner could have avoided doing so, and worse still when one could have prevented him from doing so.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. -- Clocks seem to have stopped inside many of the mansion-sized cottages that sit beyond the flowering potato and wheat fields on top of the dunes here. "Nothing is changed here," said George Roberts of his Colonial-style residence, which is one of five homes that will be open to the public today from 2 to 5 P.M. for the benefit of the East Hampton Civic Projects Fund.
The Maritime Administration intervened in the month-old maritime strike yesterday as settlement efforts deteriorated.

MOSCOW, July 13 -- A Soviet newspaper disclosed today that a narcotics ring peddling marijuana cigarettes had been uncovered in the Siberian city of Omsk and that its members had been sentenced to prison.
LONDON, July 13 (AP) -- A Government minister said today that the Soviet Union and the West must stop producing nuclear weapons and start destroying them as the price of halting their spread.
A jury of 11 men and a woman was sent to a hotel at 12:20 A.M. today after failing to reach a verdict in the vehicular-homicide trial of Gareth Martinis.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 13 -- One of baseball's oldest sayings, that "things even up in the long run," had new confirmation today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- A Senate subcommittee turned on a snooping device today and couldn't make it quit.
The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to ask Mayor Wagner to set up an advisory transportation council to help establish priorities for the city's transportation programs.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ordered a former Buffalo clergyman released from state prison yesterday unless the state granted him a fourth trial "within a reasonable time" on a charge of murdering his wife.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- Attorney General Nicholas deB, Katzenbach said today that the National Rifle Association's concern over legislation to control sale of firearms might be related less to sportsmen and more to some commercial gun dealers.
The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company awarded $60 million of 40-year debentures yesterday to a group led by Halsey, Stuart Co.

American homemakers will pay more for comforters and pillows as a result of the war in Vietnam and the increased demand for down by Europeans. This was made known yesterday at the domestics, curtain and drapery show at the New York Trade Show Building. This fall prices on products filled with down will cost about 20 per cent more than last year.
The British pound eased in moderate dealings on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The Storer Broadcasting Company exercised its option on Monday to buy controlling interest in Northeast Airlines from the Hughes Tool Company. July 30 has been set as the closing date.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the possibility that dummy orders charged to a put-and-call broker may have left a number of New York Stock Exchange member firms with substantial losses.
NEW DELHI, July 13 -- India announced today that she had extended diplomatic recogntion to the 13-nation Arab League. She became the first to grant such recognition.

Ground was broken yesterday on Murray Hill for a 24-story six-sided office building and communications center for the New York Telephone Company. The structure will be erected at 233-37 East 37th Street, on a site extending through to 38th Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Internal Revenue Commissioner Sheldon S. Cohen and Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach acknowledged today that Federal agents had used illegal wiretapping, hidden microphones and two-way mirrors in investigating suspected tax frauds.

The Liberal party, allied on a citywide slate with the Republicans, reasserted its political independence yesterday by announcing it was endorsing Democrats in a number of pivotal borough and local races.

Corrupt policemen have joined inspectors of the Board of Education in demanding graft payments from contractors on the $17 million annual school maintenance program, according to evidence gathered by District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn.
GADSDEN, Ala., July 13 (UPI) -- Representative James D. Martin, Republican of Alabama, called Judge Marshall's appointment today "a direct affront to the South."
Controller Abraham D. Beame went home to Brooklyn yesterday to open his sidewalk campaign with a folksy appeal to noonday crowds.

The Polaroid Corporation confirmed reports yesterday that it plans to market a camera retailing at $19.95 that will produce finished black-and-white pictures within 10 seconds. The new camera, to be called the "Swinger," also offers a built-in flash gun and a built-in viewfinder that indicates when the setting is correct.

Charles Munch will conduct the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall in the opening concert of the orchestra's French-American Festival at 8:30 P.M. Soloists will be Adele Addison, soprano, and Robert Casadesus, pianist.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Leonard H. Marks has been chosen to succeed Carl T. Rowan as director of the United States Information Agency, President Johnson announced at his news conference today. [Opening statement, Page 20.]
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A bill requiring a health warning on cigarette packages cleared Congress today and was sent to the White House.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 13 -- The National League overpowered the American League, 6-5, in a free-swinging All-Star Game today and took its first lead in the series since Babe Ruth won the opening game with a home run 32 years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- There is a passage somewhere in a Joseph Conrad tale of the eastern islands about a white man who lived and walked among the colored natives "as if he were passing through the shadow of a tree upon his path."

HELSINKI, Finland, July 13 (Reuters) -- The chief American delegate at the World Peace Congress here received a standing ovation today when he urged negotiations on Vietnam and said the conflict there was "America's shame."

Herbert M. Franklin, a lawyer in the office of the chief counsel of the Federal Urban Renewal Administration in Washington, D.C., has been appointed director of the Urban Redevelopment Division of the ACTION Council for Better Cities.

A petition signed by 1,180 residents of Greenwich Village protesting "intolerable" and "offensive" activities in Washington Square Park was presented to Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris yesterday by two New York University professors.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Johnson pledged today a major effort to solve the problems confronting Negroes.

BERLIN, July 13 -- The United States Army announced today the stationing in West Berlin of two additional helicopters and two one-engined liaison planes to increase Western Allied aviation capability in the city and rebut East German Communist claims of air sovereignty.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 13 -- The Secret Service has halted the production by a jewelry concern here of fake gold bars as paperweights.
PARIS, July 13 -- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball sought to convince the European allies of the United States today that the world, not the United States, a crisis over Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Navy said tonight it plans to produce for its aviators a new type of fluid-shielded goggles capable of cutting off instantly the light from an atomic-bomb explosion.
RICHMOND, Va., July 13 -- A Negro physician narrowly lost a bid today to be nominated in a Democratic primary for the Virginia House of Delegates.

NEWARK, July 13 -- Federal Judge James A. Coolahan emphasized today that both Hudson County and the United States Internal Revenue Service had valid claims to the $2.4 million fortune amassed by Joseph (Newsboy) Moriarty, a former numbers racket leader.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 13 -- Some action-hungry fans who will wager on nearly anything were offering odds tonight that the "exacta" would be in operation at Roosevelt Raceway within 48 hours.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands July 10 -- Europe's discovery of American modern dance proceeds apace. Here in Rotterdam tonight Paul Taylor and his dance company ended a series of spectacularly successful appearances in this year's Holland Festival.
CAIRO, July 13 -- The official radio of the Sudan reported tonight that a new military clash had broken out between heavily armed rebels and Government troops.
Abilities, Inc., the Albertson, N.Y., components producer staffed entirely by handicapped workers, announced yesterday the selection of a new chairman.

Mayor Wagner and other officials are reported to be favorably disposed toward the proposed earmarking of 1/2 to 1 per cent of total construction costs of all new public building in New York for the purpose of artistic embellishment.
Proposals for a civilian review board to take up charges of police brutality were praised yesterday as a safety valve for explosive community tensions, and denounced as a first step toward anarchy.

The Westinghouse Air Brake Company announced yesterday plans to acquire the rock crushing, mining machinery and industrial manufacturing business of the Goodman Manufacturing Company for $9.5 million in cash.
LONDON, July 13 -- The House of Lords debated today a motion that speeches in the House of Lords should be shorter.

Polonia Bytom of Poland can tie for first place if it defeats West Bromwich Albion of England in their International Soccer League match tonight at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. Game time is 8:30 o'clock.
Two executive vice presidents of the P. Lorillard Company were promoted yesterday to the top positions of the producer of Kent, Old Gold, Newport, Spring and York cigarettes.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 13 -- Sailing three near-perfect races, Mrs. Timothea Schneider Larr of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club took an almost insurmountable lead today in the Syce Cup competition for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 13 -- Over-all global output registered an increase of at least 5 per cent last year above the 1963 level, the United Nations reported today in its world economic survey for 1964. The momentum carried into the early months of 1965 especially for the industrialized nations, but is expected to slacken somewhat before the year is out.
ALBANY, July 13 -- Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill aimed at restoring the sweep of the American Falls of the Niagara.

It was heartening to read your editorial judgment of July 9 that Congress acted unwisely in banning for four years the Federal Trade Commission and state and local authorities from requiring a health hazard statement in cigarette advertising.
McKinsey and Company, international management consultants, announced yesterday the election of Dr. David B. Hertz and John D. Macomber as directors.

ALBANY, July 1 -- A spokesman for Governor Rockefeller, who is vacationing in Venezuela, said today the Governor would first have to study the Federal bill, but that New York would "probably" make its cigarette labeling requirements conform to the Federal rules.

American television shows are making friends and influencing people abroad. An increasing number of foreign sales were responsible last year for an income of $86 million to to the three networks and independent producers.
IF the magnificent wildlife of East Africa is not exterminated within the next generation that happy development will be due to the dedicated labors of a few men.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Johnson disclosed today that the Soviet Union had agreed to resume disarmament negotiations at Geneva this summer.
HARTFORD, July 13 -- John Lodge, former Governor and former Ambassador to Spain, today was appointed one of six assistant floor leaders of the constitutional convention.
FREEPORT, L.I., July 13 -- If the seas are rough, watch out for Holocaust, Sea Deuce and 008. If it's smooth, don't overlook the JJ Class outboards.

MAIDENHEAD, England, July 13 -- Four years ago, when he was an old man with a sore back and a sour stomach, Laurence Lipton bought the Hawthorne Hill Race Course, an abandoned pony track near here. He planned to turn it into another investment coup.

TORONTO. July 13 -- The Toronto Stock Exchange suspended trading today of the shares of Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., and the Ontario Securities Commission disclosed it is investigating the company's affairs, including recent trading in its stock.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 -- A pro-Cairo publication here has charged that followers of former Premier Ahmed Noman of Yemen plotted to have President Abdullah al-Salal assassinated. The journal, Al Horriva, said its information had come from Sana, the Yemeni capital, and Cairo.

A syndicate of real estate investors, who prefer to remain anonymous, plan to purchase and rehabilitate as many as forty run-down residential buildings, according to Earl Douglas Hansen, Inc., a real estate broker of 509 Fifth Avenue.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 14 -- The antitrust division of the Department of Justice lost in a last-minute attempt in United States District Court here today to block the purchase of the Narragansett Brewing Company of Cranston by the Falstaff Brewing Corporation of St. Louis.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Mike Belkin a 19-year-old Miami (Fla.) University sophomore, defeated a Davis Cup star, Martin Riessen, today in the third round of tile national clay court tennis championship, 6-1, 6-2.

Guild, Bascom Bonfigli, Inc., will run an ad next week lamenting the loss of $4.3 million in billings, but suggesting to any interested parties that they now have "a glorious opportunity to seize some of our presently uncommitted creative and marketing experience."
New-car sales were strong in early July. Domestic producers sold more than 195,000 cars in the first 10 days, against 177,300 in the 1964 period. This was a rise of 11.2 per cent.

CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP) -- Dr. Sam Sheppard lost his fight for a new trial in the slaying of his first wife today, one day before the anniversary of a court order that freed him temporarily from a life sentence.
The Monsanto Company reported yesterday the biggest quarterly and half-year's sales and earnings in its 61-year history.
BONN, July 14 -- West Germany, which came up with the idea in the first place, is proving the weak link in Western Europe's first multinational parallel bond issue.

SPOLETO, Italy July 14 -- One of Ezra Pound's few musical compositions, "Le Testament," was presented ase a musical rarity tonight at Gian Carlo Menotti's Festival of Two Worlds, now in its last week in this ancient hilltown of central Italy.
The nation's electric power production rose 3.9 per cent in the week ended July 10 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
Paul O'Dwyer, a scrappy 5-foot-8 candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, sliced his projected campaign expenditures to $125,000 yesterday, just half the original estimate.

ARTHUR BISGUIER, New York's peripatetic grand master, facing some of California's most talented enthusiasts, scored 9 1/2-1/2 in a recent simultaneous exhibition with clocks. The event was the highlight of the opening of the newly organized Herman Steiner Chess Group of San Diego.

The $50 million debenture issue of the Lone Star Cement Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission July 1, is expected to be offered to investors this morning. The debentures carry a 4 7/8 per cent interest coupon and are priced at 100.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The House passed Administration legislation today to give the nation a new coinage after it had almost dealt the program a major setback.
ATLANTA, July 14 -- A $1.5 million slander suit was filed against Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today by attorneys for Lieut. Thomas R. Gilligan of the New York Police Department.

PERHAPS the most persistent myth in bridge is the idea that one should always lead the highest card of partner's suit. No reputable bridge authority has ever made such an assertion, but this traditional misconception has been passed on for decades at the lower levels of the game and bridge teachers run up against it constantly.

Philip Van Rensselaer, identified by his publishers, Trident Press, as "the great-great-great grandson of Stephen Van Rensselaer, (1764-1839), the last of the patroons and perhaps the first American multimillionaire," has written a novel about an heiress with $300 million.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 14 -- The leaders of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints -- the Mormon church -- have been rebuffed in an attempt to get Mormon members of Congress to cast votes as a matter of religious duty.

Three policemen delayed formal pleadings last night on departmental charges of conspiring to take a $50,000 bribe to cover up alleged abortion activities. A new hearing at police headquarters was set for 4 P.M. today.
LAE, New Guinea, July 14 -Pacific islanders sought here today to increase their participation in the social, economic and educational developments involving their territories.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday earnings gains of 74.5 per cent for the first-half of this year and 57 per cent for the second quarter.
The country's leading cigarette producer, the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, attained record profits in the three and six months ended June 30.
Adlai Ewing Stevenson was a rarity in American public life, a cultivated, urbane, witty, articulate politician whose popularity was untarnished by defeat and whose stature grew in diplomacy.
OSLO, Norway, July 14 (AP) -- Ron Clarke smashed two world records tonight as he became the first runner to crack the 28-minute barrier for 10,000 meters.
TORONTO, July 14 -- Joe Campbell, aided by the astute advice of his caddie, scored a four-under-par 66 today to take the first-round lead in the $100,000 Canadian open.

Last night's "Evening of Russian and German Music" at Lewisohn Stadium was well-planned by the Metropolitan Opera, and the music was well-performed. The fact that the enormous field looked so empty did not dishearten the musicians, though, for it was an evening of solid and often exciting music-making.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Most Communist diplomatic personnel in the United States are a dangerous threat to national security, J. Edgar Hoover said today.
PARIS, July 14 -- The world's most famous and most difficult bicycle race, The Tour de France, ended here today with a brilliant upset victory for a lean-faced young novice from Italy.
PASADENA, Calif., July 14 -Mariner 4 completed its rendezvous with Mars this evening and sailed on into space carrying, it is hoped, a series of tape-recorded pictures of that mysterious planet.

BUENOS AIRES, July 14 -- A sharp political attack by former President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu against the Government of Dr. Urturo U. Illia was being weighed today in terms of its effect upon the oil negotiations.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Senate Judiciary Committee action was deferred today the nomination of former Gov. James P. Coleman of Mississippi to be a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

The Democratic leadership in the Legislature filed a new petition with United States Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan yesterday seeking a stay of Tuesday's Federal court order requiring a state election in November.

ALTHOUGH he didn't plan it that way, it seems only right that James Galanos should have presented his fall collection on Bastille Day. The 40-year-old, Philadelphia-born, Paris-trained, California-based designer asserted his legendary independence yesterday by daring to be consistent.

THE HAGUE, July 14 -- The International Court of Justice was told today that in administering the territory of South-West Africa, the Republic of South Africa was seeking to develop among nonwhite groups "a voice that could be heard in the councils of South Africa."

Adlai E. Stevenson of Libertyville, Ill. was the man New York City voters wanted to be President of the United States. When he ran for the office a second time, in 1956, New Yorkers cast 1,614,800 votes for him. In the nation, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower won by a landslide that year, but he got 1,551,900 votes here.
Water conservation programs for 14 million persons in the metropolitan area were stepped up yesterday, while some officials looked to avoid future shortages.
LONDON, July 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson collapsed on a London street today and died.
MOSCOW, July 14 -- Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania began weeklong celebrations today to mark the establishment of Soviet rule 25 years ago in the former Baltic independent states.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Army legal officers told Congress today they believed servicemen had paid millions of dollars in excess charges to companies making loans for automobile purchases and other purposes.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- President Johnson accepted today the credentials of the new Ambassador from the African nation of Malawi and offered some friendly advice as one parent of two daughters to another:

LONDON, July 11 -- There is perhaps nothing fresh to be said about "Giselle," but the old, story was given in appropriate new wrapping by the Ballet Rambert last night, opening the troupe's annual London season at the Sadler's Wells theater.
THE world of Sean O'Casey was brought to life with glowing understanding and agonizing brevity last night in a beautiful half hour offered by WNDT, the educational station.

An official of the Canadian Government strongly defended yesterday his country's wheat sales to the Soviet Union, Communist China and other nations behind the Iron Curtain as a means of improving the country's trade balance.
LEE, Mass., July 14 -- Just a few years ago, it was only in America that one could find small, highly skilled dance companies that specialized successfully in contemporary works. works.

Three soldiers who escaped from their Army guards at a Georgia stockade failed yesterday to elude two patrolmen here who chased them across the Triborough Bridge onto Randall's Island and into the East River.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- He wanted to enter public office as a Senator, but in 1948 the Democratic slate-makers in Illinois nominated him for Governor instead. He wanted to stand for re-election as Governor in 1952 on his record at Springfield, but the Democratic National Convention overruled both this ambition and the deep conviction he expressed that he was temperamentally unqualified for the Presidency.
ERROL, N.H., July 14 -- Too often, urban Eastern anglers lack curiosity about the country that lies within a day's journey of their homes. This can cost them good sport.
ROME, July 14 (AP). -- A Vatican weekly magazine addressed an open letter to Pat Boone today, telling the American singer that it liked both his voice and his family life.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- President Johnson asked Congress today to add $5 million to the $7 million already in the budget to fight floods and to repair and restore facilities hard hit by floods and other natural disasters in recent months.

The suggestion that universal water metering is a suitable conservation measure for New York City [editorial July 7] is about as pertinent as proposing a return to drawing water from a well in the town square.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 14 -- Pat Schwab of the Crestmont Country Club scored a four-under-par 35, 31 -- 66 today and took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the 45th New Jersey open golf championship at the Spring Brook Country Club.
The British pound inched ahead yesterday in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here.
Miss Barbara Cavanagh said yesterday that she and Mayor Wagner would honeymoon on Marco Island, 50 miles south of Fort Myers, Fla., after their wedding July 26.

Nothing seemed to excite the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume rose to 1.12 million shares and the trend of issues traded was anything but inspiring. In fact, it really amounted to still another standoff.

HONOLULU, July 14 (UPI) -- The 73-foot sloop Kialoa II, third to cross the finish line, unofficially took the lead today in corrected times for the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific yacht race, which ended last night with the Ticonderoga the first craft to cross the finish.
LANCASTER, Pa. -- There is a cartoon of Pennsylvania Dutch life in which one man asks another if he is a native. "No," the other man answers, "I was born here, but my father came by car."

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 14 -- The circling of Block Island, which was to have engaged the yachts participating in the Storm Trysail Club's Race Week today, was smothered by fog that made sailing too dangerous.
Your June 23 editorial "Of Air and Death" singles out Con Ed as the chief offender in the pollution of New York City's air.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 14 -- Mrs. Timothea Schneider Larr of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club won the Syce Cup today as the Long Island Sound women's sailing champion.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Johnson Administration hinted even more strongly today that the war in Vietnam would probably soon require the mobilization of reserves, larger draft calls and the extension of enlistments for men on active duty.
BOGALUSA, La., July 14 -Both sides in the Bogalusa racial conflict appealed to President Johnson for help today.

The San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit District sold its third bond issue yesterday, moving a step closer to the $1 billion grand design to provide fast interurban rail transportation in northern California by 1971.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- State officials approved today special engine attachments for the 1966 models of most of the major automobile manufacturers, designed to eliminate a considerable portion of exhaust fumes.

Leonard H. Marks, a Washington attorney and long-time confidant of President Johnson, is a surprising choice for head of the United States Information Agency. The job, which ideally demands expertness in both information techniques and foreign affairs, has more usually been held by a man from the world of communications or by a career diplomat.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., raised its net profit to $4,280,000 in the 40 weeks ended June 10 from $3,729,000 in the period last year, despite a drop in earnings in its third fiscal quarter.

CINCINNATI, July 14 (UPI) -- A total of 96 million tons of commercial cargo, a record, was transported on the Ohio River last year, the United States Army Corps of Engineers said today in its annual report.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -The widow of a contractor killed in a 1963 plane crash will receive $1,225,000 under a settlement agreed upon today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, urged Congress today to set a $2 an hour minimum wage and a 35-hour work week.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A cost-reduction program by the Defense Department has been so successful that President Johnson directed the heads of all agencies today to read a report on it and come up with similar plans.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- A bomb exploded in, or under, a car parked near the R.R. Donnelly Company, a large printing plant, on Chicago's South Side late tonight, shattering many windows in the area.

THE French-American Festival of the New York Philharmonic opened last night in Philharmonic Hall. Appropriately enough, it was Bastille Day, and it was a nice touch to lead off with a fanfare, the one from Debussy's "Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian."

Warren Spahn's career as a New York Met, and possibly his entire baseball career, ended yesterday when the Mets formally asked $1 waivers "for the purpose of unconditional release" on the 44-year-old pitcher who has won more games than any other left-hander in baseball history.
Cobble Hill Park, a tiny center of "passive recreation" that might have been the site for a supermarket or an apartment building, was dedicated by the city yesterday.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 14 (AP) -- William F. Buckley Jr., editor and columnist, withdrew from Superior Court today a $500,000 legal action against The New York Herald Tribune.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday July 15 -- United States jet fighter-bombers yesterday made their deepest officially announced strike into North Vietnam, ranging to a point less than 40 miles from Communist China's frontier in one of a series of raids.

CLEVELAND, July 14 (AP) -- Jim Schaffer's tie-breaking double and Al Weis' two-run single in the 12th inning -- after an error opened the gates -- gave the Chicago White Sox a 12-10 victory over Cleveland tonight. The victory extended the Indians' losing streak to seven games.

A 4-year-old girl was found dead in a clump of weeds in a Queens lot yesterday only hours after she and her 5-year-old brother had disappeared mysteriously from their mother's garden apartment in Flushing.
After acting like a zombie Monday and Tuesday, the stock market suddenly came to life yesterday, with many issues making substantial price gains on increased volume.

CHICAGO, July 14 (UPI) -Adlai E. Stevenson 3d said today that funeral services for his father probably will be held in Springfield, Ill., where Mr. Stevenson served as Governor of Illinois for four years.
Municipal bond dealers were heartened yesterday by the pace of sales to investors for the large new tax-exempt issues that were sold at competitive bidding yesterday.
Tributes to Adlai E. Stevenson will be carried today by the major television networks.

Howard A. Newman, president of the Philadelphia Reading Corporation, said yesterday that his company's offer of $22 a share for the common stock of Lone Star Steel Corporation would expire July 30, unless extended by P. until August 13.

THE most impressive aspect of the New York Shakespeare Festival's "Coriolanus," which opened officially on Tuesday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, is Coriolanus himself. Robert Burr makes of him a proud, impulsive, foolish, uncompromising figure with whom any of us can identify.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -With tears in his eyes, President Johnson mourned Adlai E. Stevenson today as "the flame which illuminated the dreams and expectations of an entire world."

The appointment of John Timothy Collins as general chairman of the finance campaign for the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, was announced yesterday by William E. Petersen, president of the Councils and of the Irving Trust Company.
PARIS, July 14 (AP) -- Ramon Sota of Spain shot 70, 67 in the final two rounds of the French open golf championship today and beat Cobie Legrange of South Africa by a stroke.

A Westchester mayor has questioned a "possible conflict of interest" by Governor Rockefeller in a new 3.5-mile road spur the mayor says would take through traffic away from the Rockefeller family estate in Pocantico Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -The Internal Revenue Service taught wiretapping techniques to agents, and supplied experts from Washington to help tap wires, despite service regulations against wiretapping, a revenue intelligence chief testified today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Justice Department urged today that conditions be imposed if the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads occurs.
Statements of sorrow and tribute were made yesterday by leading American and foreign figures after the death of Adlai E. Stevenson. Among them were the following:

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff indicated today that he felt the automobile industry was failing in its public responsibility to provide the safest cars it could for the American motorist.
CAIRO, July 14 -- A military faction with Maj. Gen. Hassan al-Amri as Premier will take over the Government of Yemen in the next few days, informed sources said tonight.

ZERMATT, Switzerland, July 14 -- Bands played, flags waved and many speeches were made in this Alpine resort today to mark the centenary of the first conquest of the Matterhorn, the pyramidlike mountain that defiantly pierces the sky.
BONN, July 14 -- A spokesman for Chancellor Ludwig Erhard expressed "profound shock" tonight at the death of Adlai E. Stevenson.
After two full days of deliberation, the jury considering the Gareth Martinis case was unable to reach a verdict this morning.
The New York Stock Exchange's weekly list of insider transactions disclosed yesterday the sale of some large blocks of stock in Big Board companies.

DUBLIN -- The most sensational buy in Ireland would probably be an old door. Hundreds of Georgian houses with unforgettable doors -- made of oak with gleaming brass knobs, name plates and tiny slots -are being demolished despite the anguished cries of Desmond Guinness and his group, The Georgian Society.
Investigators said yesterday that at least six and perhaps as many as 12 Big Board member firms face potential losses in a stock purchasing scheme run through a put-and-call broker.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The nation's total output of goods and services rose by $9.2 billion in the second quarter of this year, not far from the average quarterly rise of $10 billion that has prevailed since the beginning of 1964.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- The Board of Education, in a move to ease racial tensions, voted 8 to 3 today for "immediate" appointment of an assistant superintendent in charge of integration.

ATLANTA, July 14 (AP) -- The Georgia Supreme Court said today that the United States Supreme Court "by striking down established rules of procedure in trials is shaking the foundation of orderly judicial trials which can only be followed by chaos in the courts of America."
The National Labor Relations Board designated 17 polling places yesterday for the largest union representation election among unorganized workers here in five years.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 14 -- Federal antipoverty money appears to be bringing some order to the population expansion here and cutting welfare costs, too.

PASADENA, Calif., July 14 -- Each time an unmanned spacecraft rockets upward from Cape Kennedy to explore space, its post-launching control is centered in a cluster of anomalously modernistic buildings in a rustic canyon on the edge of Pasadena.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service announced today extensions to Nov. 1 for filing and paying of excise taxes by certain categories of business under the recently enacted tax-reduction law.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The 1965 Christmas postage stamps will show the archangel Gabriel blowing his horn. It will be the first time in the four-year history of Christmas stamps that a religious theme will be used.

Adlai Stevenson belonged to a distinguished line in American history -- Clay, Calhoun, Daniel Webster, come quickly to mind -- who were great figures without ever reaching the summit of office and power. In Stevenson's case, it was, paradoxically, the splendid quality of the man that blocked his way.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14 -- A telephone inquiry from an anonymous radio listener broke the news today to the United States mission that Adlai E. Stevenson was dead.

SAM MELE, the manager of the Twins, and Dick Sister, the manager of the Reds, were chatting on the sidelines just before the All-Star Game in Minnesota on Tuesday. A photographer spotted them together and raced over to take a picture.

After a two-month search, Representative John V. Lindsay announced the appointment yesterday of his campaign finance chairman -- Bernard J. Lasker, a stockbroker who has raised nearly $50 million for civic and charitable causes.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 14 -- The military junta placed Guayaquil under martial law today and decreed a curfew in that key port city.

" We must shed the illusion that there is a war against poverty. There is merely a BB shot against poverty," Herbert Hill, an official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, told his organization's convention the other day
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission challenged legislative efforts to cut its controls over the electric power industry.
WASHINGTON, July I4 -- One major difference between the House and Senate texts of the Administration's medicare-Social Security bill was quickly settled by compromise today.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP) -- Start Poploski, 43-year-old Pittsburgh real estate salesman, scored a pair of 1-up victories today and led the way into the third round of the national public links golf championship.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Construction of more than 1,200 miles of special mountain highways designed to improve the accessibility and economy of depressed Appalachian communites was approved today by the Appalachian Region Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- In about three months the Government will start collecting patent fees at about triple the present scale.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Following are the texts of statements today on the death of Adlai E. Stevenson by President Johnson, made at a White House luncheon honoring Japanese Cabinet members and in a later television appearance:

The city will go into court today to oppose a challenge of its right to borrow $255.8 million to help finance the budget for the fiscal year that began July 1. A Brooklyn taxpayer's suit charges that the borrowing would be unconstitutional.
The Kaiser Steel Corporation reported yesterday a 67.2 per cent increase in second-quarter earnings.
HONG KONG, July 14 -- A leading North Vietnamese Communist has indicated that Hanoi is looking more to Peking than to Moscow for ideological guidance and assistance in the Vietnamese war.

The American Tobacco Company signed a lease for 475,000 square feet of space yesterday and became the title tenant of the office tower that the Uris Buildings Corporation is erecting at 245 Park Avenue, north of Grand Central Terminal.
Children's summer theater has started its second season at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, where 20 performances will be given through Aug. 4.

Norbert Pogrzeba scored two goals within two minutes late in the second half and drew Polonia Bytom of Poland into a 2-2 tie with West Bromwich Albion of England last night in an International Soccer League match at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

The Queen Elizabeth sailed yesterday for Southampton, England, with a near-capacity list of 2,099 passengers, including, 76 persons who were able to make a last-minute transfer from the liner United States.
The Police Department will start in Harlem tomorrow a series of street-corner demonstrations designed to show the danger and degradation emanating from narcotics addiction.

Representatives of commerce and industry gave qualified approval yesterday to a proposed change in the city's Zoning Resolution that would allow some manufacturers to expand their plants and perhaps curtail the departure of business from the city.
The appointment of Prof. Harry G. Albaum as director of the division of graduate studies at Brooklyn College has been announced by Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of the college.

Native Street encountered no traffic difficulties whatever in racing to victory in the $30,300 Astoria Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The fleet filly, owned by Abraham Savin, set the pace all the way in the 5 1/2-furlong test for 2-year-old fillies, scoring by 2 1/2 lengths over the Birchfield Farm's Lyvette.
IF George Farkas had owned the Bloomingdale's on the corner of 59th Street and Lexington Avenue, he says he would not have allowed another department store to be built across the street.
Pennsylvania sold $27 million of bonds yesterday to finance the acquisition of fish-and-game and park land.
HOLLYWOOD, July 14 -- There is growing talk in Hollywood about forming a repertory film company that might produce pictures dealing with serious contemporary themes.

Prof. Preston R. Wilcox's harangue (July 2) against five civil rights leaders is an unfortunate example of the internecine bickering which cripples genuine efforts to cope with the difficulties faced by Negro citizens of New York.

MENEMSHA, Mass., July 14 -- America celebrates success, but occasionally it pauses to regret the men who didn't quite make it -- the also-rans, the good men who arrived near the top at the wrong time, the rejected and the disappointed.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 14 -- The police of the military junta withdrew by nightfall from a major checkpoint they had occupied in the city earlier today after concern was expressed over mounting agitation among the rebel adherents.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The decision of the Chase Manhattan Bank to convert to a national charter appeared certain today to add fuel to the continuing controversy over the policies of James J. Saxon, the Controller of the whose office regulates national banks.
ATHENS, July 14 -- Premier George Papandreou asked King Constantine today to sign a royal decree dismissing Petros Garoufalias as Defense Minister and to appoint the Premier in the place.
The financially ailing Wheeling Steel Corporation, which has been plagued with delays in its $175 million capital improvement program, reported some progress yesterday.

ROME, July 14 -- The Italian electricity monopoly's experiment in parallel issuance of bonds in six Common Market countries has fared well in Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg, but lagged in Germany, France and the Netherlands.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 14 -- Patrons at Roosevelt Raceway were urged repeatedly tonight to turn out early tomorrow night and to be prepared to stay late. The attraction: The introduction of the exacta, a form of wagering in which the bettors are asked to select the precise 1, 2 finish of the last race.
FALMOUTH, Mass., July 14 (AP) -- Nine bodies recovered from the Atlantic Ocean in the crash of a radar picket plane were identified today at the Otis Air Force Base near here.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -Gene Oliver's second home run of the game, in the seventh inning, paced the Milwaukee Braves to a 6-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today after the Cubs won the opener of a double-header, 5-2.
BIENHOA, South Vietnam, July 14 (AP) -- United States paratroopers at the Bienhoa air base won a major concession from their commanding officer today -- a beer ration.

After two days of public hearings on a civilian review board for the Police Department, the City Council's City Affairs Committee will take up the politically explosive question in executive session today.

POP ART, which Harold Rosenberg once described as "advertising art advertising itself as art that hates advertising," may deserve this book. Like pop art, "Pop Art" is chic, banal, unanalytical, anti-critical, historically vague, repetitive, fatuous, possibly a "put-on" (meaning possibly, legpulling, but whose leg?), up-to-the-minute (give or take a few years) and high-priced.

More than 400 persons celebrated Bastille Day at Rockefeller Center last night. From 9 o'clock on they gathered in the English Grill and the Cafe Francais and danced outdoors in the Promenade Restaurants in the local version of the street dancing traditional for Bastille Day in France.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 14 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, a nine-time winner and Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells, five times a runner-up, shared the first-round lead today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association championship.
MYSTIC, Conn., July 14 -- Two vote registrars are asking $10 each for having lifted Miss Vivien Kellems into the arms of the police after she sat down in a voting booth during the June 15 election.

PARIS, July 14 -- Economic experts of the French Government have come to the conclusion that the level of foreign and particularly American investments in France "is not excessive" in relation to the country's gross national product.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 14 -- Frank Sedgman of Australia was beaten in the opening round of the $15,000 United States professional grass court tennis championship today at the Longwood Cricket Club.
Two Bronx State Senators, long allied with Charles A. Buckley's Democratic organization, were reported yesterday to be planning to run independently in this year's primary.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, the largest state-chartered and third-largest commercial bank in the nation, disclosed yesterday it was giving up its 166-year-old state charter to become a national bank.
A sharp increase in the price of copper futures took the spotlight in the commodities market yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, July 14 -- Ignoring a Justice Department antitrust suit, the Falstaff Brewing Corporation's stockholders today approved acquisition of the Narragansett Brewing Company of Cranston, R.I.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Johnson declared today that merely lengthening the life span of the average American, while a "major achievement," was not enough.
The overseas traveler and his money soon may be abruptly and permanently parted through loss or theft, unless he takes the precautionary steps best suited to his needs.
In his letter of June 27 Ernest Nash three times implies that your June 15 editorial ("Strife in World Communism") was a "fruitless" analysis.
Prices were mostly steady in very quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
ALBANY, July 14 -- Governor Rockefeller, due back at his office tomorrow after a vacation in Venezuela, faces a pile of more than 600 bills.
I read with interest your June 30 editorial "The Northeast Rail Corridor."

A thousand persons, most of them women, will flock on Sept. 21 to Alexander's new store at Lexington Avenue and 58th Street for the International Haute Couture Fashion Show and Champagne Basket Luncheon.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A Senate bill calling for a three-year study of the feasibility of this country's adopting the metric system of weights and measures won wide support today.
Strikebound United States shipping lines called off mediation and bargaining sessions yesterday and canceled sailings of six more passenger ships on which more than 4,000 travelers had been booked.
To vote in the Nov. 2 elections, you must be registered.

LONDON. July 14 -- "The Creeper," which opened tonight at the St. Martin's Theater, is a first play by a new writer, Pauline Macaulay. It is a creepy piece about an eccentric millionaire who engages as a companion it young man whose apparent dullness is tempered by a weakness for strangling people.

A television newsman who chatted privately with Adlai E. Stevenson two days before his death said yesterday that the United States representative at the United Nations wanted to quit his post but was not sure how or when to tell President Johnson.
The latest manufacturing plant set up by a small businessman in New York City is a $250,000 garden compost factory opened formally yesterday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
The election of E.F. Laux as marketing vice president of the Ford Motor Company was announced yesterday in Dearborn, Mich., by Henry Ford 2d, chairman.
Cummings Point Farm, a 121-acre estate fronting on Long Island Sound in Stamford, Conn., has been sold by C. Russell Feldmann to a group of businessmen headed by Alphonsus J. Donahue Jr.

CELINA, Tenn., July 14 (AP) -- Welby Lee, who traveled 100,000 miles in search of the man who drove the car that killed his father, heard a jury convict Grover Jones of involuntary manslaughter today. Mr. Lee said unemotionally, "Justice was done."
The Polaroid Corporation will give its new inexpensive Land camera a rather expensive sendoff this fall.
It has been suggested that the Democratic party county committee in each of the five counties of New York City hold a special meeting to choose the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

PARIS, July 14 -- President de Gaulle watched proudly today as part of his budding strategic bomber force swept across a gray sky for the first time to open the annual Bastille Day parade with an accent on France's new atomic power.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Alarmed by mounting costs of the expanding war in Vietnam, some Senators stepped up a drive today to increase the pending $45 billion annual Defense appropriation.

Moved by Consolidated Edison's eloquent plea for mercy, Civil Court Judge Pelham St. George Bissell 3d has fined the giant utility $50 for its latest air pollution violation instead of the maximum ($500) penalty asked by New York's Corporation Counsel. Con Ed can afford this fine without too great inconvenience; its yearly sales approach $800 million.
The election of Robert B. Anderson former Secretary of the Treasury, as a director of Pan American World Airways, was announced yesterday by Juan T. Trippe, chairman.
The state charter that the Chase Manhattan Bank is seeking to give up dates to 1799 and contains no mention of the banking business.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -President Johnson asked today that a report be submitted to him within a week on how the Federal Government could help alleviate the "urgent water problem" in the New England and Middle Atlantic States.
BONN, July 14 -- Eva Maria Mariotti, a darkly beautiful 47-year-old widow, was pronounced a free woman today in the climax of one of West Germany's most sensational postwar murder cases.
Loew's Theatres, Inc., reported yesterday sharp increases in earnings for the three and nine months ended May 31.

YONKERS, July 14 -- Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N.J., the defending champion and seeded No. 1, and Diane Matzner of West Hempstead, L.I., seeded No. 2, reached the final of the girls' Eastern clay courts tennis championship at The Racquet Club of Yonkers today.
MOSCOW, (Reuters) -- Russian women will no longer find all their friends wearing the same new dresses, a Soviet newspaper maintains.

Zohra Lampert, a New York actress for 10 years, will be elevated to stardom in the title role of David Rayfiel's new drama, "Nathan Weinstein's Daughter." The play is to be presented the week of Feb. 7 on Broadway by Philip Rose. Several weeks of local previews will be given.
FREEPORT, L.I., July 14 -- In a startling nautical version of the tortoise and the hare, a 20-foot Owens won the seventh annual Around Long Island Marathon today.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 14 -- Members of the Government and Opposition parties battled with their fists in the National Assembly tonight in a dispute over the South Korean-Japanese treaty of amity. A free-for-all took place on the speaker's platform.
Second-quarter earnings of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation rose 69 per cent from the 1963 level on a 29 per cent sales gain, the company reported yesterday.

NEWARK, July 14 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Robert Shaw has refused to allow the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) to exchange its stock for all outstanding shares of stock in the Potash Company of America.
Should the New York Stock Exchange compile its own average, or index, of stock prices?
William Zeckendorf, who resigned recently as chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., has sold 2,250,000 common shares of the real-estate company in a private transaction.

ALBANY, July 14. -- The Appellate Division ruled unanimously today that private utilities must be reimbursed when they are forced to relocate facilities to make way for limited-profit housing in urban-renewal projects.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 14 -- Members of the Government and Opposition parties battled with their fists in the National Assembly tonight in a dispute over the South Korean-Japanese treaty of amity. A free-for-all took place on the speaker's platform.
Second-quarter earnings of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation rose 69 per cent from the 1963 level on a 29 per cent sales gain, the company reported yesterday.

NEWARK, July 14 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Robert Shaw has refused to allow the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) to exchange its stock for all outstanding shares of stock in the Potash Company of America.
Should the New York Stock Exchange compile its own average, or index, of stock prices?
William Zeckendorf, who resigned recently as chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., has sold 2,250,000 common shares of the real-estate company in a private transaction.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Don Buford slammed a two-run homer and Dave Nicholson rapped a two-run triple tonight as the Chicago White Sox defeated Los Angeles, 5-2, and ended the Angels' four-game winning streak.
The elections of Arthur P. Taylor, Clifford J. Thompson and Frederick W. Turner as vice presidents of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company were announced yesterday by Harold H. Helm, chairman.

BUDAPEST -- The striking thing about Communist Hungary is that despite angry official warnings the Vietnam crisis is bound to lead to disaster if U.S. policy doesn't change, there is an easy lack of tension along the Danube's summery banks.

The State Housing Finance Agency yesterday granted what it termed the largest single mortgage loan ever made -- $250.9 million -- to build Co-op City, a 15,500-apartment cooperative in the Baychester area of the northeast Bronx.
The state appealed yesterday a landmark decision that a child born as a result of the rape of a patient in a state mental institution might recover damages for having been brought into life.

ATHENS, July 15 -- Premier George Papandreou, who has been in bitter dispute with King Constantine, resigned today. The 25-year-old King immediately designated the President of Parliament, George Athanassiades-Novas, to head a new Government.
The American Stock Exchange showed little sparkle in yesterday's trading. Volume rose slightly to 1.14 million shares from 1.12 million shares on Wednesday, but no clear-cut pattern evolved.

In their present pitiful condition, the New York Yankees are grateful for any victory that comes their way. None could be cheaper, however, than the 2-1 decision they gained over the Washington Senators in 12 innings at Yankee Stadium last night.
The Pan American Sulphur Company said yesterday it had received a written offer from the United Nuclear Corporation to purchase all its assets.
The Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill was named president of St. John's University yesterday to succeed the Very Rev. Edward J. Burke, who has headed St. John's since 1961.

Mrs. Cooper Schieffelin, the only sister of Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican Liberal designee for Mayor, was found dead early yesterday in the swimming pool on her 11-acre estate in Laurel Hollow L.I.
PASADENA, Calif., July 15 -- The pictures of Mars that were made by Mariner 4 are being transmitted to earth as a series of 5 million radio signals representing zeros and ones.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Senate sent to President Johnson today a bill to eliminate all silver from dimes and quarters and cut the silver content in half-dollars from 90 to 40 per cent. The House passed the measure yesterday by a vote of 255 to 151.

CLEVELAND, July 15 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Fred Whitfield and clutch singles by Joe Azcue and Pedro Gonzalez were the key hits as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6-3, tonight ending a six-game losing streak.
The jury that had been deliberating the fate of Gareth Martinis reached a "hopeless deadlock" yesterday and was discharged.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Johnson wants to name Thurgood Marshall to be the first Negro on the Supreme Court, according to informed comment on the President's selection of Judge Marshall to be Solicitor General.

The City Council, voting 27 to 8 yesterday, approved legislation on the combined state-city sales tax program that will take effect Aug. 1. Republican Councilmen attacked their Democratic colleagues for "rubber-stamping" the State Legislature.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Little old ladies, in tennis shoes or not, no longer are busy transferring their nest eggs from one savings and loan association to another in order to obtain new-account premiums and fractional interest-rate differentials.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- A Congressional committee is stepping into the jurisdictional dispute between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union.

A Harlem bank was ordered yesterday to turn over to Mrs. Esther James nearly $18,000 that had been collected to help Representative Adam Clayton Powell pay off a defamation judgment the 68-year-old widow had obtained against him.

Twenty years ago today the first explosion of an atomic bomb took place at Almagordo, N.M. In the train of this historic act, the world has become an ever-more dangerous place in which to live as the number and destructive power of nuclear weapons has steadily increased, along with the growing roll of nations that have achieved nuclear capability.

Appointments to the new positions of executive director and managing director of the American Press Institute of Columbia University were announced yesterday by the university's president, Dr. Grayson Kirk.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Commerce Department estimated today that retail sales amounted to $5.07 billion in the week ended July 10, virtually unchanged from the level in the week last year.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- If the merger of the Pure Oil Company and the Union Oil Company of California occurs before Aug. 12, special dividends will be paid on Pure's common stock, the company's directors announced today.
How is it helicopters are now flying at low altitudes across the middle of Manhattan?

I find myself in disagreement with Walter Mendelsohn when in his letter (Times, July 9) he expressed the view that since the "opinions expressed in The New York Times are accepted as gospel" all over the world, you should remain silent, rather than express any "hostile viewpoint," concerning world affairs.

A search by at least 300 patrolmen and detectives yesterday in parks and wooded areas near Flushing, Queens, failed to turn up a clue to a missing 5-year-old boy, who was apparently abducted with his 4-year-old sister from a Kew Gardens Hills apartment early Wednesday morning.

With a week remaining of the 30-day bill-signing period, Governor Rockefeller has returned from a brief Venezuela vacation to dispose of some 600 bills left of the 1,100 originally sent him by the Legislature. Under fire from both left and right wings of his own party, the Governor's action on two measures passed by the Democratic majorities in the Legislature in fulfillment of their party's platform will be watched with especial interest by political observers.
Most of the major commodities traded on the nation's exchanges showed gains yesterday in moderately active trading.

PASADENA, July 15 -- The first close-up picture of another planet ever received on earth shows "clouds, a canal" and other odd features, but none of them is real, according to Dr. R.B. Leighton of the California Institute of Technology.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 15 -- Ecuador's military junta announced today that it was prepared to revise its timetable for restoring constitutional government and perhaps shorten its own stay in power.
The British pound gained yesterday in moderate dealings on foreign exchange markets here.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Intercity truck tonnage and rail-freight carloadings in the Independence Day holiday week ended July 10 were considerably below the corresponding week of 1964. The holiday was not observed during the comparable week last year.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Five baby trumpeter swans, described as the first ever hatched in captivity in this country, skimmed around Bird Lake at the Philadelphia Zoological Gardens today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Republican leaders in Congress joined today in calling on President Johnson for advance consultation if he decided to step up United States ground fighting in South Vietnam or to call up the reserves.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 -- American and Vietnamese commanders, appraising the first seven weeks of the Communist monsoon offensive, have found their losses high in manpower but low in territory.
The Metropolitan Opera, now rounding out the fourth week off its first summer at Lewisohn Stadium, has apparently provided considerable stimulus fort outdoor music in Manhattan.

ROME, July 15 (AP) -- The Jesuit Order, Roman Catholicism's largest religious group vowed today "new initiatives" to reach atheists and announced that its Superior General's term of office would continue to be for life.
The Mississippi Power Company sold yesterday $11 million of first mortgage bonds and 50,000 shares of preferred stock to finance expansion in the southeastern part of the state that it serves.
Monroe County, Tenn., sold yesterday $3 million of school bonds to an underwriting syndicate managed by the First National Bank of Memphis.

The interminable strike of marine engineers and other ships' officers has obliged the Department of Defense to patch together what amounts to a commandeered naval auxiliary of fast cargo vessels to insure delivery of adequate military supplies for the war in Vietnam. Strikebound ships are being moved out of idleness and being placed under charter to the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service.
ROME, July 15 -- If the citizens of the European communist world ever get a cheap family car in which to learn the joys of Sunday driving it is quite likely to look like an Italian Fiat.

TORONTO, July 15 -- Slim Bruce Devlin of Canberra, Australia, recovered for a par 5 from beneath a spruce at the 18th hole in the $100,000 Canadian Open golf championship today for a 66. The par gave him a one-stroke advantage and a 36-hole aggregate of 134.

STRASBOURG, France, July 15 -- World Jewish leaders are holding quiet talks with Russian diplomats to bring about the formation of a central body to represent the Jews of the Soviet Union and to participate in international Jewish affairs.

A THOUSAND years ago the world was full of frightening mysteries, witches, devils, evil spirits, miracles and magic. Today the world is full of even more mysteries incomprehensible to all save a new priesthood of learned initiates, mysteries such as electric light bulbs, telephones, radio, television, guided missiles, hydrogen bombs and whatever other appalling devices the scientists disclose next week.
PARIS -- Foreigners often get their first taste of claustrophobia in a typical French apartment.

The Socialist Workers party said yesterday it had designated three citywide and two Manhattan candidates for the city election, and has asked support from another left-wing group, the Progressive Labor party.
The city's right to borrow $255.8 million was sustained yesterday in a Brooklyn court when a taxpayer's challenge was tossed out.

JERSEY CITY, July 15 -- A small, two engined plane skimmed over a freight train and a 36-inch natural gas main, narrowly missed a structure that contained 3 million cubic feet of natural gas, struck a heavy wire fence and burst into pieces between two huge gas and oil storage tanks here at 10:30 A.M. today.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., July 14 -- A thousand acres of wooded hillsides here that two years ago had only one resident -- a hermit in a cave -- today had 500 children paddling canoes, shooting arrows, exploring an Indian burial ground and learning the ways of frogs and raccoons.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Faulty equipment, poor judgment and inaccurate weather information contributed to the airline crash near Zephyr Cove, Nev., on March 1, 1964, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.
LONDON, July 15 -- President Ho Chi Mirth of North Vietnam has invited President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana to visit Hanoi, reports in London said tonight.

Representative William F. Ryan, Reform Democratic candidate for mayor, criticized Bronx Democratic Leader Charles A. Buckley yesterday and called for a "new approach to politics through the Democratic party."
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A joint Federal-state study of the development of the Hudson River was proposed today by Representative John G. Dow, Democrat of Rockland County, New York.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- General Lucius D. Clay, the new Republican finance chairman, tightened his grip on party fund-raising activities today and announced plans for his first big money-raising dinner.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The American Bar Association has canceled two dinner parties Scheduled at the Bath Club in Miami Beach during its annual meeting in August because the club does not admit Jews and Negroes to membership.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., June 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson will be buried here Monday near the grave of his grandfather and namesake, Adlai Ewing Stevenson, Vice President of the United States during Grover Cleveland's second administration.
In a letter sent to stockholders yesterday, the directors of McKesson Robbins, Inc., advised shareholders to reject the tender offer of the Glen Alden Corporation.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 15 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan has lashed back angrily at President Johnson's decision to withhold United States economic aid to Pakistan.

ON Wednesday night the New York Philharmonic's French-American Festival at Philharmonic Hall opened with a French program. Last night it was the United States' turn, or, more strictly, the turn of one American composer -- Leonard Bernstein.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 -- After more than five months of steady aerial bombardment of North Vietnam, military sources here are convinced that the Hanoi regime's support of the Vietcong war effort in South Vietnam has been seriously impeded.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 15 (UPI) -- Norman Mailer, the author, and several university professors denounced President Johnson and his policies in South Vietnam at a Harvard teach-in last night that was attended by more than 2,000 summer school students.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15 -- A memorial service for Adlai E. Stevenson will be held at 3 P.M. Monday in the General Assembly Hall, the United States mission announced today. Secretary of State Dean Rusk will speak.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Industrial production rose another half point on the Federal Reserve Index in June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Delay in reaching a settlement in the Dominican crisis is reported to be increasing sentiment among Latin-American diplomats here for postponing the special inter-American conference scheduled to open in Rio de Janeiro Aug. 4.

The Xerox Corporation shattered all records in sales and earnings in the second quarter and half year ended June 30, the report of Joseph C. Wilson, president and chief executive officer disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Johnson signed a bill today designed to restrict illicit traffic in stimulant and depressant pills.

Henry T. Heald, who has directed the giving away of $1.7 billion of the Ford Foundation's funds, announced yesterday that he would retire as its president Dec. 31. A successor has not yet been appointed.

CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) -- A controversial home run by Jim Coker and Tommy Harper's two-run double paced the National League-leading Cincinnati Reds to an 8-1 rout of the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported yesterday sharply increased sales and earnings for the three and six months ended June 30.
It was a busy day yesterday at the Time and Life Building. After a board of directors meeting, Time, Inc., announced:
ST. LOUIS, July 15 -- An error here, a wild pitch there and some inadequate relief pitching tonight helped the New York Mets turn an early 5-0 lead into another defeat -- their fourth in a row.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charged 10 employers and five labor unions with racial discrimination today. It was the first major series of complaints filed under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

WHAT'S going to happen to television now that the Nielsen families know they are important? The deeper consequences of last Monday night's documentary on ratings are beginning to dawn on anxious executives.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- President Johnson's omnibus farm bill cleared the House Agriculture Committee today, 21 to 13, and headed for uncertain floor action, its fate largely in the hands of city Democrats.

Three policemen refused to sign waivers of immunity yesterday before a grand jury investigating possible bribery in illegal abortions. The case opened a challenge on how much self-incrimination public employes may be compelled to risk.
PASADENA, July 15 -- Mariner 4 has sent to earth the first close-up photograph of Mars.
Mayor Wagner appointed a college 'dropout' to fill a vacancy on the Board of Education yesterday.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 15 -- The city that Adlai Stevenson said gave him the best years of his life today awaited his final return.
WHITE SANDS, N.M., July 15 -- The desert sun and sand have softened the scars of the world's first nuclear explosion, set off in the desert here 20 years ago tomorrow.
A great outpouring of condolences and sympathy from abroad indicated yesterday that in the death of Adlai E. Stevenson, the United States lost an important asset on the world scene.
CORNING, N.Y., July 15 (AP) -- Three former golf champions remained in the running today at the close of the second round of match play in the New York State women's amateur golf tourney.
OSLO, Norway, July 15 (AP) -- Lieut. Billy Mills of the United ed States Marines won handily from his teammate, Bob Schul, in a 5,000-meter run tonight at Bislet Stadium.
BONN, July 15 -- Former Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss won a victory today in his protracted libel suit against Rudolf Augstein, publisher of the news magazine Der Spiegel.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- Repertory theater, new to Pittsburgh, opened here tonight at a black-tie premiere, followed by a champagne party. The theater was sold out, and 540 persons, including financial, social and government leaders, attended.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve, William McChesney Martin Jr., cautioned Senators today that the recent improvement in the nation's balance of payments did not mean the problem had been solved.
ALBANY, July 15 -- A bill abolishing blue-ribbon juries in New York State was signed today by Governor Rockefeller.
Television drama may make a comeback this fall on Channel 13.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The chief United States negotiator in the Kennedy round of global tariff-cutting bargaining warned today that the United States would refuse to reduce its trade barriers more than the other main industrial trading nations.
