What's in a name? Well, a filly by the name of Valiant Queen won the Queens Chamber of Commerce Purse, the feature race on the program at Aqueduct yesterday. She won in so convincing a manner as to delight those in the crowd of 26,071 who made her the odds-on favorite.

WHEN Barbara Cavanagh is married to Mayor Wagner July 26 in a chapel of St. Patricks Cathedral, she will be wearing a hat made especially for her and .given to her by Mrs. Therese Ahrens, for whom she used to work.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's Ambassador at Large, conferred for more than three hours today with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin in what Mr. Harriman called a "significant" discussion of Soviet-American relations.

THE notation beside Boat No. 6X had said "Out at Greenport Harbor, engine trouble," but Harold Levy's entry in Wednesday's Around Long Island Marathon turned out to be a lot farther out than that. At 9:45 A.M. yesterday, 26 hours after the start of the race at Freeport, L. I., Levy an(t his co*driver, Tom (Buzz) Millard, were still aboard 6X -- drifting helplessly in thick fog off Block Island.
ITHACA, N.Y., July 15 -- Final tabulations made today on Cornell University's centennial campaign for capital funds showed that $75,580,000 had been riased.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Adlai E. Stevenson returned tonight to a nation that mourned him in death as deeply as it had admired him in life. The Presidential plane bearing his body touched down at 6:35 P.M. Eastern daylight time at Andrews Air Force Base, 15 miles from Washington.
Prices were quietly firm yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Interest centered on insurance, tobacco and steel issues.
MILWAUKEE, July 15 (AP) -- A relief pitcher, Dan Osinski, snuffed out a Pirate attempt to overcome a nine-run deficit as the Milwaukee Braves defeated Pittsburgh, 9-6, tonight.
Mutual funds were a stabilizing force in the stock market during the recent downturn, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, July 15 -- Motion picture executives these days are pondering a paradox that holds good and bad tidings for the future of their industry.

Although I have long been a supporter of Senator Maurine Neuberger in her efforts to decrease disease, disability and death from cigarette smoking in the United States, I cannot agree with her letter of July 14 that the bill just passed by the Congress "does provide a foundation . . . upon which future effort and affirmative action can be taken."

The Greystone, a seven-story apartment building in the Riverdale area of the Bronx, has been sold by the Greystone Hills Corporation to the Park Lane Realty Company for cash over a first mortgage of $1.04 million.

A FIELD of outstanding quality will compete tomorrow in a special pairs event organized by the Cavendish Club. It is intended primarily to give practice to expert partnerships preliminary to the Summer National Championships in Chicago next month.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that communications companies and not the Communications Satellite Corporation should handle television broadcasts via Comsat's Early Bird satellite.
LONDON, July 15 -- The sumptuous new production of "Swan Lake" by London's Festival Ballet at the new Victoria Theater had two new pairs of dancers yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Johnson is expected to act quickly to designate a successor to Adlai E. Stevenson as United States representative at the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- In the early days of his Presidency, Lyndon Johnson is supposed to have remarked that his support in the country was like a Western river -- wide but shallow. The remark probably had no special relevance to the specific question of his policy in South Vietnam, but in the months and years ahead the depth of that particular river may be thoroughly tested.

Earnings of the American Can Company in the three months ended June 30 were the highest for any quarter in its 64-year history. They lifted half-year profits to a record, according to the results announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 15 (UPI) -- Ham Richardson upset third-seeded Frank Froehling today to advance to a semi-final match against Dennis Ralston in the national clay courts tennis championship at suburban River Forest.

The city was accused yesterday of trying to condemn several downtown buildings so they could be purchased by two large property owners who are allegedly assembling land to sell to the New York Stock Exchange for its projected new building.

William H. McKeon, a controversial figure for two of his three years as Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday he would submit his resignation to the Democratic State Committee at a meeting called for July 27.
LONDON, July 15 -- The Premier of South Vietnam, Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky, has disavowed an alleged interview published in a London newspaper that quoted him as having called Hitler his hero.

BUENOS AIRES, July 15 -- A minor operatic scandal here resulted in the replacement of Giuseppe di Stefano by Richard Tucker in the dress rehearsal of Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera" at the Teatro Colon this afternoon.

The Olivetti Underwood Corporation has elected Gianluigi Gabetti as its president, it was made known yesterday following a meeting of the board. Mr. Gabetti succeeds Guido Lorenzotti, who will return to Italy to direct the commercial operations of Ing. C. Olivetti, S.p.A., parent organization of the Olivetti Underwood Corporation.

George Taylor of Houston and Mike Estep of Dallas eliminated the top-seeded players in the junior division quarter-finals of the Eastern junior and boys tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Johnson Administration committed itself today to an expansionary economic policy again next year with the aim of keeping the record boom going indefinitely.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 15 -- Three times within a stroke of losing the opening set, Malcolm Anderson of Australia defeated Alex Olmedo of Peru and Los Angeles today in the United States professional grass court tennis championship at the Longwood Cricket Club.

TOO many great athletes acquire blind spots when the end of the trail is clearly in view. They fail to see it even though everyone else recognizes the signposts that warn of the dead-end street. Released by the Milwaukee Braves last year after an unhappy, disastrous season, Warren Spahn took a risky detour, the New York Mets. But that also ended in an impasse.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 15 -- The United States Coast Guard icebreaker Northwind left Denmark today on a three-month scientific voyage that will take her into the Soviet Arctic. Northwind's basic mission is to provide "a floating platform" for civilian scientists aboard to conduct oceanographic and meteorological studies in the Barents and Kara Sea areas, for which scientific data is virtually nonexistent in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A Negro who has been trying to organize farm worker's in Mississippi has charged before two Congressional committees that tenants on the plantation owned by Senator James O. Eastland live in poverty and Squalor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 16 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and Henry Cabot Lodge, who is taking over as Ambassador to South Vietnam, arrived today for a survey of the need for more American combat troops in Vietnam.

Prentice-Hall is putting out a nine-volume series on the history of music. "Music in the Classic Period," by Reinhard G. Pauly, and "Folk and Traditional Music of the Western Continents," by Bruno Nettl, will be issued on Aug. 12.

COURMAYEUR, Italy, July 15 -- The Presidents of France and Italy will snip a ribbon tomorrow to open officially a seven-mile tunnel through the Alps that will profoundly change patterns of trade, tourism and traffic.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Navy exploded about 1,500 tons of obsolete ammunition under water off the Virginia Coast today, sending a plume of water 600 feet high.
OTTAWA, July 15 -- Raymond Denis, a former Cabinet aide, was arraigned today on charges of attempted bribery and obstruction of justice.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 15 (AP) -- More than 4,000 acres have been added to President Johnson's ranch properties in Texas since he entered the White House, The Minneapolis Tribune and The Des Moines (Iowa) Register said in a copyrighted article tonight.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 15 -- There were 151 yachts sailing in six classes in the Storm Trysail Club's Race Week competition today and not one became a winner although most completed the circuit of Block Island that was the order of the day.
AS the deluge of millinery showings finally ceases, the conclusion is inescapable that there is very little news in hats for fall but hundreds of reasons for women to start buying them.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 15 -- Laotians will elect their legislative body, the National Assembly, Sunday in an atmosphere of tension.
The net reserve position of New York City banks improved slightly in the week ended Wednesday, but much more narrowly than the Federal Reserve System as a whole.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a 56 per cent increase in earnings in the second quarter of this year.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk set aside more than an hour today to exchange views on United States policy in Vietnam with 18 New York City Democrats.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 (UPI) -- A 21-year-old college student advanced to the semi-finals of the national public links golf tournament today by defeating the defending champion, Bill McDonald, and another strong contender.

Though all its findings are not yet in, it is already clear that Mariner 4's historic journey to Mars is the most successful and most important experiment man has yet conducted in space, as well as one of the most brilliant engineering and scientific achievements of all time.
Mayor Wagner signed a bill yesterday banning the drinking of alcoholic beverages in public places by teen-agers.
DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Jerry Lumpe doubled and then scored on Al Kaline's single in the 10th inning to give the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 (AP) -- Don Drysdale pitched a three-hitter for his 14th victory and singled home two of Los Angeles' five runs in the fifth inning tonight as the Dodgers beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-0.

Scottsboro, Ala., announced yesterday the sale of $55 million of tax-exempt bonds to finance construction of an aluminum rolling mill. This is the largest issue of this controversial type of local government financing on record.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 15 -- Two former champions, Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge and Milton (Babe) Lichardus of Baltusrol, took charge of the 45th New Jersey open golf championship today with 36-hole totals of 137 -- three under par.

The jazz avant-garde came out last night when the Jazz Composers Orchestra played a program in the "Jazz in the Garden" series at the Museum of Modern Art. But even though the musicians moaned and fluttered and wailed in their customary fashion, most of their sounds drifted off aimlessly on the gentle night air, blending gracefully with honking horns and barking dogs.

The dynamic rate of growth of the chemical and drug industry continued in the second quarter. This was reflected in the record sales and earnings of five diversified com panies whose second-quarter and half-year results showed increases ranging up to 25 per cent above those last year.
Moscow, July 15 (AP) -- The United States, Britain and France accused the Soviet Union and East Germany today of failure to cooperate in West Germany's prosecution of Nazi war criminals.

Charges of graft and corruption in the city's $400 million-a-year school building program will be investigated by a special Kings County grand jury, District Attorney Aaron E. Koota announced yesterday.
LONDON, July 15 -- After 22 days and 220 hours of debate, the House of Commons tonight gave the longest and most complicated finance bill of the last half century its third and final reading.
Tennessee Williams has made extensive changes in "The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Anymore" for its presentation next Friday night by the Actors Workshop in San Francisco.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The House approved today the construction of a $431 million, 25-mile subway-rapid transit system for the District of Columbia, the country's fastest growing urban center.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, which has been on strike against eight of the nation's major ship operators since June 16, called yesterday for an immediate resumption of negotiations.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 15 -- Joseph and Terry McBride of the Arcola Country Club captured their second consecutive Metropolitan Golf Association father-and-son championship today, carding a 75 on the 6,461-yard par-71 Tuxedo Club course.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Administration forces narrowly rescued a rent subsidy plan as a $7.3 billion housing bill passed the Senate tonight.
Municipal bond sales, which started to quicken Wednesday, continued at even a faster pace yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service is telling taxpayers caught in last year's under-withholding bind to pay up by Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- More than 70 engineers will meet for a week in the heart of Appalachia next month to see what engineering can do for impoverished areas in the 11-state region.

The stock market started strong yesterday but finished comparatively weak. But profit taking and the usual pre-weekend balancing act and more to do with the late price declines than any underlying frailty.
Close political allies of Senator Jacob K. Javits are convinced he has the power to end Governor Rockefeller's reign in Albany in 1966 and are urging him to use it.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 15 -- Joe Namath, the man with the paid-for golden arm, threw passes that had beauty and brilliance. Cosmo Iacavazzi, the Princetonian, said that as long as he had one life to give, he would like to give it as a running back.

A high Government official praised American businessmen yesterday for their cooperation in curbing the outflow of dollars. He also made public, for the first time, details of the dollars-and-cents impact of President Johnson's voluntary program.

AREA A -- Kingfish are plentiful round the jetties in Long Branch. Some have been seen in the Surf City surf. Striped bass and blackfish also are near Long Branch. There are porgies and some blues at Brielle.

McGeorge Bundy's denial in The Times of July 5 of a view attributed to him by Prof. Henry Graff was no doubt made in perfectly good faith, but it is inaccurate if it implies that no one in the Administration holds any arrogant views as to America's role in the world.

THE householder who has recently whipped the covers off the old summer furniture and discovered to her horror -- guests coming up for the weekend, imminent party on the patio -- that it just won't do is in luck this year.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that the city needed Federal and state aid in its quest for new water supplies.

Frank Wille, State Superintendent of Banks, issued an urgent call yesterday for action on the Federal level to correct the inequalities between state-chartered and Federally-chartered commercial banks.

BOGALUSA, La., July 15 -- The Louisiana State Police announced sharp cutbacks today in the number of troopers on duty in this racially torn town, and city officials immediately said they feared for the safety of the populace.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- The 6, 4 daily double paid $102.60, the 2, 2, 2, 3 twin double $593.60 and the 3, 8 exacta $77.20. Since bingo, roulette and dice were not on the program, those accounted for the returns on the extracurricular wagering tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, where it was possible to make bets on an even dozen propositions, including nine races.
LONDON, July 15 -- The body of Adlai E. Stevenson rested in honor for a few hours today at the American Embassy and then was flown home.
A Negro ex-convict was fatally shot by a rookie policeman in a fight yesterday at the busy intersection of Nostrand Avenue and Fulton Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 15 (UPI) -- A two-out two-run double by Tom Reynolds in the ninth inning of the second game gave Kansas City a split with Minnesota in a twilight-night double-header tonight. The score in the final was 3-2 after the Twins had taken the opener, 7-2.

Domestic airline passengers will soon be allowed to carry free as much weight as they can get into two pieces of luggage, according to a change in regulations announced yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Justice Department took a new tack here this week in its long dispute with the Supreme Court over the rights of criminal suspects.
Police photographers riding three helicopters photographed swamps, woods and deserted areas around Flushing yesterday in an effort to locate a missing 5-year-old Queens boy.
SAIGON, July 16 -- The United States military command confirmed today the presence of a regiment of the North Vietnamese Army in South Vietnam.

A 26-year-old patrolman and three civilians were arrested yesterday in connection with an alleged attempt to extort $2,500 from Robert Gibson, a Greenwich Village singer and guitarist, according to Deputy Police Commissioner Joseph Martin.

The United Nuclear Corporation is trying to acquire the Pan American Sulphur Company to "get us into another basic industry in which we see profit possibilities in the future," Walter F. O'Connell, chairman of United Nuclear, said at his concern's annual meeting yesterday.
COURMAYEUR, Italy, July 26 -- The Presidents of France and Italy proclaimed today the new 7 1/4 -- mile vehicular tunnel through the heart of Mont Blanc to be a great symbolic achievement for Europe.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 16 (AP) -- Trustees of the New Haven Railroad filed today with the United States District Court their first formal report on creditors' claims against the bankrupt carrier.

A multiplicity of happenings took place in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, a 1 1/8-mile turf event that was won by the Mill River Stable's Ribot's Fling. In scoring, Ribot's Fling finished in front of the odds-on favorite, Roy Kidder's Flag, by a neck, with a pair of dead-heaters, Ginger Fizz and Alina, coming next, 1 1/2 lengths behind.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 17, (AP) -- The Defense Ministry announced today that Col. Pham Ngoc Thao, leader of at least two unsuccessful coup attempts, was killed yesterday by South Vietnamese security forces.
The AVCO Corporation would expand its financing operations through the proposed acquisition of the Iowa Finance Company, of Omaha, Neb.
WASHINGTON, July 16--Adlai E. Stevenson, twice denied the nation's highest office, was given a national funeral today in recognition of his services to his country.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that during the first half of 1965 it placed $3.4 million -- the major part of its net revenues -- into a special trust fund.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Statewide Airlines of Brooklyn has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to provide scheduled air service in New England.

Father Eugene J. Molloy's letter of July 8 describing the participation of the Brooklyn Diocesan school system in Project Head Start was a deeply moving account of a great institution's involvement in one of the important, imaginative and valuable programs undertaken by the Office of Economic Opportunity.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of David R. Baldwin of Pennsylvania as Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

When the Ford Company of Antwerp, Belgium, takes delivery shortly on the first shipment of a $200,000 order of heat-resisting alloy trays and other fixtures it will do so with the knowledge that is saving time and money.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 -- The New York Mets wasted four home runs and outdid themselves in poor defense tonight, as they allowed the St. Louis Cardinals to overtake them and finally win, 8-5, before 16,175 persons at Busch Stadium.
LONDON, Saturday, July 17 (Reuters) -- Adlai E. Stevenson had no wish to act as a "screen" for "policy inspired" by the hawks of Washington," the Moscow radio said today.

A DIMINUTIVE designer who left the tribulations of Seventh Avenue less than 18 months ago for the joys of custom dressmaking is hoping to combine the best of both worlds this fall. Arnold Scaasi has been approached by several stores that are interested in buying models from his custom collection for reproduction purposes.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- Mr. Harriman said today that it was up to the North and South Vietnamese, not the United States and the Soviet Union, to arrive at a settlement of the Vietnam war.
The management of the bankrupt Yale Express System, Inc., turned yesterday to James R. Hoffa for help in trying to make the big trucking company profitable again.
Mortimer M. Caplin, the court-appointed trustee in the reorganization of Webb Knapp, Inc., will seek to auction the Paramount Building Aug. 31.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 16 -- A 23-year-old soldier who had been on a hunger strike as a conscientious objector was discharged from the Army today.

ONE of the major Italian national championships is a contest in which each team represents a city. Distances prohibit such an event in the United States, although a match between teams representing two cities is held each year before the Summer Nationals.
Civil Court Judge Mario A. Procaccino of the Bronx announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Controller as an independent.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 16 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics chased Jim Grant with a four-run first inning tonight and went on to trounce the Minnesota Twins, 10-2.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 16 -- Miograd Bulatovic, the best known of Yugoslavia's younger writers, faces the prospect of having his latest novel banned in this country while it is published in three other countries.
BONN, July 16 -- The United States has begun to draw upon its pool of highly trained combat troops in Western Europe to reinforce its growing forces in Vietnam.
In your obituary for Ralph Courtney, printed on July 2, you refer to him as a "disciple" of Rudolf Steiner, the founder of the "spiritualistic and mystical Anthroposophical Movement."

Representative Robert E. Sweeny, Democrat of Ohio, has demanded that the Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission investigate the pending merger of the Pure Oil Company and the Union Oil Company of Ohio.
STOCKHOLM, July 16 -Ingmar Bergman will start shooting a new film, "Persona," in the middle of August. The premiere is scheduled for the fall of 1966.
BONN, July 16 -- Willy Brandt, national chairman of the opposition Social Democratic party, proposed today a reform of the North Atlantic alliance, granting all members a voice in strategic planning.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Space officials said today that the Soviet Union's launching of a 26,000-pound space vehicle was a "very substantial achievement" but not wholly unexpected.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- W. Tapley Bennett Jr., the United States Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that there was "a strong Communist influence" from the beginning in the Dominican revolt.
MOSCOW, July 16 (Reuters) -- A Soviet critic today accused the United States entry for the Moscow Film Festival shorts competition of being "a rose-colored lie."

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- Organized labor and the food processing industry lined up today on opposite sides on President Johnson's request for increases in "penalty overtime" and a cutback in overtime pay exemptions for seasonal industries.
Prices of grain futures started slow and then firmed on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
PASADENA, Calif., July 16 -- From Mariner 4 data presented here today, Mars emerges as an even more inhospitable place than previously supposed.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Twenty years after the first atomic bomb, Federal spending for the peaceful atom has finally drawn abreast of spending for nuclear weapons.
Wall Street drowsed in the summer sun yesterday.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -The Boston Maine Railroad has filed exceptions with the Interstate Commerce Commission to a report by I.C.C. escaminers recommending approval of a Pennsylvania-New York Central railroad merger.
Robert Moses submitted a revised plan yesterday for a proposed bridge-causeway across Long Island Sound that would link Westchester and Nassau Counties.

MONTREAL -- Within a few weeks, Canada's "oldest stock exchange" will enter the final phase of planning for a shift to new quarters that will make its facilities one of the most up to date in the world.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 16 -- Dr. Sidney Weinberg, Suffolk County Medical Examiner, revealed today that Lisa Howard, former television reporter who died here on July 4 at the East Hampton Medical Group of an overdose of sleeping pills, had taken enough barbiturates to kill five persons.

Relations between the United States and Pakistan, which at one time were excellent, have unfortunately been steadily worsening. Washington's displeasure at the growing friendship between President Mohammad Ayub Khan's government and Communist China has been no secret for a long time. It was widely regarded as the main reason President Johnson last spring suddenly called off his scheduled meeting with the Pakistani leader.

A cautious feeling that trouble in the streets can be averted this summer prevails in Harlem, where violence erupted a year ago tomorrow over the fatal shooting of a Negro youth by a white police officer.

" Caribbean Crisis," by Jay Mallin, will be published by Doubleday as a paperback on Aug. 6, four weeks after the manuscript reached the editorial office. Mr. Mallin flew to the Dominican Republic to cover the revolt in April.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 16 -E.W. (Skip) Etchells opened defense of the Corry Cup, emblematic of Great South Bay Star Class supremacy, by posting a first and a second today in the initial events of the five-race series that continues over the weekend.

A preliminary survey of 62 investment companies shows that shares of metals and mining concerns constituted the fa-favorite group for portfolio advorite group for portfolio additions in the second quarter.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 -- The Security Council was summoned today to meet at 10:30 A.M. Tuesday on the situation in the Dominican Republic.
BOGALUSA, La., July 16 -Jeering segregationists attacked civil rights pickets six times at a shopping center here today while Louisiana state police troopers looked on 50 yards away.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 16 -- At least 47 persons died and more than 70,000 were driven from their homes today when floods swept many parts of central Korea. An additional 38 persons were reported to be missing.

The National Urban League and its local branches throughout the country have quietly become an important channel through which Federal funds are being moved into manpower training, retraining and other facets of the antipoverty program.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 16 -- Premier Moise Tshombe has put off a dispute with President Joseph Kasavubu over who should fill two vacant ministries in his Cabinet by taking on both the portfolios himself.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan refused today to prohibit New York State officials from holding a special legislative election next fall.

Japan's top trade official said yesterday he was confident his country would increase export sales to $10 billion a year by 1968. This would be a rise of more than one-third over last year's $6.7 billion.
BONN, July 16 -- West Germany's Federal Bank has disclosed plans to transfer $116 million from its account in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to the Bank of England.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 16 -- Kenneth Rosewall and Malcolm Anderson of Australia put on a display of shimmering ground strokes that held a gallery of 3,500 entranced at the Longwood Cricket Club today. They received a standing ovation when the superbly fought match ended with Rosewall the victor, 6-1, 10-12, 6-4.

TOKYO, July 16 -- A 172-acre man-made island of refuse in Tokyo Bay, planned as a future beauty spot, was drenched in oil and set afire today in an attempt to eradicate a plague of flies that has made nearby areas of the city all but uninhabitable.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -The index of wholesale primary market prices rose one-tenth of 1 per cent to 102.6 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended July 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Funeral services were held here yesterday for Nathaniel Nakasa, the 28-year-old South African writer who jumped or fell to his death early Wednesday from the apartment of a friend at 418 Central Park West.

The two men who guide the destinies of two of the best-known brand names in the men's furnishings field, Arrow and B.V.D., come from different backgrounds but have a similar view about the importance of salesmanship to success.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A White House spokesman said today that the LBJ Company had leased 5,00 to 6,000 additional acres of land for grazing purposes since President Johnson assumed office late in 1963.
BRUSSELS July 16 -- Walter Hallstein denied "emphatically" today that he wished to resign as president of the Common Market Commission.
The Johnson Administration has intervened to unsnarl the tangled threads of the immigration reform bill in the House.

A television viewer tuned to Channel 13 was amazed last night to find the Detroit-Baltimore baseball game coming in from WJZ-TV in Baltimore after the educational station WNDT in Newark had left the air.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Government officials -- alarmed by water shortages in New England and the Middle Atlantic States -- are considering the possibility of constructing an elaborate network of pipes to transfer water from surplus areas to areas stricken by drought.

NELSON, England, July 16 -- After helping local authorities raise hundreds of thousands of pounds every day, Mrs. Kathleen Starkie and the three other Nelson housewives joke at quitting time every night about the need to stretch housekeeping budgets to buy a pair of nylons.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Floyd Robinson, who had tied the game earlier with a two-run double, tripled home the winning run in the 11th inning as the Chicago White Sox gained a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.

A revolution in the making is likely to shape man's destiny even more profoundly than the one that was signaled 20 years ago by the first atomic explosion, according to the editor of a leading scientific journal.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 16 -- Jacinto Vasquez completed three days of extraordinary campaigning today at Monmouth Park as he rode five winners. Four of the victories came in the last four races.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 16 -- Most of the 62 Opposition lawmakers signed resignations from the National Assembly today to demonstrate their determination to block "by all means" ratification of the controversial treaty between South Korea and Japan.
GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 16 (AP) -- Carol Mann and Marilynn Smith tied for first place today with two-under-par 70's in the first round of the $15,000 Yankee women's open golf tournament.

PARIS, July 16 (Reuters) -Britain, supported by the European maritime powers, rejected today a United States demand that information about trans-Atlantic freight rate disparities be made public. The issue was shelved indefinitely.

PARIS, July 16 -- A five-year $400 million dollar aid commitment by France has contributed to a new Sahara-oil accord with Algeria, informed sources said tonight. French and Algerian negotiators reached an agreement here Tuesday night after 20 months of intermittent bargaining.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -A six-man Davis Cup squad headed by Dennis Ralston and Arthur Ashe Jr., was named today to play in the American Zone final at Dallas July 31 to Aug. 2.

ROME, July 16 -- No people in the world feud with quite the same energy and eloquence as the Italians, who actually blossom during a long, nasty skirmish. Furthermore, the Italians are rarely selfish about these feuds: They would not dream of depriving an ignorant outsider of a chance to join the fray.
BLOCK Island, R.I., July 16 -- The Cowes silver tankard from England, with its hands-across-the-sea implications in the world of yachting, finally gained a winner today, after three days of trying.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- The new chief of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division said today he hoped to issue enforcement guidelines so businessmen could tell when mergers might bring Government prosecution.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed firm yesterday although initial advances, resulting from a government statement that no further economic measures were in prospect, were not fully held.
FISH cooked over an open fire is the dream of many an amateur fisherman as he heads for lake, stream or bay.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- The Soviet Union successfully fired today a powerful new booster rocket that put into orbit the heaviest payload ever launched, an unmanned space vehicle called Proton 1.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 16 (UPI) -- The New York Jets went through their first workout today, concentrating on fundamentals in morning and afternoon sessions.
LONDON, July 16 -- The London commuter is a quiet, aloof, meticulous, punctual chap rarely given to excesses.

BOONTON, N.J., July 16 -The defending champion, Mrs. George Dwyer of White Beeches, and Mrs. Jack Harris of Montclair tied for first today at the end of 36 holes in the 14th annual Women's New Jersey Seniors golf championship at the Knoll Golf Club.
CINCINNATI, July 16 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds scored a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phils tonight behind the five-hit pitching of Sammy Ellis.
A concert performance of Puccini's "La Boheme" was given by the Metropolitan Opera at Lewisohn Stadium last night, with Licia Albanese and Barry Morell.

Four detectives and two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents recovered stolen coins and postage stamps valued at $40,000 in a raid yesterday afternoon on an apartment at 877 Bay Ridge Avenue, Brooklyn, according to the police.
ATHENS, July 16 -- Violence broke out tonight in downtown Athens as the new 15-man Government led by Premier George Athanassiades-Novas was sworn in.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Radio Corporation of America has found a cure for the television affliction called snivets.

The greatest of all the artists of the rough and ready American West of the eighteen-eighties and nineties? Leave it to the cowboy buffs if you want to get a unanimous canyon-filling shout for an answer. And that shout would be for Charlie Russell, who signed his oils and watercolors "C.M. Reports of a growing world silver shortage are prompting private interests to melt down coins for their silver content.

IN "Atomic Diplomacy," Gar Alperovitz presents an intensive study of a critical four-month period in the closing days of World War II -- spring to September, 1945. The author's purpose is to show that the atomic bomb played a major role in the formation of American policy with Russia, particularly in connection with President Truman's meeting with Stalin at the Potsdam Conference, July-August, 1945.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, July 17 -- The army was reported today to have captured a diary in Spanish that had been kept by a Cuban fighting with the rebels in the eastern Congo. Its author was said to have been killed in a skirmish.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- Five scientist have been named to receive the 1965 John Scott awards as "ingenious men who make useful inventions."

The phrases Mr. Crowther uses to describe "What's New Pussycat?" (June 27) are the giveaways of the generation of taste that he is a member of. To say that the comedy is "unwholesome" and "antagonistic toward the disciplines of society" is to date oneself in the era when comedies had to be "wholesome" to be funny and it was unreasonable to be "antagonistic toward the disciplines of society."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 17 -- Ed Charles, a pinch-hitter for a pinch-hitter, drove in Rene Lachemann with a ninth-inning sacrifice fly today and lifted the Kansas City Athletics to a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins. The triumph was the A's third straight victory over the American League leaders.

FAR from diminishing, the number of lavishly produced art books, trophies of coffee-table culture, actually seems to be on the increase. One wonders if the market is large enough to absorb them all, if the public won't soon have too much of a good thing. Apparently not.

OTTAWA, July 18 -- Canadian financial observers are busily assessing, with somewhat mixed emotions, the first official Government figures ever issued on payments made to foreign investors, corporate managements and unions in a single year.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A group of 17 leading citizens, forming a committee of the Atlantic Council, strongly recommended today that improvement in the world's monetary system be based on the present International Monetary Fund.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- William A. Wieland, a State Department officer who came under Congressional attack for his role in shaping United States policy on Cuba in the early days of the Castro regime, has been cleared and restored to full active duty, according to a department announcement.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- More than 250 of the nation's leading highway proponents, ranging from Congressmen and state officials to contractors and their suppliers, will gather here tomorrow for a two-day conference to celebrate the nearing of the "halfway point" in the construction of the $46.8 billion National System of Interstate and Defense Highways.

WAIRAKEI, New Zealand -- Engineers here are experimenting to see if they can continually, renew the geothermal energy that has been harnessed in this beautiful region of lakes and mountains for the generation of electric power.

Norton Simon, the industrialist and art collector, now controls the largest single block of stock in the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc. The concern is the parent company of the A.B.C. coast-to-coast television network and the nationwide chain of Paramount motion-picture theaters.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 18 (AP) -- Manager Sam Mele of the Minnesota Twins was thrown out of the first game of a double-header with the Los Angeles Angels today for throwing a punch at Umpire Bill Valentine.

ULSAN, South Korea -- "Ulsan is the symbol of economic reconstruction in our country," the local Citizen Charter says. "Our plan is to make it the Pittsburgh, the Osaka or the Essen of South Korea," declared Mayor Choi Byong Han.

The police captured a 62-year-old building superintendent early yesterday after he had barricaded himself in his East Harlem apartment and fired seven shots at policemen who had surrounded the building.
GREENSBORO, Ala., July 18 (UPI) -- Two Negro churches burned to the ground here last night, but civil rights leaders said today they would not slow their campaign, which has been marked by violence.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 18 -- Rodney Laver and Kenneth Rosewall will meet tomorrow in an all-Australian final for the United States professional grass court tennis championship and top prize money of $3,000.
COLOGNE, Germany, July 18 -- West German meat packers have put a direct challenge to American ingenuity before the United States companies now exhibiting at the Meat Equipment Fair in Cologne.

That fascinating phenomenon of modern show business, the long and widely publicized love affair between Judy Garland and her following, was on full display Saturday night with all its adoration and some of its sickening overtones.

" The Therapeutic Nightmare," by Morton Mintz, which deals with the question of the safety of marketed drugs, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Oct. 7. In the preface, Mr. Mintz writes: "In this book I shall deal with how and why it came about that drugs went on sale which had not been thoroughly tested, had not been been demonstrated to be safe, were worthless and were irrationally prescribed."

The Rev. Dr. Kyle Haselden, editor of the influential magazine Christian Century, told nearly 2,000 worshipers at Riverside Church yesterday that "real" Christianity required deep involvement in the world of men and human affairs, not "monastic, pietistic withdrawal."
The east side of Madison Avenue from 89th to 90th Street has been assembled for a builder who plans to erect a 35-story luxury apartment house on the site.

Mayor Wagner defended the city's economy yesterday as a second major rating agency downgraded its credit rating.
The search for 5-year-old Edmund Crimmins Jr., missing since last Wednesday from his home in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, remained unfruitful despite increased efforts.

LONDON, July 18 -- Terence Reese and Boris Schapiro, the British bridge players accused by Americans of cheating at the world championship tournament in Buenos Aires last May, are angry over a delay in the investigation being conducted here.

ABOARD CARRIER INDEPENDENCE, in the China Sea, July 18 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara acted as the catapult officer on the flight deck of this huge carrier this afternoon and launched a powerful bombing attack against North Vietnam.
ATLANTA, July 15 -- Keever Suit pulled a pencil stub from the bib of his overalls, totaled the money he had earned as a day laborer during the last week and said it came to "just under $16."
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (UPI) -- The Houston Astros scored four runs off Gaylord Perry in the first three innings today and went on to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 5-2.

The tax-exempt bond market was bubbling last week.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for an immediate investigation of what he termed a virtual monopoly control by Eastern Air Lines over air routes between Boston and New York.

A proposal for an elected Vice Mayor in charge of traffic and transportation problems has been offered by the City Fusion party, which has designated Council President Paul R. Screvane as its candidate for Mayor.

AFTER scolding Seventh Avenue designers, including himself, for lack of originality and for creating in the shadow of Paris, Norman Norell promised American fashion a "new proportion." He delivered it last Thursday night. It was vintage Chanel. Not chanel of the last decade who, in a triumphant, septuagenarian comeback, put the women of the world into her braid-trimmed suit uniform but the original, Jazz Age Chanel of exactly 40 years ago.
The three newest names on the various Democratic tickets for the November elections -- Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Orin Lehman and W. Bernard Richland -- are relatively unknown in city politics.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 19 -- Vietnamese troops reopened late yesterday a strategic road through the Central Highlands. The force, which was keeping Route 19 cleared of guerrillas for the first time in six weeks, was the largest ever assigned by the Vietnamese Government to a military operation.
ATHENS, July 18 -- Greece's new Premier, confident that tension caused by the change in government had eased, concentrated today on trying to muster parliamentary support to complete his Cabinet.
CLEVELAND, July 18 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox scored three runs off Jack Kralick in the first three innings today as they downed the Cleveland Indians, 4-1.
Governor Rockefeller's veto of the bill that would have provided state aid for the pre-school education of disadvantaged children will, regrettably, slow down this important experiment.
NYACK, N.Y., July 8 -- Closed-course racing on the Hudson River for outboard pleasure craft made an auspicious, if hazy, debut here today.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- Wholesale prices shot up in June to a record level, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House Republican leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, said today that Congress should take a hard look at any move by President Johnson to call up reserves or extend military enlistments because of the fighting in Vietnam.

Zygmunt Schmidt, a substitute inside right, scored a goal three minutes from the end yesterday to give Polonia Bytom of Poland a 2-1 victory over Ferencvaros of Hungary in the feature match of an International Soccer League doubleheader at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

BUFFALO, July 18 (AP) -- "I never knew people could be so cruel," said a young nurse today. She said 20 persons had stood and watched a 66-year-old man bleed to death moments after he had been stabbed 22 times.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 18 -- Ollan Cassell the national 440-yard champion, won the 220-yard dash in 20.6 second today in the Bergen Pacers track and field meet.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Denison Kitchel, the director of former Senator Barry Goldwater's Presidential campaign in 1964, acknowledged today that he joined the John Birch Society in 1960.
" AN Evening of Latin-American Music," the Metropolitan Opera's presentation at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday night, was an evening of fun.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A White House study group is laying the groundwork for a massive attempt to revive the structure of the Negro family.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- British animal-protection societies reacted angrily today to flourishing sales of stuffed baby alligators from Florida.
A 19-year-old youth was shot and killed by a sniper early yesterday on a dark, tree-lined street in Tompkinsville, S.I.

ATHENS, July 18 -- In the eye of the political storm now raging in Greece is a calm, scholarly figure as well known for his poetry as for the political career that culminated in his appointment as Premier last Thursday.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Home runs by Nelson Mathews, Dick Green and Ken Harrelson paced the Kansas City Athletics to a 7-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox today and gave them a split of a double-header.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18 -- No one went near the water at the pool-warming given yesterday evening by Mrs. Alexander Cushing. The freshly laundered Southampton air had a gray overcast, and as the fog rolled toward the house, so did the guests.
Because of an increase of mixed marriages, many conversions are merely nominal, according to an Orthodox rabbi-professor at Yeshiva University.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 18 -- Eight skippers completed sweeps today as the Narrasketuck Yacht Club's weekend invitation regatta ended. Fog and rain squalls provided an uncomfortable afternoon for the 140 skippers participating.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A severe thunderstorm accompanied by hail swept over the Washington area tonight, knocking down trees and power lines, smashing windows, tying up traffic, and flooding stores and homes.

New York City is studying an Army offer to rebuild the Hudson River pumping station near Beacon on a round-the-clock basis to provide 100 million gallons of water daily. It is estimated the job could be done in six months.

This weekend's torrential rains brought only minor abatement in the metropolitan area's desperate shortage of water. The shortage both here and throughout the Northeast is compounded of nature's inconsistency and man's reckless profligacy, with man most to blame. Ten years ago the Board of Water Supply was saying here: "New York City is assured a plentiful supply of the finest water for the rest of this century."

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 18 -- The Congo's next government, President Joseph Kasavubu insists, must be a broadly based "government of national union" because the country is not yet ready for national political parties or one-party cabinets.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- Ground was broken today for a $1 million apartment development sponsored by Negroes who hope to attract some white tenants.
THURMONT, Md., July 18 (AP) -- The Rev. Billy Graham, one of President Johnson's favorite preachers, conducted private religious services at Camp David today.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 18 -- The town where Adlai E. Stevenson will be buried tomorrow, his home town, is a mellow, somewhat shabby but self-satisfied place.

Your July 12 editorial "Merging Ali City Transit" describes an eminently sensible policy which could hold the line on mass transit fares, yet provide the financial means to improve facilities. This might in turn help lure back riders who use the subways, trains and buses only when there is no alternative.
ALBANY, July 19 -- Two bills legalizing rent strikes in New York City have been signed by Governor Rockefeller.
The National General Corporation, which operates 220 motion picture theaters, mostly in the West, announced yesterday plans to acquire or build 100 more theaters in the East.
NEW DELHI, July 19 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri called today for the development of India's traditional medical systems to help meet the critical health needs of rural areas.

New York's 15 largest savings banks had a net increase in deposits during the first half of July of $39,476,000, the Savings Banks Association of New York State disclosed yesterday. However, the gain was 38 per cent below last year's increase for the period of $63,954,000.

Staten Island Republicans defied Representative John V. Lindsay last night by ignoring his request that they endorse Albert V. Maniscalco, the incumbent Democratic - Liberal Borough President of Richmond.

The new president of St. John's University was criticized yesterday by two faculty members who said he "apparently backtracked" on an agreement that ended a revolt against the previous administration.
A jury deliberating whether to impose life imprisonment or the death penalty on a man convicted of murdering a policeman failed to reach a decision last night and was discharged.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, has told friends he hopes to leave the State Department by the end of the year and return to polities in Michigan.
The nationwide hotel movie theater and other interests of Schine Enterprises, Inc., are being acquired by the New York real estate partnership of Lawrence A. Wien and Harry B. Helmsley.

A specialist in international economics warned yesterday that the "so-called moral suasion" and voluntary cooperation in reducing the outflow of dollars from the United States will have only short-term results and asserted that the Government must do more to alleviate the problem.

The Chicago North Western Railway and its subsidiaries yesterday reported a net income of $3,807,424 for the first half of 1965, the largest in 20 years. Earnings in the corresponding period of 1964 were $552,030.

The International Longshoremen's Association, faced with a legal action, formally agreed yesterday to permit one of its locals here to hold an election of officers.

A grand jury began questioning the first of 26 witnesses yesterday in an investigation of the fatal shooting a Negro former convict by a white policeman last Thursday in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO July 19 (AP) -- Dick Ellsworth didn't allow a hit until the sixth inning today, but then weakened and had to have help as the Chicago Cubs scored a 6-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills eased downward somewhat this week.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 19 -- Kenneth Rosewall's incomparable backhand quelled, the tempest of Rodney Laver's volcanic opening assault and carried him to victory in the all-Australian final of the United States professional grass court tennis championship today.
LISBON, July 19 -- Arrests and trials of students in Portugal have disclosed the rise of a new "impatient generation," generally from well-to-do bourgeois families.
Top labor leaders in the city spoke early this morning at a rally held in Madison Square Garden by the Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee.

The monotonous superhighway, the billboard and the junkyard are three aspects of a single failure. The failure is in the effort to reconcile technology with man's deepest nature. It has come about because in making use of the automobile, the most widely shared triumph of American technology, this country has rarely recognized any arbiter but economies.

CINCINNATI, July 19 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates got 12 hits tonight, including Donn Clendenon's ninth homer of the season, and beat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-1, behind the six-hit pitching of Vernon Law.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 19 (AP) -- The longest shot in the field of eight, J.F. Keeler's Play Rough, won by a head in the six-furlong feature race before a crowd of 20,036 at Monmouth Park today. Wayne Chambers rode the 6-year-old, who covered the distance in 1:10 4-5.

PARIS, July 19 -- Eugene R. Black, President Johnson's special adviser on Southeast Asian development, outlined plans for an Asia Development Bank today at a special meeting of the Development Assistance Committee of the 21-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

The Atlantic Refining Company reported yesterday that it earned a record $30.14 million or $3.02 a share, on sales of $336,476,000, a new high, in the first six months this year. In the period last year, Atlantic Refining earned $22,789,000, or $2.28 a share, on sales of $316,388,000.

President Johnson's proposals for overhauling the Federal-state unemployment insurance system are moving more slowly than any other element in his design for a Great Society. The outlook is dim for action in either house of Congress this year, even though the Administration plan would represent the first basic revision since the job insurance system was created thirty years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Treasury Department announced today that preliminary, technical steps had been taken leading to a renegotiation of the tax treaty between the United States and Britain, as it applies to taxation of dividends.
One of three policemen accused of attempting to extort money from an alleged abortionist changed his mind yesterday and agreed to sign a waiver of immunity and appear before a grand jury.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, July 19 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, seemingly exhilarated by his visits to American military men in the field, hailed them today for their morale and dedication.

JERSEY CITY, July 19 -- An electrical fire and dense smoke in the eastbound tunnel of the Port Authority-Trans Hudson Tubes halted commuter service between Exchange Place here and New York's Hudson Terminal for about three and a half hours this morning.
LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- Two men indicted on charges of conspiring to criminally libel Senator Thomas H. Kuchel were fined $500 each in Superior Court today and were put on three years' probation.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 20 -- The Saigon police foiled a Vietcong attempt today to assassinate Maxwell D. Taylor, the United States Ambassador, at a rally here, police sources reported.

MILWAUKEE, July 19 -- There wasn't a trace of the Mets' Monday magic tonight. Instead there was the usual day-by-day note of Met failure as the Milwaukee Braves, behind the seven-hit pitching of Ken Johnson, beat the Mets, 6-0, before 5,591 fans at County Stadium.
Alexander N. McFarlane, chairman of the Corn Products Company, was elected yesterday to the advisory board on international business of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.

The mailers' union disclosed yesterday that it had authorized a strike against seven newspapers represented by the Publishers Association of New York City in a dispute over protection of jobs that might be involved in automation.

Mrs. Henry Ittleson Sr., social-work leader, will be honored Sept. 23 on her 90th birthday at a dinner in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The event is being sponsor by the Social Work Recruiting Center of Greater New York, Inc.
The Court of Appeals has unanimously approved a broad interpretation of the Fair Sabbath Law that will permit thousands of New York City stores to stay open on Sunday.

BUENOS AIRES, July 19 -- Efforts to end the protracted tug of war between the Argentine Government and private petroleum companies will center this week on a series of conflicting proposals submitted to President Arturo U. Illia by his advisers.
TOKYO, July 19 -- Japan plans to build 7.4 million gross tons of shipping to overcome a deficit of $417 million in international payments in the maritime industry, the Government reported today.
The Swiss franc rose sharply yesterday in foreign-exchange trading here. It closed at 23.15 3/8 cents, compared with its final price on Friday of 23.11 1/2.

WHITE PLAINS, July 19 -- Westchester may distribute Federal surplus foods to impoverished families soon for the first time, even though some county officials consider it costly to the taxpayers and degrading to the poor.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 19 -- A former New York State champion, Mrs. Albert B. Bower of Pelham, was medalist today in qualifying for the Women s Tri-County Golf Association championship.

BONN, July 19 -- Volkswagen and Daimler-Benz, which have been stylistic conservatives among West Germany's thriving automobile makers, will bring out more powerful and faster standard models this fall.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 19 -- Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian Communist party secretary, conducted a kind of minuet of independence today as he opened the party's ninth congress.
The three television networks were urged yesterday to reconsider simultaneous blanket coverage of national political conventions.

BOGALUSA, La., July 19 -- Federal authorities initiated broad legal action today against three law enforcement officials, the Original Knights of the Ku Klux Klan and 35 segregationists in an attempt to halt racial violence here.
ATHENS, July 19 -- The deposed Premier, George Papandreou, was almost mobbed by his supporters tonight as he rode to the headquarters of his party, the Center Union.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Arthur Schlesinger Jr., writing in the current issue of Life, provides an inside observer's fascinating account of official activities prior to the invasion attempt of the anti-Castro Cubans at the Bay of Pigs that was launched by the uncertain trumpets of the Kennedy Administration, to perish in bloody disaster.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 20 (AP) -- President Ho Chi Minh of Communist North Vietnam vowed today that his people would fight another 20 years or more if necessary to achieve final victory.

The largest mobilization of the nation's merchant fleet since the Suez crisis has been ordered by the Department of Defense to support United States forces in Southeast Asia, maritime industry sources reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A plea that the United States recognize the usefulness of Yugoslav's version of national Communism was made today by Senator J.W. Fulbright.
The American Stock Exchange opened the week's trading in low gear. Volume dipped to 967,800 shares in yesterday's trading from the 981,400 shares traded on Friday.
Operations of the Weyerhaeuser Company in the second quarter this year resulted in record earnings and the highest sales for any quarter in its history, the semiannual report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 19 --Congress rebuffed the Administration today by moving ahead with two military bills on which the White House frowns.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. had the highest quarterly sales and earnings in its history in the three months ended June 30. The half-year results also set a record, according to the company's midyear report issued yesterday.

The police on Staten Island said yesterday that "admirable cooperation from the public" had led to the arrest of a 21-year-old hospital porter in the sniper killing of a 19-year-old student early Sunday.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 19 -- Many defendants in the University of California sit-in case refused today to accept probationary sentences that would have prevented them from taking part in picketing and other direct action demonstrations.

The appointment of Kermit J. Feldman to the new post of industry coordinator of the Joint Labor-Management Industry Fund of the Sheet Metal Workers Local 55 has been announced by Joseph Frederick, the local's chairman.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Post Office Department has discovered that the angel Gabriel on the 1965 Christmas stamp has a feminine torso.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 19 -- A military investigation was under way in Danang today into the episode of two drunken American marines who climbed into a B-57 jet and threatened to bomb Hanoi. The two men, neither of them a pilot, were taken into custody when they called to guards on the airstrip to ask them how to start the plane.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The difference between President Johnson's White House conference on education, which starts tomorrow, and President Eisenhower's in 1955 tells a story of dramatic changes in American society and education.
LONDON, July 19 -- An ambitious long-term plan for redeveloping Parliament Square as a plaza virtually free of traffic was put forward today by an architect and an authority on traffic.

NOBLESVILLE, Ind., July 19 (UPI) -- James T. Neal, editor of The Noblesville Daily Ledger, was arrested and placed under $50,000 bond today on a charge of criminal contempt of court. The citation against Mr. Neal, who is also secretary of the Indiana Republican State Committee, was issued by Judge Edward New Jr. of the Hamilton Circuit Court.

Leading roles in "Hot September," the new title for the musical version of "Picnic," will be played by Sean Garrison and Kathryn Hays. Other important parts have been assigned to Lovelady Powell, Patricia Roe, John Stewart and Paula Trueman.
Life aboard the disabled passenger liner Seven Seas, adrift in the North Atlantic some 500 miles east of Newfoundland, continued normal yesterday, her master reported.
A Federal grand jury indicted 17 men yesterday on charges of hijacking more than $150,000 worth of merchandise in seven armed holdups from April to October, 1964.

The J.C. Penney Company, big retail and mail-order chain, may acquire Channing Financial Corporation, a holding company with subsidiaries in the fields of life and casualty insurance, investment advisory services and distribution of mutual funds, for about $50 million in stock.

ALBANY, July 19 -- The state has ordered the construction of a nuclear-powered plant :in eastern Long Island that will convert sea water from Long Island Sound to a million gallons of fresh water daily.

ABOARD U.S. ICEBREAKER NORTHWIND, in the Artic, July 18 -- The way military men keep time, it was exactly 0737 Greenwich mean time today when this Coast Guard vessel crossed the Arctic Circle off the Norwegian coast.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 19 -- Humphrey B. Simpson's yawl, Kittiwake, and Dr. Stuart A. Kay's little sloop, Strathspey, were the respective division winners today as the fleet on the 34th annual American Yacht Club cruise raced 22.1-nautical miles across Block Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Defense Department retreated part way tonight from its previous denial that a United States Air Force photo-reconaissance plane had flown over a French nuclear installation.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 19 -- Adlai E. Stevenson was buried here today near the graves of three generations of forebears who had played leading parts in this community since its beginning.
The ticket-making for the city election nears completion.

It used to be that if a man scored half his pitching victories over the New York Yankees, it made his stature in the baseball world secure. Nowadays, and in the case of Jim Lonborg of the Boston Red Sox, it merely says something about the Yankees.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 15 -- President Julius K. Nyerere said today that relations between the United States and Tanzania "must and should improve" and indicated that he would soon return his Ambassador to Washington.

MOSCOW, July 19 -- W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's Ambassador at Large, pressed today for more Soviet-American exchanges in scientific and technical fields during a two-and-a-half-hour talk with a Soviet Deputy Premier, Konstantin N. Rudnev.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 19 -- With more than half of the winners in yesterday's elections now known, it was apparent that a surprisingly large number of young candidates had been recommended for seats in the National Assembly.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 19 -- Many followers of the New York Giants find it difficult to accept Gary Wood as the No. 1 quarterback of a team that has had over the last 15 years such venerable stars as Y.A. Tittle and Charley Conerly for football's No. 1 position.
TALLINN, Estonia, July 19 -- Young Estonians, dressed in national costumes, danced in the cobblestoned streets of old Tallinn under the pale midnight sky.

As a visitor in your country I feel peculiarly responsible for the image my own country possesses here. And so it was with some interest that I read your special correspondent's July 1 news account of New Zealand attitudes to the Vietnam conflict.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 20 (Reuters) -- Gen. Li Tsung-jen, former Nationalist Chinese Vice President, returned to Peking by special plane today with his wife after a 16-year self-imposed exile in the United States. Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, said.
Wheat futures registered a good gain yesterday for the fourth consecutive session. The rise was 3/4 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel in moderately active trading.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange eased yesterday in light trading.
Dr Calvin E. Gross, former New York City Superintendent of Schools, has reportedly been offered the position of dean of the School of Education at the University of Missouri, Kansas City.

PARIS, July 19 -- France protested to the United States today against the alleged intrusion of an American photoreconnaissance jet in the forbidden airspace over the heart of France's nuclear-production facilities.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Late in 1960, when Gerhard Mennen Williams was preparing to leave the Governor's office in Lansing, Mich., to take up his new duties as Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, newspapermen in the capital composed a little farewell ditty that began: "Far across the ocean blue,/ Kasavubu waits for you,/bye, bye, Soapy."
PARIS, July 19 -- Andre Courrges has concluded that the manufacturers of women's wear have sabotaged his revolution in what the women of today should wear.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today he would vote against Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen's reapportionment proposal unless it were changed to meet his objections.

The Metropolitan Theater Ticket Agents Guild is taking further legal steps against License Commissioner Joseph DiCarlo to prevent the sale and distribution of tickets for Broadway shows or sporting events through unlicensed sources.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Dick Green's three-run homer capped a six-run, seventh-inning outburst tonight that carried the Kansas City Athletics to a 6-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox. The victory was the Athletics' fifth in their last six games.
DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- Automobile manufacturers are in the final weeks of production of 1965 models, with some assembly plants already finished with their '65 lines.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 1 (UPI) -- Barbara McIntire of Colorado Springs and Marcella Rose of Jefferson City, Mo., tied for medalist honors with two-over-par 77's today in qualifying for the women's Western amateur golf championship at Wayzata Country Club.

GENEVA, July 19 -- A three-man arbitration tribunal has ruled in favor of the United States in a dispute with Italy over the interpretation of the accord regulating air services between the two countries.

Kelso was assigned the top weight of 132 pounds yesterday for the $100,000 added Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct on Saturday, an impost that caused no surprise among horsemen. Mrs. Richard C. duPont's famous campaigner, now an 8-year-old, will be making his first New York start of the year in the 1 1/4-mile race.
Standard Poor's Corporation will continue to give New York City bonds an "A" credit rating.
American Airlines announced yesterday that it would put new baggage rules into effect on Aug. 1 that were recently approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

LONDON, July 19 -- A voice from the past floated up to make itself heard in Western dance tonight. The voice was that of Kasyan Goleizovseky and the occasion was the Western premiere of his ballet "Scriabiniana" danced by the Bolshoi Ballet at the Royal Festival Hall tonight.
Production of steel rose 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Kelso was assigned the top weight of 132 pounds yesterday for the $100,000 added Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct on Saturday, an impost that caused no surprise among horsemen. Mrs. Richard C. duPont's famous campaigner, now an 8-year-old, will be making his first New York start of the year in the 1 1/4-mile race.
The new Metropolitan Opera house, already a gigantic tidbit under glass, is more than half-finished.

City Council President Paul R. Screvane and his running mates, Orin Lehman and Daniel P. Moynihan, won the endorsement of the New York County Democratic organization yesterday in their political bow as the team with the "fresh look."

LOS ANGELES, July 19 (AP) -- Don Drysdale smashed a single and double and gained his fourth straight triumph tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers extended their winning streak to five games by beating the Houston Astros, 8-3.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 19 -- Yesterday was the day the rains came. It was a day 600 party and charter-boat anglers, who headed out to sea from here, will remember. It produced fog, thunder, lightning, squalls and plenty of fish.
PASADENA, Calif., July 19 (UPI) -- Mariner 4 continued today sending pictures of Mars to Earth.

ALBERT STOCKLI the executive chef and a guiding spirit of Restaurant Associates since its inception, has turned in his toque blanche as the organization's chef director. In that capacity his scope over the years included the kitchens of such luxury establishments as The Four Seasons, The Forum of the Twelve Caesars, and the Tower Suite atop the Time and Life Building.
Twenty eager scholars converged on a new research library at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts yesterday.
STONY BROOK, L.I., July 19 -- A new center for nuclear research, experimentation and education is being set up here at the State University of New York Center.

Following are the texts of statements by Paul R. Screvane, Daniel P. Moynihan and Orin Lehman concerning the acceptance by Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Lehman of invitations to run on the ticket with Mr. Screvane:
Following are the statements by Representative John V. Lindsay and Milton Mollen concerning Mr. Mollen's decision to run for Controller on Mr. Lindsay's ticket:
I write to urge public support for pending legislation vital to civil liberty that seems to have faded from the public eye during this hectic legislative session.
The body of a boy, believed to be that of 5-year-old Edmund Crimmins, who disappeared with his 4-year-old sister from their Queens apartment last week, was found at 11:30 A.M. yesterday.
STARKVILLE, Miss., July 19 (AP) -- Mississippi State University enrolled Richard Holmes today as its first Negro student.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Explosive issues touching on the lives of all Americans will he explored in depth at a White House conference on education opening here tomorrow.
Soaring profits and pleas for higher prices were juxtaposed in second-quarter reports issued yesterday by leading aluminum and steel companies.
OTTAWA, July 19 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson outlined today a national medical care plan to be put forward by the Government on a basis of "cooperative federalism."
HONOLULU, July 19 -- Syngman Rhee, founder and first President of the Republic of Korea, died here in exile today after three years and four months as a semi-conscious invalid. He was 90 years old.

DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- Ken Hamlin, who entered the game with only eight runs bateed in this season, knocked in four with a pair of home runs today as he led the Washington Senators to an 8-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

ROME, July 19 -- If Italy's favorite girl of the hour -- a blond actress with smoldering eyes and a sulky smile who is named Virna Lisi -- doesn't buy her clothes at Valentino on Via Gregoriana, she should drop everything and go right over there.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19j (AP) -- Warren Spahn, the winner of more games (360) than any other left-hander in baseball history, today agreed to terms with the San Francisco Giants. The action came less than a week after the New York Mets had released him.

Two large municipal bond syndicates prepared yesterday to bid this morning for the $175.05 million of New York City bonds scheduled to be sold at competitive bidding in a sale complicated by recent reductions in the city's credit rating.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, said today he was shocked and astounded that Western Union sometimes telephoned rather than hand-delivered telegrams notifying parents that their sons had been killed in Vietnam.
CAIRO, July 19 -- In a major shift of policy the Sudan's new right-wing Government issued an ultimatum tonight to the rebels in the south to lay down their arms or face harsh Government action.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 (UPI) -- Chris Short nipped a St. Louis Cardinal rally tonight by striking out Bill White with the bases filled to win his 11th game for the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-2.
WASHINGTON July 19 (AP) -- Appointment of three new regional manpower advisory committees for the Great Plains, Middle Atlantic and New England states was announced today.

The West German passenger liner Seven Seas, adrift since Saturday night some 500 miles east of Newfoundland, was expected to resume her interrupted voyage during the night the Cost Guard said here yesterday.

WAYZATA, Minn., July 20 (UPI) -- Barbara McIntire of Colorado Springs, the national amateur champion and Carol Sorenson of Janesville, Wis., the British amateur champion, fell in stunning upsets today in the first round of the women's Western amateur golf championship at the Wayzata Country Club.

I am an assistant teacher with the Project Head Start program at P.S. 119 in Harlem. During the past few weeks some criticism has been leveled at this program whereby we try to help underprivileged preschool-age children prepare for entering regular school in the fall.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said today the new Equal Employment Opportunity Commission was finding the question of sex discrimination to be "terribly complicated."
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Johnson named Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court today to succeed Adlai E. Stevenson as United States representative at the United Nations.
A brisk demand for gold-mining shares was the outstanding feature in an otherwise dull session on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

A 19-year-old college student helped the police yesterday afternoon by pursuing a stolen car for about a mile in Queens, forcing it to a halt and holding its two teen-aged occupants until they could be arrested.

ROCHESTER, -- N.Y., July 20 (AP) --Sgt. Israel Jacobson of this city, who served on the front lines for 570 days as an infantryman in World War II, was awarded seven medals in belated ceremonies last night. The Sergeant, who is ill with cancer, was presented with the medals by two retired Army officers, who said he had earned them in the war, but had not received them.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax pitched a three-hitter for his 11th straight victory tonight and singled in the winning run in the ninth inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 20 (AP) -- Stuart T. Saunders, chairman of the board of the Pennsylvania Railroad, came to Hartford today to assure Connecticut that "we're not trying to discontinue service here."
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 20 -- Soviet and Chinese Communist leaders vied openly today for the favor of their hosts at the Rumanian Communist party congress.
GENEVA, July 20 -- A "see-America-next" campaign was begun among international officials today by a 20-member team of United States convention managers and airline and hotel representatives.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 20 -- Promptly at 4:30 P.M., Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Kempner, their maid, chef, butler, parlor maid and the two gardeners heard the whistle piercing the estate's curtain of Japanese dogwood, maples and weeping willows.

THE Philharmonic's current French-American Festival was turned over to two specialists last night, Zino Francescatti, the violinist, and Robert Casadesus, the pianist, and they came up with a chamber music program that was in keeping with the series by being slightly off-beat and fascinating.

LONDON, July 20 -- The last two days have seen a flurry in gold trading in the London Bullion Market, with the price rising today to the best level since April 27. There was speculation that China may once again have been in the market as a buyer.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Wednesday, July 21 (Reuters) -- All the prisoners holding out in New Zealand's top security prison after a riot yesterday morning surrendered today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 20 (UPI) -- Directors of the Scrivner-Stevens Company and Boogaart Supply Company have approved the proposed acquisition of Boogaart by Scrivner-Stevens, the companies disclosed today.

THE LITERARY REBEL By Kingsley Widmer. Foreword by Hurry T. Moore. 261 pages. Southern Illinois University. $4.50. This is a bedside book for readers who are wide awake. Kingsley Widmer's sentences are packed with words like "nullifidian;" his paragraphs can be a page. But, as the author of books on Henry Miller and D.H. Lawrence, he is equipped to deal with all kinds of rebels, including missing ones.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (AP) -- Bob Shaw lost his bid for a no-hitter when Ron Santo blooped a single to right field opening the eighth inning today, but the San Francisco Giants' right-hander went on to blank the Chicago Cubs, 2-0, with a two-hitter.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- General Li is the most prominent figure to go over to the Chinese Communists since the collapse of the Nationalist regime.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 20 -- President Chung Hee Park agreed today with the leader of the Opposition to put off temporarily the parliamentary fight over proposed ratification of the treaty establishing normal relations between South Korea and Japan in the hope of averting a political crisis.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- House and Senate conferees informally agreed tonight on the final text of the Administration's medicare-Social Security bill.
Uneasiness over Vietnam led to the clobbering of most stocks on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market yesterday.

The body of Nelson Erby, 28-year-old Negro ex-convict who was fatally shot by a white policeman in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last Thursday, will be exhumed for examination of a wound in his head.
