Congress is beginning to show the usual symptoms. Tempers are growing a bit short. Speculation about "when we'll get out of here" is the staple of daily small talk. The pressure rises to postpone all but the most urgent bills. This syndrome is indicative of that well-known summer ailment, adjournment fever.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Many of the nation's leaders nibbled timidly at the great educational issues of the day today as the White House conference on education got off to a slow start.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 20 -- A flight of three United States-made T-28 planes of the Laotian Air Force rose from the steaming runway of Vientiane Airport this morning, their undercarriages heavy with bombs and rockets.
MILWAUKEE, July 20 -- The Mets purchased Gary Kolb, a utility man, from the Milwaukee Braves today and the Braves claimed Jesse Gonder, a Met catcher, on waivers.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 20 -- Theodore Hallet, very much alive in Stamford, Conn., got some startling news the other day. He learned that his name was on a bronze plaque honoring Port Chester's dead in World War II.

A South Vietnamese colonel who was killed last week by the security police had predicted in a letter that the more planes and bombs the United States used in his country, the more quickly it will "lose the confidence of South Vietnam and of Southeast Asia."
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board asked Congress today to extend its supervisory authority to cover savings and loan holding companies.
CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) -- Russ Snyder and Boog Powell hit two-run homers in support of Dave McNally's six-hit pitching tonight as the Baltimore Orioles whipped the Cleveland Indians, 6-1.
Despite high sales volume, earnings of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company declined to $1.09 a share in the second quarter from $1.28 a share in the 1964 period.
TRENTON, July 20 -- New Jersey is studying the feasibility of constructing an expressway to link the approaches to the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge.
Three New Jersey security dealers and a former Securities and Exchange Commission investigator they allegedly conspired to bribe were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Arthur J. Goldberg's appointment to replace Adlai Stevenson at the United Nations illustrates again President Johnson's ability to make the unexpected move that turns out, on close inspection, to be the right move.
Controller Abraham D. Beame, one of the leading Democratic contenders for the mayoralty, will round out his ticket today by naming Civil Court Judge Mario A. Procaccino for Controller.
The "silent center," most of the American people, should be heard from on Vietnam, Freedom House said yesterday in a "Credo of Support" for the Johnson Administration's policies in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- In mid-June of 1962, many of the country's major airlines were deep in a bitter labor controversy with two unions -- the Flight Engineers and the Pilots.
The new $30.7-million Belmont Park, for which ground was officially and irrevocably broken yesterday, isn't going to be quite the same as the old Belmont. But it will still be Belmont.

FORT ERIE, Ont., July 20 (Canadian Press) -- Three men carrying travelers' checks that i the police said were stolen in a multimillion-dollar bank robI bery last April were charged :here today with possession of stolen goods.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 -- The Lebanese Cabinet of Premier Hussein Oweini resigned today.

BETHPAGE, L.I -- Inside a two-and-a-half-acre pink stucco shoebox on the Hicksville Road (Route 107) is the bargain basement of Nassau County. There are more than 300 booths with every variety of merchandise, but the foodstuffs are the leading commodity. The Nassau Farmers Market, something of a misnomer because it carries little local farm produce, is open Friday and Saturday only.

A secretary on her lunch hour was critically hurt yesterday when a window-opening pole fell like a javelin from a ninth-floor office and pierced her skull as she walked along 42d Street near Times Square.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to make assassination of the President or Vice President a Federal crime punishable by death.

President Johnson achieved complete surprise with his announcement yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg will succeed the late Adlai E. Stevenson as United States Ambassador to the United Nations. Once the initial shock of astonishment wore off, many an American must have wondered to himself why he hadn't thought of Justice Goldberg too -- because the more one ponders this selection the more logical, even the more brilliant, it appears.

NEW HAVEN, July 20 (UPI) -- Two camera-shy bandits pistol-whipped a bank cashier today and fled with $35,000 after draping towels over the lens of an automatic camera to prevent it from making a film of the robbery.

Art independent poll taken among Negroes in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens indicated yesterday that most of those questioned intend to vote for the Democratic candidate in the Nov. 2 election for Mayor.
New York City made the biggest bond sale in its history yesterday -- a $175,050,000 offering -- but it will pay roughly a quarter of 1 per cent more interest than it did for bonds issued last April.
The Household Finance Corporation is again wooing the City Products Corporation, a general merchandising chain, after its first merger proposal failed three years ago.

VIENNA -- In 1953 I attended an international Communist peace congress in Budapest and the key words, in all languages and which brought down the house, were "Lee Sing Man." Rather simple-mindedly I asked my polyglot interpreter what this strange phrase meant.

The District Attorney's office reported yesterday that Richard Robles, a 22-year-oldl narcotics addict accused of the East Side killing of Janice Wylie and Emly Hoffert, would go on trial for first-degree murder "probably in the fall."

DANBURY, Conn., July 20 -- The Mallory Hat Company plant here closed today after 148 years of turning out felt hats. The closing left this former hat-making capital of the world with only one such plant still in operation.
Three oil companies registered sharp increases in earnings for the second quarter and half year ended June 30, according to midyear statements issued yesterday.

A $1 million shopping center will span the tracks of the New Haven Railroad at the site of its station in Greenwich, Conn. The center will be built in a year or so by the two Greenwich residents who have just purchased the four-and-one-half acre station plot from the railroad.

ALGIERS, July 20 -- Col. Houari Boumedienne presided tonight over the installation of an interim five-man Executive Secretariat of the National Liberation Front, formerly headed solely by the deposed President Ahmed Ben Bella.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today with only two dissenting votes President Johnson's appointment of former Gov. James P. Coleman of Mississippi to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The Yale Alumni Fund, the oldest and largest unrestricted gift plan in its field, closed the books on its 75th year yesterday with a total of $3.3 million in donations to the university.
ST. LOUIS, July 20 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals walloped three home runs today and beat the Philadelphia Phils, 4-3, for their fifth victory in six games.

I have found most interesting your July 12 editorial "Merging All City Transit" as well as your news articles on the same subject. As you correctly state, the Gilhooley plan, which is an excellent one, is not original, as it has been advocated many times over the past fifteen years.

Decision was reserved yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Aloysius J. Melia on whether three policemen should be dismissed from the force for refusing to sign waivers of immunity before a New York County grand jury investigating abortion bribery.
New York's largest union organizing campaign reaches a climax today, with more than 10,000 taxi drivers and mechanics expected to vote in a National Labor Relations Board election.
A shortage of civic courage -- not of rain -- is the real root of the New York area's water crisis, a consultant to the city's water supply board charged yesterday.

Two bandits forced a messenger boy into a doorway in the financial district during the lunch period yesterday, tore a briefcase containing $2.1 million in stock certificates from his grasp and escaped.

A group of upstate Democratic leaders are considering opposing Mayor John J. Burns of Binghamton for the party's state chairmanship despite his support by both Mayor Wagner and Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 20 -- A 16-year-old girl was killed and her husband and another man were wounded last night by a mortar bombardment of the rebel stronghold in downtown Santo Domingo.
LONDON, July 20 -- Prime Minister Wilson indicated today that it might be time to change the law that makes the Lord Chamberlain Britain's theatrical censor.

The most recent visit of Secretary of Defense McNamara and Ambassador-designate Lodge to Vietnam has come at a time when the Vietnamese war appears to be escalating to the proportions of a different and more sinister Korea. It comes, too, after both President Johnson and Mr. McNamara have warned the nation that the limited reserve call-up, extension of enlistments and increased draft calls might be necessary.

THE eighth annual New Hope (Pa.) Automobile Show will be held on the school grounds in the picturesque little town on the Delaware River on Saturday and Sunday, Aug. 14 and 15. This event, which has become one of the largest and most complete automobile exhibitions in the country, will be even larger this year with the addition of the exhibition by the Delaware Valley Region of the Vintage Chevrolet Club of America.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 20 -- The defending champion, Jerry Courville of Shorehaven, dropped a 5-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today and won the 13th Ike golf tournament at Wykagyl Country Club.

The management of the Marlene Industries Corporation, a maker of women's apparel for chain stores, blocked a union attempt yesterday to call attention to recent violence arising from organizing efforts at the company's plants in the South.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- Dr. Richard Cloward, a Columbia University professor who said in a speech last month that crime problems were greatly exaggerated, was shot in the shoulder early today by one of two men who had stopped him on the campus of Temple University.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the appointment of James B. Gorman, John J. Grinch and Francis X. Kosch as vice presidents.
The Queens police questioned yesterday a former servant of Mrs. Edmund Crimmins, whose two small children were found dead after they mysteriously disappeared from home last week.

Northern Florida's Oklawaha River is one of this country's most beautiful free-flowing streams. Its peaceful, meandering course is ideal for wilderness boating and its waters are noted for excellent fishing. The adjacent swamp-forest in the mile-wide valley supports an abundance of wildlife.
LONDON, July 20 -- The highlight of the Ballet Rambert's London season has been tonight's premiere of Norman Morrice's. "The Realms of Choice."
The Vietnam conflict hit Wall Street from two directions yesterday, sending stock prices tumbling with losses of from one to five points in many blue-chip issues.
Mel Stottlemyre subdued the Boston Red Sox, 6-3, for the New York Yankees yesterday with his pitching arm, his bat and his speed afoot.

HONG KONG, July 20 -- Gen. Li Tsung-jen, former Acting President of Nationalist China, who flew to Peking today after 16 years of exile in the United States, pledged support of the Communist cause to make up for his "guilty past."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that he had found the situation in South Vietnam still serious and that in many ways it had deteriorated in the last 15 months.
LONDON, July 20 -- The House of Lords approved tonight the bill to abolish the death penalty for murder in Britain.
LONDON, July 20 -- A 61-year-old unemployed resident of Newcastle-on-Tyne will appear in court tomorrow on charges of stealing a Goya portrait from the National Gallery four years ago.

The day of reckoning for Mayor Wagner's borrow-now, pay-later policy to "balance" the city expense budget has arrived promptly, with the new fiscal year barely under way. The city's credit rating is downgraded, the interest rate upgraded. The result -- just as predicted, but not by the Mayor -- is increased cost for borrowing, increased cost of government.
Diversification is paying off for Esquire, Inc., and further diversification through acquisition is planned.

I take strong objection to your July 7 editorial sponsoring the universal metering of water in New York City. You state: "The only valid arguments against metering are its difficulties of installation."
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- House Republicans today challenged Sargent Shriver's operation of the antipoverty program.

Thirty years after Louis Untermeyer wrote his autobiography, "From Another World," he has written another which Harcourt, Brace and World will publish as "Bygones." It will appear on Oct. 1, Mr. Untermeyer's 80th birthday.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Racial segregation in housing in Chicago's North Shore suburbs Will be protested at a rally led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his aides said today. Dr. King has scheduled three days of civil rights activities here this weekend.
ALBANY, July 20 -- New York State has a new, broadened Fair Sabbath Law.
WOMEN viewers who yearn for vicarious escape from phlegmatic spouses with flat chests undoubtedly are among those who contribute to the size of the banner audience for "Bonanza" every Saturday night.

The month-old mystery of a ghostly whistle heard far above the Hudson -- a shivering WHOOSH that ended a split-second later with an ear-shattering KA-RUMP on the wooded flank of Anthony's Nose, near Bear Mountain Bridge -- was apparently solved yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- A lawyer testified today that the Boston Internal Revenue Service office was run by a "Dr. Strangelove," whose agents used "torture chamber" tactics.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Defense Department has curtailed the use of polygraphs, commonly called lie detections, and the scope of questioning in cases where electronic or mechanical devices axe still authorized.
The top echelon of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey was shaken up in a series of executive changes announced yesterday. The changes are effective Sept. 1.
A project to stimulate the professional theater in suburban areas has been organized by the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theater and Academy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 21 -- Communist forces last night probed the new American combat infantry positions around Bienhoa air field for the third night with mortar and small-arms fire.

ELYRIA, Ohio, July 20 (UPI) -- the Mid-Continent Telephone Corporation, Elyria, has acquired the C.T. N. Telephone Company, Casey, Ill., according to a joint announcement by officials of both concerns.
NEW DELHI, July 20 -- United States officials here have strongly recommended a sharp increase in aid to India, informed sources said today.
A cast of international leaders is being assembled by the National Broadcasting Company for its three-and-a-half-hour special on United States foreign policy.

MILWAUKEE, July 20 -- The Mets got away to another lead against the Milwaukee Braves today. This time they held it for 6 1/2 innings. Then the Braves scored all of their runs in the seventh for a 7-1 victory.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Gemini 5 spacecraft, schedule to start an eight-day orbital mission Aug. 19, will use a fuel cell for all its electric power, the space agency said today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor was questioned sharply for four hours today at a Congressional hearing on President Johnson's proposed bills to beautify the nation's highways.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers told a Congressional panel today that current tax rates would produce about $170 billion in Federal revenue five years from now, or almost $50 billion more than this year.

THE traditional advice, dating back to whist days, to lead "up to weakness" is sound enough as far as it goes. An obvious exception occurs when the dummy is short of entries, because the defender must then be careful not to permit the declarer to take entries he would not be able to take if left to his own devices.
BLOOMTNGTON, Minn., July 20 (AP) -- Bobby Knoop got four of Los Angeles's 15 hits to pace the Angels to a 9-1 victory today over the first-place Minnesota Twins.
The Manhattan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election as a director of Donald C. Platten, senior vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The House of Representatives gave a 410-to-0 vote of approval today to a bill increasing the pay of military personnel by more than 10 per cent. However, the measure is almost certain to be trimmed before it gets through the Senate.

Increasing concern was being voiced in Washington and elsewhere in the country yesterday about deficiencies in weapons, equipment, training and personnel in the armed forces. The criticism focused primarily on the Army and its reserve components. It was voiced privately by men in uniform and with increasing public vehemence by some members of Congress.
A group of New Yorkers plans to establish a Library of Presidential Papers here. It would contain originals or copies of all the papers of American Presidents.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- The appointment of Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg to succeed Adlai E. Stevenson as the United States representative at the United Nations caused great surprise and some dismay today when it became known among delegates and members of the Secretariat.

DETROIT, July 20 (UPI) -- Dave Wickersham won his second game of the year after eight straight losses and Willie Horton hit his 21st homer as the Detroit Tigers downed the Washington Senators tonight, 2-0.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 20 -- In this era of coast-to-coast harness racing, with many rich stakes events, the successful trainer-driver is the one who surrounds himself with top-flight assistants.
LONDON, July 20 -- Ghana's High Commissioner here and a delegation of seven other Ghanaians left suddenly today for a trip to Moscow, Peking and Hanoi.
Gains of 55 per cent in half-year earnings and 44 per cent in sales gave the Magnavox Company new records for the period, the report yesterday informed some 35,000 shareholders.
B. Altman Co. announced yesterday that it would build a store in Lord Taylor's Fifth Avenue Fashion Center, in Bergen County, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, had to filibuster in the Judiciary Committee today to stave off a defeat of his constitutional amendment on apportionment of state legislatures.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Following are texts of President Johnson's announcement of Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg's selection as United States representative at the United Nations and Justice Goldberg's response:
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended July 15 soared by more than a million shares.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 20 (UPI) -- The United States sent a pair of satellite scouts speeding one-quarter of the way to the moon today to reinforce American's watch for any secret nuclear tests in space.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- Both sides in the Dominican Republic asked today for the withdrawal of the inter-American peace-keeping force, made up principally of United States troops.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Commissioner George P. Larrick of the Food and Drug Administration told the House today he favored stationing inspectors in drug manufacturing plants to make sure only pure drugs were manufactured.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee gave swift approval today to the nomination of Leonard H. Marks, a Washington lawyer, to be director of the United States Information Agency.
Reforms introduced by the Police Department into procedures of its civilian complaint review board were praised yesterday at City Hall as tending to improve the board's effectiveness.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 20 -- One upset marked today's opening round of match play in the 15th annual Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at Leewood Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The volume of new orders received by manufacturers of durable goods fell in June for the second consecutive month, the Census Bureau reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Johnson and Democratic leaders agreed today that Congress should adjourn by Labor Day if it had completed work on major legislation.
BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, July 20 -- The Danube's worst flood in a century is receding, but Czechoslovakia's richest farmland has suffered damage that will take several years to repair.
OTTAWA, July 20 -- Quebec and British Columbia today criticized Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson's plans to have the courts settle the issue of offshore oil rights.

THE mystical bond that unites the New York Mets with their ancestral forebears, the Brooklyn Dodgers of those glorious days of the Daffiness Boys, will be given renewed emphasis on Saturday. This will be Old-Timers' Day at Shea Stadium and returning with the other storied heroes from the past will be Floyd Caves Herman.

An official of the International Monetary Fund said yesterday the United States, in defending its gold reserves, should not restrict credit facilities to the point where "a deflationary chain reaction" might spread throughout the world.

The First National City Bank confirmed yesterday that the $4 million net loss in its foreign exchange operations, which it reported last month, was the result of forward market operations in sterling at its Brussels branch.
ATHENS, July 20 -- Former Premier George Papandreou lost his majority in Parliament tonight when five of his deputies defected to join the four-day-old cabinet of Premier George Athanasiadis-Novas.

BOGALUSA, La, July 20 -- A day-long series of civil rights demonstrations were carried out without incident today, prompting Mayor Jesse H. Cutrer to predict that Bogalusa "may be over the hill" in its six-month racial crisis.
Prices of currencies registered few changes yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 20 -- Two Australian Davis Cup stars, Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle, eliminated two opponents each in catching up with the field in the third round of the 66th Pennsylvania grass-court championship today at the Merion Cricket Club.
The board of directors of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., said yesterday it had acceuted "with regret" the resignation of John C. Doyle as president, chairman, and head of the executive committee.

Representative John V. Lindsay declared yesterday that the presence of Milton Mollen on his ticket would not inhibit him "in the slightest" from attacking the Wagner administration's housing policies.
Moscow, July 20 -- A massive new screen adaptation of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" and a Hungarian film called "Twenty Days" shared the Grand Prize at Moscow's fourth international film festival today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- Platon D. Morozov, of the Soviet Union, who is President this month of the Security Council, called upon members to rise at the opening of the Council session today for a minute of silence in memory of Adlai E. Stevenson.
Two new animal displays at the World's Fair, both of which have won favor this season, are a study in contrasts.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A bizarre story of $4 million in union welfare funds that found its way into "research foundations" in Puerto Rico and Liberia was unfolded today before the Senate Investigations subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Johnson said today that there was a growing awareness that the nation had been "laggard and neglectful of its transportation responsibilities and opportunities."
City welfare unionists picketed the State Department of Social Welfare yesterday in support of their pleas for relief from summer "overwork."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Hale Champion, the California state official who, with his wife and young daughter, was terrorized for 24 hours two weeks ago by kidnappers, gave a Senate panel today his personal reasons for backing a law to restrict the interstate traffic in firearms.
HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 20 -- Last Friday Bob Golardi, who owns the neat sportsfisherman Evelina, captured six striped bass on the red side of Roamer Shoals shortly after dawn.

Hal Connolly and Jay Silvester, two of the world's outstanding weight throwers, withdrew yesterday from the United States track and field team that will oppose the Soviet Union. The meet will be held July 31 and Aug. 1 at Kiev.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., July 20 -- Beverly Packard of Hewlett, L.I., seeded first, and Nancy Cox of Greenvale L.I., seeded second, entered the girls' 18-years-division final in the Long Island girls' tennis championships at the Seawane Club today.
ALBANY, July 20 -- Maintenance doses of narcotics may be administered to addicts in the course of state research programs under a bill signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.

In reporting Moscow's insistence that the United States reconsider Hanoi's four-point proposal for ending the war in Vietnam Peter Grose (July 8) inaccurately summarizes one of these points as requiring "a political settlement according to the program of the Vietcong insurgents."
CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP) -- Bob Bailey hit a grand-slam homer -- his first in the major leagues -- to lift the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-6 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company forecast yesterday a continued rise in the gross national product amounting to $7 billion or $8 billion in each of the remaining quarters this year. This prediction, on the whole decidedly encouraging, is the highlight of the bank's monthly survey of business conditions.
The bonds sold by New York City yesterday to a large banking syndicate were quickly snapped up by investors after they were reoffered for sale to the public.

Alphonse Campaniello has been elected a vice president of First Realty Capital Corporation, which specializes in real estate secondary and equity financing. Mr. Campaniello will retain his post as assistant secretary.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Some 3,000 students from 70 countries met President Johnson on the White House lawn today, but the annual tumult failed to develop

TALLINN, Estonia, July 20 -- A prosperous fishing cooperative on the Gulf of Finland near this attractive Estonian capital suggests that the Estonians have found ways of turning the Soviet collective system to their own advantage.

Not quite all the excitement in Wall Street yesterday centered on the bidding for the record $175.05 million of bonds sold competitively by New York City, recently downgraded by two influential credit reating services.
LONDON, July 20 -- The crime rate is soaring in Britain, and the police are finding it increasingly difficult to catch criminals.
A retired city police inspector and a captain were named in court testimony yesterday and a patrolman was arrested in the revived investigation of a $50 million-a-year gambling syndicate.

PARIS, July 20 -- If President de Gaulle plans a wrecking campaign against the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, as almost all observers here believe he does, his hand has been strengthened by the incident involving the appearance of a United States reconnaissance plane Friday over France's first nuclear plant informed French sources said tonight that the Government had no desire to exploit

ROME, July 20 -- Henry Ford 2d's daughter Charlotte and her mother, Mrs. McDonnell Ford, almost had a spat here last Saturday when they saw Irene Galitzine's new collection two days before anyone else had a peek at it.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 20 (UPI) -- A 13-inch rain today turned six placid rivers and several smaller streams into raging floodwaters that swept through northwestern Missouri, causing property damage estimated at millions of dollars and driving thousands from their homes.
Most grain futures moved lower in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
Bert Lahr and Phyllis Newman are expected to appear in "The Passionate Witch," a musical version of Thorne Smith's story that was filmed as "I Married a Witch."
TO BE YOUNG and unhappily in love may not be one of the peaks of human felicity, but it is an experience which many people as they grow older look back upon with tender nostalgia.
Builders of machine tools in Japan are working hard to sell their standard products abroad.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 20 -- Archie Oldham of Upper Nyack, N.Y., unseeded, eliminated Bob Barker of Port Washington, L.I., the second-seeded player, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, in the fourth round of the United States men's 35 years clay-court tennis championships today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The more liberal course taken by the Supreme Court since Justice Arthur J. Goldberg's appointment to the bench will probably not be radically altered by President Johnson's ultimate choice of a successor to Mr. Goldberg, observers here believe.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (UPI) -- Aluminum Company of America announced today it planned to shut down its aluminum-mill plant at Edgewater, N.J., and to build a multimillion-dollar rolling mill at Lebanon, Pa.

General Li's return to Communist China astonished American scholars at Columbia University with whom he had worked on a 1,000-page autobiography in English translation now complete and under consideration for publication by the Columbia University Press.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, denied today that he was about to leave the Government to return to Michigan politics.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Western Long Island Sound was ideal for water skiing today, but of little use to the sailors at Larchmont Race Week. Weak winds prevented all but 71 yachts from finishing the afternoon's courses within the time limits.

Sales and earnings of the FMC Corporation for the quarter and the half year ended June 30 were the highest of any corresponding periods in the company's history, it reported yesterday in San Jose, Calif.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The man who planned the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba would do it differently if he had to do it again.
PASADENA, Calif., July 20 (UPI) -- The space agency named the Jet Propulsion Laboratory today to manage development of a Project Voyager landing capsule to search for life on Mars in 1971.

Although Norton Simon has increased his stake in the Canada Dry Corporation by about $2.1 million, the atmosphere at the beverage producer's annual meeting yesterday -- the first since Mr. Simon became a director -- was considerably less electric than last year's.
NEWARK, July 20 -- The third man charged with the transcontinental transportation of $500,000 in forged and fraudulent bonds three months ago was arrested in Maplewood, N.J., today.

TRENTON, July 10 (UPI) -- A young mother told an Assembly investigating committee today that children were forced to walk through the cold in ill-fitting clothing and without underwear at Greystone Park State Hospital.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- Wheatley Stable's Queen Empress, voted champion of her division last season, made her 3-year-old debut today at Monmonth Park and won by half a length.
JAMESTOWN, R.I., July 20 -- The fleet sailed across Block Island Sound today as the second-day race of the American Yacht Club cruise covered 22.1 nautical miles from Block Island to Jamestown.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Western Long Island Sound was ideal for water skiing today, but of little use to the sailors at Larchmont Race Week. Weak winds prevented all but 71 yachts from finishing the afternoon's courses within the time limits.

Sales and earnings of the FMC Corporation for the quarter and the half year ended June 30 were the highest of any corresponding periods in the company's history, it reported yesterday in San Jose, Calif.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The man who planned the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba would do it differently if he had to do it again.
PASADENA, Calif., July 20 (UPI) -- The space agency named the Jet Propulsion Laboratory today to manage development of a Project Voyager landing capsule to search for life on Mars in 1971.
The strike by licensed officers of the merchant marine enters its sixth week today with costs mounting and with little prospect of an early settlement.

ROME, July 20 -- A former Italian Foreign Minister was freed tonight from the threat of prosecution on abuse-of-power charges. The action was taken by the Italian Senate and Chamber of Deputies in an unusual joint session.
LONDON, July 21 -- The invitation said "morning dress or uniform or lounge suit," and it seemed simpler to opt for the lounge suit. That was a mistake.

The Palace will open as a legitimate theater on Dec. 28 with "Sweet Charity," the musical starring Gwen Verdon. The booking was confirmed yesterday by Lawrence Carr, co-sponsor of the offering with Robert Fryer and the husband-and-wife team of Joseph and Sylvia Harris.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Observers of last summer's Democratic National Convention may remember Frederick Berger as the hefty Mississippian who stayed and supported the nomination of President Johnson.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 21 (AP) -- The wife of Dr. Duane E. Graveline, one of the six new scientist-astronauts, has filed a suit for divorce charging her husband is "a man of violent and ungovernable outbursts of temper."

The mystery behind the Glen Alden tender offer to purchase a million shares of McKesson Robbins stock and to resell them to the big drug distributor deepened yesterday. None of the top officials of either company would comment on the negotiations which have been under way between their lawyers for the last several days.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange fell moderately yesterday. The list was weak in early trading, but selling was relatively light and prices later leveled somewhat.

DETROIT (AP) -- A two-run homer by Don Demeter in the seventh inning carried the Detroit Tigers to a 2-1 victory over Cleveland and, coupled with a 10-5 victory in the first game, gave them their first double-header sweep of the season.
BOGALUSA, La., July 21 -- Six months ago, Ralph Blumberg, the proprietor of a thriving radio station, squared off in verbal battle with the fast-growing Ku Klux Klan.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Johnson began today to fashion a series of major decisions about the United States' military, political and economic involvement in Vietnam.
LONDON, July 21 -- One of the most famous fossil sites in Europe is being used as a village dump, the Council for British Archeology was informed today.
The American political convention, currently a favorite target of politicians and broadcasters, will come under television scrutiny on the Columbia Broadcasting System this fall.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Eight New York labor leaders invoked the Fifth Amendment against self-incrimination 157 times today when asked by a Senate panel about their unions welfare funds.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Johnson began one of his favorite official operations today -- "the search."
NEWTON, GA., July 21 -- Charles Sherrod, a worker for the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, was beaten today on the courthouse square.
Federal officials yesterday called for resumption of mediation sessions in the maritime strike, which goes into its 37th day today.
MEXICO CITY, July 21 -- The two Mexicos, one very rich, the other very poor, are back in their separate worlds after a rare meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Johnson's nomination of Leonard H. Marks, Washington lawyer, to succeed Carl T. Rowan as director of the United States Information Agency.

CLEVELAND, July 21 (AP) -- Jim Brown, the star fullback of the Cleveland Browns, denied today that he had sexual relations with or beat an 18-year-old girl who has accused him of assault and battery. Brown testified for the first time today in the eighth day of the jury trial.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 21 (AP) -- Washington administrative sources said today that the White House had told the Post Office Department to stop distributing its summer jobs under the "Youth Opportunity Program" as Congressional patronage, The Des Moines Register and The Minneapolis Tribune reported in a copyrighted story.
Five drag and cosmetic manufacturers reported yesterday record-breaking sales and earnings for the first half of the year.
The New York Air Brake Company announced yesterday a realigmment of its top executive team. It also reported that sales and earnings rose to new highs ill the second quarter and first half.

Governor Rockefeller and Senator Jacob K. Javits held an unannounced private meeting here Monday -- their first face-to-face session since the recent outpouring of reports of a deep rift between them.

The Times news story of July 1 left the impression that the New York City public school system does not provide a full program of summer activities for our children. Having striven for expansion of summer opportunities when I was president of the Board of Education, I must call the following facts to your attention.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Johnson disclosed plans today to establish a series of Adlai E. Stevenson Fellowships to enable young people to work in United Nations organizations.

JOHN WILLIAM GARDNER, chairman of the White House Conference on Education, is widely regarded as the most powerful behind-the-scenes figure in American education today. But he would be the first to deny vigorously that he plays such a role.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A Justice Department official warned today against excesses in civil rights demonstrations that would lead to violent upheavals.

THE last quarter-final in the series of matches among the candidates for the challenger's role to the world title -- a best-out-of-ten game match between Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia and Bent Larsen of Denmark -- was won by Larsen, 5 1/2-2 1/2.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Under Secretary of the Treasury Joseph W. Barr said today that the rise in defense activity required by the war in South Vietnam would not require a tax increase.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 21 -- A 63-year-old politician Huh Jik, burned himself critically today in a suicide attempt to protest the treaty establishing normal relations between South Korea and Japan.

The stock market behaved like an expectant father yesterday. Pending some news, it had to keep moving, although the pacing up and down bespoke a bad case of nerves rather than the desire to go somewhere.
Mayor Wagner made the first official disclosure of his wedding arrangements yesterday, through his Executive Secretary, Debs Myers.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Democratic leaders said today the controversial bill to repeal state right-to-work laws would be brought to the floor in the House Monday.
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation set records in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales and net income for the second quarter and the first half of 1965.
LIMA, Peru, July 21 -- President Fernando Belaunde Terry said today that Cuba and the Soviet Union were helping Communist "gangsters" bring unrest to his country.

LONDON, July 21 -- The London Symphony Orchestra announced today its plans for the 1965-66 season, which will include four concerts at Carnegie Hall in New York. The dates are April 2, 3, 6 and 7, and all four will be conducted by the orchestra's new chief conductor, Istvan Kertesz.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has elected William Widmayer a senior vice president, it was announced yesterday by Thomas S. Gates, chairman.
ALBANY, July 21 -- The New York City Transit Authority is empowered to build a Manhattan-Queens subway tunnel at 63d Street under a bill signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.
A NEWLY created position in Macy's home furnishings department, announced yesterday by the store, may have an important effect on what customers will ultimately be able to buy.
TWO German shepherds and three dogs of mixed breeds have been selected from among 55 nominees as the finalists in the 12th annual Ken-L Ration competition to choose America's Dog Hero for 1965.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Former Senator Kenneth B. Keating urged today that the Government establish a broad birth control program and stop "treating family planning like the unwanted stepchild of medical practice.
TOKYO, July 21 (Reuters) -- Japan announced today it would impose heavy fines on airlines that land passengers here without visas when these are required.
The Democratic leaders in the State Legislature started legal action yesterday to prevent the next Legislature from creating a permanent reapportionment plan for the state.
TANGIER ISLAND, Va., July 21 (UPI) -- The homemade white banner read, "Thank God for Dr. and Mrs. Watson."
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board notified 66 cities today that traffic at their airports has not been meeting the C.A.B.'s "use it or lose it" standards.

CAIRO, July 21 -- Mostafa Amin, one of Cairo's most prominent newspaper editors, was arrested today on undisclosed charges. Rumors spread through usually informed circles that he had been picked up for providing official information to Americans.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Three new accounts of the Bay of Pigs invasion, provided by former Kennedy Administration officials, agree that President Kennedy's political misgivings about the project materially reduced whatever chances of success it had.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 21 (UPI) -- Five Job Corps antipoverty trainees from Chicago faced charges today in the shooting of two air policemen. Two were accused of assault to murder and three others were to be arraigned on charges of having conspired to rob the airmen.

BARNEGAT LIGHT, N.J., July 21 -- Although the seas were rough and there was a 20-knot wind, Capt. Dick Clineman, who knew there was a large school of tuna holding a convention southeast of here, decided yesterday that he would try to get in on the meeting.

The twice-postponed meeting of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States has been postponed again, this time indefinitely. Whatever the official excuses, the real reason is that there was nothing fruitful to talk about. State Department officials doubtless breathed sighs of relief, for a conference on the planned date of Aug. 4 would have been more embarrassing than useful.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 (AP) -- Felipe Alou stroked four hits and Henry Aaron had three, including his 20th home run of the season, as the Milwaukee Braves won their ninth straight game, beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-4, tonight.

Japanese bowlers have their "hayai" alleys (fast ones) and their "osoi" alleys (slow ones), and Swedish bowlers call a split a "skadis." But in all 35 foreign countries where the sound of crashing tenpins reverberates, a strike is a strike.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he was "anxious" to explore the advantages of creating separate city Department of Recreation.

A New Jersey economics professor reported yesterday, after a visit to Saigon and other capitals, that the North Vietnamese had demanded United States agreement in principle on a withdrawal of forces from Vietnam, and not an actual withdrawal, as a precondition for negotiations.

The split in the Brooklyn Democratic organization was dramatized again yesterday when 11 of the 22 male district leaders endorsed City Council President Paul R. Screvane for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

DEARBORN, Mich., July 21 -- The list of possible successors to Ford Frick as commissioner of baseball was narrowed today from approximately 50 to 20 as the owners of the 20 major league clubs held their annual summer meeting.
ATLANTA, July 21 -- A Negro police chief hired last week by the small town of Crawfordville, Ga., has resigned.
The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, a big utility that supplies electricity to an area in northern California with a population of 7.72 million, sold $75 million of bonds yesterday.
News magazines continue to make news of their own with new ones cropping up in various parts of the world with the Time format and, occasionally, the success story to go with it.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities secretly questioned today the first witness in its long-pending inquiry into the Ku Klux Klan.
The Appellate Division, in Brooklyn, has ruled that the city violated its own charter in giving preference to a synagogue in bidding against a commercial builder for a strip of property.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Johnson's highway beautification program appeared headed for a dead end today unless he persuades Congress to pay an extra toll.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 21 (AP) -- The Ghanaian peace delegation to North Vietnam flew back here from Moscow today because, its leader said, the Soviet airlines had too much business to fly him via the direct route to Peking and Hanoi.
The Women's Auxiliary Board and Hospital Associates of St. Barnabas Hospital will hold their annual benefit fashion show and card party in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Sept. 28.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- During the House debate today on the antipoverty bill, Representative Charles E. Goodell, Republican of New York, said his 5-year-old son Michael had been invited to join the Headstart program in Northwest Washington.

A new pharmacological approach holds out great hope for combating the wretched evil of narcotics addiction. This is the development of antagonistic drugs -- methadone and several others -- that apparently have the property of affecting addicts so that even if subsequently they revert to heroin, it no longer produces the effect they crave.

The Board of Education last night unanimously elected Lloyd K. Garrison as its new president to succeed James B. Donovan, who resigned on June 30. Alfred A. Giardino was elected vice president, to succeed Mr. Garrison.
THE high-stake rubber bridge games played each spring in the famous White Room of the Monte Carlo Casino are among the wildest as well as the most cosmopolitan in the world.

THE French-American Festival presented by the New York Philharmonic filled one of its important functions by presenting Berlioz's "The Damnation of Faust" at Philharmonic Hall last night. For this is one of those big works, masterly in many ways, that do not get done as often as they should because of their requirements in terms of chorus and soloists and because they are not of great public appeal, at least in this country.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The State Department announced today that "no increase in aid to India is being contemplated at this time."

HARTFORD, July 21 -- Golfers turn professional at too early an age, Jack Tuthill, the tournament supervisor of the Professional Golfers Association, said today. He said that is one reason the caliber of amateur competitive golf in this country is dwindling.
TRENTON, July 21 -- The State Education Department refused at a public hearing today to restore immediately the accreditation of Shelton College in Cape May.

ALBANY, July 21 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he had vetoed 11 bills that would have weakened his liquor-law reform program. At the same time, he signed into law three measures to strengthen the program.

RIVERHEAD, L.I. July 21 -- The grand jury completed its investigation this morning of charges that the Suffolk County Republican executive committee had been influenced by the underworld in its selection of candidates.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 -- American and South Vietnamese officials were preparing today for at least a doubling of United States forces in Vietnam despite Secretary McNamara's contention that no decision has been reached.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A report to Congressional Republicans said tonight that President Johnson was weak in dealing with the press and that the party should take advantage of this by making friends with newsmen.

Although he hadn't been in action in more than a month, Our Michael of Edgehill Farms was made the overwhelming favorite in the $29,450 Great American Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The son of Bolero justified the fans' faith by winning the 5 1/2-furlong race decisively in the excellent time of 1:033-5.
Earnings and revenues of American Airlines, Inc., soared in the first half. Results in the second quarter also were impressive.
The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday the election of Gerald J. Fischer as vice president and head of foreign credit operations of the Ford Motor Credit Company, a subsidiary.
New York's poor will soon be involved in an unusual experiment in democracy.

Percy C. Magnus, 72-year-old New York civic leader, corporation head and one-time president of the New York Board of Trade, was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday morning to six months in jail for failing to pay his income tax on time.
Saigon, Hawaii and Washington, including the White House, the Pentagon and the State Department, are all involved in the target selection and bombing procedures used against North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A Senate-House conference committee approved today the final text of a history-making bill providing health insurance for the elderly and otherwise liberalizing the Social Security program.

BOSTON, July 21 (AP) -- Bob Allison hit a two-run triple in the ninth inning and scored on an error as the American League-leading Minnesota Twins defeated Boston, 11-8, tonight and completed a double-header sweep.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A 27-year-old patronage employe of the House of Representatives who heads a conservative you group, Young Americans for Freedom, has become the focus of the latest intraparty squable among Republicans.

The vehicular homicide indictment against Gareth Martinis was dismissed in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday on the ground of double jeopardy. If the decision of Justice Samuel J. Silverman is upheld, Mr. Martinis will not have a new trial, which was sought by the prosecution after the second trial ended with a hung jury last week.

LONDON, July 21 -- British moviegoers will soon see the name of this country's former Ambassador in Washington on the censorship certificate shown at the start of every film. Lord Harlech became president of the British Board of Film Censors today.
The $111.1 million of New York City bonds offered publicly Tuesday were reported completely sold shortly after trading started yesterday morning.

ATHENS, July 21 -- One student was killed and 130 persons were injured as police riot squads using tear gas battled in downtown Athens for four hours tonight with demonstrators demanding that former Premier George Papandreou be retrained to power.
LONDON, July 21 -- In one of the heaviest trading days since the London gold market reopened in 1954, the price of gold rose today to its best level since April 21.

A warrant for the arrest of Archbishop Iakovos, primate the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America, on charges of housing violations, was revoked yesterday by Civil Court Judge Martin Kraus.

American consumers have become increasingly convinced that they are facing good economic prospects throughout the rest of the decade, but they are not quite so positive regarding the near-term outlook, a survey by the University of Michigan indicates.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. urged today speedy strengthening of the enforcement powers of his new Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to help end job discrimination.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 22 -- Thirty B-52 jet bombers raided a Vietcong-held jungle sector 30 miles north-northwest of Saigon at dusk yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, July 21 -- Army lawyers took a deposition from a witness here today in the court martial of Capt. Sanford Wolfson, a medical officer accused of feigning mental illness in South Vietnam.

BALTIMORE, July 21 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Orioles swept a doubleheader from the Kansas City Athletics tonight, winning the opener, 1-0, on the four-hit pitching of Milt Pappas and Dick Hall and gaining a 9-2 victory in the second game.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Communications Satellite Corporation filed new rates today for the use of its Early Bird satellite for trans-Atlantic television.
WHITE PLAINS, July 21 -- An attempt by Port Chester to curb all-night drinking by teen-agers was held unconstitutional today by State Supreme Court Justice Joseph F. Hawkins.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange continued to lose ground yesterday in moderate trading.
When a product or service is offered at a price that seems too good to be true, there is a good chance that it isn't.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 21 (AP) -- Barbara Fay White, last year's winner, gained the quarter-finals of the Women's Western Golf Association tournament today, but Jan Ferraris of San Francisco played the best golf and moved up among the top contenders.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California made an extraordinary public appeal today to Senator Thomas H. Kuchel, a Republican, to stay in the Senate rather than run for Governor.
The latest chatty newsletter sent by Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, to the membership takes pains to explain the need for a new building.
Wheat futures advanced in moderate trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Other grain futures were mixed.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley was accused today of being anti-Negro and of using the city's share of Federal antipoverty funds to strengthen his Democratic political machine.
LOS ANGELES, July 21 -- The poems and commentaries by Robert Frost were not designed for the stage, but they shed an uncommon glow of intelligence and sensibility when spoken in a theater.

LONDON, July 21 -- The Beaverbrook Newspapers "unreservedly withdrew" today any suggestion that a former Civil Lord of the Admiralty had had a homosexual relationship with William J.C. Vassall, convicted in 1962 of having spied for the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley is irked over the refusal of airlines to transfer some of their flights from over-burdened O'Hare International Airport to the smaller Midway Terminal.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The most striking fact of the White House Conference on Education was the changing of the guard of educational leadership. The representatives of educational organizations who used to symbolize the Establishment seemed displaced by men and women who represent themselves and their own ideas.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Johnson Administration is taking unusual steps to avert adverse reaction among Arab and African states to the appointment of Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court as chief United States representative at the United Nations.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 -- Al Jackson came closer to pitching a no-hit game than any other Met pitcher has when he held the Pittsburgh Pirates hitless for 7 1/3 innings tonight. Then Willie Stargell cracked a sharp single to felt.
HISTORIANS overlook a cryptic reason for British settlements in America. The Cavaliers, the Pilgrims, and all, were opening a new world for visiting English lecturers.
ROME, July 21 -- Alberto Fabiani, an estimable figure in the Italian couture, is a perfect example of how silly the Rome-Florence fashion feud is.
PARIS, July 21 -- The French Government went out of its way today to dispel the notion that it might be engaged in an attempt to mediate the Vietnam war.

It is evident that our Vietnam policy has the effect of lending strength to irreconcilable anti-American elements in Soviet Russia, not to speak of mainland China, and it has alienated responsible people in many parts of the world.
Mayor Wagner will go on radio and television tonight to tell the city "what we must do" to meet the water crisis.
DETROIT, July 21 -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association appointed today a top-level committee to prepare a program to expand the industry's safety efforts.
OTTAWA, July 21 -- Lucien Rivard, Montreal narcotics suspect, will be extradited to the United States within a day, to face charges at Laredo, Tex.

One of the first areas planned for designation as a historic district by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission is in the path of the Lower Manhattan Expressway. Whether the expressway is constructed above or below ground, the buildings seem slated for certain demolition.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- House Republicans tried today to write more state and local controls into the Federal campaign against poverty.
OF all the people we know, Jim Lee is the only one whose life was irrevocably altered by a Vienna sausage omelet.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- The American Osteopathic Association voted today to maintain its identity as a separate and distinct school of medicine.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 21 -- Gene Scott of St. James, L.I., was sorely challenged in gaining the quarter-finals of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today, with Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia.
The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance has liquidated its preferred stock investments in the Borg-Warner Corporation and the Corning Glass Works.

Speaking of Vietnam in a recent press conference President Johnson said: "Our national honor is at stake. Our word is at stake." It was not the first time that the Administration has taken this position, but the emphasis and the timing of Mr. Johnson's remark gave it special importance.
Following are excerpts from the opinion handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman in Bronx Supreme Court in the case against Gareth Martinis:

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- George L. Wilson, a Federal tax agent who believes in fighting "fire with fire" against suspected racketeers, acknowledged today that he had ordered wiretaps on three occasions.

LONDON, July 21 -- Thunderstorms raged over London as Norman Hartnell and Charles Creed showed their fall collections. The models paraded against a background of spattering hailstones and flashes of lightning, better prepared in their voluminous tweeds for the extreme cold of the Scottish moors than for the English monsoon season.

Mrs. Patricia DeAlesandro, the former Playboy Bunny who was arrested in Sunnyvale, Calif., on July 12, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of trying to bribe a Federal juror in a narcotics trial.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- France shipped $268 million of gold from New York to her own vaults in May, the Department of Commerce figures disclosed today.
The following statement appeared in a news report in The Times of July 11, concerning the growing problem of juvenile delinquency in New York's Chinatown:

MOSCOW, July 21 -- W. Averell Harriman conferred today for the second time with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin. They explored opportunities for Soviet-American understanding despite the hostility over Vietnam.

Three policemen have been dismissed for refusing to testify, under a waiver of immunity, before a grand jury that is investigating charges that they conspired to extort $50,000 from a Cuban doctor now sought as an abortionist.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (AP) -- Bob Schroder's pinch-single off the right-field fence with the bases loaded in the 11th inning gave the San Francisco Giants a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 21 -- Two men who took a light plane without permission were killed last night when the single-engine craft struck a power line here and crashed into a lot.
A witness may leave the Federal grand jury room to consult his lawyer, but 83 times in 3 hours is too much, a Government prosecutor declared yesterday.
The Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee was declared the winner this morning of collective-bargaining elections in 23 major taxicab fleet garages.
Commuters may soon be able to travel on the Long Island Rail Road directly through Brooklyn into Manhattan over BMT subway tracks.

Tom Tresh did double duty last night for the New York Yankees. In the Chicago White Sox half of the 10th inning, he saved the game. In the Yankee half, he won it with a home run that provided a 7-6 victory.
ELY, Minn., July 21 -- Lynda Bird Johnson, who is roughing it on a secret itinerary somewhere in the three-million-acre Superior National Forest, was having a "good time" today.

CHICAGO, July 21 (UPI) -- Ernie Banks singled in the 10th inning today to score Don Landrum and give the Chicago Cubs an 8-7 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The Cubs made 18 hits and the Phils 13.
San Juan, P.R., sold yesterday $9.7 million of public improvement bonds to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Northern Trust Company, the Bank of America and the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy has driven a narrow political wedge between Representative John V. Lindsay and his campaign chairman, Senator Jacob K. Javits.
WARSAW, July 21 (AP) -- Poland named a new National Police (militia) chief today, 39-year-old Gen. Tadeusz Pietrzak, member of a nationalist Communist faction called the Partisans.
BOGOTA, Columbia, July 21 -- On the 155th anniversary yesterday of the start of Colombia's wars of independence from Spain, President Guillerno Leon Valencia convened a new Congress.
The Swiss franc continued to gain strength yesterday in relation to the dollar in foreign exchange dealings here. It rose to 23.17 3/8 cents from Tuesday's closing price of 23.17.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The Ford Motor Company promised today that seven safety features that are now optional on new cars would be standard equipment on all the company's 1966 models.
MOSCOW, July 21 -- Aleksei Solyanik, a Soviet sea captain who was a hero to a generation of schoolboys, found his popular image shattered today in a torrent of official abuse.

Two publishers are bringing out anthologies that bear the title, "The Wit and Wisdom of Adlai Stevenson." Hawthorn Books has started printing a hard cover book on the subject for publication on July 30. Pyramid Books has announced a paperbound edition for Sept. 1, "or much sooner, if possible," according to Nathan Keats, vice president.
RUMSON, N.J., July 21 -- Ten young women will be presented at the sixth Rumson Debutante Ball, to be held on Sept. 7 at the Sea Bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Organization of American States decided today to postpone indefinitely the special inter-American conference that was to have opened in Rio de Janeiro Aug. 4.
The music of Richard Strauss was on tap last night at Lewisohn Stadium, and for the occasion the Metropolitan Opera brought in Elisabeth Schwarzkopf.
If there is a chance that a man might end up in Vietnam or some other trouble spot--as soldier or civilian--he may have difficulty in buying a standard life insurance policy.
CAIRO, July 21 -- The split between the peace and war factions in republican Yemen has not been resolved by the formation of a new Cabinet, informed Yemeni sources said today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 21 (UPI) -- Waters of northwestern Missouri's devastating flash floods ebbed slowly today, exposing shattered and mud-filled homes, stores and utility plants, and the bodies of two men who drowned in rescue attempts.

ABOARD U.S.S. CURRITUCK, in the South China Sea, July 15 -- At least 18 American warships and 15 seaplanes have been patrolling the coast of South Vietnam to block infiltration by Vietcong troops and supplies.
The Continental Can Company had some good news yesterday for its stockholders.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 21 -- Reveille was sounded at 7:10 A.M. today at Westchester County's first summer camp for advanced studies of the visual and performing arts by teen-agers.

Negotiations between the central bank of Uruguay and leading commercial banks here concerning the recasting of $50 million in Uruguayan debt with the banks have come to a standstill, the head of the Uruguayan financial mission disclosed last night.
ALBANY, July 21 -- State legislators and legislative employes will be barred from practicing for a fee before the Court of Claims after Jan. 1 under a tightened Code of Ethics.

New York City's current water shortage is the most severe of a series which the city has suffered during approximately the past decade. Our experience over this period makes it evident that unless our water reserves are promptly and very substantially increased, we are certain to undergo similar, and quite likely more severe, crises in the immediate future.

A few months ago, Francine Farkas, the wife of Alexander Farkas, president of Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., was stressing the pervading influence of the snood-type hat in all fashion price lines in her job as Alexander's fashion coordinator.

Indictments charging grand larceny and bribery in the construction of a section of the New York Thruway, dismissed nine months ago in Westchester County Court, were reinstated yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.
The police said yesterday that there was "nothing new" in the search for the killer of a Queens boy and girl who were abducted from their home last week.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Senate liberals, who have made a career of denouncing the use of the Judiciary Committee to prevent a floor vote on legislation they favor, are now employing the same committee to prevent a floor vote on legislation they oppose.

Reports linking cigarette smoking and cancer apparently have had little effect on the American Tobacco Company's business. The big producer of cigarettes and its consolidated subsidiaries had record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30, the company reported yesterday.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 21 -- The four favored players today filled semi-final berths in the 15th women's Tri-County Golf Association championship tournament at the 6,017-yard, par-72 Leewood Golf Club.

Visitors to the United States will be able to make confirmed reservations at any of 6,000 American hotels and motels before leaving home, under, a new arrangement between Pan American World Airways and the American Hotel and Motel Association.

A medical examination of the body of Nelson Erby, 28-year-old Negro former convict shot by a white policeman in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last Thursday, showed no wound of the head, District Attorney Aaron E. Koota said last night.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A Senate Banking Committee tentatively approved legislation today to empower a Federal Reserve Bank to buy and sell securities of French and other foreign governments.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 21 -- Nationalist China tried to take the defection of its former Acting President, Gen. Li Tsung-jen, to Peking in stride today. Officials here are attaching as little significance to the defection as possible.
A 200-acre mountainous tract in Rockland County that is expected to yield more than $1 million in landfill has been leased from H. Pierson Mapes, head of the Pierson family holdings.

Polonia Bytom of Poland moved into a commanding position in its bid for the International Soccer League's Second-Section title last night when it blanked Kilmarnock, the Scot-Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 21 -- Marshall Green, the new United States Ambassador to Indonesia, arrived tonight from Hong Kong accompanied by his wife and 14-year-old son.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd criticized today the staff of a Senate subcommittee for distributing a publication that described the American Friends Service Committee as "a well-known transmission belt for the Communist apparatus."
KAMPALA, Uganda, July 21 -- As the rebellion in the Southern Sudan drags on, it raises an increasing treat to black African states on the Sudanese frontier.
TO avoid confusion, let it be understood that the "Harlow" that opened yesterday at the Palace and the 58th Street is not the "Harlow" that was exhibited at the Paramount a couple of months ago.

" MODERN football is a much better and much more attractive game than the one I played and coached," said Harry Kipke. "It's become wide open and high scoring with the premium on offense. In my day the concentration was on defense and that's why Fielding (Hurry-Up) Yost became so great a coach.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 21 -- The $35,800 United States Harness Writers' Trot, a one-mile race for 3-year-olds to be held at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night, was made a nonbetting race today and shifted from the regular card to a 7:15 starting time.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 21 -- Negotiations by the mediator committee of the Organization of American States with the conflicting Dominican factions were resumed today after a suspension of nearly a week.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -- The teenie-weenie bikini has not yet arrived at Larchmont Race week. Some institutions are still sacred. But the two-piece bathing suit, the grandmother of the bikini, has definitely gone to sea.
The Borden Company will acquire the Bama Company, a processor of preserves, peanut butter and salad dressing, effective Aug. 3, for 400,000 shares of common stock worth $17 million

Nine pacifists tried to block the entrance to the Army and Air Force Recruiting Center at 39 Whitehall Street yesterday and were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct. They were among 50 pickets who carried signs denouncing the draft, the war in Vietnam and the United States intervention in Santo Domingo.

So deservedly multitudinous and so understandably expansive have been the encomiums for and analyses of Adlai Stevenson since his death that they tend to overshadow such tributes as came to him while he was still alive to hear them.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A system to alert drivers about highway dangers by equipping their auto radios to speak pre-recorded words of caution was demonstrated today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States intends to press its proposal for a world monetary conference despite French rejection of the idea, a high source said today.

An alleged plot to smuggle $180 million in gold bullion out of the country, so it could be sold at a price higher than the $35 an ounce paid in the United States, was described in State Supreme Court yesterday.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 21 -- Tony Vincent of New York, the defending champion, defeated Edward Kujan of Manhasset, L.I., seeded eighth by 6-1, 6-1, today and gained the semi-final round of the United States men's 35-years clay court tennis championship.
An unusual plagiarism suit against the publishers of a novel about a 16th-century Irish pirate queen has been settled here.

Prospects of sensible liberalization of New York State's 1787 divorce law, that makes adultery the only allowable grounds, have been greatly improved by the appointments made to the Joint Legislative Committee on Matrimonial and Family Laws, which will report recommendations by Dec. 15.

BOSTON, July 21 -- Despite the addition of three new vessels, the Boston fishing industry remains becalmed. Figures released by the U.S. Bureau of Commercial Fisheries show that for the first half of 1965, a total of 51,609,000 pounds of fish were landed here.
The July 13 editorial headed "The Literacy Test" indicates a conspicuous inconsistency on the part of The New York Times.
A 36-inch water main burst early today at 295 Central Park West, and hundreds of thousands of gallons of water poured into the roadway between 86th and 91st Streets, the police reported.

In the brisk, firm manner of a docent determined to see that the viewer gets his money's worth, this book clicks off thousands of corridor miles through the science museums, art galleries, planetaria, boyhood shrines, restored villages, historical societies and national monuments that dot our culture-conscious communities.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate approved today a measure of local suffrage and a limited form of self, government for this city of 815,000 persons.

A precise ride aboard Royal Beater in the feature race was only one of the victorious performances contributed by Braulio Baeza at Aqueduct yesterday. The stolid jockey from Panama entertained the gathering of 27,124 by guiding home four winners in the seven races in which he rode.
The widely diversified Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that sales and earnings rose to historic highs in the three and six months ended June 30.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Dr. Nicholas J. Capos, a prominent Chicago surgeon, was spared yesterday from serving a jail sentence for income tax evasion because a judge decided that society needed his medical skills.
OTTAWA, July 22 -- Any step to tap the Great Lakes to satisfy New York's urgent water needs would deeply concern Canada.
The bond market yesterday was the quietest it has been this year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, took issue today with statements by Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach about the bureau's efforts in the campaign against organized crime.

A year-round theater, suitable for stage presentations, films, industrial exhibits, conventions, sports events and special attractions, will replace the Westbury (L.I.) Music Fair, a 2,064-seat tent theater-in-the-round.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
The Armco Steel Corporation earned $24,123,000, or $1.63 a share, on sales of $312,409,000 during the second quarter of 1965, the company announced yesterday at its headquarters in Middleton, Ohio.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 22 -- The potential extra gallons that a Hudson pumping station would provide New York City may be only a drop in the bucket, but they made a big splash in Poughkeepsie today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission will dismiss all equal time complaints of the democratic national committee against radio stations based on last year's campaign, a spokesman said today.

General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday first-half operating revenues of $134,886,522. This compared with $126,152,903 a year earlier. Net income of $24,345,588, equal to $1.02 a share, compared with $22,613,789, or 95 cents a share, in the 1964 period.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- The wife of a State Department employe told the police she had been raped in daylight today as she took her dogs for a walk in the Georgetown section of the capital.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- The Soviet Union brought a young British language teacher to trial today on charges of subversive activity in the service of a shadowy group of anti-Soviet emigres allegedly working for Western intelligence agencies.

Stephen Glazer, 24 - year - old Bronx resident, who was convicted in 1962 of the fatal stabbing of his fiancee, was released in bail yesterday to await a new trial after serving two years and seven months in Sing Sing.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United States apologized to France today for having "inadvertently" violated forbidden air space over a French nuclear production plant.
ALBANY, July 22 -- Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a Democratic bill that would have required the counties of the state to reapportion their governing bodies on a population basis.
LONDON, July 22 -- Sir Alec Douglas-Home resigned tonight as leader of the Opposition and of the Conservative party.

John V. Lindsay has declared that the presence of the chief administrator of the city's housing program on his ticket would not inhibit him "in the slightest" from attacking the Wagner administration's housing policies.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A record $4 billion of corporate issues of bonds, notes and debentures was sold in the second quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
ALBANY, July 22 -- A complete revision of the state's 84-year-old Penal Law, embodying sweeping changes in line with present judicial and social thinking, was approved by Governor Rockefeller today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today he thought Representative John V. Lindsay was leading in the race for Mayor of New York but had not built up an "insurmountable" advantage.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Dr. Harry J. Goett, director of the Goddard Space Flight Center, will become a special assistant to the National Aeronautics and Space Administrator, James E. Webb, the space agency said today.

DETROIT, July 22 (AP) -- The nation's domestic passenger car production this week will total an estimated 169,567 units, compared with 187,704 last week, Automotive News, a trade publication, said today.

CAIRO, July 22 -- The Egyptian Government's official press agency has accused a prominent Cairo newspaper editor, Mustafa Amin, of having spied "a long time" for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange were mixed yesterday as volume slumped to its lowest level of the year.
ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury in St. Louis indicted 18 oil concerns and 17 individuals today in connection with price fixing on the sale of liquid asphalt to the state of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today that new methods of handling drunken persons should be considered as one way of easing the burden on the nation's law enforcement system.

VIENNA -- There is no such thing as a Geiger counter measuring freedom, but one cannot doubt, after a nine-year lapse, that there is far more liberty in Hungary today than under the earlier and infamous Rakosi dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits accused President Johnson today of compromising the national policy on civil rights by his appointment of former Governor James P. Coleman of Mississippi to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

The resignation of Sir Alec Douglas-Home as leader of the Opposition in the House of Commons has a much greater importance in British politics than any similar development could have in the United States. The Opposition leader in Parliament has an official position and a government salary. He would be the man to take the Prime Ministership if the reigning party were defeated in a general election.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- President Johnson saidl today he had directed Federal gencies to provide al! the emer- I gency assistance that theyi could to alleviate the record l drought,

AREA A -- Blues are running in fair quantities 14 to 16 miles east northeast of Manasquan Inlet. Sea bass and porgies are being found from Manasquan Beach to Shrewsbury Rocks., Tuna, ranging in size from 30 to 50 pounds, have been sighted south of the bluefish area.
