Trans World Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to reject a request by the Hughes Tool Company to withhold 1,363,636 common shares of T.W.A. from the voting trust set up in 1960 as part of a financing program for the airline's jet fleet.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today an immigration reform bill that would wipe out the 41-year-old national origins quota system for selecting new United States citizens.

The appearance of the Pee Wee Russell Quintet in the Jazz in the Garden series last night at the Museum of Modern Art was covered by National Broadcasting Company television cameras and by a steady drizzle.

CAIRO, July 22 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced a plan tonight for the withdrawal of Egyptian troops from Yemen within six months provided a satisfactory peace can be worked out for the country's civil war and Saudi Arabia ends her aid to Yemeni royalist tribes.
A check for $2,034,631 was presented yesterday to Goodbody Co. of 2 Broadway to settle the largest robbery claim ever made to an insurance company by a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A "Russian ballot" -- one with little choice -- and strict election rules were used by leaders of a teamster local in the New York metropolitan area to dominate union members, Senate investigators were told today.

BANGALORE, India, July 22 -- Catcalls, insults and black flags greeted Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri when he arrived here today for a party meeting. The demonstrators were protesting the Government's stand on the Goa issue.
Preliminary reports showed yesterday that new car sales in mid-July continued to roll along at a record pace.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is conducting a campaign to publicize the existence of family-planning clinics in five Catholic hospitals in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A Federal report warned today that unless immediate action was taken, two of the main reservoirs supplying New York City with water would be completely dry by November, and the six others would be sorely depleted.

Srikebound ship operators have offered to let George Meany set up special arbitration machinery to handle troublesome issues on manning that are balking a settlement in the 37-day walkout of marine engineers.

KANSAS CITY, July 22 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association and the United States Track anti Field Federation today agreed to sanction the United States team's warmup meet at Wichita tomorrow night, clearing the way for Randy Matson, holder of the world shot-put record, and other collegians to participate.
The speed with which orders are executed on the New York Stock Exchange and the rapidity of relaying these order confirmations to customers always have been a source of pride to brokerage houses.
Governor Rockefeller vetoed yesterday a bill that would have permitted primary fights for the governorship and other statewide offices.

A small art gallery exclusively for the work of New York State artists has sprung up in the city offices of Senator Robert K. Kennedy. To give "encouragement and exposure" to lesser-known artists, the Senator has been borrowing works from galleries and museums throughout the state.
BUFFALO, July 22 (AP) -- The defending champion, Don Allen, and a 1962 champion advanced to the quarter-finals of the New York State men's amateur golf tournament today on a rain-dampened course.
HARTFORD, July 22 -- Bob Goalby scored a 64, a total he has seldom duplicated, to take the lead in the $70,000 Insurance City open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A plan to use the Early Bird satellite for live television coverage of the recovery of the Gemini 5 astronauts flared into a dispute today over control of a proposed shipboard communications station.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 22 (AP) -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, First Secretary or chief of the Soviet Communist party, and Teng Hsiao-ping, the Chinese party secretary, met here twice this week to discuss the Vietnam situation, reliable sources said today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- There is a grim, cautionary note for President Johnson in the sad unfolding of so many personal accounts of the Bay of Pigs disaster. All of these memoirs agree on one thing -- Mr. Kennedy mistrusted the whole invasion plan he inherited but was unable to halt it for longer study or cancel it altogether.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 -- Steps toward transforming the dream of an Asian development bank into a reality were discussed today by the Secretary General, U Thant, his chief advisers and members of a United Nations committee appointed for that task.
BONN, July 22 -- W. Averell Harriman, President Johnson's special representative, arrived by air tonight for a round of talks with members of the West German Government.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 22 -- Vice President Fazil Kutchuk and the three Turkish Cypriote Cabinet ministers are excluded from the provisions of a bill to extend the life of the present Cyprus Government up to one year. The bill will be discussed by the House of Representatives tomorrow.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 22 (AP) -- Gov. John McKeithen said today he expected the 40-man biracial advisory commission he will appoint to drive the Congress of Racial Equality out of Louisiana, but later modified the statement.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- In a "call to action," the Commission on Religion and Race of the National Council of Churches has urged the nation's churchmen to appeal to their Congressmen "in the strongest terms" to turn down any proposed reapportionment amendments.

BRUSSELS, July 22 -- The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community transmitted to the six member countries today its revised package of proposals on agricultural financing and fiscal issues.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House passed today the bill to enlarge and extend the drive against poverty.
AUBURN, Ala., July 22 -- A surgical operation that could prove to be one of the most expensive in history was carried out here today in an antiseptic little room overlooking a cow barn.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 22 -- An appeal by residents in Turkey was cabled to President Johnson yesterday asking that Pvt. Kenneth Baldwin of Utica, N.Y., be allowed to remain in Turkey when he is discharged from the United States Army.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Pete Richert drove in three runs tonight with a single and a bunt that refused to roll foul to lead the Washington Senators to a 5-1 victory over the Los Angeles Angels.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 -- A former national champion in the Ensign Class continued a tight struggle with the current holder of the title in that fast-growing species of fiberglass racing sloops and a former North American women's sailing champion maintained her successful efforts in the International One-Design Class in the biggest sailing carnival of Long Island Sound today.
Representative John. V. Lindsay Republican-Liberal designee for Mayor, called for postponement of the Lower Manhattan Expressway yesterday "until the next Mayor of New York takes office."
BADEN-BADEN, Germany, July 10 -- The German spas, those opulent watering places that reached their zenith of splendor in Victorian and Edwardian times, have become fashionable once again.

ROME, July 22 -- The return of Charlie Chaplin to filmmaking as star and director, with Sophia Loren as his co-star, is virtually assured for this fall, according to Carlo Ponti, Miss Loren's husband.
Mrs. Lira Wou Chang, the newest officer at the 181-year-old Bank of New York, is known to her associates as being "yung yun le kwan" -- forever optimistic -- when it comes to the stock market.

TORONTO, July 21 -- Five weeks after the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation was placed in receivership, the youthful Canadian money market is still unsettled by the repercussions. Part of the difficulty is attributed to the usually enthusiastic United States lenders who are keeping more of their dollars at home at the urging of President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Epilepsy Foundation said today that two drug companies were peddling a mail-order treatment of epilepsy that might be dangerous.

A college band, neatly uniformed in striped seersucker jackets, white shirts and black ties, sat under the protective eaves of the United States Pavilion at the World's Fair yesterday afternoon and played the Battle Hymn of the Republic.
Anheuser-Busch, Inc., brewer of Budweiser beer, announced yesterday that its sales, earnings and beer volume in the first half of 1965 were the highest in history.

MIAMI, July 22 (UPI) -- A beachboy friend of Jack Murph the Surf) Murphy and a woman who previously worked as a Playboy Club "bunny" were charged today with a $150,000 jewel theft at a Miami department store.
As part of a fall housecleaning, the National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it planned to revise its morning schedule.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman disclosed today that the Chase Manhattan Bank had bought $500,000 worth of notes, some of them already in default, from a Newport News, Va., bank two months before it failed.
ELY, Minn., July 22 -- Lynda Bird Johnson and her party headed back toward civilization by canoe today from Minnesota's wilderness area adjoining Canada about 50 miles northeast of here.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), July 22 -- A libel law that increases the protection of victims of libel and slander was enacted early today in the final hours of the fifth Knesset (parliament).
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's address last night on the city's water crisis:

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 22 -- The sixth Monticello Antiques Show and Sale, which benefits the student loan fund of this community, will be held from noon to 10 P.M. on Aug. 10, 11 and 12 on the grounds of the Monticello High School.

Consolidated net income of The New York Times Company for the first six months this year amounted to $3,444,000, equal to $7.79 a share on 409,980 shares of common stock outstanding, according to the semiannual report.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- Bob Allison capped a big seventh inning today with a three-run homer, then connected again in the ninth as the Minnesota Twins crushed the Boston Red Sox, 11-5.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 22 -- The lowest scorers in the qualifying round for the women's Tri-County Golf Association championship tournament advanced today to the final with easy victories at the Leewood Golf Club.

A controversial $50 million plan for renewal for a blighted 14-block area on Manhattan's Lower East Side was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Federal approval is expected as a matter of routine.
Universal water metering is an idea that dates to the days of ancient Rome and has been adopted by virtually every major city except New York.

OAKDALE, L.I., July 22 -- Richie Boyd of the Bayberry Yacht Club triumphed in the last two races today to defeat Pete Tarr of the Babylon Yacht Club for series honors in the western area eliminations for the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's midget championship.

BOSTON, July 22 (UPI) -- The directors of Northeast Airlines approved the issuance today of 4.5 million shares of common stock to Storer Broadcasting Company of Miami, which is buying a controlling interest in the airline.

CASEY STENGEL'S magnificent incomprehensibility, taken in stride by baseball people for lo these many years, was turned loose in an unfamiliar setting yesterday, and there followed two hours of excitement that swept from coast to coast with jet-age speed.
Two men in Sing Sing Prison for assaulting a painting contractor denied in court yesterday that they had tried to bribe a patrolman to avoid arrest.
W.R. Grace Co. said yesterday it had terminated an agreement to sell its 50 per cent equity in Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) to Pan American World Airways.

ROME, July 22 -- This week's boutique and high fashion collections show that the Italians are all worked up about crazy stockings. Some designers even forgot about shoes: Their models padded around in their printed-stocking feet.
The Boys Club of New York will benefit from the "Autumn in New York" dinner dance to be held in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza on Oct. 21. The annual event was formerly known as the Fall Ball.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 22 (AP) -- Barbara Fay White of Shreveport, La., and 18-year-old Jan Ferraris of San Francisco scored one-sided victories today in the quarter-finals of the Women's Western Golf Association championship.
OTTAWA, July 22 -- Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson set up a special Cabinet committee today to try to head off a postal service tie-up that threatened to become nationwide.
BOGALUSA, La., July 22 (UPI) -- Nine Negroes and a white civil rights worker failed in one bid to integrate a restaurant today, but were successful at a second previously segregated cafe.

SEATTLE, July 22 (UPI) -- The Boeing Company reported today that earnings rose in the second quarter of 1965 despite a drop in sales. The profit gain was attributed to a rising backlog of commercial orders.
Trading in gold-mining shares again dominated dealings on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
CAIRO, July 22 (Reuters) -- "Why was a Jew appointed United States Ambassador to the United Nations?"
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that it had completed acquisition of Avis, Inc. The car-rental service will be operated by a new subsidiary, ITT Avis Inc.
Alberto Morillo, senior member of the Uruguayan central bank mission here to recast some $50 million of debt owed to a number of leading banks, left unexpectedly yesterday morning for Montevideo.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (AP) Hank Aaron and Rico Carty hit homers in a four-run first-inning surge tonight as the Milwaukee Braves extended their winning streak to 10 games by downing the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-2.

Governor Rockefeller's signature has now completed the arduous four-year task of modernizing New York State's penal code. Many dedicated individuals have participated in the overhaul and re-examination of the state's criminal statutes to bring them more into conformity with present-day needs and mores.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Administration moved closer today to a decision that will probably mean a substantial increase in the number of American soldiers in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Director of the Budget said today that the new way of looking at the Federal Budget as a means of promoting expansion in the economy required stricter control of Federal expenditures than ever before.
The Taxi Drivers Organizing Committee, backed by New York's merged labor federation, has won bargaining rights in two-thirds of the garages covered by a National Labor Relations Board election.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 -- The Security Council heard a report today from the United Nations special representative in the Dominican Republic that 22 mortar shells were fired Monday night from the area held by the United States-backed junta into the area held by the rebel forces.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 22 (AP) -- A $29 million damage suit was filed yesterday in United States District Federal Court here by the Flight Engineers International Association against Eastern Air Lines and the Air Line Pilots Association over a "third seat" in jet aircraft.

What Mr. Schwartz fails to note in his protest is that the letter of the Secretary of State was written in the context of a comment on the Feighan bill. Thus the Secretary's observations are relevant solely to such provisions of the Feighan bill as a six months' cut-off of the national-origins quota system and the imposition of an overall ceiling on immigration, exclusive of that from the Western Hemisphere.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 22 -- A mob of 400 to 500 Indonesian demonstrators forced the Indian Ambassador, Perala Ratnam, to depart hurriedly from Surakarta Tuesday, reliable informants said today.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- One way into Chicago is the "fabulous scenic lake route."

The marriage rate in the United States is booming for the sixth year in succession. There were 1,731,000 marriages in 1964, compared with 1,657,000 in 1963 and 1,580,000 in 1962, according to the Statistical Bulletin, published by the Metropolitan Insurance Company.
Commissioner Ford Frick declared yesterday that investigation had shown "nothing wrong" in the deal that sent Jesse Gender from the New York Mets to the Milwaukee Braves on waivers Tuesday.
PASADENA, Calif., July 22 (UPI) -- Scientists decided today on an encore for Mariner 4, a rerun of its photos of Mars after the final pictures are received Saturday.
The British pound gained moderately in fairly active trading in foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The possibility of a major United States military build-up in Vietnam drove copper futures up sharply on the Commodity Exchange yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 22 -- Gene Francis of the Wheatley Hills golf club fired a 37, 35 -- 72 to win a medal in the 42d Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club today. Par for the 6,463-yard course is 35, 35 -- 70.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Labor Department said today that seven major manpower centers were reclassified last month to categories representing lower levels of unemployment.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 22 -- The fleet competing on the 34th annual American Yacht Club cruise had a brisk 18 1/2-mile race around the buoys today, with T. Vincent Learson's Thunderbird, sailed by Roger Fortin, and Richard P. Sheehan's Pursuit being both. first to finish and the corrected-time winners in their respective divisions.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 22 -- Bill Tully of Pelham, N.Y., the third-seeded player; King Lambert of Bronxville, N.Y., and Richard Goldstein of New York advanced today to join Tony Vincent of New York in the semi-final round of the United States men's 35-years clay-court tennis championship at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The State Department confirmed today that Bruce Odeil had been briefly detained, questioned and then released in connection with the arrest of Mustafa Amin.
Three New York hotels are making some quiet changes in their staid attire.
MONTECATINI, Italy, July 19 -- The place where Marcello Mastroianni was taking the cure in the movie "8 1/2" is so quiet these days that you can hear your blood pressure drop.
PATERSON, July 22 -- Sporadic violence broke out in a predominantly Negro neighborhood last night.

TORONTO, July 22 -- Prospects for proceeding with the much-delayed Churchill Falls hydroelectric development in Labrador have been enhanced by the decision of the Federal Government of Canada to give to the provinces its share of the corporation tax on private power utilities.

MYSTIC, Conn. -- A harpoon's throw from this thimble-size village lies Mystic Seaport, a typical mid-19th-century seafaring town sprawled over 37 acres along the Mystic River. Three hundred and sixty-three days a year (it is closed Thanksgiving and Christmas) families come here by station wagon and bus, by yacht and assorted small craft to escape the jittery jet age by taking a giant step into America's seagoing past.
WAUKEGAN, Ill., July 22 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, left the bulk of his $550,000 estate to his three sons, his will showed today.
Mr. and Mrs. August L. Saltzman of Short Hills, N.J., are celebrating their 39th wedding anniversary on a $17.5 million cruise ship all by themselves, except for a crew of 120 to serve them.

LONDON, July 22 -- Clive, a young designer in the preponderantly middle-aged field of London couture, showed clothes today that were young but not gimmicky, fresh and unfussy. Fur hats by Graham Smith and fur muffs by Clive himself were the only concessions to winter in the collection.

The election of Sidney N. Weniger as vice president in charge of the real-estate financing division has been announced by the Standard Fiancial Corporation, a nationwide lending and factoring company.

Sargent Shriver, the nation's antipoverty chief, came to town yesterday and met some of his program's workers and the people they are trying to help. "I like what I see here," Mr. Shriver said. "I see people participating in programs that were nonexist ent nine months ago.
THE most widely read novel published in this country in 1964 was John Le Carre's "The Spy Who Came In From The Cold."
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A bill to repeal state "right-to-work" laws heads for a House showdown next week after the most subtle legislative "cat and mouse" game of the session.

The admirable dignity with which the great majority of Negroes have been carrying on their efforts toward equality of opportunity is unfortunately not characteristic of some urban groups who seem to be imbued with a vindictiveness that has moved into guerrilla warfare against the whites.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds routed Warren Spahn in the third inning today and went on to gain a 5-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 22 (AP) -- Union and management negotiators reached tentative agreement today on a new three-year contract that would end a 22-day strike at the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation.
W. Vincent Abrahmson, president of the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, has been elected a director of Johnson Johnson, its parent company.
LONDON, July 22 -- A commission investigating lapses in British security recommended today bodily search of those with access to classified documents.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 -- The 1965 Newport Folk Festival began four days and nights of open-air concerts and workshops in a new site tonight, windswept Festival Field.

A 26-year-old Brooklyn patrolman who shot and killed a Negro he was attempting to arrest last week and who was himself wounded has been transferred to another hospital to protect him from threats and abuse.

HOLLYWOOD, July 22 -- Electronovision, Inc., the movie company that in one year produced three films, a storm of controversy in the movie business and $30 million in law suits, closed its offices this morning.

SYRACUSE, July 22 -- Binghamton Mayor John J. Burns won the endorsement of "a substantial majority" of upstate Democratic county, chairmen tonight for Democratic state chairman to succeed William H. McKeon.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the Senate minority leader, executed a fast parliamentary end run around the Judiciary Committee today to force Senate consideration of his stalemated proposal for a constitutional amendment on the reapportionment of state legislatures.

RYE, N.Y., July 22 -- Richard Cimaglia of Harrison carded a par 35, 37 -- 72 over the Apawamis Club course today and won the medal in qualifying for the 46th Westchester County Golf Association's amateur championship.
One of the world's largest international banks, the Chartered Bank, plans to open its first mid-Manhattan branch office next spring.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 -- Three American F-105 Thunderchief planes wrecked a highway bridge 42 miles from North Vietnam's frontier with China today.

Disregarding the pleas of leaders of both major parties, Governor Rockefeller vetoed yesterday the bill that would have enabled any candidate for statewide office who had received the votes of 25 per cent of the delegates at his party's convention to force a run-off primary.
Directors of the Carborundum Company voted yesterday to raise the quarterly dividend to 60 cents a common share from 50 cents in previous quarters.
A half century of subway service to Brooklyn and Queens was commemorated yesterday by the Transit Authority, which took about 50 city and transit officials for a ride in some 50-year-old cars.

BALTIMORE, July 22 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics pounded out 15 hits, including two-run homers by Ken Harrelsen and Bill Bryan, and trounced the Baltimore Orioles, 9-2, tonight. Fred Talbot pitched a six-hitter for the victory.
Mayor Wagner announced last night that the worsening water crisis was forcing him to reconsider his stand against the installation of residential water meters.

ONE of America's most respected elder statesmen in the sphere of amateur athletics is Robert J.H. Kiphuth of Yale. He served as head coach of many Olympic swimming teams, built a swimming dynasty at New Haven, became a top college administrator as Yale's athletic director and later turned his limitless energy to the job of treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union.
Loans to business at the 14 weekly reporting New York City banks dropped by $163 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on a compromise $7.5 billion omnibus housing bill, which includes a controversial program of rent subsidies for low-income families.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 -- Roy Emerson played like the monarch of amateur tennis that he is and all but annihilated Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., today in the Pennsylvania grass-court championship.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Incidences of murder, rape and aggravated battery in Chicago increased last year over the previous year but there was an ovr-all reduction of 3.1 per cent in the total of major offenses, the nonpartisan Chicago Crime Commission said this week in its annual report.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A picture of space engineers poking into garbage dumps, polluted streams, jails and public filing cabinets was painted today for Congress by Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California.

GENEVA, July 22 -- Maschinenfabrik Oerlikon of Zurich said today it had abandoned its projected union with another leading Swiss manufacturer of electrical engineering equipment rather than lose its independence.

Norman Rothman, the president of Korvette Carpet Centers, Inc., is expected to be named president of Korvette Home Furnishings Centers, Inc., a projected wholly owned subsidiary of E.J. Korvette, Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Johnson's highway beautification program encountered opposition today.

Israel Rogosin, an American textile official with worldwide interests, announced yesterday that he had donated $2.5 million to the first-year drive of the Israel Education Fund, a program of the United Jewish Appeal.

Thomas Luchese, the reputed Mafia leader known as Three-Finger Brown, was taken from the United States Court House at Foley Square by private ambulance yesterday after an attack of "dry heaves" before a special Federal grand jury.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Chicago civil rights leaders indicated surprise today at Representative Adam Clayton Powell's cancellation of plans to hold hearings on school segregation here.

The Shell Oil Company and its subsidiaries achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or half-year in its history for the periods ended June 30, according to a midyear report issued yesterday by Richard C. McCurdy, president.

The New York State Constitution says that "no person shall be subject to be twice put in jeopardy for the same offense." The United States Constitution says "nor shall any person be subject for the same offense to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb."
RIGA, Latvia, July 22 -- Moscow is abuzz with talk about economic reform -- and terms like profits, relaxation of planning controls, expanded rights of factory managers and so forth are in the air.
CHICAGO, July 22 (UPI) -- Ed Bailey batted in eight runs today with a three-run homer, a grand-slam drive and a singgle to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 10-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

CLYDE, N.Y., July 22 -- The General Electric Company announced today it would give its semiconductor plant here to a local civic development corporation. G.E. decided May 4 to phase out the plant for economic reasons.

" China in Crisis," by Sven Lindqvist, will be published by Thomas Y. Crowell on Aug. 30. The author, a teacher of Chinese history at the University of Stockholm, was cultural attache of the Swedish Embassy in Peking and a private student at the University of Peking for two years.

How do you show off a new kind of outdoor billboard lighting to an outdoor advertising convention that is meeting indoors, and in midtown Manhattan? Why, you rent a billboard, of course -- in midtown Manhattan.

ATHENS, July 22 -- Premier George Athanasiadis - Novas said tonight that the "true cause" of the Greek political crisis was pressure by the former Premier to assume the Defense Ministry to cover up his son's implication in a secret left-wing organization in the army.

Baseball, the saying goes, is a game of inches. If any proof was needed, it was provided yesterday by the two home runs that gave Whitey Ford and the New York Yankees a 3-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 22 (UPI) -- The Alabama Senate passed a redistricting bill early this morning while the chief opponent of the measure was home sleeping.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Retail sales amounted to $5.35 billion in the week ended July 17, an increase of 9 per cent over the corresponding week of 1964, the Commerce Department reported today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 22 -- Alabama voter registration boards began administering a simplified literacy test today, but a Negro leader called the new questionnaire "just another trick" to keep Negroes from voting.
BERLIN, July 22 -- The Western Allies have quietly taken some small but significant steps to strengthen their position in Berlin.
The Carrier Corporation, a Syracuse, N. Y., manufacturer of air conditioning equipment, announced yesterday the election of Melvin C. Holm as president.

A lawyer for the Democratic leaders of the State Legislature argued yesterday that the leaders' proposal for the creation of a three-man panel to draw up a legislative reapportionment plan was necessary to avoid political chaos.

HOVE, England, July 22 (Reuters) -- The Conservative party won a special election in this south coast resort town today, reducing the Labor Government's majority in the House of Commons to only three seats out of 630.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Intercity truck tonnage and carloadings of rail freight in the latest week ended July 17 were considerably ahead of the corresponding week of 1964.
THE Brooklyn Championships of the Greater New Bridge Association, which now have only a nominal connection with Brooklyn, begin this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 -- The $35,800 United States Harness Writers' Trot -- not on the regular program at Roosevelt Raceway tonight -- attracted next-to-no spectators, had no betting and proved no contest as Noble Victory, matching the track record of 2:01 3/5 for one mile over a half-mile track, romped to a six-length victory.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 22 -- Three hundred Dominican constitutionalists have begun officer-candidate training in guerrilla warfare and street fighting.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 22 (UPI) -- The Ohio Supreme Court has ruled, 4 to 3, that homeowners are entitled to compensation if low-flying airplanes interfere with the use of their homes.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 22 -- Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today that the use of solid news judgment in the coverage of incidents of violence could contribute to solving the problems of racial tension.
Hyman Solniker, a Democratic district leader on the Lower East Side, was sworn in by Mayor Wagner yesterday as a judge of the Criminal Court.

An 8-month-old boy in a baby carriage and his 34-year-old father were seriously injured last night when they were struck by a hit-and-run car and hurled across the intersection of Park Avenue and 119th Street.
Councilman Paul O'Dwyer yesterday named William T. Andrews, a Negro lawyer and former Assemblyman, on his ticket for the Democratic nomination for Controller.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Charles Louis Schultze, the youngest man ever to occupy the powerful position of Director of the Bureau of the Budget, is also a man whose appointment last April confirmed a very new tradition.

TOKYO -- A major industrial zone is expected to rise on reclaimed land in the Inland Sea, between Honshu and Shikoku islands, around Japan's biggest steel mill. The plant, still under construction by Nippon Kokan K.K., is now turning out 12,000 tons a month from its first completed unit, an 80-inch temper mill.

THE style, the youth and the humor that will always be part of the memory of President Kennedy constitute so strong an attraction for film producers that documentary tributes are almost certain to be presented periodically for years.
The Union Carbide Corporation turned in a sparkling performance for the quarter and six months ended June 30.
The Ford Motor Company broke all its sales and earnings records in the second quarter and first half of this year.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate quickly confirmed Arthur J. Goldberg today as United States representative at the United Nations. Scarcely two hours after he had appeared at 10 A.M. for what turned out to be an unusually friendly bearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Justice Goldberg's nomination was approved unanimously by a voice vote of the full Senate.

OTTAWA, July 23 -- Walkouts of postal employes spread across Canada today despite an appeal from Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson to keep the mails moving while the Government reviews salaries of clerks and mailmen.

BALTIMORE, July 23 (UPI) -- Brooks Robinson's long single to center field with the bases loaded drove in Luis Aparicio with the winning run in the ninth inning tonight as the Baltimore Orioles beat the league-leading Minnesota Twins, 3-2.
The New York Telephone Company, wholly owned subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday a drop of $127,000 in second-quarter net earnings.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank said today the management of a now bankrupt savings bank in Newport News, Va., "did not act in good faith" in a $500,000 deal with Chase.

Officials of the New York Botanical Garden and the New York Zoological Society have written to Mayor Wagner requesting that the city extend its hospital and medical insurance benefits to zoo and garden workers whose salaries are paid for by the city.

AT 10:40 last night, Merce Cunningham began to compose the final strains of John Cage's "Variations V," the final work of the New York Philharmonic's French-American Festival program at Philharmonic Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Johnson signed today legislation giving the nation its first new coinage in 173 years. The signing came only seven weeks after the President had requested Congress to authorize the change.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The State Department announced today the suspension of another Pentagon study project concerning Latin-American affairs and said the whole procedure for Government reseach affecting foreign affairs was getting a special review.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Teddy Roosevelt banished it from the White House, Nellie Grant was married under it, Harry Truman coveted it and Jacqueline Kennedy finally got its twin back to the Executive Mansion.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- Jose Cardenal collected four hits, including his ninth homer, and Jim Fregosi contributed a home run to power the Los Angeles Angels to a 7-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.
NOTTINGHAM, England (Reuters) -- Britain's nationally owned coal industry is pointing with pride at its newest baby -- the world's first completely remote-controlled coal mine.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 23 -- The 61-member secretariat of Mapai, Israel's dominant party, took a final step today to expel David Ben-Gurion, the former Premier and one of its founders.

ST. SULPICE, Switzerland, July 23 -- "The police will have to drag us out -- me, my wife and our four children," Harry Fentener Van Vlissingen, a Dutch-born United States citizen, asserted today in his villa on Lake Geneva.

CORDOBA, Argentina, July 23 (UPI) -- About 1,000 workers who had lost their jobs attacked and seized the Italian-owned Fiat Concord car and tractor assembly plant today after a fierce gun battle with the police.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 23 -- The second annual Stanford Summer Festival of the Arts is as ambitious as the first -- and probably more costly. But even though the deficit this year will be larger than last, no one is distressed.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- The second day of the Newport Folk Festival's study in diversity posed this question: What is your favorite type of music?
Mayor Wagner and Barbara Joan Cavanagh strolled through the back yard at City Hall yesterday to pick up their marriage license in the Municipal Building.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, July 16 -- This delta port ships bananas the way Hershey, Pa., moves chocolate bars or Santos, Brazil, exports coffee.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A Long Island consulting engineer concern has adapted principles of aerial photography to automobile design with a considerable saving in time. By three-dimensional photography, the measurements of clay models of car bodies are trans ferred to tape or punched cards and used to operate machine tools for cutting dies.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Senate liberals opposing the proposed constitutional amendment on legislative reapportionment said today that they had 34 votes against it.
LONDON, July 23 -- The price of gold rose today to the highest level in more than three months in both the London and Paris bullion markets.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 -- A Woman fatally shot a Roman Catholic priest, secretary to James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, this afternoon in a conference room a few yards from where the prelate was sitting at his desk.

ATHENS, July 23 -- George Papandreou warned today that the present upsurge of unrest would lead to a revolt unless King Constantine called him back to the Premiership, from which he was deposed eight days ago, or ordered a national election.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Justice Department came out today for abolition of the death penalty.
BANGALORE, India, July 23 -- The ruling Congress party's top body failed to reach agreement today on a resolution supporting last month's cease-fire with Pakistan in the Rann of Cutch.

Proposals to retain the Federal and New York State Pavilions after the World's Fair closes were rejected yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on the Future of Flushing Meadow. Nineteen other structures were recommended for retention.

GENEVA, July 23 (Reuters) -- The Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations went into summer recess here today in an atmosphere of uncertainty left by recent French discord with other members of the Common Market.

Mariner 4 has apparently completed sending its historic pictures of Mars.
PORTSMOUTH, Va., July 23 (AP) -- The fishing trawler Snoopy, with at least 12 persons aboard, exploded tonight about 45 miles east of Currituck Sound, N.C., the Coast Guard said.
WASHINGTON July 23 (UPI) -- The Defense Department called today for 17,000 Army draftees in September.
Donald L. Boyes has been named assistant group executive in charge of the automotive components divisions of the General Motors Corporation. Mr. Boyes was general manager of the Delco-Remy division.

LONDON, July 23 -- It took an all-night session of the House of Commons, until 6:22 this morning, to pass a Government bill raising the pay of most British judges by 25 per cent.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 24 -- Premier Eisaku Sato's ruling Liberal-Democratic party suffered a shattering setback at the hands of the Socialist party and other leftists in the election to the Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly yesterday.

The stock market, which had been sliding slowly downhill since last Friday, showed an encouraging gain yesterday as the week's trading ended.

BUENOS AIRES, July 23 -- The Argentine Government has moved to break the impasse that has stalled its negotiations with private petroleum companies and practically foreclosed the possibility of receiving new economic assistance from the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Dartmouth, "used" three times during the course of the one-mile trip, just lasted and captured the $50,000 Harness Tracks of America Trot final tonight at Liberty Bell Park.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 23 -- Rookie week ended at the New York Giants training camp today with seven empty beds in the dormitory at Fairfield University. The players cut from the squad after eight workouts included two draft choices, Mickey Bitsko and Ray Popp, both linebackers.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to make the assassination of the President a Federal crime, punishable by death.

PORT MORESBY, Papua, July 21 -- Australia is pushing the eastern half of the big tropical island of New Guinea along toward self-determination as fast as it can go, faster than many observers think it should.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today the members-of a commission that has been set up to improve the United States patent system.

Members of the Social Service Employes Union yesterday staged their second demonstration in a week, protesting heavy caseloads in the Department of Welfare and the lack of vacation replacements for social workers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 24 (AP) -- United States and South Vietnamese police set up a huge dragnet today for an American aid official wanted in the slaying of his boss, Jack E. Ryan, and a Vietnamese woman.

The novelistic fantasies of Jules Verne will come to life in the next few weeks when Navy divers and French and American scientists begin to live, swim and work for periods of two to 30 days on the ocean bottom, 215 to 600 feet beneath the surface.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 23 -- Bills to extend Archbishop Makarios' term as President for another year and to abolish separate Turkish Cypriote voting rights were unanimously approved today by the Cyprus House of Representatives.

CAIRO, July 23 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced last night the resumption of peace talks to end the civil war in Yemen, but warned that if the talks failed it would mean a direct conflict between the United Arab Republic and Saudi Arabia.
Clarence Fanto emphasizes, in a letter in your July 5 issue, the need for maintaining "a clear and level-headed view of the situation" in Southeast Asia.

PADANARAM, Mass., July 28 -- Roger Fortin, sailing the light-displacement 40-foot sloop, Thunderbird, and Richard F. Sheehan, at the tiller of his new sloop-rigged Ohlson-36, Pursuit, each won on the American Yacht Club cruise for the second successive race today.

Three Bermuda octopuses were welcomed, though somewhat gingerly, at the New York Aquarium yesterday. The octopuses were among 152 seagoing creatures that arrived at the aquarium's Coney Island quarters, having made the passage from Bermuda in six fiberglass boxes aboard the Queen of Bermuda.

! At Philharmonic Hall tonight iat 8:30, the New York Philharmonic, Lukas Foss and Darius Milhaud conducting, with Robert, Gaby and Jean Casadesus, pianists, and the Camerata Singers, will present premieres of new works' by Milhaud, Messiaen and Casadesus.
Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor reversed yesterday a ship subsidy ruling that had disrupted negotiations 11 days ago in the long maritime strike.
HOUSTON, July 23 (UPI) -- Cincinnati combined Joey Jay's one-hit pitching over the final eight innings with a belated outburst at the plate tonight to hand the Houston Astros a 9-1 defeat.

BONN, July 23 -- President Johnson's special envoy, W. Averell Harriman, called on President Heinrich Lubke and officials of the West German Foreign Ministry today to report on his recent discussions with Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin in Moscow.
NEW LONDON, Conn., July 23 -- Fifteen West African women, back here from a tour of this country, say they are increasingly disenchanted with America.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 -- One of those rare occurences in modern-day tennis -- the defeat of a high-ranking Australian by an American -- took place today in sweltering heat at the Merion Cricket Club.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 (AP) -- First-inning home runs by Willie McCovey and Jesus Alou carried the San Francisco Giants past Milwaukee, 5-1, tonight and ended the Braves' 10-game winning streak.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Bob Friend allowed only one hit today -- an infield single by Don Landrum in the fourth -- and posted his 34th major league shutout as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Chicago Cubs, 6-0.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The nation's money supply rose sharply again in the first half of July, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (Reuters) -- South Vietnam's military Government warned today that penalties of death or imprisonment would be imposed for a variety of offenses ranging from "hooliganism" to support of neutralism.
ALBANY, July 23 -- Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill that would have required the state to take over the East Hudson Parkway Authority by Jan. 1 and pay all its debts.

WICHITA, Ka., July 23 -- The world record-holder in the shot-put, Randy Matson, had a winning put of 65 feet 2 inches tonight and young Jim Ryun disappointed a home town crowd by finishing third in the mile run during a display of some of America's top track talent.

RYE, N.Y., July 23 -- Greg Powers, a 19-year-old golfer from the Country Club of Darien, today eliminated the defending champion, Clem Miner Jr. of High Ridge, in the second round of match play in the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Apawamis Club.
LONDON, July 23 -- That span across the Thames River between the financial district and Southwark is to be demolished.
MIAMI, July 23 (AP) -- Three bars of gold bullion valued at $103,000 disappeared on June 19 somewhere between the airport at San Salvador and Miami, Pan American airways said today.
The adage that time and tide wait for no man was proved apt again the other day in the birth of Stephen Edward Stonehouse.
Increased profits were reported yesterday by major oil companies for the three and six months ended June 30.

Ginger Rogers will be hostess on the season's first "Bell Telephone Hour," on Sept. 26, when the National Broadcasting Company television program moves to alternate Sundays. Miss Rogers, who will replace Carol Channing in the Broadway musical "Hello, Dolly ?" on Aug. 9, will appear with Ella Fitzgerald, John Davidson, Roberta Peters and Earl Wrightson in a musical tribute to Jerome Kern.
Another step in the formation of the Northwest Pipeline Corporation was taken yesterday before the Federal Power Commission.

A runaway automobile with a dying man at the wheel slashed through the intersection of West 65th Street at Columbus Avenue and Broadway late Thursday night, killing two women pedestrians from Illinois and injuring three other persons.

All new police station houses "are being designed as community centers," Police Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick said yesterday. And he urged that "members of the public on legitimate business" be made to feel welcome at all station houses.

YONKERS, July 23 -- A subcommittee of the House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee will hold two public hearings in Westchester tomorrow to consider a bill for establishment of a Hudson Highlands National Scenic Riverway.

THE 218 -- count 'em -- 218 model rooms in Macy's sprawling ninth-floor furniture department have just been refurbished, using some decorative concepts that represent a modest departure for the store. Four "apartments" have been set up in the modern furniture department.
The American Stock Exchange staged its only advance of the week yesterday on slightly stepped-up trading.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23 -- Those with eager fingers reaching toward Larchmont Race Week sailing championships with reasonably good chances of gaining the silverware after today's competition included Norman Elliott in the Rhodes 19 Class, Cornelius Shields Jr, in the Shields Class and Mrs. Timeotha Larr among the International One designs.
The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the nation's largest earthmoving-equipment producer now in the billion dollar sales league, is seeking to expand its business.

Before a "round-the-world trip" for pleasure this spring I, perhaps hesitatingly, would have favored disengagement. Today, after four weeks spent in Australia and New Zealand, I believe that there are compelling reasons, many of them based on obligations to these two countries, for supporting United States policy in Vietnam.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 23 -- Israel's fifth and largest Festival of Music and Drama, opening here on Monday, will be dominated by American artists.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 -- Destroyers from the Seventh Fleet began this week to assume a more direct role in the Vietnam war with daily offshore shellings of suspected Vietcong coastal bases.

The Soviet Union named 42 men and 16 women yesterday to oppose the United States track and field team next weekend at Kiev. To the surprise of no one, the athletes were more or less the same old Russians.
The American Society of African Culture, an eight-year-old organization of Negro scholars, writers and artists, has published the first issue of a new quarterly, African Forum.

DETROIT, July 23 (UPI) -- Orlando Pena's shutout relief pitching and three home runs powered the Detroit Tigers to a 6-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight. The victory moved the Tigers into fourth place in the American League, one-half game ahead of the White Sox.

Domestic architecture has always been a fascinating subject of study for the social historian. From primitive man, who scratched graffiti on the walls of his cave, to his modern counterpart who makes his own muralettes, Homo sapiens has had an urge to put finishing touches to his dwelling.

WHITE PLAINS, July 23 -- The state today bought the roadbed of the New York Central Railroad's old Putnam Division from Eastview to Mahopac. It paid $250,000, according to J. Burch McMorran, State Superintendent of Public Works.

Eastern Air Lines protested to the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday that the new liberalized luggage allowances for air passengers would cause a financial hardship to the domestic airline industry, and therefore should be suspended.
JACKSON, Miss., July 23 (AP) -- Jackson is moving to file suits against individuals and organizations that charged "police brutality" during recent civil rights demonstrations.

Prices of men's suits and coats are going up 5 to 10 per cent for fall. Leading manufacturers in the men's wear industry said yesterday that their branded and unbranded garments being shipped to retailers would bear higher price tags as a result of a June 1 wage increase.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- President Johnson and his top military and foreign policy advisers considered today whether to increase draft calls because of the situation in South Vietnam.
CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) -- A jury found Jim Brown innocent today of assault and battery against an 18-year-old girl in a motel room here last month.
All 40 persons aboard an Allegheny Airlines plane escaped yesterday afternoon when the plane made a crash landing near Williamsport, Pa., after catching fire.
The British pound declined slightly yesterday in moderately active trading on the foreign-exchange market here. It closed at $2.7903, dipping 2 points from its previous day's closing of $2.7905.
New-car sales in mid-July continued to set records, topping the year-before level by 19.5 per cent.

Twenty-one-year-old Peter Connolly, who is so severely mentally retarded that nobody ever tried to teach him anything but how to keep clean and quiet, carried a clarinet yesterday confidently up to a piece of music he had never seen before and played it -- note perfect.
Prices advanced slightly in the final session of a quiet week on the London Stock Exchange.
ARMAND LANOUX won the Prix Goncourt, an esteemed laurel in France, for "The Broken Shore." It is an interesting, rather wily novel about war and peace seen through various Gallic sensibilities.

HOUSTON, July 23 -- Lucien Rivard, the central figure in a Canadian Government scandal who is alleged to be the mastermind of a narcotics ring, indicated today he would not be able to free himself on bond.
Soybean futures turned downward yesterday in moderate trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

ALTHOUGH it is assiduously promoted as a soldier, "America's Movable Fighting Man," the fact is that Hasbro's increasingly popular G.I. Joe is a doll -- a fully jointed, 11-inch-high-doll. And as such, it is the first to score with small boys since Raggedy Andy.
WITH the impatience, energy and indifference to consequences that are often regarded as attributes of the young, David Ben-Gurion, at the age of 78, has begun a new career.

We submit that Manhattan Borough President Constance Baker Motley has rendered her community another meritorious service with her proposal that the Squadron A Armory site, bounded by Park and Madison Avenues and 94th and 95th Streets, be given over to a combined junior high school and middle-income housing development.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- A Soviet court passed a five-year sentence tonight on a young British college teacher who admitted that his "flaming head" got him mixed up in a band of anti-Soviet Russian exiles frequenting the coffee bars and colleges of London.

Because of the cloudy weather, more low-flying planes were routed over Lewisohn Stadium last night than during any of the Metropolitan Opera's earlier presentations there, but that was the sole complaint, and one that was easily borne in consideration of what was heard from the stage.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 24 (UPI) -- The Hanoi newspaper Quan Doinhan Dan published today a report on the capture of two United States Navy pilots and photographs of the men.

BUFFALO, July 23 (AP) -- Don Allen, the defending champion, and Bill Tryon, the man who beat him for the title in 1962, battled their way today into the final of the New York State men's amateur golf tournament.
The Wyman-Gordon Company, of North Grafton, Mass., has completed delivery of the four largest closed die forgings ever produced from maraging steel, a high nickel, low carbon alloy.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 -- The Vietcong have increased their taxes and extortion throughout South Vietnam as the increase in their troops has raised their expenses.

The New York Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-2, before 38,533 persons at Shea Stadium last night in a 10-inning game marked by three spectacular collisions involving seven Philadelphia players.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23 -- With a swift, sulky-rocking move down the backstretch that disposed of Cardigan Bay, Fly Fly Byrd soared to victory tonight in the $25,000 Dr. Stanton Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
I wish to comment on your July 17 editorial concerning inclusion of chiropractic in medicare.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- An attempt to tap a huge reservoir of drinkable water beneath the Atlantic Coastal Plain was proposed today by Senator Clifford P. Case.

ROCKVILLE, Md., July 23 (UPI) -- Gary Player ripped eight strokes off par and turned in a course-record of 63 today to take a 10-stroke lead in the second round of the $50,000 Big Three special challenge golf match at the 6,834-yard Lakewood Country Club course.

Reports reaching here yesterday from Montevideo, Uruguay, of the inability of Uruguayan officials to identify Neville Morgan heightened the mystery surrounding the man who has been offering the South American country a loan of $130 million.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Legislation authorizing a five-day work week for postmasters was approved today by the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee.

NEW ORLEANS, July 23 (AP) -- At least four Irish seamen were killed in a pre-dawn explosion and fire that roared through the crew's quarters of a freighter tied up here today. A fifth man was reported missing.
A Federal judge fined eight large steel companies $50,000 each yesterday on charges of conspiring to fix prices in the $3.6 billion-a-year carbon sheet steel industry.
More than 4,000 postal workers clogged the Eighth Avenue sidewalk in front of the General Post Office yesterday afternoon in a demonstration for an immediate pay increase.
Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that the city must cease immediately its attempts to induce new industry to come here by holding out promises of unlimited supplies of water.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld, July 23 (AP) -- The 12,500-ton cruise ship Seven Seas, disabled by an engine room fire at sea, was towed into port here shortly before noon today. She was carrying 400 passengers and 210 crew members.

EASTCHESTER N.Y., July 23 -- Mrs. Kenneth Springer of Ridgeway today won the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's 15th championship by defeating Mrs. Albert B. Bower of Pelham, 2 and 1, in the 36-hole final at Leewood Golf Club.
ALGIERS, July 23 -- United States oil and gas company spokesmen here are taking a wait-and-see attitude toward the new Franco-Algerian oil and gas agreement.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 23 (AP) -- Florida's Gov. Haydon Burns warned Negro leaders today he would not tolerate racial demonstrations in St. Augustine and promised to fill the city with National Guardsmen if necessary to prevent them.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The State Department brushed aside today President Gamal Abdel Nasser's charge that the United States had made "astonishing" demands on the Egyptian Government in return for aid.
Legal experts cautioned yesterday that Mexican divorces might not stand up in other states despite their validation last week by New York's highest court.
A $30,354,546 bill to the city as the price for having taken over the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines and a subsidiary in March, 1962, was affirmed yesterday by the Appellate Division.

ALBANY, July 23 -- Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill that will put a second public-housing question on the ballot Nov. 2, a development that some state officials say is likely to confuse the voters.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 23 -- Ralph Johnston of the Garden City Country Club, the defending champion, led the way into the quarter-final round of the 42d Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club today.
Four Hawaiians, who have completed a tour of Southern cities, yesterday said they bellieved they had had some success in explaining how racial integration works in their islands.

Cast off the lines, mates. "Spring Tides," by Samuel Eliot Morison, will be released by Houghton Mifflin on Aug. 12. Admiral Morison has sailed all kinds of craft, in addition to the bark of history, and he wants to inform readers about this avocation.
RIGA, Latvia, July 23 -- "Ours is an international city and we are proud of it," said an aggressive Latvian newspaper editor in haranguing a group of visiting foreign correspondents.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 23 -- Freshly painted signs with arrows and the word "Theater" on them studded the grounds of the famous Old Westbury Gardens tonight, amid all the other signs pointing to an Italian garden, a rose garden and a cottage garden.
HOLLYWOOD, July 23 -- The television networks, whose soaring growth totally disrupted the economies of the motion picture industry 15 years ago, may soon emerge as a major financial backer of movies.

With New York City's water supply reduced to 47 per cent of capacity, and a Presidential report warning that two of the city's main reservoirs may be completely dry by November and six others badly depleted, Mayor Wagner went on television to advise the public that "there is no reason for panic or fear."
The New York Stock Exchange is in the market for a name.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 102.7 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended July 20, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods decreased in price, while industrial commodities advanced.

THE Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional tournament continues this afternoon at the New York Hilton. The Open Pair Championship play is at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. The tournament will end tomorrow with the Open Teams meeting at 1 P.M. and 7 P.M. and a special Novice Game being played at 7 P.M.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 23 (AP) -- A small group of Pure Oil Company stockholders balked today at a $50-a-share offer from Union Oil Company of California to complete Pure Oil's merger into the west coast concern.

In an editorial published on July 13, we stated in detail our reasons for opposing the school-and-housing project proposed for the site of the armory at Park Avenue and 94th Street, for which another appeal is made in our Letters column today.

Dr. Calvin E. Gross, who resigned as superintendent of New York City's public schools last month under pressure from the Board of Education, has been named dean of the School of Education of the University of Missouri at Kansas City.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- A tiny needle giving out electrical impulses has been demonstrated effective in preventing pain that is usually controllable only by drugs, a University of Chicago scientist says.
LONDON, July 23 -- Reginald Maudling, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, crept ahead tonight in the Conservative party's leadership stakes, at least in the opinion of those betting on the outcome.
LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- A British pajama manufacturer said today that Mrs. Charles de Gaulle has bought the French President a pair of British sleeping togs in size 48.

Nicolae Ceausescu, chief of the Rumanian Communist party, has delivered what is in effect a manifesto on National Communism. His emphasis on Rumania's right to build its economy along the line of Rumanian aspirations, his failure to pay the usual fulsome compliments to the Soviet Union and his persistent refusal to take sides in the Sino-Soviet dispute all suggest that the rulers in Bucharest are determined to be their own masters.
The $150 million of Montgomery Ward Co. debentures scheduled to be offered next Tuesday are expected to be priced to yield 4.90 per cent.

CLEVELAND, July 23 -- Luis Tiant, a pitcher batting only .079, and Duke Sims, a part-time catcher batting only .170, slammed a home run apiece and drove in four runs between them as the Cleveland Indians beat the Yankees, 5-2, tonight.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 23 -- Mrs. Walter Cooperstein, Harbor Hills, and Mrs. Armand Cantor, Fresh Meadow, scored 71, 77 -- 148 to win the Women's Cross County Golf Association's 36-hole, better-ball-of-partners championship today on the 5,748-yard, par 173 Rockville Links.
CINCINNATI, July 23 (UPI) -- Susie Maxwell of Oklahoma City posted a 5-under-par 67 today to take a three-stroke lead in the $10,000 Buckeye invitation golf tournament.

BUCHAREST, July 23 -- As the ninth Rumanian Communist party congress drew to a close today, two Politburo members, Emil Bodnaras and Alexandru Birladeanu, elaborated on a uniquely Rumanian interpretation of party tasks.
HARTFORD, July 23 -- Dave Hill found "everything going just right" as he scored a 66 today in the $70,000 Insurance City open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today an amendment to one of its guidelines governing bank lending to foreigners.

ELY, Minn., July 23 -- By the final night the tempo of the campfire singing had sagged a bit, but Lynda Bird Johnson's party of fledgling Journeyers held up very well in the wilds, according to an old canoe hand here.

PARIS, July 23 (UPI) -- France and Algeria initialed today a new petroleum agreement that is expected to step up oil production in the Sahara by nearly 50 per cent and give Algeria royalties estimated at 75 per cent of profits compared with 50 per cent in the past.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate passed by voice vote today the Administration's $90 million, three-year program to develop and test a high-speed rail system.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today an amendment to one of its guidelines governing bank lending to foreigners.

ELY, Minn., July 23 -- By the final night the tempo of the campfire singing had sagged a bit, but Lynda Bird Johnson's party of fledgling Journeyers held up very well in the wilds, according to an old canoe hand here.

PARIS, July 23 (UPI) -- France and Algeria initialed today a new petroleum agreement that is expected to step up oil production in the Sahara by nearly 50 per cent and give Algeria royalties estimated at 75 per cent of profits compared with 50 per cent in the past.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate passed by voice vote today the Administration's $90 million, three-year program to develop and test a high-speed rail system.
Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican-Liberal designee for Mayor, took a helicopter of the city's physical problems yesterday afternoon for a wide-ranging overview of what's wrong with New York.

DANBURY, Conn., July 24 -- The police used tear gas and nightsticks last night and early today to quell an outbreak of violence between Negro and white youngsters. Two youths were injured and five arrested.
Reports from across the country underscore the remarkable extent of the current capital-spending boom. Unlike some previous such upturns, it is truly nationwide in scope.
The United States Merchant Marine Academy Alumni Association has come out against recent proposals to divert the construction of American-flag merchant ships to foreign shipyards.

The hardest task of every government agency that exercises a police function is to find and maintain the proper balance between respect for the rights of the private citizen and zeal in the detection of lawbreakers.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The means employed by President Johnson and his principal advisers on the conduct of the war in Vietnam to call public attention to the urgency of their deliberations are justified by the gravity of the problem and the need to prepare the American people for whatever new sacrifices may be required of them.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara returned last Wednesday from his latest mission to Saigon and plunged into a series of conferences which the White House described as "a penetrating review of many facets of the situation in South Vietnam."

LONDON, Sunday, July 25 (Reuters) -- Freddie Mills, a former world light heavyweight boxing champion, died in a hospital here early today after having been shot near his nightclub shortly after 1 A.M.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 -- Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., won the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today, going through the tournament without losing a set.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- Home runs by Norm Cash, Bill Freehan and Al Kaline led the Detroit Tigers to their fifith straight victory, 7-4, over the Chicago White Sox today. The loss was the White Sox's sixth in a row.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 21 -- Most maps of Laos show a major roadway linking the administrative capital, Vientiane with the royal capital of Luang Prabang, seat of King Savang Vatthana's court.
Great loops of hose-like rubber fenders that can absorb the pressure of a 40,000-ton tanker are being linked along the water side of piers in Port Everglades, Florida's deepest harbor.
FRANKFURT, Germany July 24 (UPI) -- West Germany is pressing efforts to aid its "Thalidomide babies," but some believe not enough is being done.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 16 -- A leading South African lawyer who is in hiding because of his opposition activities is fighting a move to have him struck off the roll of advocates.

THE Federation Internationale de Philatelie has banned the display of certain stamps of Panama in exhibitions it approves. These consist of memorial issues for President Kennedy, and series for film actors and actresses, the New York World's Fair and American and Russian astronauts.
SYRACUSE, July 23 -- "I didn't think anyone would pay attention to any letter I wrote," State Senator John H. Hughes said with a smile and a touch of understatement.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Every red-blooded American who once sent in a couple of box tops to become a Melvin Purvis Junior G-Man, complete with badge, handcuffs and secret code, carries in his heart an undying stereotype of the F.B.I. -- a vision of peerless agents, looking like James Stewart or Ronald Reagan, closing in on John Dillinger, Pretty Boy Floyd and Ma Barker.

IN the summer of 1924, in Prague, Joseph Szigeti played Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1 for the first time. It was not the world premiere, but it was the beginning of a series of performances by Mr. Szigeti that boosted the work to its present prominence.
Erskine Caldwell's article ("The Deep South's Other Venerable Tradition," July 11) is a classic example of the curious double standard beginning to afflict race relations.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 24 -- Undaunted by a public address announcement that mighty Kelso had run third at Aqueduct, a crowd of 28,545 at Monmouth Park today made George D. Widener's Eurasian a 3-to-5 favorite for the $43,750 Choice Stakes.

STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 24 (UPI) -- Competitors from the United States carried off 11 more gold medals and set four records today on the final day of the annual international paraplegic games.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Don Lock hit two home runs and Willie Kirkland hit one with two men on today as the Washington Senators routed the Kansas City Athletics, 9-2.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) Bait Virdon and Roberto Clemente slammed homers and Gene Alley had three straight hits, including a pair of doubles, as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored an 8-5 victory today over the Chicago Cubs.

The Bronx Assistant District Attorney who handled the appeal that led to the Court of Appeals order that Gareth Martinis be tried on vehicular homicide charges, has announced he is a candidate for Democratic nomination for City Councilman. He is Bertram R. Gelfand.

DIEPPE, France -- Two new car ferries, the Villandry and the Valencay, have joined the fleet that regularly crosses the English Channel between Newhaven and Dieppe, the motorist's gateway to Normandy and Brittany.

VIENNA -- It can be argued that Austria is the world's most neutral country because it is neutral in internal as well as external policy. Because of its peculiar political heritage it is neutral from the very marrow out.

WASHINGTON -- A bill to expand the United States Travel Service so that it would also provide for a "domestic travel service" was introduced in the Senate last week by Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York. In its present role, the Travel Service is limited to attracting foreign visitors to this country.

PUAN, South Korea -- More than 16 square miles of flat muddy tideland off the mouth of the Dong Jin River here will become green farmlands and villages when South Korea's largest coastal reclamation project is completed in 1967.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 -- Sixteen United States Air Force Thunder-chief bombers and support aircraft hit a North Vietnamese explosives plant today for the first time.

One of the most perplexing geologic formations is a series of giant concentric ridges in West Africa. Like gargantuan fortifications, they enclose a central dome. So symmetrical is this so-called Richat formation that it seems man-made, yet it is 30 miles in diameter and obviously of great antiquity.

DIRECTOR JOSEPH LOSEY and playwright Harold Pinter, who did a highly commendable job as a film team with "The Servant," are joining forces again. This time they will collaborate, as director and scenarist, naturally, for producer Sam Spiegel on the movie verson of "The Accident," a novel by Nicholas Mosely that was published in England by Hodder and Stoughton.
Work on the first major revision in 60 years of the three sets of traffic rules governing United States domestic waters is about to be completed.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The State Department so baffled and frustrated President Kennedy that he decided to select a new Secretary of State after the 1964 election, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., a Kennedy adviser, reports.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- Tom Haller's tie-breaking home run today led the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves, who committed four errors and dropped their second straight game after arriving yesterday with a 10-game winning streak.

MANY children know Marquis de Lafayette only as the Frenchman who left his country at 19 to join the American rebels under George Washington. Fewer know that he was also an important figure in the French Revolution.

MOVIE music once was judged by its success in enhancing the story being played out on the screen, but now film scores are being put on disks at such a rate, one must consider their merits also on a non-visual basis.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 24 -- Mike Grinnel sailed his Thunderbird to Lightning Class honors yesterday on Manhasset Bay, finishing 15 seconds ahead of Steve Moore's fireball.
RINGWOOD, N.J., July 24 -- With a blast that made the earth tremble 200 yards away, 60 pounds of dynamite leveled a 130-foot brick chimney here this week.
Israel Shenker's "Guided Tour of Tourists in Rome" (July 11) seems to be the answer to President Johnson's hopes to keep Americans and American dollars in the U.S.A.
With peeling noses and sun-bleached hair, 13 young men and women arrived in New York City by canoe yesterday morning, ending a 16-day trip down the Hudson River.

KEARNEY, N.J., July 24 -- Dr. Louis Benet of New York scored a 3-6, 9-7, 6-2 victory over Arnie Wickstrom of River Edge as the New Jersey State seniors singles tennis tournament opened today at the Arlington Players Club.
Science on earth is essentially provincial, but most scientists are forgetful of this fact. For example they have every reason to believe the laws operate elsewhere exactly as they do here.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 24 -- Calooh, Jack M. Brown's yawl, was the Division I winner of the annual Knicker-bocker Yacht Club Day race yesterday with a one-second margin of victory over Dr. Walter Newman's Sitzmark IV in corrected time.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 24 -- Sophocles Logothetis won the 13th annual predicted-log contest for the Mortimer D. Doolittle Trophy conducted by the Stamford Yacht Club today. Logothetis took his 33-foot Ca-Ri-Anne II around the 28-mile closed course at 9 knots and had a low total error of 41 seconds or 0.2600 per cent error corrected.

LONDON, July 24 (UPI) -Peter Snell left London airport today on his way home to New Zealand and refused to say whether he would stick to his completed a series of races in North America and Europe but did not finish his tour because of ill health.

HOUSTON, July 24 (AP) Joe Nuxhall pitched hitless ball F for 7 1-3 innings and wound up with a one-hitter as the Cincinnati Reds defeated Houston, 2-0, tonight after losing to the Astros, 4-2, in a day game.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Ten local builders have been selected by the Philadelphia Housing Authority to purchase and rehabilitate 750 rundown houses and then sell them to the authority for an estimated total of $9.3 million.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y. July 24 -- Belting a homer or winning three straight sets are relatively minor triumphs for 60 Bronx youngsters commuting to a day camp here who prefer to score in a Bach suite or achieve a passable pas de deux.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, July 24 -- "Proshim" means dissent or secessionist in Hebrew, and to many Israelis whose memories go back to pre-independence, it has a somewhat stronger flavor. It was used then to refer to the Irgun and the Stern Gang -- terrorist organizations whose leaders refused to recognize the official underground, the Haganah.

SALONIKA, Greece, July 24 (AP) -- A mass demonstration organized by pro-Communists was held here tonight amid shouts against the United States, President Johnson and the Greek royal family.
ST. JOHNS, Nfld, July 24 (Canadian Press) -- The 12,500-ton cruise ship Seven Seas, disabled last Saturday after an engine-room fire, was towed out of the harbor here early today, bound for Halifax.

HARTFORD, July 24 -- Dave Marr led the $70,000 Insurance City open golf tournament today with a 54-hole total of 204 after a brief downpour at the Wethersfield Country Club. Marr finished with a one-under-par 70 to gain a one-stroke advantage over three other golfers.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 24 -- White South Africans are being advised these days that if they address their domestic servants by name, speak to them in a language they understand and try to remember that they are human, racial tensions may be substantially reduced.

LIMA, Peru, July 24 -- The Rev. Daniel McLellan doesn't take no for an answer when it comes to getting funds for the People's Cooperative Movement he has founded in Peru.

CARMEL, N.Y., July 24 -There was a distinct medical touch to the 808-dog Putnam Kennel Club show on the grounds of the Kent Elementary School today. Half of the six finalists in the ring were owned by physicians and one of the dogs, a whippet, Ch. Greenbrae Barn Dance, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Clare C. Hodge of Bryn Mawr, Pa., went all the way to the top.
